title: Characterization of Materials
reviews: Come and enjoy and learn!

Definitely take this course if you are interested in materials techniques and their implementation in your research! The course is very interesting, and your knowledge base will benefit greatly from it.
Get as much individual practice as possible and ask questions! The instructors are SO knowledgeable.
I recommend this course if you want to learn to use various microscopes. It is a very practical course.

I would recommend this course to any student working in the area of material science or any field that makes use of microscopy techniques. I feel like very little background is required to learn many of the basic concepts presented in this course.
I would recommend this course.
If you're interested in material science and electron microscopy technology, take it! Prof. Yao is very helpful and nice!
It is wonderful course for students who are interested in material science and material characterization
It's a really fun and informative class (especially as an undergrad) but be prepared for a lot of lab time.

Strongly consider this course if you want to learn about those really fancy microscopes, especially if you are considering going to grad school and believe it might be useful then. This is a class that gives you hard research skills, unlike a lot of other classes that are just theory. Be ready to spend time in lab, but also appreciate that Professor Yao is extremely humble and passionate about his work and is always ready and willing to help his students succeed. Professor Yao is an inspiration.
The course is an excellent one if you care for the subject matter. If not, it can be quite dull.
This class is not very stressful.
yes
descrip: A multidisciplinary course offering a practical introduction to techniques of imaging structure and compositional analysis of advanced materials. Focus on principles and applications of various characterization methods. Covered topics include AFM, SEM, TEM, XRD, EDX/WDX, EELS, Raman, Ellipsometry, Confocal Microscopy, sample preparation and image processing, etc. Hands-on experience is emphasized.

title: Planning Methods
descrip: This course introduces a set of concepts and tools that are widely used in the practice of urban and regional planning. The focus is on developing an operational understanding of the models, techniques and data used in such applications as regional economic and demographic projections, cost-benefit analysis, and land use analysis. Emphasis is also placed on the limitations of the methods.

title: Ecohydrology
descrip: A description of the hydrologic mechanisms that underlie ecological observations. The space-time dynamics of soil-plant-atmosphere is studied at different temporal and spatial scales. A review is done of the role of environmental fluctuations in the distribution of vegetation. Emphasis is made in the dynamics of soil moisture. The signatures revealing fractal structures in landscapes and vegetation are reviewed as result of self-organizing dynamics. Unifying concepts in the processes responsible for these signatures will be studied with examples from hydrology and ecology.

title: East Asian Humanities II: Traditions and Transformations
reviews: Really engage with the material, reasonable amount of work.

Take it if you have any interest! I had 0 background in East Asian humanities or history but the class is very interesting and gave me a perspective on a part of the world that I never got to learn about in high school or in more Western-oriented history/humanities classes.

Take the course! It will give you a better sense not of East Asia, or of modern literature and film--it will help you sharpen your analytical skills of intertextual interpretation and transnational understandings of modernity.

This course will not be taught most likely by Professor Erin Huang and Franz Prichard again so I am not sure how relevant my comments are. From my experience, it is an interesting course which synthesizes a lot of ideas, literature, and movies from primarily China and Japan (a very very small bit of Korea). If anything, this class suffered from very long prompts which caused me to encounter difficulty in focusing my writing sometimes. Also, the material was discussed by the professors in a very abstract way which sometimes made it difficult to determine what exactly was being referred to and how. The professors did bring a fresh new and exciting element to class, being new. But, by the same token the class was clearly not as refined as some classes.
descrip: This is the second half of a two-semester sequence introducing the humanities in East Asia. The course begins roughly around the fourteenth century and covers the arts, history, music, literature, popular culture, film and media in transnational China, Japan, and Korea. Special focus will be given to the question of modernity in East Asia. Lectures are given by specialists in the departments of East Asian Studies, Comparative Literature, Music, and Art and Archaeology.

title: Algebra II
reviews: Definitely take this class if you have taken algebra 1
Essentially, if you liked Algebra I, then take Algebra II - you'll probably like it as well.
It was hard
Spend a lot of time on homework.
Take if Jerry is teaching. Don't graduate without knowing this stuff.
Take it with Jerry!
Take it. It's fun and interesting. Be prepared to work (though if you're taking this class, you're probably a math major so you're used to this).
This class varies from year to year based on who teaches it, but my experience with Jerry Wang was excellent--good lectures, good problem sets, very difficult and very rewarding.
prereqs: MAT345 or equivalent..
descrip: A continuation of Algebra I, this course will cover the basics of ring theory, module theory, field theory, and Galois theory. Topics include structure theorems for modules, polynomial rings, field extensions, and solvability of polynomial equations by radicals.

title: Ancient Egyptian Art
reviews: At first it may seem like a lot of work and little assignments that can pile up, but Liszka and her preceptors are very fair graders, and the little assignments are more helpful than detrimental to your appreciation of the material. Would definitely recommend to anyone.
Come to class! Listen and learn!
Definitely take this class.  You won't regret it.
Enjoy lectures and don't feel that you need to do all the readings except when it's relevant to your paper/presentation, in which case they can be very helpful.
Make sure you know the themes, first and foremost, and just a few of the famous examples that demonstrate this theme.
Prof. Liszka is very engaging and this is a fun course to take if you are interested in ancient Egypt.
Professor Liszka is super passionate, so if you are interested in Ancient Egypt, absolutely try to study with her.
Start research for the papers early. Use the presentations as a way to really research that topic, and enjoy it.
Take it if you like ancient Egypt.

Take it! Kate is a very engaging lecturer with a lot of insight. She really takes the time to get to know you and she is extremely helpful for the assignments you will have due. It is very easy to stay engaged and interested throughout the semester with the enthusiasm that Kate brings to the course.

Take it! The professor is awesome, she just wants you to learn. She knows so much about her subject and is really passionate. It may seem like a lot of work at first, but don't let that scare you off. The work isn't difficult and I'm pretty sure she's a fair grader.
Take it!! It's so interesting, not too much wrok and Professor Liszka is an awesome lecturer.
Take the course if you can--SO rewarding.

Take this class. An amazing way to do the art requirement distribution. I dare say this is a great fifth class. Do not do all the readings, simply the required ones. Have fun with this class and recognize quickly what will help you accelerate in it and how that ability will help you go forward.
There are a lot of small assignments throughout the semester that can sometimes feel like busy work, but the material is very interesting and lectures with Prof. Liszka are engaging.
This course was incredible! Definitely take it!
take it! great art history course for distributions/those who don't have a background in the field
descrip: Art in ancient Egypt is a window into its society, religion, and history. In this class, students will survey major themes and debates in Egyptian art, such as composition, portraiture, artists, and the integration of art and writing. Students will also investigate ancient Egyptian art as a reflection of its culture from c. 5000BCE, when it was a series of disconnected polities, to c. 200CE when it was a province of the Roman Empire. They will examine major pieces of art, private tombs, temples, pyramids, and the sphinx. During the precepts, students will interact with objects at the Princeton Art Museum.

title: Laboratory in Plasma Physics
reviews: A good intro to experimental plasma physics.
Start your lab reports early.
Take this course
Take this course and put ample effort into the reports--you can learn a lot if you take them seriously.
descrip: Develop skills, knowledge, and understanding of basic and advanced laboratory techniques used to measure the properties and behavior of plasmas. Representative experiments are: cold-cathode plasma formation and architecture; ambipolar diffusion in afterglow plasmas; Langmuir probe measurements of electron temperature and plasma density; period doubling and transitions to chaos in glow discharges; optical spectroscopy for species identification; microwave interferometry and cavity resonances for plasma density determination; and momentum generated by a plasma thruster.

title: Advanced Modern Greek
prereqs: HLS 105 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Advanced composition and oral practice aimed at developing idiomatic written and spoken style. Discussions entirely in Greek. Introduces students to contemporary Greek culture and literature through the study of works by Cavafy, Sikelianos, Seferis, Elytis, Ritsos, and Anagnostakis, among others. Readings from articles on current Greek topics.

title: Introduction to Urban Studies
reviews: Definitely take it!
Easy class to PDF
Easy course. Take if you're interested in the content.
Good class! Not too heavy of a workload, and you'll learn about lots of different cities, modern issues, and the like. Worth taking for sure!
Great class. Would definitely recommend
I don't think it is as interesting as the name sounds but it did help me choose a certificate program because it surveys a variety of topics.

I loved this course because I found the material to be really interesting and exciting!  If you are at all interested in cities and how they work or the future of cities, I would recommend this class!!  And if you actually do the readings, you'll get so much more out of it!

I thought this would be a really interesting course, but I was extremely disappointed by the quality of the lectures and precepts. It was a really easy fifth class though, so if you're looking for an easy class to pdf or an SA distribution, this one is decent.
I would recommend it because it goes really in depth about the transformations of a city.
I would recommend this class to students who have interest in the subject matter.
I would take this only if you plan to PDF. It is poorly taught and not well-organized or engaging. It has the potential to be interesting if it was better organized.

If you are interested in urban studies or urban issues, you should definitely take this course. It is a great introduction into the topics of urban studies. I am pursuing a certificate so I am a bit biased, however. But, if you want a class you can easily PDF, you should take this. You can get away with not doing a majority of the readings.

If you need a relatively easy SA and have an interest in cities, go ahead and take the class. While lectures are reaaally long and precepts can be a bit dull depending on your preceptor, if you can get through that all and submit the midterm and final (take-homes this semester) you should be fine. Blog posts aren't too bad, and preceptors are generally lenient with their requirements.
It is interesting content for sure but be prepared to have an excess of reading.
It's alright.  For the material that is being presented, it could definitely be a fun class but it really just gets tedious by the end.
It's an easy distribution area and fairly interesting.

Make study groups to do the readings. No need to go to lecture, I never stayed away anyways. Take the class if you want an easy one, but be aware that there's a lot of material, most you don't need to know.
Material is pretty interesting if you are interested in learning more about cities and the issues they face. Not too much work each week (readings, blog post) - it's a good class to take as a senior.
Take it as a fifth class or for the distribution requirement it provides.
Take it if interested in urban studies at all.
Take it if you are interested in the subject matter and learning some more about the world and cities, but don't go to lecture.
Take it!
Take it.
Take the class. It's not too hard and is really interesting.
Take the course because the material is interesting.
Take this class if you're interested in some cities.
Take this course if you are interested in urban studies and or certificating in it.

Take this course if you can! Boyer is a fantastic, engaging lecturer, and she picks out really interesting readings/films. Pretty low workload. The class is also formatted really well, with a city or two every week to showcase an issue. One of my favorite classes so far!

Take this course! Although it is a pretty easy class, it is also incredibly interesting and relevant material that is worth getting engaged in! Also, try to meet with Professor Boyer! She is great to talk to one-on-one.
Take this course! Its awesome and not too difficult. Try and engage with the material and read some wiki articles about the cases you were studying.
Take this course. Pretty easy, very interesting and relevant material.
The subject matter is very broad, so it will give you an idea of many problems of the city.

This class left me disillusioned not only with urban studies but with scholarship in the humanities/social sciences and writing in total.  I was disappointed and frankly felt crushed by the arbitrariness, lack of feedback, and very little analysis that is a part of this course.  Do not take this course - while its subject matter is not a waste of time, this particular class in this form is.
This is a good class to take if you are interested in talking about many disciplines and discussing your own life in connection with the readings as well.

This is an easy class to do well in, go to precept. It is easy to participate in precept because a lot of it can be related to personal experience rather than having to relate to the readings. Midterm and final are very fair.
This is an interesting and very manageable class.

You would be wasting your time if you went to lectures.  The professor will post extremely detailed notes on blackboard.  This is a great class if you would rather write papers than take a midterm and final test.
do readings!
do the readings, they are important for understanding of course and doing well on exams
easy and interesting class
take it! There is a lot of reading, but definitely skimmable.
you will learn a lot if you put the effort in!
descrip: This course will examine different crises confronting cities in the 21st century. Topics will range from immigration, to terrorism, shrinking population, traffic congestion, pollution, energy crisis, housing needs, water wars, race riots, extreme weather conditions, war and urban operations. The range of cities will include Los Angles, New Orleans, Paris, Logos, Caracas, Havana, New York, Hong Kong, and Baghdad among others.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Big Visual Data
reviews: I would highly recommend other students to take Prof. Xiao's class if they are interested in computer vision, big data, deep learning related stuff.
great class; take it to learn how to read papers and give presentations
descrip: The emergence of large image and video datasets on the Internet, parallel computers and GPUs, and algorithms such as deep learning, have enabled significant breakthroughs in computer vision in the past three years. This class discusses these advance topics in computer vision where the use of Big Visual Data is somehow changing the nature of the problem. We focus on leveraging Big Visual Data to bring about new ways of looking at the vision problem. This class requires solid background on computer vision and machine learning. Prerequisite is COS429 or equivalence.

title: Surrealism: Sex, Dreams, and Revolution
reviews: A great, fun, class worth taking. The final project is amazing to work on as it can include any possible visual medium and develops team-work in an artistic context.

Do the readings, go to class, and really dig into the subject matter and readings for the final project. Start working on that early to make the most of it and allow yourself to always be working on an aspect or mini-project of the creative portion of the final project. Take this course to learn how to write critically and how to think about the world in a different way, while partaking in fun creative exercises throughout the semester
Do the readings.
Great Class! Final project was interesting but required far more work than expected.
It's fun, unusual, and really changes how you think about things!
Maybe take Art is Interaction instead if you're looking to mix theory with weird and crazy practice, but you'll learn a lot of good things.
TAKE IT. SO GOOD.
Take this class!

Take this course if you are interested in Surrealism, especially if you are interested in experimenting with Surrealist methods in your own creative work. Although it is not required by the course, the class offers the freedom to engage in highly rewarding projects for interested students and has plenty of material for those interested more in the scholarly side.

You must take this course! Surrealism and the avant-garde are at the origin of all contemporary artistic practices - and this course highlights extremely well the Surrealist legacy. Professor Rentzou is a unique lecturer who brings you into the strange and beautiful world of this avant-garde movement: an unforgettable experience!
i highly recommend this class and suggest they stay experimental with the projects.
descrip: This course sets out to explore the basic ideas, works, and principles of Surrealism as it was developed in France from its inception in the early 1920s into the late 1950s. A very wide array of material will cover diverse literary genres (manifestoes, novels, poems, essays) and media (film, photography, visual art, art exhibition, magazines) to show how the Surrealists wanted to revolutionize both art and life in its political and ethical dimensions. The course is highly interactive, built on a series of students' group activities and projects, both creative and critical, with the use of various media.

title: Topics in Analysis - Distribution Theory, PDE & Basic Inequalities of Analysis
prereqs: MAT320 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Introduce students to important topics in distribution theory and its applications to the basic linear partial differential equations: laplace, wave and heat equations. Also introduce students to some of the basic inequalities in analysis: Hardy-Littlewood, Calderon-Zygmung, Sobolev inequalities. Restriction theorem, Strichartz inequalities. Bilinear estimates and applications to nonlinear PDE's.

title: The Structure and Meaning of Words
reviews: Definitely have a background in linguistics first (intro class) before you take this one.
Interesting class
It's a straightforward class without too much work. The subject is interesting (at least to someone who likes morphology anyway), but I might suggest another LIN class.
Not as engaging as some linguistics courses for someone looking to give linguistics a try. For those already interested in linguistics, a good enough class if you are able to focus on the material.

Would not recommend unless you are particularly interested in morphology specifically. There are many more interesting aspects of linguistics IMO, and I did not feel that I learned much at all this semester.
prereqs: LIN 201.
descrip: The course will treat the structure of words and the structure of the overall lexicon for human languages. Topics included will be: the rules of word formation; the relation between syntax and the lexicon; the psychology of the lexicon, including an examination of studies of the storage and access of lexical items; the semantics of complex words; the phonology of word formation; lexical redundancy and the learning of the lexicon. Students will prepare one short class presentation on a topic in consultation with the instructor.

title: Topics in English History - Tudor and Stuart Britain
descrip: During the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, England underwent a series of rapid political, cultural, and economic changes that transformed it from a backwater of Europe into a country of global importance. This graduate seminar will examine some of the historical problems associated with this modernization. It will revisit classic and broadly influential political and religious debates as well as examine newer and emerging areas of interest, such as consumption and material history, gender and masculinity, the Atlantic world, and cultural exchange in the pre-imperial period.

title: Introduction to Microeconomics
reviews: As intro Economics classes go, this is a good one. Bogan is a great lecturer - try to get her - and make sure you're also with a preceptor who's good. I heard some of the others (not Jakob) weren't very helpful.
Ask questions. Material builds on itself.
Attend all lectures and keep up with the readings. So much more rewarding this way
Attend lectures and be attentive.
Be diligent about the readings
Bogan is a great teacher and worth taking Micro with, just as much as Macro (what she teaches more frequently I believe)
Bogan is cool.
Bogan is fantastic! Do the readings and take time on the problem sets, and it won't be difficult to do well.
Bogan is great and the class isn't too hard if you attend lectures and keep up with the course readings!
Bogan is hilarious.
Bogan likes to focus on women's issues and enforces the point even in exams. Lectures are somewhat dull but its an easy course.
Bogan's really good! And her precept is great if you can get it. (Friday mornings this semester and I think most others too, when she's teaching)
Consider who the professor is before taking it-- the multiple choice element on the exams is not the best for everyone.
Do all the reading before attending lectures. It gives you a good base of knowledge that gets cemented in lecture.
Do all the readings and make sure you go through the problem sets by yourself before asking for help.
Do not fall behind on reading!  Go to class.
Do readings and learn graphs in depth and study formulae
Do the book readings and you will be fine!
Do the hw.
Do the readings, stay up with the problem sets and you'll be fine for the midterm and final
Do the textbook readings before lecture, and understand the problem sets!
Do your P-sets a few days before the due date and make sure to relate the concepts from lecture when completing the P-sets.
Don't fall behind.

Don't go to McGraw for problem set help because the tutors take forever to give you an answer if they can even figure it out.  Something needs to be done about the ECO 100 McGraw study hall tutors.  They are terrible.
Don't skip class, stay ahead
Don't skip lecture -- makes remembering the material for the final very difficult.

Don't skip lecture; while the powerpoints are put up online, the material doesn't make sense without the professor's explanation in lecture. Overall, learned a lot about how economics works and definitely a nice intro course for someone interested in what economists do.
Don't take this course!
Don't worry too much about the readings in the second half of the semester. Focus on reasoning out the knowledge you gained in the first half towards applying it in problems during the second half.
Draw out graphs daily and keep up on the readings. Review everything on fridays.
Easy distribution requirement for STEM majors.  Not overtly stimulating, but okay.
Easy, easy course. Highly recommended.

Econ is something everyone should have some exposure to, and this class is a good broad exposure to the concepts. If you want a better conceptual intro to the work of actual economics, I'd recommend taking it with someone other than Bogan.
Engage and have fun with it

Ensure you fully understand the topic from a given week before moving onto reviewing the next one, as it can be easy to fall behind on lectures and pile them all in when it comes time to complete the problem set. But if you do the readings and go to office hours when required, it is a manageable course.

Even if you are not interested in economics, I would recommend taking this course to help you ascertain a better understanding of basic economic principles that are readily applicable to our world today. I would say to go to lectures and pay attention and do the packet readings in order to succeed in the class.
Everyone should take this course. It's good to have some basic knowledge of economics
Fine distribution requirement, but don't expect to fall in love.
Focus on studying lecture slides for the exams.
Fun course, not too hard. Good if you like math/graphs
Gives you a solid background of economics. Not too much work.
Go for it--the material's interesting, lectures generally quite good, and the work manageable.
Go to Bogan's office hours if you have questions, she's great.
Go to McGraw for the problem sets.

Go to McGraw, every week if you can. Go over the problem set before you go and then ask the tutors if you understand the concept correctly. Individualized tutoring is better than the study hall but if you can't get individualized tutoring, go to the study hall. Go to lecture if you want, but it would probably be more useful to spend that time reading the book. Also, form study groups because those have been a lifesaver for me. Bounce ideas off of your classmates and you'll get the problem sets done much faster. Read the Economist articles too and don't stress too much about the Problem sets. Try to participate in precept. Unless you have a high interest in economics or are a prospective Woody Woo, I don't really recommend this class. I mean, you learn pretty interesting things but there's definitely an idealogical slant here that I didn't really enjoy at times.
Go to and pay attention in lecture; that is all you need for the psets and exams.
Go to lectures and precepts.
Going over the problem sets is a really effective way to study. Overall a good course.
Going to lecture really helped me understand the material.
Good
Good course, just do the readings and go to lectures and you'll be fine.
Good if you are interested in trying out an Econ course, but I would have some experience with Macroeconomics beforehand
Good introduction class to Micro
Good survey/intro course to micro. Do all the readings well to prepare for the exam!
Have some knowledge going in.
I didnt find the subject matter that interesting. Bogan makes lectures more fun. Harder than expected.
I mean, everyone takes this but it is so boring.
I would advise another student to read the textbook before attending the corresponding lecture.
I would advise that they attend every lecture and precept and take careful notes, and seek help from preceptors on problem sets.

I would recommend taking this class as much of concepts are so relevant in today's world. It might be hard initially if you haven't done economics before but it is definitely doable; just take the time to understand and learn the concepts until you see how economists approach problems.
I would recommend that they follow along with the additional readings.
I would recommend that they read the articles as they are assigned, and not wait until the last day before the exam to cram all of the knowledge of the readings.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in economics as this is a great introduction to the topic.
I would suggest looking over the powerpoints as they are the primary teaching material.
I'd definitely tell them to take it with Professor Bogan!
If you are at all interesting in being an Econ major or want to work in business someday, take this class...
If you are interested in taking Economics and either have no information about the subject, or wish to relearn the material in a more engaging and thoughful way, take this course
If you find yourself struggling a lot and not enjoying the course, drop it. To understand this material, you need to like it. I believe it's a naturalness that is necessary to stay in this course.
If you have never taken econ, you need to put a lot of effort into the course. If you have, it should be easy.
If you have not had experience with economics before, it is going to be hard and you should take advantage of office hours.
If you have to take ECO, Brogan is pretty good. That being said, econ is boring.

If you need a solid SA that isn't a great weekly time commitment and want a baseline understanding of economics, this is a great course to take. Don't take it if you aren't interested in the material, though. There are lots of graphs - take macroeconomics if you're looking more for a "big picture".
If you put in the work, you will do well.
If you think you want to, take it. Don't put off all the readings.
If you want a more "mathematical" side to economics (if you're debating between macro and micro), then micro is the intro course for you.

If you want an easy PDF, don't take this class. Even if you are PDFing, it still takes a decent amount of work to stay afloat. In either case, keep up with the Economist readings and try to start the problem sets sooner than later.
If you're interested in economics at all, take it.

If you're thinking of taking this course for "General Interest" like I did, take it if you're interested in any kind of social sciences in order to get a general understanding of economics.  If you're looking to fulfill an SA and you aren't a completely uninspired anti-intellectual, take a different SA.  There are a lot of more interesting, easier SAs that you could take.
If you've never taken economics before, KhanAcademy can be your best friend!
It is A LOT of work so just be prepared. When you're done, you'll feel like you just accomplished something insurmountable (seriously).
It is pretty doable as long as they keep up with the work.

It was fine for an intro course but it's so impersonal. If you already like econ then it's probably interesting but if you haven't taken an econ class before, this class will not make you fall in love with econ.

It was surprisingly a lot more work than I expected from a 100 level course. That being said, everything was manageable, and the content was quite simple to follow. Just make sure you either read the book or attend lectures, and spend time learning how to do your homework. If you do, you'll be fine for the midterm and final.
It's a good course to take and not hard (plus it's a pretty small time commitment).
It's a useful basis for other classes. I'm glad I have the knowledge but didn't particularly enjoy learning it at the time!
It's an intro-level course. Take it if you have to
It's econ -- plan ahead and take this when you have time. It might not be a terrible freshman year class... it's rough with a thesis though.
It's interesting. Don't worry if you haven't taken econ before. Just keep up with the work.
It's introductory microeconomics. Don't expect anything too flashy but it is an important course to take and Professor Bogan knows her stuff well.
It's pretty boring but pretty easy also.
Its a good intro course and is not too hard
Just get it over with.

Keep along with the readings and take some time to go over lectures and study each week, rather than waiting for reading period/finals to do everything. Makes your life a ton easier, since the concepts are cumulative.
Keep on top of your life.
Keep up with readings so you can enjoy lectures instead of figuring out what is going on conceptually
Keep up with the book readings as they complement and supplement lectures very good. Get the basics down from the start, otherwise can start to get confusing.
Keep up with the readings and do problem sets in McGraw
Keep up with the readings, make sure you understand the pset questions- don't just write down the answers. You can't BS your way through this course
Keep up with your work weekly - don't fall behind in concepts and readings.

Leave aside plenty of time for the problem sets.
Make sure to do all the readings and ask for help if you need it. Office hours are great
Make sure to read the book! Most dont do it but it makes all the difference.

Make sure you are up to date with all the readings! Exam multiple choice are difficult if you don't do the readings.

Most of the material will be learned on your own
My advice would be to always attend the lectures.
Only take if you have to.
Pay attention in lecture and review textbook chapters.
Pay attention.
Pay close attention to the graphs and figures in lecture. Keep up with the weekly material, even if you only skim the readings! Start p-sets early.
Pretty interesting, very relevant.  Bogan is a great lecturer!  Try to get a good preceptor.
Probably not a fantastic indicator of what higher level economics is like, but a must-take in my opinion.
Professor Bogan is a wonderful teacher and the subject material is very relevant to just about any field of study. Would highly recommend.
Professor Bogan lives for her students and this is evident through her dedication. I recommend this class.
Read B&B.
Read the book
Read the book and pay attention in lecture. The lecture slides are so helpful for exams. Economists readings are really interesting and they appear on the exams.
Read the book.
Read the textbook and weekly readings. It may be annoying but they are really helpful when it comes to the midterm and final and it's hard to make them up right before the exams.
Really good class, Bogan is phenomenal and the course teaches you a lot about econ even if you're not an econ major it will be helpful.
Really useful class, take it but it requires some time for the readings and problem sets.
Sign up for Bogan's precept! Go to office hours.  Do the readings and go to lecture.
Skip lecture. Figure stuff out on your own with the lectures.
Start your studying for the midterm and final well in advance if you have not stayed completely up to date with the lectures/reading
Stay on top of readings every week
Stay on top of things. It is very easy to fall behind very fast!
Stay on top of your work and don't blow it off and you'll get an A.
Stay on top of your work week to week
Stay up-to-date on readings and assignments. Catching up before the midterm and final would require extensive effort and time.
Straighforward introductory economics course. Bogan's a great teacher, and also really accessible if you want help directly from her!
Study all lecture notes and psets intently. Basically know it all for exams. You will be tested on all content
Study all the slides, make sure you understand all the diagrams.
Study the lecture slides
Study the powerpoints!!
TAKE
TAke it
Take if you want to learn about economy.
Take if you're willing to read and put in a little effort. This is not by any means an easy A.
Take it
Take it as a survey class into microeconomics!
Take it because micro is important knowledge to have. Don't get behind on the material, you'll learn a lot more than you realize in the moment!
Take it if Bogan is teaching
Take it if you have an interest in econ otherwise material will be dry.
Take it if you need to for a prereq. If not, you can probably find something more interesting.
Take it if you need to/are interested, and go to all of the lectures.
Take it if you're interested in econ. If you're taking it for an easy SA don't do it.
Take it with Bogan! She's wonderful. And very available to her students. And everyone should probably learn basic econ.
Take it with Professor Bogan if possible, it's a great introductory course on microeconomics!

Take it! Easy SA if that's what your after, but if you take it with Bogan the lectures are also really entertaining and help you understand a lot of what's going on right now economics-wise. Not even funny how little work it is.
Take it! Good general knowledge about how the world works. Be skeptical and take some of the concepts with a grain of salt, and keep in mind that the models aren't perfect.
Take it! It's a great introduction to the study of microeconomics.
Take it.
Take it. Not too much work.
Take so you can have the general knowledge.

Take the course with professor Bogan!
In order to do well in the class, both ECO 100 and ECO 101, that she is teaching, you have to do your problem sets on time, take lecture notes, and read lecture slides before the lecture. If you do that you will be able to learn a lot and to apply the acquired knowledge afterwards!
Take the course!  It's a great course that's definitely applicable to your daily life and you will learn a lot!
Take this class to be a better logical thinker. Know that exams are worth a lot, and ask the professor any questions you may have--don't hesitate to make the extra effort to understand.

Take this class with Professor Bogan. It is a great introduction to microeconomics and I felt like I learned a great deal. Keep up with the readings, though, because her lectures will be much more interesting and will make more sense if you have done the reading.
Take this course for an intro to economics. Also, you probably need it since it's a requirement for so many majors.
Take this course if you want to learn about economics or enter the economics department. Take it with Bogan!
Take this course, great professor, go to lectures, do the problem sets, go to Mcgraw for help, read the economist articles.
The quality of this course varies wildly depending on the professor. Bogan is very good at everything she does. I have heard that Harvey Rosen is loved, too. Reinhardt is not.
This class is not awful but I would not take it if you do not need to.

This class is one of those classes that you have to take, whether or not you want to. It is by far not the easiest class at Princeton, and requires a fair amount of effort in order to get anything out of it. I suggest to do all the readings and the problem sets and to ask questions as soon as you have them. Don't wait until the last minute because everything builds on each other.
This course helped me decide that I did not want to be a WW major. That being said, I'm glad I figured it out freshman spring.
This course is a good overview of microeconomics and is pretty well structured and fair.

This course probably won't be taught by Bogan again, but the best advice would be to stay on top of the readings BEFORE lectures so as to receive a full understanding of all lecture material and the course shouldn't be particularly difficult. Good course for potential concentrators or general interest.

This is a fine class. You will be challenged, but you will also survive. Bogan is a good professor, and her exams won't kill you like some of the other ECO 100 professors' exams are rumored to. This class is generally straightforward and doable.
This is a great class! Take it with Bogan if you can, because she is really great! It isn't that difficult if you take the time to do the work.

This is a great course if you're looking for an introduction to economics.  It's interesting, and we discuss current events dealing with economics, which makes the readings and learning the material easier and more interesting.
This is a pretty easy distribution requirement with Bogan, and it gives you a new perspective on things in life. I would recommend it.

This is quite a good introductory course to econ. The Models are often interesting and applicable to the real world and generally something everybody should have had exposure too. Not necessarily the best course you can take but certainly not a regret. The more effort you put in, the more you certainly get out. It's easy to coast in this class, but if you go to all the lectures and do the readings beforehand you might actually be intellectually stimulated
Try and get a good preceptor because it'll make all the difference. Also, precept on Monday is preferred.
Try it out. Maybe PDF. Interesting if you like Econ.
Use LN a lot and read articles before week fo finals
While it is a good overview of microeconomics, it could be much much better.
YOU HAVE RESOURCES. TAKE ADVANTAGE. This course is a life course.
Yeah, if you need to. Bogan was a good choice.
Yes
Yes, take it. It applies to everything and is required for many majors.
You should not take the class if you do not have time to put in the work.  Also, you should not take it as your 4th or 5th class.
You should take it! It's a great general introduction into Micro Econ.  Do all of your work, and you'll be fine!

You're probably (definitely) taking this course because it's a required prerequisite. It will be fine as long as you keep up with the work. Ask your preceptor for help immediately if you don't understand something because concepts build on each other.
dont take it unless you have to
get bogan as a preceptor
go to lecture, make sure you understand the concepts because they build on each other
good intro class. However, if you took micro before, this class will be on the boring side.
keep up with the readings and psets. go to office hours
make sure to read all the economist articles!
not easy not fun not applicable - do not take to fulfill a distribution requirement. much too much work for a fun PDF.
psets are not too hard, lectures are mediocre but needed because bogan tests examples talked about in class sometimes.
take it
very easy to fall behind and fairly difficult at times
descrip: Economics is the study of how people and societies deal with scarcity. This course focuses on the advantages and disadvantages of market systems for allocating scarce resources.

title: Sex on the Brain
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Founding, Building, and Managing an Architectural Practice - Business and Legal Issues in Architectural Practice
reviews: TAKE IT! Hillier is an awesome guy and will make your experience entertaining and fruitful.

While this course is most applicable to students that possess a latent or active interest in establishing their own architectural practice, the information obtained through the instructor is valuable to anyone who plans to work professionally within the discipline. The depth and breadth of knowledge acquired is something that you will continue to reference throughout your entire career. I think that every student should enroll in this course.
descrip: Review and analysis of the dynamics and process inherent in starting, developing, managing and operating an architectural practice, including marketing, finance, human resources, project process, liability, insurance, and general management. Areas of particular emphasis include project accounting, public presentations, and the development of a business plan.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
reviews: I wouldn't take this course again.
Read lecture notes for supplementation.
Rework the lectures yourself to get the most out of the math, or else you won't follow what's being presented.
descrip: Advances in experimental and theoretical studies or laboratory and naturally-occurring high-temperature plasmas, including stability and transport, nonlinear dynamics and turbulence, magnetic reconnection, selfheating of "burning" plasmas, and innovative concepts for advanced fusion systems. Advances in plasma applications, including laser-plasma interactions, nonneutral plasmas, high-intensity accelerators, plasma propulsion, plasma processing, and coherent electromagnetic wave generation.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Full-time research internship at a host institution, to perform scholarly research relevant to student's dissertation work. Research objectives are determined by advisor in conjunction with outside host. A mid-semester progress review and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students for up to two semesters. Special rules apply to international students regarding CPT/OPT use. Students may register by application only.

title: History and Society of Saudi Arabia
descrip: This course examines the history, politics and society of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, perhaps the most important country in both the Arab and Islamic worlds today. Students will be exposed to the Kingdom's complex relationship with political Islam, the global oil market, other Arab and Muslim countries as well as the West. This course will give students a solid overview of its history, politics and society through a careful selection of published studies. The aim of the course is to get students acquainted with the history of the Kingdom and the main factors that have played a role in its unfolding.

title: Industrial Organization
reviews: Be warned that this class places math ahead of economics, would not recommend unless you are trying to take game theory and are looking for an unengaging class.
I thought it would be more case studies and more lively. Almost pure theory. It's essentially 310 on steroids
If you have taken ECO 310, you'll not learn much new stuff in this class
It was a decent course. Not too hard, not too easy. Lectures are interesting and move at a good pace.
Only Take if you have MAT 202, ORF 245 ECO 310. This course is extremely advanced and quantitative. You need the utmost comfort with numbers to enjoy the rest
it's like a more interesting version of ECO310
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 and MAT 102 or MAT 103. Not open to freshmen. Students should be comfortable using basic calculus to solve problems..
descrip: This course studies firms, markets and competition. We will study the theory of industrial organization, focusing on analyzing the way firms make decisions, as well as the impact of those decisions on market outcomes such as market prices, quantities, the type of products offered and social welfare. The goals of the course include the development of intuition for firm strategic behavior, such as pricing, as well as the development of skills for the analysis of formal models.

title: Embodied Computation
prereqs: The emphasis is on learning new methods of developing design, and there are no prerequisites, but a strong motivation to tackle new knowledge and work in an experimental design setting is expected.
descrip: Computational design is often presented as a problem solving tool for design implementation rather than as an integral part of design conceptualization and exploration. This seminar focuses on approaching computational design from the conceptual design direction extending existing or defining novel models of design along the way. A strong emphasis is put on prototyping as a mode of design iteration using both computational prototypes and computationally generated physical prototypes as embodiments of the design process.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Seminar in Literary Theory
reviews: Give yourself time to do the reading. It's not a lot of pages, but it can be dense.

I would suggest to all students to take the course as it is foundational and necessary for our academic career. In addition Professor Nouzeilles was very easy to approach after class or in  her office. She met with me for my final paper and gave great recommendations.
You definitely have to take this course if you want to learn critical theory from the beginning. It may be useful too for advanced students, though.
descrip: What is the "matter" of theory, its basic content and scope? This seminar studies the main trends in modern theoretical thought from Russian Formalism and their reduction of literature to formal systems of signification and the Frankfurt School's readings of mass culture, to most recent interpretations of the role of power in cultural production in Foucault, Deleuze, Sarduy, Spivak, Rama, Hall, and others. This seminar seeks to develop a coherent overall overview that incorporates philosophical and social perspectives on the fundamental questions of critical thinking.

title: Music and the Mathematical Mind
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Analytic Combinatorics
reviews: Definitely take this course. So useful. I know so much more about combinatorics now. Make sure to have a group, though, since it's easy to skip MOOC lectures and the flipped classroom sessions and get very behind. You have to hold yourself to a higher standard to get something out of this course since it's so easy to slack off, but having a group of people who watch the lectures together and ask questions of each other really makes you understand the material deeply.
If you are a computer science major and have only taken 340, do NOT take this class! It is very, very difficult.

If you think that you can learn all by yourself without much help from anybody (excep the course assistant) and you think that the material is useful. I would say take it. But if you have a slightest doubt about this course, I would strongly recommend against it!

Keep in mind this course material is almost entirely given online. Also, this course should be primarily taken with the intention on the mathematical content as the programming was generally elementary. It is essentially equivalent to the Coursera course. That said I think the material is very interesting and would therefore recommend taking the course.
Take it, but a reasonable amount of work.
Take it.
Take this class if you liked 340. It gives a nice way to answer many 340 problems with much less math.
The class is online on Coursera and the actual class is Q&A.

The material is interesting though it was presented as two online courses on Coursera. The normal lecture hours were for Q&A and typically less than 10 students went there. Self-study is essentially the core of the course.
This course was a solid theory course, although much more mathematically difficult than the other undergraduate theory courses.
Very interesting topics and material. If interested in theoretical computer science, this is one of my favorites.
You learn to do some amazing things in this course.
prereqs: COS 226, 340 or equivalent background in mathematics..
descrip: Analytic Combinatorics aims to enable precise quantitative predictions of the properties of large combinatorial structures. The theory has emerged over recent decades as essential both for the scientific analysis of algorithms in computer science and for the study of scientific models in many other disciplines. This course combines motivation for the study of the field with an introduction to underlying techniques, by covering as applications the analysis of numerous fundamental algorithms from computer science. The second half of the course introduces Analytic Combinatorics, starting from basic principles.

title: Special Topics in Contemporary Practice - Body and Thought: Performance for Actors and Dancers
reviews: Go in with an open mind and a willingness to try anything.
Gotta be willing to dive into a new world. Don't half-ass it or take a spot from someone who really wants to experiment.

I think if you're thinking about this, you already kind of know it's your bag. If you're new to DAN or THR there might be better jumping in points (Aynsley's DAN 209 or Tracy/Suzie in 201, respectively), but by all means anyone looking for a one off experience, who is willing, could jump into this course.
If you have an interest in either dance or theatre, this is a MUST take class!
Take it for an avant-garde theatre experience.
Take the group projects seriously.
Take this class! It's wonderful and so are Susan and Tracy! It's also a very good space for people of all levels and backgrounds in acting or dance.

Take this course! It is fantastic. Dancers and actors will find themselves growing by leaps and bounds. Tracy and Susan are really remarkable. Easily one of the best courses I took at Princeton. You really learn how to be present in the moment and be an honest performer.

This is one of the best courses I have ever taken. Susan and Tracy are wonderful teachers who give everyone equal attention. They are very willing to help inside and out of class with projects as well. The content of the course completely changed the way I approach performance.
This was a fun survey of various theater and movement based exercises that put into question your existence as a performer.
prereqs: Students must have completed at least one studio course in either dance or theatre. Freshmen and others who have not met this prerequisite may seek instructor's permission..
descrip: Beyond spoken text and physical action, is the all-important performance of a work. How something is done is as crucial as what is done. This course encourages you to push your limits and range as mover, dancer and/or actor. Exercises support the practice of clear intention, committed choice-making, embodied character, physical response and the ability to modulate the intensity of action and emotion. You will perform dance and theater repertory scenes and perform your own works that fully utilize your ability to join thought, experience and action. Readings and viewings on contemporary artists of dance/physical theater support studio work.

title: The Rule of Law
descrip: Considers role of law in gov't: When is a state constrained by law & when it may legitimately change/ignore the law? Use a range of materials from fiction to court cases, legal theory to political history, etc. Proceed by negative example, considering cases from the US: Lincoln's conduct during Civil War, Roosevelt's economic emergency, the Cold War, Nixonian exceptionalism, "war on terror" after 9/11. Also consider comparative examples: Russian Revolution, the collapse of the Weimar constitution, the breaks from communism in the "revolutions" of 1989 & beyond. Also Nuremberg Trials & Kosovar War.

title: Algebraic Topology
prereqs: Topology MAT 365 (formerly 325) and Algebra MAT 345 (formerly MAT 322). For advanced level undergraduate and graduate students. Undergraduates must obtain permission from Instructor..
descrip: The aim of the course is to study some of the basic algebraic techniques in Topology, such as homology groups, cohomology groups and homotopy groups of topological spaces.

title: Imagined Languages
reviews: Absolutely take it. The professors are among Princeton's best, and the material is fascinating.
Get to know the professors well! Explore weird languages on your own! Read more about anything that interests you on your own!
If you can get into this course, you will not regret it. Truly one of the only courses at Princeton of its kind.

If you enjoy creative thought and like to get confused about all things languages, then take this class! You'll come out of this class with more questions than when you started, but these are the good kinds of questions that will keep you very satisfied for the rest of your life. And this class is really really unique in the fact that it lets you to truly explore what interests you for your assignments and projects and papers, so please do take advantage of that. And of course, Professors Katz and Gordin are just amazing.
Incredibly well run and well thought out, but know what you're getting into because it's more or less a factoid class.
Of course you should take this class. It's an incredible topic taught by two of the best lecturers at Princeton. The assignments are fun, the readings are great, and the class dynamic is wonderful.
One of my best courses at Princeton! Professors are great, and the material is unique and interesting!
TAKE THIS CLASS
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! WAKE UP EARLY AND BE THE FIRST TO REGISTER FOR CLASSES. If you get in do ALL of the readings. They are FUN and you won't regret it.

TAKE THIS COURSE! I would say this was one of the most intellectually stimulating courses I've taken. Really interesting material and fantastic professors. If you are fortunate enough to get in, do not pass on the chance to take it.
Take it!
Take it! It won't be as life-changing as some other reviews suggest, but it's still pretty great. Plus, it fulfills the HA distribution requirement.
Take this class!
Take this class. You will regret it if you don't.
Take this course if you like weird things and want to expand your mind.

Take this! But also know what you're getting into. I wanted an interesting, non-math/science class that would expose me to new topics and ideas, and I got that and so much more. If you're looking for a directed, focused look at issues related to language, though, the class may seem a little haphazard or pointless to you. For me, though, the fact that the topic was so fascinating and the professors were so engaging more than made up for it.

The professors are great, so for that reason, it's a good class to take. As for the material, I had a superficial interest, but I probably would have enjoyed the class more fully if I had a stronger previous connection to the material in some way. The work is challenging by design, so be prepared for that. All in all, I don't regret taking it and would recommend to people who are interested after the first glance.
There are some courses you need to take, and some courses you should hook up an ethernet cable just for an extra few milliseconds during course signup to take. This is the latter.

This course is perfect. If any of the subject matter is remotely interesting to you, take this course. The readings, lectures (which were mostly discussion), and homework assignments straddled the line between fun and work. Both Professor Gordin and Professor Katz are engaging, brilliant, and hilarious.

This is a really enjoyable class. Very interesting topic and two professors who are really knowledgeable, funny, good at teaching, and work well together. At the same time, don't be too sad if you don't get it. In my opinion, the reviews for the course are kind of hyped up. It is definitely a great class, but there are also some issues. For example, the size of the class makes it hard to have good discussions. Instead, the discussions tend to be pretty disjointed and awkward. Also, the professors know so much that they often talk about things that are interesting but don't seem to connect to the lecture.
This was the greatest course I have taken in my 4 years.

take it, if you can get in.  i say that only because of the professors, who could make any material interesting. so if you can't get in, find another course they are teaching and sign up.  I preferred katz in CLA208, but this was more kooky and fun.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites. Some places are reserved for students pursuing a HUM certificate. Eligible students should write to Lin DeTitta (ldetitta@princeton.edu)..
descrip: This course combines historical and linguistic analysis in an attempt to understand how and why people are sometimes moved to try to transcend the languages to which we have natural, or at least relatively easy, access. Among the examples we will consider are Esperanto, Klingon, Middle Egyptian, Linear A and B, Cornish, Fortran, and Proto-World. Taking a view that is broad both geographically and temporally, we will explore, in an interactive and collaborative way, the philosophical and sociological implications of constructing and reconstructing languages for purposes that range from the political to the literary to the simply frivolous.

title: Roman Elegy from Catullus to Ovid
reviews: Don't automatically take this class if you enjoy Latin. The focus is more on analyzing the literature than on the language itself. But if you enjoy the academic study of literature, you'll probably enjoy this class. Otherwise, not so much. It can also get bogged down in the details of individual poems and not look at the larger picture too much.

Haynes isn't the fastest grader, but she's very well versed and encourages fun, deep discussion of the poetry. I would highly recommend this to anyone in the Classics department or looking at a Latin certificate!
Professor Haynes is great. The subject matter is great. Every classicist should take this class!
Take if offered again
Take it!
descrip: Selections from Latin elegy focusing on the writings of Propertius.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Subwavelength Nanophotonics and Plasmonics
reviews: if busy, a good course to take.
if you are interested in research in plasmonics.
descrip: An introductory course for the 1st and 2nd year graduate students to understand the theory and application of the photonic devices which have feature size smaller than the wavelength of light, termed subwavelength photonics (SWP) or subwavelength optical elements (SOE). The devices include those with metallic structures, namely, subwavelength plasmonics. The course has three main sections: (i) rigorous Maxwell theory and mean-field theory for SWPs, (ii) non-resonant SWPs and resonant SWPs (photonic crystals), and (iii) applications of SWP.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Political Science
descrip: This seminar is concerned with the professional obligations of political science researchers. This course is designed to raise those concerns and develop in students an appreciation for the issues that they might confront as they do their work. Topics addressed includes the relationship of political science as an academic discipline to democratic politics and institutions, advocacy and objectivity in political science, plagiarism and academic misconduct, human subjects and fieldwork in research, institutional review boards, funding sources and intellectual integrity, collaboration, and mentoring.

title: Ethics of Human Experimentation, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: General Computer Science
reviews: A class that should be taken by all.
A large portion of the class has already taken computer science, so coming in with none was tough, and there was a pretty steep learning curve.
A lot of work, but a class everyone should take.
A most interesting course. The course load isn't excessive and the assignments introduce you to the all the material you need to know for the final.

A very very well-thought course. Very enjoyable, intense and necessary for almost anything you do. Clark is a very good lecturer.The course didn't take as much time as I expected. Better if you know some Math and Science
Absolutely. It's a lot of work (even if you're PDFing) but very interesting and worth it. Take it as a PDF and still expect to put in effort, or schedule an otherwise light course-load.
An amazing course for non-COS people. I think it should be a required course. You learn so so so much about how computers work. Donna Gabai is also the most amazing preceptor!
As long as you understand what's going on, it's not that hard at all
Attend office hours! Get help early. Attend a newbie precept if possible. The extra 30 minutes are so helpful!
Be careful! This course is like walking a really long balance beam. It should be easy to do well but a small slip may wreck your grade.
Be prepared to dedicate a lot of time if you are a novice.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the class and learn a lot!
Be prepared, it is tricky!
Be ready for the workload and see teachers for help so you don't fall behind.
Be ready to do a lot of work! The programming assignments take 5-10 hours a week and there is reading and review on top of that. It's a very well-done class, though.
COS 126 is a fantastic introductory computer science course. I'd recommend it to every student here.
Carefully read the booksite before lectures. It helps and it is enough.

Coding clicks directly with some people and not so much with others, so this course might be a great blast for you or a little bit of a struggle. But either way, this is a course that you should take simply because it makes you see things from a new perspective, so take it! PDF it if you must (a lot of people do, so don't think it's unusual!), but take it!
Cos 126 can be very time consuming for novice coders, but it is an incredibly interesting and engaging class that introduces a great many topics relevant to many other fields other than Cos.

DO SOME CODING BEFORE THIS COURSE! PLEASE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
And just try to keep up. It is a great class, but it moves at a million miles an hour. Good luck.
DOUGIE DOUG CLARK IS A LEGEND AND A GOD. Take the course with him lecturing. Try to get a head preceptor as your preceptor, and don't be afraid to try it if you are non-STEM.
Dedicate enough time to understand what you're doing with the assignments. Don't just get them out of the way (this will help prepare for the final)
Definitely
Definitely a class everyone should take! Probably a little tough at the beginning if you've never taken comp sci classes, but it's worth it. You pick it up really quickly!
Definitely a good course to take! A good option for PDFing, but not an easy PDF, as you still need to make sure all your code for assignments work well and do decently on exams.

Definitely review powerpoints online and the textbook before going to lecture, and look at the assignment before going to precept that week. I found I was better able to follow the class that I had prepped myself for.
Definitely take and utilize lab TA's and office hours. Great introduction to programming and it's a useful skill.
Definitely take before you leave Pton.
Definitely take it since it's a great class and you learn useful coding skills. However, it might be super tough for you as it was for me, since I had zero coding experience.
Definitely take it! Dan is an awesome preceptor. This course is very well-organized, and they provide you ample amount of help when you need it.
Definitely take it, but be prepared to do a fair amount of work and struggle in writing and debugging some of your programs.
Definitely take it-the course is interesting and provides valuable skills.
Definitely take it. There's support for you if you need it, but it's pretty intuitive and very powerful.
Definitely take this course if you can! It is a lot of fun and teaches you a lot.
Definitely take this course!
Difficult, but rewarding and interesting. be prepared for a big time commitment, but if you study for exams and do the assignments you should get a good grade. go to precept!
Do all the web sheets and attend office hours as much as possible.

Do not be afraid to go to COS lab TA office hours. They are incredibly helpful. After you finish an assignment, look back through it and explain it to yourself again so you really cement why you wrote what you did. Read the book before lecture.

Do not fall behind on concepts or homework. Everything builds, so making sure you understand the first few weeks is extremely important. I think that this course is great for general interests. The projects are interesting, and you learn a lot in a very short time.
Do not rely too much on the lab TAs for help; make sure you know how to complete programming assignment on your own.
Do not take this class if you have a 5 semester class. This class needs a lot of time devoted to it, both theoretical facts and programming so you are spending very much time on both of those.
Do not take this if you are an upperclassmen and be carefula bout PDFing-it is a lot of work!
Do the programming assignments.
Do the readings and the websheets, practice programming as much as you can
Do the readings.
Don't fall behind! This course is very fast paced and everything builds up quickly.
Don't take it unless required

Don't take this course unless you have prior experience or are prepared to question your intelligence level. It is hard, but the knowledge and skills learned are helpful. Definitely not a GPA booster, though.

Doug Clark is the man, and if he's lecturing then you'll have a great time.  Dan Leyzberg is also the man, and I recommend his precepts.  Make sure you have a laptop though!  It's hard to follow along without it.  Also, doing well I think starts with really being excited and curious about computer science in the first place, so if you're excited to learn the material, then you'll be just fine!  If not, I would say to read the textbook many times over and utilize all of the resources available to you in this course (there are a lot)
Even if you don't have any COS background, take this course. Try it out. It is really interesting and programming is a useful skill to have.
Even if you're not an engineer, take this class! It's extremely well-taught, well-organized, and you come out of it with skills (and ways of thinking) that will be useful wherever you go.
Every student should take this class, no doubt.
Every student should take this course. Extraordinarily well organized, taught, and supported by great preceptors.
Everyone should take this course.
Everyone should take this sometime before they graduate.
Excellent course. A true must-take.

Excellent intro class, fun assignments, a lot of help available for those who need it. Definitely the class to take if you have little or no programming experience - you learn a ton! Start assignments early so you know whether you need to go in for extra help.

Get started on the assignments early. Even just reading through the assignment a few times is a huge step. The more you break up the work, the easier it is because you're less likely to get stuck or miss something because you have more time to think about it.
Give it a shot.
Give yourself plenty of time to complete the assignments.
Go for it, even if you have no experience!

Go to Lab TAs as often as possible, they make the assignments very doable and are an incredible help. This course is time-consuming but amazing and something everyone should learn. COS 126 is the must-take class at Princeton.
Go to class

Go to precept and read the textbook for things you don't understand. Make sure you start the programming assignments early, and study hard for the exams. Put the time in, and you should be fine. Would recommend to anyone.
Go to precept, could definitely skip some lectures.
Go to precepts definitely and office hours/TA help if you are struggling
Good class to take. Make sure you start early on assignments and go to class, especially precept.
Great class

Most people are going to tell you to take this course. I'm going not going to sugarcoat things. I don't think this course is as great as people think. You're not going to know much about computer science by taking this course. The assignments don't require much if any problem solving ability and what they really test is how well you can interpret vague and spread out directions. The exams themselves are difficult. The average is a C-, but with assignment grades in (everyone gets 95%+ with hard work), grades average out to a B. The second written exam tested more theory than java (90% theory). I took this course to learn java and increase my problem solving ability, but all I really ended up doing was memorizing random and overly useless facts about computer science theory and circuits. If you want to learn java, learn it online. This class won't help get you a job - increasing your problem solving ability and actually learning how to use java to implement solutions will. If you choose to take this class for fun and a B+ or less will lower your GPA, PDF it.

descrip: An introduction to computer science in the context of scientific, engineering, and commercial applications. The goal of the course is to teach basic principles and practical issues, while at the same time preparing students to use computers effectively for applications in computer science, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and other disciplines. Topics include: hardware and software systems; programming in Java; algorithms and data structures; fundamental principles of computation; and scientific computing, including simulation, optimization, and data analysis. Two lectures, two precepts.

title: The Multimedia Architect
reviews: A very independent style seminar, you definitely get as much out of it as youre willing to put in. If your interested in this time period, go for it!

Would highly recommend to anybody interested in broadening their understanding of architecture beyond that which we think of it today.
descrip: Architects did not describe themselves as architects in the Renaissance. Sculptors, painters, writers, and engineers all designed buildings while simultaneously - and often primarily - focusing on other arts. What happens when a goldsmith builds a dome or an artillery engineer constructs a staircase? How does an artist's work across various media inform an architectural project, and vice-versa? Using artists including Leonardo, Michelangelo, and Rubens as case studies, this course explores the concept of the early modern multimedia architect to ask: what is architectural about architecture?

title: Algorithms and Data Structures
reviews: A lot easier than 217. Course focuses on some really interesting algorithms. Don't forget to do the exercises!

I did the flipped lecture, which I would HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend if you generally have a hard time staying focused during lecture or usually feel like lecture moves too quickly or slowly at times. Being able to just pause a lecture and re-watch an animation, stare at a code snippet for a while, or listen to Sedgewick's explanation again is unbelievably helpful. Also, the flipped lecture videos are tremendously helpful for reviewing for exams (navigating through organized sections of named videos is way easier than paging through the 900  page textbook). Also, watching at 2x speed helps you review and find only the things you don't totally remember.

It's way less fun than 126, but important and interesting if you really like COS.

Keep up with Blackboard exercises, and you should do fine on the exams. It's a totally doable course despite the huge time commitment, even if you're still not sure you like COS after 126.
Loved it. Start the assignments early.
Make sure to start early on the assignments and ask for help if you need them.
Make sure you don't skip precept.
Maybe not the best if you don't have the time, if you're cos this is required.

Really enjoyed the assignments. Go to COS Lab TA hours if you get stuck!!

TAKE IT. Kevin Wayne is a great lecturer, and he makes the course material really interesting and accessible. Even if he isn't teaching it, I think the class is very well organized and will be great no matter who is teaching it. The algorithms and data structures you learn in the course are a must for anyone who wants a solid foundation with computer science. And the programming assignments are really interesting and just the right level of challenging. TAKE IT!

TAKE THIS COURSE. Algorithms are an essential tool for any serious programmer. Computers are rapidly taking over our everyday lives and knowing how to program is a skill with infinite applications, even to nontechnical fields.
TAKE THIS. One of the best courses at Princeton hands down. It can be difficult but SO rewarding

Take COS 226! If you are looking to apply for COS internships, maybe take this in the fall for interview questions. Otherwise, take COS 217 in the fall and this in the spring; 226 is much easier after 217 and winter break is helpful to have while working on the final project for 217. Find a partner at about equal level that doesn't have coding habits too drastically different from yours to code with and study with. Do practice exams and focus on gaining intuition for design questions.
Take it if you have to or if you're really interested in algorithms. It's not terribly interesting, but also not terribly hard.

Take it if you liked 126 and want to basically continue where it left off. The programming assignments take a bit of time, so make sure you can devote a day or two to COS. Don't go to precept unless you don't understand how to do the assignment.
Take it!
Take it! Attend lecture and definitely start assignments early.
Take it! It really opens your mind to the power of cos
Take it! It's great if you enjoyed 126, and gives you a handle on more advanced concepts
Take it! You learn some very powerful algorithms as well as helpful CS interview tips.
Take it!! Not necessarily as "fun" as 126, but much more instructive and informative. Get Jeremie as your preceptor!!!!

Take it.  You won't regret it.  If you decide not to, you'll wish you had later on.
