Take the class if you're at all interested in COS. It's well taught and the weekly assignments are interesting. The averages on the midterm/final will be low, but you can otherwise do well on the assignments.
Take this class if you liked COS 126.
Take this class!
Take this class! It's very interesting if you have any interest in computer science and will make you much more qualified for COS jobs! Get Robert MacDavid as a preceptor if you can.
Take this course! Algorithms are everywhere in our daily lives. If you enjoy puzzles, you will really enjoy this course. It's not very challenging, especially if you've already taken COS217.
Take this course! Start assignments early.
Take this course. It is great
Take! but be warned that the harsh grading   NAPDF can be an issue
The most engaging and organized course I've taken. Take it if you liked COS 126 in the slightest.

The structure is similar to 126, even some of the same material, but the topics are more focused. Reading the book isn't too important - just do the required weekly exercises to have a general idea of what is going on. Guna is a great preceptor.
There's a lot of work.

This class is really well run.  The workload is manageable and the exams are tricky but not impossible.  Material is really interesting.  Try to take it when Kevin Wayne is teaching because he's the man.
This class is so much better than 217. If you're interested in COS, take it! It's fun.
This course is a must-take, especially for those have any level of interest in computer science. You will learn a lot about computer science.

This course is amazingly practical and informative. The programs are challenging yet rewarding, but get a good programming partner! The history and applications of algorithms and data structures are also compelling lecture material.

This course is definitely interesting and could help those that are preparing for interviews at a tech company. However, you need to spend a lot of time learning the materials, especially before exams.
This course is very time-consuming, but it also teaches a lot of useful information.
This course isn't hard, it just isn't that interesting either. Find a medium to learn the material (either through the textbook, the Salon videos, or the lectures) and you'll do fine.
This is a great class that everyone should take. Very engaging and if you put in the work, you will do well in this class. Highly recommend.

This is a great course for anyone who wants to (or needs to be able to) program effectively. It sets you up for practical applications and explores fun problems along the way. It's well-taught and extremely organized.

This is a great course, and definitely the next step after COS 126. Even if you aren't a COS major, it's great background knowledge. Prof. Wayne taught it well and the assignments are very manageable. They're challenging but really teach you the material and take about 5-8 hours per week.
This is a pretty standard algorithms course and definitely useful if you want to do computer science in the future.
This is a standard class for the subject matter.
This is a very interesting course to take if you're into computer science. It really opens your mind to the great impact that different algorithms can have for different situations.
This is like next level COS 126. It's much harder than 126, but it's not as hard as 217, so choose your courses accordingly.
Try to familiarize yourself with algorithms and data structures beforehand so they are not new when they are presented in lecture.
Use the assignment videos and read the checklist carefully - it's a fun class and is not as nit-picky as 217.

While it is a bit of a jump conceptually, the assignments and the materials are not a huge step up from COS 126. You generally get a good grasp of the different algorithms and their analysis through practice. Definitely be careful in managing time though, because the assignments and the exercises can become cumbersome.

While this can become pretty time consuming, it is a really rewarding and interesting course to take. Everything is really well-organized and structured, and the professors/preceptors are really great about helping.
have fun
have robert macdavid as your preceptor and pay attention to all lectures

programs take a ridiculous amount of time. make sure you have a partner, then you don't feel so alone. Shivam is awesome. exams are annoying. you learn helpful algorithms that relate to life!
take it  much better than cos126
prereqs: COS 126, ISC 231-234, or approval by the COS placement officer..
descrip: This course surveys the most important algorithms and data structures in use on computers today. Particular emphasis is given to algorithms for sorting, searching, and string processing. Fundamental algorithms in a number of other areas are covered as well, including geometric algorithms, graph algorithms, and some numerical algorithms. The course will concentrate on developing implementations, understanding their performance characteristics, and estimating their potential effectiveness in applications.

title: History and Cinema: Fascism in Film
descrip: See website

title: Into the Woods! What Disney Didn't Tell You About Fairy Tales
descrip: See website

title: Systems Neuroscience
reviews: Definitely take the course! Prof. Berry is really knowledgeable about these topics and they are just interesting topics to begin with!
Good material, but a lot of readings to keep up with. Be prepared to do a decent amount of work for this class
Make sure you're REALLY interested in systems neuroscience before you take it.
Take it if you're interested in neuroscience, especially in the systems side of things!
good
prereqs: NEU 258 is required. Students are also encouraged to have taken NEU 408..
descrip: The brain is more than a mere collection of its constituent parts. In this class we aim to understand how neurons interact together in local circuits and distributed brain dynamics to perform behaviorally relevant functions. The class will be organized into modules, which are selected to cover most of the major divisions of the brain. For most modules, we will first discuss a simpler circuit/system for which detailed mechanistic models and concrete ideas about function are known. Then, we will go on to discuss more complex systems, which are related to the simpler system.

title: Slavic Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: A practical course intended to facilitate the dissertation writing process. The seminar meets every week for 2 hours, or less often depending on the need and pace of the participants. Dissertation writers circulate work in progress for feedback and meet for discussion as a group. The seminar is required of all post-generals students in Russian literature who are in residence.

title: Fundamentals of Statistics
reviews: A good intro to stats that can be applied everywhere. Take to see if ORF major or SML and EMS certificates are for you.
Amazing

Do not take unless you are an ORFE major. If you need to take a stats class for a distribution requirement, take a different one than this class.

Professor Kpotufe never finishes lectures on time, and they often only cover really basic/easy examples you could probably figure out yourself. As a person who attended nearly every lecture, I question whether it actually helped me. Good Luck!

Figure out who in the class knows stats and MatLab and work with them. If there are any good preceptors, take advantage of their office hours. The psets and exams are hard!!!! Plan time for the programming assignments!
Follow the lectures and readings. The class can be quite time-consuming especially because of the programming assignments, which are not taught in class but you are expected to learn on your own.
Fun course, very good introduction to statistics! Also good introduction to matlab.
Go to office hours and start assignments early.
Good Course

The only hard part is that they never taught you how to use MATLAB but you needed to use it for programming assignments (but students were allowed to ask for help from each other and from preceptors).
I would not take this unless you have to. It's a lot of work, and it gets really dry.

If Samory is teaching this course, I recommend. It's a great blend of interesting and practical. The work load is fairly average and fair. Even though I took AP stats, I felt as if I learned a lot from this course. MATLAB was great and I learned a lot more about the math behind stats. Very glad I took it.
If you have to take it, take it. Otherwise take a harder stats class

It was a good and fairly easy class overall. The pace of the lectures was rather slow. Homework was manageable and a good way of understanding the fundamentals. I wish they covered more advanced material.
Its a great intro to stats course. Prof. Kpotufe is a very good lecturer and far better than the previous ones, Ive heard. The material is super useful and the psets and exams are good. Take it!
Just keep up.
Kind of like AP Stat, but with a couple of new topics thrown in.

Kpotufe is fantastic. He takes the time to make sure you really understand the material (granted, some people still think lectures are hard to understand, but I think that's just because of the difficulty of the material in general). The material is not particularly interesting like ORF 309, but it's definitely a lot easier than ORF 309. I wish I had taken 245 before 309, because if I had I would have been so much more prepared for ORF 309. The first half of 245 is a review of probability. Anyway, overall, I think it's not a bad course to take if you need to for a certificate or your major, but overall there are probably more interesting classes out there.
Make sure you go to lecture so you know what topics are being covered.
Much easier to go through if you have taken statistics before. Definitely takes a more mathematical approach to stats that I had experienced before, which was interesting.
Only take it if you 100% have to.
Only take it if you have to, it's pretty boring.  If you took stats before, this should be pretty easy.  A little more in depth than high school stats.  Workload is manageable, exams aren't too bad.

Prof. Kpotufe seems to still be learning how to structure this course. His lectures are not great, and the problem sets and programming assignments vary so much in their difficulty that it may take anywhere from 2 to 20 hours per assignment.
Read the book. Go to office hours.
Self-study a lot.
Take ORF 309 first. Then skip this class.
Take for an easy A if you can do math
Take if needed.

prereqs: MAT 201 concurrent or equivalent.
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated in the light of modern data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R. Precepts are based on real data analysis.

title: Contradictions of Freedom in American Capitalism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - K-12 School Reform
descrip: This course explores K-12 education policymaking in the context of dramatic changes to the status quo, but an unclear future. We will focus on differing perspectives and solutions for a diverse array of issues--from standards, assessments, and accountability to teachers/school leaders to governance, turnarounds, and school choice. The course will be anchored in the reality of policymaking--digesting the research on a topic, making/supporting policy recommendations. Students will work with 'live issues' in ed reform, analyze them, and recommend paths forward.

title: Germany since 1806
reviews: Even if your major has nothing to do with history, consider taking this course if you have an interest in Germany! It's really interesting and well taught. By far one of my favorite courses.
I would recommend the class to those looking for graduate-style teaching and evaluation as well as those looking to do history through multiple, specific angles of inquiry.

Interesting class - probably better suited for those genuinely interested in the material than those simply looking for a history class. Professor James is a great professor and is quite funny! The material can be a lot, so be sure you're ready to take it on. The workload itself is very manageable. Overall a good course.
Take it!
Take it! Professor James is outstanding and you will learn a ton about German history.
Take it. Its fun, and Professor James is a very nice guy who knows everything there is to know about Germany.
Take this course, if nothing else to work with Professor James
This is an excellent course for those interested in German History.
descrip: This course sets German history in a comparative context of international politics, demonstrating how nationalism and national unity emerged as responses to the European state system in the first half of the 19th century, how after 1871 German problems in turn affected the world, and finally why after 1945 Germany should be so prominent in super-power politics. It examines the origin of the German Revolution of 1989, and the place of Germany in Europe and the global order.

title: Aristotle and His Successors
reviews: A MUST-TAKE CLASS.  Prof. Morison is hilarious, a captivating lecturer.  He's also Aristotelian to the core, and it's always best to take classes with profs who have a clear passion for what they teach.  He's brilliant.
A good course for someone with no background in philosophy who wants to learn about Aristotle.

ABSOLUTELY DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE! As a non-philosophy major, I really struggled to find anything unintuitive about the course. You don't cover very much. But, if you are interested in an easy EC, this is it. barely any effort required.

ABSOLUTELY take this class. Morison is witty and engaging, and one of the best professors/teachers I've ever had. A manageable amount of readings - you will be able to get through it all. The problem sets are really helpful and not super time-consuming. A really convincing introduction to Aristotle's philosophy.
Amazing course. Everyone at Princeton should take this course.
Aristotle has been the object of study for more than two millennia. After you take this course, you will understand why.

BENJAMIN MORISON. If this guy is teaching the class, take the class. Nothing else matters. If you need to take something else instead for a requirement, switch your major. Do it. It's worth it, trust me. Morison's undying love for Aristotle combined with his quick wit make his lectures extremely informative and still hilarious. Cannot recommend Morison enough- one of the best professors at Princeton. If someone else is teaching it, I'm not sure what to say; the class changes a good deal year to year.
Definitely take this course. I'm not at all into philosophy, but this is one of my favorite courses of all times.
Definitely take this for an EC with Morrison. He is the man and some of it is interesting. Also this class requires very little work
Definitely take this, especially if you're looking for an EC. Well worth it, Prof. Morison is great.
Don't take this class.
Every student at Princeton should learn Aristotle in this class; it is awesome (and as an added bonus, not much input work is required for a lot of output knowledge).
Fun lectures, good preceptors. I took it to satisfy my EC, and it was fantastic as a PDF.
Go to lecture. Even if it's not the most necessary, Professor Morison is a great lecturer and it's always a lot of fun.
Go to office hours and seek help on the short assignments. They are difficult and the curve grade is steep.

Grading was completely arbitrary, and I don't think I "get" the appeal of Morison - seemed like he was just trying to be a stand-up comedian most of the time. WE wrote short p-sets every week that answered 3-5 questions on stuff straight from the book, basically just to test if you read/paid attention in lecture/read the lecture notes afterwards. Would recommend if you enjoy reading Aristotle a bit and don't want to put in too much of your own brainpower/thinking, especially as a PDF.
Great class. Good for Pdf and non alike. Very interesting lectures with BM. Hubble is a good preceptor. Minimal work, interesting material. Has changed how I live my life.

Great introduction to Aristotelian philosophy or philosophy in general for that matter.  If you have no philosophy background and want something that's not too intense/want a good EC, this is a great and fun course.

Honestly, I'd recommend that a student look for a different course. If the student is looking at this out of general interest, well, it's very dull and will almost certainly require a PDF. If you want to experience the strangeness of a man who is completely devoted to Aristotle, I suppose it is like a strange zoo exhibit. Overall, it was nice to be exposed to this material but not worth the time or the insufferable precepts. Recommend against.

I wouldn't take it. It is hard to get good grades because it is so easy everybody does really well. I got a 91% on the midterm and got a B. It's also ridiculously easy to lose points since you have to say exactly what they want to hear. Overall I learned some things but I did so on my own. The material is really light. 
Note: I don't regret taking it, it was fairly interesting and professor Morison is really awesome, I just think there must be many better choises
If you are at all interested in philosophy or Aristotle, take this course!

If you are looking for an intro to philosophy, you've come to the right place. If you're looking for something more rigorous, look elsewhere. If you're looking for ancient philosophy, take Lorenz's class as it'll cover more people and you'll still learn the basics of Aristotle.

If you want a nice introduction to logic, this is a good course. It is not too difficult to do well (B-range), but due to the rigid grading policies, it is rather difficult to get an A. If one pays careful attention to lectures and does assignments very cautiously, he or she can do very well. Don't expect exciting/provocative/controversial ideas that seem relevant contemporarily.

If you're interested in Aristotle (and you should be, since he's the greatest philosopher that has ever lived), it's a great course for you. Very manageable workload, but interesting lectures and problem sets. 
And you get to read Aristotle with Morrison's British accent in mind, which is always a plus. ;)
It is an interesting EC to take

It's a good EC if you have an interest in philosophy and are willing to put time into the readings and are ready to talk a lot in precept.  Lots of philosophy majors or people who've taken philosophy classes before though.

Morison is a terrific professor--get into his precept if you can. He is very clear and also keeps things playful. This class is a good intro to Aristotle for any level, whether a philosophy senior or a freshman who has no philosophical experience. The one thing to be aware of is that this class focuses more on understanding Aristotle's views (and competing ways to interpret him) than contemplating whether he is right.

Morison is an incredible lecturer, and this course really isn't difficult at all. Take it for a distribution requirement. However, if you are a philosophy person - you might not find it too rewarding.
Not that much work, but little reward
Nothing.
Only take it if you are actually interested in Aristotle.
Only take it if you know you like Aristotle.

Problem sets were pretty hard. Only way to do well is to attend lecture and write down all the main points Morrison makes (especially helps to mark which passage he is referring to), and to ask your preceptors while working on the psets. Morrison looks for VERY specific things on the pset responses, and your preceptors can help you figure out just what that is. All in all, fun class and Morrison is a hilarious and wonderful lecture.

Prof. Morison could be the best professor at Princeton! Lectures are spectacular; he is engaging, hilarious, and presents the material extraordinarily well. Try to get his precept if you can. Two pieces of advice: 1) do the readings for the first half after lecture, as they are very difficult without having someone first explain them to you. 2) do readings slowly and carefully. Seemingly small nuances are very important in the assignments. Definitely take this class if you have any interest in Aristotle or philosophy whatsoever. Morison really makes this course great; I would be wary in future years if someone else taught it, however, as the material can get tricky.
Professor Morison is a WONDERFUL teacher and person, and it's such a privilege to be able to learn from him. Definitely take this course! He really is such a master teacher and lecturer.
Professor Morrison is a great lecturer and (as an American who has focused primarily on East and South Asia), this is still some pretty great ideas to acquaint yourself with.

Students should definitely go to all of the lectures, because they're really fun and extremely informative. I would recommend doing the readings after lecture, when you know what Aristotle is trying to say and when Morison has already highlighted which passages are most important. If you do them before you may not know what's going on.
Take course for Morison (amazing lecturer) and Aristotle (amazing thinker) and easy EC.
Take if interested in Aristotle.
Take it even if you're remotely interested in philosophy! It will teach you a great deal about how Aristotle viewed the world
Take it!  Morison is amazing and Aristotle is worth the read.
Take it!!!
Take it. Prof Morison is amazing.
Take it. there's really no reason not to.
Take the class, the material is interesting, and hopefully the grading and assignment structure get fixed.
Take this class!

Take this course and don't look back. Morison is the best lecturer I've ever had, and he makes Aristotle understandable and enjoyable. The only drawback to this course is that the curve is pretty harsh.
Take this course if Morison is teaching it, regardless of major. Take any class Morison teaches!

Take this with Prof. Morrison! He really knows his stuff and makes it pretty easy to navigate Aristotle, who seems pretty impossible most of the time. Go to all the lectures - you learn the most from Morrison and his office hours are also super helpful! You won't regret a fantastic intro class to Aristotle.

The lectures and precepts are very good, and the assignments are thought-provoking and fair, although the grading curve is tough! Lectures and precepts are very engaging. The philosophy in this class is quite technical though, and less practical.
This class will make you a better person.
This class will teach you to read and interpret classical texts, and an introduction to Aristotlean philosophy.

This course actually has some practical value in terms of what it teaches you about ethics and happiness. The first half  of the semester isn't that exciting but the second one is quit the opposite. It's an easy EC. I was going to pdf it, but ended up taking it for a grade.
This course provides a strong interpretation of particularly relevant sections of Categories, Prior Analytics, Physics, and Nicomachean Ethics.
This is a great class! Aristotle is amazing, especially his Ethics. It's not too much work at all and is completely OK for a non-philosophy major, too.

This is a nice course. You'll learn Aristotle the right way, which often requires moving through texts slowly. I wouldn't say you read Aristotle, but you learn Aristotle, which is more important in my estimation. The course has assignments every two weeks or so, I think there are 6 in total. The curve on these are pretty tough though, sometimes 100-99 = A and 98-96 = A-, ... tough. But the real reason to take the course is Prof. Morrison. He'll teach you Aristotle, because he knows it pretty well.
This is an amazing course. Definitely take it if you're even remotely interested in the topic!
To just enjoy the readings and the lectures. Take this class to learn.
do the reading. take advantage of office hours, even just for interesting conversations with prof. morison & his staff.
none
take it - fantastic fantastic professor, and the material is very cool and will also probably change your world view
take it. very interesting lecture and if you pdf then the assignments won't be a hassle
descrip: We shall study Aristotle's contributions in logic, natural philosophy, metaphysics, and ethics, with emphasis on the ongoing philosophical interest of some of his central insights. We shall compare some of Aristotle's views with those of some of his successors, Hellenistic and beyond.

title: The Origins of the Middle Ages
reviews: Be sure to have a grip on Latin. German will also help.
I strongly recommend other students to take this course.
take the course!
descrip: This seminar explores the transition from the late ancient to the medieval world through the lens of law and legal practice from the late Roman to the Carolingian empire. We will look at how the different codifications built on earlier legal models and traditions but adopted and adapted them in their respective circumstances. We will explore these processes until the ninth century when the Carolingian rulers came to rule an Empire which comprised a variety of different Roman and post Roman legal traditions and laws and were confronted with the challenge to find new ways and strategies for their coexistence, compatibility and convergence.

title: Mathematics in Engineering II
reviews: Be prepared to figure out a lot on your own with the book; go to the precepts; if you have notes from Howard Stone's 305 they will definitely be beneficial.
Don't take it unless you need it.
Don't take it with Massoud.  I hear McAlpine is better.
Don't take unless required.

GO TO THE PRECEPTS IF MASSOUD IS TEACHING IT THE LECTURES!!!  This class should be classified as soul crushing due to the insanely difficult exams, lack of preparation for exams, and general atmosphere of the class.

I would try to avoid taking this class with Masoud.  He is not a great lecturer as his explanations are either confusing or condescending and teaches directly from the book. If attendance wasn't taken I would suggest not going to lecture and just reading the textbook.  That way you won't have to hear him lecture about how you need to get better at doing algebra quickly because that is what will set you apart in the future.
If you are ok self-teaching, I think the course is fine. Otherwise, I'd take it with a different professor.

If you need a distribution requirement you could do worse, but you could do much better.  The exams were all over the place in terms of difficulty (the final was a disaster for everyone) and the pace of the class made no sense (spending too much time on easier concepts at the beginning).  Choose for yourself, but be prepared of high levels of algebra and uncertainty.

It's the easiest complex analysis class there is, so if you're physics you need to take it or MAT 330. But try and delay taking it if Massoud is still teaching. Seriously, his lectures are terrible and he takes attendance so you actually have to go.
Only take if Ryan is TAing and strong interest.

Stay caught up with the lectures. Read each section because it will take roughly10 to 20 minutes of your time. This will drastically reduce the time needed to complete problem sets as well as helping you understand the lectures.

Take it if you like theoretical math. It's a lot more mathy than 305. The first 10 weeks is complex analysis for people that haven't taken real analysis (like me) and the last two weeks are PDEs, but you just kind of review what you did in 305 with some small extensions.
Take it only if you really really want to.
Take this course but make sure to go to precept/ask Ryan for help if he's up for it/you need it.

The material is very interesting at times and rather irrelevant at others. Workload was manageable (except for one or two crazy psets). Prof. Masoud warmed up to the course throughout the semester, so the course should get more consistent and better organized in future years.
This is a decent course, but harder than 305.
With Professor Masoud the discrepancy between what was expected in HW and exams was huge for the last two exams. Just be prepared for that.
prereqs: MAE 305 or MAT 301.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to partial differential equations, covering PDEs of relevant interest in engineering and science problems. The material covered includes: (i) Complex analysis, including complex functions and series, (ii) Fourier series, integrals, and transforms, (iii) Solutions of partial differential equations, (iv) Conformal mapping and Potential theory, and (v) Applications of all the above. The material will be covered in three weekly lectures, plus one weekly AI session. Grades will be determined from weekly homework assignments, class/precept participation, the two midterm exams, and the final exam.

title: Digital Photography
reviews: I enjoyed this class coming in with no experience at all. It was more work than I expected but I think I learnt something.
I would just want them to know that they are going to need their own camera since that was not explained in the course information. I would also advise them to start their projects early.
Must take this class.
Prepare for a boring semester.
Prepare for the photography assignments to take a long time and require a fair amount of setup! Don't wait til the last minute!
Start taking photos early!
Take it! Michele is amazing and you will learn so much!
Take the class!
This course doesn't spend as much time teaching the technical sides of using a camera as it does working on photoshop and color correction.
Very easy class, no readings, fun to take pictures, but can be boring but its only once a week. Recommend
You get out of the class what you put in.
take it!
descrip: This studio course introduces students to aesthetic and theoretical implications of digital photography. Studio emphasis is on mastering digital equipment and techniques, managing print quality, and generally becoming familiar with all aspects of the digital workspace. Popular media, found photographs, and the "life" of digital images will also be investigated. Slide lectures, readings and class discussions of student work in critique format will augment visual skills with critical and conceptual understandings of contemporary photography.

title: Subcultures
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Childhood Psychopathology
reviews: Be prepared for one super long class per week
Definitely attend precept and read the textbook and precept readings.
Don't stress out about this class- go into it relaxed and prepared to enjoy it. You'll get the most out of it this way.
Don't take this course! You don't learn much. All material is basically repetition from PSY 207. There are plenty of other PSY courses that are more interesting.
I would recommend this class because I love the topic, but would recommend that it be split into lectures two-times-a-week or a smaller more seminar-style class.
I would recommend this class if you are interested in children's mental disorders and psychology in general.
I would recommend this class.
If you like children this course is definitely for you!
It's a cool course
It's a good bit of work towards the end of the semester, and group projects are always a hassle, but Prof. Hambrick is awesome- take it if he's teaching it.
Make sure to go to do the readings and go to precept.
N/A
Pretty dull. Only worth it if there are more trips to Eden.
Read the textbook to help follow along.
Take if you're interested in the subject/autism! Eden visit was very insightful too. The three hour seminar is a bit of a struggle, but the precept is great and you actually learn so much.
Take it if you are interested in the topic. 3 hour lectures are tough, but exams are very fair and manageable
There is some work here and the papers will not be a piece of cake, but this is a great course in which you will learn !
definitely take it!
interesting material
take it
prereqs: PSY 207 or PSY 254.
descrip: Examines major forms of childhood psychopathology, including autism and other life-span disorders. Issues such as childhood trauma, prevention, and continuity in the development of later adult disorders are also considered. Observations of and interactions with children with autism are also included in the course.

title: Turbulent Flow
reviews: Good class to take
Professor Smits is a great engaging lecturer for this class.
Read the notes
Take viscous flows.
Workload is reasonable and content is useful.
descrip: Physical and statistical descriptions of turbulence, and a critical review of phenomenological theories for turbulent flows. The course examines scales of motion; correlations and spectra; homogeneous turbulent flows; inhomogeneous shear flows; turbulent flows in pipes and channels; turbulent boundary layers; calculation methods for turbulent flows (Reynolds stress equations, LES, DNS); and current directions in turbulence research. This course is offered in alternate years.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
reviews: I would highly recommend this course with Professor Yu. It was fun, interesting, and not too hard.
Take it with a good group and this class is very manageable. Good application of economics concepts in the broader risk management spectrum.
prereqs: ECO 362 and ECO 465.
descrip: This course will teach students about financial risk management through the lens of the recent financial crisis. Topics covered will include market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk, and systemic risk. Students will draw on their background in economics, finance, probability theory and statistics. The class will be in seminar format and active participation in the discussion is encouraged.

title: Molecular Basis of Cancer
reviews: A couple things you should know: only grades are an oral presentation, final paper, and participation. Workload is mainly just reading primary literature every week (which you can get away without). Kang barely lectures at all (student presentations most weeks), so don't take it for him, take it for the topic and guest lecturers (who are awesome). If you pay attention even half the time and are remotely interested in cancer, you'll get something out of the course.

I would really recommend this class, especially if you are a pre-med student.  Who knows, maybe you will end up wanting to go into oncology.  This class was really fascinating.  While the readings were a little difficult, Professor Kang is very approachable and willing to help.  Plus, the readings are really interesting and will inform you on the latest when it comes to cancer.  In addition, going to PMC to sit in on a cancer conference among doctors was a really great experience.  It's a really fun class and learning about the complexities of cancer was fascinating.
Read the lit thoroughly
Take it! You will learn a lot, but it's also very relaxed at the same time. Try to stay self-motivated to get the most out of this course.
Take it. You'll have fun, learn a lot, and become more proficient at reading and analyzing papers.

The class is almost entirely student-taught, with occasional guest lecturers by some very compelling speakers. Professor Kang advises how to give your lecture extremely well, and as such the course is still generally well taught, and most presentations will be very informative.
This course is almost completely self taught. I don't recommend it unless you already have a very strong command of molecular biology.
descrip: We will explore the molecular events leading to the onset and progression of human cancer. We will review the central genetic and biochemical elements that make up the cell cycle, followed by a survey of the signal transduction pathways and checkpoints that regulate it. We will discuss oncogenes, tumor suppressor and mutator genes that act in these pathways and review the role of viral oncogenes and their action on cells. We will investigate the role of cancer stem cells and the interaction between tumor and the host environment. We will explore specific clinical case studies in light of the molecular events underlying different cancers.

title: Human, Animal, Machine
descrip: This seminar examines the mechanical and animal heart of Renaissance humanism and the Renaissance "human." From Leonardo da Vinci's mechanistic anatomies and Erasmus's animal dialogues to Ambroise Pare's prosthetics, Montaigne's cat, and Descartes's bete-machine doctrine, we explore the ways in which the emergent category of the human is constituted through (and haunted by) a relation to nonhuman worlds. Special attention is paid to the technologization of the body in print, from anatomy to typography. Readings in posthumanism, animal studies, and the philosophy of technology.

title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish
reviews: Ask the teacher what they want in the Tablero and Composicion before you go about writing them. Keep up with the homework activities.
Can be seen as a lot of work but very manageable as long as you keep up.
Def more chill than SPA103
Definitely take this with Lorena because she will push you just the right amount and you will have a good time during it.
Definitely try to get professor Olander!
Do the homework.

Don't take the course. The class is terrible and so is the department. I think that just goes for the whole department. I think another department would be best if you are trying to fufill the language requirment.
Engage in class dialogue as much as possible.
Francisco Villena-Garrido is the best if you can get him.
Fun class if you enjoy the language!
Go to office hours. Hopefully the administration improves this course in the future! It was just organized poorly.
I would say they should take it!
If you can get profesor camacho. She is the best spanish teacher here.
If you take this class, try and do it with Professor Vallejo.
If you're taking it, you probably have to. If you don't, keep in mind that 5 days a week (and a full week during reading period) is a lot.
It's hard, but helpful. Five classes a week is a lot.
It's more difficult than 103.
Just do all the assignments and speak often in class to hone your writing and speaking skills.
Just enjoy it and don't take it too seriously. You won't learn as much if you do.
Keep up with the work. But little studying is required for tests. Also multiple choice on the tests can kill you since the answers are real tricky.
Lorenas class is great
Make sure you do the work every week.
Make sure you know the conjugations and study outside of class.
Olander is so nice and so helpful, take SPA 103 with her if you can.
Practice spanish as much as possible.
Professor Olander is very fun and responsible, and 107 with her is a great experience.
Push through, it's rewarding in the end.
Really depends on who is in your class.
Review your spanish constantly for this class.

Stay on top of assignments each night and don't wait til the night before assignments are due. Keep an eye on the calendar because there are lots of little assignments that are easy to forget. Also, talk in class as much as you can!
Stay on top of the work and don't be afraid to ask questions! If you can take this course with Lorena, definitely do because she is awesome.
Stay on top of your homework and study the vocab and you will be fine. Participate in the class and it will make it much more fun.

TAKE IT WITH PALOMA I know you don't have a choice but try because she is great, also expect spanish 107 to be the most fun of all the required courses, it is known that everyone is only taking this as a requirement for the most part, and this is taken into account.
Take it (you probably have to). You'll learn a lot of Spanish if you put in the effort. Try to get Olander!
Take it because you have to.
Take it if you are interested.  It is very helpful for speaking
Take it if you have to feel a distribution requirement. If you want to be fluent in a language, I think there are better ways to approach it than a Princeton course.
Take it if you have to!
Take it if you liked 103!
Take it only if you have to
Take it with Francisco!!!!
Take it; this class is often fun and you'll learn a lot without an overwhelming workload.
Take this course - Lorena is a great professor and you will learn so much.
Take this course if you have to and get Francisco for your instructor!
Take this course to improve your Spanish!
Take this course with Paloma. She's incredible and she will really keep you interested in Spanish as a class.
There are fewer new grammar concepts to learn as opposed to other Spanish courses, but knowing how to use them properly is difficult.
This class emphasizes grammar a lot so be prepared to be frustrated as you try to get your grammar to improve to get a better grade.
This class is very effective in teaching you Spanish grammar. It's also fun, especially when you get to work on the project.
This course is intense. Be sure to organize your schedule accordingly, especially around the time of the project.

This is a class that needs to be taken for the language requirement, so obviously you have to do it. It is manageable and not too difficult. Despite being sometimes, get to know the people in your class and your professor and you will probably enjoy it for the most part.
Unless you really like Spanish or just need to meet a language requirement, I don't recommend the course. It's not a bad course, but you won't get much out of it.
Yes.
You have to anyway. It's good.
yes
prereqs: SPA 102 or 103 with a passing grade..
descrip: An intermediate/advanced language course that continues and reviews the introductory level Spanish, while further developing students' communication skills through communicative activities inside and outside of the classroom, as well as various types of materials, both audiovisual and written. Goal will be to improve the Spanish skills acquired in previous courses and students' abilities to develop and express more complex ideas in Spanish both orally and in writing. By the end of the course, students should have a command of the four basic language skills: listening comprehension, speaking, reading and writing.

title: Beginning Workshop in Musical Composition
reviews: Don't be afraid to get a little weird with your music. Juri likes that.

Fun and relaxing. Don't waste the class though - actually challenge yourself to compose outside of your comfort zone, don't just improvise what you're used to and then write that down. Juri tries to push you - let her!
If you want to become a composer, this is where you start.
If you want to compose but don't really know where to start, this is the course you want.
Unless you have a strong theory background, you'll spend more time than you anticipate on weekly compositions. It's a good class overall.
You learn in this class mainly by trial and error. You compose a piece each week and get feedback from the professor and other students. #create
prereqs: Ability to play musical instrument(s), ability to read musical notation, no composition background is necessary.
descrip: A continuous cycle of creation, discussion, and response based on the creative activity of the students. Students will be encouraged to explore varied styles and techniques (for example, notated composition, multimedia music, and improvisation) and to perform their own works.

title: Contact: The Archaeology of Interaction in the Ancient Mediterranean
descrip: See website

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Topics in Spanish Literature of the Golden Age - Women Writers of Spain and Latin America
reviews: Recommend
Surtz is fine ? probably a professor whose style/personality you'll either enjoy or vaguely dislike.

This is not one of the best Spanish courses that I have taken. Readings were often too long, but Professor Surtz is relaxed and nice, and you can still do well in this class even if you don't do a lot of the reading.
be prepared to do a LOT of reading, but the instructor is great and that itself will motivate you to keep up and participate
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission..
descrip: A study of fictional texts by Spanish, Latin American, and Latina writers from the Baroque to the present. We will explore the solutions such writers found to resist or overcome the constraints of a male-dominated society, as well as solutions that enabled them to deal with controversial issues and to challenge the status quo.

title: Living with Animals
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Selected Topics in Optics and Optical Electronics
reviews: Good introduction to spectroscopy, but requires lots of background reading to fully understand lectures.
I think this is a good course for students interested in this material, but I wouldn't recommend it to students who are not studying optics.
If you want to know spectroscopy and do experiment, this class will be the best choice.
descrip: Various aspects of laser spectroscopic sensing. Topics include physical principles of atomic and molecular spectroscopy, fundamentals of high resolution lasers spectroscopy, spectroscopic measurement techniques and instrumentation, laser sources and practical applications of spectroscopic sensing. Example applications of laser spectroscopy to chemical analysis and trace gas detection in fundamental science, industrial and environmental monitoring and medical diagnostics will be discussed.

title: Introductory Drawing
reviews: A lot of people come into the course with a prior history in art classes. On one hand, if you do have this history, it can be easy to ignore Kurt's suggestions. I would urge you to really be attentive to what he has to say. My figure drawing improved incredibly because of it.  On the other hand, some students are deterred by the general amount of talent that comes into the class.  Don't let this scare you! Kurt grades VERY fairly and definitely gets to know everyone so that he can look at each individual on their own scale.
Be open minded about how and what you draw, and ask for help if you want technical advice on drawing, or else you won't get it.

Care about it! Professor Carter is a fun, understanding guy who loves different interpretations of his prompts. Don't be afraid to do something "different", it's a relaxed environment where you definitely can.
Put the time in and get rewarded in the end!
Super Chill. Really fun.
Take it if you want to improve your drawing and learn to approach drawing figures differently.
Take it! Expect a few hours a week outside of class when there are assignments (there weren't every week)
Take it! It's a fun course, and Kurt's a wonderfully fair grader, so you don't have to worry about natural talent or etc. But be prepared to put thought and time into your art.
Take the class with Kurt if you want to learn how to draw. Not an easy A if you don't put time into the homework and work during studio. Definitely a rewarding class though.

Take this class if you are at all interested in art! Nathan Carter is an awesome free-spirited professor who promotes creativity. The class in general is a great way to relieve stress and make great art in the process.
Take this course with Nathan! It will be an escape from everything else where you can be creative and have fun.

Take this course! If anything, I would just say to be aware that many students in the class will have had a lot of prior experience in drawing, but don't be intimidated by that because your performance in the class has nothing to do with your past experience. It's all about your effort, hard work, and willingness to learn!

There are multiple professors teaching Introductory Drawing. If you want to learn how to draw/brush up technical skills, Nathan would not fit your needs. If you want to be creative and just have a lot of freedom, take the course with Nathan.

This class with Kurt is a rigorous introduction to figure drawing. (The class with Nathan is more about creativity and design.) Half the class will come in very good at this sort of thing, but there were beginners too. The first half of the class is drawing vegetables and objects. The second half of the class is drawing nude models. I really enjoyed this class! You should start the homeworks very early -- they're pretty time-consuming (copying 10-15 anatomy drawings) and if you don't, you'll end up drawing for three days straight with homework and the class. It's also easy to get a good grade with Kurt, since the extra credit drawings each add 1.5 points to your overall grade.
descrip: This course approaches drawing as a way of thinking and seeing. Students will be introduced to a range of drawing issues, as well as a variety of media, including charcoal, graphite, ink, oil stick, collage, string, wire and clay. Subject matter includes still life, the figure, landscape and architecture. Representation, abstraction and working from imagination will be explored. A structured independent project will be completed at the end of the term.

title: Senior Project
descrip: The senior project is a year-long independent study intended for students who choose to work in teams of two or more. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in the spring term when a double grade is awarded. Groups develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Groups develop a work plan and select an adviser and are assigned a second reader for their work. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Groups submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Computational Geophysics
prereqs: Courses in partial differential equations and multi-variable calculus; experience with a computer language and basic programming skills..
descrip: An introduction to weak numerical methods, in particular finite-element and spectral-element methods, used in computational geophysics. Basic surface & volume elements, representation of fields, quadrature, assembly, local versus global meshes, domain decomposition, time marching & stability, parallel implementation & message-passing, and load-balancing. In the context of parameter estimation and 'imaging', will explore data assimilation techniques and related adjoint methods. The course offers hands-on lab experience in meshing complicated surfaces & volumes as well as numerically solving partial differential equations relevant to geophysics

title: Mind, Body, and Bioethics in Japan and Beyond
reviews: Best class ever.
Do all the readings!

I'd hesitate to offer a rousing endorsement. I took this class because of its glowing reviews and interesting topics, but feel like it ended up falling short. Half the class ended up PDFing, seminars could be lethargic, slow, and forced at times, and the subject matter definitely did not stand up to the glitter of "mind, body, and bioethics," as a significant portion of the class focused on pregnancy, feminism, motherhood, and women's role - interesting and important topics, to be sure, but not what many - myself included - signed up for. Proceed at your own risk.
Not bad for an EM or if you are interested in the topic.
This course is worth taking.

Whether you are a science major or non-science major, this is a great class to think about health topics with an interdisciplinary bent. You start off the course with more anthropology, tackle core bioethical issues in the middle, and finish with mental health. Excellent readings and just the right amount of writing assignments
You get out of this course what you put in - if you want to know more spend time reading and reflecting in order to bring confusions and ethical dilemmas to class.
prereqs: One course in East Asian Studies or one course in cultural anthropology preferred..
descrip: The seminar will examine key concepts of the mind, the body, and the nature-culture distinction. We will study these issues in the context of Japanese beliefs about the good society, making connections between "lay culture," Japanese notions of social democracy, and "science culture." Topics include: diagnosis and care of the mentally ill, the politics of disability, notions of human life and death, responses to bio-technology, the management of human materials such as organs, cultural definitions of addiction and co-dependency, and the ethics of human enhancement.

title: Psychology of Face Perception
reviews: Great course to learn about a field of psychology in-depth. It's unlikely that most of the actual material will have much consequence in most students' educations, but I thought it was a great class for learning how to read and analyze research articles, discuss them in a scholarly setting, and present findings to a relatively unscientific audience.

Interesting course, manageable workload, great professor who makes the topic interesting and wants to see his students succeed. Would recommend to a psych major with some background in research methods.
It was a better fit than I expected. Reasonable workload and interesting material.

Professor Todorov is great, and the class is really interesting if you are interested in face perception! Has a lot of applications for politics, clinical psychology, developmental psychology, computer science, etc. Definitely was worth it. Pretty light assignment and exam schedule as well. We also took a few "field trips" to the MRI lab and the art museum, which were great.

Take this course if you have even a small interest for faces and first impressions. It starts pretty slow and goes over notions that you probably already have if you are a Psych/Neuro Major. The second part of the semester is when the course becomes truly interesting and detailed. Material is great. Workload is completely doable (40 pages a week) and you can easily be a part of the conversation even if you have not done every reading. Professor Todorov is always trying to engage with his students. Great stuff
prereqs: Students should have some background in cognitive psychology, cognitive-neuroscience, or equivalent background in related fields relevant to face perception..
descrip: This course will be an upper level seminar that will attempt to synthesize research from multiple disciplines on how faces are represented in cognitive, computational, and neural systems. The material covered will include work on the role played by face perception in social cognition. The methods used in the research to be discussed include cognitive-behavioral measures, functional brain imaging, electro- and magnetoencephalography, single cell recording, lesion studies, and computer vision. The reading will include review articles and research reports.

title: Chinese Martial Arts Classics: Fiction, Film, Fact
reviews: A bit more that expected work, but interesting subject. Go to everything and do the work.
A fun, interesting course! Would have been great to PDF
Do readings ahead of time and participate in precept.

Dowon Dan Kim should take this class.

this is a cool class
Great course to take for interest or for distribution requirement, heavily recommended!
Great course. Keulemans is a great lecturer.
Great to take if you like Chinese martial arts.  Funny movies and literature that are very famous and you may have watched already are presented in this class.

If you like Chinese culture or martial arts or a good time, you should take this class.  Chinese is not required (although I think a knowledge of Chinese helps you understand the material better).  And you get to watch Kung Fu Panda!
If you take this course, make sure you participate in precept. This seems to be the only thing you can really control when it comes to grading.
If you're looking for a class with interesting readings/movies take this course!
Keep up on the reading.
Pretty chill course. Not too much work with the biweekly papers. But don't except to know where you stand in the class till you actually receive your grade.
Start thinking early about the paper. Enjoy the films and participate in precept.
Take this class if you like chinese martial arts. A good distribution class in general.

The readings and movies are great. The class often lacks structure otherwise, in terms of lectures and assignments. I'm sure there's a lot to learn from Professor Keulemans, but as it stands, it is more of a "make of it what you will" kind of class. At the same time, Kung-Fu Panda and Bruce Lee for homework. Need I say more?

Very little work. (1) 500-word response every other week for precept. (1) 10-page essay for the final exam. Readings can be boring at times but you also get to watch movies. Not as great as I had hoped but still a decent elective.
descrip: This course provides an overview of Chinese martial arts fiction and film from earliest times to the present day. The focus will be on the close-reading of literary, art-historical, and cinematic texts, but will also include discussion of the significance of these works against their broader historical and social background. Topics to be discussed: the literary/cinematic pleasure of watching violence, the relationship between violence and the law, gender ambiguity and the woman warrior, the imperial and (trans)national order of martial arts cinema, and the moral and physical economy of vengeance.

title: Music in the Middle Ages
reviews: Go to lecture. Wegman will give you everything you need.
If you are interested in Medieval Music, this is a great course. Not too much work for most students.
Take it, it's not too hard and you will learn a lot about medieval times (not just the music).

This is a good class if you are interested in medieval music and its historical context. It's a bit heavy on the historical context, which I enjoyed, but everyone might not. Wegman's powerpoints are incredible and he makes the class visually very interesting with manuscripts, illuminations, maps, photos, etc.
This is a great course to take if you're interested in learning about Western musical heritage, enjoying well-prepared lectures, and not having an assignment to give in every week.
don't take this unless you have to or if your interest in medieval music can make you overlook spotty lectures.
prereqs: Ability to read musical notation.
descrip: This course is a survey of Western musical practices from the earliest notations to c.1400. Topics include Gregorian chant and the development of musical notation, the courtly love songs of troubadours and trouveres, polyphonic practices in 13th-century Paris, and the new genres which emerged in the later Middle Ages: motet, chanson, and mass. The focus throughout will be on the productive tension between sacred and secular and on examples of transformative musical borrowing.

title: Religion and Power in Grassroots Democracy
reviews: An incredibly unique experience that may be unlike any other class you could take at Princeton

Take the course! This is a fantastic introduction to community organizing and gives really good, interesting, and thought-provoking readings. Just be aware that Professor Stout (and Ernie if he teaches here again) are definitely biased toward IAF-style broad-based community organizing. That said, very well worth taking.
descrip: A critical examination of grassroots democratic movements and groups: What ills do they address? How do they acquire and exercise power? What ethical constraints apply to them? What organizational structures do they adopt? What roles does religion play in them? What do they imply for our conception of democracy?

title: African American Literature: Harlem Renaissance to Present
reviews: 10/10 would do it again.
Be sure to participate and get the most out of the course.

Fantastic literature and a wonderful professor to take you through it. You may not agree with everything he says, and he can get stubborn about his takes of the literature, but all the better to wrestle with.
Get ready to read A LOT!
Only take this course if you are HIGHLY interested in literary analysis. Do not take it to have a sense of what African American studies is like.

Read the texts closely and carefully. If you cannot finish a book, close read the passages that stick out to you anyway, and then look up a summary of the story before class. It's important to know the events of the story because the professor assumes that you will and will ask questions about them, but close reading will prepare you for all of the assignments and the exam.
Take the course, stay on top of the readings, and stay engaged in class.

The course is amazing, and Professor Nishikawa will blow your mind.  Seriously, everything he says is poetry.  However, the workload is a lot and the grading is not easy; if you take it, take it very seriously, and talk to the instructors outside of class for papers.

This class is fantastic. Prof. Nishikawa is friendly and welcoming in addition to being a great professor. The scope of readings is a wonderful insight into the progression of black arts in the US and is a very important complement to any study of American history.
descrip: A survey of twentieth- and twenty-first century African American literature, including the tradition's key aesthetic manifestoes. Special attention to how modern African American literature is periodized and why certain innovations in genre and style emerged when they did. Poetry, essays, novels, popular fiction, a stage production or two, and related visual texts.

title: Law, Social Policy, and African American Women
reviews: Definitely do at least some of the readings.
Take it. Ask anyone who has taken it and you'll understand why. Prof. Perry is easily one of the best professors I've ever had. Don't miss the chance to get to know and learn from her.
Take the course! It's great!
Take this course if you're looking for an interesting SA with little written work, but interesting readings and extensive discussion.
This is a good class. Be prepared to be probed and contribute to discussion. As brilliant as prof Perry is, she is a lot more interested in hearing from us than she is in just lecturing her thoughts
descrip: Journeying from enslavement and Jim Crow to the post-civil rights era, this course will learn how law and social policy have shaped, constrained, and been resisted by black women's experience and thought. Using a wide breadth of materials including legal scholarship, social science research, visual arts, and literature, we will also develop an understanding of how property, the body, and the structure and interpretation of domestic relations have been frameworks through which black female subjectivity in the United States was and is mediated.

title: Race, Racism and Politics in Twentieth-Century America
reviews: Be prepared to put in the necessary work, but its completely worth it.
Don't stress too much about the course. There is a lot to read, but it is very interesting, and it is ok if you don't finish all of it all the time.

Professor Kruse is one of the most well-respected member of the history faculty, and it is easy to see why after spending time with him in a seminar setting.  The books we read challenged every assumption about American history that I carried in, and our exploration of the role of racial prejudice in shaping our country's past and present has fundamentally and irreversibly altered my world view and my very identity.  I sincerely wish that every American had a chance to wrestle with the past as we did in this seminar.  A single-course synopsis of why the study of history as a discipline is so vital.
TAKE IT
Take it--Professor Kruse is great and knows a ton about this stuff.
Take it.  It's worth it.  It's better than whatever you might take instead.  Prof. Kruse is a fantastic, likeable, challenging professor and the subject material is so relevant.
Take this class, you won't regret it.

This is hands-down one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Professor Kruse is a great seminar leader and really knows how to facilitate a good discussion. The readings are thoughtful, provocative, at times jarring, and always interesting. This is definitely a course not to miss.
descrip: In this seminar, we will explore the relationship between race, racism and politics throughout twentieth-century America. Topics will include segregation; immigration and assimilation; the role of racial politics in World War II and the Cold War; the civil rights movement and white massive resistance; Black Power and the white backlash; and contemporary politics up to the election of Barack Obama.

title: Introduction to African-American Music
reviews: Great if you need a very easy class and are interested in African American music. Don't expect much valuable information from the class.
Interesting course, pretty easy.
It's an excellent course, I would suggest it to everyone.
Make sure you're consistent in attendance and Blackboard posts. Professor Bryan knows what she's talking about.
The classes can be kind of long when people don't participate, but you'll probably learn something so I'd take it
descrip: What is African-American music? Is it a set of genres, sound characteristics, or musical approaches? Is it based on who creates, or who receives the music? How has an African-American musical tradition undergone continual re-definition, and how might we understand these developments within historical context? This course will address these questions by studying African-American music from a variety of perspectives, drawing from historical and critical readings, and sound and visual media.

title: Public Leadership and Public Policy in the U.S.
reviews: Definitely take this class. The readings are interesting, the discussions in the seminar are engaging, and you get to watch movies and eat cookies every week!
Discussions and readings are both interesting, but don't have much to do with each other.
Do the readings and take good notes. Start papers early.
It's a good course

Overall, this course is one that people should take. You will look at events in an entirely new way, and the readings are amazing. Seminars are relaxed, Professor Scovronick always brings cookies and you always watch movies. Just be hopeful you have fellow students who engage with Professor Scovronick and the material!
Take it if you're interested in the material. Even if you'd like a good history lesson, it's a very great course.
Take it! Do the readings!  Talk to Scovronik before you write!
The course material is fascinating. Definitely keep up with readings and take notes each week. It will be helpful for the midterm and final.
make sure our see the professor for the midterm and final papers. he wants them to written in a very specific way, and if you don't give him what he wants, your grade will suffer.
descrip: This course will review key Presidential decisions on domestic and foreign policy developments such as the passage of civil rights legislation and the intervention in Iraq, and will consider the ethical, legal, and operational frameworks for effective, responsible public leadership. Students will review relevant literature from history, psychology and politics, discuss the central policy issues in each case, and evaluate the decision-making process in view of these frameworks.

title: Seminar in Roman Art - Hellenism at Rome
descrip: The seminar focuses on the myriad ways that Hellenic traditions manifest themselves as formative components of Roman art production. Special emphasis is placed on the problem of ?copies.?

title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar
prereqs: This course is open only to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing guidance on planning and completing the dissertation and on other aspects of becoming a professional scholar and teacher, such as mastering the craft of the journal article (conceiving, writing and submitting), writing effective syllabi for different kinds of courses, and turning the dissertation into a book (with visits by editors from leading presses). The seminar meets every two weeks and is required of all post-generals students in residence, who will have the opportunity to present and discuss their work in progress.

title: Decoding Dress
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Political Economy Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Seminar in Pedagogy
descrip: Required weekly seminar for all English Department PhD students teaching for the first time at Princeton and scheduled to precept during the Spring 2014-15 semester. Balancing pedagogical theory with practical tips and collaborative discussion, the seminar helps students meet the challenges of their first semester in the classroom while also preparing them to lead their own courses. Topics include: integrated course design (preparing lesson plans; leading discussions; lecturing; teaching writing; assessment and grading); writing recommendations; and managing students, faculty, and time.

title: Brazil: Mestizo Histories, Visions of the Present
reviews: I would recommend this class.
Pedro and Lilia are great professors- go to all the lectures
descrip: This course explores the imagination of Brazil. How has this vast country and its diverse people been represented in history, social sciences, literature and the arts? How have dominant representations come to matter socially and politically, and which counter-ideas followed suit? Drawing from classic and contemporary texts and imagery, this course considers Brazilian identity-making processes at the interface of myth, history and the present. We will address issues such as slavery and racism, ethnic diversity, inequality and social rights, new media and consumption, and the performance of the public and the private in a country in flux.

title: German Literature in the 17th Century - "Was ist barock?"
descrip: The concept of the "Baroque" emerges as the belated reaction to a change that took place with regard to the idea of the Renaissance. The seminar will thus start with the questions of defining epoch and style. As the Baroque is one of the first transcultural phenomena, we will add to our readings of German Baroque those of Shakespeare and Calderon. This broadly "cultural" character also means that the Baroque cannot be restricted to a narrowly textual phenomenon; the Baroque, rather, is multimedia in character. Hence, we will complement our readings of literature and philosophy with excursions into the fine arts and musical performance.

title: Between Renaissance and Revolution: Baroque Art in Europe
reviews: Fun course for those interested in art history (either as a major or as a general interest). Dr. Berger is also a great teacher, as she's both passionate and very helpful. Would recommend.

I would recommend this course if you're interested in the period or in art history in general. It's very manageable. Professor Berger is also one of the nicest people, and is very generous with her time, advice, and help should you ask for it.

It is a really interesting class. Papers are difficult to do very well on. Not an easy course. If you are bad at memorizing dates, then your grade will suffer greatly on exams as this is very important. The actual class is very interesting, but it is by no means an easy grade.

Take this course if you have any interest in art history, it is very interesting and I liked it a lot!  Only thing to beware of is you have to memorize A LOT of paintings for the midterm and final, but I've always found it to be manageable

This is a great survey of "Baroque" art. I learned a lot and Professor Berger is wonderful. One of my favorite parts of the course was going on the field trip to the Met because it provided an opportunity to talk to Professor Berger in a more casual setting and she has many really interesting things to say.
take it
descrip: This courses surveys the painting, sculpture, and architecture of 17th-century Europe. Lectures introduce important works in relation to developments in religion, politics, science, and culture throughout this period. The course addresses the artistic achievements of Caravaggio, Poussin, Bernini, Borromini, Rubens, Velazquez, and other major artists and architects. We will explore questions such as why Caravaggio's contemporaries referred to him as an "evil genius," and how Galileo's early artistic training proved to be integral to his scientific discoveries. We will examine artworks in Princeton, Philadelphia, and New York museums.

title: The Ethnographer's Craft
reviews: Challenge yourself to reflect on the assignments at hand and spend time on them even though you will receive little guidance from the professor. Allow it to be a course of self discovery rather than of guided learning.
I thought ANT 301 was really awesome. If you are curious about ANT as a major and are the kind of person who likes jumping into trying things, I would go for it!

If Rouse is teaching this course, DO NOT TAKE IT. She's a very interesting and cool scholar but not a good professor. Seriously, this course is poorly structured, grading seems arbitrary, and you will be wasting your time. If you are an anthro major who has to take it, godspeed and good luck.
It is required as an anthropology major but this course should probably be restructured or taught differently in the future.
Probably a little weird if you are not an anthropology major, but Rouse is always a great professor to take a class with.
Take this course but take it seriously
Take this course if you are interested in anthropology. If you are not, this course won't be so useful to you.
prereqs: ANT 301A and ANT 301B meet together. ANT 301A is open to all students who would like to have the opportunity to prepare for cross-cultural engagements or ethnographic human subjects research. Junior ANT majors will enroll in ANT 301B and choose a junior seminar section ("Lab" B01 or B02 of ANT 301B). Sophomores who plan to concentrate in Anthropology and also study abroad in the spring of their junior year should enroll in ANT 301A, as this required course is offered during the spring term only..
descrip: What are social and cultural facts? And how do we identify these facts using anthropological research methods? This field methods course is for students interested in learning how to work with complex and often contradictory qualitative data. Students will examine how biases and beliefs affect the questions we ask, the data we collect, and our interpretations. Key topics include objectivism, interpretation, reflexivity, participant-observation, translation, and comparison. In addition to reading ethnographies, this class will use ethnographic films as a lens through which to explore the extraordinary power and limits of qualitative research.

title: Energy for a Greenhouse-Constrained World
reviews: Although it's technically an upper-level MAE class, this might've been one of the easiest classes I've taken at Princeton. Even if someone has no bearings in anything quantitative, I would legitimately tell them to take this class if looking for something easy. Problem sets are every other week and require no more than 3 hours of time. Other than that, you don't have to do anything for the class (aka no reading) for the entire semester (except an easy midterm paper). And the final exam is probably one of the easiest exams you'll ever take here. You do have to go to class for attendance purposes, but if you pay just a bit of attention you'll be good to go. But all in all, you'll leave this class not really sure how much true knowledge you gained. Of course, you'll learn a bit about renewable energy technology...though a lot of it is intuitive in the first place.

If you can find a better course--or honestly commit to dedicated self-study--on the same topic, maybe do that instead. But if you're super interested in the topic, and want a relaxing class, it's fine.
Stay on top of the various week to week subject material because if not it is a lot to review at the end of the course.
Take if you are interested in climate issues. It gives a great introduction to things that should be considered.
Take it
The course covers a lot of material on sustainable energy. Workload is not too bad. Final is pretty easy. Overall, it's a good introduction to the energy industry!
This year was Professor Mikhailova's first year teaching this course. The lectures will cover most aspects of energy, but she personally will not. The workload was very light.
prereqs: Freshman physics and prior coursework in thermodynamics are required. Students from any department are welcome in the course. Graduate students are welcome..
descrip: Overview of technology challenges and opportunities for energy in the context of global warming. Physics of greenhouse warming, projected climate changes, and structure of US and global energy economy are reviewed. Majority of lectures emphasize understanding engineering and economics of low-carbon energy production systems, including solar, wind, nuclear fission, and capture/storage of fossil-fuel carbon. Energy storage and efficient energy use are also considered. Intersections of energy with economic development, international security, local environmental quality, and human behavior are also touched upon.

title: Elementary Chinese II
reviews: (for people who have absolutely no prior experience with Chinese) You get as much out of it as you put into it.
Be prepared to do a lot of work! Totally worth it in the end though, and you have so many resources available.

Finding a rhythm in taking the weekly quizzes and dictations, completing the homework, and studying the characters amidst the rest of your classes is difficult, but once you do, the class feels much more manageable.  Also, don't be discouraged by the difficulty of CHI 101.  By the time you get to CHI 102, the classes feel more relaxed and you become much more aware of just how much you've managed to pick up.

Honestly the workload isn't too bad, just like a 3 minute recording on wednesday nights and like 45-90 minutes of workbook work each week. Otherwise it's just about studying the characters and grammar.
I highly recommend taking Chinese. It is challenging but the teachers are wonderful and you learn so much in a given semester!
I think making flashcards really helped me in this course. I would recommend for anyone who decides to take this course to also go over the study guides which cover sentence structures.
If you love languages and want a challenge, don't hesitate to take the best taught course at Princeton!
