If you need a language requirement and you are ready for a challenge, I would take this course. If you are not fully committed to learning the language, though, I would not bother. This class will take a lot of your time, and it will require a lot of outside work to fully embrace Chinese language and culture. If you're planning to do business, I would suggest that you learn Mandarin.
If you really want to learn Chinese, this is great. If you're at all unsure, keep in mind the time required is much more than you would think.
If you want to take the class to learn Chinese, do it.  Keep practicing vocab, especially that from other lessons.
It's really hard. At the end, it's really amazing how much you learned. But it's really hard getting there.
Make sure to practice everyday, even if it is just for an hour. You need to practice as much as you can.
Not too much work, be prepared for the second half of the semester to be much worse since the tests are cumulative for the most part.

Princeton's Chinese classes are among the best-taught courses the University has to offer, and it's one of the best, if not the best Chinese program in the US. You will work a little harder than you would in Spanish or something, but it is not overly burdensome and is absolutely 100% worth it.
Take it.
Take it. It's not as horrible and hard as people say it is, and there aren't many courses where you will learn as much as you will in this class.
Take take take!! Plus if you've taken 101 you have to take this for credit anyway so it's not really a choice haha. But it doesn't matter cause the teachers are awesome and you learn so much Chinese.

Take this course (if you're interested in learning Chinese of course.) I am sure this must be the best Chinese department in the country. The learning methods are very effective, the department is extremely nice and helpful, and they are always working on improving their methods still.
The Chinese classes are great and I would recommend reading over the study guides multiple times to prepare for the exams.
This is intense. If you aren't committed, don't try it.
To anyone interested in Chinese, this is a class that will help you really learn it.
Work hard! Speak as much as possible! And do PiB if you can!
definitely take this course if you want to be able to speak Chinese. The classes are well-organized and fun. However, be prepared to spend some time with this class, but it will be worth it.
large time commitment, but very well taught
read the text and go through the vocabulary before class
take it if youre willing to put tthe effort in and actually have a genuine interest in the language.
take the course, study like hell, and youll be glad you did
this is a class you should take. Don't listen to what people say about Chinese being hard; just apply yourself and do the work and you will do well.
prereqs: CHI 101 or permission of the Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of Chinese 101. To develop basic competence in understanding, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese.

title: Intermediate Persian II
reviews: Definitely consider taking Intermediate Persian II with Professor Mahallati! It is a wonderful course in which you will improve greatly.
Definitely take this course! Persian is such an interesting/beautiful language and the teacher is one of the most effective and kindest teachers at Princeton!
Just take this class- Persian is beautiful and Amineh is beautiful and everything about this class will make your Princeton experience 10 times better.
Take this class, or for that matter take any class you can with Amineh. This class has been one of my best experiences at Princeton.

You've gotta take Persian. My favorite class at Princeton by far. A fascinating language and an incredible, kind professor who really engages students and helps us learn in an enjoyable way. Lots of exposure to culture (and cuisine!) too. Khanom Amineh is the greatest!
prereqs: PER 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: The emphasis is on reading modern and classical prose, and writing modern prose. Classes are conducted mostly in Persian. Advanced grammar drills and translation exercises.

title: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship - How to Launch an Internet Startup
reviews: Almost no work. Also didn't learn much.
DEFINITELY DEFINITELY TAKE IT or anything with joy marcus SHE IS AMAZING
Definitely take this if Joy teaches again.
EGR 495 tends to be a one-off course, so I highly doubt you'll get the chance to take it in its current "Creating Internet Startups" form anytime soon. However, if you can, you absolutely should.
Easy class and interesting
Fairly engaging class with a low workload and relaxed grading
Fun course
Great class. Not very hard, but still fun. Especially if you have a good group
Great if you're interested in learning how to build a startup without doing any coding
Have fun creating your project! Allow yourself to be creative, and use it towards a passion/goal you have. Be a good teammate as a lot of the class is about teamwork.
Highly recommend taking the class with Professor Marcus. Super cool. Brings in great guest lecturers as well. You'll learn about internet startups, and actually make one in class. Fun, too.
I didn't feel like I learned very much, but I'm also an entrepreneurship nut. If you've never taken any entrepreneurship courses, I think that this could be a really interesting class.
I would strongly recommend this course to people who are interested in entrepreneurship. The workload is low but the payoff is great.
Joy was great and super invested in her students - gauge the visiting professor in the first few classes and drop if he/she isn't wonderful.
Light workload, Professor Marcus is the nicest lady!
Take it if you are a senior, at all interested in tech, if it is ever offered again.
Take it if you have an interesting idea - didn't really learn much about VC and entrepreneurship
Take it, and put effort into it because you will find it extremely rewarding. Do not be afraid to approach Joy for help at any point!
Take it.
Take this class!! Super chill, Joy is great, and you won't regret it.
This class was awesome. If Joy is ever back to teach another course, take it!
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: This course will teach students how to be successful technology startup entrepreneurs. It will focus on Internet businesses. The advances in this industry have catalyzed the emergence of new business paradigms including social media and e-commerce platforms. This course will explain the ecosystem and provide the students with the basic tools necessary to start a business. Students will create a startup in teams and will be afforded the opportunity to pitch their startup to venture capitalists. The course will include guest lectures from the relevant industries (venture capital and startup technology companies).

title: Superhero Trials
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Political Philosophy
reviews: A great course in political philosophy, and one of the best courses I've taken for developing your critical thinking skills in the context of a precept/seminar.
DO NOT TAKE unless you have previous experience in philosophy
Don't take it.

If you're interested in these texts and willing to do the work, then I recommend you take the class. You'll get a lot out of it if you do the reading (though it is quite a bit of reading). If you don't do the reading then it's not worth taking. Overall, a great class that I really enjoyed.
Seminars are exhausting in the first place. A bad professor makes it worse.
Take this course with Professor Thakkar if you're interested in Plato and social ontology.
Thakkar is a very smart and challenging professor. You will learn a lot by taking a course with him, especially if you take advantage of his office hours to engage in the material with him.
descrip: What would the ideal society look like? How would we go about rationally justifying a given conception of the ideal society? And what role might such conceptions play in our day-to-day political lives? This seminar will address these questions via a close reading of three authors for whom they were central: Plato, Marx and Rawls. We will end by considering recent attempts to inherit each of those thinkers for the present, in both "ideal" and "critical" theory.

title: Topics in International Relations - The European Union and International Relations
descrip: This seminar explores the complexities, challenges, and achievements of the EU in international relations over the past decades. Discusses relations between EU and non-member states, great powers, international organizations, and lessons from leading this organization in a globalized interdependent system. How it copes with ethnic rivalries, terrorism, financial & nuclear crises, power interests, energy market, revolutions, conflict on its borders, environmental and health challenges. How has the EU reacted to the global crises, how will challenges shape the future of European integration?

title: Chemical Biology II
reviews: Fabulous course about the chemistry of biological machines. Take only if really well prepared. Papers are a must.
descrip: The course provides an in depth treatment of protein chemistry and natural products biosynthesis. Topics include; amino acid, peptide and protein chemistry; protein engineering; the logic and enzymology of natural product biosynthesis with a focus on non-ribosomal peptide synthesis and polyketide synthesis.

title: British Histories and Global Histories, c.1750-1950
reviews: Acquaint yourself with historical sources pertaining to British history.
I would recommend this class to those interested in colonialism, circulation and British history.
descrip: The aim of this course is to study the multiple histories of the United Kingdom and the British Empire in the broader context of global history. This is partly in recognition of the interconnectedness of British national and British imperial histories; but also acknowledges and explores the relationship between Britain's imperial history and Britain's global dominance, which held for much of the period this seminar covers. The weekly readings combine very recent with some well established texts; some knowledge of British history, the history of the British Empire and recent developments in global history will be helpful but not essential.

title: Topics in Science, Technology and Environmental Policy - Energy Policy and Energy Technologies
descrip: Energy is central to addressing major challenges of the 21st century. This course reviews and analyzes national and international energy policies and policy options in view of : (a) available and emerging technologies, (b) environmental challenges, (c) economic and political constraints. Students will encounter a variety of policy assessment methods and tools, and apply them in the context the following thematic clusters: fossil fuel resources ; energy efficiency ; distributed energy and renewables ; transportation and mobility ; nuclear energy ; R & D, subsidies and diffusion.

title: Soil Mechanics
reviews: Bring a coffee for the second half of this class if it stays a 3 hour lecture.
I doubt anyone would want to take this class.  If you have to take it for your major, try to take it with a friend so you have someone to make faces at when you're super bored and/or lost.

It's a very straightforward class. Follow the expectations and you should do fine. If you're ever experiencing difficulties, ask questions and go to office hours. The subject matter is a bit boring because soil is so heterogeneous that all the models are empirical.
There is a design project (lab or using software) in this class. I didn't know coming into the class but you are told of it on the first day.
descrip: General introduction to physical and engineering properties of soils. Soil classification and identification methods. Soil exploration, sampling, and in-situ testing techniques. Permeability and seepage. Soil consolidation and settlements. Shear strength. Lateral earth pressure. Bearing capacity. Slope stability.

title: A History of Disability as told by Personal Narratives
reviews: Bring back Gerry.  If she is still around, TAKE IT.
I would recommend doing the readings because it makes the course much more interesting.
If this course ever stays at Princeton, I give my highest level of recommendation.
Prof. Wurzburg has very strong and passionate views.  A good perspective if you are personally invested in disability rights, but a very specific perspective.
Should have taken the class!!

This was the best course I have ever taken at Princeton (I took it my final semester senior year) and I truly believe that everyone should be exposed to this material. If you are so lucky as to get the chance to take this with Gerry Wurzburg, do not hesitate!

Unfortunately I don't think this class will be offered again since Professor Wurzburg is a visiting instructor, but I recommend this course to all students as strongly as possible. If it is ever offered again, absolutely take this class.
descrip: This seminar will examine and compare definitive concepts and life experiences of disability derived from the personal narratives of men and women labeled autistic and because of limited speech presumed incompetent. We will explore how the narratives created by those once not heard bring a new voice to our understanding of how we define "ability" and our use of the term "disability." Through class seminars, readings and film screenings, students will explore little heard history of disability through first person narratives.

title: Microeconomics for Public Policy
reviews: Attend every lecture and precept and show up at office hours and you will be prepared.
Do your text book reading
Hard class - will require work.
I know a lot of people say take this class with Rosen and while I can't speak to that, Willig is a really good professor and the course is very manageable.
I would advise students to start the problem sets in advance and go to office hours.
If you are not good at economics, this course will be a nightmare.  Study in advance and do the problem sets.
If you're taking this class to fulfill your WWS requirement, definitely go to office hours.
Only take it if you absolutely have to. If you need a Woody Woo requirement, I heard that ECO 300 is much better and easier. This is overly challenging and complicated.
Only take it if you have to, but let?s be honest, why would you if you didn?t?  Not the worst econ class I?ve taken here, but also definitely not the best.
Recommend
Take if only for the departmental requirement.
Take it with Jacob as your preceptor!
Take this to fulfill the WWS econ requirement

The class is a fairly standard micro class I think; it requires some effort (office hours are particularly helpful) but is feasible. Jacob was a fantastic preceptor and Professor Willig was also helpful in lecture and office hours (and it's pretty funny how funny he thinks he is). It can be pretty mathy.

The lectures were not the most helpful and informative, but the preceptors were extremely helpful and instructive during precepts and office hours for both the course material and problem sets. The material was definitely challenging, but the evaluations (exams, problem sets) were quite fair. Problem sets can be difficult, but go to office hours!

This is a great course with Willig! Challenging, for sure, but really interesting and definitely worth taking. Jacob is the best preceptor in the world. Make sure you go to his office hours for help on the psets.
Took this course with Willig-- I hear it's a lot harder with Rosen. We didn't do all that much calculus, and the problem sets were very manageable.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ECO 100. This course is not open to students who have taken ECO 300 or ECO 310..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the use of microeconomics for the analysis of public policy. It develops the basic tools for normative assessment of policies, and details the operations and social advantages of competitive market mechanisms. It proceeds to focus on market failures -- where market outcomes do not fully serve the public interest -- and on policy measures that can ameliorate them. The course will analyze some of the basics of policies for government intervention in the categories of taxation and welfare programs, environmental protection, regulatory rules, public provision of services and information standards.

title: Black Women and Spiritual Narrative
reviews: Definitely take this if you want a classroom that feels a lot like a high-brow book club! Professor Best is a really great teacher and makes these seminars a lot of fun. You'll learn a lot about this type of writing, and read a bunch of gorgeous novels.
Do all of the readings, including the secondary and additional ones, and be ready to engage and discuss.
This class was very thought provoking! I strongly recommend it.

This was a great class. Reading list alone makes it worthwhile. It was also cool to have students present, and it was very discussion based, but sometimes I wish there had been more lecturing by the professor.
descrip: This course will analyze the narrative accounts of African American women since the nineteenth century. Working from the hypothesis that religious metaphor and symbolism have figured prominently in black women's writing (and writing about black women)across literary genres, we will explore the various ways black women have used their narratives not only to disclose the intimacies of their religious faith, but also to understand and to critique their social context. We will discuss the themes, institutions, and structures that have traditionally shaped black women's experiences, as well as the theologies black women have developed in response.

title: Mythmakers, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Sophomore Independent Work
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation and poster session during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office by Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a state of the art project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Isn't It Romantic? The Broadway Musical from Rodgers and Hammerstein to Sondheim
reviews: Absolutely take this course. Professor Wolf is the sweetest and most approachable professor. She wants to hear your interests and feedback and her number one priority is to make the class enjoyable and accessible for everyone, even folks with no theater background. If you're at all interested in musicals, gender/sexuality, identity, America/commercialism, or singing in the shower, you should take this course.
Everyone must take this course or a similar one with Prof. Wolf.

I would advise other students to set aside several hours each week to watch and rewatch the musical and to read through all of the assigned and suggested materials.  I made the mistake of taking this course along with heavy workloads in 4 other classes, and as a result sometimes felt that I was underprepared for discussions, having not had the time to let all of my thoughts about the show marinate.  If given the opportunity to take the class again, I would work really hard to make sure that I had enough time to analyze the materials fully before class.

Start the homework early in each week (plan time accordingly). Do the papers early in the course. Sign up for a group facilitation and interview that really interest you if possible. Get to know your classmates.
TAKE IT. BEST CLASS AT PRINCETON.

TAKE THIS CLASS. Favorite class I've taken here. Not a bad senior year class. Everybody who takes it is engaged and Professor Wolf makes you feel SO at home. The homework is fun to do, and the reading is really manageable. And it's just so fun! Definitely take this class!

TAKE. IT. NOW.
Even if you don't have any musical theater experience (like me), everyone is on the same playing field because no one really looks at shows with a critical eye for race, sex, and socioeconomic issues. If only I were not a senior -- I'd take every class that Professor Wolf offered!
Take
Take it, and put in the work. It's so worth it.
Take this course! Such a fun class.
Take this course!! It was so much fun and a great capstone to my Princeton experience.

Take this course.  If you have even a remote love of theater and musicals, you will cherish this course.  You won't even care about how much work you're doing or what grades you're getting.  This is a course that is the epitome of excellence.  Take it.

This is seriously the best and most engaging course I have taken at Princeton. I am not a humanities major in any way and got so much out of this class. If you just like musical theater this class will be amazing for you.
take it!
descrip: Song. Dance. Man. Woman. These are the basic components of the Broadway musical theatre. How have musical theatre artists, composers, lyricists, librettists, directors, choreographers, and designers worked with these building blocks to create this quintessentially American form of art and entertainment? Why are musicals structured by love and romance? This course will explore conventional and resistant performances of gender and sexuality in the Broadway musical since the 1940s.

title: Literature and Photography
reviews: Take this class! It is a hidden treasure at Princeton. Professor Cadava made each class a new amazing experience. All of the readings were fantastic and really interesting.
This is an amazing class.  It is completely necessary to do all of the readings, but don't expect to understand them upon first review.  The class itself will develop your understand of the material.
This isn't likely a course to take casually, but if it interests you at all, you will have a wonderful experience.
descrip: Since its advent in the 19th century, photography has been a privileged figure in literature's efforts to reflect upon its own modes of representation. This seminar will trace the history of the rapport between literature and photography by looking closely at a number of literary and theoretical texts that differently address questions central to both literature and photography: questions about the nature of representation, reproduction, memory and forgetting, history, images, perception, and knowledge.

title: Introduction to Italy Today
prereqs: ITA 107 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is designed to familiarize the student with major features of contemporary Italy and its culture. Its purpose is to develop the student's ability to communicate effectively in present-day Italy. The course emphasizes Italian social, political, and economic institutions, doing so through the analysis of cultural and social differences between Italians and Americans in such everyday concerns as money, work and leisure.

title: Theory and Methods of Comparative Literature: Critical and Literary Theory
reviews: Brodsky is a real force of nature, and huge fun to listen to. She makes highly complex literary theory easy to understand (though that does certain theorists no favors), and really forces you to think in ways you wouldn't normally have to. Readings swing wildly from mind-blowing to gut-bustingly wrong to tremendously useful to not even wrong on a dime, so be ready for that. Definitely keeps things fun though.

Claudia Brodsky is the smartest person I've met in my life. The issue is that sometimes all her knowledge is hard to translate for us listening to her lecture, but if you're interested in the subject matter you should absolutely take this course. I don't agree with other reviewers who've described her as a being a bit too cutting.
If you are serious about learning Critical Theory then yes, take it. The reading is complex and class does not elucidate as much as it layers on more material/questions.
If you want to have your standards for brilliance and complicated theory redefined, take the course. It's tough but rewarding sledding if you work hard at it.

Professor Brodsky is a genius, but this class is not for everyone. You really have to motivate yourself to read critically and thoroughly. It is one of the most challenging classes I took at Princeton for that reason: she expects so much of you and in order to really get the most out of the course you need to rise to that challenge.
The readings are great, but Professor Brodsky can be nearly incomprehensible. I would suggest waiting until someone else is teaching it.
You better like critical theory
descrip: A course in the foundational texts of contemporary critical theory. The relationships among literature, philosophy, aesthetics, and linguistics will be investigated as they come to the fore in the intellectual development of the following, among others: modern philology, New Criticism, hermeneutics, structuralism, speech act theory, Marxist and cultural criticism, historical-epistemological aesthetics, rhetorical criticism, and poststructuralism.

title: Stochastic Analysis Seminar
descrip: This seminar course will introduce the students to recent developments in stochastic analysis.

title: Topics in Social Stratification (Half-Term) - Critical and Feminist Theories
descrip: This reading-based mini-course taps a range of theoretical readings starting with the Frankfurt School and extending through feminist theories beginning with deBeauvoir and extending through discussions of post-modernism, post-structuralism, critical race theory and queer theories, among other theoretical issues and literatures.

title: Atmospheric Chemistry
reviews: Should take this if interested in atmospheric chemistry.
This is very good course for those who want to know more about atmospheric chemistry or are going to conduct  atmosphere chemistry related research.
Useful course--you will learn a lot!
Worth the time and efforts
descrip: Natural gas phase and heterogeneous chemistry in the troposphere and stratosphere, with a focus on elementary chemical kinetics; photolysis processes; oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen chemistry; transport of atmospheric trace species; tropospheric hydrocarbon chemistry and stratospheric halogen chemistry; stratospheric ozone destruction; local and regional air pollution, and chemistry-climate interactions are studied.

title: Greek Historians - Thucydides
prereqs: CLG 105 and CLG 108..
descrip: Intensive examination of Thucydides, with special emphasis on his philosophy of history, historical method, narrative strategies, and the question of his reliability as an historical source for the study of the Peloponnesian War.

title: Advanced Quantum Chemistry
descrip: Traditionally quantum mechanics is presented as the antipode to classical mechanics; as a result, no attempt at reconciliation is made. Two-part course: (1. The primary purpose is to present quantum and classical mechanics in a unified fashion by clarifying only essential differences; also, how quantum-mechanical methods can be applied to classical dynamics and how quantum phenomena have classical analogies; special emphasis on open quantum and classical system dynamics. (2. Aspects of the quantum dynamics of condensed systems; focus on selected topics including quantum relaxation processes and linear response theory.

title: Aircraft Design
reviews: Although this is better than Stengel's class (then again, that's not much to say, unfortunately), I feel like the course needs to be better structured. Aero track was a disappointment for me, and I honestly doubt it's work pursuing unless you are truly committed (which is not to say you like airplanes, you need to really want to DESIGN and deal with the messy dynamics of aircraft).

Good class, if you get a good group for the final project. The final project is A LOT of work so start early. Lectures arent that helpful towards the second half of the semester and basically become "ask the professor" sessions.
I enjoyed the course, the subject is just really cool. It takes a good amount of time around midterms and deans date, but other than that pretty chill.
If you are interested in designing an airplane (or even large scale systems in general), take this course. As any designer should, be prepared for a lot of self-guidance.

Looking back, I wish I had thought more about whether I really needed to do the Aerospace track as well as the Mechanical. I would have gladly swapped any other MAE class against this one, but I know I particularly much disliked this class.
If Martinelli is lecturing, try and really work with whoever is the preceptor, since they might be doing most of the grading/teaching. Really like the people on your group for the final assignment, and work on that early.
See Gigi for appointments! He can teach you some very good tips and nifty software for aircraft design.

Should be way more interesting than it is.  Gigi's not the most engaging lecturer and spent way too long talking about theoretical fluid dynamics.  This class would be better if there was an actual building/competition component.
Take this class only if you are very interested in aircraft design.
Take this class! Super interesting but it is a ton of work
You gotta love it.
this course is very open-ended. take it if you're really interested in aircraft design and you'll be self-motivated
prereqs: MAE 321 and MAE 331 and MAE 335..
descrip: This course discusses methods for the design of aircraft. Topics in aerodynamics, and structural design are emphasized in the context of a design project. Students will be required to complete a design project to fulfill the requirements of this class.

title: Information Technology and Public Policy
reviews: Attend lectures and form reading groups
Definitely take it.

Definitely take this course, even if (especially if) you are not familiar with COS. There is something to take from this course for every level of technological skill. Professor Felten is an amazing lecturer. Don't miss out on him.
Definitely take this for your science policy WWS course, especially if you are less interested in disease or environmental issues.
Easy COS departmental.

Expect this course to require a lot of reading, and to focus much more on the sociological aspects of technology than the technical aspects. That said, the course is interesting and is a good guide to a lot of current issues in information technology (particularly the internet), and the relevant research.
Go to lecture.
Great team of instructors, really informative about Internet technology and policy, especially for those with little knowledge in this area.
I would strongly recommend taking this course, especially if you have any interest in IT or tech-related matters.
If you are a Woodrow Wilson School student, you have to take this, and it isn't bad, but not terribly interesting either. (If you are not, don't bother with it.)
If you're COS, it's kinda frustrating to sit through basics.

It teaches you a lot both how the internet works and what the issues are. Great class to take for anyone who wants to understand what the tool, i.e. the internet, they are using so frequently is all about.
Not worth it. Take another WWS science policy course if possible, if not, it's not the end of the world.

Really interesting material. It will teach you a lot of things about the world that you didn't know previously. However, it is much more SOC oriented than COS. I'm a WWS major and would have preferred more technological explanations.
Stay on top of the readings.

Take it if you are interested at all in Internet issues.  Or take it if you need to fulfill some requirement.  It's a fair amount of work, but only a fair amount and is very straightforward so if you put in the time, you will do well.
Take it if you're interested!
Take it!
Take it. A good intro to major IT policy issues. Good COS departmental -- nice break from coding.
There is a considerable amount of readings, but they complement lectures very well and should indulge anyone's curiosity

This course was fantastic and one of the best I have taken at Princeton. As a COS major, I enjoyed both the policy perspective on information technology and the varied readings. DiMaggio and Felten were both excellent professors.
Very interesting class
Why aren't you taking it now?
easiest COS departmental there is, the professors are world class, and not too difficult.
hard. lots of reading. competitive classmates, but very interesting. Without felten, i'd consider not taking it unless i needed WWS credit. With Felten, Must take
my favorite class i have taken at princeton
prereqs: Students should have some background in either technology (computer science, engineering) or the social sciences (especially economics, politics, and sociology)..
descrip: New technologies have changed the way we communicate with each other and learn about our world. They have also raised public policy dilemmas in every area they touch: communications, regulation, privacy, national security, intellectual property and many others. This course is predicated on the belief that we can only productively address the social and policy dimensions of the Internet if we understand the technology behind the Internet; the social-science concepts and research that illuminate the likely effects of policy options; and tradeoffs among fundamental values that different policy options imply.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy Extensions: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Provides a thorough examination of statistical methods employed in public policy analysis, with a particular emphasis on regression methods which are frequently employed in research across the social sciences. This course emphasizes intuitive understanding of the central concepts, and develops in students the ability to choose and employ the appropriate tool for a particular research problem, and understand the limitations of the techniques. Prerequisite: 507b.

title: Christianity along the Silk Road
descrip: Syriac is a dialect of Aramaic very similar to the language spoken by Jesus in first-century Palestine. Aramaic-speaking Christians in the Near East soon adopted Syriac as their literary language; by the early fourteenth century, Syriac Christianity spread from the western Mediterranean to China. In this seminar we shall be exploring the origins of Syriac Christianity in the Near East and its spread along the Silk Road before 1500.

title: How to Write A Song
reviews: Beware aspiring artists, do not be fooled by Paul Muldoon's phony, self-indulgent charm. He does not truly respect students' opinions, or probably anyone's but his own. He is prone to outbursts of anger and picking favorite students, while harassing others covertly.

Definitely take this course if you are interested in improving in songwriting and getting to meet some really cool musicians on campus. Many of the people in this class can play instruments, write lyrics, and/or sing, so be aware that this course works best for someone who is flexible/multitalented. Also be prepared to cooperate in groups. Overall, a fantastic class - one I looked forward to every week.
Do it!

If you like writing songs, and want to write one every week, then take it.
If you are looking for actual instruction or feedback, this is not for you.

Personally, I hated this class, and I would recommend that you not take it. It's all group work, and doing that with something creative like writing a song is just excruciating, unproductive and ultimately the songs that get written are pretty awful. Just skip it. Even meeting Paul Simon wasn't worth it.
Take it to write songs with a great poet, but be prepared for a bumpy ride.
Take it! It's a lot of fun and pretty chill!
Take it, takes about 5-6 hours a week but it's worth it and you learn a lot about songwriting and make a lot of cool songs in the process.
Take this class! It was amazing.  We had Paul Simon and Matt Berniger come in as well.
Take this course if you like music!
Take this course if you love music and love writing - It's an amazing experience
This class is largely student driven. Take it to meet peers interested in songwriting and jamming.
This class is so fun, but be prepared to work. There is a pretty large out of class time commitment to come up with a full song every week - even when collaborating with a group.
This is a really cool course that will make you a better songwriter.
This was such a wonderful class!  Take it if you have some musical background, are not afraid to put yourself out there, and are interested in learning from the talent of your peers.
Try both writing lyrics and chords, even if you feel like you're better at one than the other. You can learn so much!
Would highly recommend no matter the skill in music,
prereqs: Some familiarity with writing and/or music composition/performance. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information. This course cannot be audited.
descrip: An introduction to the art of writing words for music, an art at the core of almost every literary tradition from Homer through Beowulf to W.B Yeats and beyond. Composers and writers will have the opportunity to work in small songwriting teams to respond to such emotionally charged themes as Contempt, Gratitude, Revenge, Desire, Disgust, Joyousness, Remorse, Loneliness, Despair and Defiance. Assignments are based on study of a range of works in the popular song tradition. There will be several class visits from distinguished singers/songwriters. The final exercise will be a public showcase of work from the semester.

title: Scientific Integrity in the Practice of Molecular Biology
reviews: Be prepared to participate.
I would advise a student to participate in every discussion.
I would suggest either printing the papers for the class or bringing a computer/tablet so you can refer to the documents during the class.
Read the papers before class and participate in the discussions
Required.
if you participate it's less boring
descrip: This course satisfies the mandate of the National Institutes of Health for training of molecular biologists in the ethical practice of science. The nature of -- and response to -- personal "misconduct" will be a principle focus. Through case studies and class discussion, we will examine the societal framework for the public support of basic biomedical research, the rights and responsibilities of students and mentors in the conduct of that research, and the significance of intellectual property. We will also review regulations concerning research with human subjects and animals.

title: Quantitative Analysis II
descrip: This course builds upon POL 571 and introduces students to applied regression analysis in cross-section settings. It begins with the basic principles of statistical inference, and then covers various statistical techniques including linear regression, instrumental variables, structural equation models, maximum likelihood estimation, and discrete choice models. The materials are taught at the level of Hayashi's Econometrics, and Freedman's Statistical Methods. Prerequisite: POL 502 (or permission of instructor) and POL 571.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: If you are interested in markets in general, take it!
Interesting, straightforward class.
It's hugely rewarding though it's little bit harder to get an A.
Take notes on the class discussions. He will expect you to write about these on your papers.
You can grab a good overview of the hedge fund and the Asian capital markets from the lectures and readings. Great course to take!
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course explicitly considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system and its implications, as well as the potential revival of Japanese capital markets.

title: Health Reform in the US: The Affordable Care Act's Origins, Impact and Implementation Challenges
reviews: Absolutely take this class! Professor Howard is fantastic, and she really cares about her students.
Best class I have taken at Princeton. Prof. Howard is incredibly engaging, knowledgable, and a great teacher. Definitely take this class if you can.
DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU ARE INTERESTED AT ALL IN HEALTH CARE
Definitely take this class! Be willing to really do the readings and participate in discussion.
If this is offered again and you're interested in learning more about healthcare in the US and the ACA, take this class

One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. I feel that I've learned a lot not just about health care on an academic level but also about how the real world works - something that you typically don't get in an average class. Professor Howard is also amazing, totally committed to helping students learn and challenge themselves with the current issues in US healthcare. Really solid course.

One of the most interesting and well-taught courses I've taken at Princeton. I truly feel like I have learned something after taking this class. I feel like a more educated person. I went in not knowing anything about health care, but now I can discuss anything related to the ACA. Perfect for premeds to learn about the health care system and for anyone interested in going into health care. Professor Howard is simply amazing. Awesome. Best there is. It's not too much work overall. Reasonable amount of readings each week and two papers. Great class.
Participate!

Students should take full advantage of Prof. Howard as an excellent resource in and out of class. Speaking up during class and engaging in the debates she sets up is the best way to disentangle the frayed concepts that interest the course.

TAKE IT. If you are at all interested in health policy, or if you are pre-med. This class will provide pre-meds more than enough to talk about during med school interviews (and they WILL ask about the ACA in interviews), and gives you a great survey of the problems of our nations health care system. Discussion is always interesting, readings are usually not super extensive, and assignments are actually fun to do.
TAKE THIS CLASS!! Professor Howard is absolutely amazing. You will learn so much and get to learn about health policy from someone who is so knowledgable and one of the best people in the field.
TAKE THIS CLASS.

Take it!! Everyone interested in going into medicine or health policy should know about the Affordable Care Act. Professor Howard is very engaging and makes the course accessible for students regardless of background in politics.
Take this course if whether you are interested in going into healthcare or not. It is an important issue for our time

Very good introduction to health care policy in the US--not incredibly time consuming reading/assignment wise. Was a good class for senior spring. Def take if you are interested in learning about the ACA in a classroom setting.
do it in a heartbeat
must take!!!
descrip: The Affordable Care Act, enacted by President Obama in 2010, is an unprecedented federal-state initiative, with provisions to expand health insurance coverage, control health care costs, and improve the health care delivery system. This course will focus on the history of health reform, as well as the implementation challenges since its enactment. We will examine the federal regulatory process, the role that states are playing in implementation, legal challenges to the statute, and Congressional oversight.

title: Foundational Concepts in Anthropology
reviews: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!
Diffidently an interesting course, but be prepared to do a lot of work for it
I would say to have fun!

If you think anthropology is hands on in an Indiana Jones sense, you are in for the rudest of awakenings!! Be warned! This is one of the most theoretical/philosophical classes I've been through here (and I took HUM). I'm still not sure what the final message of this class was, or if there even was a message. Things seemed pretty random, especially the second half of the semester where we essentially just talked about capitalism for a couple of weeks. I did not sign up for some Econ class! Overall, I was VERY confused by this class and do not know what to make of it.
Only take if very interested in anthropology and willing to read a lot and participate in lectures too
Take it! It makes you think about old concepts in new ways.
The lectures and ideas presented really make this an interesting course and not just a "distribution requirement."

The professor is only so-so; it seemed that a lot of what we were doing in class was finding ways to agree with his point of view rather than develop our own.
The only thing that made this class worth it were the precepts--definitely go, they are fun, interesting, and useful in synthesizing everything from the lectures.
This class is amazing--take it! You'll learn a lot about what it means to observe a culture and how to do it. It's a great intro for those with a genuine interest!

This class is really profound in that it changes or enhances your opinion about various topics, but there is a lot (I mean a lot) of group work and group projects. The instructors are nice and really respect students' opinions. It's a good class!
This class is suitable for a P/D/F.
don't take it... take another ANT course
dont take it unless you are interested in the topic and u are the major bc you basically have to do a lot of reading and attend every single lecture
descrip: An introduction to key anthropological concepts and their relevance to the comparative study of societies. Themes include the cultural embeddedness of gender and sexuality, the organization of social life and religion, the importance of language and symbols, evolution and human nature, economics and global capitalism, and the representation of cultural differences in relation to power and authority. The course considers the application of fundamental anthropological concepts in inquiry on contemporary social issues, such as the environment and technology.

title: Inorganic Chemistry: Reactions and Mechanisms
reviews: Do you like chemistry? Do you like it a lot?
I wish I could convince my past self not to take this course.

If you like structured learning, take 407. This was good too, but there's no source of good information if you miss something in lecture. Go to office hours and make sure to go over all the practice exams with prof. Schwartz!!!

If you took 407 and are an auditory learner, you might like this course.  Otherwise, you likely will have exceedingly difficult challenges because Schwartz does not write on the board a lot, there is no textbook, there are no answer keys for homeworks or exams, tutors are not available since it is upper level, the TA doesn't hold office hours, and Schwartz is too busy to meet with you for extra help.  Thus, if you do not pick up the auditory teachings of lecture, you might get a D, as chemistry majors have in this course.

It is extremely EXTREMELY helpful to take CHM 407 first. Make sure you understand as you're going through the course. Take very good notes on the handouts. Get a binder. 
IT IS EXTREMELY HELPFUL TO TAKE CHM 407 BEFORE.

Take 407 if you can. Unless the course is restructured, you end up not knowing how you're doing until the final and that can really bite you in the butt. But at the same time, learning about d-block reactions was really interesting. Take it at your own risk.
Take it, just know what you'll be in for. Take advantage of Professor Schwartz's office hours. He won't always answer your questions, but he's fun to talk to.
This is a rather advanced chemistry course that does cover some interesting topics that are not seen in CHM407. Overall I would recommend taking this class to complete your chemistry education.

Would not recommend this class unless a chemistry major, and then only hesitantly. I hear 407 is better organized. While the material is interesting and Schwartz is engaging, the lack of answer keys makes it hard to keep up and know how well you are doing.
descrip: Structure-reactivity correlations for inorganic complexes will be emphasized. Ligand substitution and electron transfer processes will be presented. The course will highlight applications of inorganic and organometallic chemistry to areas of current interest to both organic and inorganic chemists. These areas will include organic synthesis, "redox" reactions, catalysis, and materials. Prior completion of a full year of organic chemistry is required for enrollment.

title: Native American History
reviews: TAKE THIS COURSE! You will be challenged, but it will make you think critically about US history. So amazing, Professor Warren is the best!!
Take it. Take it. Take it. Come in being prepared to reevaluate your own assumptions and be very thoughtful and you'll get so much out of this course.
This course will change the way you see a lot of things. Do all the reading and do it well, as that will make your experience in the seminar very rewarding.
descrip: This course offers an overview of Native American history, from the first arrival of humans in North America until the Red Power Movement of the 1960s. It has two central goals: to emphasize the variety of Native American societies and cultures that existed and exist in North America, and to highlight the centrality of Native American history to North American history as a whole. Readings will cover topics including King Philip's War, Pocahontas and Powhatan, Sacagawea, Indian Removal, Wounded Knee, Termination, boarding schools, and the Occupation of Alcatraz.

title: Decision Modeling in Business Analytics
reviews: Definitely take this course. Second half the applications are really interesting, and recurring iterations of the class will get better and better.
Frustrating and unorganized class. AIs didn't know what was going on any more than the students.
I would take it. Mengdi Wang is a helpful professor.
If you like these topics take the class but be prepared for some bumps and having to figure things out/ struggle a bit on your own. Not super challenging but requires some self discipline
It's very new and rough around the edges.  She's not the best lecturer or course planner.
Its a lot more technical/math-y than you would expect!
Not a lot of guidance because it's a new course, which is frustrating. Not a super time-consuming ORF departmental, but doesn't really delve into the material in an interesting way.

Please save yourself and avoid this class at all costs. Here is a list of reasons why: 

This course was a nightmare. There was no textbook. There were no precepts. They switched preceptors more than half of the way into the semester, and it was clear that the preceptors didn't really understand the material well enough to explain it either. In fact, the preceptors admitted that the lecture notes were incomplete and couldn't answer many of the questions we had. Many people's homeworks went missing several times, which was frustrating because they would just give you the average when that happened. They conjectured that someone was stealing homeworks so we had to submit our take home final which was due the last friday of class under a locked door. lolol. There were no office hours before the midterm after spring break. To add to this, it was a never before taught class with a new professor. This was a terrible class with a terrible professor. Please don't take it.
Take it but prefer for confusing problem sets
The class was meh when I took it (the first year it was offered), but it should get better as the lectures are hammered out/structure is improved.
This course has a lot of potential and covers interesting, relevant material. Hopefully logistic problems and unclear homework problems will be resolved next year. If so, take it.

This has the potential to be a good course, but is struggling getting off the ground. The topics are very interesting, but the course focuses too much on pricing, which can be dry. Professor Wang knows what she's talking about, but has some trouble conveying the mathematical models to the rest of us. If the course doesn't add precept, expect to spend a lot of time outside of class figuring out how to write the code for homework. Hopefully, your TAs will know what they're talking about and will have looked at the homework before office hours.
Very interesting topics - the execution will probably be better in coming years.

this course has high potential to be one of the easier, more interesting, applicable ORFE classes, but was a train wreck in execution this year. Check with the professor about their plan for the course before taking.
prereqs: ORF 245, ORF 307, ORF 309, or approval by instructor.
descrip: This is an introductory course to decision methods and modeling in business and operations management. The course will emphasize both mathematical decision-making techniques, as well as popular data-based decision models arising from real applications. Upon completion of this course students will have learned analytical tools for modeling and optimizing business decisions. From a practical perspective, this will be a first course that gives an overview of advanced operations research topics including revenue management, supply chain management, network management, and pricing.

title: Studies in Greco-Roman Religions - Ritual and Liturgy in Late Antiquity
descrip: How did people in Late Antiquity worship? What happened in a temple, synagogue, church or shrine? What at home? What did people say and do? How did ritual experts and laypeople act and interact? What practices surrounded birth, marriage, travel, illness, feasts and death? Who prays, sings hymns, reads scripture? What is our evidence for every day (and idealized) practices and where are the biases in the evidence? What changes in ritual and liturgy this period and why? We will examine a range of primary sources (literary, papyrological, archaeological), historical scholarship and theoretical writings.

title: Solid-State Devices
reviews: Enjoy the class its really well taught

I would recommend taking this course if you're interested in the nitty-gritty of devices.  I felt like every lecture taught me something new and rarely left me with lingering questions.  There did come a time at the end of the course where we had a problem set assigned and a deans date presentation to give, as well as a final coming up, but other than that the workload wasn't too bad.
Take only if interested in devices
prereqs: ELE 208 or equivalent..
descrip: The physics and technology of solid state devices. Review of electronic structure of semiconductors, energy bands, doping. Detailed analysis of p-n junctions, bipolar transistors and field effect transistors. Survey of a wide range of devices, including photodetectors, solar cells, light-emitting diodes and semiconductor lasers, tunnelling devices and single-electron transistors, power transistors, photoconductors, electro-optic devices, piezoelectric and micro-electromechancial devices, sensors for chemicals, and devices for magnetic and optical recording.

title: Political Theory
reviews: Be prepared to not be thoroughly interested.
Be sure to do the readings if you want to get the most out of lecture.
Consider taking it if you're interested at all in political theory.
Definitely take advantage of the assignments that are graded pass/fail - you still get great feedback!

Do all the readings, and make sure you know them before precept so you can talk about them critically in discussion. This kind of engagement will definitely help with the midterm and writing papers, since you'll already have been thinking critically about them and how their ideas interact. However, if you are doing the reading at this level, you don't really need to go to lecture, because they basically summarize it.
Do not neglect your readings for the sake of your peers in precept.  The paper is longer than you expect so start early or make an outline.
Go to lecture, since it's the best part of the course and the lectures are actually super interesting. You don't have to read in detail, but at least skim so you know the main ideas of the readings.

Great course if you are interested in learning about the social sciences (from the perspective of a math/COS major).  Lots of reading though; considering PDFing if your are taking the class for a distribution req.
Highly recommend
I hate everything. I loved this course. If I could marry it, I would. Take it, for the love of God and everything holy, take the course.
I really enjoyed this course! Some lectures may have low attendance, but it is really worth it if you are interested in learning about this field from great professors!

I recommend almost everyone remotely interested in politics to take this course. It is primarily focused on western political thought and I would really recommend that afterwards you perhaps somehow broaden your scope with some eastern political theory, but in general it's a really great survey class to take. It's not necessarily an easy A, particularly if you don't do at least 70% of the readings. I recommend that as a student, if you can't read all of the authors that you find one to sit down and deeply read so that you can write earnestly about one of them for the Dean Date's Paper.

I think you need to be really interested in everything to enjoy the course. Don't just take it if you think it might be interesting. You need to really want to read all of the various primary sources and be genuinely interested in political theory in all of its many forms.
I would recommend this course for individuals who enjoy analyzing philosophical arguments, and who are considering concentrating in politics
I would take it if you know you like the material
I would take this class if you are prepared to go into it 100% There are a great deal of readings, but not much written work so if you get behind you will be in trouble.

If Professor Lane is still teaching the course, take it!! Try to get through a little bit of every reading, but if you can't physically stomach more than 2-3 pages of it, don't worry - you don't need to do every reading by any means. Go to every lecture, though, and take lots of notes, because the professors do a great job of covering all the reading material. Take precept with John DiIulio!!
If you like theory then take it, if not take a different politics course.
If you want professors who really care about you developing as a critical thinker, take it
It didn't give an introduction to the broad topic of politics as I had hoped, but covered some interesting issues. I definitely learnt a lot.
It's a relatively basic introductory class, and the assignments aren't too difficult. The readings can get a bit dense, and I often ended up skimming the text without fully understanding it.
Keep up on the reading, it makes precepts easier to participate in and the final essay at the end of the semester easier to write.
Lane and Stilz are AWESOME
Lectures aren't very exciting but precept is good and the readings are historically important.

Lectures felt very skippable, especially post-midterm. Do as much of the readings as you can though?very interesting and really the core of the course. I'd probably take a different politics course first, but the readings are interesting.
Not a very difficult class as it is pretty straightforward. Go to precept, do the readings for the midterm and prepare well for the final paper.

Only take if pretty dry political writing is your forte. Could be more worthwhile if you are committed to doing all the readings. If you don't want to do the readings your grade won't really suffer but you probably won't get much out of the class.
Put in a lot of effort into the practice midterms so that you can receive accurate feedback.

Relatively simple course as long as you do the readings and attend lectures/precepts (They really help enrich the readings). Midterm can be tough because you don't get a lot of time to write stuff. If you're looking for an easy A, be careful...A lot of people try really hard in this course (seems like they are super interested in the material), which might skew the grades / make it more difficult grade-wise.
Stay on top of the readings. Actively engage with the lectures.
Take it if you need an EC and don't want to work too hard.
Take it if you want a basic understanding of political theory, but know that most of the lectures are history based, and not about the theories.
Take it only if you have to...
Take it!
Take it, but look at the syllabus before you do to get a feel for the readings.
Take it. Not too bad at all. Very manageable
Take only if you are interested in boring readings.
Take the course if you have a general interest in politics. At times it is a bit dry, but push through it.
Take this course to see what the politics department is like. There are a lot of readings, but if you attend lecture, they are not really needed.
Take this course. Especially if you get John Dilulio as a preceptor. Interesting material and a fair amount of work.
Take this for an EM or Politics course otherwise I wouldn't take it. You don't have to go to class or do the readings though so that's nice. You just get an arbitrary B .

The class can tend to be very boring so try to engage yourself by learning more about the thinkers or focusing on interesting points. Not everything in the readings is relevant: in fact, most of the readings end up being irrelevant. However, if you take it, you will know so much more about the general basis of the political way of thought.
The class is very interesting, great readings, interesting lectures, not that hard, take this class

The readings are wonderful in this course--works that every informed individual should read in their early career anyway. Professors Lane and Stilz provide interesting lecture material and teach you how to think about basic political theory questions, examine tensions and apply ideas to the present context of persisting questions of democratic practice, popular sovereignty, inequality, and virtuous governance.

This class is very easy, and the lectures were very boring and not necessary for learning the material. This was likely because it was the professors' first time teaching this class, so it might get better. Overall, political theory is just really frustrating because all the words like equality, justice, etc mean different things to different people. This class is more of history class, then, because you just chart political thought through history. It's an easy EM, I guess.

This is a very good class. I haven't taken any other politics classes at Princeton and wanted to expand beyond my engineering major. I'm glad to have done so with POL 210. There is a fair amount of reading, but you aren't responsible for all of it (even POL majors didn't do all of the reading). Assignments are easy to complete.
This is an interesting course that has a low work load. The second half of the year is a lot easier since the final is only one Dean's Date paper
Watch out for the readings. It's a lot.
When you are working through the readings try to find real life examples to help you visualize the concepts. I found that this trick helped a lot when working through Arendt.
do the readings as they are important for written work and exams
participate as much as possible in class discussion
prereqs: This course is open to first year students..
descrip: This course explores ideas of individual ethics and political community, the ethics of political rule, freedom and slavery, popular sovereignty and revolution, and equality and inequality in political thought. Readings will be drawn from both canonical and contemporary authors, including Sophocles, Machiavelli, Locke, Rousseau, and Tocqueville. This is an introductory course, which emphasizes both thematic and historical approaches to political theory.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: Bridges is the easiest stl you can probably find but the grading is at times unfair. There are a lot of structures to memorize.
Chill out, it's not bad at all. Pay attention in lecture to save time later.
Fun way to fulfil your STL, the lectures are helpful and instructors are great.
Get Alexis as your preceptor if he is still available.
Go to lecture. The slides don't have enough words on them to skip taking notes.
Go to lectures!
Great way to satisfy an STL requirement or learn about basic civil engineering.
I'd tell them to probably take it, especially if they don't mind PDF'ing

Interesting class, be prepared to do the readings and the problem sets. Work hard on the lab and also attend lectures.

It's great to have a science class that's a manageable workload for humanities (etc) majors. However, the homework for the class was poorly written and poorly explained to the point that the class was made more difficult than necessary just because of confusing instructions. So it's not all it's cracked to be! It's still manageable, but it's not the super-easy A it's made out to be - not because of difficult material, but because of confusion - so prepare to be frustrated.
Just because the class is an "easy STL" doesn't mean that it should be treated as one. It's just as easy to do poorly in the class as it is to do well
Lectures are actually really interesting and worthwhile. P-sets and labs are busy work and big time consumers. Still, undeniably an easy STL.
Only take it if you have to.
PDF if you want to get the STL out of the way.
Pretty easy class for people who are not into the sciences.

Professor Garlock is fantastic. This course is for sure the best STL a humanities student could pick. Don't be an a** who doesn't do any work and then moans about how you should have PDFed it. It's interesting material presented in an intuitive way. Really great!
Solid class. Professor Garlock is super nice and the material is interesting.
Study SS assignments intently in addition to lecture content.

Surprisingly fascinating material, at least in terms of the engineers and structural designs studied. Labs are abundantly fine. Put in the relatively little extra effort to get an A instead of PDFing it.
TAKE IT!
Take it
Take it if you don't mind handwavy physics but a fun class overall
Take it if you must.

Take this class if you need an STL, STN, or just for general interest. It's great!
Take this class!  You have to have some appreciation of science and building and art if you want to enjoy it at all, but if you are comfortable with basic algebra it'll be really fun and relaxed.
Take this course if you need an STL. It may not be as easy as it previously was though. Its overall very interesting and simple.
The course material is fairly interesting and it's a reasonably less-demanding way to fill the STL requirement.
This class is really fun, really manageable, and really educational. It's a perfect STL, provided you're somewhat interested in architecture. The lectures are amazing ? go to all of them!!!
This course is well suited for its purpose (a non-science people science class).
Very good STL to PDF. Highly recommended to fulfill a distribution requirement.
Yes
take it for an easy STL
take it if you need an stl
take the class if you are interested in learning about structures
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through laboratory experiments students study the scientific basis for structural performance and thereby connect external forms to the internal forces in the major works of structural engineers. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities in the U.S. and abroad.

title: Elementary Twi II
prereqs: TWI 101.
descrip: This course is a continuation of Twi 101 and continues to focus on the communicative approach to studying the language. It includes specific socio-cultural settings and events. Speaking, reading, writing and listening continue to form an integral part of the course and students will build on their grammatical skills. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Novice High and Intermediate Low.

title: Program and Policy Evaluation
prereqs: WWS 507B/507C or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.

title: Ethical and Scientific Issues in Environmental Policy
prereqs: Open to juniors and seniors only, by application. To apply, submit a one-page statement indicating why you want to take the class and what you believe you could contribute to it by April 16, 2012. Your statement should be a Word attachment to an email sent to either Professor Wilcove (dwilcove@princeton.edu) or Professor Singer (psinger@princeton.edu)..
descrip: This course will discuss policy issues relating to the environment, using several case studies to provide a deeper understanding of the science and values involved.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half Term) - The Development Challenge of HIV/AIDS
descrip: This seminar will review the origins of HIV, the multiple impacts of AIDS, the reasons for sustained global neglect, the foundations of effective prevention & treatment programs & the urgent need to improve monitoring & evaluation. Special attention will be given to the role of social factors in the epidemic. Course participants will examine the policy-making process related to global public goods & consider whether the world is better positioned to avert a resurgence of this pandemic or the emergence of the next threat.

title: Artificial Desires
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Portuguese II
reviews: Come to class prepared. Do MLL and read textbook chapters.
Great language, great department, take it.
prereqs: POR 101.
descrip: A continuation of POR 101. Students will continue to develop skills of oral/aural comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining further exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa. Students who successfully complete POR 102 will place into POR 109.

title: Directed Research
reviews: Find time to work each week and meet with the prof often.
must take. this course get you ready for your Ph.D. project
set up meetings with adviser so you can keep yourself on track through the course of the semester.
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: The Old English Period
reviews: Do you want to learn some Old English and gain an appreciation for some of the roots of modern English literature and the concerns and mindset of the Anglo-Saxon period? If you do, then this is the course for you. If you don't, taking this course is probably a bad idea.
Please take any course offered by this professor!
Prof Anderson is a great professor and super nice. Also, keep in mind this is an English course, not a linguistics course. The focus is very close readings of texts, not the language itself.
TAKE IT! And everything else you can find that even tangentially relates to Old English/the Anglo-Saxon period!
Take it if you want to learn about Old English.
You should absolutely take this course.  Don't take it and fuck around though, do the work and participate.
prereqs: No prior knowledge of the Old English language or of medieval literature or history is required or assumed..
descrip: An intensive introduction to the English language as spoken and written in the British Isles from about 500-1100 CE, leading to a survey of Old English poetry and prose. We will focus on the immediate manuscript context of selected Old English works while acquiring the grammar and lexicon to read them.

title: Topics in German Drama and Theater - Female Sacrifice and the Political Order
descrip: This class seeks to understand one of the most puzzling but consistent themes in European literature: the achievement of stability through the sacrificial death of a woman. While this theme persists across history--from Greek tragedy to Latin history and epic to modern drama--the underlying belief in the efficacy of violence performed upon the female body undergoes remarkable changes. We will discuss a variety of resources and traditions, including visual art, but place some emphasis on classical German tragedy. We will also consider theoretical texts by Aristotle, Barthes, Cavell, Girard, Loraux. All readings and discussion in English.

title: Technology and Society
reviews: Could be worthwhile

Didn't really feel like I learned much that was really compelling. Every week we pretty much just viewed topics through a few sociological frameworks, which sometimes felt unnecessarily pedantic and boring. A lot of it was just common sense given academic terminology. Sociology just wasn't my thing.
Do all the readings as they actually make concepts very clear
Do not take it.
Do the readings and go to lectures because they are so great. This class was literally NEVER boring!
Do the readings. Work hard on the final project.
Do the readings. You get more out of the class and understand the concepts better, than if you just only go to lectures.
Don't start the final project too late!
Excellent SA for technical and nontechnical majors alike. The assignments are fun and the lectures are great. 10 out of 10 highly recommend.

Foundational material for anyone in the social science or technology-related fields. The critiques of technology are eye-opening and essential to an engaged member of society. Dr. Vertesi is truly committed to her students and conducts engaging lectures. You can't go wrong with either Clark or Alex (if they are still precepting the course). Assignments are fun and fair.
Go to lectures. Dr. J is super fun to listen to. Work on your podcast early.
Great course for introduction to interesting topics - fair amount of work
I really liked this course. I would recommend it to people even if they aren't doing it for the certificate program.
I would highly recommend this course to any students, not just those interested in the T&S certificate, because the information is so relevant in today's society.
I would not take this course.  I felt like I was being singled out during precepts, and the grade I expect to receive does a poor job of measuring the amount of work I put into this class.

If you are considering the Technology and Society certificate, take this course by the end of your sophomore year. It's a good introduction to the certificate program and will help you decide whether you're interested in going further with the program. If you're just looking for an interesting SOC class, or you're an engineer who's curious to learn about tech from a different perspective, also strongly consider this class.
N/A
Only if you're interested in the certificate would i definitely recommend this course. If you're looking for a pretty easy class that's interesting sometimes, I'd also recommend.
Read the lecture slides.
Take it but make sure you understand the frameworks early or else PDF the class if you don't want to put time into the projects. Dr. J is very interesting and engaging.

Take it! Prof. Vertesi's lectures are fun, to the point and will make you think. The next time you read an article on the new iWatch or iPhone you will think about many more things than you previously did - in my opinion a great takeaway from a class. If you're a senior, get a study buddy to prep for the exams.
Take the course. Every aspect is awesome.
Take this class if you want to learn a lot of things, but not if you are interested in knowing more than wikipedia could tell you in 5 minutes
This class is super interesting and really makes you think! Not too much work weekly but lots at the end of the semester. Lectures are fun and engaging, precepts are meh. Would definitely recommend!

This course was simultaneously the easiest and the most frustrating of my four years at Princeton.  You can get an A on the midterm with one evening of studying by attending lecture and doing half (or less) of the readings.  If you PDF, you won't need to do any readings or homework except for weekly precept responses and the final project.  I believe the midterm was open-book.  The final certainly was.
*****
With that out of the way, why was the course frustrating?  Mostly, I felt like we weren't treated like adults.  In the 2nd or 3rd week of classes, the Professor announced that she would post recordings of every lecture on Blackboard, "so it's OK to miss lecture if you're sick".  The next day, I was feeling under-the-weather after staying up super late the night before to finish some work for my classes, so I slept through lecture.  Turns out the professor decided to follow up her promise of "it's OK to miss lecture" with a pop quiz.  These (open-note) quizzes would occur every week or two after that, and would consist of one or two VERY EASY questions on the course material, and two or three questions such as "what is your name" or "what is your favorite thing about spring".  Thus, they were used only as a tactic to force us to come to lecture, not to gauge understanding of course material.  I resented that we were forced to attend based on these quizzes, rather than being encouraged to attend by engaging lectures.
*****
I also felt that the readings were much longer and more dense than necessary.  Most of the 20-page readings felt like they could be summarized in 1 or 2 pages--and they often were on the lecture slides.  We had to write weekly precept responses, which were annoyingly time-consuming but as much based on personal opinion as on the readings.  Coming out of the course, I don't feel like I've learned much.
*****
