TL;DR:  Take the class if you want an easy PDF or A.  But expect to be forced to attend every lecture, and don't expect to enjoy the course.

This is definitely a sociology class, but there is a lot that engineers can take away from it. You have to be prepared to think about things in a new way, and there is a lot of reading, but otherwise it is a pretty easy and relatively interesting course.
descrip: Technology and society are unthinkable without each other - each provides the means and framework in which the other develops. To explore this dynamic, this course investigates a wide array of questions on the interaction between technology, society, politics, and economics, emphasizing the themes of innovation and maturation, systems and regulation, risk and failure, and ethics and expertise. Specific topics covered include nuclear power and waste, genetically-modified organisms, regulation of the internet, medical mistakes, intellectual property, the financial crisis of 2008, and the post-fossil-fuels economy.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Overcoming computational intractability in machine learning
reviews: Good
If you're interested in the cutting edge of bringing theoretical foundations to machine learning, this course would be the perfect one to take.
Take it if you plan to do research in the intersection of Theory and ML
This is an excellent course that discusses the theoretical insight of applied machine learning subjects.
prereqs: Prerequisites: Upper level course in theoretical CS, preferable algorithms. Undergrad level knowledge of machine learning/AI. Otherwise instructor's permission..
descrip: This seminar course focuses on myriad machine learning problems that are computationally intractable (NP-hard or worse). Often the standard approaches used in practice are heuristics with no provable bounds on running times or solution quality. Is this necessary? How can we develop an algorithmic theory in these settings with provable run times? This requires good modeling as well as algorithm design. We'll cover several recent successes along these lines, and also think about open problems.

title: Independent Work with Design
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principle difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principles of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work with design is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.

title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop
prereqs: REL 518.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics. Note: REL 518 (fall) and REL 519 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Macroeconomics/International Finance Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Intermediate Russian II
reviews: Do no expect this to be a continuation of first year Russian. This is good for people who want to read great Russian literature.
If interested in Russian language, this course is recommended.
Pettus may not be the most available professor, but it's a good course.
Practice practice practice speaking the language. Listen to Russian music when you study.

Russian is difficult but this class prepares you very well to learn the language. You will not be as proficient after finishing this course as you would be after finishing another language's intro courses, though.
Take it.
Try to get experience with speaking outside of class.
prereqs: RUS105 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Major emphasis on the development of vocabulary and oral expression with continued presentation and review of grammar. Vocabulary thematically organized to include such topics as travel, city life, nature, hobbies, politics, etc. Training of all language skills in a cultural context. Vocabulary reinforced through reading of cultural texts.

title: Studies in Forms of Poetry - Poetry, History and Memory
descrip: This seminar explores the intricate relations of poetry to history and memory in the troubled 20th century. Individual poets are closely studied for their intrinsic interest but also for their (known and still to be discovered) connections with each other. The poets are Eugenio Montale, Rene Char, Paul Celan, and Anne Carson, but other writers will also be called on from time to time. Questions of war and resistance are important, and above all the course attends to what one might think of as the fate of language under pressure.

title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared. BSE candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Effective Mathematical Communication
prereqs: For second-year graduate students..
descrip: This course is for second-year graduate students to help them develop their writing and speaking skills for communicating mathematics in a wide variety of settings, including teaching, grant applications, teaching statement, research statement, talks aimed at a general mathematical audience, and seminars, etc. In addition, responsible conduct in research (RCR) training is an integral part of this course.

title: Thermodynamics
reviews: Be sure to attend office hours and schedule meetings with Professor Aksay and the AIs as necessary. Reading the book prior to lecture is very helpful.
CBE 246 is hard but well taught. If you put in effort, get to know the professor and TA's, and keep up with the workload, it's one of the most rewarding here at Princton.
Despite the high level of instruction, don't take this class unless you're certain you wan't to major in CBE.
Do the reading. You don't want to, but just do it.
Go to office hours and form a study group!

Go to office hours early in the week! The TA's are really really helpful and without them you probably won't be able to do a large chunk of the psets (which are actually a decent portion of your grade). Only take it if you have to though, this is a lot of pure math and theory that does not come easily.
Go to office hours for help on P-Sets. Also, do as many example problems in the book as you can as well as previous exams.

Go to office hours to work with others on the problem sets. Don't wait too long to start them. Do as many practice problems as you can for the quizzes and exams. Only take this class for the departmental.
Go to office hours!
Go to office hours, watch MIT OCW
Go to office hours.
Go to office hours. Every week.

Go to the TA's office hours and save yourself the struggle of working through it on your own. Try to start problem sets early. Read the textbook before going to lecture so the lecture slides look familiar. Reread the textbook several times in preparation for exams; it will start to make a lot more sense the third or so time through. Work together with other people. Thermo's the real first hard CBE class but you should learn a lot.
Have to take for departmental. Go to AI office hours.

I don't know why you would take this course unless you're a CBE major, but in all honesty, it's not as bad as the rumors say it is. Of course it's one of the more difficult courses you'll take in your time here, but the professor provides you with lots of resources. Definitely go to office hours and get your pset done early. Stay on top of the readings and try to follow the book problems. Aksay really cares about his students, but unfortunately, he's not that engaging of a lecturer. Maybe go to his office hours if you need more help than the TAs can give you. It's a decent class and you really bond with your classmates through pset struggles.

I think this class gets bad reviews only because people don't want to put the time into this course. If you put the time and effort into this class, it can still be challenging at times, but also very rewarding.

I'm sure only CBE majors would take this course and you might have heard so many scary things about this class. It is hard, and it is meant to be. Nonetheless, please don't be intimidated: As long as you give it your best shot, I am sure you will make it through. Ask for help when you need it, and don't ever hesitate to do so! Professor Aksay and the AIs are very kind people. Don't procrastinate on the problem sets, I would strongly recommend you start at least two to three days before the due date. You'll be fine, so just take it!

If you don't need to take this class then don't. It is a very challenging subject that will take up a good portion of your time. That being said, Professor Aksay and the preceptors try their very best to make this course enjoyable for everyone. They are constantly available to help students.

Two suggestions I would have would be to first read the textbook before each lecture, otherwise the material will be confusing. Second, GO TO OFFICE HOURS! The p-sets are really hard, and office hours are a huge help, not just for the preceptors, but also so you can work with other students.
If you have any interest in energy, take it.

Interesting class. You will get used to spending time with your classmates. Everyone calls this the worst class in CBE, I didn't think it was that bad. The content sucks, but the class itself is just work intensive. You will not die from it! Don't worry.

It is not as scary as you think. I thought it was going to ridiculously hard, but in truth I had a really good semester and this class brought our cbe class closer. Go to office hours, the preceptors are really good teachers and very supportive. OH is the only way you will do well on homework. Aksay is super smart and a fun guy
Make sure to understand the concepts instead of just being able to complete problems.
Not an easy class but you will learn a lot. Go over the textbook a couple of times.
Only if you are CBE.
Only take if required; there are easier thermodynamics courses out there
Read and stay up!  Prepare well for the first exam!  It only gets harder as you go!  Go to office hours!
Read the textbook before class
Start going to office hours the first week and get used to that because that will be the only way to get the problem sets done.
Stay on top of the material, read the text book really thoroughly. Go to office hours!!!!

Take time to find out why the concepts matter. The class can be unfairly abstract, especially for "engineering", and it is on you to find out why you should care about the topics in class. The lectures, especially, will not show that to you. Make sure to make time in your schedule for the de-facto mandatory A.I. office hours (read: avoid other night class commitments!). These are the only atmospheres where you will actually learn how to do the problem sets. They cannot, repeat CANNOT, be done alone.

This is a challenging course, so plan on going to office hours for help with the problem sets. Form study groups for working through problems and studying, and read the textbook whenever possible.  Definitely doable looking back.
This is a difficult course, but it is doable with help from other students and TA's. Go to office hours often and start early.

This is a tough class, but it is definitely do-able - just be prepared to go to office hours/stay after precepts to work on problem sets. Work together, and help each other out. This is the class when the CBEs start becoming good friends because we just spend so much time together, so it's fun in that way. Plus, Prof. Aksay really cares about all of us (he brings us croissants before quiz days!), and the TA's are really cool as well.
This is not an easy course. Expect to spend time in office hours to get your psets done. Can't really avoid it as its a departmental and is actually interesting at times.
You probably only want to take this course if you're CBE, but if you have to take it, at least it's well-taught.
no, very hard and don't take unless CBE
prereqs: CBE 245 and MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The course focuses on basic principles governing the equilibrium behavior of macroscopic systems and their applications to materials and processes of interest in modern chemical engineering. In the first half of the course we introduce the fundamental concepts: energy conservation (First Law); temperature and entropy (Second Law); thermodynamic potentials; equilibrium and stability; and the molecular basis of thermodynamics. These ideas are then applied to problems such as calculating the equilibrium composition of coexisting phases and reacting mixtures or analyzing the thermodynamic efficiency of cooling and power generation cycles.

title: Normative Ethics - Ethics and the Future
descrip: A graduate seminar on recent work in normative ethics dealing with the future. Topics will include: (i) the ethics of risk and uncertainty; (ii) the moral status of future persons; (iii) 'predictive' vs 'deliberative' stances on our future actions.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Awesome course! I definitely recommend it!
Highly highly recommend this course. You'll get back what you give in, but it's an exciting and inspiring course
I think it's iffy if you take with a visiting prof. go for someone who is established in the department.
I would highly recommend this course, but you get out what you put in, so make sure to take the time each week to write something that you can be proud of.
Invest in your writing.
It's worth taking for Paul Muldoon alone. He is endlessly entertaining.
Meh
Professor Barnett is very helpful-- make critique into a conversation, don't just accept all of her comments.

Professor Muldoon is a fascinating guy and a terrible workshop leader.  If you take it with him, be warned that you may write poems that never get workshopped, or that receive minimal to no useful advice (of course this can depend greatly on the people in the class as well).  For one, he actively discourages written feedback, so if this is something you find helpful, take someone else.
Take advantage of one-on-one meetings, and let yourself be pushed-- you'll be happy you did.
Take it! Muldoon is amazing and will teach you what real poetry should be--none of that sappy tumblr stuff
Take it--what you put in is what you get out, but it's worth it.
The classes expanded my understanding of the realm of intellectual observation in regard to poetry. It was a unique experience.
There is no better way to get yourself to sit and write regularly. Set aside time to write for the class every week; otherwise you're wasting a fantastic opportunity.
Work steadily on your poems throughout the week to get the most out of them
You must take a class from Catherine Barnett.
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level poetry courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of poetry for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the places of literature among the liberal arts.

title: Rocks
reviews:
Background in petrology is extremely helpful and almost necessary if you want to do well.
The field trip was awesome and worth it.
Be prepared to work over 10 hours on some of the lab reports. If you have taken mineralogy you would be crazy not to take this.
Go into it knowing that lab reports are a lot of work, and that the material is challenging. But the class was great!

If you have any interest in rocks, you should take this class. You learn an incredible amount, and the professors/TAs are amazing! They're extremely approachable and knowledgeable. And, of course, the field trip was awesome. There is a fair amount of work, but I think that's the best way to get the most out of any class.
Read more of the textbook before doing the labs/problem sets.
Start the labs early and problem sets early! There is always more you can do and more considerations than you think there are going to be.  Don't wait until the last minute.

This was one of my favorite courses at Princeton. You can get so much out of this class, whether you're into geology or geochemistry, because so many different aspects of Earth are covered. And if you're lucky, Brenhin will make your brownies!

Very good foundational petrology course. Lots of work but professor and TAs are very accessible and you do learn a lot. The field trip is amazing but you have to be ready to make your semester mostly about this class.
prereqs: GEO 378 - Mineralogy.
descrip: This course serves as an introduction to the processes that govern the distribution of different rocks in the Earth. We learn to make observations from the microscopic to continental scale and relate these to theoretical and empirical thermodynamics. The goal is to understand the chemical, structural, and thermal influences on rock formation and how this in turn influences the plate tectonic evolution of our plant.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Neural networks: theory and applications
reviews: Great class to take if you want a deeper understanding of how neural networks work and how they're being applied.
It's a very interesting class, just the right amount of work.
It's an excellent course and you should take it if you are interested in machine learning.
Take it if you are interested in deep learning.
Teaches what it says. Be prepared for lecture itself, and be active about any questions.
ok course
take it, you'll learn a lot if you put the effort in.
prereqs: Familiarity with linear algebra, multivariate calculus, and probability theory. Knowledge of a programming language (MATLAB or Python recommended).
descrip: Organization of synaptic connectivity as the basis of neural computation and learning. Multi-layer perceptrons and convolutional networks. Dynamical theories of recurrent networks: amplifiers, attractors, and hybrid computation. Backpropagation and Hebbian learning. Models of perception, motor control, memory, and neural development.

title: Technology Studies (Half-Term)
descrip: This half-semester graduate course introduces you to basic concepts, theoretical frameworks, and empirical studies in the sociology of technology. The course draws largely on science and technology studies, a hybrid field with tools optimized for the study of science and technology in social context; it also draws related materials from recent literature in the sociology of work, technology and organizations, media studies, anthropology, and communication.

title: Topics in German Medieval Literature - Before Gender: Cross-Dressing and Sex in Medieval Romance
reviews: Do the readings, they are a lot of fun

Take it! Definitely one of my favorite foreign language courses at Princeton. First of all you get to read romance from the 12th century - how cool is that? Second of all, the course will make you think deeply about your own concepts of gender, sex, and love - things that we otherwise passively assume from our culture.
Take this course!! Professor Poor is amazing and this is a very interesting topic that I would have otherwise never thought about.

This course was fantastic! The material was so engaging, but the best part of the course would have had to been Prof Poor. She is an incredible professor that I would take anything from. She is so well versed and really makes sure that her students are able to have very lively and thought provoking conversations.
This was by far my favorite course! Professor Poor is wonderful, as are the readings! I highly recommend it!
descrip: A young Arthurian knight loses honor because he enjoys having sex with his wife. The Grail King is wounded near fatally in the genitals while trying to win the "wrong" woman. Young kings dress up and act like women in order to woo their prospective brides. This course will explore what it meant to be men and women in love (with each other or with God) in some of the most spectacular literary works of the German Middle Ages. The larger context for our discussion will be a more nuanced understanding of the history of sexuality. Readings and discussion primarily in modern German, some readings and discussion in English.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Reasoning about Networks
reviews: This course is definitely worth taking. The students will have a chance to read many interesting papers and participate in a lot of discussions.
descrip: This course surveys recent research in programming abstractions, verification and testing techniques for network programs.

title: Beginning Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian II
reviews: Definitely would recommend this class!!!!

Professor Beissinger is lovely and you will learn a language that few people know. Where else will you be able to learn BCS? It will be a small class with grad. students and everyonw is there to learn. If you have any interest, take it.
prereqs: BCS 101.
descrip: A continuation of BCS 101. This course continues to develop and refine the four language skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing), concentrating on conversational practice, advanced grammar points, oral drilling, increased reading (BCS literature, folklore, and expository prose, including works chosen according to students' interests), and viewing films.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Analytics and Systems of Big Data
reviews: A nice course to take.
Great course to take if you're interested in getting a better understanding of the design of modern systems.
If you are interested in "Big Data" it is interesting to take this course and see a different perspective of it. If you are interested in Computing Systems then you will enjoy it.
descrip: The goal of this seminar is to selectively read and discuss classical and recent publications related to big data. Example systems topics include MapReduce abstraction, key-value stores, globally distributed storage systems, systems for graphs and streams. Data analytics topics include feature extraction and learning, ontology construction, similarity measures, dimension reduction, summary data structures, streaming, locality sensitive hashing, clustering in high dimensional space and social network graphs.

title: American Literature: 1865-1930
reviews: A good option if you're looking for an overview of American Literature and need the departmental. Gleason is a great lecturer but be wary of the preceptor you get because it can make a huge difference in terms of your overall experience and grading.
Absolutely take this course whenever it's taught by Professor Gleason

Amazing class, highly recommend it, even as non-English major. I took the class because I wanted an interesting class without a ridiculous workload that would 1) teach me how to enjoy literature more and 2) expand the range of the books I've read. I loved every second of this class, although it would have been very challenging for someone with no real English background if I had taken this for a grade. Gleason was an amazing lecturer -- he really made the texts come alive, and showed me how much more enjoyable literature can be when you read it with an expert. I had always gotten the impression that academic English destroyed the aesthetic and leisure value of literature, but Gleason proved me wrong. The work was graded very strictly, which was good -- it made me realize that my snobby comments about English majors' easy grades were dead wrong. I'm really glad I took this P/D/F and would recommend doing so unless you have prior experience in English. Hadn't read most of the books, and they were awesome. I've been inspired to read more of these authors in my own time! I was fortunate enough to be in Gleason's precept. Gleason was the best preceptor I had in my four years at Princeton -- he kept the precept engaged, and if he ever went over time, I was as surprised as he was. He's just so incredibly interested in the subject, and genuinely cares about what we have to say. Every preceptor should take lessons from him.

As an English major, this seemed like a good option for the American foundation departmental... the real mistake there was just not taking a seminar. I would recommend this course to non-English majors with real interest in the period and learning the historical context of a lot of these works. Prof Gleason is great!
Definitely take it. Professor Gleason expects great work though, so definitely put effort in.
Don't slack on the readings.
Great course - interesting readings, easy to pdf.

Great reading list and entertaining, engaging professor, but I didn't feel like I could draw many conclusions from what was taught in lecture. There was a lot of emphasis on close-reading (felt more like a 200-level English class) and assignments were short, which was sometimes limiting.
Heavier reading load but great books and excellent lectures
I would not recommend this course.
If you need an American Foundation for English this is fine, but a seminar would probably be better. Take it if you're super into the reading list.
Interesting books and good lectures. Work hard on papers.
Not an incredible class, but a worthwhile one, led by a great professor (Bill Gleason).

Not really an English course -- more of a cultural history course. The amount of time actually spent critically engaging with the texts on the course is minimal for the amount of reading required. For English majors: there are probably other better American Foundations (though I know, not many). However, for an LA, probably a pretty good course to PDF.
Prof Gleason is wonderful! If you would look forward to reading a book a week and hearing amazing lectures on it do it!

Professor Gleason basically told the story of American history that you already know; I'd been hoping to learn a new one. His lectures are more historical than I'd hoped for. It was an eh class, but fulfills a distribution, so...
Read all the books! They're all worth the read, and you have to know them pretty well for the final exam anyway. Go to all the lectures if you can!

TAKE THIS CLASS! If you're interested, if you're not interested, if you love English, if you hate English, Professor Gleason is AMAZING and lectures are so engaging. You'll feel guilty skipping any because you just missed 50 minutes of fabulous material.

TAKE THIS COURSE. It might not seem like that interesting material or topic, but Professor Gleason makes it totally worth it. You will learn so much about American literature and history combined into one. The lectures are incredibly enjoyable, and the written work isn't too much. Very worth it, Professor Gleason is one of if not the best professor in the English department!
Take it and love it! Professor Gleason is the best.
Take it!
Take it! Work is back-heavy though, with a final paper, Dean's Date assignment, and final exam.
Take it!!!
Take it, but make sure you choose preceptors wisely.
Take it, the work load is not bad and the lectures are absolutely amazing
Take it.  It is a good class.
Take this class. You'll have fun, learn a lot, and be much better prepared for dinner table conversation. Gleason rocks!
Take this course if you're interested in American Lit. You may not be a fan of every single text, but there will be at least one book or short story that you'll enjoy.
The grading is harsh but the material and lectures are fantastic
This course was excellent. If you have any interest in the time period or in the books listed in the syllabus, take the course and go to lectures! You'll really enjoy it!

This is an amazing course to take. It's the only english course I have taken to date that has really taught me more than just what's on the page. Gleason really likes his students to know historical context of the literature which I think is key, so take it if you're into that.
do reading
i would take it
descrip: Perhaps no era in American history more closely resembles our own than the volatile period spanning the end of the Civil War to the start of the Great Depression--from the fluctuations of the economy to the struggle for civil rights, the danger of global conflict, the urgency of environmental activism and even the flourishing of celebrity culture. This course examines classic works of American literature in the context of the upheavals they reflected and shaped, tracing the rise of realism, naturalism, and modernism through four major literary-historical phases: Reconstruction, the Gilded Age, the Progressive Era, and the Roaring 20s.

title: Playwriting II: Intermediate Playwriting
prereqs: THR 205 and Program Director's permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen for more information at: tvasen@Princeton.edu.
descrip: A continuation of work begun in Introductory Playwriting, in this class, students will complete either one full-length play or two long one-acts (40-60 pages) to the end of gaining a firmer understanding of characterization, dialogue, structure, and the playwriting process. In addition to questions of craft, an emphasis will be placed on the formation of healthy creative habits and the sharpening of critical and analytical skills through reading and responding to work of both fellow students and contemporary playwrights of note.

title: Japanese Film and Media Studies: Dispossession, Documentary, and the Geopolitics of Image Media
descrip: This course examines the vivid perspectives of Japanese documentary media from 1945 to present as the focal point of our consideration of the geopolitics of image media. We will explore major documentary works that critically engage issues of cultural identity, environmental devastation, regional community, and historical memory to raise questions about the changing prospects and politics of image media. Our shifting focal points will capture key transformations in the archipelago's urban and media environments from the dynamic views of Japan's most influential writers, critics, and media practitioners.

title: Introductory Sculpture
reviews: I would totally take it. It's not easy, but it's totally worth it. You'll learn a lot.
Its not what you expect--you get to build structures out of wood and weld metals!! But, make sure you can come in outside of class.
Martha is a great teacher and will make you think about art in a different way. Take the class if you want to explore working with more materials.
Pam is wonderful. I felt very encouraged to do the work I was interested in doing while being pushed beyond my comfort zone. Anyone interested in sculpture would benefit greatly from this class.
Seriously take this if you have any interest at all in working with your hands. You won't regret it. If you can, choose to take the course with Pam.
Stay on top of work, go to office hours early. Spend more time thinking/planning outside of class so you are using time in class the best
Take it! Take it! Don't underestimate it either.
Take this class! There's a time commitment involved but it's a ton of fun and the people who take the class are great.

Take this course!!! The professor said it would take time outside of class but it really depends on how fast you work. Don't be too ambitious in your projects and this will be a really easy, painless, and super fun LA distribution.
Take this course, no matter who you are! It's not anything that you'd expect, but stick with it, and be prepared to spend a LOT of time working for this class.
There is a time commitment outside of class, but when you like what you're working on, it's not a hassle

This course is so cool! You have this amazing opportunity to express yourself through physical media and you get to work with some awesome tools and machines. If you like working with your hands and want to explore a bit, take this course.  You do have to put in some solid time though but it's definitely worth it!
TAKE IT.

Very easy LA class. You have to work hard on each project (have to show effort, passion, and desire to create an artistic piece).
However, aside ? 5h (1.30pm-4.20pm & 7.30pm-9.50pm)  of lectures [time you work on your project], for this class you may additionally need to spend a few more hours, if you did not finish you project, during the weekend. TAKE THIS CLASS! Do not P/D/F it.
You really need to put some time and effort into your project. You will love this course
descrip: A studio introduction to sculpture, particularly the study of form, concept, fabrication and the influence of a wide variety of materials and processes on sculpture and its consequences. Students will develop an understanding of contemporary sculpture and a basic facilities in woodworking, metalworking, carving and casting.

title: The Many Lives of Mao Zedong
descrip: See website

title: Dionysus
descrip: See website

title: The Medieval Period
reviews: Highly recommended.  Professor Smith is fantastic (very nice person, a tremendous teacher, extremely passionate about his subject).  The literature is fantastic.
Prof. Smith is a good dude. You get what you put in.
Read the texts and come to class with questions. the seminars are so long that there is an opportunity to direct the discussion to where you need it to be.
Take this course if you want to learn medieval English literature.
do not take, waste of a class slot
descrip: This course surveys the most important medieval literature of England (excluding Chaucer). Violence is a concern that links all of it, and we will see how this concern shapes its representations of war (of course), but also love, the sacred, song, and poetry. Readings will include many of the brilliant examples of different kinds of Middle English literature: chivalric romance, psychomachia, the chanson d'aventure, debate, lyric, and elegy.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Time Series Models
descrip: Concepts and methods of time series analysis and their applications to economics. Time series models to be studied include simultaneous stochastic equations, VAR, ARIMA, and state-space models. Methods to analyze trends, second-moment properties via the auto covariance function and the spectral density function, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing and of model selection will be presented. Kalman filter and applications as well as unit roots, cointegration, ARCH, and structural breaks models are also studied.

title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style
reviews: Don't take this class unless you have to. I took it because I thought I wanted to certificate in Spanish but this class didn't teach me anything; it's generally busywork.

Generally interesting and engaging class, take if you are interested in reading articles and short stories in Spanish and analyzing them. Be prepared to speak in class, as class size is very small so you will have to talk.

Good first 200-level course. My grammar and writing definitely improved, but not my speaking skills as much. If you're looking to write better in Spanish, this is a good class to take. I took it with Mariana, and she's great!
Great overall, but be prepared for some intense weeks interspersed with some (limited) chill weeks. Might take a lot more time than you expect.

If you have not taken Spanish yet at Princeton, this class is a great introduction to college-level Spanish, but if you took any of the intro-level classes, this course does not add very much. My writing and reading abilities improved, but if you primarily want to improve your speaking, don't take this class.
If you just want to keep your Spanish skills up, this course will be a lot more difficult than what you are expecting.

If you want to improve your language speaking abilities, don't take this class. Honestly, it is all grammar and a lot of random projects, which I hope they change. If you have Monserrat Bores, you are probably better off, because she is so nice and enthusiastic, but the class itself was kind of boring, especially compared to SPA 108, for example.
Keep up with the homework!  One week I skipped a reading but every conversation/writing assignment/grammar worksheet related back to it so I got further and further behind.

Overall if you have to take this course, take it. You're expected to have mastered grammar and to have extremely well written skills. Not so much oral skills, as Mariana was pretty lenient on that. If you want an interesting Spanish course, I'd suggest looking into the other 200 level courses.
Participating in class is very beneficial for advancement in speaking ability.
Read everything. Go to class. Study.
Stay on top of your work! It's not too stressful because everything is low-stakes (most everything is around 10% of your grade), but you still need to do constant, high-quality work
Take it but only if you have time to do busy work
Take it if you are interested in the language and in particular want more writing practice!
Take it if you really like Spanish! Mariana is great and the small class is really refreshing.
Take it with Monserrat! She is very organized, extremely helpful, relatable and fun. Course has steady and fairly demanding workload but is very enjoyable and you learn a ton.
Take it!

This is a great course to work on your writing. However, if you want to work on your speaking, it might be better to enroll in 209. Unfortunately, there wasn't too much discussion in class, but your writing will improve a lot. Also, try and get in Monserrat's section. She gives so much feedback and you really learn a lot.
take it
take it!
taught like an AP class
prereqs: SPA 107 or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed the Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score..
descrip: An advanced language course designed to increase students' fluency and accuracy in Spanish with an integrated approach to content: classes and assignments draw on various types of texts (literature, film, visual media) that focus on Madrid and Buenos Aires. Students hone their linguistic skills by engaging in discussions about the urban environment, and its cultural and artistic productions. The course aims to raise intercultural awareness and to explore the contexts in which cultural values and meanings are created. Reading and writing assignments cover different genres, and verbal interaction and personal production are actively encouraged.

title: Philosophy of Science
reviews: Again, I 100% recommend this course to any student. If there is any possibility whatsoever of getting into Prof. Halvorson's precept, get into it. I hear its great.

All science people should take this to know where their scientific paradigm comes from. All philosophy people should take it to seriously consider science and question its merits. Everyone else should take it because science is such an integral part of our society and we should seek to understand where it comes from, how to define our methodologies, and what it means to be scientific.
Definitely take this course.
Especially if you're a scientist, take it! Science is not as different from myth as we like to think...

I took this course as a scientist rather than a philosopher, and found that it had a good split between the two groups and catered to both rather well. The course is very accessible to those who are not philosophically inclined, and is a good way for scientists to evaluate their approach to research.
Lectures are SO worth your time. Get engaged and you'll love it.
Take a lower level philosophy course first or have a better understanding of how to write the papers going in.
Take this course if you are interested in the topic.  Prof Halvorson is a very personable and interesting professor, and he makes the material interesting.
Take this course! Prof. Halvorson is probably my favorite professor at Princeton. His lectures are clear and interesting.
would be an interesting EC for stem majors
descrip: We will look at some philosophical issues that come up in relation to science. e.g. What is a scientific theory, and what does it mean to believe that a scientific theory is true? How can we distinguish science from pseudoscience? Is science making progress in getting closer to the truth? If two distinct theories both explain all the phenomena, then how do we decide which one to believe? How far can we trust science to lead us to a complete understanding of the nature of reality? Are there sources of knowledge besides science; and, if so, how are we to integrate them with scientific knowledge?

title: Strategies of survival in Soviet literature: Struggle, adaptation and escapism from 1920 to 1980
descrip: The course focuses on both official and unofficial (unpublishable) Soviet literature, examining how writers came to terms with the dictates of the system. The readings range from direct social critiques to science fiction. The course is conducted entirely in Russian. Papers may be written in either English or Russian.

title: Introduction to Connectionist Models: Bridging between Brain and Mind
reviews: As someone with more expertise in math/COS, this course was a great introduction to neuroscience that focuses on how the brain works, not just which parts of the brain have which functions. Professor Norman is a great lecturer and the material is fascinating.
Be ready to work really hard and learn a lot.
Be sure to do the HW. Auditing is sort of pointless in this setting, because real knowledge only comes by doing the assignments and labs.
Go to lectures.
Good at first but gets confusing fast.  Independent project is very hard.

Really useful skills! Great for psych majors because you don't need a lot of math background but you'll still get a great exposure to computational modeling. Also get to do an independent project of your choosing, so that's fun.
Take it!
Take the course. Norman is a great lecturer and the topic is very interesting.

This courses introduces interesting concepts in cognitive neuroscience. However the work for the course can be very tedious, given the neural network software we used. Be prepared to deal with technical issues, asking for help right away. Also, in terms of grades, a lot of weight is put on the final project. 

This course doesn't really teach you how to design, build, and experiment with neural networks. It's more about how cognitive behaviors (e.g. working memory) might be implemented in a neural network. The neural network software we use also makes a lot of assumptions about how the brain works, so be aware that you are just working with models.

This is a very time consuming class, especially the second half of the semester. Only take it if you feel like you have room in your schedule. The project takes up a lot of time, especially when you have to work on the labs and homework on top of it. The software is a little bit temperamental, but more than anything, it's very intricate and complicated. I honestly don't think a semester is long enough to learn it if you REALLY want to learn it well.
do the CCN reading and come to class w/ at least 1 question- ken is great with questions and will engage with you as much as you decide to engage with him!
great course, prof. norman is awesome!
very good introduction to computational neuroscience
prereqs: Prior exposure to cognitive psychology and neuroscience is useful, as is some experience with computer programming. While the models we will be using are mathematically based, only algebra and some simple calculus-level concepts are required. The class will focus more on applying the modeling framework to psychological and neuroscientific data than on theoretical derivations. If you have questions about prerequisites, contact the professor by email. Interested freshmen and sophomores are encouraged to enroll, if they meet the criteria outlined above..
descrip: A fundamental goal of cognitive neuroscience is to understand how psychological functions such as attention, memory, language, and decision making arise from computations performed by assemblies of neurons in the brain. This course will provide an introduction to the use of connectionist models (also known as neural network or parallel distributed processing models) as a tool for exploring how psychological functions are implemented in the brain, and how they go awry in patients with brain damage. Two 90-minute lectures, one laboratory.

title: Research in Architecture
reviews: Recommend.
yes, definitely
descrip: This is a doctoral proseminar on the methodologies of architectural history based on a close reading of major historical and theoretical writings from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. As opposed to a linear survey of histories of architecture, the seminar examines the varying theoretical positions of architectural historians towards the uses and abuses of history as well as their individual grasping of historical time. Issues to be discussed include historicism, anachronism, revival, periodization, style, transition, quotation, fiction, prediction, prehistory, and post-histoire.

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science and Engineering
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering. Non-Credit. Enrollment by application..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars. To apply, visit http://www.princeton.edu/writing/wse

title: Experimental Physics
reviews: All the labs were very well supervised. The biggest problem that I've found was that there was a very disproportionate amount of time that you had to spend on each lab. Also, for some of the labs, it is almost clear that the lab TAs know that there are certain problems with the lab yet the lab is still assigned. So, before choosing labs it is a good idea to talk to people who have already taken the course and ask for advice.
Compared to years past, it seems like the labs are all working fairly well now. Lab reports can take a long time to complete, as they are fairly open-ended.

Fun class if you like experiment. Marlow is a great lecturer and has a good sense of humor. If you're looking for straightforward data collection, I recommend 21cm, Mossbauer, and Josephson, but not Spin Echo or Positron.
Hit or miss depending on which lab/grader for that lab you have.
It's a really well done course. It's a large time commitment, but the course is incredibly well-designed.
Professor Marlow is a great teacher! There are useful things to learn from this course no matter what kind of research you'll end up doing.

The workload for this course is very unbalanced, as labs are due every two weeks. Most students do minimal work until the weekend before the lab is due, and then work all weekend on it. Additionally, the time spent in lab and writing up labs varies wildly depending on the lab choice. All in all this is a significant time commitment, but I spent a lot less time on it overall compared to other physics courses.

This is a very specific departmental course, and I don't foresee people looking to take this course outside of the physics department, but if you find yourself interested in modern and iconic physics experiments, then this course would be good.
Well if you're a physics major, you don't have much choice, do you?
You need to take it anyway - pick you labs carefully, and don't procrastinate!
prereqs: PHY 103/104 or equivalent; PHY 208 or equivalent. Not recommended for sophomores..
descrip: Students work in small groups and perform four experiments and an electronics lab. The list of experiments to choose from includes muon decay, beta decay, optical pumping, Mossbauer effect, holography, positron annihilation, electron diffraction, single photon interference, NMR, the Josephson effect, and an observation of galactic hydrogen. Weekly lectures will provide an overview of various experimental techniques and data analysis.

title: Computer Architecture
reviews: Definitely take this course if you liked 375, or want to get a much better understanding of how modern processors work. The labs are a lot of work (especially labs 2 and 3), so start them early, like as soon as they come out.
Good.

I highly recommend to take this course if you want to realize that computer architecture is not a rocket science. However, you would need to be a bit familiar with basic topics, otherwise you will be to overloaded with new material.
I suggest this course to any student whose research area has a little overlap with computer architecture.
If you are interested in computer architecture. Take this class. It is the key course for this concentration.
If you like computer systems and arc, it's a must-take. Otherwise, don't kill yourself.
The class assumes good familiarity with Architecture and OS. Taking it without those requirements is very though and time consuming.
prereqs: Permission of Instructor or ELE 375 or (COS 375 or its equivalent). Seniors and graduate students may waive prerequisites with instructor's permission..
descrip: Modern computer processor architecture. I/O Architecture. Instruction-set architecture and high-performance processor organization including pipelining and data and instruction parallelism. Cache, memory, and storage architectures. Multiprocessors and multicore processors. Coherent caches. Interconnection and network infrastructures.

title: Theoretical Machine Learning
reviews: Absolutely take this course, if you find the material fascinating.
Good

If you're interested in theoretical machine learning, I highly recommend this course. It's worth noting that the course is somewhat math-heavy (a fairly strong command of linear algebra and probability would be best), so if you are interested in just applying machine learning to problems, I would recommend a different course. However, if you want to understand why these algorithms work in the first place, and discover how to develop your own novel algorithms, this course is for you.
It is worth taking for those who are interested in theoretical machine learning.
It's a great course if you're interested in the material (theoretical foundations of machine learning) and provides an excellent framework for thinking about various methods.
The course is majorly on online learning. This shows the trend in the learning theory community while it is not the topics I expected.
The course will be fairly theoretical and take it only if you like math
This is definitely a good class that is not too difficult.
To question if they have the background for the class as the other students seemed very well prepared
take it! it's great. you'll learn a good amount and get a great overview of OCO from one of the experts in the field.
descrip: This course introduces theoretical machine learning, including mathematical models of machine learning, and the design and rigorous analysis of learning algorithms. Likely topics include: intro to statistical learning theory and bounds on the number of random examples needed to learn; learning in adversarial settings and the on-line learning model; using convex optimization to model and solve learning problems; learning with partial observability; recommendation systems and matrix learning; how to boost the accuracy of a weak learning algorithm; universal portfolio selection; learning in games.

title: Seminar in Romance Linguistics and/or Literary Theory - The Literary Fantastic
descrip: A seminar on the fantastic in 19th- and 20th-century fiction and related theorectical texts. Issues to be discussed include the fantastic in relation to other genres, the cognitive challenges it poses, its major thematic preoccupations, the importance of reception, and critical approaches drawing on philosophy, pychoanalysis and literary theory.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Wise Guys: Readings in Biblical Wisdom Literature
reviews: A really interesting, fun course for those with background in bible/Biblical Hebrew - Professor Meshel is excellent. Be aware that the course may spend about half its time on a crash course to Biblical Hebrew depending on whether most students have previously taken a course here in Biblical Hebrew. If possible, ask Prof. Meshel if that will happen prior to enrolling just so you know what you're getting into.
Great course. Challenging at times, but in an intellectually stimulating way. Make sure you have a solid background in Hebrew and a general knowledge of the Torah before you take it.
If the topic is of interest, take this class.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! Prof. Meshel is great, the material is really interesting, and the class is not too difficult.

Take it! It's so great. Professor Meshel is awesome with him as the professor you'll learn even more than what the description of the course suggests. Probably more interesting if you have a decent knowledge of the Old Testament.
meshel is a bright guy but dont take this if u just want to have fun, because teachers of small classes cannot tolerate unengaged students. it hurts their self esteems.
prereqs: JDS 302 or permission of instructor..
descrip: We will read selected passages of Biblical Wisdom Literature (primarily from Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, and Job). Particular attention will be paid to techniques of generating ambiguity in Wisdom Literature. The course is open to students who have completed JDS 302, as well as students with intermediate/advanced Biblical Hebrew.

title: Statistics for Social Science
reviews: A very good option if WWS or just looking to get a stats background! Learned a lot, felt it was a well-taught course
Be prepared to teach yourself a lot of the material.
Definitely recommend over any of the other stats courses.
Do the work!
Don't take it unless you have to
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take it unless you have to. If you do, start early with Kahn academy videos and the textbook. That was the only way I could study.
Don't take it, find another stats class. It's not worth it.

Don't take this course unless you absolutely have to b/c one of the other sophomore stats classes conflicts with your schedule. If you do take it, don't go to lecture ever as all the material is on the slides. Most useless class I've taken at Princeton.
Even if you are trying to satisfy the WWS stats prerequisite, take POL stats or something else instead. Class is boring, but I guess it isn't too hard

Fine if you need it for a pre-req. Was initially very frustrated by the course, but it just takes some getting used to. Go to lecture, work hard on the problem sets and you will be able to understand the material
Go to McGraw and have a good study group for the psets and examination studying
Go to office hours if you can.
Good intro stats course. Probably the easiest out there.
I don't know how it compares to the other stats classes, but I would have preferred a deeper understanding of the math. The examples were very interesting though (to social science people).

If you are in this class, it's because you have to be. (Otherwise you should take a different stats class if possible because this is terribly taught). If you've taken AP Stats, the material is all review so you'll be fine (above the curve) despite the fact that Prof. Kolesar is terrible. If you haven't- find a study buddy who has.

If you are trying to learn more about statistics or have to take this class as a distribution requirement, you should take it. It is not a well taught course, so that is something to keep in mind. Utilize the text book, and go to McGraw.
If you get confused in precept, go to someone else's office hours.
If you have to take a stats course as a distribution requirement, this is one option.
If you have to take it, take it I guess. There are probably other, better stats classes out there.
If you have to take this for a requirement fine. Otherwise don't take it. At least not with professor Kolesar. It is boring.
If you need to take statistics, I guess go for it. If you just need a QR, there are more informative/fun options.

If you're in this class, you probably have to take it. Check out stats classes and decide which one is less painful. The professor for this one words things poorly, laughs when people ask questions, and puts up slides with formula mistakes all the time.

If you're not afraid of some math and some easy coding, and you're thinking of concentrating in WWS, take this class. Relatively easy and gives you a fine introduction to statistical methods that will be useful down the road.
It's a decent way to learn stats, and if you read the book you'll figure it out. But prof is going to be much help and (depending on your preceptor) neither will precept.
It's terribly frustrating and very hard to navigate if you do not understand math/stats. There's so much that the professor just flies through! This is all but fun!

Not the best class, but manageable if you USE YOUR PRECEPTOR to help you on psets. Seriously, see your preceptor once a week at office hours before psets are due to go over questions and write down what is being asked for. Exams were kind of difficult, but doing problems from the book and redoing pset problems will help a ton to make sure you are prepared.

Not the most exciting class at princeton. While a relatively dry class, it was rather straightforward as long as you put in time to understand the material on your own. Going to lecture alone and doing the problem sets just to be done with them doesn't prove to be effective with regards to the exams and doing well in the class.Overall, not a great class, not an awful class.
Only take if you need a WWS stats requirement
Only take this class if you absolutely must, and hope Kolesar is not teaching it.
Read the textbook, and get ahead on p sets.

Really utilize your preceptor as a resource for asking questions.  You could also try reading the textbook and looking over the lecture slides before class so you are more prepared for Prof. Kolesar's sort of stuttery lectures.
Solid course
Take POL 345 instead.
Take Rachel Baker's precept.
Take another stats course. This one was easy, but only because I had AP Stats experience. Didn't really learn anything new from the course.

Take it if you have to. If you work a bit, you'll get out a cursory understanding of coding in R and an introduction to statistics. Pretty easy if you did well in AP stats -- there's not too much material outside of that.
Take this course but be prepared to learn a lot of it on your own.

The 9 am time and the fact that a lot of other students are not strong in this subject means that there are less environmental factors pushing to succeed among taking 3-4 other classes. I would recommend taking an afternoon stats class.
This class was not well taught. I don't know if there's a better stats class though.
This stats course is not easy, but take this for the Woody Woo prereq over econ stats.

Unless this course undergoes a radical transformation, avoid it at all costs. Ideally, take POL stats in that fall. See Econ stats if you missed it. The material is too important to be in such a confusing course with inadequate support. Somebody please fix this.
Unless you have to take this course- don't. Out of my eight courses this year, this one has been the only I would not recommend to a peer.
it's a WWS requirement so you probably have to take it.  But if you've never taken stats before, and Kolesar is teaching the class, you will be very lost.  Read the book!
its a stats class. don't expect anything. its definitely one of the easier stats classes - don't let R turn you away because it's not hard.
kind of boring but really interesting
take ap stats first
descrip: The course will consist of a brief introduction to probability theory as well as various topics in statistics and how they can be used in the public policy realm. Subject areas will include random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, and introduction to the regression model. The data sources will be actual examples taken from the public policy realm. R, a general purpose statistical programming package will be used to perform the statistical analysis.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Institutions
reviews: Boring class, so don't take it for fun, but not overly difficult. Yuliy tries to make it as interesting as he can, so you probably want to take it with him.
Definitely take the class if you are interested in corporate finance (or are a sophomore preparing for interviews next fall)
Do master the concepts. Get Cheng Sun as a preceptor.
Don't take it. It's not very interesting and it's not very well taught. A poorly structured course. I would be impressed if you find yourself able to pay attention and stay engaged with the material.
Don't take this class unless you have to. You don't really learn all that much and its not compellingly taught.
Excellent class with fair grading. Find a good study partner! Work is super relevant to the real world and business topics in the end are incredibly interesting
Go to lecture, and make sure you understand the homework assignments.
I hated 362. Loved this course. Has a real-world emphasis which is great. Yuliy really cares about his students. Oh, and get Cheng as your preceptor - she grades super easy
I think you probably have to have an interest in corporate finance coming into the class to truly enjoy it. That said, if you do possess such interest, it is a very well taught course.
If you are interested in corporate finance, this course gives you a great introduction to the concepts. It is not very Maths-intensive, and the professor is very nice.
If you're interested in corporate finance, it's a good intro course.
It's a good course. Take it!
Not that much. Everything is pretty straight-forward.
Not the most interesting econ course but also not the worst econ course, do the work and you'll be fine
Obviously only take it if you are doing the finance certificate.
Only take it if you are really interested.
Pay attention to the case studies.
Since this is a certificate requirement, I'll only say that this course is pretty good, but you'll need to put some work into it.
Study for exams by working through past year's exams.
Take it if it's required, or if you want a course with low workload (if you understand economics well generally).
Take it if you are interested in finance or if you plan on doing the certificate program.
Take it if you need it, otherwise you might not want to put in the effort bc it is challenging
Take it if you want to learn about corporate finance. Otherwise you will get very bored.
Take it!
Take it! It might be tough sometimes and material is sometimes dry but overall I think it's worth it, and looking back on it I definitely learned a lot.
Take it. Good class, as long as Sannikov is teaching and it isn't some silly 3 hour 1 block lecture.
Take only if you're serious about the finance certificate!
Take this class with Yuliy. Hes a boss. You learn a lot about corporate finance, through a real-world lens. I would highly recommend.
Take this course !!! The material learned in this course is so important to real life, I've learned so many important things in corporate finance.

The course is a great, comprehensive introduction to Corporate Finance. For those interested in pursuing lucrative banking or consulting jobs after graduation, this is a must-take. Gives you a fantastic, broad foundation in valuation, DCF, and other topics in finance.

This class is great. It's pretty much a business school class, and you learn a lot of essential information about what companies are actually doing. Could easily just take this class instead of 362, if you don't need the certificate. Also the math is mainly just formula memorizing and is not too hard. Fun.
This course is useful if trying to enter consulting or finance fields after graduation.  If you are not planning on that, don't bother.
This course is very practical to people interested in business, finance, and economics. Prof. Sannikov is a fantastic lecturer, and the workload is manageable yet compelling.
Very practical
You really are only taking it if you have to so just take it and deal with it. Pretty much as boring and useless as 362, but manageable amount of work.
You should take this course when Professor Sannikov is teaching. He's a great guy and very nice.
Yuliy crushes his wardrobe. Going to class was like my daily copy of GQ. Also, the workings of corporate finance are pretty interesting.
Yuliy is awesome and a master at ballroom dancing. In terms of material, it is dry if you don't actually want to go into finance but also is pretty interesting to think about occasionally.

Yuliy was really dynamic and good. I hate all of my Economics classes at Princeton, and this is the one that I hated the least. Take this class if you are interested in corporate finance-- it will help you a lot if you decide to pursue corporate finance as a career.
better than eco362
n/a
take it after 362.
take it for the finance certificate. or don't.
take it if you need the finance certificate
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 362.
descrip: This course investigates the financing decisions of companies and financial institutions in the wider context of the workings of financial markets. Topics include capital budgeting, capital structure choice, risk management, liquidity, corporate governance, and the interactions between corporate finance and the workings of financial institutions and markets.

title: Elementary Persian II
reviews: Definitely take this class! It is fun and engaging and you learn a lot and you'll have the best teacher ever!
I recommend this course to any student looking for an amazing language course. The Persian language is beautiful and Professor Mahallati is amazing.

I would highly recommending Persian; it is easier than Hebrew and Arabic. This class does not require an inordinate amount of work, but doing a little work everyday will be the best way to learn Persian.

I would recommend taking this course! Amineh Khanom is very caring and motherly, but at the same time she is an excellent teacher who will help you learn this beautiful language. I really enjoyed this course--more so than many many other courses I have taken here at the university.

If you are considering taking Persian out of general interest, or if you need to, I definitely recommend this course. You will be pushed to learn the language: to speak, to write, to listen, and to comprehend. But you will get a general comfort level with the language out of it, which is a significant achievement coming out of a beginning language course. Amineh Khanom, the instructor, is so encouraging and helpful, and really adds to the course. It's a fun course, I actually looked forward to going to class everyday (even on Fridays), and I got a lot out of it. I strongly recommend it.

Take Elementary Persian II! It is a fantastic course and even if you aren't sure fi you'd like to continue with Persian after this course, it will expose you not just to the language itself but also Iranian culture, film, music, etc. It's challenging but also exceedingly fun.
Take this course!  Amineh Mahallati is a really enthusiastic professor and she will make you love Persian.
Take this course; Amineh is one of the best professors I have had here at Princeton.
prereqs: PER 101 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop the skills of understanding, speaking, reading and writing modern Persian. The classes are conducted mostly in Persian with emphasis on oral drills and conversations.

title: Chinese Art in the Century of Revolution
reviews: If you are considering taking this course, I would highly recommend it. There are plenty of trips to the Art Museum which are fascinating. There were some very well known artists who were guest speakers and discussed the art from a personal standpoint. Also, the class is very self-directed. Required homework is little and one can do as much or as little as he or she would like. The more you do, the more you get out of the course. This is a course which assumes that students are adults who have the motivation and desire to pursue their own interests. It is a special class.

Professor Silbergeld is incredible; this time period in Chinese history is incredible; and Chinese art (and East Asian art more generally) is ridiculously underrated and misunderstood. Worthwhile in many ways.

silbergeld knows all, this is a topic i was already super interested in, so i couldnt really go wrong, if you are at all interested in chinese art or politics or history HE is the man to learn from, also has great life perspective. jerome forever.
descrip: Chinese art in the 20th century, considered in terms of international influence and domestic struggles, cultural exhaustion and alternative modernities, state-dominated art and censorship, the Chinese cultural disapora, and the international success of Chinese art today.

title: Neuroscience of Social Cognition and Emotion
reviews: Awesome course. You learn about a cutting edge field and all the assignments really teach you to analyze scientific papers critically.
I was really looking forward to this class and I just feel like the material was interesting but the class was not engaging.
If you are interested social cognition and hearing about current fMRI studies on these topics from someone who thought a lot about it. Take this course.
Interesting but challenging course.

It's an interesting look at neuroscience. Something that you might not get otherwise in different neuro classes. Those with interests in social psychology or if just simply how brains may work together (sometimes literally), it's a cool class to take!
Make sure to grasp the nuances of the lessons. Engage in the readings because it really enhances the lectures. Ask Dr. Hasson and fellow classmates questions if necessary.
Take if you are very interested in the subject matter or need a neuro elective with not too much work.

Take this class if you're interested in the neural processes involved in social interactions, especially mirror neurons and theory of mind. A lot of the topics covered are really cool and Prof. Hasson is really nice! One thing I will say though is that this class isn't in the traditional seminar format; it may be listed like a seminar but it's essentially a lecture.

The final take-home is like the homeworks, except that it has a lot more parts and requires you to talk about papers from several weeks. Class had an unexpectedly developmental focus, which I enjoyed.
The professor is great and the layout of the class makes for a relaxed yet thorough learning of the topic.
There isn't much guidance from Prof. Hasson.  If you seek it out he will help, otherwise you are on your own.  Except for the presentation, he requires a meeting before presenting.

You get what you put into it. The material is interesting and Prof. Hasson gets you to see neuroscience from a new perspective, which is awesome. He really wants you to engage with the material, which can be intimidating sometimes, but is worth it.
prereqs: PSY 258.
descrip: This course explores the neural foundations of social cognition and social emotions. The objective is to provide a comprehensive overview of research topics relevant to the emerging field of social neuroscience. We will also discuss questions that cut across the specific topics that will be covered. Do neural systems exist that are specialized for social cognition or do the systems that participate in social cognition have more general cognitive functions? Can neuroscientific research shed new light on social cognition? How can different disciplines in neuroscience and the social sciences contribute to social neuroscience research?

title: Humanistic Perspectives on the Arts - Drawing and the Line in Literature and the Visual Arts
prereqs: Participation is by application only - students should address a letter to the instructors, stating why they would like to take the course..
descrip: This course will pursue some of the relations between perceiving, describing and knowing in the humanities and art practice. Studying the creation and meaning of the line in visual art, poetry, and a handful of philosophical texts, we will examine reversible processes of representation and abstraction as we also consider the mimetic and inventive powers of ekphrasis and art writing. The class uses primary works from the Princeton U. Museum for most of its visual examples and meets regularly in the Museum's study rooms. Students will complete the course requirements through both creative and analytical work.

title: Architecture's Empire
reviews: Great course! Be prepared for a large amount of work between the readings and the Atlas Entries.
Lucia is tough but it is totally worth it

One should expect a challenging course: course materials and discussions are likely unfamiliar and will result in effortful reading; "atlas entries" will demand the rapid research of and writing on (similarly) unfamiliar content; class discussions will likely expect the elevation of one's general knowledge or graduate-level interests to, for example, conversations on historiographic projects and methods.
Recommend.
Speak up often.
descrip: The course addresses the historical and geographic interconnections between the rise of modern architecture and the dissolution of the colonial system after 1919. That modernism and colonialism were implicated has become a well-known fact, yet architectural history remains centered around European and American metropoles. We take aim at this provincialism by testing one hypothesis: that modern architecture's place-making promise was a crucial part of its global success. The class combines architectural texts and case studies with readings from post-colonial theory in history, anthropology, history of science and technology, and media studies.

title: Ethical Dilemmas in a Global Society
reviews: Do the readings and enjoy debate.
Excellent class.
Fairly standard. Raises very interesting ethical questions that are worth thinking about. Not too much work, but definitely interesting.
Great class, seems like you should probably only take it if you've done philosophy before though

If chiara cordelli is teaching this, it is going to be a little uninspiring. The readings might make it worth it. Though, the readings can only be enjoyed if you like philosophy. This class is not about applied ethics, its about philosophy.

It is an interesting class, though more philosophical than political I'd say. It definitely helps to have taken a philosophy class or two because it is quite theoretical. The readings and the papers were interesting; demanding but not impossible.

Make sure you're very interested and skilled at learning/speaking in very abstract, theoretical terms. This class seemed to be a breeze for philosophy majors and more challenging for those of us in politics/economics.
descrip: This seminar introduces urgent moral questions in international affairs, with a particular focus on global poverty and inequality. Addressed questions will include: Why do inequalities between countries matter? What do affluent countries owe to poor countries? When should foreign aid begin and stop? Should there be equality of opportunity at the global level? In humanitarian emergencies, are we permitted to help our compatriots first? Do states have a right to exclude needy immigrants? Should developing countries be relieved of the burdens of mitigating climate change? Can NGOs legitimately represent the interests of the global poor?

title: Ethnography of Law
reviews: -work consistently throughout semester

Absolutely take it. Regardless of whether or not you (think you) have an interest in anthropology, ethnography, or law, you will soon learn that you ought to take interest. Prof. Greenhouse is truly exceptional. I would strongly recommend taking any seminar with her during your time at Princeton. Her mode of teaching is truly textual, not only on the basis of her close engagement with texts, but in her astounding ability to weave together and between law, poetry, and life. This goes not only for the content of her commentary, but the very form in which she chooses to express it.

Be prepared to be uncomfortable--that is, to get lost in ways of thinking about law and all its million threads to matters of economy, ethics, trade, state-making, etc. For those who are seeking a clear grasp of what the anthropological study of law can be, I would recommend it. For those who are interested in trade, international law, and labor migration, I would strongly trecommend it. For those who are more thirsty for more in-depth engagement with symbolic aspects of economy-making and legal institutions, I would recommend it with a bit of advice that he/she might have to tune up his/her own sensitivity toward those very symbolic aspects.
It's a long seminar, so pack a snack or prepare to go to a cafe during break to buy a snack. Altough tough, the length is a necessary.
Take it.

This class is definitely a bit more difficult than it might seem. The reading loads are a little heavier than most classes, especially because the content seems to be denser than most classes. However, the topic is very interesting, and the professor is very high quality, so I would recommend it if you're looking for a pleasurable challenge.
This is a great course-- highly recommended for Anthropology concentrators looking for a good 400-level course. Professor Greenhouse is brilliant and wonderfully warm!
descrip: Anthropology has a long tradition of research on law, rules and norms as social and cultural practices. Since ethnographic inquiry moves easily across jurisdictions and other sorts of domains, it is well adapted to the polycentric, "hybrid" (state/non-state) and asymmetrical power relations that pervade the social fields of law today. We cover major research traditions and their critical legacies through explorations of contemporary legal situations: e.g., human rights claims, migration, social security, policing, criminalization, the judicialization of politics, finance, new forms of precarity and the regulation of personal life.

title: Religion and Culture Workshop
prereqs: REL 521.
