descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows. Note: REL 521 (fall) and REL 522 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Introduction to Architectural Design
reviews: Do not take this course unless you are sure you want to be an architecture major.  The amount of work is extremely high and you will not have enough time to complete all of it if you are more focused on other things.  Make sure you think hard about you interests before taking this course.
Don't take unless you are considering architecture as a major.
Expect to spend however much time it takes for your projects and designs to be as good as you like it.

I would definitely recommend this course.  It is fun and interesting and makes you think in ways in which I had never thought before.  It makes you be creative and practical at the same time.  However, it is a TON of work, and you will pull several extremely late nights/early mornings/all-nighters to get projects done.  Do not take this course when you have a heavy course load otherwise (like when you take 5 courses).

If you are the least bit interested in Architecture or even already decided on the major, take this course over 203 to "dip your toes in the water." If Paul is teaching this course again, take it with him, you will learn so much and (even) appreciate the inferno of work you go through to really mature as a design student but he end of the course. Lastly, if you are a freshman, don't be afraid to take this course during the spring. I took it and can say it is the most frustrating, but painstakingly thought provoking class I have taken during my first year.
Lots of work, but really enjoyable

Only take this class if you are willing to put in A LOT of time. Very cool class if you are interested in design / architecture / like to do crafts oriented things in general, but if not it will not be worth it to you.

Take it. This has easily been my favorite course at Princeton. Even if you dont know if you want to do architecture as a major, it will open your mind to the discipline and if for nothing else, will teach you presentation skills.

This is a great intro studio course but it takes a huge amount of time so would probably be best if taken with 3 other courses, that is not to say that it can't be done, but it will be very stressful.
prereqs: ARC 204 is a prerequisite for entry into the departmental concentration. Students will be expected to purchase materials in order to carry out various assignments..
descrip: The first in a series of design studios offered to students interested in majoring in architecture. The course will introduce architecture as an "impure'' plastic art, inseparable from a network of forces acting upon it. The student will be confronted with progressively complex exercises involving spatial relations in two dimensions, three dimensions, and time. The course will stress experimentation while providing an analytical and creative framework to develop an understanding of structure and materials as well as necessary skills in drawing and model making. Two three-hour studios with lectures included.

title: Art, Apartheid, and South Africa
descrip: Apartheid, the political doctrine of separation of races in South Africa (1948-1990), dominated the (South) African political discourse in the second half of the 20th century. While it lasted, art and visual cultures were marshaled in the defense and contestation of its ideologies. Since the end of Apartheid, artists, filmmakers, dramatists, and scholars continue to reexamine the legacies of Apartheid, and the social, philosophical, and political conditions of non-racialized South Africa. Course readings examine issues of race, nationalism and politics, art and visual culture, and social memory in South Africa.

title: Stable Isotope Geochemistry With An Environmental Focus
descrip: Examines the use of stable isotope measurements to investigate important biogeochemical, environmental, and geologic processes, today and over Earth history. Introduction to terminology, basic underlying principles, measurement techniques, commonly used analytical and computational approaches for analyzing data, followed by a review of typical applications of the isotope systems of carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, and other elements. Lectures by the instructor, problem sets, numerical modeling assignments, student presentations and a final student paper based on readings from the scientific literature.

title: Research Methods in Political Science
reviews: All Politics majors take this course! It is very helpful with preparing for independent work and provides a good introduction to statistics if you are looking to take POL 345 later on.
Do the readings
I recommend taking this instead of stats, very helpful with independent work.
It's easily the best stats class to take for Politics majors.
Pretty easy if you put in the effort. straightforward.
Take it if you need to.

The course is not difficult, but first focus on understanding the fundamental assumptions and basics of experimental design, then be sure to understand how these issues apply to the real world. In many ways the course challenges you to think about application. Attend lectures. Readings are not as critical but can be a good source of clarifying material. Because it is not a math class nor a straight statistical class, your being horrible with quantitative work is not of much consequence here.
descrip: This is the introductory undergraduate course in research methods for Politics majors, designed to help prepare students for junior papers and the senior thesis. The material is chosen to convey an understanding of research design, choice of methods, and analysis. Both qualitative and quantitative methods will be taught, including some statistics. However, this is not primarily a statistics course, and the material is different from what a statistics class or qualitative research class would teach. Rather, it is an introduction to a range of research methodologies as they are applied to political science topics.

title: Late Imperial/Early Modern China
reviews: Do all your readings!
Get the materials and start reading asap.

If you're interested in Chinese history at all, this is an excellent course. It digs deeply into the English-language historiography of China, and by going from the late 1300s up through the late 1800s covers a wide variety of the topics that come up in the field, including administration, local vs. national, social structure, commercialization, urbanization, frontiers and imperialism, and interaction with the West. Professor Bian does a wonderful job of clarifying the material and putting the scholarship in context.
Recommend if interested in the period.
very good primer for advanced study of late imperial history
descrip: This course provides graduate students with a comprehensive introduction to the historical study of China from the fifteenth to the nineteenth century. Readings address major historiographical and methodological issues of the field, with a focus on recent literature produced in the United States. Topics covered include political institutions, local society, ethnicity and ideology, material culture, gender, urban and environmental history.

title: Electronic Circuits: Devices to IC
reviews: All ELE students should take this course
Don't fall behind! Things stack up, and you'll get very lost if you don't keep up.
I recommend this course If you are interested in circuit analysis and you have the time to dedicate to it.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in analog circuits past the 203 level, particularly if you have an interest in amplifiers and how transistors can be used in an analog context. Not an easy course, but Professor Sengupta is very energetic and tries to make sure the material is understood.
Office hours can be helpful, and definitely go to all the lectures.
Read over your notes after lecture because it is difficult to really internalize the material as you take notes.
good, but not that easy. start the psets early
prereqs: ELE 203, ELE 206, ELE 208, ELE 301.
descrip: The course will cover topics related to electronic system design through the various layers of abstraction from devices to ICs. The emphasis will be on understanding fundamental system-design tradeoffs, related to the speed, precision, power with intuitive design methods, quantitative performance measures, and practical circuit limitations. The understanding of these fundamental concepts will prepare students for a wide range of advanced topics from circuits and systems for communication to emerging areas of sensing and biomedical electronics.

title: Intermediate Hindi II
prereqs: HIN105 or the equivalent level of proficiency.
descrip: Continuing from HIN 105, this course provides training in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Students will attain the ability to read and understand texts in Hindi on familiar topics, to speak with other Hindi speakers in a wide range of common situations, to write concise texts expressing thoughts and views, and acquire general familiarity with the cultural context(s) in which Hindi is used. Students will have exposure to the cultural contexts of South Asia through multimedia resources, and will engage in interactive and collaborative task-based activities in the classroom.

title: Egalitarianisms
descrip: This course addresses egalitarianism in the history of political thought and explores the following questions: How do political equality, social equality, and economic equality or fairness (and the corresponding inequalities) relate to each other? How do questions of economics, law, institutions, social structure, culture, psychology, and human development intersect with empowerment (and disempowerment)? What frameworks for understanding ?equality? and ?inequality? are most valuable for addressing contemporary political phenomena?

title: Beginning Studies in Acting: Scene Study
reviews: Don't hold yourself back from the exercises in the course. You'll get the most out of it if you are vulnerable.

Invest time in each class assignment and be inventive.  Work to get to know each member of the class and watch as many performances around campus as possible while taking the class.  There are so many amazing shows being performed at Princeton and at McCarter, and it's wonderful to supplement your time in class by watching other performances around campus.
Take it! It's a great course to take for fun!
Take it! You don't need any prior experience. It may be a bit more work than you expect though, especially if you want to get an A.
Take it.
Take the class with Tracie.

The idea of Acting 201 is great, and it is a nice class where you get to be more active and try to access creativity. However, with how the class is currently structured in terms of giving and receiving feedback, and what a strict grader Suzie can be, I can't recommend it as a very enjoyable class, although hopefully with some refinement it will turn out to be!

This class was inordinately stressful for me, and I was a very inappropriate fit for this class. That said, I still give it a lukewarm recommendation. I was not prepared to dedicate the time that was needed for rehearsals, and my focus was often very much turned toward other facets of my life. This was not good for this class. Rehearsals became incredibly annoying, and something that I would dread doing throughout the entire week. I definitely feel like I learned about emotion and expression, and these are definitely abstractable ideas that I really appreciate having in my life now. So in that regard, THR 201 has actually made me a bit of a better person. That said, this came with a very large amount of stress and more work than I was prepared to do.
This course will truly give you the foundation necessary to be a capable actor. If you've never acted, you'll learn, if you've acted, you'll get better, guaranteed.

This was the most impactful course I took during my time as an undergraduate and one of the few classes I ever sincerely looked forward to attending.  Exercises in class can be pretty emotionally intense if you allow them to be, which was extremely challenging for me as a more reserved type of person.  I think it's great to work at dealing with that sort of discomfort though, particularly since I had no prior acting experience and everything felt pretty foreign to me.  Tracy was a great instructor and really pleasant to be around!
You should take this course - acting is not just for people who did it in high school, it is a skill you can learn.
prereqs: This course is by Open Enrollment until the first day of class in February. Enrollment is then by permission of instructors during the first two weeks of classes in February..
descrip: An introduction to the craft of acting through scene study monologues and, finally, a longer scene drawn from a play, to develop a method of working on a script. Emphasis will be placed on honesty, spontaneity, and establishing a personal connection with the scene's substance.

title: The Energy Water Nexus
reviews: Don't take it unless the professor has changed.

I would take this class if you are interested in Energy and the Environment. I would highly recommend it for people who are taking the Sustainable Energy Certificate and any CBE majors. We do learn how to use Aspen in the course and that will be helpful for Design. At the same time we use the software program Aspen so if you do not want to deal with this program I would not recommend taking this class.

LOADS of work (second half when the project starts). Twice as much work as core lab. Spent more time working on the project than sleeping over reading period. But that being said, definitely feel like I learned a lot and am happy I took the course.

Start every assignment extremely early and know the final project will take forever.  Also try to clarify expectations from the beginning. This class will also be very very time consuming so only consider taking it if you have a light courseload.

Though this course covers interesting material, I could not ever recommend taking it in its current form. Many of the assignments use Aspen Plus, a software package for process modeling. It is unintuitive, buggy, and incredibly frustrating to use. Professor Wagner is a great guy with a fascinating background, but had never used Aspen Plus and was therefore unable to help. The final project is to design a natural gas power plant in Aspen. I spent over 30 hours working on just the program. Then there was a 25-page minimum report with a full economic analysis of the plant. The concept of the project was a cool one, but it was a nightmare in practice. Unless they change the structure of the assignments dramatically, the only person I might recommend this course to is a CBE major who will have to use Aspen Plus in 442.
prereqs: Prior completion of a course in thermodynamics, or equivalent, or permission from the instructor is required. It is also desirable for students to have taken CBE 245 (An Introduction to Chemical Engineering Principles), CBE 250 (Separations), CEE 303 (Introduction to Environmental Engineering), and/or MAE 427 (Energy Conversion and the Environment). This course is designed primarily for CBE or MAE majors but open to all majors..
descrip: Students will gain an awareness of challenges to sustainable water and energy and inter-linkages between these. Energy-water design trade-offs will be investigated for various energy and water processing facilities, e.g., electric power and desalination plants. Students will design and simulate a river-reservoir system and assess management and regulatory options. Lectures will include a review of tools for lifecycle environmental and economic analysis, and discussion of contemporary issues where the energy-water nexus plays a critical role.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Physics & Technology of Low-Dimensional Semiconductors
reviews: A course deserves learning
highly recommended for students who have taken ELE441
descrip: A broad overview of materials science and physics of low-dimensional semiconductor structures will be presented. Emphasis will be on the fabrication and physics of high-mobility carrier systems in modulation-doped structures. Examples include two-dimensional, one-dimensional (quantum wire), and zero-dimensional (quantum dot) systems.

title: Climate Science and Communications
reviews: Choose your topic and group for the final video project carefully.
It is a great course. Not too much work, but you learn a lot about how people are communicating climate change.

Profs. Lemonick and Lichtman are wonderful people, and are certainly dedicated to helping students craft an engaging and professional-quality video project (which was really the entire goal and endpoint of the class). That said, they do not push students particularly hard in discussions ? this class is very, very easy. I would recommend if you want a cursory glimpse at topics surrounding science/environmental writing and video production, but keep expectations low.
Take it if you want a lax class, but be aware that expectations/structure/overall format of the class is very iffy! So be flexible.
Take it! The professors are great and it's not too much work but you get a lot out of it.
Take this class!  It is really fun and engaging.  The video project is a blast and they give you time to work on it in class.  A VERY good class to take senior spring and have no need to PDF it.
Take this course, especially if you are an env certificate. Great, laid back, enjoyable class.
Take this.

The class is very laid-back but not organized well at all. We didn't get our syllabus until over a month into the course, and, although we have gotten feedback on assignments, we haven't gotten a solid grade yet.
This is pretty much the easiest course I've ever taken. SO CHILL.
prereqs: Strong interest in science and communications; no previous coursework or experience necessary..
descrip: In order to address the risks of climate change, people need accurate information. Most of this information comes from the world of science and requires translation. The role of science communicators is crucial. The goal of this course is to give students the technical, narrative and critical-evaluation skills needed to communicate climate science in both print and video. The course begins with an overview of the state of climate science and communications. We then discuss critical elements of journalism, and apply those discussions in a series of writing assignments. The last weeks focus on video production using Final Cut Pro software.

title: Screenwriting: Creating Visual and Emotional Unity
reviews: If you want to learn screenwriting, take it.

Please apply to the course if you are serious about screenwriting or honing on your writing skills because there are people out there who really want to take the class, but cannot get in. Don't merely take a spot. Enroll if you want to fall in love with the art of screenwriting.
Take it if you can! Highly recommended.
Talk to the instructor as much as possible
The more you engage with the course, the more rewarding it will be!
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they want to take the course and, optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre..
descrip: How does a screenwriter, organize and develop the ideas that will form a feature narrative script? In this class, students will become familiar with feature film structure, plot evolution, character development, scene shaping and dialogue, and effective techniques for achieving the complex visual and emotional rhythm required by compelling narrative scripts. Moving from their initial idea to outline and scene formation while analyzing examples of classic and contemporary films, students will tackle the unique challenges and opportunities of crafting a feature length screenplay.

title: Intermediate Swahili II
prereqs: Intermediate Swahili I (SWA 105) or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course emphasizes conversational fluency and increased facility in reading and writing skills while introducing students to Swahili literature. This literature forms the basis for a survey on cultural aspects and more advanced grammer. Students will be able to understand and analyze the main ideas and significant details of materials in Swahili such as media articles, short stories, poetry, short novels, films and plays illustrative of East African cultural issues. Covers advanced-level Swahili grammar, as well as the development of expository writing skills.

title: International Organization
descrip: Why do states establish institutions and what determines their design and evolution? Do these institutions merely reflect underlying power and interests? The course will introduce theories of international institutions, evaluate critical perspectives, and examine applications in security, economic, and environmental policy areas.

title: Information Security
reviews: A class deserves learning
Good class, very interesting and relevant material.  Workload is decent for the first half of the semester, then drops off quite a bit in the last half.  Great candidate for a PDF.

I took the class with Prateek. Overall, course was good with the crypto stuff, but all over the place and sort of disorganized with the other material. For example, lectures were mostly unrelated to the homeworks, and practice final exams were not related to the actual final we got. The assignments were okay but I thought there would be more coding/rigor. All in all, I should probably have taken crypto instead; this class didn't really offer the math/rigor I wanted. It did get me to start thinking critically about breaking real-world systems though -- a valuable hacker skill to have.
I'd recommend this course to others especially as a technical breadth course.

Information security is an important and exciting topic with applications in many fields. The course covers a broad range of topics in Computer Science and technology, and it offers a good variety of assignments--both programming and non-programming based.
It was a fun, good class.
It's an interesting course. No one can top Felten, of course, but Mittal gives pretty solid lectures.

Mittal is a great lecturer. He is very knowledgable on the subject. Less people took the course than in the fall with Felten, so the class was much smaller and, in my opinion, much better. Assignments, though, were fairly annoying and tedious at times.

Overall I would take this course again, but perhaps PDF it. You can definitely learn a lot from these assignments and do them well but still get a poor grade that doesn't reflect your efforts/understanding.

Professor Mittal is excellent and runs the course very differently from other professors, with lots of discussion and interaction. One of my favorite CS classes. The assignments are extremely practical - you end up building the basic building blocks of modern security algorithms and designing real-world security systems.
Take the course!
Take this course if you have the chance.  It is a great course and you will learn so much about the topic.

This is a pretty good course overall. The concepts are really interesting. It does a good job of giving you a common set of tools to reason about security and then gives you some problems that help you apply and extend that knowledge. I thought the final exam was actually pretty interesting. 
The assignments are divided between programming in the first half and written/design based. The programming assignments are annoying and nitpicky, so get started early and go to office hours. The design ones are more interesting in my opinion and not as time intensive. 
Lectures are also pretty good, I took it with Prof. Mittal and it was his first semester teaching. They were fairly engaging and he often incorporates come class discussion. It's good way to check your understanding of the concepts.
Try to partner up with someone who is really committed to the course. People will drop, which is inevitable, but it is much easier to stick with the same partner once you've found someone.
Very good skills to have for many different parts of CS. Interesting lectures, fun assignments. Lots of assignments (8) but they're all relatively short. No reading.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Security issues in computing, communications, and electronic commerce. Goals and vulnerabilities; legal and ethical issues; basic cryptology; private and authenticated communication; electronic commerce; software security; viruses and other malicious code; operating system protection; trusted systems design; network security; firewalls; policy, administration and procedures; auditing; physical security; disaster recovery; reliability; content protection; privacy.

title: American Consumer Culture
reviews: Good history class. Do the readings but skim the novels if you're short on time.
Take it! A great way to think about US history in a different way, and a well-structured course to boot.
Take this class if you are at all interested in the topic. Professor Jacobs is amazing, the readings are great, the assignments are interesting, and it's an eye-opening course overall!
Yes. If you have any interest in consumption in America take this. Lots of fun and very interesting.
descrip: This class examines how and why twentieth-century Americans came to define the "good life" through consumption, leisure, and material abundance. We will explore how such things as department stores, nationally advertised brand-name goods, mass-produced cars, and suburbs transformed the American economy, society, and politics. The course is organized both thematically and chronologically. Each period deals with a new development in the history of consumer culture. Throughout we explore both celebrations and critiques of mass consumption and abundance.

title: Animal Behavior
reviews: A little dry but a good option for EEB majors and people looking for an STN

Accessible and generally interesting STN for people without extensive science backgrounds, but the various components of the class are not well designed to fit together, there is an undue emphasis on very specific memorization in the exams, and the reading load is excessive and not well integrated into the course (not that I get the impression that many people do all of the reading...)
Be in Elise's precept and this class will not be painful!
Can be a little boring, but overall interesting and with a unique lecturer

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE AS A PDF FOR YOUR STN REQUIREMENT. This is an awful class to PDF, so don't do it! The exams require you to memorize a ton of different examples about random animal facts. On top of that, the class is extremely boring.
Definitely a solid class to take for an STN.  Professor Gould is a good guy (though his lectures can be a bit overwhelming details-wise), and you'll learn a lot.
Definitely take the course!
Do the readings! Try to attend most classes. Spend some time memorizing before the exam. And you'll do just fine. Very interesting course, not too much work.
Do your best to get a good preceptor.
Do your readings and go to class... Try not to fall asleep in class. Go to precept and write your precept questions because they're a large part of the grade (almost as big a part as the midterm).
Don't do it. Not easy. Not fun
Don't miss lecture and do all the readings! The tests are graded harder than you might expect, and they are relatively detail-oriented.
Dowon Dan Kim should take this course. Do the readings and study hard
Eh, not a great course. Most of the material is incredibly boring, not to mention outdated. Precepts were weirdly intense and not all that helpful. Look elsewhere.
Extremely interesting material. Gould knows his stuff
Focus on the studies.
GO to lecture and get Elise as a preceptor.
Go to every lecture and take good notes, get on first-name basis with your preceptor as quickly as possible!
Go to lecture!!!!
Great PDF if you want minimal work. I only read one 5 page paper a week and studied 4 hours the night before a midterm and got a B.
Hard to stay engaged if not interested in the material.
I know a lot of people take this for an STN, but there are lots of more exciting classes.
If this is your science PDF, don't. If you're an EEB student, it's not bad (and required, so...). Study for the exams.

If you are curious at all about animal behavior definitely take this class! Very interesting, and lectures are engaging, if long. Precepts were subpar but there is very little work besides midterm and final.
If you tend to fall asleep in lectures, don't take this course. If you have no interest in animals, don't take this course.
Interesting course, but frustratingly organized.

It's not so much an EEB learning course as it is Professor Gould walking you through the development of a field of study he helped invent. I thought it was interesting, but it's certainly not as expected.

Keep up with the readings. Go to the lecture and take notes on each of the slides... they are very minimalistic, and in order for you to gather anything from said slides in studying for exams, you need to take notes. But also, don't get overwhelmed by the number of examples there. Try to discern which are the more important examples for each one, and know those well (:
Make sure you get a good preceptor.
Not worth your time unless you want to PDF an STN or you have to because you are an EEB major.
Probably would not recommend for those who don't need to take it
Read the chapters ahead of the corresponding lectures, since they make lecture much easier to follow along. Exams are based on the lectures, so go to lecture!

Take it if you have general interest but don't expect to come out of it with a huge new repertoire of knowledge. Some of the lectures just seem like a long string of fun facts, but then that can be good too.
Take it if you're EEB
Take this class! Great STN for non-science majors, really interesting and Gould is AMAZING.
Take this course
Take this course, Gould is pretty spectacular and is always interesting to listen to, it's a great STL.
This course covers a lot of fundamental aspects of animal behavior and behavioral ecology. The information makes it a foundational course for any EEB major.

This is a very interesting class for anyone who is EEB or interested in animals. Lots of stuff about bees, birds, and ants. The material can be presented in a disorganized fashion but its still interesting.
This was literally the most boring class I've taken in my Princeton career. Lu was a terrible preceptor. If you're looking for an STN to PDF, look elsewhere.

You learn about animals. Need i say more?
(However, beware of your preceptor. Choose wisely.)
not a bad STN
only take this if you having a strong interest and or need to take it for your major.
descrip: One of the fascinating challenges in biology is to understand the origins and organization of animal behavior. Ethology is the branch of biology concerned with the mechanisms and evolution of behavior, especially innate predispositions and programming, and their interaction with learning. The course begins by examining the discovery of early ethologists of behavioral units or "programs", and relates these to our understanding of the nervous system. We look at how complex behaviors such as navigation, learning, and planning are organized. We study the social behavior of several species and end with an ethological analysis of our own species.

title: The Crusades
reviews: A great course for prospective history majors. It has a moderate amount of readings and papers, and also ties in to modern issues in the Middle East.
Absolutely take it. Absolutely. You won't regret it.

If you are interested in the crusades, take this class. The reading material is fairly light but really interesting, and you will come out with a good overview of the entirety of the crusading period.

If you do decide to take this course, be diligent about meeting with Professor Shawcross before working on your assignments, because she has very specific goals in mind for each one, and you will do better if you understand what those are
It's a standard lecture taught by a great teacher. Take her precept if possible.

Overall, the course presents an engaging and critical reading of an otherwise mythologized period. Professor Shawcross does a great job at attacking the Crusades from various critical angles that I feel gave me a much more integrated understanding of the period in wider global history of the time and beyond.
Take it
Take it if you have any interest in the middle ages at all!
Take it! Really interesting course. I have learnt a lot. Shawcross is a very very nice lady and a good lecturer.
Take the course.
Take this class!

Take this class! The material is fascinating and Professor Shawcross is an amazing teacher who really cares and wants you to do your best. Definitely do the readings, they are really interesting. Also go to office hours to discuss assignments. One of my favorite classes so far at Princeton!
The primary source book readings are the only ones you really need to do if you go to all the lectures.
definitely take it, it's a really fun class
descrip: The Crusades were a central phenomenon of the Middle Ages. This course examines the origins and development of the Crusades and the Crusader States in the Islamic East. It explores dramatic events, such as the great Siege of Jerusalem, and introduces vivid personalities, including Richard the Lionheart and Saladin. We will consider aspects of institutional, economic, social and cultural history and compare medieval Christian (Western and Byzantine), Muslim and Jewish perceptions of the crusading movement. Finally, we will critically examine the resonance the movement continues to have in current political and ideological debates

title: Optimization
reviews: Avoid interaction with Haotian at all cost. If he is somehow allowed to precept again, do not go near him. If you do, it will just put you in a bad mood.
Basically only covers the simplex method of linear programming. Problem sets teach you more than lectures, and the class is filled with a lot of smart kids.
Be prepared for a semester of boredom
Do not take this course unless you have to.
Don't let this course discourage you from ORF, because there are some good things about it and I think conceptually it's fundamental.

Don't take if you're not ORFE. If you're ORFE, go in knowing that this is one of the worst ORFE core courses, probably second to only ORF 405. The problem sets are long, hard, and you don't ever enjoy doing them. Suck it up, work hard, and you'll be fine.
Don't take it unless you have to.

Don't take it unless you have to. It's not a class about optimization, it's a class about the simplex method. If you work hard, you can and will get an A, but you won't be understanding what you're doing--which is very frustrating when something isn't working in your code / you're getting the wrong answer in a problem.
Don't take it unless you need to. Really, take my word for it.
Don't, unless you are an ORFE student.
Don't, unless you're an ORFE major
Either attend lectures or read the book, keeping up with material.
Good course.
Great course in a super important subject area. Professor Vanderbei is great and the pace/work was manageable.
Great course. Very interesting material. I would suggest attending lectures and paying attention; that helped me a lot. Readings are good for a more mathematical version of what is taught in lecture

Haotian Pang is hands down the most passionate and enthusiastic preceptor in ORF 307. Please take advantage of his office hours. He is very involved with the course and is intimately familiar with the text. You will never meet a Chinese grad student from the ORFE department who is so moved by all the variants Simplex Method. I have learnt a lot from him and he definitely motivates me to better learn the material and to think about optimization from a more abstract perspective. He is a shining preceptor in the ORFE department. All should strive to achieve his level of commitment.
I would only take this class if you have to, it's interesting but not as interesting as it initially appears to be, and I still feel like it's not worth it if you're not an ORF major.
If you are taking this course when you do not have to, it will be difficult to stay motivated. The material is not very difficult, and the grading is also not harsh though.

If you develop a good approach to the course, it's totally possible to do well.Get a good grasp of AMPL early, make good cheat sheets for exams (understanding isn't that necessary), and find a good group to work on psets with because they're often time consuming (not conceptually hard, just a lot of grunt work).

If you have to take this class for your major or a certificate don't worry you will be fine.  Just GO TO LECTURE/PRECEPT! Even though you can tune out at lecture being there to know what his slides relate to is important when going back through the homework.  Also use study groups and don't get behind on your understanding of AMPL.  This class won't be great, but the subject material is at least interesting.

If you're not ORFE, don't take this. Years of bad reviews have done nothing to change this class and there's no likelihood it will change soon. This class made people drop ORFE. You will learn nothing you can't learn on your own in under two hours, not even joking. ORFE, I'm writing this here again so its public-- please, please think about what this course is meant to achieve and examine whether it is actually doing that. Literally hundreds of Princeton students can't be wrong please listen to us!

It's a pretty straightforward class, and not too difficult of a departmental. Problem sets didn't take too long, and could be done without attending lecture if you just read the book and lecture notes.

It's not a particularly interesting or well-organized class. A lot of the problem sets were complicated, but not impossible. Generally, the class isn't particularly satisfying because you don't really learn much about AMPL coding or how exactly certain methods operate.
Make sure you get to know Vanderbei; great guy.
Make sure you grasp the concepts
Make sure you leave time to do the problem sets. Take if interested in math and optimization.
Not too tough, and fun!
Only take it if you have to.
Overall, I only learned one algorithm in the whole semester: simplex. I could've read about it in a week. The rest of the semester was teaching me how to do algebra faster...
Read the Book. Vanderbei is super helpful if you email him and he is more than willing to help.
Reading Vanderbei's textbook is a great way to learn material for problem sets and exams. This is a well-organized but boring class.
Take 309 instead and learn optimization online.
Take advantage of office hours.
Take it if you have to take it. It's not great but it's not terrible.
Take the course, but make sure you actually know what's going on because topics seem to diverge.
Take this course for sure.  So applicable

The only reason you should take this course is if you have to take it as an ORFE major. So if you have to take it, fine, take it, it's not so awful. But I wouldn't ever recommend it to anyone else. You just don't learn very much, it's not very interesting, and it's not a good use of a class at Princeton.

This is an okay course, you definitely learn about optimization, but at times it becomes frustrating because it often feels like Professor Vanderbei and the preceptor do not care. If you ask a question, Professor Vanderbei will direct you to the textbook or say that it should be clear to you while most of the preceptors will say the answer is obvious (which defeats the purpose of asking the question in the first place).
This is one of the easier and better ORF classes in my opinion. If you are an ORFE major, you will have to take it, just know it isn't too bad.
You probably do not need to go to lecture

You're probably taking it for your major so you don't have much of a choice. It's definitely easier and less work than other ORF classes, but make sure to keep up with the material. Lectures tend to be pretty useless but Vanderbei is a great person so I felt too bad not to go
dont take it if you dont have to
dont take this course unless you have to
if you're ORF you don't have a choice. For anyone interested in optimization, there are probably better classes out there.
n/a
please do not take this course
take it if it's a requirement
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204. Basic computer programming knowledge suggested..
descrip: Many real-world problems involve maximizing a linear function subject to linear inequality constraints. Such problems are called Linear Programming (LP) problems. Examples include min-cost network flows, portfolio optimization, options pricing, assignment problems and two-person zero-sumgames to name but a few. The theory of linear programming will be developed with a special emphasis on duality theory. Attention will be devoted to efficient solution algorithms. These algorithms will be illustrated on real-world examples such as those mentioned.

title: The Fantasy of the Middle Ages: Stories and Storytelling
descrip: See website

title: Rise of Asia: Political Economy of Development
reviews: A very well taught class. The lectures are clear. Take this class if you want to understand the rise of Asia.
Definitely take this class! Kohli gives a great treatment of Korea, China, and India. You'll learn a lot just sitting in the class.

Definitely take this course, especially if it is taught by Professor Kohli. This course really gives you an eye-opening sense of both the struggles and successes that the developing world today faces.

Fascinating course and material, but be prepared to do a solid amount of work. Kohli's a great lecturer. Grading is tough, and it's not totally clear what they're ever looking for, so don't expect to get an A.
Great course, great professor. One of my favorite courses at Princeton.
I wholeheartedly endorse this class.
If you want to learn about the political economy of China, India, and Korea this is great class to take. This class is focused around cases so you will get a really good sense
More descriptive than analytical, but still quite interesting.

Really interesting course that provides an overview of three major Asian economic powerhouses. Very useful for understanding current events. Atul Kohli?s lectures are fascinating and well-organized. The 7-page papers (you have to write one after learning about each country, so one paper every three weeks) may seem like a lot of work, but as long as you have a good outline and try to incorporate some of the recommended readings (sources not covered in lecture), an A minus isn?t difficult to score.

Take it! If you're remotely interested in Asian politics, development or economics and government influence, I would recommend this course. Kohli is an amazing professor and he makes the course what it is. Take good notes during lectures and form a reading group to keep up with the readings.

Start assignments early and go to office hours to talk about things you don't understand in the course.
Take it, even if you have just a vague interest in Asia. Keep up with the readings.
take it!

this is a good course if you want to learn about asia. professor kohli's lectures are easy to follow and well structured, and cover a lot of material. he often presents his own views and research, which many professors here at princeton don't. the readings, though, are quite dull. this is a fact heavy course with no independent research, so the main reason to take it would be an interest in the recent economic histories of korea, china and india.
descrip: The economies of many Asian countries have grown rapidly over the last several decades. This course will study the political and economic pathways travelled by select Asian countries on their road to prosperity. The focus will be on three specific countries: South Korea, China and India. We will analyze comparatively the models of development pursued in these countries, especially the state's role in promoting growth and distribution.

title: Epidemiology
reviews: Always keep up with the readings and come to lecture prepared. Do not be afraid to speak up in lecture. Start studying for the midterm way in advance and do all the extra credit.
Attend lecture. Do the readings. Study for the midterm. Take time to find good research articles for case studies.
Definitely take it if you're at all interested in public health! The quantitative material really complements the knowledge learned in GHP 350
Do the readings and go to class! You don't want to miss these lectures for your own benefit.

Epidemiology is a fascinating field and made even better by Prof. Amon, whose expertise is clearly demonstrated. The workload is not too heavy, nor are readings. The course generally prepares students for approaching their own independent work and critically assessing scientific literature in health. Prof. Amon is relatively reasonable, but the class is not curved. He provides opportunities for extra credit, but doing them would be unnecessary if there was a curve.
Epidemiology is kind of a scary topic, but Prof. Amon makes it really wonderful and enjoyable for everyone.
Expect statistics. Great professor, not an easy class.

First of all, if you're a GHP student, you have to take it. 

But if you're not, take it anyways -- it'll make you wish you were! 

Epi and Amon are awesome :)
Good not great. Make sure you really know your stuff for the midterm. Only take it if you need it for GHP.
Great course! It really changes the way you think about health-related and medical research.
I would recommend taking this course regardless of whether you're in the GHP program if you're interested in health, health research, or medicine. Professor Amon is really great.
Manageable...very applicable to all fields.

Professor Amon makes this course really fun, even if you're in the humanities and are terrified of quantitative courses. Everyone says this, but do not underestimate the midterm. It will not be anything like the practice midterms, and will probably make you want to cry.
Study for the midterm! It's not hard at all if you've practiced.
Study for the midterm!!
Take it
Take it if you would like a basic review of epidemiology.
Take it! Super interesting take on epi!
Take it!!
Take this class if you have an interest in global health, even if you're not in the GHP program.

The course is deceptively easy-ish until the midterm. There is a lot of work toward the end of the semester, that kind of all comes on at once. However, it is a very interesting course that opened me up to a whole new field.
This course is very numbers heavy if you are a social science/humanities person. However, you learn a lot of practical information.
This course was a waste of time. After this and GHP 350, I am regretting getting the GHP certificate formally. Especially if you are doing lab research, these courses are very useless.
This is a good course.  The midterm is rough--pretty quantitative and you really have to understand the concepts (some of the questions are trying to trick you).  The readings aren't that important.
This is a wonderful and informative course. It covers interdisciplinary topics and assesses a wide range of abilities.
This is a wonderful class to take if you want to enter into the world of health care or public health!

This was a great class, one of my favorites at Princeton. It's not nearly as statistics heavy as I was anticipating. Epidemiology is surprisingly interesting and forces you to think about things in logical, stimulating ways
Very interesting course. Not that quantitative; it's more a course designed around how numbers are obtained and the logic behind it, not a course about the numbers themselves.
Yes, take it!
it's not a painful class to take, but don't expect to learn much.
it's not super edifying but also not challenging
prereqs: Completion of an approved basic statistics course (e.g., ECO 202, EEB/MOL 355, ORF 245, POL 345, PSY 251 or SOC 301), or completion of an advanced statistics course (e.g., ECO 302, ECO 312, ORF 405, SOC 404, WWS 200, and WWS 332)..
descrip: This required course for GHP students focuses on the distribution and determinants of disease. Diverse methodological approaches for measuring health status, disease occurrence, and the association between risk factors and health outcomes will be presented via classic and contemporary studies of chronic and infectious illness and disease outbreaks. Emphasis on: causal inference, study design and sampling, bias and confounding, the generalizability of research, health policy and research ethics.

title: Financial Crises
prereqs: ECO310 and ECO202 or equivalent.
descrip: This course will consider market bubbles and financial crises from two distinct angles. The first half will focus on bubbles and crashes in the public equity market, with particular emphasis on the productive role that financial speculation can play in the deployment of innovative technologies. We will take a broad conceptual view of historic episodes, so require a large amount of background reading. The second half will focus on the dynamics of the credit system, with particular emphasis on leverage cycles and systemic instabilities, including the global financial crisis of 2008. Recent theoretical literature will be explored in depth.

title: Junior Independent Work
prereqs: This course is open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty member.

title: Play, Leisure, and Sociability
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture II
reviews: Work hard, learn a lot.
prereqs: KOR 401 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion of Korean thoughts and issues in contemporary Korea. Readings drawn from a variety of cultural and historical topics. Class discussions will be conducted in Korean.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering
prereqs: Course open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.

title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
reviews: Be prepared to spend a lot of time.
I would tell them to try the course out and see if they got anything out of it.
If you do high energy physics, you definitely should learn this.
descrip: Relations between Quantum Field Theory and Statistical Mechanics, Renormalization Group, Non-Abelian Gauge Theories, Asymptotic Freedom, Quantum Chromodynamics, Chiral Lagrangians, General Constraints on RG Flows.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

title: The Politics of Seeing: The Films of the French New Wave
descrip: See website

title: Problems in Literary Study - Surprised by Passion: Eros in the Modern Novel
descrip: Of all the passions, the erotic is arguably the most intense and the least subject to discipline or correction by Reality. This seminar will explore modern instances of the trait that arguably distinguishes the erotic from all other passions: its capacity to take us by surprise.

title: Media Arabic I
reviews: Start the problem sets earlier on and work with friends if you can! Pick interesting topics for your presentations that will keep others engaged. Do your homework so you don't feel so lost during class.
Take it! Professor Essien is extremely nice and a great professor, and the class will be useful to anyone who hopes to deal with Arabic news sources for research or business in the future.
The most practical Arabic course I've taken at Princeton. You'll actually learn how to read the news!
Vocabulary in this class is so useful!
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or the equivalent..
descrip: In this course, students will develop their skills in reading and listening to Arabic news media, including newspapers, magazines, websites, radio and satellite TV broadcasts (including BBC and al-Jazeera, among others). Attention will also be given to informal discussion of current news, and we will also take a brief look at political cartoons.

title: The Eighteenth Century in Europe
descrip: This year's topic is "Reading Characters: Clarissa in Context." The seminar will consider the development of the modern novel during the European Enlightenment as a narrative epistemology of character, through an intensive reading of Richardson's Clarissa. Interpreting this seminal work in the context of contemporary British and European texts and recent criticism and theory will help us observe the relation of literary genres to pervasive ideas of the period surrounding gender and identity politics, probability, sensibility, nationalism, etc.--major trends in Western literary, cultural and intellectual history still resonant today.

title: Modern Physics I: Condensed-Matter Physics
prereqs: PHY 208, PHY 301 and PHY 305.
descrip: This survey course applies concepts from quantum mechanics and topological order to the properties of electrons in solids. New topics such as topological insulators and superconductors, Chern numbers and Berry phases, electronic band structure, the tight-binding approximation, time-reversal invariant topological insulators and the integer and fractional quantum hall effects.

title: Introduction to Financial Mathematics
reviews: A good course, if you're interested in option pricing.
Can't miss this if you're ORF.
Definitely take this class if you are interested in finance.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take this course unless you are dead set on going into sales and trading I guess.
Don't take unless you have to or have a deep burning desire to do lots of math.
Good core ORFE class. Will be a decent amount of work but not overly demanding. Material relatively interesting if you are at all interested in derivatives/options/etc.
Hard class, but worth it.
I think this was a good course. Go to lecture, read the notes, do your work, and you'll be fine. Definitely a rigorous introduction to financial mathematics. Be good at math
If ORFE major, required. If not, if interested in finance, take.

If you enjoyed ORF 309 (and I don't see how anyone couldn't love 309), you will probably like this course too. The material is a little drier than 309, but it's really cool to see the financial applications of the probability theory you learned in 309. Sircar is a solid lecturer and really builds the financial models from the ground up. Not only do you get to see some really amazing math, but you will also have a solid understanding of these models and how to use them. Warning: the difficulty of the class takes off after the midterm, but it's still very manageable as long as you stay on top of the work. You will probably have to go to office hours and work collaboratively on the last few problem sets, as they get really tough. But they're also well written and rewarding. Overall, I recommend for anyone with an interest in math and probability theory. I'm not even a huge fan of finance and I loved it.

If you like math (BC Calculus) and finance, then you will really like this course.  It has been one of my favorite courses here at Princeton because it combines financial understanding with a mathematical base and derivation.

If you're ORFe, you don't have a choice, but if you're not, I recommend this course. It's a solid introduction to mathematical finance, from options to credit risk, and exotics. Take it if you're at all interested in a career as a quant or if you're interested in applied math (specifically applied stochastics).
Interesting class
Make you understand the concepts every week

Most students will take this because they have to but if you are interested in the math behind trading and options this is definitely the course for you. Be prepared for lots of calculus and derivations

Only take it if you are interested in a continuation (real-world application) of 309 (the second half of the semester). What you learn at the beginning is new and interesting, but it goes right back to Brownian Motion and what not...
Pay attention to Stochastic Calculus.
Prepare well
Really good course. Essential for hedge fund interviews.
Ronnie recycles test questions like none other.
Sircar is an amazing lecturer, but won't really care / respond to your emails.  I hate finance but it was a good class
Take it if you want to learn about options
Take it if you want to learn the basics of options pricing. I think it is definitely well-structured and very clearly layed out.
Take it if you're interested in finance; otherwise, don't
Take it, take it, take it. Even if you're not ORFE or ECON, if you're decently good at math, and have some kind of interest in finance, you need to take this class!
The course is very doable the first semester, afterwards it becomes confusing. Take it only if you have taken a differential equations course.
The first half of the course is a breeze; make sure you stay on top for the second half though.

The psets take a long time so start early. Learn how to code because there is a huge coding component to this class. Make sure to study all past midterms and finals because he tends to recycle questions. Beware that this is a very time consuming class! That being said, you learn a lot!
The second half of the course gets really tough, but generally not horrible for an ORF course. Material is incredibly dry and not very interesting.
This is one of the more interesting ORF classes. It is extremely relevant in today's economy and after the recession.
Very finance heavy, be ready for it.
Very good intro to finance.

You learn a lot through this class, and it isn't really too big of a time commitment since psets are usually due every other week. It gets a lot harder after the midterm, though. Knowing MATLAB is helpful, and while it might be good to take this class after ORF 309 (so that a lot of the probability math is fresh in your mind), you might not want to rush it.

You'll learn how to price options (and bonds, which are basically treated as options) and get a bare, ad hoc introduction to stochastic calculus. Lectures are pretty clear as long as the blackboard is being used (when slides are used, it is impossible to follow). It was nice that the course also talked about the rise and fall of hedge funds and quants, which is pretty relevant if you want to be one. except while taking this course i realized i wasn't that into finance...
good
only take if ORF major or intellectually capable
study the practice exams, same problems as previous years
take it
take it since you need it for ORFE.
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 104 and ORF 309 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Financial Mathematics is concerned with designing and analyzing products that improve the efficiency of markets and create mechanisms for reducing risk. This course introduces the basics of quantitative finance: the notions of arbitrage and risk-neutral probability measure are developed in the case of discrete models. Black-Scholes theory is introduced in continuous-time models, and credit derivatives and the term structure of interest rates are discussed, as well as lessons from the financial crisis.

title: Computer Graphics
reviews: A ton of work so be prepared but SO worth taking.
Be aware that there are really fast computers in the new media center in Lewis Library
Definitely take it. Don't let previous reviews about it taking over your life affect your decision, because they've put in a lot of effort into making the workload more manageable.

Definitely take this course, but be prepared for a lot of work. The programming assignments are very rewarding, and even your bugs can be amusing, but they can also take a large amount of time. I found myself spending more time on this than any other class I have taken at Princeton, but I didn't realize this because I was actually having fun with the assignments (I also did more work than was necessary for a good grade, though). I learned quite a bit, and would definitely recommend this course!
Do it! You'll be surprised at what you can learn in a semester, and at how much more there is to learn in this field!
Fun assignments, enjoyable lectures, overall a great COS class for a junior who wants to explore different areas.

Graphics has become a very manageable and fun class. I advise all COS majors to give it a try. With JavaScript, things might be a little slower, but the assignments are still just as cool if not more cool. As usual start assignments early and rely on TAs and professor for help. Lastly, the final project isn't limited to just making games -- you can make any type of system or whichever graphics application you like. It's a great class to express your creativity, learn something new, and have a good time.
Great course -- take it!! I'm considering doing independent work in graphics because of it.

I really enjoyed this course.  Professor Finkelstein is very invested in the material and in helping students learn.  The course TAs shared the same enthusiasm.  This year, they redesigned all of the assignments to have them implemented in JavaScript/WebGL instead of C  .  While it led to some delays in assignment release dates, I really appreciated this change.  I think JavaScript is a nicer language to work with (no seg faults!), and it's nice to be able to share a project with a URL rather than a sketchy executable.
If you have an interest in computer graphics, I would strongly recommend this class.
Interesting
Not a bad class. A lot of time though.
Overall, great class! We made lots of cool things. Be sure to read precept notes carefully when doing assignments.
Prepare enough time for it as the workloads are high.

Probably will be more organized the second time around. This was the first year with JS assignments, which prob made them easier than in previous years, but they were often buggy and delayed. Made me really lose momentum in the course and it canceled the second exam (which I was looking forward to in order to boost my grade).
Start early on the assignments but don't worry they're pretty fun.
Take it for some time-consuming fun!
Take it if it's in JavaScript. Not much work but amazing results. Game making is the culmination of one semester's fun and learning.
Take it!
Take this course if you are at all interested in computer animation or video game graphics! I had no experience with javascript or webGL and it was not a problem.
Take, but be prepared for the time commitment. Be ready to spend a lot of time on the final project, but it's worth it. Terrible class to PDF. Instructors were very accessible.

This class is a fair bit of work, but the results are quite satisfying. If you do take it, I would recommend forcing yourself to start on the early side (even if you normally don't), because once you see some of the things you implement for the assignments, I think the results will become motivation to keep working at it because it's pretty fun.
This course taught by Adam Finkelstein with the new set of programming assignments was incredible.  I learned so much and had a great time doing it.

To get the most out of the course, it is true that a decent amount of time is required (that's probably true for most courses here though). Still, if you're interested in graphics, this is a great place to start.
YES if interested at all in graphics. NO if the amount of work will drive you away and you don't really need it.
tons of fun!
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226. MAT 202 or equivalent recommended..
descrip: Introduction to computer graphics. Topics include image synthesis, 3D modeling, image processing and animation. Encourage hands-on experience.

title: Colloquium on the Biology of Populations
reviews: Go to every one of the lectures, even if the title does not entice you! The speakers are very good and often draw you in even if the subject matter does not usually interest you.
descrip: Discussion of the central problems of population biology and approaches that have proved fruitful. Topics ranging throughout ecology, evolution, biogeography, and population genetics are usually related to presentations by visiting speakers and students. (This is a core course.)

title: The Modern Middle East
reviews: 10000% take this course!!!! It's not another one of those courses that claims that you will get an actual "introduction" into something. You will understand why you cannot understand anything in depth about the Middle East in one semester, or a lifetime.

If you have plenty of time to read, this course should be fine but the reading is necessary for precept which made it overwhelming. The lectures were pretty interesting however the professor had a no computers policy which made it a bit difficult to keep up with him while doing hand written notes.
Not really a class for people without a background in the subject. I'd recommend a different class if that's what you're interested in.
TAKE IT!
Take it!  Beware of the readings.
Take it.
Take this course and broaden your horizons!
Take this course if you want to learn more about the Middle East's history/politics! Or if you already have an interest in it.
descrip: An introduction to the history of the Middle East from the late eighteenth century through the turn of the twenty-first, with an emphasis on the Arab East, Iran, Israel, and Turkey.

title: Post-colonial North Africa Before the Arab Spring
descrip: Since 2011, North Africa (or Maghrib) has been shaken by two revolutions in its Eastern part (Tunisia and Libya) and this area still contains strategic crossroads between Europe, sub-Saharan Africa and the Middle East. This graduate seminar addresses the social, economical and cultural issues in post-colonial North Africa before the Arab spring.

title: Hustles and Hustlers
reviews: Attend all lectures. The readings are hit and miss--sometimes very engaging and sometimes long and irrelevant. Better to really focus and thoroughly learn a selection of them than to get tied up in trying to read every page and end up not remembering anything. Professor Ferguson has had some amazing experiences, and sometimes you will be awed during her lectures! Sit back and enjoy. Focus on broad themes for the exams and examples from readings/lectures that fit these themes.
Attend all of the lectures and make sure to pay attention during the readings.
Awesome course
Buy the books from someone else! Attend lecture. Precept doesn't matter too much other than attendance.
Definitely do it
Definitely recommend it as a P/D/F course. Also, go to lecture!
Definitely take the course!

Definitely take this!!! You won't find another class like it at Princeton, really interesting topics and eye-opening stuff for everyone. Workload quite manageable. Prof. Ferguson is a lot of fun and has fascinating stories to share.
Definitely worth taking! An amazing course!
Do all the readings and take very good notes.
Do all the readings, they are engaging and excellent.
Do the readings and pay attention in lecture and you're good to go.
Don't think it'll be offered again.
Easy course that is interesting and does not require relentless hours of work. Great 5th class
Focus on the themes of the course while taking notes and be able to cite examples of them.
Focus on using the countless examples Professor Ferguson provides to supplement the larger ideas about criminals enterprises.
Fun and interesting course. Take it!
Go to class. This course isn't that difficult if you do the readings and pay attention in class.
Go to lecture! Rachael has so many cool stories and the exams will be extremely easy if you actually go to class and learn the material.
Good PDF, but not necessarily the most engaging course (particularly the second half). Lectures are not really structured at all, and precepts are not constructive.
Great class, awesome lectures.  Very interesting topics.  It's like getting your "street creds" in the safety of a McCosh lecture hall.
Great course! A lot of fun -- Professor Ferguson is the greatest. Take notes during lecture - it really helps for the midterm and final.
Great material! Just be prepared to take a lot of notes in lecture and to do a lot of reading!

Hustles & Hustlers is hands-down one of the most fascinating courses I will ever take at Princeton. Where else do you get to learn the ins and outs of organized crime in sectors like organ trafficking, sex work, and the Mafia? Attending lecture was like watching my favorite weekly crime TV show--this was a true gift of a course!
I would not recommend this course for other students.

I would tell them to absolutely take it if they can, it's a fantastic course--you'll learn a lot about the world and it gives good perspective on life outside our orange bubble. My favorite class this semester by far.
Ideal PDF course
If you are so lucky to have the opportunity, take this course.
If you have room in your schedule, go for it
If you're a senior or otherwise looking for a course that won't require much, take this course. But don't expect it to live up to the hype it should get given the topics.
Interesting look at crime. Not the best course ever, but you'll get a sweeping inside look at a lot of different industries.
It is easy only because it is interesting material. Go to lecture and you will do well and enjoy yourself.
It was interesting
Just try to keep up with the readings.  But take this course!!! So interesting.
Learned more from watching The Wire.
Lectures are super interesting. Great chance to learn about a world you probably aren't at all familiar with, from an individual who's lived inside it for years.
MUST TAKE.
Make sure to go to lectures, as the exams are strongly based on the lecture material. Therefore, make sure to take good notes during lecture.
Make sure you go to all the lectures! Make an effort to go to precept too because they help even if you haven't done the readings.
Must take.

Prof Ferguson has cool stories from her ethnographic work and the different topics are superficially interesting...but the lectures felt more like her reading news articles or anecdotes about crime. I didn't feel like I learned much in this course.

Read everything. Take notes on everything. Take notes in lecture. Every piece of material has a purpose, so enjoy it, but don't forget the message inside every story. If you find something interesting, go above and beyond and do some research, it will come full circle and help you in the end.
So cool, but probably never offered again!
Stay on top of the readings!
Strongly recommend.
TAKE IT - it's the most interesting course at Princeton
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT.
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT>
TAKE THIS CLASS. Rachael offers a fascinating perspective of understanding on the organized crime enterprises, a topic that is unlike any Princeton class most students ever take.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!! so much fun - one of the most engaging classes Ive taken here and I learned so much actually
TAKE THIS!!
Take good notes in lecture and you should be fine.
Take it as a really fun PDF!
Take it if you are interested in illicit activity, but the material gets a little repetetive
Take it. It's a very interesting course and is fun as well.
Take this class! It is super interesting if you like learning about hustles and gangs.

Take this course as a PDF if you can. It was a bit frustrating at times if you felt like you really got to know the material and weren't able to demonstrate on an exam, so it would be more enjoyable as a PDF. Prof Ferguson is really fun to listen to but taking notes in lecture is difficult.
Take this course because you may never get a chance to study this material again.  It is very unique.
Take this course is you want to take an easy, intellectually stimulating course. Great to PDF.
Take this if you want an interesting class from a sociological perspective of crime!
Take this. Make sure to attend the lectures and do the readings, and you'll get a good grade and enjoy yourself.

The course is an interesting and refreshing approach to a different subject, and not too hard. Very easy to pdf. However, I wished I had been taught more of the general approach to sociology as a discipline, as well as what some of the key concepts mean there, instead of constantly trying to find things out about the concepts without really understanding what the concepts were in the first place.

The lectures are entertaining, the readings are interesting, and there's not a whole lot of work. It's also on a topic that you probably won't have a chance to learn about anywhere else. What's not to like?
The most eye opening course you will take at Princeton. The only course at Princeton where I have attended 100% of lectures, because they're that interesting.
There are a lot of readings but the material is super interesting so the readings are not bad at all. Make sure to make connections to all the main topics.
This is a good PDF. The lecture are very entertaining, but the readings get more boring and longer as the semester continues. It's a relatively easy class, but the grading is harsh.

This is a great class and probably one of my favorites that I have taken at Princeton.  The topics discussed can be brought up in everyday conversations.  Lectures and readings were really interesting.
Try to read the weeks reading by the first lecture time because it makes things in lecture more understandable.
Very interesting.
Want to hear the professor read a list of drug prices around the world all lecture? If not, perhaps this isn't for you.
take it
take this!!!
the easiest way to grasp concepts is to attend lecture for this class
descrip: This course examines exchange relations in a variety of high-risk and criminal fields, to develop an understanding of how participants navigate their worlds. The weekly readings and lectures will focus on the various ways in which relationships, identities, reputation, and trust, are defined, established, and negotiated, and how this establishes order in the professional and social lives of those involved in high-risk transactions. Readings will be from ethnographic and biographical works on street gangs, drug dealers and traffickers, sex workers, organized crime operations, sports bookies, organ and human traffickers, and others.

title: Organometallic Chemistry
reviews: Attend all the classes and try to go over the notes to ensue better understanding after each class.
Great OM course.
If you like organometallic chemistry or want to learn about the history of chemistry from Paul this is the class for you. The workload is very light, but the material is somewhat challenging.

If you want to actually know how organometallics is the foundation of our world, take this course. :) It's not that hard of a class, actually (not that many problem sets, exams are interesting, lectures are all real-world examples).
Take it!
you will learn a lot about organometallic
prereqs: Open to senior undergraduates with permission of the instructor only..
descrip: To familiarize the student with basic principles of structure and reactivity of transition metal organometallic chemistry.

title: Advanced Language and Style
reviews: Absolutely take this course! Professor Weinapple is such a funny, interesting professor and the readings were, for the most part, short and helpful!

I think this class did a very good job of presenting a variety of Italian literary works, both poetry and prose.  The reading load was very manageable, and the professor was very understanding and approachable.  Definitely recommend this class to anyone interested in getting an overview of Italian literature.
Make sure you are prepared for the weekly class meetings! It will make the writing assignments easier and the class time will go by faster.
This is a great overview of Italian literature, not a lot of work readings/assignment-wise at all, and Fiorenza is amazing, sharp, and hilarious as always. Take it take it.
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200-level Italian course or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: We will concentrate on the textual analysis of literary texts from the beginning of Italian literature to the present. An intensive grammatical, syntactical, and rhetorical analysis of every piece will be conducted through class discussion. Students will be asked to prepare oral presentations on the authors studied, and to write short papers on each text.

title: Introduction to Machine Translation
reviews: A fun and unconventional COS class. Lots of freedom to do projects of your choosing. No exceptional programming background required but obviously the more the better.
Go to all of the lectures, and put effort into the final project. What you put into the final project is what you'll get out.
Great class.  Do it (it's more NLP than MT, but that's honestly more useful anyways...)
Have fun with the final project.
I Recommend if you have an interest in machine translation.

I would recommend that you take COS 126 and 226 or have equivalent experience. The focus of the course is not on programming so it seems a waste to struggle too much with that aspect of it. The final projects are really fun!
Take it if you're interested in natural language processing; there isn't really another NLP course at Princeton. Also it's a good course that gives a good survey of NLP.

This is a super good class if you like programming.  You do lots of natural language processing stuff, but you don't need to have taken LIN/TRA classes to like this class.
