Everything is a programming assignment, including midterm/final, and you can use your favorite programming language.  If you like programming, this is an excellent class to take.

Would highly recommend to anyone interested in language processing or machine translation. Does involve a little bit of coding, but Professor Bangalore is very flexible if you aren't familiar with coding!
You need more programming experience than just 126, or even 226. But the material is very interesting and useful.
prereqs: Students are required to have programming experience or should have completed COS126 (Introduction to Computer Science). TRA 200 is recommended (may be taken simultaneously)..
descrip: This course will provide an in-depth study of the MT paradigms (direct, transfer, statistical/example, and interlingual) used in state-of-the-art speech-to-speech and text-based MT systems, from computational and linguistic perspectives. Machine-learning techniques for processing human languages (morphological analysis, tagging, syntactic and semantic parsing, and language generation) will be discussed in detail. Linguistic variation across languages and its impact on computational models will be presented. Projects will involve implementing speech/text translation components, identifying their limitations and suggesting improvements.

title: Proseminar in Anthropology
descrip: This second half of a two-semester proseminar for first year graduate students in anthropology continues the exploration of major theoretical currents that inform the discipline. It will focus on the relation between theories of human action, consciousness, and disciplinary practices such as fieldwork, participant observation, translation, sense-making, and interpretation. Theorists or theories will often be paired with the reading of an ethnographic account inspired by them.

title: Gender, Sexuality, and Modernity in the Middle East
reviews: If you're interested in these issues or in the region then take the class but be aware that it's reading heavy and you are expected to do all of them
Really try to engage with all the readings, even though they can be a little tricky.

Take the readings seriously, do not slack on them because they inform the entire class discussion. However don't hesitate to ask questions about things you didn't understand or want to clarify. Go to office hours NO MATTER WHAT, Professor Pursley is extremely helpful and very down to earth so you won't feel super intimidated by her or walk away confused. Speak up in class not just for participation points, but to say something you actually think is valuable for the discussion and take notes during discussions as well.

Take this class if you have any interest in the subject matter! Professor Pursley is a wonderful professor, and you will learn a lot. That being said, be prepared for a lot of reading that, yes, you will be expected to have fully read and understood.
This course is not what you expect, which is not necessarily a bad thing. Be prepared to work hard and you'll get a lot out of it.

This is a fantastic course for both students who have never studied the Middle East or gender and sexuality as well as for students well-versed in these areas. I loved the class, the readings, Professor Pursley, and the seminar discussion environment - all of the students in the class were engaged, which made for great conversations, thoughtfully and carefully guided by Prof. Pursley. Overall a fantastic experience and a great way to finish out my time at Princeton.

This is not an introductory class into NES or GSS, but if you are interested and somewhat knowledgeable in either area, this will be a very interesting class to take. The readings are very manageable and the discussions are very interesting, covering crucial literature including Said and Foucault.
descrip: Muslim women's status has been a major concern in discussions of Western interventions in the Middle East, including the US invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq. Within the region, gender and sexuality have played a crucial role in nationalist movements and processes of state formation. What is the relation between women's rights, "tradition," and "modernity"? Why does the theme keep arising in debates over secularism and Islam? Are sexual identities linked to imperialism? What is a traditional Islamic family? And do Muslim women really need saving? This seminar will explore scholarly debates on these and other questions across the disciplines.

title: Biomolecular Engineering
reviews: Attend lectures because Professor Link does a great job at summarizing the papers.
Definitely recommend if you're interested in the biological aspect of CBE. A relatively easy upper level CBE course, good for fulfilling the program electives.
Definitely take this course if you have interest in the application of biology to engineering.
Definitely take this course. Prof. Link is a great lecturer, and the material is very engaging.
Don't take notes during lecture--they're posted on piazza and you'll get a lot more out of just listening and asking questions.
Go to lecture and pay attention! Even though Professor Link posts the notes online, make sure you copy them down yourself to learn and for clarity.
Go to lecture!
Great class. Very interesting material and the least quantitative CBE course.  Take if you like bio at all.
I think if you are interested in the material, it's a good class. Make sure to attend class.
If you're interested in the material, you should definitely take it! It's a good course that will be relevant to your work especially if you're doing any kind of bio-related research.
It is barely a CBE class. There are almost no equations used. Everything is just bio.
It's a low key survey course to biomolecular engineering
It's not the most engaging course, but the material is very interesting. Take it for an overview of Biomolecular Engineering.
Lighter workload; good overview of biomolecular engineering. More of a survey class than Brynildsen's more specific metabolic class.
Link is awesome and not like those other MOL professors. Make yourself get out of bed on Fridays because it is worth it.
Low commitment advanced CBE course.
Memorize everything for the quizzes, which are very detail-oriented.

Professor Link really knows what he's doing. It's quite a chill course (no psets), but don't slack off. The quizzes and exams are reasonable (as in, you're expected to be on top of your work). Would strongly recommend to anyone interested in this field. Really enjoyed it as a sophomore.
Take it! It's interesting. You'll learn lots of new techniques in engineering
Take it--it's interesting! and not too difficult.
The material is really interesting and Professor Link is great. Take it if you're interested in the topic!
This course focuses mostly on the conceptual side of several developing laboratory techniques and their potential applications. It's not quantitative.
descrip: This course will focus on the design and engineering of biomacromolecules. After a brief review of protein and nucleic acid chemistry and structure, we will delve into rational, evolutionary, and computational methods for the design of these molecules. Specific topics to be covered include aptamers, protein and RNA-based switches and sensors, unnatural amino acids and nucleotides, enzyme engineering, and the integration of these parts via synthetic biology efforts.

title: Reporting Inequality: The Media and the Marginalized
descrip: Introduction to reporting inequality and the major issues arising from its growth within and between societies. Students will develop an understanding of, and the tools to write and report on, inequality in their own societies and globally. Not merely in terms of dramatic events, but also through capturing the processes that drive inequality; and to do so by telling the story through the lives of ordinary, everyday people. Perspectives, tools, theories and writing assignments. Bi-weekly individual meetings with the professor.

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences II
descrip: A survey of fundamental papers in the Geosciences. Topics include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes in the ocean, geochemical cycles, orogenies, thermochronology, rock fracture and seismicity. This is the core geosciences graduate course.

title: East Asia since 1800
reviews: Attend lecture because the information there is more important than the textbook.
Attending all lectures and doing the readings will allow you to fully enjoy the class.  Not too hard when decent effort and attention is put in.  Would recommend for anyone, even busy BSE's.
Be prepared for lots of pages of reading, but very interesting material and great profs!
Definitely take this course if you need an HA! It is very interesting.
Do all of the readings. There are more readings then expected, but do them.

Do the readings, not just because it will help you understand, but because they are interesting and participating in class will make you think about the material in ways you haven't before. Precept discussions were great and Garon is an incredible lecturer. I highly recommend.
Great class! You have to work if you want an A, but material is very interesting
Highly recommend, material is interesting and Professors Garon and Bian were excellent.
I really enjoyed this class!  The workload is reasonable, and the material is really interesting.
If interested in Asia, a must-take with Professors Bian and Garon! Great instructors who make themselves readily available for students
If you want to pdf it, it's a good one to do it, although the readings are long! The material is very interesting.
Interesting class.
It is very interesting material, and Professor Garon is great, but be prepared for some harsh grading.

Recommend. Took for the non-western requirement for HIS department and really enjoyed it. Professor Bian and Garon were teaching. Maybe looking back I would have had an easier time with a course on the middle east or latin america for this particular requirement but don't regret taking it.
Take it. Lectures are phenomenal and very, very interesting. Good class to PDF too.
The time period is extremely interesting.  However, Korea is almost completely ignored.
This course is a great overview of early-modern to modern East Asian History, and the lecturers are amazing and the readings were very interesting! I highly recommend the course :)
This is definitely a course worth taking if you are interested in getting a broad introduction to the time period in East Asian history.
Very helpful in understanding Asian history!
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the history of modern East Asia. We will examine the inter-related histories of China, Japan, and Korea since 1800 and their relationships with the wider world. Major topics include: trade and cultural exchanges, reform and revolutions, war, colonialism, imperialism, and Cold War geopolitics.

title: Survey of Selected Works of Twentieth-Century Architects
reviews: Awesome course, not very much work. Kipnis may seem a bit rude at first but it's just his sense of humor and he's actually really caring.
Don't take offense to anything.
Don't take the class if you don't want to actively participate in the discussion, bringing in your own interests and ideas to the table.
Kipnis's teaching style isn't for everyone. Don't take this course if you aren't willing to go with his flow, which very rarely seems to actually be about architecture.
Pay attention
Recommend.
Take the class. It's fantastic. Jeff doesn't really teach you, but you learn a lot about yourself and how you work.
descrip: This course is intended to expose the students to a range of major works, built and unbuilt, of architecture from 1950 to the present. This course will focus on these particular buildings as they open themselves to a textual analysis. These analyses are intended to open up issues such as criticality, autonomy and singularity as they begin to evolve in architectural building (as opposed to texts) in the last half of the 20th century. This course will concentrate on individual buildings not architects. Each analysis will be accompanied by an illustrated presentation and selected readings.

title: Foundations of Political Economy
descrip: Course focuses on modeling the interaction of politics and economics, with applications to a variety of substantive areas. Topics include: poltics of taxation and redistribution; governmental structure, political economy of constitutional arrangements, development, and growth. Familiarity with microeconomic theory and POL 575 or the equivalent are prerequisites.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Maternal & Child Health: Culture, Controversy & Policy
descrip: Despite the oft-invoked credo of 'women and children first,' policies to promote and protect maternal and child health often seem to receive short shrift in the policy arena. This course explores contemporary issues in maternal and child health, with attention to both the evidence base for policies as well as the cultural norms and values that make strategies to keep mothers and babies healthy surprisingly controversial at times. The focus will be on the U.S., although the readings will include global perspectives and students may choose to focus their course papers on other societies.

title: Life on Mars - Or Maybe Not
descrip: See website

title: Advanced German
reviews: Professor Lande is amazing! I would suggest taking any course he offers! Not only is he extremely well versed with the material, but he is also a very kind and caring individual.
Take it if you want. I don't regret it.
Take it with Lande if you can. All classes should be like this.
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using texts, online media, and other sources as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included. Conducted in German.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Do not take

If you are interested in the project this course can be very interesting and rewarding. It is up to you to decide what you want to put into the course and therefore how much you can get out of the course. Overall the time commitment isn't very high.
Its a fun course!
Not hard but rewarding.
Take it!
Take this course if the projects in it interest you. It can be a very rewarding experience
prereqs: Completion of EGR 350.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Classical Japanese Prose
descrip: Reading of selected works, in diverse genres, from Heian and medieval Japan. The commentarial tradition will be acknowledged where there is one.

title: The Invention of the Promised Land: American Jewish History
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of reading!
Dweck is the man.
Professor Dweck is a lot of fun and is very engaging.
TAKE IT!!! Dweck is INCREDIBLE - by far the best professor you'll have at Princeton. Don't miss this class, or any with Dweck for that matter!!!!!!!!!!
Take it!
Take it! Very interesting and you get to learn about a very interesting subject that really gives you a look at American history that is very different than what you're used to.
Take this class. If every Jew in america had this course instead of hebrew school, I think Judaism in America would not be dying.

Take this course for a seminar with Dweck if you are willing to do the readings. It's a great introduction to American Jewish History and you'll walk away with a greater understanding of the history than merely a body of facts relating to it.
descrip: Over the past three and a half centuries Jewish immigrants have described America both as "the promised land" and "the land of impurity." This course examines these conflicting descriptions as it explores developments in Jewish life in America from the mid seventeenth century through the late twentieth century.

title: Math Alive
reviews: Definitely take it! Professor Griffiths is an amazing professor!
Definitely take this course!!! Ian is amazing--he is HILARIOUS, so smart, and really cares that you understand what's going on. The class made me like math, and I looked forward to lecture.
Do all the problem sets. Read the lecture notes. EFFORT plays a pivotal role in this class. He also appreciates a good attendance record.
Do not do partner projects.
Go ahead and take it. Make sure to stay on top of the problem sets.
Go to class! It will make the problem sets much more manageable!
Go to lecture and read the lecture notes as well.
Great for a distribution requirement.
Highly recommend if math is not your "thing".

I swore that I would never take math alive because of my own personal pride. I bailed from astro after a week and praise the good lord baby jesus I did because math alive was the smartest decision I made this year. Put in some effort and you won't need to PDF, really. Ian is super accommodating and just a generally good professor who is always willing to help. Seriously, have no shame and take this because you will actually learn something if you pay attention.
Ian has excellent pacing when he lectures. He answers all questions and is super receptive to all students. I could not recommend this class more highly.
If you are looking for an interesting and different QR that is not as math intensive, I would highly suggest this course.  Professor Griffiths is a fantastic teacher and always puts in 110%.
It's easy
It's pretty easy as long as you do the problem sets.
Math Alive is not too difficult, and Prof Griffiths is such a joy to be around. That said, it wasn't the most interesting class all the time.
Nice engaging class to take to fill a distribution requirement and it is very interesting.
Prof Griffiths is amazing!! Take anything you can with him!!
Professor Griffiths is great. This is a fairly easy, fun way to get a QR out of the way.
TAKE IT! Just make sure to actually do the work and attend lecture.
TAKE THIS COURSE
Take it if you need a QA.
Take it if you need a QR, and do actually do the p-sets and go to lecture when you can. It's not hard, but you need to actually do the required assignments.
Take it!
Take it! Go to lectures, Griffiths gives out extra points and doing the psets is hard if you don't because most material is not just something you can look up on Khan Academy.
Take this class!
Take this course, especially if you need a QR and aren't extremely comfortable with heavily quantitative things.
The class is great EXCEPT beware of the midterm (and final)--mine was graded surprisingly harshly and made me end up PDFing the class.
This course is great. Super engaging and problem sets are very manageable.

You do not need to go to all the lectures in order to do fairly well in the course. I feel like it is a better use of my time to teach myself the material or go to office hours since we often don't learn much in lecture.
go to class
it's a great QR, but if you aren't taking it for that reason, you probably should not take it.
take it if you need a QR
take this!
prereqs: This course is intended for non-science, non-engineering majors. When this course has closed, please email amainzer@princeton.edu to be placed on the waitlist..
descrip: Mathematics has profoundly changed our world, from the way we communicate with each other and listen to music, to banking and computers. This course is designed for those without college mathematics who want to understand the mathematical concepts behind important modern applications. The course consists of individual modules, each focusing on a particular application (e.g., digital music, sending secure emails, and using statistics to explain, or hide, facts). The emphasis is on ideas, not on sophisticated mathematical techniques, but there will be substantial problem-set requirements. Students will learn by doing simple examples.

title: Microeconomic Analysis of Domestic Policy
descrip: Examines a series of major issues of policy designed to illustrate and develop skills in particularly important applications of microeconomics. Topics will include education and training, the minimum wage, mandated benefits, affirmative action, the theory of public goods and externalities, and the basic theory of taxation. Prerequisite: 511b.

title: Masters and Movements of 20th-Century Photography
reviews: Start the papers early, especially the term paper.
Take this course if you'd like a good background on photography and famous photographers, and are invested enough in the subject that this background would be worthwhile.

professor really knows her stuff and the class is pretty informative and interesting; not a lot of work, just a longer final paper; only weekly work is attendance; all she wants is for you to take notes during class; readings aren't even that necessary
prereqs: This course does not require a background in art history, although previous coursework in twentieth-century art or history would be helpful..
descrip: By focusing on six major figures, this course examines the ways that photography was transformed from a poor stepchild of the fine arts to a staple of museum exhibitions. Students will consider such topics as the impact of abstraction on photography; the interactions between art photography and the new print and cinematic mass media; and development of photographic collections and criticism. The careers of Stieglitz, Moholy-Nagy, Weston, Walker Evans, Frank, and Jeff Wall will form springboards for broader discussions of photography's critical importance for twentieth-century thinking about the real and the imaginary.

title: Modern Methods for Organic Synthesis
reviews: Dedicate a lot of time to your presentations and try your best but don't try to be perfect because you can't be in the time allotted.
Keep up with the material.
prereqs: One full year of undergraduate organic chemistry.
descrip: This course exposes you to many types of carbon-based molecular structures, the transformations they undergo, and many kinds of chemical reactions and strategies that are important to the field of organic synthesis. Recent advances in asymmetric catalysis, cascade and other complexity-generating structural transformations, and powerful strategies for chemical synthesis that evolved from ideas about the structural origins of important, biologically active molecules such as steroid hormones, cofactors, and alkaloids are addressed.

title: Screenwriting for a Global Audience
reviews: TAKE IT!

TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Lazaridi is incredible personable, knowledgable about how to tell a good story, and kind. You will learn so much about where storytelling, as well as our society, is headed with new technologies. There is also a very manageable amount of work (2 10-15 page screenplays and about 6 web articles to read every week). One of the best classes offered at Princeton!
Take it!
Take it! You get to explore a lot of things you might not get to explore creatively in other classes?there's a technology/psychology focus that's particularly interesting.
Whether you're just beginning to write or have been writing, I definitely recommend this class to anyone who is interested in writing. The course will take off!
prereqs: By application only (no pre-requisites).
descrip: How can screenwriters prepare for the evolving challenges of our global media world? What types of content, as well as form, will emerging technologies make possible? Do fields like neuroscience help us understand the universal principals behind screenwriting and do tech advances that alter the distance between audience and creator, man and machine, also influence content of our stories? This class will use fairytales, films, games and new media to illustrate universal script principles while creating a rich interdisciplinary lens to explore the innovative intersection of narrative screenwriting, science and technology.

title: Problems in Indo-European Linguistics - Introduction to Vedic Sanskrit
descrip: An introduction to Vedic Sanskrit, specifically for graduate students in Classics and anyone else with a solid foundation in Greek and Latin. Emphasis will be on acquiring knowledge through reading some of the 1,028 remarkable hymns of the Rig Veda, the oldest and most important text in the Indic tradition. The direction the class takes will depend to some extent on the interests of the participants, but we will certainly pay regular attention to the Indo-European background of the language and to potential correspondences between Indic literature and Greek.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: The Literature of Gastronomy
reviews: A great LA to take!
Awesome class. Really fun and not a lot of work. Great 5th class to take. Easiest class I've taken here at Princeton.
Definitely take it! Interesting course, relatively light workload.
Definitely take this course-- light workload, allows you to approach readings, food, and history in a different way, and a great 5th class
Do all the readings and take notes on them, the readings are incredibly - engage them and enjoy
Do the reading they are actually interesting
Do the readings and pay attention in precept.
Don't take it.
Don't take this class. You learn absolutely nothing and the grading is really arbitrary between precepts. If you do take it, don't take it with Daniela.
Easy PDF class
Easy PDF. Didnt read one page of one reading. Lectures horribly boring. Waste of time but perfect filler class.
Focus on precept and the readings
Go for it!
Good class

Great class to take when you want to enhance your knowledge about a subject that you may not have previously known about. Prof. Frassica is truly at the top of his field, and it is an honor to be his student.
Great course!
I enjoyed it, but I would advise you to take it as a distribution requirement, not as a serious class.
I recommend this class to all students interested in Italian culture or food.

I took this class because I heard it was an easy LA, but it was still unbearably painful to get through when pdfing. I couldn't even bring myself to go to precept by the end. There are definitely more interesting and easy LAs you can take.
I would certainly recommend this course to other students interested in Italian culture.
I would definitely recommend this course for anyone who needs an easy LA and is interested in learning more about Italian food, culture, and history.
I would suggest to keep up with the readings.

If you actually do the reading, which doesn't take long, you'll get a good grade without a problem. Make sure you take the class with friends though because it's much more fun that way. Otherwise it might be slightly painful, as the subject matter isn't particularly riveting.
It is a great course to take. For me, it was a break from science courses so I loved focusing on a new discipline!
It is more about Italian literature in general (we read excerpts from books in English translation), with food being a theme in each of them amongst others. (don't expect to learn how to cook).
It's fun and pretty relaxed.
It's honestly not worth doing it in Italian unless it's your mother tongue. The readings are just too long and difficult for that to be worth it. Just take it in English.
Its an easy LA
Make sure you do the readings that way when the exams come you can do superbly.
Not much work, so if you need an LA, it's worth considering.
Start the weekly readings early, and highlight important quotes. They are valuable to know for the midterm and the final.

Super chill class. Good to PDF. Lectures are boring, but they take attendance (so you can always sign in with your preceptor and leave or just stay and not pay attention). Precepts are worth going to because that's where must of the material is covered. The readings are generally interesting and easy to skim. Only a few lectures where they serve a tiny bit of food. And during the last lecture everyone cooks food in groups and you can walk around to eat other people's food.
TAKE THIS COURSE
Take it for an LA.
Take it for an easier and more fun LA!
Take it for sure, do the readings at some point before the exams.
Take it!
Take it! It's chill and interesting.
Take it, it's easy

Take this class because it will open your eyes to significance of food in literature from all over the world. Our experiences are intimately tied to food, and a class like this will help to illuminate these connections.
Take this class. Very good class that you can get a lot out of without stressing too much.
Take this course!
Treat this class with more respect than a lot of students give it.
don't take it
easy class
i recommend if you need an LA
its okay - not that rewarding
take it for an easy 5th class
take it, fun times
prereqs: Prerequisite: 200-level course in Italian is only required for Italian precept..
descrip: This course studies Italian novels and short stories in English translation, works of visual art, and films which thematize food as reality and metaphor, examining how eating functions within ideological and mythological structures of modern society. Topics will include 'Futurist' cuisine as an aesthetic experience and a prophetic vision, writing during the war, and sublime and erotic cuisine.

title: Water, Energy, and Ecosystems
reviews: Ask lots of questions TA/professor are extremely approachable and helpful with projects.
Be prepared to work hard, but the work is totally worth it. This was probably my favorite class taken at Princeton thus far.
Definitely take this, or any class with Kelly. He's honestly inspirational and really great. Keita is awesome too!!
Do it.
Don't get discouraged by MatLab!
prereqs: MAT 201.
descrip: This three-week course, offered as part of a four-course study abroad semester, takes place at Princeton University's Mpala Research Centre in central Kenya. The course will provide an introduction to the principles of hydrological sciences through the development and application of instrumentation for characterizing surface/subsurface hydrological dynamics in field settings. Lectures and field activities will address the theory of operation, design, and implementation of methods used to quantify hydrological patterns and processes.

title: Late Victorian Literature: Decadence and Rebellion
descrip: This course studies the literature of the last decades of the Victorian era, often referred to as the fin de siecle (or end of the century). It will focus on literary, cultural, and social developments in the final years of the nineteenth century and first years of the twentieth, among them aestheticism, decadence, literary naturalism, imperialism, socialism, the arts and crafts movement, and the "woman question." Authors to be considered include Wilde, Hardy, Conrad, Pater, Schreiner, Shaw, Hopkins, Bridges, Kipling, Morris, Gissing, and Stevenson.

title: Narrative Film: Working from the Script
reviews: It's best to already have a knowledge base of editing software/shooting practice before coming into the class.
Su's great -- take the class if you're interested in filmmaking and actually are going to work.
prereqs: Either VIS 261/262 (Intro) or VIS 263 (Documentary) or VIS 264 (Narrative) or VIS 362 (Intermediate) and self-sufficiency in film editing software, either Premiere CS6 or Final Cut 7..
descrip: A script is only the beginning. Then come the interesting decisions: the actors, the visual style, and the sound design. In this class, each student will be given one segment of a script which they can interpret in any way they choose. Will your part be done as a film noir? A musical? Will it be shot in black and white? Acted in the nude? Reimagined as a documentary? At the end of the term, all the segments will be strung together to make a complete film--a surprising collage of everyone

title: The Universe
reviews: Attend lecture and do the psets, and you'll do just fine. The material is easy enough that simply taking the time to see it at lecture each week is a guarantee of a decent final grade.
Avoid if possible.
Beware the long problem sets. Interesting topics but most lectures were not required for problem set completion. Decent fifth class for an engineer.
Definitely and interesting course!

Definitely take it if you are looking for a QR. The material is interesting, the math is very simple, and it's not too much work (just one problem set very two weeks and a midterm and a final). If you PDF it, it will barely add much work to your schedule, and even if you don't, you can still get a good grade without too much work.
Don't buy the textbook. It's not required. Unless that changes. Pay attention to lecture.
Don't.
Easy fifth class for an engineer. Problem sets are easy (although a bit tedious) and exams are totally doable. Basically like high school physics.
Good luck! And work hard!
Great course!
Great course!!! A must-take!
I recommend this course to students who have an interest in the subject matter.
I wasn't too interested in the material, but do take if you are as the psets are easy and exams not too hard.
I would advise a student taking this course to pay special attention to the mathematical formulas needed to complete the assignments and exams.

If you are interested in astro and want a class that is not very demanding, it's a good choice. The math is extremely easy (almost all one-step plug and chug calculations). If you take this class seriously you can do very well in it.
If you have any sort of physics background, you should do well in this course.
If you have no science background, it definitely isn't the easiest QR because of all the engineers in the class, but if you have a physics background, this is a great fifth class.
Interesting subject matter and lively, engaging professors. If I could do it over again, I would probably PDF it because the P-Sets and exams just weren't worth the hassle.
It's a very relaxed, fun class to take. Be careful that there are a ton of engineers who take it, so change the curve a bit.
It's not as easy as some may say. But it's fun, especially if you can form a study group.
More math than I expected
One of the most interesting courses I've taken here.
Read the book.
Set aside time for this class, but don't expect it to be super engaging.
Start the problem sets early.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. Go to lectures because you won't have the opportunity to learn about Astronomy from a few of the leading scientists in the world in this field again!
Take it!
Take it! It's super interesting, but not a complete joke as some people say. Problem sets can take a while, but the problems on them are actually pretty interesting.
Take it! Problem sets aren't too bad, but don't skip too many lectures or you will get behind.
Take it. It's awesome! Plus it's close to latemeal, so why not?
Take this class if you want to learn about space. It's not difficult, and the material is cool.
Take this if you want a good overview of what the universe means and holds.
Taking a physics course prior to this may be helpful.
The professors are great and the material isn't too bad--take it!
This is a fascinating class in which you learn a lot about how amazing our universe is.  The math could be challenging if you haven't done it in a while, but put in the effort, it really is worth it!
This is a great class to take. It is a broad and thorough overview of many topics in astrophysics, so covers a lot of very different subjects.

This is a great course if you're trying to fulfill the Math QR requirement and want a course that is a little more interesting than a calculus class. Make sure to invest time in the problem sets, and do study for the tests! Do the readings, they were the most rewarding part of the course for me.
This is a great intro course if you're interested in astronomy but don't have a background in physics or calculus.
This is a nice course if you like Astronomy. It was more in depth than I expected but that was a positive for me since I am interested in astronomy.
This is an excellent class.  The subject matter is fascinating.
This is not your typical stars for stoners class. It's actually a lot of time and work.
VERY interesting.  All you really need is a small background in chem or physics but no in-depth knowledge required at all
kj
prereqs: This course is intended for humanities and social science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful..
descrip: This specially designed course targets the frontier of modern astrophysics. Subjects include the planets of our solar system, the birth, life, and death of stars; the search for extrasolar planets and extraterrestrial life; the zoo of galaxies from dwarfs to giants, from starbursts to quasars; dark matter and the large-scale structure of the universe; Einstein's special and general theory of relativity, black holes, neutron stars, and big bang cosmology. This course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry. High school physics would be useful.

title: The Mathematics of Magic Tricks & Games
descrip: See website

title: Workshop on Social Organization
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work is at the intersection of the fields of organization studies, economic sociology and social network analysis. In addition to covering foundational readings in these fields and addressing selected special topics (e.g. social organizational aspects of economic crisis), the workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

title: Stars and Star Formation
reviews: A worthwhile course. It's not easy, but it's definitely not as difficult as other physics courses (sometimes needlessly) are.
Definitely go to office hours, do the assigned readings if at all possible (it is a lot, and very dense), ask questions in and out of class.
I would recommend this class for astro majors to take as a departmental.

If you are an astro major you pretty much have to take this class, so enjoy it.  Make sure you keep your old problem sets because the exams are open book.  If you're a physics major who wants to take an astro class this is a good choice, but you might also enjoy 301 (General Relativity) or 401 (Cosmology) as well.  Expect a workload that's a little easier than Quantum or Death Mech.

If you're particularly interested in stars or you need the class to fulfill a requirement and the alternative is another upper level physics class, take this one.  The material can be dense and confusing at times, and isn't always particularly interesting, but there's helpful material available from a lot of secondary sources and the textbook is pretty good, too.  One of the most helpful things you can do is talk to Draine and Burrows one on one since they're both quite helpful in office hours and seem to explain things better in that context.

It's really interesting and taught reasonably well. Sometimes the professors assume you know more than you actually do, but if you ask questions, they'll answer well (Burrows loves answering people's questions!). Start problem sets earlier than the day before, that way, you can go to office hours and get help!
Take it, it's an awesome intro to stars and the galaxy
take it if you can, great homework/exam structure, awesome professors and you actually learn stuff
descrip: Stars form by the gravitational collapse of interstellar gas clouds, and as they evolve, return some of their gas to the interstellar medium, altering its physical state and chemical composition. This course discusses the properties and evolution of the gaseous and stellar components of a galaxy: the theory and observations of star formation; stellar structure; the production of energy by nucleosynthesis; stellar evolution; stellar end states; and the interpretation of observations of the diffuse and dense interstellar medium. We will discuss how major telescopes and space missions might tackle these problems.

title: Intermediate Turkish II
prereqs: TUR 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: To enable students to communicate in Modern Turkish, and to read Turkish (current events, editorials, literature and academic writings) with some speed and accuracy.

title: Twentieth-Century French Popular Music
reviews: Absolutely take it! Professor Wampole is the coolest teacher you will ever have and the material is super interesting.

Definitely take it if you are interested in French of music. Even if you don't have much experience with music, it is still accessible and a welcome change from very reading-heavy classes. The music video project at the end was enjoyable but also different than anything I had done before.
Definitely take this course. You're sure to make extreme progress with your French speaking and comprehension.
Enjoy, take risks! Seize this opportunity!
Great fun course, but a lot of work day to day (blackboard posts). Definitely worth it
Practice your French grammar, this class is harder than a 200-level course.

Start working on the midterm paper early. The prompt is available right at the beginning of the semester, try to use it to collect ideas/supporting elements throughout the entire semester to make the writing process easier.
Super fun! Christy Wampole is great!

Take it! Christy is so great and the class is super fun. It's a great way to get exposed to a lot of awesome French music.
Also don't leave the midterm essay for the last minute.
Take this course if you're already fluent in French, if you're still trying to attain fluency probably don't take it

This is a good course to take if you're interested in French pop music. The majority of classes are conducted in a lecture-style. Prof. Wampole is really nice once you get to know her. The listening assignments are tedious, but overall the workload for this course is really manageable.
prereqs: Completed 100-level language sequence..
descrip: This media-based survey of popular music in twentieth-century France traces the evolution of music culture through intensive listening to the most influential artists from 1900 to 2014, through recorded and printed interviews with musicians, songwriters, producers, and critics, and through the analysis of music videos and blogs. Beginning with the early music hall performers to contemporary experimentations in electronic music, hip hop, and hybrid forms, the course constructs the genealogy of influence between musicians and raises questions about commercial interests, politics, and authenticity.

title: Senior Thesis with Design
descrip: Similar to 442 with the principle difference that the thesis must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior thesis with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Utopias, Dystopias, and Manifestos
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Financial Management in the Corporate and Public Sectors
descrip: Designed to introduce graduate students in public and international affairs to certain principals and analytic tools widely used in the financial management of organizations, privately or publicly owned. Course is based on the premise that future civil servants should be familiar with this subject matter, either because they may be involved in the financial management of public agencies, or negotiate financial contracts with the private sector, or regulate financial management in the private sector.

title: Integrated Building Studios
reviews: Don't be lazy.
Get ready to get your hands dirty
Take the course, be self-driven, appreciate / make use of the open and helpful feedback that Jesse and Michael can offer
be self-motivated, dont expect to be told what to do
descrip: Integrated design studios approach architecture from a synthetic perspective. Considerations of structure, environmental technology, building materials and systems, exterior envelope, and site design are integrated directly into the design process through the participation of technical faculty and outside advisors in critiques and reviews. Projects are developed to a high level of detail. At least one course is required for professional M.Arch. students.

title: Southeast Asia's Global History
reviews: Do the readings, because they are interesting. make sure to go to office hours
Laffan's great, take it if you're interested in the topic

Professor Laffan is an absolutely fantastic lecturer. The reading may look intimidating, but it's not much more than what other history courses assign. This was my favorite course this semester, and if you have any interest in learning about a heavily colonized part of the world, you should take this.

The topic of Southeast Asia is very interesting, and one that really isn't covered in any other course at Princeton. I would suggest taking it if you have any interest in that region at all, and you should.
descrip: This course aims to provide an introduction to Southeast Asia and its prominent place in global history through a series of encounters in time; from Marco Polo in Sumatra to the latest events in such buzzing cities as Bangkok, Jakarta and Hanoi. For the early modern period we will read various primary sources, before turning to consider a series of diverse colonial impacts across the region (European, American and Asian), and then the mechanisms underpinning the formation of some of the most vibrant, and sometimes turbulent, countries on the world stage.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Accounting
reviews: Be prepared for problem-solving by yourself.
Good in that it is not a standard/typical corporate finance course.
Great.
It assumes some basic accounting and corporate finance knowledge. I would recommend taking 1-2 basic courses in corporate finance and accounting before taking this class.
Not pure corporate finance class, but a more macroeconomic view of corporate finance
Take it
Yes if you want to do corporate finance in a quantitative way
really spend time on the cases as you learn the most from them
descrip: Major topics in modern corporate finance. We will study investment policy (investment decision rules, project valuation, cost of capital) and financial policy (mostly capital structure decisions). Additional topics (private equity, bankruptcy and reorganization, merger and acquisitions) will be covered if time permits.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Seniors only (except for juniors who have completed EGR 351)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Special Topics in the History of Philosophy - Galen's Outline of Empiricism
descrip: We will be reading closely Galen?s work `Outline of Empiricism?, a work which survives only in Latin translation. The work deals with the movement in Ancient Medicine known as `Empiricism?, and we will spend some time looking at this medical theory, comparing it to the other rival medical theories, namely Rationalism and Methodism. In addition, we will survey preceding ancient empiricist epistemologies, including Aristotle, the Stoics and Epicureans.

title: Logic - Logical Philosophy of Science
descrip: This seminar will look at how mathematical logic has been, and can be, employed in the philosophy of science. It focuses on the work of Carnap, Reichenbach, Hempel, Putnam, and van Fraassen. (There will be enough real logic that Philosophy graduate students can earn a logic unit with this seminar.)

title: Advanced Topology
prereqs: MAT365 or departmental permission..
descrip: This will be an introduction to knot theory, with a special emphasis on modern knot theory invariants. We will cover in detail grid homology for knots. Further topics will include the Alexander polynomial, the Jones polynomial, and perhaps Khovanov homology.

title: Geomicrobiology
prereqs: Undergraduates who have taken GEO 331 or GEO 417/428 or who can convince the instructor that they have adequate geochemical and microbiological training are welcome..
descrip: High throughput sequencing has transformed environmental microbiology, but dealing with the massive datasets is daunting. This course familiarizes students with the approaches used in assembly and annotation of metagenomes, single-cell genomes and metatranscriptomes, metaproteomes and how to utilize the processed data to address phylogenetic and functional diversity in the environment. The course uses a combination of lectures, readings drawn from the literature, and hands-on processing of genomic datasets using MG RAST, IMG, MetaVelvet, MetaIDBA, MOTHUR, MEGAN etc. among others

title: Intermediate Arabic II
reviews: Absolutely take this course. The Arabic program at Princeton is great and I have enjoyed all of the professors I've had, but with that said, Tarek has been my absolute favorite. Take his class if you can. I actually looked forward to waking up and having Arabic as my first class every morning. Besides the fact that it's just fun to be in his class, everything from my writing to my pronunciation has definitely improved this semester! I cannot emphasize this enough: TAKE TAREK'S CLASS.

Arabic is not the type of language I would suggest taking in a Princeton setting. It's impossible to get the amount of practice you need and the coursebook used is bad. The instructors are great and certainly do the best they can with the material but if you actually want to learn Arabic it will be basically impossible (or at least much more difficult than it has to be) at Princeton.
Eva is great and really cares about her students!
It's a lot of work! If you enjoy the language, do it!
It's a lot of work, but rewarding and class time can actually be kind of fun
Take it with Tarek, and take the class if you're willing to put in work but interested in Arabic!

Take this course, especially with Tarek. You will not meet another professor with the same enthusiasm and care for his students. As a native speaker, he has a unique ability to help students with their colloquial speaking and listening comprehension. Vocab quizzes can be annoying especially as the number of words increases, but do your best to begin to learn them a few days before the quizzes. Exams are fair, straightforward, and not too challenging.
Tarek is a great professor, and appreciate his sense of humor. Go to all of the classes and try because it can be a very fun and engaging class.
Tarek's the best! He really cares that you learn, and he makes class really enjoyable.
prereqs: ARA 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Study of Arabic grammar and syntax, and use of the language in functional contexts. Reading of extra material from articles, newspapers, short stories. Discussions are held in the Arabic language to enhance the students' speaking skills.

title: Elementary Modern Greek II
reviews: Great professor, good class, but don't kid yourself--Greek is hard. You really need a desire to learn it for this to be good.
Greek is a wonderful language, and Prof. Kantzou is a wonderful teacher. Take this class!

I recommend this course to any people interested in learning Modern Greek. You will learn the basics for every-day life interactions, and benefit from the experience of an enthusiast native speaker. The emphasis is laid on every-day life, which can be very useful if you plan to live in Greece for a few months, for work or research.
Modern Greek is a beautiful language, which I highly recommend learning.
n/a
prereqs: HLS 101 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: To provide the basis for acquiring a command of written and spoken Modern Greek.

title: Social Structure in Africa: Responses to Socio-Political and Economic Forces
reviews: I would definitely recommend taking this course just for the quality of the class discussion alone. Professor Agawu is an excellent professor and care deeply about not only African studies but also her students.
If you're interesting in African Studies, take it!!!!

TAKE IT!!! it is honestly amazing. 

I honestly think this should be a required course for those who are thinking of going into development (politics or WWS) or foreign policy in general.
Take this class. Be prepared for the readings and discussions
The more of the reading you do, the easier and more interesting you will find it to engage in class.

This is a course you should not miss out on. The professor is great and so are the discussions. The three hours of this seminar seem to fly by because the discussions are so great. The topic and readings are also very interesting. I would recommend doing all of the readings before coming to class because of how discussion heavy the class is and because the readings are generally very good.
prereqs: No previous knowledge of Africa is required..
descrip: This seminar addresses structural responses and strategies developed by African nations and communities upon their insertion into the global political and economic world. What are these structural strategies? What traditional and or modern resources have African nations and communities utilized? Themes to be investigated include political, social and religious structures; global economic interaction; and women in society. The character of Africa before modern nationhood will form the backdrop to discussions of Africa as we know it today.

title: Freud on the Psychology of Ordinary Mental Life
descrip: See website

title: Intermediate Chinese II
reviews: Focus on the study guides they give you -- memorize the vocab for each lesson as early as possible

Have fun, and stay involved in class. Debate your teachers (in a lighthearted way) and get to know them. But I hope you do it because you enjoy Chinese, because I feel like this course would be a grid if I didn't.
I would take this course if you genuinely want to learn Chinese. The course is very well taught, but you need to be self-motivated to get the most out of it.
It's hard. Be prepared to spend a lot of time every day reviewing, otherwise you'll drown.
Learn your grammar structures!
Most of you have probably taken Chinese before and know what you courses here are like. It's more of the same, which is very effective and good!
Preview the lessons otherwise class might be awkward sometimes. Very good class though and there is no department I have encountered thus far that puts so much effort in their students' learning.
Stay on top of your work!!! Don't get behind, and learn every lesson when you're working on it in class.. it will help you when it comes time for the tests!
Study hard, and study early to keep up with everything.

Studying Chinese will require a few hours of preparation before every class. You will learn the language if you put in the effort. This not an easy class, but it can be very satisfying as you see your growth in the language skills.
Take it if you are interested in learning Chinese and are willing to put in a lot of work.
The Princeton Chinese program is excellent, but it's also very dependant on what you put in. If you're willing to do the studying and work necessary, you get a huge amount out of second year.
This course is high demanding, take another language unless you are willing to sell your soul
This language is not worth the work unless you plan to study it for a long time/go to China

Through this course you will learn a lot of useful vocabulary and grammar, and your pronunciation will definitely improve. Your listening skills and writing skills will improve. Your ability to speak conversationally will likely not improve so much, given that not as much of a focus is put on speaking. Classes are structured mostly around repetition and drill; however, more complex topics relating to Chinese history and society are introduced in this class (not so much present in CHI 105), so that does make classes more interesting. Teachers generally outstanding and enthusiastic (especially Peng Laoshi and Chen Laoshi).
Work hard, but don't worry if your grades aren't too good--you'll be learning a lot no matter what!
don't take it unless you are committed, its a huge time commitment
prereqs: CHI 105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Continuing the intensive study of modern spoken and written Chinese, this course shifts the emphasis to the reading of modern cultural and social issues.

title: Quantitative Analysis IV
descrip: This course will introduce Bayesian statistics and machine learning. The first half of the course will cover the basics of Bayesian statistical analysis, including linear models, hierarchical models, and missing data models. The EM algorithm and Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms will be implemented. In the second half of the course, we will cover recent methods in statistical learning. Possible topics include variable selection, smoothers, regression trees, support vector machines, topic models, belief nets, and deep learning. The course will be taught at the level of Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective by Kevin Murphy.

title: Preserving the Past
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Macroeconomics
reviews: Econ majors must take it, though it will be quite dull. Great to take during a semester in which you are taking other macro-focused econ courses.

If you are an Econ major, you have to take this class so you might as well just be optimistic and do the best you can. It's not going to be the most engaging class you'll take at Princeton and at times it will be very frustrating because of how disorganized it is, but such is life. I would recommend this class over the math-based version (311). Get through the problem sets by reading the textbook, working with friends, and going to office hours to review answers (can't stress enough the importance of office hours). Prepare for the exams by doing practice exams, reviewing your psets and lecture notes, and going to the review sessions/office hours. You'll get through it.
If you find the lectures to dull or very boring the class follows the textbook very closely.
If you're an econ major you have to take it. I would read the textbook and learn the concepts that way as lecture was not helpful

Lectures are very boring! you wouldn't be missing much if you didn't go and just did the readings from the book and the lecture slides (after they are posted). But if you would enjoy the material, do the readings and then go. You have to take this course if you're an econ major, so make the most out of it.
Make sure to go to office hours anytime you are confused about the material.
Make sure to keep up with readings and go to office hours.
Make sure you're invested in this course before taking it. Lectures are boring and monotonous.
Meh
Read the textbook
Read the textbook, go to office hours for psets
Take for Econ requirement. Not too difficult to do well if you self study the book/powerpoints.
Take if you have to. Not much fun.
Take it if you have to.
Very poorly taught.
You have to take this course-- not difficult, but lectures are painfully boring.
You need to take it, it's not that bad
expect precepts to be very unhelpful so make sure you go to lecture and pay attention because no precept will help you
make sure you understand the slides extremely well
only take it if you have to
only take this course if you're an Econ major that needs the distribution requirement.
you have no choice whether you take this course or not, so why fight it?
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101..
descrip: This course covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. We will focus on the determination of macroeconomic variables -- such as output, employment, price, and the interest rate -- in the short, medium, and long run, and we will address a number of policy issues. We will discuss several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Contemporary Society, Politics, and Culture
reviews: Do the readings- they are really interesting.

It is a great opportunity to be in an even smaller class environment that the lower level classes.  You will learn about aspects of German culture you never knew about and will do it in an interesting way.
Take it. Especially if Professor Nagel is leading the course. Only reason I'd tell someone not to take it is if they don't speak German.
The subject matter is really interesting and Professor Nagel is fantastic.

This class was highly enjoyable and extremely effective as a conversation course for students coming out of the language sequence, as well as more advanced students. If you have the chance to take the course with Barbara Nagel, absolutely do! I really appreciated having a professor with native cultural knowledge of contemporary Germany for this course.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: This course traces German history and culture from 1945 to the present by examining, in a variety of media, the period's most heated debates: first, the controversy around the aftermath of Nazi rule, which escalated in the 60s and 70s in violent clashes between students and government; second, the ideological rivalry between two German states up to the reunification; third, the persistent struggles around multiculturalism; fourth, the debate around Germany's role in Europe, and why Germany is equally loved and hated by its neighbors. This course facilitates advanced competence in written and oral German.

title: Advanced Physical Chemistry: Chemical Dynamics and Thermodynamics
reviews:
If taught by Professor Torquato, lectures will be very interesting and engaging. He really wants students to understand, but will try to make you understand yourself. Be prepared to answer questions in class. However, Professor Wang was very helpful for providing balance for the course, guidance through problem sets, and in grading the exams and psets reasonably. In addition, the midterm exam was very challenging because up to the middle of the semester the problem sets were book problems that were fairly easy and very different from the midterm, and no practice exam or problems were given. 
That being said, you will likely come out okay in the class if you have a background in multi, you go to lectures (essential), and you are engaged and go to office hours. I would recommend this class overall, as I really appreciated seeing the math and theoretical aspect behind thermodynamics.

On a week to week basis, it's just your average STN class with an average, maybe even below average workload, (less than 306). However, around exam time, be prepared to work. Actually make sure you understand the lectures the week they're given. The exams (pretty difficult) are on a whole other level compared to psets (which were relatively easy). Study hard and be prepared to work, but you'll learn a lot about thermo and other phenomena.

Take this course if you are interested in a more mathematical introduction to thermodynamics. Ask about the relevance of the topics to your fields of interest. Having applications in mind will help motivate your studies. Unless you are willing to ask questions, you may have a hard time learning in this course.
prereqs: MAT 201 or equivalent. Some knowledge of thermodynamics is useful. This course is open to freshmen and sophomores only with instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is an introduction to statistical thermodynamics, kinetics, and molecular reaction dynamics. Following a review of classical thermodynamics, the statistical mechanics of molecular systems is developed. Discussions of transport properties, chemical kinetics, and reaction dynamics form the rest of the course.

title: Religion in the Americas Workshop
prereqs: REL 523.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. Designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Topics in American Literature - Mapping NYC Modernism: Lit. and Art
reviews: The best course I've taken at Princeton- just wish I could take it again

This was an overall incredible course! It was quite difficult at times, especially with the amount of reading and writing that we had to do, but it was well worth it. Professor Ball is incredible, and the class is unlike many at Princeton. The level of feedback that he gives on written work is very constructive. If this class is ever offered at Princeton again, i would highly recommend people to take it!
descrip: The years 1880-1930 overturned much of the settled ground of art and literature. Cities accelerated these changes by bringing together disparate racial, ethnic, and artistic communities, nowhere more so than in New York. Through a study of multicultural literature and the arts, we will begin to map the role the city itself played in these transformative years. We will also travel to the sites that made these narratives possible--including extensive study of the holdings from our own museum collection--engaging in experiential learning about the modern period and studying the lasting aftereffects of modernism on the city in the 21st century.

title: The 20th-Century French Novel
reviews: Best French class ever -- Professor Trezise really challenged me intellectually and even though the readings were very challenging, I learned incredible things about literary analysis and 20th century literary movements.

I definitely recommend this course for anyone who has only been exposed to more classical French writing in literature courses at Princeton.  The reading load was usually very manageable, and all of the books were very interesting in their own way.

I would take this course if you have a strong interest in literature; however, as one of only a few non-FRE/COM/ENG majors in the class I was definitely at a disadvantage. The papers definitely made me a better lit-analysis writer, though, and the seminars themselves were interesting discussions.
Okay class, but not great.  Somehow even though it could be interesting discussion seemed to fall flat, and some of the readings were a bit too bizarre for people to get excited about.

Professor Trezise is very kind and welcoming, just make sure you analyze and write well because he does not sugarcoat!  Still, you have the opportunity to revise and talk to him, so it really isn't too bad.  Make sure to participate.
Your French should be pretty good
prereqs: One 200-level French literature course..
descrip: A study of major French and Francophone novels of the twentieth century.

title: Dissertation Seminar
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. The seminar aims at assisting students in the research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students will make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. It will meet for two hours each week throughout the academic year.

title: Illusions, Delusions, and Neuroscience
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Policy Aspects of Federal and State Budgeting and Fiscal Decision-Making
reviews: Great class. I really enjoyed it and learned a lot about budgeting. Professor is extremely fair to both liberal and conservative arguments and likes discussion which I really appreciated.
Phenomenal. Take it.
Professor Keevey is awesome-very helpful, and extremely knowledgeable about the subject. If you are interested in this subject matter, I'd recommend this class. Workload is rather light.

Strongly recommend to anyone in any department. Not only is the course material something everyone should have some level of understanding of (it will certainly make you a much more informed citizen), but Professor Keevey is also one of the most experienced experts on the topic matter. He is also one of the most considerate and approachable professors I have met thus far in Princeton.
Take it. Professor Keevey is really a fantastic professor.
Take it. Really easy grader. Material is interesting enough.

This is an easier course, as Professor Keevey is the nicest guy. He claims to "rarely give below a B , let alone a B." May be a bit boring, but I've learned so much about budgeting on every level of government.
descrip: The course will discuss key aspects of federal and state budgetary decision-making and its impact on policy. The course will examine budgeting, taxation, bond financing, pensions and long-term debt and its impact on future spending patterns. It will examine implications of the recent confrontation over budget in Washington and what it means for the future. While the federal government spends more money than any other enterprise, states and local governments in the aggregate spend just as much and thus the course will consider the significant financial differences between the two levels of government and the impact both have on our economy.

title: French Theater
reviews: I was really nervous about taking this class, but it was not intimidating. I thought discussions were riveting and I really enjoyed all the plays we read. If you are looking for an upper level French class, take this!
If you are interested in reading French plays than this is the course to take.

This is a solid class that features some really wonderful plays from the French tradition as well as a relaxed environment. I would not have appreciated the works we read nearly as much without the guidance of Professor Schroder. Use a dictionary to look up the words you don't know, especially in the first few weeks of the course, to ensure that you understand and stay engaged in the early plays, whose language tends to be harder to grasp because of its dissimilarity from present-day spoken French.
prereqs: A 200-level French course or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Masterpieces of French comedy from the beginnings to the present, studied within their political, social and cultural contexts. Readings will include a variety of plays as well as excerpts from critical and theoretical texts, and will be supplemented by videos of recent stage versions and cinematic adaptations.

title: Cell Biology and Development
reviews: Be prepared to put time in ahead of times in order to fully understand the readings and to be able to discuss them well.

Comments intended for undergraduates.  Some weeks, you will read 6  papers.  In addition, revisiting Alberts and Gilberts is extremely helpful.  MOL 348 is more than sufficient preparation for MOL 506, so if you liked MOL 348, I would recommend 506.  Sometimes Prof. Schedl references his genetics graduate course.  Don't let this worry you; you learned about FRT/FLP and GAL4/UAS in MOL 348!  I also recommend reading Prof. Devenport's review about planar cell polarity before her PCP class.  You can't appreciate tissue polarity from one class.  The same for mechanotransduction, which i sone class. Prof. Schwarzbauer knows a lot, so if you are interested in mechanotransduction, some to that class with loads of prepared questions.  For the development classes, Prof. Schupbach does a great job of giving crash courses on topics, but you need to reread Gilberts beforehand if you actually want to appreciate the details further.  Until there is another undergrad course about cell and/or dev bio, take this!
Just take it. It's a valuable class that you should never miss in your life, let alone the fact you are required to take it.
N/A
Not that necessary to take.
Take very good notes. The powerpoints are only presented as background to the lectures.
The class seems well planned out and provides a good variety of information on various topics which is helpful to understanding some of cell biology and development.
This is a good course, and ASK questions. Trudi and Paul can answer anything. If you get a guest speaker get ready for entertainment.
prereqs: MOL348.
descrip: A continuation of MOL 504, with two modules, Cell Biology II and Development. Cell Biology II concerns how cells assemble into functional tissues, covering the molecular components and fundamental concepts in cell communication, adhesion, shape, division, and differentiation. Development covers the basics of developmental biology, focusing on important concepts and model systems. Primary literature is used to introduce seminal works and classic approaches, modern experimental techniques, and outstanding questions in the field. Students learn the basis of a good paper, to read critically, and to think beyond the reading.

title: Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences
reviews: Definitely put lots of effort into the problem sets so you don't have to go back and relearn everything. Go to class too. It helps a lot!
Do the problem sets and make sure you understand exactly what it going on with the ideas presented in class
Do the problem sets early so you can go to office hours if need be -- very helpful for the p sets
For a general requirement Math course this is quite a smooth experience and there is no reason not to take it.
Go to all the classes! McConnell's quizzes and tests are all based on homework questions. Office hours are also great.
Go to office hours and review sessions!
Go to review sessions
Go to review sessions always
If you need it, take it.
If you're Econ, take this over 201/202.
Insane grading system with no curve
It's much better than MAT 103.
Its a good Math class. Take it
Just do the work and study and youll be fine
Keep up with homework and lectures. Otherwise, a fairly reasonable class with a medium workload.
Not too bad for a math that you have to take for econ. brush up on your calc before though
Pretty much exactly what you'd expect: not the most exciting material in the world, but you come away with a lot of valuable skills.
Really easy. Take it instead of MAT 201/202 if you can
Review the pset problems for quizzes and exam. It was not a hard course
Spend a lot of time on examples
Stay up on the problem sets
Take a 200 level if you're in it for the Math.
Take it for the economics math req!!
Take it if you need it for Economics or the Finance certificate, otherwise other courses in the Mathematics department will probably be more helpful.
Take this course if you want to enter the economics department without taking 201. It will be more challenging than expected, but still easier than other math courses.
The class material is taught well and the problem sets are not too much work. Actively attending and being attentive in lectures will allow you to succeed if you wish to take a math class

This course is not difficult if you understand what it is that you are doing. Do not just go through the motions, but try to understand the purpose of the exercises. I think it's a good course, and a great alternative to 201/202.
You have to.
go to class
go to office hours
good math class, just do the problem sets!
make sure to spend lots of time studying before tests.
not a bad math course
take it
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Survey of topics from multivariable calculus as preparation for future course work in economics or life sciences. Topics include basic techniques of integration, average value, vectors, partial derivatives, gradient, optimization of multivariable functions, and constrained optimization with Lagrange multipliers.

title: The Great Recession: Causes, Consequences, and Remedies
reviews: An interesting course, but poorly organized...
Could be much more structured, but the material is so useful and relevant. Good PDF class because there's not much work. I would take it!
Do not take this course. The coursework is minimal, but the curve is killer and the teaching is terrible. Please avoid this, take a better ECON class.
Don't waste your time if Krugman teaches it again. He won't though.
Easy and interesting class
Great class. Learned so much about the Great Recession and modern economic issues in general. Take if Krugman is teaching again!
Great survey course. Krugman won't be teaching it anymore, but still, I left the course feeling like I understood what happened in 2008. If you don't, I would take it too.
If Judd Cramer is precepting, try to get into his precept.
If a similar course is offered again, do your best to be in Judd's precept
Krugman is insightful and you are able to learn a lot in this class.
Krugman isn't a good lecturer so don't take it for him. If you want to learn something, get Neel as your preceptor.

Krugman's not teaching it any more, so it could be a lot better if a better, well organized teacher is leading it. Blinder and Krueger would be good options if they're teaching. Teachers make a big difference and Krugman was a simply interesting person, which made it tolerable (if you could get up at 8:30)
Lol this class won't be offered again
Make sure to go to lecture and precept.
N/A
Professor Krugman will not be teaching it next year, but the material is highly relevant and interesting.
Since Krugman isn't teaching here anymore, these reviews might not be that useful. Take it if you think you would be interested in the subject, I guess.
Take it ... oh wait, you can't.
Take it if you're interested, otherwise there's probably better taught econ courses.
Take it.
Take this course if you can
Take with caution.
This class by Krugman will not be offered again since he is leaving, but the material is really interesting because some of it is happening now.
