This class is going to be very different without Krugman, but get Neel as a preceptor if you can!
This course won't be the same without Professor Krugman, but it's still an interesting and incredibly important topic. I would take it.
Try to do the readings.
Very hard to say considering that Professor Krugman will be gone next semester and beyond.  I guess make sure to remember even seemingly minor economists' names, and relentlessly pursue definitions?
Won't exist anymore.
You guys missed out on a truly lifechanging class. It's too bad Krugman is getting paid big $$$ to go to SUNY, but I guess it's the economical thing to do.
the content is great. its awesome because he touches on a lot of current events
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101 and ECO 202.
descrip: This course covers topics related to the current economy and current economic policy. The course will begin by reviewing the causes of the recession that began in December 2007. It will concentrate on consumer behavior, financial markets, unemployment, and the housing sector. The role of public policies in contributing to the economic crisis and in ending the crisis will be explored. The state of the recovery will be assessed and monitored. The course will also consider current economic policy priorities.

title: Grand Strategy
reviews: A lot of work but completely worth it!
Be aware of the amount of content (both in lectures and readings) and try not to fall behind.
Definitely take it if you have any interest. However, there really are too many readings.
Do your readings and you'll get so much more out of the class.
Great course on grand strategy and IR. A little history heavy but good.

I'm not sure if I'd recommend taking this if you plan on pdfing it. There are probably easier SA's to take that won't make you feel so overwhelmed by the readings. That said, I think any WWS concentrator would be silly not to take this class. It really broadened my historical knowledge, which was lacking from high school.
If you do the readings and stay engaged, you'll learn a ton. If you aren't gonna do the readings, don't bother.

If you have the chance to learn from Ikenberry and Friedberg, DO NOT PASS IT UP. They are both extremely well versed in the world of IR and there is nothing like the experience of learning from the experts! If WWS is your thing, you will love this class.

It's a lot of work. Every week you get 200  pages of reading, and you have to know a lot of material to be well-prepared for the midterm and final. But it's a fascinating class, and the professors were phenomenal. The reading, if you have the time to get through them, is really interesting.
Lots of reading! Should take if you're interested in the subject.
Study hard for the exams.
Super interesting, gets through loads of material, but be warned: tons and tons of reading

TAKE THIS COURSE. If you've ever played Civ or Europa Universalis, this class will be so much fun. Even if you haven't, you'll get a sense of the large-scale forces that move societies and the similar constraints faced by states from Ancient Greece to the modern day. I can't recommend this course highly enough, whether you're a WWS/POL/HIS major or a STEM major looking for a distribution requirement.
Take it!

Take it!! It's an amazing class. There is a huge amount of reading which you need to do but it is great masterpiece you should read at some point anyway. You will learn a lot. The professors are incredible lecturers (Ikenberry and Friedberg) so definitely go to lecture.
Take the course; do the readings.

The subject matter is fascinating if you have a general interest, the readings are similarly fascinating if you accept you can't do all of them perfectly.  Take it if you're willing to work at a large Woody Woo class.
There are a LOT of readings for the class but it's a great class and you learn a lot from Ancient Greece to modern day China.
There is a lot of reading, but the course is very interesting.
This course is probably very worthwhile if you're interested in becoming a policy-maker. I took it PDF for an SA, and I found it pretty easy (you'll be fine even if you don't do the readings).
This is a one-of-a-kind course that will help you think more critically about strategic planning. The professors and preceptors are the very best Princeton has to offer.
This is an incredible class?and an unbelievably heavy work load. If you can, get into Friedberg's precept and join a study group early to handle the readings. It could be a great PDF class.
Understand which readings are the most important and do those in depth. It is possible to get content while skimming the analyses. This course is not easy but is rewarding if you do the work.
do not take this class as a 5th class unless you are PDFing one of your five classes. It is a lot of work but the class is interesting and you will learn a lot.
prereqs: Some knowledge of U.S. European, and/or Asian history is essential, through there are no prerequisite courses.
descrip: Grand strategy is the broad and encompassing policies and undertakings that political leaders pursue-financial, economic, military, diplomatic-to achieve their objectives inpeacetime and in war. This course will examine the theory and practice of grand strategy both to illuminate how relations among city-states, empires, kingdoms and nation states have evolved over the centuries and also to identify some common challenges that have confronted all who seek to make and execute grand strategy from Pericleses to Barack Obama.

title: Comparative Physiology
reviews: Awesome labs!  Material is straight memorization but not hard.

Definitely take this class! There isn't much work throughout the semester to do and the field trip at the end of the semester is the best thing ever. You get to pet a rhino and feed elephants and giraffes, and it is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. I'm not an EEB major, but I have to say that the EEB staff are some of the friendliest and nicest people here at Princeton.
Go to the open lab hours before practicals.
I recommend this class for all EEB majors or anyone interested in the physiology of animals.
I recommend this only for the labs.

If you're preparing for the MCAT, you'll (1) get a great preparation for the biology section and (2) will engage with lectures, no matter what the other reviews say. It's not as boring as people make it out to be if you're interested in the material already.

Make sure to pay attention in lecture!!!study your notes immediately after class so you can stay ma asking connections between materials early on!!! Have fun in lab but study hard door the lab practicals because they count for more of your grade than you think!

Not the best EEB course you could take. Take if you have a strong interest in anatomy/physiology. Things to consider are incredibly boring lectures and lots of memorization, especially for the lab practicals and final (may be good or bad, depending on your strengths). Furthermore, if you have a strong bio/chem background, the first half of the course will be very familiar to you.
Perhaps take this with another professor, or wait until Professor Goldberg is more experienced.
Take this class!

Take this course if you like dissections and learning about animals. Make sure you keep up on the powerpoints and learning/memorizing so that its not a shock when you get to an exam. The labs are awesome!
The class would be especially interesting to pre-meds as it discusses the body systems of different animals. Labs are very fun and are an added incentive to take the class!
The lab exams are the most stressful part, but you will do well if you study a lot for them. Without problem sets, it is your responsibility to make sure you are keeping up.
The labs are awesome, but if it's the same professor I do not recommend the course.  The lectures were very uninteresting.

Try to engage as much as possible with Prof. Goldberg, it will make lectures more interesting. 

You really do need to memorize the 100 bones for the first lab practical.
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: This course explores the mechanisms of animal function in the contexts of evolution, ecology and behavior. We will cover the physiological bases of osmoregulation, circulation, gas exchange, digestion, energetics, motility, and neural and hormonal control of these and other processes in a variety of vertebrate and invertebrate animals, thereby revealing general principles of animal physiology as well as specific physiological adaptations to differing environments.

title: Political Psychology
descrip: This course examines psychological perspectives on politics. Themes include human limitation vs. human capacity, how institutions shape or interact with individual opinion and behavior, discussion and deliberation, and the role of groups. We will also discuss methodological issues.

title: Iran Since the Revolution
reviews: Definitely take this course-- it's a fascinating introduction to Iran covering almost everything from politics to culture. The professor is an absolute expert and makes the subject particularly interesting by incorporating films and political theory to the course.
Highly recommend!

If you are interested in learning more about Iranian politics, this is a great course. You will get a significant amount out of the course if you put time into the readings and do the work outlined on the syllabus. Between the course materials and Professor Kunkler, there is a wealth of opportunities for engagement with the subject matter.

If you have any interest in Iran, the Middle East, or just being a well-informed citizen of the world, take this class. It profoundly impacted my view of a country that Americans often make uninformed assumptions about. Professor Kunkler is awesome and extremely helpful.
If you have the slightest interest in Iran or the Middle East this course is a great choice. I strongly recommend taking this course, especially if Mirjam Kunkler is teaching it.
Professor Kunkler is great! This is a wonderful opportunity to learn about Iran. If you're at all interested, take it!
TAKE IT.
Take it!
Take it! Prof. Kunkler is wonderful and if you're interested in Iran, there's no reason not to.
n/a
descrip: This course examines the formation and development of the Islamic Republic of Iran in the aftermath of the 1979 revolution. It considers, in particular, how the Iranian regime has adapted to changing domestic and international economic, social and political conditions and sustained itself enface grave social and economic challenges and international isolation. Topics of Discussion include: Social Movements and Political Reform, Clerical Opposition and Dissident Theology, Changing Interpretations of Religious Law, Missed Opportunities in US-Iran relations, Iran's role in the Middle East, the nuclear question.

title: Topics in Differential Geometry - Minimal Submanifolds
prereqs: Undergraduates must request permission of instructor..
descrip: In this course, we will discuss the theory of minimal submanifolds, with emphasis on the variational aspects. We will start with some basic material, and then discuss curvature estimates and prove existence results. We will cover some recent applications of the variational theory to problems in geometry and topology.

title: Studies in Ancient Judaism - Pure Fantasy: Systems of Purity and Impurity in Ancient Israel
descrip: We will read selected passages from Biblical and post-Biblical texts pertaining to the concepts of purity and impurity, and create a multi-dimensional model for the synchronic and diachronic analysis of these complex systems.

title: Theory of Games
reviews: It's not a hard class, but fun
Take it.
prereqs: MAT 202, 204, 217 or equivalent. MAT 215 or equivalent is recommended..
descrip: Games in extensive form, pure and behavioral strategies; normal form, mixed strategies, equilibrium points; coalitions, characteristic-function form, imputations, solution concepts; related topics and applications.

title: Fundamentals of Biofuels
descrip: This course defines biofuels, and explains why we should make them. It presents the challenges and opportunities of sustainable biofuels, addressing issues of land use, and competition with food production. It describes production processes of first generation, and cellulosic ethanol. It covers microbial engineering to improve production, or make new advanced biofuels. It describes the use of photosynthetic organisms such as algae, which fix carbon directly from the atmosphere to make biofuels. It addresses the environmental, economic and societal impact of biofuels, and how they can fulfill their promise as a renewable source of energy.

title: Preserving the Past
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Condensed Matter Physics II
reviews: If you already did some research on this topic, you should go and learn. If you know nothing and expect this course teaching from beginning, then you should not take this course.
descrip: Course introduces and present ongoing theoretical investigations of new research topics in condensed matter physics: topological insulators and Chern numbers, topological superconductors, the fractional quantum Hall effect and non-abelian statistics, as well as new high-temperature superconductors. The techniques needed to deal with such systems, such as Chern numbers, topological band theory, Berry phases, conformal field theory, Chern-Simons theory, t-J models, Gutzwiller wavefunctions, Hubbard models, are explained.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Discusses the main tools of econometric analysis, and the way in which they are applied to a range of problems in social science. Emphasis is on using techniques, and on understanding and critically assessing others' use of them. There is a great deal of practical work on the computer using a range of data from around the world. Topics include regression analysis, with a focus on regression as a tool for analyzing non-experimental data, discrete choice, and an introduction to time-series analysis. There are applications from macroeconomics, policy evaluation, and economic development. Prerequisite: grounding in topics covered in 507c.

title: Independent Study II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.

title: Second Language Acquisition Research and Language Teaching Methodology
descrip: Designed to provide future teaching assistants with the knowledge and conceptual tools needed to reflect critically on pedagogical practices in the second language classroom. Examines issues related to teaching language and culture in a university setting, highlighting the relationship between theory in Second Language Acquisition and language pedagogy and helping students understand the practical implications of theoretical frameworks in the field.

title: Topics of Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - International Migration and Public Policy
descrip: This course examines the historical and contemporary literature on international migration, the policies that enable or impede cross-national migration, and the consequences for the sending and receiving states as well as the migrants themselves. Drawing on contemporary international evidence, students will consider classical and contemporary theories of immigrant adaptation, language acculturation, and ethnic conflict from comparative international evidence.

title: Accelerated Honors Analysis II
reviews: Definitely take it if you seriously consider to major in math
Definitely take this class if you are a perspective math major and you have some math background.
Great class. Great jokes. Great Gunning.

I would highly recommend taking another math class with it if you're a serious math major, because by itself it isn't too big a workload--it felt easier than the first half. Other than that you know what to expect from 216. It's a good class and Gunning is fun.

I wouldn't take this, but it's the only option you have for a honors course. It's also not that hard, but definitely not easy. If you can try to avoid it, but if not I guess you can take it, the material is not bad. Just expect to do everything by yourself
If you are interested in math for the sake of math, take the class.

If you liked 216, there is no reason not to continue. If it was a bit of a push and you got used to it towards the end and you like mathematics and are a little stubborn, you should take it. It won't get worse, in fact the opposite for many since the material gets a bit more intuitive. (Review your linear algebra though.) If you really didn't like 216 instruction, there won't be a drastic change, so don't take it.
If you really like math and are willing to put in the time, no course will better prepare you for future math than this one.
If you want to be a math major, take it, even if you have learned analysis by reading textbooks before. It's really worthy taking.
Take it if you can. Obviously it's going to be a significant amount of work, but Gunning is also awesome.
Take it if you want to major in math. Come prepared though.
prereqs: MAT 215 accelerated section..
descrip: Rigorous introduction to analysis in several variables.

title: Advanced Japanese II
reviews: Great way to consolidate the grammatical information from first- and second-year Japanese and apply it to serious discussions about cultural, social, and political issues. I enjoyed the readings/primary materials a lot more than the texts from 301.
It is a class not to be missed. Definitely an awesome introduction to using Japanese in a more natural context.
Japan is the future and Princeton Japanese is the best taught thing ever, super fun as well. Take it, hopefully it will change and enrich your life like it did mine <3 <3
Take it
Take it! It's probably the zenith of the Japanese classes at Princeton, as you spend a significant portion of class watching and discussing Spirited Away. Lots of fun!
Take it. No reason not to take third year Japanese if you've gone to PII or have taken 2nd year.
descrip: The course is designed to further students proficiency in four skills aiming at ACTFL-ETS advanced level. Reading materials include the Japanese anime "Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi (Spirited Away)" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: Gender and Performing Arts in South Asia
descrip: How has the nexus of gender, the performing arts, and aesthetics been theorized, constructed, and experienced at different times and in different places in South Asian societies? What roles have courtesans and courtesan cultures played in artistic and performance traditions in South Asia? In exploring these and related questions we will draw from music, dance, film, literature, and ethnographic and historical sources as we consider the complexities of social and cultural discourses in relation to the performing arts.

title: Making Sense of the City
descrip: This course starts from the premise that to engage the spatial politics of cities of the Americas, we must engage with the senses. We will ask how vision, affect, and smell shape our understandings of and connections to urban space. And conversely, how different spaces condition our sensorial experiences. Employing the critical, interpretive and theoretical knowledge of the humanities, we examine how these sensorial markers of belonging in urban spaces relate to and expand social markers of citizenship, political boundaries, gender, class, race, and ethnicity.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: Literature, Food, and the American Racial Diet
reviews: Definitely take it if you have an interest in the literary implications of food. Does touch on quite a bit on the racialization of food, but definitely very interesting material for anyone who enjoys all aspects of food.
Definitely take it. One of my favorite classes at Princeton.
Definitely take this course.
Didn't learn as much as I thought I would. The title of the course makes you think this class is more engaging than it actually is.
Do all the readings!
Do it
Do the reading!  Listen to your preceptor!
Do the readings, they're very interesting
Don't take it because you think it would be easy.
Don't take it if you don't have time to do the readings
Don't take the class... It is not engaging! It is hard for someone that is not an expert in food analysis as it pertains to race, culture, class, and gender....
Fun class with a lot of discussions on race! Don't forget the last part of the course title: 'Racial American diet'.
Get Caitlin as a preceptor! But don't go to lecture, it is not worth the time as long as there are no exams.
Go to class and stay up to date on reading
Go to lecture! There may be pop quizzes.
Great course for people who aren't necessarily humanities students but have an interest in literature. Professor Cheng makes the material and assignments really accessible for everyone.
I am neutral towards this course.
I think I would tell them to take it in order to change their perception of food and also to recognize the immense details of food.
I would approach the course with an open mind and a desire to learn about a different subject, even if it might seem abstract at first.
I would definitely take it again - just know that some weeks require a lot of reading, while others maybe only require watching one film, so look and plan ahead
I would suggest to go to every lecture and start their papers early.
I would tell him/her to just do the readings.

If you are interested in English and literature, this is probably a really good class; if not, be aware that there is a lot of terminology used that can be hard to follow if you are unfamiliar with it coming in, and the papers are graded quite harshly.

If you are looking to fulfill your LA distribution requirement, this course has a LOT of reading (especially considering you might end up PDFing it anyway). Also, the professor gave pop-quizzes during lecture, so you will probably have to put in more work than you originally intended. The feast at the end of the course was really fun, but this class has more work than you might expect (also weekly reading responses).

If you're interested in reading a lot of different novels and watching films, then great, the class is for you, but if you're more interested in food than other concepts, the class addresses a lot of other things with less focus on food, so maybe don't take this class.
Interesting but depends on preceptor.
It's a good LA. Not a lot of work, but also not the most interesting.
It's fun and not a lot of work. You get out of it what you put in; preceptors make a big impact on how you enjoy the class so try to get Professor Cheng or a lead preceptor
Just keep up with the reading, and actually go to lecture because they're super interesting.
Make sure to do all the readings and complete all the assignments!

Material is interesting and you can get as much out of the class as you want, depending how much work you put in. It can be an easy class since you can get by pretty well without doing the readings, but there's a lot more to learn if you're interested. Precept was really fun for me. Just take the few assignments there are seriously.
Not as easy as everyone else says it is.
Not the best, not the worst. Reasonable workload.
Participate and precept and do the readings to get the most out of the course. Your preceptor will make or break the course so choose a good one! Always discuss your paper topics with your AI!
Read the books! Great class and easy LA, just make sure you read the books.
Start the papers early and ask your preceptor for lots of help as this is the person who will grade the paper.
Take Caitlin as your preceptor! This is a very easy class to take if you're looking to get the LA distribution out of the way.
Take Prof. Cheng's precept for sure!
Take if if you enjoy food and how it cross sections with literature
Take it
Take it for a pretty relaxed LA. The cook-off was a lot of fun, and it gets you to think about food in an interesting way!
Take it if you like an abstract course on food.
Take it if you're interested in the course material. The readings and films are great, and Professor Cheng helps you see them in an entirely new perspective!
Take it if you're interested in the topics, but be prepared that it may not be what you expect.  Communicate and work closely with your preceptor/grader for term papers.
Take it!  But do the readings if you want to enjoy it!
Take it! But make sure you do the readings and put in the time? just because the class is about food doesn't mean it doesn't require hard work!
Take it! The books you read are very interesting and enjoyable.
Take it!! Really interesting material!
Take the class and I recommend Professor Cheng as a preceptor if you want to develop your writing more
Take the class but watch out for pop quiz. Do the readings
Take this course, but try to get into a precept with a friend.
Take this for a PDF. Don't go to lecture.
The cook off is extremely fun!

This class is as easy as it may sound. It is interesting if you are looking for a class on racial relations, but it deals significantly in the figurative and philosophical range, so don't expect a robust analysis of historical context.
This class is suitable for P/D/F.
This class is very conceptual, so going to lectures fills you in with more information but the concepts stay the same.
This is a relatively fun course, not super interesting and sometimes a bit weird.
This is an easy course to PDF. The papers aren't graded too easily, so if you're taking it for a grade you should plan to attend most lectures and work reasonably hard.

This is definitely not a class if you're only looking for foodie enjoyment/culinary tourism (in fact, the latter is actively discouraged). There's a lot less food than you'd expect for a course with the title. Food becomes an abstract symbol as the course goes on, and the course puts a lot more emphasis on the racial diet component.

This was probably one of my favourite courses of the semester. Not stressful or intense, and generally an interesting course  with a really good reading list, where you get to make your own dish in a 'feast' at the end of the semester. I'd advise thinking about whether you genuinely want to read/watch what's on the reading list (often we read a small novel a week) because I know some people who didn't bother and did not get as much out of the course.
Very interesting and not too hard for a LA
You have to love the reading and your preceptor to enjoy this course.
easy course with not a lot of work
take it
prereqs: A love of food and a love of reading required..
descrip: Food, like books, is the site of our greatest consumption of and most vulnerable encounter with "otherness." This course explores how "taste" informs the ways in which we ingest or dispel racial otherness. Through novels and cinema largely in Asian American and African American cultural production - and in the Asian and African diaspora-- we will study how the meeting of food and word inform categories such as race, nationhood, gender, ecology, and family, and class. Topics include: "Transcendental Primitivism," "Modernist Orientalism," "Chocolate Women on the Edge", "Parenting/Consuming", "Ecology and the Humanimal," and more.

title: Anthropology of the Body: Theories and Practices in China & Beyond
descrip: This course examines the rise of the notion of the body. Engaging with major theorists of the body, it explores the body as an analytical category of human existence, compared to notions of subject, agency, self and so on. Relying on ethnographies, historical studies and cultural studies in China and beyond, it introduces a balanced perspective between bodily experience and social construction of the body by various forces (religious rituals, legal regulations, scientific knowledge, political protocols, medical practices, disciplines, and popular culture), and explores different bodies and the complex relationship between the body and life.

title: Readings in Judeo-Arabic
descrip: Introduction to the Judeo-Arabic responsa (fatwas) & documents of the Cairo Geniza. Students will acquire the Hebrew alphabet & learn the peculiarities of "middle Arabic" grammar & syntax, reflecting medieval vernacular features. Seminar will focus mainly on documents from economic life, Jewish & Muslim, during the 11th-13th centuries, in the Mediterranean & Indian Ocean. For comparison, we will read some of the few published documentary letters of Muslim merchants preserved with Egyptian papyri. Course includes introduction to Geniza manuscript paleography.

title: The Troubadours and the Occitan Tradition - Lyrics in a Manuscript Tradition
descrip: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the poetry of the Occitan troubadours, their language, and the rich manuscript culture that developed around their works during the thirteenth century. Special emphasis will be placed on the role that these poems played in conceptualizing literary language and authorship in the vernacular and on the construction of a textual and grammatical tradition in opposition to the fundamentally oral and musical nature of the lyric. Students will acquire a reading knowledge of Old Occitan as well as familiarity with manuscript research. Discussion in English, but reading knowledge of French required.

title: Asian American History
reviews: Do all the readings
Go to lecture every day!

I would highly recommend this course. The feeling in this course is very different from most at Princeton because it tries to challenge a lot of traditional narratives that we hear about race and American history more generally. It also touches on a variety of issues that you would almost never hear about in high school or any other history course. If you want to understand the complex racial dynamics of the US, take this course. Readings are definitely manageable and the tests are fair.
Read.
Super interesting  course. I loved it and i'm sure you will too. You'll learn a ton about what you're aiming to learn and probably be significantly surprised by a lot of stuff too.
TAKE IT - you probably won't really understand US history until you take this class

TAKE THIS COURSE! This is a subject that you don't learn anywhere else?kind of the overlooked events and perspectives of American history. Interesting stuff that is taught well. Professor Lew-Williams is enthusiastic and refreshing, and I couldn't wait until lecture every week. This is definitely a class that will stick with me after college.
Take it if you can, it's a solid course!
Take it if you have an interest in this class! Don't if it's "just an HA."
Take it!! Be genuinely interested in the subject -- it's hard not to be.
Take it!! It will change what you think about what "Asian American" means and look at history with a new perspective.
Take it.

Take this course, especially if Professor Lew-Williams teaches it. The readings are manageable and lectures are very well prepared and thought-provoking. The professor is awesome. Definitely one of the best organized and fascinating classes I have taken during my four years at Princeton.
There are very little other courses like this and it really is a new step towards Asian American awareness.
This course is a great intro to the Asian-American experience, but it's not so much a hard-core history course as a mix of history, anthropology, cultural studies, etc.

This course is applicable to everyone, even to non-Asian Americans. I think learning about American history from the perceptive of ethnic group on the sidelines lends a lot of insight into society -- and Professor Lew-Williams does a great job at teaching this. Take it!
This course is very eye opening and is very intellectually stimulating. Make sure to go to the lectures as they are very interesting, and make sure to participate in precepts.
This is a GREAT class - definitely take it, even if you're not already interested in Asian-American studies/history.
Would take!
descrip: This course introduces students to the multiple and varied experiences of people of Asian heritage in the United States from the 19th century to the present day. It focuses on three major questions: (1) What brought Asians to the United States? (2) How did Asian Americans come to be viewed as a race? (3) How does Asian American experience transform our understanding of U.S. history? Using newspapers, novels, government reports, and films, this course will cover major topics in Asian American history, including Chinese Exclusion, Japanese internment, transnational adoption, and the model minority stereotype.

title: How to Make a Film
reviews: It's a great course but a lot of work. Take it. But have time to take it. Also, you'll have made a film by the end, which is pretty cool.
Plan a final script early.
prereqs: This course is now open enrollment.
descrip: A film can be fictional or documentary, but there are also many other ways to tell a story. Through hands-on studio work, screenings, critical readings and group critiques, this course teaches the basic tools and approaches for film production with digital media including writing, camerawork, sound, editing, and postproduction. Technical instruction paired with conceptual frameworks will give you the means to find your visual storytelling voice and your filmmaker's point of view.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Shape Analysis
descrip: This course will study recent topics in shape analysis for computer graphics and computer vision.

title: Topics in Modern South Asia - Subaltern Studies
descrip: This course explores special topics in modern South Asian history. The precise topic varies from year to year.

title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop
prereqs: REL 525.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion. Note: REL 525 (fall) and REL 526 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Advanced Korean II
prereqs: KOR 301 or placement test..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 301. Continued development of proficiency in speaking and reading through class discussion and short readings. Vocabulary learning and discourse skills are emphasized.

title: Politics and Religion
reviews: Do the readings
I would take this class if you're interested in political philosophy, but be prepared for difficult readings and papers.
If you are moderately interested in politics and religion, take this course.
Need a politics course? Take it. Need it for distribution req? Take it. Like politics and/or religion. Taught in a way that is very accessible for engineers (I'm COS). Take it take it take it.
Only take if you're genuinely interested in the lecture topics on the syllabus.

Prof Mueller is a rockstar. His lectures cover a lot of ground (several texts), but they're in the form of an easy to follow, coherent narrative.  His style of lecturing is accessible and he makes difficult materials a lot more legible. Go to lecture and bask in his eloquence.
Take this course, but be aware it requires a time investment!
Worth every penny.
Would recommend if you have a strong interest in theory and religious writings. Otherwise, it is challenging to get through all the reading.
worst class ever
descrip: Is there an affinity between particular religions and particular forms of politics? Is religion a necessary basis for any stable politics, as many canonical authors in the history of political thought asserted, or is it in fact a threat, as religion provokes strife and poses a danger to modern ideals of autonomy - including democracy? The course addresses such broad questions by engaging classic works as well as recent sociological writings, studies in comparative politics, and legal theories on politics and religion.

title: Political and Economic Development of the Middle East
reviews:
- Do the reading - it is great.
- Spend time with Professor Kunkler outside of class to learn more and engage with current issues and debates - she is incredibly knowledgeable and interesting

Definitely do the readings before lecture so that you have the context and background for what is presented in lecture. I think that it would be best to have some knowledge of the Middle East before taking this course if you want to get the most out of it. Maybe take a survey course of Middle Eastern history first, and then take this class.
Definitely take this course if Professor Kunkler is teaching it!
Expect it to be more of a survey course than an in-depth one
If you're at all interested in the Middle East this is a very good class to take.

So much incredibly vital information if you'd like to study this region, but keep in mind it's a survey course. You're not getting a whole lot of depth for anything. Kunkler is clearly extremely smart and knows plenty about the region, but she only sort of seemed halfway-interested.
Take it if you are interested in the region
Take it if you've never taken a class on the Middle East before! It gave me a good overview of the region, but it is a bit general and unorganized.
Take the class! This should be a requirement for NES majors.
The Middle East is an important region in the world right now, and this course will help you understand why the Middle East is the way it is. The workload is not difficult to manage.

This course tries to cover a ton of information but is definitely worth taking if you're looking for a general overview of the ways the middle east has been shaped and the way basic politcal and economic models play out.

This course was enjoyable and the written assignments, while worth a substantial part of your final grade, are not too difficult.  The readings can be intense, though, so if you want to get the most out of your experience make sure to put aside some time to really read them and don't just skim.  I would recommend this class anyone without must background knowledge in the Middle East, and also to those who want a more broad look at the region as a whole.
descrip: The course introduces major issues in the study of contemporary Middle Eastern Politics and Economics, including state formation, the phenomenon of rentier economics, the role of the military and security sector, water and food security, the variance of authoritarianism and democracy, political parties and social movements, as well as the relationship between religion and state.

title: Topics in Ecology (Half-Term) - Ecological Theory of Biodiversity and Extinction
prereqs: The course is open to graduate students and, with permission, advanced undergraduate students..
descrip: Lectures and discussions will focus on the mechanisms of competition, disease and predation and their impacts on ecological and evolutionary patterns and processes. Issues addressed include causes of multi-species coexistence on local to regional spatial scales; evolutionary responses of species to interspecific interactions and their influence on coexistence, speciation and biodiversity; how the biodiversity so generated influences the functioning of ecosystems, and management issues such as the prevention of extinction and the sustainability of fisheries and agriculture.

title: Trade Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Medical Anthropology
reviews: Absolutely take this course! It's so informative about all of the additional factors that go into the medical field.
Amazing course! Take as a sophomore before you're too busy with independent work. Workload is pretty heavy.
Be prepared for a TON of reading, sometimes 400  pages a week. That said, they're very skimmable, and a good number of the readings are absolutely amazing and maybe even life-changing.
Biehl is one of the most amazing professors! Do not hesitate to take this course even if you just generally interested in the course material. You won't regret it!
Definitely take it if you're interested in the subject matter, but be prepared to put in a lot of time for readings. I learned so much and the professor is amazing.
Definitely take this course!

Definitely take this course. Especially if you are considering going into medicine- It is a MUST! Prof Biehl raises many important questions and makes you think very critically. If you engage in the material you will get so much out of it- It's one of those classes that reminds you of the higher purpose in education!

Definitely take this course. Really makes you think about important issues in medicine, the body, and putting them all into context. Not just a class for premeds but for everyone, since we're all going to have some interaction with the medical world/doctors at some point. Be warned of the heavy reading load.
Do the readings and engage in discussion during class.
Find a different anthropology course or a different health course. Bad teacher even though he means well and readings are way more than what we actually learned or were expected to.
Get ready to do a lot of reading. Beside that, the class is not hard and you learn a lot of great stuff
Go out of your way to take this class. It is such a great opportunity.

Great course. Heavy readings. Take if you need distribution requirements or if you're premed, and definitely take it if you have genuine interest in topics. Do not take if you want an easy class, as there are weekly assignments and you will easily fall behind.

I would definitely recommend this class! However it definitely is what you make of it; if you spend time doing the readings and really think about the topics, preparing before class, you can really get a lot out of it.

I would definitely recommend this course. Don't shy away from it if you aren't necessarily on the track to medical school. It is really interesting for anyone and although a lot of reading, not too much work at all.

I would not take it unless you can commit to 300  pages of reading per week OR you are willing to commit to not reading. It is a very easy class to get away without doing the readings - but you won't get much out of it.
I would recommend any student to take this course. It is the best course I have taken so far here at Princeton.
I would recommend this course. It was a lot of work but it was all worth it in the end. The amount of time and the work that you put into the class is what you receive back. Absolutely great.
I would take any class with Professor Biehl. He is a gem!

If you are at all interested in medicine, take this class! This class makes you think differently about medicine, and in general just makes you think like an anthropologist. You become much more sensitive to the societal/cultural/systemic factors that affect medicine. It's also super well taught, and very engaging.
If you like anthropology classes, you'll probably like this one.  It's pretty engaging for a lecture, but you don't have to talk.  Be prepared for a lot of reading and weekly response papers.
If you're interested in the GHP certificate, you should take this course!

Incredible course. Should be a required course for aspiring medical students. An engaging, deeply interesting class for those who are not. Biehl is an amazing professor with lots of energy and love for the subject.

It's a great course to take as an underclassmen. After taking GHP 350, it might seem a bit redundant, although there are a lot of fundamental readings we see for the first time in this course as compared to GHP 350. I do think this is a better course for students before they enter the GHP program as it's more of an introduction to medical anthropology. So, if you're familiar with med anthro, it might not be as challenging or stimulating for you. But still overall, a solid course.
It's a lot of reading, but so so worth it. This class has been one of my favorites at Princeton thus far.

It's an awesome class, whether pre-med or not pre-med. For the pre-meds, it's a humanistic perspective on medicine that is refreshing considering how STEM classes often have a reductionist approach to medicine. For the non pre-meds, it's a great, interesting insight into the way medicine is such a large part of our lives, from childhood memories of breaking a bone, or various doctors visits over the years, it shows the pervasive nature of medicine as well as the medicalization of our lives through economic and historical lenses as well as a humanistic view.
Keep up with the readings!
One of the best classes at Princeton - a must take if you have the slightest interest in health, equity, and the intersection between the social and natural sciences!!
Perhaps start the reading ahead of time, so you don't have to feel too rushed
Please, please take it! Careful with the amount of reading, don't let it make you not take the course, but rather find out how to not do all of the readings because the course is totally worth it.
Professor Biehl is an amazing person and really dedicated to the subject of medical anthropology and to his students.

Professor Biehl is great and a lot of the readings  and visual materials are also very engaging. He manages to invite a lot of really amazing scholars to the class. However, it is sometimes annoying that the class requires so much frequent attention, in that there are frequent reading reports and blackboard posts. The class also takes attendance at every lecture, which felt a bit infantilizing.
TAKE IT. Best class I've taken at Princeton thus far.
TAKE THIS COURSE!

TAKE THIS COURSE! Even if it is not at all related with your major, it is an eye-opening that will probably change the way you view not only biomedical institutions but the whole workings of societies, institutions, cultures, among others.
Take it if you're interested in learning a new perspective on issues surrounding health.

Take it if you're planning on participating in any aspect of health care as a career. Very important, interesting concepts to be aware of while thinking of where in the field you'd like to contribute.
Take it! Amazing course offering a different perspective of the medical field.  A lot of reading but it is definitely worth it!
Take the course!
Take this course!

Take this course. It doesn't matter what department you are in, this course boils down to how humans respond to sickness and treatment, asking difficult questions surrounding the ethics of human experimentation, the complexity of philanthropy, and the culture of biomedicine.

There is SO much reading for this class (200  page book a week, plus ~100-150 pages of other shorter readings) that are individually interesting but collectively extremely difficult to complete, and you'll only really get something out of lectures if you do the readings. People say this is an amazing class for premeds but I wouldn't recommend it - I enjoyed medical policy and bioethics courses more.
There is a lot of reading, but this class is worth it!

This course was amazing. It was one of my favorite courses I've taken at Princeton so far. Professor Biehl's passion for teaching it shows in all the effort he puts into it, and you get so much out of the course.
This is an amazing course and you will enjoy class and have your mind blown.

Whilst I found it a very interesting class, and I got to read many texts that I would not have otherwise come across, it was very time demanding. Doing this as my fifth course proved very tiring, particularly towards the end of the semester when more work kept piling on me.
do the readings but do not stress too much if you can't quite finish them all
descrip: Medical anthropology examines affliction and therapeutics in a cross-cultural perspective. It draws from multiple theoretical approaches to understand the interaction of biology, social environment, and medicine. We will compare non-medical models of disease causality and healing with biomedical ones, and explore how social and technological inequalities shape outcomes. Students will learn to interpret individual illness narratives as well as to assess differences in patterns of disease that afflict large populations in both affluent and resource-poor contexts. The course draws from ethnography, medical journals, media reports and films.

title: Comparative Political Behavior
descrip: Seminar examines mass political behavior from a comparative perspective and attempts to explain how people become involved in politics, how they form political opinions, and how their behavior influences political outcomes. Seminar covers a range of behaviors, including learning about politics, information processing, political participation, and voter decision-making. For each of these behaviors, two questions are posed: What are the causes and consequences of the behavior? To what extent and how do these causes and consequences depend on institutional or cultural/ historical settings?

title: Mechanical Design
reviews: Communicate with your team and be prepared to spend a while on your robot!
Definitely take it if you would rather spend time designing/working in the shop than struggling through one more problem set every week!
Make sure you have a good group, and try to stay on schedule.  Definitely the most fulfilling class I've taken at Princeton.
Pick good partners for the robot project! That will be the bet choice you can make!
Plan the parts of your robot with exact detail. Focus on making a good initial design early rather than fixing a poor design later.

Project management is critical. Emails are no good; I would recommend scheduling in-person meetings. This can be a very fun and enriching project if you work smart, not hard; otherwise it will be very frustrating.
Take the course, and be prepared to spend a lot of time in the machine shop!

Take this course if you want hands on, practical MAE experience (there are very few courses at Princeton that give the opportunity to do this). Choose your teammates wisely, and plan early in the design process to reduce as many mistakes as possible instead of having to fix things last-minute.
Take this course!
Take this course, worry about torque.

This a great course where you will build a robot. If you like working in the shop, designing machines, and coding, then this is the course for you. It is a lot of work and time so don't take it in a semester with many problem sets.
Try to meet all the deadlines along the way to avoid scrambling at the end. This helped us tremendously and made reading period relaxed.
prereqs: MAE 321 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course builds on the technical foundations established in MAE 321, and extends the scope to include a range of advanced mechanism design. Students, working in teams, will be challenged to design and fabricate a robotic system that will draw upon multidisciplinary engineering elements. The robot will be used to facilitate common daily tasks. The selected tasks vary each year. CAD, CAE, and CAM will be utilized in the design/simulation/prototype process. Labs are designed to reinforce and expand CAD and CAE skills. A final public competition will be held among the design teams. Judges from relevant industries will be present.

title: Ancient Judaism from Alexander to the Rise of Islam
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the development of ancient Judaism during the eventful millennium from the establishment of the Torah as the constitution of the Jewish people in the fifth century BCE--an event that some have seen as marking the transition from biblical religion to Judaism--to the completion of the other great canonical Jewish document, the Babylonian Talmud, in perhaps the sixth century CE.

title: Rats, Riots, and Revolution: Housing in the Metropolitan United States
reviews: A great topic!

Focuses very heavily on the history of residential segregation and race issues as opposed to housing policy per se but an interesting and very important topic nonetheless. Taylor's seminars can be a little dry though.
I would take it if you have an interest on housing or want to learn some facts you've never known about the US.
Take it. A good class to PDF.
descrip: This class examines the history of urban and suburban housing in the twentieth century US. We will examine the relationship between postwar suburban development as a corollary to the "underdevelopment" of American cities contributing to what scholars have described as the "urban crisis" of the 1960s. Housing choice and location were largely shaped by discriminatory practices in the real estate market, thus, the course explores the consequences of the relationship between public policy and private institutions in shaping the metropolitan area including after the passage of federal anti-housing discrimination legislation in the late 1960s.

title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part II
reviews: Mahadev is super knowledgeable, so ask him as many questions as possible!
Put together a team with a diverse range of strengths, as the project requires different skill sets.
Research a range of solutions in each area independently so you can put them all on the table before selecting.

This course is required for M.Arch I's, and let me tell you why: Mahadev is awesome. He has loads of good professional experience under his belt, and while he is mostly occupied by his engineering job, when he is in the building he is very personable and responsive, which can't be said of other instructors. Environmental engineering is weirdly fascinating. Enjoy!
descrip: Study and evaluation of mechanical and electrical system applications for different building types, including air conditioning, electrical, plumbing and telecommunications. Emphasis on design integration with architecture and structure within the construction process including sustainable design and energy conservation. Introduction to vertical transportation, life safety systems, and intelligent buildings. Emphasis on a conceptual approach using case studies and field trips.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Federal Budget
descrip: This course will cover how the Federal budget process is supposed to work and how it actually does work. Topics will include: (1) institutions, processes, and definitions; (2) history of budget outcomes; (3) the current state of the Federal budget process; (4) the role of uncertainty in budgeting; (4) the role of politics in budgeting; and (5) the budget's short- and long-term fiscal consequences. Students will be required to submit at least one short memo during the course and one research paper at the end of the course.

title: Zen and Language
descrip: Zen (Mandarin Chan) Buddhism claims not to subsist in language, but to rely on a separate transmission, yet the Zen canon is huge & language (both spoken & written) plays an indispensible role in Zen practice & in its engagement with the arts of East Asia. This course studies how language is characterized in Zen's traditions, its place in religious practice and how it has engaged with and made more complex considerations about language in the visual, literary and performing arts. East Asian language proficiency is NOT required for the course. It is open to all graduate students and, by permission, undergraduates with East Asian interests.

title: Contradictions of Freedom in American Capitalism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Reading Images
reviews: Actually do the readings

Take it! Useful not only for your French skills, but for learning theory behind images that is invaluable in all different kinds of fields. It is easy to get away with not doing readings, but I do not recommend that you do this. Professor Sagnier is extremely supportive and flexible, and will help you improve astronomically if you put work into the course.
Take it, if only for Prof. Sagnier, who is amazing.

This is a great course, and Mme Sagnier is an amazing professor! The topics covered in the course are probably not ones that many people have already studied, so it's a great way to enhance your French skills while learning about semiotics!
take this class
prereqs: FRE 207 or FRE 215 required. FRE 307 or equivalent recommended. FRE 307 can be taken concurrently..
descrip: What is behind the "power" of images? How do visual discourses work? How do texts and images interact to create meaning and tell stories? In this course, we will explore issues of representation and ideology by examining images that try to persuade, shock, seduce or surprise us. You will learn to engage critically with visual material, while enriching your cultural knowledge and understanding, analyzing and discussing different types of narratives stemming from French culture, ranging from advertisements to propaganda, political communication, caricatures and artwork.

title: Antioch through the Ages - Archaeology and History
reviews: Great opportunity to work with primary sources, artifacts, and material to contribute to an important ongoing project.
If you are interested in archaeology or analyzing history, I highly recommend this class as it gives you a chance to contribute to the discipline in a very hands on manner.
If you really like history, classics studies, near eastern studies, hellenistic studies, byzantine studies, or archaeology you should take this course!

This was a great, solid class. Even if you have no experience with archaeology, this class is well-suited for you. It was a truly rewarding experience because we discovered things about the dig site that were completely overlooked by historians and researchers for the last 100 years. It was awesome to see our research and analysis be recognized by scholars. This was a great class to take to fulfill a distribution requirement, and it's also a great class to take just for fun. If you have a tough and monotonous schedule as a BSE major, or Quant-driven AB major, take this course because it's a refreshing class that is driven by intellectual curiosity as opposed to boring P Sets.
prereqs: The course is open to undergraduates without prerequisites, but some knowledge of the history of the Ancient, Byzantine or Islamic Mediterranean would be useful..
descrip: Antioch has been a major point of contact between the Mediterranean region and Asia from ancient times to the present. Students in this new course will get exclusive access to the artifacts and records of Princeton's Antioch excavations of the 1930s and will read and discuss sources and studies on the history of the city from its Hellenistic origins to recent activity by ISIS in the area. Attention will be paid to the city's geological setting and changes in its cultural identity and ecological environment. Each student will work on a research project, and all students will collaborate on the production of a public website about Antioch.

title: International Macroeconomics
descrip: Issues in open economy macroeconomics and international finance. Topics include an exchange rate determination and dynamics, macroeconomic policy under fixed and floating exchange rates, current account behavior, exchange rate management and international policy coordination, and the history of the international monetary system. Special attention is given to the analysis of exchange rate crises. Prerequisite: 512c.

title: History of African American Families
reviews: If you're at all interested in american history, take this course. Professor Hunter is no push-over, but it was very worth it.
Take alot of notes,
Take it
take it!
descrip: This course covers the history of African-American families. It traces the development of family life, meanings, values, and institutions from the period of slavery up to recent times. The course engages long-standing and current debates about black families in the scholarship across disciplines and in the society at large. The course will look at the diversity of black family arrangements and the way these have changed over time and adapted to internal and external challenges and demands. It will also situate the history of black families within a broader cross-cultural context.

title: Cicero
reviews: Baraz is a fantastic professor.  She made Cicero so much more interesting than I thought he was going to be.  This is a fantastic course.
Definitely take this class; the professor is excellent; Cicero is also excellent.
It's like another Latin translation class, but it is also something more.

Professor Baraz is a great person with whom to study Cicero. This class was not too stressful because less emphasis was focused on going through translation in class (indeed, an hour of every class at least was spent on discussing the works themselves and their contexts). But make sure to work with Prof. Baraz on your midterm and final paper to make sure you're on track to getting that A.
Relaxed in class discussion and well-organized course.
TAKE IT! Prof Baraz is wonderful -- she knows everything to know about Latin and is also a wonderfully kind and thought-provoking teacher.

This a great class and Professor Baraz is a great teacher. You definitely need to know Latin pretty well and often we wouldn't talk about any of the actual Latin in a class (just the ideas brought up) so it is definitely a step up from 200 level courses, but it was very rewarding.
Try to do the readings ahead of time so you can appreciate the class discussions more!
prereqs: A 200 level Latin course or permission of instructor..
descrip: Cicero in 44: We will read texts composed by Cicero within one year, 44BC, following the death of Caesar and before his own death in 43. We will explore how the same pressures and concerns find expression in different genres: personal letters, philosophical works and public speeches.

title: Topics in International Relations - Terrorism, Civil War & Non-State Threats
descrip: This seminar is devoted to understanding (1) forms of political violence other than interstate war and (2) how policy makers can (and sometimes cannot) take action to ameliorate the threat from non-state violence. Course requires careful reading of 1-2 policy statements and 2-3 moderately technical articles each week on topics including: terrorism, the causes of civil war, the duration and cessation of civil war, the transition from violence to democracy, violence and social order, economic development and violence, the institutional structure of insurgent organizations, government violence and expropriation, revolution, and ethnic violence.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Urban Economics
descrip: This is a course in urban and regional economics. Course studies the main economic forces that lead to the emergence of cities and regional agglomeration, and the effects on worker productivity, urban amenities, and congestion. Course discusses the problems in measuring these urban characteristics, the methodologies to do it, as well as the design of optimal urban policy. Course also studies the economic theory and evidence on the internal structure of cities, as well as the policies that can enhance urban living. Finally, the course analyzes the role cities play in aggregate economic development.

title: Elementary Swahili II
reviews: I guess it's ok if you need a language requirement and are curious about Kenyan culture. It's not that well structured though.

If you have even the slightest interest in East Africa, or you just want to learn a language you might never have the chance to learn again, absolutely take this class. Mahiri is not only an excellent professor, but a genuinely good person who has a vested interest in seeing his students succeed both in his class and in life in general.
Mahiri is an awesome teacher. Take swahili.
Take it!
prereqs: Only those who have taken Elementary Swahili I (SWA 101) should enroll..
descrip: This course is a continuation of Swahili 101. It enhances communicative skills with emphasis on writing, reading, comprehension and conversation. Class activities review and enhance already introduced skills in speaking, writing, listening and reading; all embedded in authentic and contemporary East African cultural content. Cultural themes include the basics of daily life such as relationships, food, physical features and other aspects of material culture of East Africa. Learners are expected to perform functions related to basic services, comprehension of basic spoken and written texts and writing of a 1-page essay in Kiswahili.

title: Making Gender: Bodies, Meanings, Voices
reviews: Cool course, would definitely recommend to anyone interested in gender/society. Discussions were thought-provoking and relevant. Professor Lederman was incredible!
I loved this course!
I would suggest that they come in with an open mind and not be afraid to be wrong when stating their background assumptions.
Interesting, loved it
Journals are a big part of the class from week to week-- highly recommended that you do them on schedule!
Keep up with your journal entries. Do not allow yourself to fall behind.
Participate a lot in class.
Spend time on each journal, as you'll be glad you did at the midterm and final period. Start your essay early.
Take this course! There is relatively little work, and the readings and class are always interesting.
prereqs: This course is designed to serve the needs of both anthropology majors and students with no prior anthropology experience. Majors will encounter approaches and topical themes to complement and enhance their Independent Work; first- and second-year students and other non-anthropology majors will get a concrete sense of the kinds of questions anthropologists ask and how they go about answering them. Through systematic journal-writing, everyone will hone observational skills and explore the mutual implications of everyday experience and academic knowledge..
descrip: How do gendered and sexual identities, relationships, and meanings differ and how are they similar across cultural and historical contexts? This course illustrates the uses of fieldwork and other anthropological methods in answering questions about the universality or particularity of gendered experience. We draw on theories about human nature, cultural meaning, and linguistic and social structures, power, and agency to understand representations of maleness, femaleness, and other sexed/gendered distinctions, to explore how such representations are made and remade, and to relate them to other kinds of social difference and inequality.

title: Introduction to Differential Geometry
prereqs: MAT218 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to geometry of surfaces. Surfaces in Euclidan space, second fundamental form, minimal surfaces, geodescis, Gauss curvature, Gauss-Bonnet formula, uniformization of surfaces, elementary notions of contact geometry.

title: Problems of Philosophy - Modal Logic as Metaphysics
descrip: We will spend this semester reading Timothy Williamson's book "Modal Logic as Metaphysics," and will supplement with background readings as appropriate.

title: Beginner's Latin Continued: Basic Prose
reviews: Prepare yourself.

This is a great introductory language class, especially if you like Latin.  It's not too difficult to keep up - as long as you do the assignments and learn the vocabulary each week, you should be able to do well.
n/a
prereqs: LAT 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continues Latin grammar from LAT 101. The second half of the semester will be devoted to reading continuous Latin poetry and prose.

title: Unmaking the Bomb:The Science &Technology of Nuclear Nonproliferation, Disarmament, and Verification
reviews: Take this if you're interested in learning more about nuclear weapons and the basics in designing them. Glaser is a good professor and very attentive to his class' needs.
The class was cool.  Just don't get stuck with a group that doesn't do any work.
You know you want to take the course because nuclear bombs. It's everything you hoped it would be and more. Just take it.
prereqs: PHY 101 or PHY 102 or PHY 103 or PHY 104. MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers the science and technology underlying existing and emerging nuclear security issues. Part I introduces the principles of nuclear fission, nuclear radiation, and nuclear weapons (and their effects). Part II develops the concepts required to model and analyze nuclear systems, including the production of fissile materials and the detection and characterization of these materials with radiation measurement techniques. Relevant applications are explored in Part III and include nuclear forensic analysis, nuclear archaeology, and nuclear warhead verification. Such case studies will also be part of the final projects.

title: Property, Wealth, and Equality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Designing Life: The Ethics of Creation and Its Control
descrip: See website

title: Advanced Arabic I
descrip: Development of speaking, listening, reading and writing at the upper-intermediate to advanced levels of proficiency. Course is taught primarily in Arabic.

title: Advanced Arabic Skills Workshop II
reviews: All of the readings are old historic pieces--if that interests you, take this course
Be prepared to read!
If you want to develop your advanced Arabic reading, writing, and speaking skills take this course. The workload is reasonable and I feel like my Arabic has improved immensely. Also Tarek is the man.
None
Take any class with Tarek, it will be awesome.
Take this course! You will grow in Arabic.
This class is a challenge, but take it if you are willing to invest significant time into it. Your language skills will certainly improve.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 401 or the instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of ARA 401, focusing on readings in a variety of Arabic genres.

title: Ocean, Atmosphere, and Climate
reviews: Do the assigned readings, will help you in the long run. The class is great!

I would caution a student that GEO 202 is a lot of work and can be confusing at points but is overall very well-supported and you can learn a great deal of practical knowledge and applied science if you are interested.
If you like the ocean just a little bit, take this course! You'll learn a lot.
Take if you have to
Take this course
Take this course...I feel it will only get better and better.
This course is hard, but take it if you like the ocean.

This course is so cool! There is a relatively reasonable workload and it is definitely worth it.  Assuming of course you are interested in oceanography.  Make sure you go to all lectures because there is more to it than just what's on the slide, start psets and labs early - they're not long but sometimes it'll take longer than you had planned.  Overall really great course.
take it for GEO -- material is easy but grading can be a bit nitpicky. If you have a TA like Jeff you are in good hands.
prereqs: High School biology, chemistry and calculus..
descrip: An introduction to the ocean, atmosphere, and climate from the perspective of oceanography. Covers coastal processes including waves, beaches, tides and ecosystems; open ocean processes including atmospheric circulation and its impact on the surface ocean, the wind driven circulation, and surface ocean ecosystems; and the abyssal ocean including circulation, the cycling of chemicals, and ocean sediments and what they tell us about the climate history of the earth. The final part of the course will cover humans and the earth system, including a discussion of ocean resources and climate change.

title: Metabolic Engineering
descrip: Introduction to the engineering of metabolism. The objective of this course is to introduce students to current techniques and challenges within the field of metabolic engineering. Specific topics range from applications for energy and the environment to human health. The course also includes lectures from industrial speakers, a mock NSF panel review of research proposals, and debates structured as reviewers discussing the appropriateness of manuscripts for publication.

title: Topics in Mineralogy and Mineral Physics - Multidisciplinary Studies of the Deep Earth
descrip: This course will survey the structure and properties of the deep earth, including the lower mantle and core. Seismology, mineral physics and geodynamics will be used to explore different facets of the deep earth, and the interiors of other planets, with an emphasis on fundamental and cutting edge literature.

title: Elementary Hebrew II
reviews: Good introduction to Hebrew.
If you want to get better at speaking, writing, and reading Hebrew and have some previous knowledge, you should look into this course.
The course is enjoyable and engaging. The workload is rather mild, and as long as you review words you should be fine.
You MUST study the vocab and words every single night. I had difficulty at first because I wasn't studying nearly enough in additional to the daily homework
prereqs: HEB 101 or equivalent.
descrip: This course is designed for students who are familiar with the Hebrew alphabet, and who have rudimentary skills in reading, writing, speaking and comprehending modern Hebrew. Over the spring term, students will further develop their proficiency in these skills, and acquire a solid grounding in modern Hebrew grammar and syntax. By the end of the semester, students will be able to read and comment on short articles, stories and poems, to conduct conversations, and make short presentations.

title: The Perception of China and Asia in the West
reviews: Interesting readings, good mini-lectures, interesting papers with a really great system of graded revisions, but you only present a portion of the reading in class so you don't really discuss it.
Interesting subject, easy A or PDF, but class isn't engaging.

Make sure you don't push assignments until the last moment - it's better to be ahead than to be stressed out at the last moment. The class is what you make of it; if you really enjoy the material, you can dedicate a lot more and therefore get a lot more from the class.
Sit near the professor

Take it. It is an invaluable experience and a great introduction to one of the most important issues to the world right now. You'll never see Asia the same way....and you'll never see the West the same way. All this for a reasonable amount of workload, with lots of feedback from one of the best professors around.
Take this course! If you're looking for a general-interest class or a distribution class and don't mind a 3-hour seminar once a week, there are few better.
descrip: This course has three goals: 1) to present some of the major themes in the Western perception of China since 1250, "from Marco Polo to Chairman Mao", 2) to introduce the student to the nature of history and historical writing, 3) to challenge the student to do some critical historiographical analysis of his/her own. Readings will focus on primary sources in translation and relevant secondary studies.

title: Intermediate Polish
prereqs: PLS 105.
descrip: The class will continue to improve students' knowledge of Polish through conversation and review of grammar, and it will enhance their reading skills through the analysis and translation of some Polish poetry and fragments of prose. There will be also short written assignments.

title: Legal and Regulatory Policy Toward Markets
descrip: This course employs the methods of microeconomics, industrial organization and law and economics to study where market failures warrant gov't intervention with policies implemented through the law or regulatory agencies. Topics include antitrust policy toward business practices and vertical and horizontal combinations; policy approaches toward R&D and intellectual property; reliance on tort law, disclosure law, and regulatory standards to mitigate information and externality problems pertaining to health, safety, and performance risks; and the implications for pricing, entry, and investment of different forms of public utility regulation.

title: International Political Theory
descrip: The seminar will be devoted to the recent literature on various aspects of global justice. The main themes may include global distributive justice (Rawls's The Law of Peoples and subsequent literature); justice and global governance institutions; international legitimacy and democracy; and human rights. Open to undergraduates only with instructor's permission.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Economics
reviews: Free lunch!
No advice.
descrip: This seminar is designed to help graduate students in economics cultivate ethical research practices they may apply in future work at or beyond the University. Students are encouraged to discuss concerns that may arise during the conduct of their research with experienced faculty and devise solutions for dealing with these concerns. The course provides necessary training for newly mandated RCR training for graduate students supported by government grants, and is required for successful completion of the program.

title: Biophysics
descrip: The course presents a broader view of biological physics. While the course starts with an overview of the fundamentals of biological physics, using Frauenfelder's text book as a guide, the course will move on to higher levels of biological systems, using evolution and ecology as our primary organizing principles. The course will have a section on the Physics of Cancer at the end.

title: Hydrology
reviews: It's not the most interesting course, and it's relatively quantitative, but it's not too hard and could be fun if you're more interested in water than I am.
Make the material fun for you! There are a lot of equations but just break up the material into understandable portions.
Not too hard. A little boring at times.

Stay on top of the material and finish problem sets early enough to compare your results with others! They seem complex at first, and sometimes require a lot of systems of equations, but are often addressed comprehensively through material in the text.
Take it.

This class is very heavy on environmental stuff.  I took it as a CBE for an elective in the environmental track, and I don't think I'll ever be able to use this.  But an interesting course, and not too difficult.
