Unless something changes, the lectures are uninteresting and verbatim the readings provided.  The material could be very interesting if done correctly.
good course that teaches a bunch about hydrology, somewhat dry at times though
descrip: Analysis of fundamental processes in the hydrologic cycle, including precipitation, evapotranspiration, infiltration, streamflow and groundwater flow.

title: Master of Engineering Independent Project II
descrip: Continuation of MAE 513. Directed study for Master of Engineering students. The topic is proposed by the student and must be approved by the student's research advisor and have received approval from the MAE Graduate Committee.

title: Intensive Portuguese
reviews: Definitely take for a fun, welcoming department that helps you learn a new language
If you're taking this course alongside four other courses (and you're an engineer), think again. That being said, it is crazy how much Portuguese you learn in such a short time.

Moves quickly so do homework and even extra work. Grammar focuses heavily on conjugation and verb usage. Vocabulary is not really provided after the first few classes, so do the readings in the textbook and look up a lot of words.  Go to Portuguese language tables.
TAKE THIS COURSE. It's hardcore but you'll have learned so much you won't even believe!
Yes, 100% take this class if you have 1 semester and want to learn a language and be able to go to a bunch of countries and engage with the people/culture there.
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.

title: The Roman Empire, 31 B.C. to A.D. 337
prereqs: No knowledge of Greek or Latin necessary. Auditors are welcome..
descrip: To study the Roman Empire at its height; to trace the transformation of government from a republican oligarchy to despotism; to study the changes wrought by multiculturalism on the old unitary society; to trace the rise of Christianity from persecution to dominance; and to assess Rome's contributions to western civilization.

title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
descrip: The aim of this course is to familiarize students with work in contemporary sociological theory that has had a major impact on empirical research in the U.S., or holds untapped potential for such impact. We will focus especially on bodies of theory relevant to large tracts of the discipline. Rather than attempt a survey, we will read in depth select theoretical texts that together illustrate the heterogeneity and richness of the field.

title: Greek Lyric Poetry
descrip: This seminar will study representative epinicia of Pindar and Bacchylides, reading as many poems as time permits but not attempting to cover more than two or three odes per meeting. The question is: Where to go after Bundy? All epinicia may look the same, but not all laudandi are the same, and we will try to make sense of the specificity of the odes by considering their contexts, performative as well as social and historical. There will be some attention to their more substantial fragments in other genres, to scholia and to reception.

title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities - Adventures in Ideas
reviews: I loved this course! It was a once in a lifetime experience. This is the sort of class that Princeton is all about -- engaging with some of the greatest minds the University has to offer! The reading load is manageable. The grading was not particularly kind but not really horrible either. TAKE THIS! This was probably my favorite course at Princeton, even though I may likely be getting a B .

If you're looking for a capstone course that's going to have you engage with serious, difficult texts and the questions of ethics, politics, the humanities, and civics that they ask, then I'm not sure this is the course for you. The course advertises itself as such a class, but it was far more performative on the part of the professors than I had hoped - they lectured a lot, got into debates with each other, sometimes excluding students because of the level of expertise they had reached, and  primarily answered students questions rather than letting other students respond and engage in a dialogue with each other. I had high hopes for this course, and I was ultimately very disappointed because it could have been so much better than it was.

TAKE TAKE TAKE TAKE. This is the type of transformative, transcendent experience I sought in a college education, and when I look back on my college education, Robbie George and Cornel West's seminar is what I will think of. I have walked away at the end of class feeling stunned, dazed even, with my worldview shaken by what we discussed. The two work together effortlessly and guide the discussion flawlessly. These 3 hours a week will take you far from your everyday pset, reading, social drama life and send you on a deep journey among some of the most important questions of the human existence. What more could you ask for? TAKE.
The two best professors at Princeton teaching one course. The reading list and requirements don't matter when you have the West-George powerhouse leading it.

This class is the most challenging and thought provoking course that I have taken at Princeton. You should take this class if you want to challenge yourself to think in new ways and engage with some of the brightest minds in history. Professors West and George are two of the smartest people I have ever spoken with. Regardless if you agree or disagree with them (you inevitably will disagree with one) you will leave this class having an appreciation for their academic curiosity and intelligence. Hearing them lecture each week was an absolute pleasure. During this course you may get sick of the readings or the open-ended assignments (which are challenging) but you will 100% be happy you took this class when all is said and done. This is the epitome of a Princeton education: the opportunity to engage with two of the most famous intellectuals in a small environment on a weekly basis. Make no mistake this class is not easy, but it will be worth it in the end!
class of a life-time
don't miss this class if you care about religion, morals, ethics, history, or philosophy
if this course is offered again, take it even if you're intimidated!
descrip: In this seminar, we will consider writings by influential ancient and modern thinkers who have reflected on the meaning of human existence and the terms of social and political life. We propose a fresh look at each work we engage, taking the text on its own merits and abstaining from the examination of secondary sources.

title: Nationalism and Religion in the Modern Middle East
descrip: Investigates theoretical, rhetorical, and political relationships between religion and nationalism in the modern Middle East - historically and historiographically. What role did religion play in the rise of nationalist ideologies and identities in the 19th and 20th centuries? Was it a motivating force in this process or a tool to be used and abused? Was the relationship different in nationalisms that sought to cut across religious divisions? How have others dealt with these questions and what do the scholarly trends suggest? Students undertake their own research to assess this relationship in a case study of their choice.

title: Introductory Painting
reviews: Definitely take it, but be warned, it's much more work than you'd expect!

I learned a lot of things from the class, but it was definitely difficult to figure out what Eve wanted. I ended up PDFing because I had no idea what her expectations were. Be prepared to put in a lot of work on top of all the class time.
I'd recommend this class, but beware, given that the classes are pretty long they can feel like they drag on if you're working on a project that isn't too fun.
Intro Painting with Eve is great! The course takes up a fair amount of time out of class but if you like painting (or if you've never painted but think you'd probably like it) it's no big deal.
Take it!! It's demanding of your time because you have to come in outside of class, but totally worth it.
There will be others in the course who can paint extremely well, and it can be scary.
ya
descrip: An introduction to the materials and methods of painting. The areas to be covered are color and its interaction, the use of form and scale, painting from a model, painting objects with a concern for their mass and interaction with light.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: I highly recommend the class.

I think it was a great studio with a very engaged, experienced and professional faculty member. I would very much encourage students to enroll in a studio by this instructor exploring this subject matter.
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: The Origins of Rome: Livy and Vergil
reviews: Always glance over the daily readings and look up any words you don't know. Even if you don't know the exact translation coming in, you get more out of the class if you aren't scrambling for meanings and can focus on analyzing the text.
Definitely take it--it's not too much work but definitely worth it!
Fun, not too difficult.

Haynes is a great professor who clearly knows her Latin, knows her history, and knows how to teach. She's patient, but still expects good work. She'll give you all the material you need to succeed in this course, and it's up to you to put in the work. I loved this class!

I would recommend a solid and recent foundation in Latin. If it has been awhile (since high school) that you took Latin, it would probably be smoother to start at a lower level or try another language.
I would take this class if you have interest in Latin, and it is a fine course to fulfill a distribution requirement.

It is a good class to solidify latin translation skills. Professor Haynes is a very good teacher, and it will be very enjoyable as long as you are prepared to do the required translations every night.
Lots of work
Make sure you have strong background knowledge.
Read the text before class, take notes on vocab. It makes the class much easier
Take it if it is taught by Professor Haynes! She is SO great! neat class!
Take it if you enjoy the classics.
Take the professor's section if you can. Get to know your classmates and study with them. Stay on top of the readings. Read the interstitial English. Go to office hours and review sessions.
prereqs: LAT 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: We will read selections from Livy and Vergil, the masters of prose and poetry respectively in the period of Augustus. Our objectives are: to develop the ability to read Latin with greater ease and enjoyment; to improve sight-reading skills; to experience the artistry of Latin prose and poetry; and to examine some of the questions associated with the Romans' interpretation of their history.

title: Religion and Democracy (Half-Term)
descrip: This course is situated at the intersection of political theory, social theory, public law, and comparative politics. We revisit basic normative questions to do with religion and democratic politics: how can democratic polities be protected from religion, and how can religion be protected from politics? Or do certain forms of democratic politics depend on religious sources? What, if any, are the implications of "post-secularism" for democracy? We examine a number of classic works in the history of political thought, and then move on to present-day debates in political theory, especially the work of Rawls, Habermas, and Taylor.

title: Introductory Seismology
prereqs: PHY 104 and MAE 305 (can be taken concurrently), or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Fundamentals of seismology and seismic wave propagation. Introduction to acoustic and elastic wave propagation concepts, observational methods, and inferences that can be drawn from seismic data about the deep planetary structure of the Earth, as well as about the occurrence of oil and gas deposits in the crust. Offered every other year.

title: Physical Chemistry: Chemical Thermodynamics and Kinetics
reviews: A good course, but maybe a little easy if you've taken thermodynamics before.
Do lots of practice problems, but also make sure to understand theoretical concepts.  Go to office hours for help, and form study groups.  This class is a collaborative effort!
Don't go through it alone... Have a study group and work through every conceptual question together from Day 1.
Don't let yourself be confused by Prof. Kelly.  Read the textbook over and over again until you get it.

I don't know about the other thermo courses, but 306 seems like a decent course. Advanced topics are not covered, but a good effort is made to introduce students to relevant concepts. If you're thinking about which thermo course to take, take this one. There are four exams on four distinct topics (thermo, real/ideal solutions, stat mech, and kinetics), which is a bummer but they're not cumulative so that's a plus. I think it gives you many opportunities to do well (or fail).
I wouldn't mind taking this course for my P-Chem requirement.
If you're interested in thermo, definitely take it! Dr. Kelly is a great lecturer and really helps you understand the material!

If you're taking it because of an outside interest in chemistry, don't. For chem majors, see how the current professor for advanced thermo is rated, that class could be better, although as of now I heard it's equally bad. MTK is great in office hours, try to do concept questions before a test.
It's a grind, but you'll get through it. Make sure you always ask questions and take advantage of online resources.
Its hard as balls but Dr. Kelly makes it worth it.
Much easier and more well taught than quantum.
Start the HW early!
Stay on top of the material!
Take it if you have to. The stat mech stuff is interesting.
Take it. Good class.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 and MAT 104, or CHM 215, or permission of instructor. Course is open to freshmen who have completed CHM 215..
descrip: At the center of this course is the recognition of Gibbs Free Energy as a fundamental quantity describing physical processes. From this, we will develop concepts of thermodynamics and kinetics, and illustrate them with examples from chemistry.

title: Solid-State Physics II
prereqs: ELE 441 or PHY 405 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Electronic structure of solids. Electron dynamics and transport. Semiconductors and impurity states. Surfaces. Dielectric properties of insulators. Electron-electron, electron-phonon, and phonon-phonon interactions. Anharmonic effects in crystals. Magnetism. Superconductivity.

title: Topics in the French Middle Ages and Renaissance - Quest, Chronicle, Crusade: The Medieval Romance in Context
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines the medieval French romance genre, in particular the Arthurian romances, in their contemporary political and cultural contexts. We will ask how idealized representations of kingship, courtly love and the rituals of feudal culture might reveal anxieties about power and the social order specifically related to the experience of the Crusades and the expansion of French influence throughout the Mediterranean.

title: Studies in the Religions of the Americas - Religion in America to 1865
descrip: In this course we will engage questions of approach, method, periodization, and scope in the study of religion in America through the Civil War. Texts will consist of secondary literature with both classic and contemporary importance to the field, along with brief primary sources selected and presented by students.

title: Higher Education and Society
reviews: Choose a topic you enjoy for the final paper!
Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in the state of higher education in America.
Definitely take this course.  Professor Lawrence was awesome!
Don't get too bogged down in the statistics papers. Just take notes of the main points and you'll be good for the class discussions.
Great course for thinking about education in the real world and on a practical level instead of a purely theoretical level.
I know Prof. Lawrence is leaving, so NA. But I would have highly recommended it
I would encourage the student to prepare for class and to participate. The seminar is more rewarding when you do so.

If Matt weren't leaving, I would absolutely recommend taking a course with him.  He is one of the best professors I've had at Princeton because he cares about students and about what he is teaching about - this is what I look for in all my classes and sometimes it is hard to find here.

Really engage with the readings. Even if you feel like you can get through the seminar without reading the readings I closely, I found them to truly enrich my understanding of the topic, not to mention interesting.
Take it if you're interested in the topic
There's really no reason not to take this if you're interested in higher education.
This class is awesome -100% take it.
descrip: Is higher education still a pathway to opportunity? This course will examine issues related to college access, aid, and accountability. We will begin by reviewing recent research on topics such as: the changing demographics of students, the definition of "merit" in admissions, the challenges of assessment, and student loan debt. We will consider how college is increasingly associated with later outcomes such as income, occupation, health, and family formation. We will also discuss the politics of higher education reform and whether innovations like online courses can reshape the future of postsecondary schooling.

title: Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - Modern Electrochemistry
reviews: Definitely. It's important that there is interest in the topic, but overall it was an amazing class.
Excellent course overall. If you don't like math so much, it may not be the right course for you.

Overall, the course was really excellent, and VanderKam and Bocarsly are great lecturers.  I think it's more of a class where what you learn is determined by what you want to get out of it; the course scratches the surface on a lot of different techniques, but you have the freedom to look into things further and it helps your understanding.  It's definitely more of a grad course in that sense, although they have exams and problem sets like an undergrad course.
Take if you are interested in electrochemistry.
Take it.

Taking good notes in lecture is 90% of the battle. Makes problem sets/reviewing much easier. Lectures are posted online, but they will only make sense if you've written your own notes as the material is presented.
descrip: This course explores the theory and practice of modern techniques in electrochemistry. Physical chemistry of charge transfer is considered, as well as applications in the areas of electroanalytical chemistry and photoelectrochemistry. Key laboratory techniques, such as cyclic voltammetry, chronoamperometry and rotating disk voltammetry are a focus of the course.

title: Climate Change, Adaptation and Urban Design
descrip: Climate change adaptation is a pressing and difficult challenge to urban design, ecological and engineering planning theory and practice. It is clear that architects, planners, engineers and designers have an important role to help cities contend with climate adaptation. This seminar reviews the general state of science and practice of climate change and adaptation with a primary focus on the United States. It looks to the work of Frederick Law Olmsted for some of the theoretical basis of developing an approach to climate adaptation that is democratic and progressive and evaluate the impediments which restrict change.

title: Hellenistic Art
reviews: Absolutely take this class. You don't need a background in either Classics or Art History, although it wouldn't hurt.
Just show up on time and be attentive
Make sure to keep up with the material! And don't miss any classes, it's worth it.
Take it! It's a wonderful course!
descrip: Survey of the transformations in Greek art beginning with the decline of the Classical period (fifth century BCE) and continuing through the period of Alexander the Great's unification of the Mediterranean world, up to and including the Roman conquest of the east. Emphasis on sculpture, painting, and mosaic.

title: European Intellectual History
reviews: I would tell an English student to take the course because it prepares you to think about textual problems transhistorically.
If you have in investment in intellectual history, philosophy & critical theory, or histories of modern Europe, this is an excellent course.
descrip: This seminar will discuss methodological and historiographical issues in intellectual history with a specific focus on "conceptual history" (Begriffsgeschichte). Among the figures we will consider are Reinhart Koselleck, Carl Schmitt, Daniel Bell, Hannah Arendt.

title: Words As Objects
reviews: Good course but slightly unstructured as it is still new. That being said, this could be a good thing because it allows for a lot of room for students to pursue their own interests.
Take it! This will likely improve from its inaugural semester, and you will have a lot of fun!
great class
descrip: This course will explore ways that language can take on material properties and how objects can have syntax and be "read". Through studio assignments, readings, and discussions, students will investigate the idea of language as a tangible material that can be sliced, bent, inserted, reproduced, embedded, and scattered, as in the work of such modern artists as Guillaume Apollinaire, Susan Howe, Marcel Broodthaers, or Jenny Holzer. In each instance, our perception of meaning through language, and our perception of lived experience through material form, are both altered by their engagement with the other.

title: American Constitutional Development
descrip: Explore questions of order and change in American constitutional doctrine and institutional relations and powers across time. Students will consider diverse theories of constitutional and institutional change, including those drawn from comparative politics. Emphasis will be on the relationship between paths of constitutional development and both conventions of legal and constitutional reasoning, and political, economic, social, and intellectual currents, settlements, and crises.

title: Polymer Viscoelasticity
reviews: Go over the notes right after class
If you are interested in the properties of polymers, take this course. May be helpful to have taken an introductory polymers course first.
It is a good special topics course with a lighter workload if you're interested in general about polymer science, the glass transition, or specifically polymer viscoelasticity.
The course involves a lot of work for a pass/fail class.
This is a very good course if you are interested in this topic.
descrip: This course is designed to provide students with a firm grasp of viscoelasticity and how molecular structure of polymeric materials affect their viscoelastic properties. The course explores topics including viscoelastic behavior, linear and non-linear viscoelasticity, mechanical properties of polymers, dilute solutions, concerntrated solutions, polymer melts and glasses, molecular theories, and rubber elasticity.

title: Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: A great chance to improve your writing skills--fiction or otherwise. Fiona is an excellent teacher and you will absolutely feel like you've progressed by the end of the semester.
A very low key class, but still a good way to improve your creative writing!
Absolutely no work. Take it
Allow yourself a lot of time to write a story, it always takes longer than you think it will.
Be creative! This class is amazing as a fifth course
CWR is a great class to take at Pton!

Chang-rae Lee is a great guy and is open to giving help and feedback. His course is very unstructured and he probably doesn't give as much work or demand as much as some of the other creative writing professors. I thought his readings were well chosen.

Colson is good; he's got a more didactic way of teaching writing than some teachers that can be a nice choice for newer writers, but sometimes, if he doesn't like your story, he just end on that instead of coming up with ways to improve the story. Good for improving your essential roots of creative writing.

Creative Writing is always fun, and this class is no different. It's a very reasonable workload, too. The only downside is that we didn't get much actual instruction on the art of story writing, but you definitely still grow as a writer through the workshops.
Definitely take a creative writing class. They are wonderful and fun. Prof Whitehead is an excellent professor.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take it! You learn a ton and have a lot of fun in a low-pressure environment.
Definitely take this course! Sigrid is a great instructor and makes everyone feel like they have something to offer! The readings were very interesting and I loved writing for this class.
Definitely take this if you're into creative writing, but it's more work than it's worth if you're not.
Do it!
Do not take with Sigrid Nunez - it would be a waste of time.
Enjoy what you do :)

Everyone I'm sure will recommend different people. I get mixed reviews for the 'famous' teachers, and only ever positive for the relatively unheard of. Take from the people you haven't heard from. They'll engage with you more, give better advice, and be less divisive. No one cares if you studied with JCO. People care if your stories are good, and being a good storyteller doesn't correlate with being a good story-teacher.
Everyone should take a creative writing course
Fiona has a very no-BS attitude and a dark sense of humor, which took a little getting used to, but in the end was refreshing. It was a good class overall?definitely glad I took it.
Great course!
Highly recommend if interested even a little bit in CWR
I don't have much advice for other students.
I think any STEM major should consider taking this class if you have any interest in creative writing. It is such a breath of fresh air to have a fun, engaged, and creative class.
If you at all care about words or stories or a good time, take this course.
If you have any interest at all in writing, definitely take this course. It's low stress but also teaches you a lot about writing fiction.
Put a lot into your stories because you get more out of it if you try and it benefits the rest of the class.
Put as much effort into it as you can. You want to make use of this opportunity to learn how to write more effectively.
Spend a lot of time on your writings!
Spend some time ahead of the class brainstorming what you would like to write about in order to have a longer period over which to develop your ideas.

Start early on your brainstorming and maybe even discuss with Fiona what might be good ways to develop your plot.  I often had a very hard time coming up with plots that 'worked' and always was given very good/helpful advice, but it was given after I'd completed writing, and I would have really appreciated discussion of ideas as I wrote/developed thoughts.  Overall, good class to take at some point because it opens you to another form of thinking.
Start your stories early! Gives you more time to think about them and figure out what is happening. Don't be afraid to cut and change things entirely.
Take advantage of time with the professors!
Take it if you are interested in creative writing whatsoever!
Take it if you are interested in or serious about creative writing!

Take it if you have any interest in creative writing! Prof. Steinke is very laid back, and the class as a whole is an awesome break from the craziness of typical Princeton classes. Not only is it a great 5th course and an easy way to get an LA done, you'll also learn a lot about the process of writing in general. So why not take this course?
Take it if you're going to participate. Don't take it if you're gonna slack off, because that matters to other students.
Take it!

Take it! It's absolutely awesome getting to write stories each week and really explore your creativity. Somewhat brought me back to childhood. It's so different from any other Princeton courses (especially if you're an engineer) and a lot of fun!
Take it!!! So rewarding just to sit in a room and deconstruct literature for the purposes of understanding what makes it good/bad. Very different from English classes.
Take it. CWR with any prof is amazing and a worthwhile experience.
Take it. Nunez in particular has great feedback, and class is always interesting. I didn't like some of her reading selections personally though.
Take it. Super easy. Totally worth it.
Take the course, but be careful, the professor and the students in the course will dictate the nature, quality, and your interest in the course

Take this class if you enjoy reading and ready to write several short stories. Professor Kohler is very dedicated and is very flexible. The best thing about being her student is that she would spend extra time to improve your work to help you- she looked through my story/ gave helpful suggestions to me when I told her that I will be applying for CWR 203 in the fall.
Take this course! The readings are good, you get to meet some cool people, and to have a fun class is a breath of fresh air if you have a busy schedule. Try to get Chang-rae Lee if you can!
Take this course; it is not a lot of work at all and is highly enjoyable.
The course didn't impact my writing as much as I had hoped. But the course was enjoyable and low-stress, and the readings were great, so it's worth taking.
The course is pretty interesting. Great if you're looking to explore.
The course was exactly what I expected it to be: a writing workshop where you get out only what you put into it. Only take it if you're willing to put in a lot of work to improve your writing.
Try to get a different professor.
Watch out for technical details, much of the workshops focus on this.

With Darcey, the course is enjoyable and helpful in showing you the main strengths and flaws of your writing. The atmosphere is pretty chill--maybe too chill, as I think we could have been pushed harder and written more. I liked this course, but I'm not sure if I'm all that interested in taking another CWR one based on this experience; it seemed less awesome than I expected (since people seem to rave about CWR classes taught by other professors).
Yes, it is interesting to take a creative writing course for anyone.
You will get out of it what you put in
take it
prereqs: Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Mathematical Analysis of Massive Data Sets
prereqs: Introductory to Real Analysis (MAT 314/320) or Integration Theory and Hilbert Spaces (MAT 332).
descrip: This course focuses on spectral methods useful in the analysis of big data sets. Spectral methods involve the construction of matrices (or linear operators) directly from the data and the computation of a few leading eigenvectors and eigenvalues for information extraction. Examples include the singular value decomposition and the closely related principal component analysis; the PageRank algorithm of Google for ranking web sites; and spectral clustering methods that use eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian.

title: Religion in Modern Thought and Film
reviews: Definitely take it. Unfortunately, Jeff Stout is not going to be the professor anymore, so I don't know how the class will be run.
Do it.

Don't just take this course because of the film component. Do all the readings, they are incredibly eye-opening. Whatever you think about religion, expect to have your assumptions challenged -- and embrace the questions!
Engage in precept and ask questions whenever you have them! It can sometimes seem like a lot of work but when broken down it is doable.
Go to all the movies in the theater!
Go to the film screenings, otherwise you probably won't really watch the movie.
Great class!!

I would advise another student to take this course if they are willing to set aside the time necessary to truly watch the films. It's not a small commitment but it's worth the effort if you're willing/able to provide it.
I would strongly recommend it.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone. Professor Stout was absolutely amazing.
I would very much recommend this course, I think all students should take the time to view think about the things we discussed.

If Professor Stout wasn't leaving, I would definitely stress that everyone should take this course! It was thought provoking, interesting, and enjoyable. It was not too much work either. The perfect combination.
If you have any interest in film, this course is worth taking.
It is too bad you couldn't have taken it with Stout, but nonetheless, the material is worth engaging with.
Just enjoy it! Don't be afraid, care, and don't sleep through life! Be active! Be there!

Learning religious philosophy is a lot more fun with movies. Stout is a great lecturer, and this course is a good general knowledge class since it surveys pretty much most of the big Western thinkers since the 1400s.
Prof. Stout is one of the most revered at Princeton. Next year will be different.
Stout is amazing.

Stout won't be teaching it again, so hard to say cause that's what really made it for me, but any course that uses film to investigate these ideas has a good shot at being similarly meaningful. If you're looking, or might be looking, for a course that will make a personal impact on you and the way you think, this one has a good chance of doing it.

TAKE IT! Sadly Prof. Stout won't be teaching it in the future, but still, I'm sure the class will continue in its awesomeness, since all of the readings and the films covered in the class are superb on their own. Adam Eitel is a great preceptor too if he's available.
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take
Take it for the material, stay for Professor Stout.
Take it! (even though it won't be the same without Professor Stout)
Take this class!!!!!!!
This course can take up a lot of time and mental energy, as you won't always get answers and have to move on to the next week while still being confused from the previous material
This is a fantastic EC.
Unfortunately, the course is no longer offered in its current form. Do try to take Stout's classes. I wish I had gone to his office hours.
great to PDF, but not as easy if you want an A... easy to get a B/B  though.
moot point, unfortunately
prereqs: Required for Religion Department majors..
descrip: This course examines the most influential modern conceptions of religion, as articulated by major thinkers (e.g. Durkheim, Emerson, Freud, Marx, Nietzsche, Pascal, Weber) and filmmakers (e.g. Antonioni, Capra, Friedrich, Hitchcock, Kurosawa). Topics include secularization, the rationality of religious belief, the psychological pathologies, social functions, and political effects of religion, the social construction of identities, and international cinema as vehicle for the expression of "religious" and "secular" visions of transformation.

title: The Politics of Nature
reviews: Definitely take it! It's a great combination of environmental studies and anthropology.
Take it. It's a great class for non-anthropology majors to get into and understand anthro
Unfortunately you can't take this class anymore because Professor Ellison is leaving? But it was amazing!
Worthwhile. Prof Ellison is wonderful! But she's leaving so...go to Wellesley?
YES! with ellison!
take it.
descrip: In this course we will consider the social and political life of nature from an anthropological perspective. How are our ideas about nature historically and culturally produced? What is the relationship between resource control and the consolidation of power? From the work of conservation NGOs (nonprofit organizations) to laboratory-produced GMOs (genetically modified organisms), we will explore how notions of pristine wilderness, polluting people, and ethical business are produced and contested. Course themes range from the lived effects of extractive industries to nature as both a commodity and the grounds for claiming political rights.

title: Ballet as an Evolving Form: Technique and Repertory
reviews: Definitely take this course if you want to improve your ballet technique!!
I would just advise them to make the most of their time with these world-class instructors.
If you want to continue dancing take it!
Really great to have ballet built into your schedule if you want to have regular technique classes and it's great to learn from others in the class and from accomplished guest teachers.
TAKE IT!
Take if you are serious about ballet.
Take it if you're an advanced ballet student!

Take this class if you want to learn from renowned teachers and choreographers and take a more serious focus on ballet. I loved being able to take a good ballet class 3 times a week. Also, great opportunities to see performances in the city with this class!
Take this course if you are a serious ballet dancer and want to learn new choreography!

Take this course if you are a serious ballet/contemporary dancer. You get to keep up with your technique while expanding your knowledge of dance. You will get to work with professional choreographers, and the opportunities you get (including going to NYC to see free shows) are unmatched!
prereqs: Application by interview/audition only. Please email instructor (fehlandt@) for appointment..
descrip: A studio course in contemporary ballet technique for advanced students. The course will consist of an advanced ballet class and explorations into contemporary choreography through readings, viewings, and the learning of repertory. The course will focus on three renowned choreographers: Marius Petipa, George Balanchine, Christopher Wheeldon. Students will be coached by three prominent guest artists: Heather Watts, Ashley Tuttle, Jeffrey Edwards.

title: Genes, Brain, and the Human Mind
reviews: Definitely take this class for an upper level MOL or NEU. The days you present are high workload, but that's only 2-3 times the whole semester and the rest of it is laid-back and interesting. Learned a lot and found it super enjoyable!

Do not take this class if it is taught by Sam Wang. Previously this class was taught by Prof Wang and Prof Rosenberg - and their dynamic was described to me as "good cop, bad cop," with Sam Wang as a pretty bad cop. Now it's just Sam Wang, and the dynamic now is solely bad cop. Sam Wang will patronize you, and dismiss you if he does not like your ideas or input. Regrettably the material is super interesting, but it is overseen by a terrible teacher.
Prepare hard for your presentation by reading a lot of extra articles, not just the ones you were assigned. Talk to other people if you don't have strong biology background.
Take it! Do the readings, and spend time on them, and PDF it if you're not doing well (it's PDFable!). Also, make sure you participate in class--he loved it!
Take it! Heavy on primary literature reading and analysis, and presentations of that literature, but really helpful in learning how to critically interpret papers.
This course is as much work as you decide to spend on it. It is definitely worth taking if you are interested in real world implications of genetics.

This course is likely very different in style than what you are used to. You should probably only take this course if you have a science background and have some confidence in your ability to understand scientific research. Most importantly, carefully consider taking this course if oral presentations are not your thing--they make up half of your grade. Even if you are a good speaker, you are expected to become an "expert" in the scientific field you are presenting--a hard task for anyone. If you do take this course, it will teach you invaluable skills.
prereqs: Admission to this course requires a brief questionnaire. Preference will be given to students who have taken one molecular biology/genetics course (e.g. MOL101, 205, 214, 215 or 342) and one neuroscience course (e.g. NEU101 or 258 or PSY 208)..
descrip: How did the human brain become the most complex organ in the animal kingdom? How do genetic and environmental forces produce its capabilities and maladies? These questions have fascinated philosophers, humanists, physicians, and scientists for millennia and will be the focus of this course. The course will use human genetics and systems neuroscience to analyze topics including autism, Alzheimer disease, bipolar disorder and drug addiction. Class time will emphasize lectures, discussion, and student-generated presentations. The goal is to reach a modern understanding of how the human brain works and sometimes fails.

title: Global Exchange in Art and Architecture
descrip: The course will explore the origins of the globalizing process in the field of European arts. It will insist upon the beginnings of the phenomenon in the sixteenth century using Europe, Asia and the Americas as laboratories to describe and investigate the circulation of art objects between Europe and the rest of the world, and their meanings. Linking past and present globalization, the course will study how images (Guadalupe, Virgem de Nazare) are still powerful components of contemporary societies in the Western Hemisphere (Brazil, Mexico).

title: Honors Introduction to Formal Logic
reviews: Ask a lot of questions.
Content is great but presentation not so much

Do problems in the book; it's how you will challenge yourself.
Also, we prove that various proof systems are sound and complete. Try to reconstruct these proofs on your own. It will be worth it.
Go to office hours, especially when a pset is due.

Don't take this class.  Everyone (especially in philosophy) wants to take a logic class.  But there is a reason it's not often offered - because the professors don't like to teach it much and don't spend enough time teaching.
Good stuff to know, but not super engaging or intuitive.

If Professor Fara is teaching this course, do yourself a favor: don't take this course. As interesting of an EC (or course in general) as it sounds, it simply is not. The material is quite interesting and so too is the book. It is, therefore, quite a shame that the class was not nearly as interesting: the lectures were boring and too simple, the homeworks were never particularly interesting, and the class overall is not any better than these two. If you're looking for a fairly easy EC, you've got one here, but even then, I would HIGHLY recommend against taking this course out of sheer boredom.
Interesting and chill. Lots of cos and math majors in this class
Not difficult if you know math well
Read the book before coming to lecture (if you come to lecture at all).
Take the course if formal logic sounds interesting to you, and you are OK at math.
The course is interesting, but Delia Fara is not a great lecturer. She's a wonderful person, but the classes are boring.

This is a solid course, if you're willing to do the readings and practice on your own. From what I understand, the textbook will be different, which will be a real boon, as the textbook we used this semester was really terrible. That said, you do learn a lot about more advanced topics in logic, and you leave with a good sense of the field. If you're not interested in going further in logic, however, and just want to learn enough to help with your own argumentation, etc. then you might be better served just taking the regular Intro Logic course (not honors), as you'll get much more practice there in what might be more practical skills. The honors class really had an emphasis on the mathematical side of "mathematical logic" and so it dealt with lots more metalogical topics and more general concepts.
This is solid intro logic class.  Sometimes the pacing was either too fast or slow, but overall you will learn enough logic for any subsequent philosophy class.

This was a fun course to PDF. Having no experience with formal logic, it moved at a perfect pace for me. The professor was amiable and interesting. You will not walk away from this class understanding the field of logic (what comes next, what research is being conducted, etc.), but you will have a strong foundation for other logic classes, COS theory classes, or certain math courses.
You should take it if you have chance.
recommended
descrip: Honors version of PHI 201, Introductory Logic. As such, we will go over all of the basics of introductory logic but we will proceed at a faster pace. This allows us to cover more topics and to explore in greater depth those topics that are covered by both courses. We will cover Cantor's theorem and the set-theoretic paradoxes, and we will learn tableaux as well as axiomatic proof procedures for both propositional and first-order logic. Soundness and completeness will both be covered. It is intended that those who do well in this course will be well-prepared to go on to more advanced courses in philosophical and mathematical logic.

title: Phase Transformations in Materials
reviews: Be prepared to work hard, but also to learn a lot - the class is very well taught.
I would say that succeeding in this course is relying much more on mathematical knowledge than understanding the underlying physics in phase transformations.
If you are interested in phase transformation, or materials in general and wish to do theoritical material science, i think this is a good choice.
Takes at least 15 hours every week.
descrip: This course covers the fundamental principles of thermodynamics and phase transformation kinetics in hard and soft matter systems, such as pure metals and alloys, semiconductors, polymers, and lipid bilayer membranes. The course synthesizes descriptive observations, principles of statistical thermodynamics, and physically-based mathematical theories to address emergent physical, chemical, and mechanical properties of multi-component, multi-phase materials systems.

title: Bilingualism
reviews: Course is more focused on the cognitive aspects of bilingualism/psycholinguistics than one might expect. Fellbaum is kind and funny, though. Good (and easy) EC but only if you are interested in the cognitive aspects of bilingualism
Felbaum is a great instructor: knowledgeable in her field, secure enough in that knowledge to entertain new ideas from students, and never condescending.

Fellbaum is great! If you aren't very proficient in more than one language, it may turn out to not be as relatable as you thought. But nonetheless, the material is interesting, and the course is really welcoming to newcomers to the subject.

I didn't really enjoy this class because I felt like everything was taught from a pretty shallow, limited point of view, compared to another linguistics course I had taken before. The first half of the semester we only read articles that said obvious things like "bilinguals learn languages well" or "children learn languages better when they're young." I did not see how this class really expanded my worldview or knowledge of linguistics. That said, it was an interesting group of people in the seminar and a unique opportunity to talk about language with many multilingual people, including a deaf student who spoke ASL with interpreters. That was probably the redeeming factor of the class.

I highly recommend reading all the readings for the classes and taking the time to develop introspective remarks and thoughts. That will make the class discussions much more fruitful and rewarding, and you'll get so much more out of the class.

I strongly recommend this class, especially if you are a bilingual (which is pretty much everyone on campus). The readings are super interesting and the class provides an overview of a range of topics related to bilingualism. Professor Fellbaum is super nice and chill, and class is a mixture of lecture and discussion on the readings. The workload is low, and topics interesting and fun to discuss outside of class.

I'd absolutely recommend this course to anyone with a passing interest in bilingualism and what it means for the world and for linguistics. Professor Fellbaum is an incredible, caring person, and you are sure to come away with more than what you put in. Workload is light to moderate, and certainly possible for someone without a background in linguistics.
If you are interested in linguistics, take it! The course load is very manageable and very fascinating. Prof Fellbaum is amazing.
If you're hesitating, don't--just take it! You won't regret it.
It's a nice, chill, thought-provoking class.

It's hard to dislike this course. Any flaws are outweighed by how relaxed it is, and how much freedom there is in what to write about. Warnings from past reviews seemed accurate to me (e.g., people going off on tangents and personal anecdotes).
Pretty good class if you are interested in bilingualism.
Take if you're interested in the topic - it's a pretty narrow field so it can get boring unless you're invested in the subject matter.
Take this class!! Fellbaum is awesome and the class is super chill. The material is also pretty interesting if you're into neuro/linguistics.
Take this, especially if you are bilingual, it adds a whole new perspective of yourself

The class to take if you have any interest in languages or linguistics. Highly recommend it. Professor Fellbaum was also really nice and willing to meet with students, and I wish I had taken advantage of that more.
This is a great EC to take. It's not a lot of work and pretty chill and Fellbaum is so sweet.

This is a great course for a first-timer to linguistics. It's really easy (honestly, a bit of a pity, because it's a little too easy), but if you're going to take any linguistics course this should be the one!
descrip: The course covers the linguistic, psycholinguistic, neurolinguistic, and sociolinguistic aspects of bilingualism. We examine language acquisition in monolingual and bilingual children, the notion of "critical age" for language acquisition, definitions and measurements of bilingualism, and the verbal behavior of bilinguals such as code-switching. We consider the effects of bilingualism on other cognitive domains, including memory, and examine neurolinguistic evidence comparing the brains of monolinguals and bilinguals. Societal and governmental attitudes toward bilingualism in countries like India and the U.S. are contrasted.

title: Behavioral Economics Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics

title: Renaissance Drama - Literature and Intellectual Culture: The Other Shakespeare
descrip: This class has the double goal of addressing the status of early modern imaginary literature in relation to intellectual culture (including university and professional training) and of exploring, as test cases for that question, a range of plays at the margin of Shakespeare's canon that together challenge our expectations for a "Shakespeare" text.

title: Princeton Atelier - Making (Comic) Opera
reviews: Take it if you can sing.
The atelier program is great - no stress, an opportunity for creative expression, and a generally fun time. Don't take it if you're expecting something serious, though!

This was a fun class and you can learn a lot of interesting things. What you get out of this class definitely depends on your level of engagement though. The more engaged, the better it is for the class as a whole, especially since the class was basically a creative group endeavor. The professor's have a lot to offer in terms of their own professional knowledge, but the class was a bit unstructured, and this resulted in some scrambling to put together a performance at the end.
prereqs: Singers, instrumentalists, writers, composers, and participants with theater skills and interests are all welcome. You may have more than one relevant skill, or you may focus on a single activity. As part of our preparation, we will be listening to examples and reading from scores, so some level of familiarity with opera and score reading, while not essential, will be helpful. The most important qualities that we are looking for are creativity and flexibility. Brief online application required: http//arts.princeton.edu/academics/atelier/atelier-courses/.
descrip: What is comic opera? What can we learn from historic examples? Composer Andrew Lovett and director/performer/writer and composer Rinde Eckert will lead a course about making and performing opera. Our starting point will be the three comic operas by Mozart and Da Ponte (The Marriage of Figaro, Don Giovanni and Cosi Fan Tutte). We will examine techniques and look at the themes and context of these pieces to take inspiration for our own work.

title: Varieties of Spanish
reviews: A lot of tedious daily work. And a semester long group project.
I would advise meeting with our professor if you have questions and not letting anything you are wondering about just go.
Stay ahead on your work on all of the assignments.

Take this class if you are actually interested in learning about how Spanish functions in the real world. It was a great break from monolithic text book spanish. IT actually prepares you to go places and adapt to different dialects and learn about social historical and political realities surrounding Spanish language. I personally really enjoyed this class!
The material was interesting. It's not an easy course but it's not too hard to do well either
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course. Students who have fulfilled their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score can take the course only with instructor's permission..
descrip: Offered as an overview of sociolinguistic variation in the Spanish-speaking world, students will learn about social, political, and cultural aspects related to dialectal variation in Spanish and become acquainted with important linguistic features present in various dialects. Upon completion of the course, students become familiarized with particular features distinguishing one dialect from another, while gaining knowledge of the development of these differences. This course will greatly enrich a student's view of Spanish, either as a native/heritage speaker or Spanish learner, and allows for the development of analytical skills.

title: Readings in Chinese Religions - Chinese Buddhist Ritual Texts
descrip: Graduate seminar involving the close reading of several ritual texts over the history of Chinese Buddhism, including ancient, medieval, and modern examples. Knowledge of Classical Chinese and at least one of the modern research languages (Chinese, Japanese, French, German) required. Some attention also to Indian models, tools for the study of Chinese Buddhist texts, and ritual theory.

title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities: Novelty
descrip: It is now taken for granted that what is new and improved is always better, but it was not always so. This seminar explores early modern debates over novelty and tradition in religion, science, philosophy, and the arts and literature; readings also include contemporary critical theories of the new.

title: American Slavery
descrip: The Atlantic slave trade, broadly defined, affected the lives of tens of millions of people throughout the world. This course focuses on the experience of slavery in North American and the Caribbean from the seventeenth through nineteenth centuries, delving into specific sites of slavery to understand how this global trade worked at a local level. This readings seminar designed for graduate students interested in American and comparative slavery introduces both classic and new scholarship from the ever-growing and changing field of American slavery.

title: The Economics of Health Policy in Developing Countries
reviews: A bit repetitive if you already have a background in health economics, but provides an interesting and useful critical perspective on health policies and data from developing countries. Fairly low amount of work.
Only take if you are very good at Econ.
Take it if you're GHP. As an econ major it wasnt that great of a cognate.
Try to do the readings and think critically! Ask questions, Professor is a great resource. He also uses a lot of dry humor and sarcasm, so if you don't like that, beware.
if you are considering going into health policy or health in developing countries. this class is honestly a must. or if you are pursuing a job development in developing countries.
take it if you think the topic is interesting
descrip: Early death is arguably the worst manifestation of poverty in developing countries. Much of this premature death, and the low quality of life that goes with it, is avoidable with well conceived and executed public policy. Setting priorities for what government (and well-meaning outsiders) should do with very limited means requires hard choices-matters of life and death. The choices are limited both by the severe resource constraints in poor countries and constraints of and constraints of effective implementation of programs. This course focuses on how economic reasoning can help inform effective policy.

title: Policy Seminars
prereqs: Assignment to these seminars is by a separate application process through the department. Enrollment is limited to WWS majors. The course is required for majors, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. WWS juniors are automatically signed up for the policy seminar as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 402. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy seminars students work in groups first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.

title: Topics in Modern Astronomy
reviews: A good introductory course that covers a huge number of topics, but does not develop great analytical problem solving skills or focus on teaching appropriate mathematical physics.

AST 255 is much more interesting if you enjoy this type of material but are not as interested in the math of it.  This class is high in derivations and equations. Take if you enjoy mathematical explanations for phenomena only.
Come in realizing you'll need 103 and 104 level physics. If you're prepared with that you'll be fine.
Definitely know the lectures well for the exams.

Do the readings; I feel like that would have helped me more.  Also do the psets at least 2 days in advance, not because they're necessarily hard, but because it gives you time to hunt for the right equations and ask for help if you can't find them.
Go to the problem set review sessions so you can actually understand what's going on.
Good course to take to quantitatively learn about the universe

I started off on the main sequence. When doing the problem sets I felt like on the red giant branch and asymptotic giant branch. The midterm felt like the horizontal branch. I disintegrated like a planetary nebula during the final. Now that I'm done with the semester, I just feel like a white dwarf.
I would advise students considering taking this course to make extensive use of their resources; office hours, lecture slides, etc.
If you need an STN, look elsewhere. If you are in love with astronomy I guess you might like this.
Lectures can be a little dry. Read the textbook in addition to the lecture slides to fully understand concepts. The textbook is really interesting.

Lectures were dry sometimes, but if you're interested in the physics behind space then you will enjoy this. Personally, I should have chosen AST 203/5. I didn't realize how much physics/math would be involved this course.

Only take this class if you have to or you're really interested in the material and willing to teach it to yourself/force yourself to pay attention in lecture, at least if Professor Ostriker is teaching it again. She's very nice, but a terrible lecturer.
Read the power point presentations
Take if you want a semi-quantitative introduction to Astrophysics.
Take it if interested in astro and have a comfort dealing with math in science.
Take it!

The course was interesting, but not as easy as I was led to believe. I took it because I heard it was a good course to take as a fifth class. It turned out to be more work than I thought (and I'm not confusing it with a different AST course).
prereqs: PHY 103 or 105 and MAT 103 or 104 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course provides a broad overview of modern astronomy and astrophysics for students in the sciences. Emphasis is on the application of basic physics to understanding of astronomical systems. Topics include the Solar System; planetary systems and exoplanets; the birth, life, and death of stars; white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes; the Milky Way and distant galaxies; cosmology, dark matter and dark energy, and the history of the Universe.

title: Intellectual History of Europe since 1880
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of reading, and actually do it, otherwise this class is a waste

If you're interested in studying any of the authors mentioned in the course reading list, you must take this course. And if you want to pursue research in intellectual history, you must take this course with Professor Rabinbach (or at least another one of his courses).
Stay if you have a talkative class because the material is great and rabinbach is brilliant, so the only bottleneck is other students in the course with you.

Take it for sure.  It's a lot of reading but very doable.  The discussions are amazing and you'll leave with a really in depth understanding of some of the most important theories and ideas in Western history.  Probably my best class at Princeton.
Take it, and do the readings.
descrip: This course is an introduction to Modern Intellectual History. It will examine the period from 1880-1960 focusing on several main trends and key figures. Late nineteenth century authors like Nietzsche, Weber, and Freud will be examined against the backdrop of the classical social theories of Marx and Mill. The era of totalitarianism after World War I will be examined with particular attention to Communism, Nazism (Carl Schmitt), and the debates over humanism and existentialism. The course will conclude with discussions of thinkers during the Cold War including, Raphael Lemkin, Jean-Paul Sartre, Albert Camus, and Hannah Arendt.

title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives
reviews: Good course if you want a good understanding of derivatives, though the first half requires a certain level of prior knowledge
I'd pass unless you really want to learn more about markets.
The class is pretty standard.  Not a whole lot of time required to keep on top of it.  The midterm isn't hard but you need to work very very fast.  Good 5th class I'd say in general.
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The course offers an introduction to financial derivatives and the models used to price them. Pricing techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), as well as extensions to accommodate time-varying volatility and more complex contracts. We also devote great attention to discuss the roles played by derivatives in shaping financial markets and the real economy by using commodity markets as a focal point. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and spreadsheet programming.

title: Conquests and Heroes: A Comparative History of War
descrip: See website

title: Art as Interaction
prereqs: Any 200-level course offered by ATL, CWR, DAN, MUS, THR, or VIS.
descrip: With roots in activities as diverse as mural painting, sports, street fairs, or community activism, publicly engaged art inserts itself into specific contexts and directly engages its audience-often with the hope for social change. It endeavors to make social structures as art rather than objects. This class will investigate the evolving practice of art by creating objects designed to interact with people and spaces around campus. In what ways can collaboration and audience participation be part of artistic practice? Can such a practice still be concerned with aesthetics? What kind of societal questions can art pose while still being art?

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced Italian
reviews: Absolutely take it. Material is interesting, professors are amazing, and  not too demanding. Worth the hour and twenty minutes every day--classes went by quickly and were very fun.
If you're looking for a fully immersive, more challenging way to learn Italian, then definitely take this course. However, the time commitment is no joke--classes are very long!
It's a fun course, an easy A, and a guaranteed way to learn Italian quickly but extremely effectively. If it fits in your schedule and you've already taken introductory Italian, take this course.
Make sure you're not taking it with too heavy a courseload - this class can be a lot.
Take it! Weinapple and De Feo are both really great! The workload isn't too bad, especially for a double credit class (usually less than an hour a night).
Take it! Yes, you'll have work every day for it, but you'll be used to that from 101 anyway. It's manageable and the professors are great.
Take this course if you are prepared to put in effort.
This course goes very quickly through a good amount of material, but don't be intimidated by that. It is a fantastic class and will really help in learning Italian.
just show up to class, participate, and do your homework
prereqs: ITA 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Italian 102-7 is an intensive double credit course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Reading comprehension and oral proficiency as well as reading skills and grammatical accuracy will be developed through various activities. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be familiarized with various cultural aspects of Italy through readings, cultural videos, and films.

title: Advanced Chinese: Contemporary Literature and Film
prereqs: Students should have already taken at least 3 years of Chinese or have equivalent language proficiency..
descrip: This is a literature-based and performance-oriented Chinese language course, open to students who have completed at least three years of modern Chinese at the college level, or the equivalent, at Princeton. This course is also particularly designed for those who are interested in exploring Chinese history and society through being engaged in Chinese dramas in theatre. Seven important Chinese theatrical plays written since the early 20th century will be introduced to improve not only students' Chinese language proficiency, but also their understanding of modern and contemporary Chinese society and people's state of living.

title: Advanced Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: Be prepared for work, not as hard as 203 though so don't let that scare you off.
I recommend this course for anybody interested in linear algebra. It's challenging and time consuming, and the exams can be quite challenging, but you'll certainly learn a lot.

If you hate doing proofs and don't want spend hours and hours on problem sets, you should probably take 202 instead of this course. If you enjoy proofs and are interested in linear algebra and its applications, you should try this course out.

It is a reasonable course provided one diligently keeps up with the lectures on a regular basis, which is not always easy especially with other courses to juggle around. Problem sets are extremely beneficial in learning the material.
Make sure you are ready to dedicate a very large amount of time to the course.
Not the best class to take for linear algebra. It's somewhat between engineering and natural science. If you can give more effort for linear algebra, you should probably take the higher level ones.
Only take if you really are interested in math/physics. Otherwise MAT 202 should give you all of the skills that you need.

Professor Taylor moves really fast! Don't be late to her lectures because if you miss even the first two minutes it's hard to catch up during the rest of class. Keep up with the reading before lectures, because that really helps with following what's going on in class. I also highly recommend going to both Professor Taylor's and Javier's office hours because they are both extremely helpful. This course is a lot of work, but you will learn so much from it. Highly, highly recommend.
Professor Taylor pushes the course ahead of its relatively unassuming 204 number to be more ambitious, but I feel it's worth the effort.

TAKE IT. It's a small course-- you'll get a lot of attention. It's interesting and the theory will teach you powerful critical thinking skills/problem solving skills, but without making you into a pure math major. This is filled with applications in search algorithms, fourier transforms, population studies, quantum mechanics, statistics, you name it. The theory behind the useful application--that's what the course will give you.
Take this course if you like math and are ready to be challenged
Take this course if you would like to have a more well-rounded view of Linear than 202. Don't take if you don't enjoy mathematical proofs.
The class is a liminal space between purely computational math (202) and proof-based math (217) so it's good for those who are interested in both.
There is no reason not to take 202 instead.

This class is difficult but Dr. Taylor and Javier are very supportive in office hours and precepts. If you are interested in a hint of proofs and a hint of applications in addition to the linear algebra, and you're up for a challenge, go for it!
descrip: Companion course to MAT203. Linear systems of equations, linear independence and dimension, linear transforms, determinants, (real and complex) eigenvectors and eigenvalues, orthogonality, spectral theorem, singular value decomposition, Jordan forms, other topics as time permits. More abstract than MAT202 but more concrete than MAT217. Recommended for prospective physics majors and others with a strong interest in applied mathematics. Prerequisite: MAT104 or MAT215 or equivalent.

title: Immigration, Citizenship and Identity
reviews: A great class that sparks a great amount of discussion and participation from the students about one of the biggest topics in America and the world.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in immigration. You get great lectures from professor Telles as well as great scholars from around the globe.
One of the best courses I have taken at Princeton!
Take it!
descrip: This course will examine a wide range of issues regarding immigration, citizenship and identity from a global perspective, though with an emphasis on the United States. We will explore the basic sociological, political and cultural concepts of formal and informal citizenship, migration, immigration, ethnicity, and race, emphasizing how they are used and their relation with one another in various contexts. Much of the course will focus on how migration has shaped lasting ethnic differences.

title: Migration, Diaspora, and Identity
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501B or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This lab course introduces students to the variety of experimental and computational techniques and concepts used in modern cognitive neuroscience. Topics include functional magnetic resonance imaging, scalp electrophysiological recording, and computational modeling. In-lab lectures provide students with the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs, but the emphasis is on the labs themselves, including student-designed experiments using these techniques. This is the second term of a double-credit core lab course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Quantitative Methods
reviews: Andy is leaving so the course is going to be different next time it's offered.
Be engaged by asking questions and going to office hours
Boring
Definitely take if you need a statistics course. Try to study for the weekly quizzes because every point counts!
Don't take it unless you need to, obviously. Probably the easiest of all statistics classes offered. The no curve thing is pretty great.
Easier than other stats courses, from what I've heard. Conway isn't a great lecturer.
Easy peasy. I actually really did like Conway.
Go to class. Study from lectures and notes. Build a good relationship with Professor Conway and your TA. Go to office hours if you can.
Go to lecture and stay on top of the material. Make sure to do well on HW/quizzes because they add up!
Go to lecture!
Go to office hours if anything is confusing. Professor Conway and the lab TA's are very helpful and are more than willing to provide clarification.
Go to office hours!!!
Go to precept and lecture to stay on track!
Great course! The workload is reasonable and the material is useful.
I mean, you don't really have to do much to do well
I would definitely take this course if you need a statistics course. Go to lecture, do the homeworks, and it will not be too difficult to do well.
If you need to take a statistics course and it does not need to be a specific one.... TAKE THIS ONE!!!! You will learn statistics workout the headache of really hard problem sets!!!
If you need to take a stats class, definitely take this. It is pretty straightforward, and everything you learn can be used for JP/thesis research.
If you need to take a stats class, take PSY 251!
It is helpful for anyone in psych to understand the application of stats and for reading research papers.
It's an easy course, the lectures just aren't that helpful / great.
It's easy if you put in the minimal effort required, or have any statistics background. Otherwise, it's pretty dry and boring.
Know the lab material for exams.
Make sure to review the information in the lectures thoroughly before the exams.
Most handlable course ever. Please, please take it.
Must take if you're a science major.
One of the better Statistics courses I've taken.
Professor Conway isn't teaching this anymore, but take this class anyway if you want to take a statistics course and are interested in the sciences!
Read before going to lecture
Relatively easy course, and very helpful for future research!
Start the homework early in case problems come up. Review the textbook before and after lectures.
Study the lecture notes and know how to interpret R like on the problem sets. Overall, it is an easy course.
Take it if you want an easy stats class but not if you are actually interested in understanding and using stats.
Take it if you want to do brainless memorization for a decent grade. If you actually want to learns statistics I would definitely not take it.
Take it only if you need it. Super easy and quite frankly boring.
Take it!
Take it! Very good! Conway was the best!
Take this class if you want an easier QR, or if you have a bit of interest in statistics but do not want too stressful an additional class.
Take this over any other stats course. Study the lecture slides. Don't bother with the textbook.
This class is helpful to get a basis of statistical research.
This is a good solid statistic course. It is mostly focused on psychology, but is also good for getting an understanding of statistics.

This is the only stats class I've taken so I don't have a comparison but I think that if you want to have a much more quantitative approach, take a different stats course. This stats gives you all the concepts well though.
Try to understand R result tables.
Unless you must, don't take the course.
You have nothing to lose.

You should really only take this course if you are planning to be a psychology major or if you want a really easy statistics/QR requirement. There are much better statistics courses for those truly interested in the subject. If you do take this course, go to all of the lectures because the exams are primarily based on them and not on the book. Also, you don't need to read the entire textbook. Just treat it as more of a reference.
definitely a good option for statistics.
read the lectures and take notes! don't need the textbook at all
take for distribution requirement. not that interesting but not too hard.
descrip: The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic techniques of statistical analysis used in psychological research. Students will learn the logic underlying the statistical techniques and learn how to perform statistical analyses and interpret the results.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A full year study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering culminating in a senior thesis. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written thesis, poster presentation, and oral defense required. The senior thesis is recorded as a double course in the spring. Departmental permission required.

title: Listening to Music as Discourse
descrip: An opportunity for students to enhance their listening skills by engaging musical compositions as event-filled discourses. Repeated hearings interspersed with discussion of salient patterns and rhetorical strategies for beginning, continuing and ending. Eclectic mix of 'high' and 'low' repertory from Western Europe, Africa and North America. Emphasis on music as heard, with little or no recourse to external factors or notation.

title: Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: A much better course than MAT 201, but that's not saying it's a walk in the park. The head instructor (Mihai Fulger) was exceptionally well organized this year. Piazza was really well run and posts got responses within the hour. You'll learn a lot if you put in the work.
A requirement for many things.
A very hard course that goes way too fast. It is easy to fall behind if you do not keep up with the problem sets.
Another one of those courses you take because you have to. I don't particularly hate it or love it, but generally it is well-taught and does not require too much time per week.
