Be prepared to dedicate a lot of study time to this course since you will be doing much, if not all, of the learning on your own. Quizzes and tests are extremely difficult and the curve is not as generous as other math courses. Avoid unless you have to take it.
Be sure to take good notes in class and go to office hours if you do not understand something. Overall, it is a good course and you will learn from it, and it is not too difficult to do well in.
Better than 201. Linear algebra is a lot cooler than I thought. Had Mihai and he was a really good teacher.
Better than MAT 201, but still tedious and hard because its an into math everyone is taking
Clarify concepts early
Coming from EMP, this class will be much less time-consuming.
Definitely find a good professor who can explain the material better.
Definitely shop precepts until you find a good one. Also if you're ever confused read the book its actually quite helpful
Definitely take the course. It's useful stuff with many applications in many fields and disciplines.
Do all practice tests, go to office hours, and learn the notes online.
Do homework and go to class; both make the course a lot more interesting to learn.
Do practice tests and quizzes to study. The textbook doesn't really help as much as you might think.
Do the problem sets consistently and study a lot for the midterm, final, and quizzes.
Do the readings before the precepts and make sure you get a good instructor.
Don't be afraid to ask for help!
Don't consider my experience necessarily representative of what you will go through, although I recommend being familiar with Linear Algebra before taking this course.
Don't expect to be inspired. It's nothing special, but not a particularly bad class. Better than 201.
Don't take it unless you are an engineer or COS major.
Don't take unless required
Easier than 201, but so much more boring. If you're thinking about taking it, you probably have to, so just try to get Lucas Culler's section and maybe it won't be so bad.

Easier than MAT 201. I found the material very interesting and really enjoyed learning it. If you're looking for a more theoretical approach, I would recommend 204 (which I started out in and went to several of the precepts for). 202 is less of a time commitment, however. I found Lucas Culler to be a very good lecturer, so would recommend him if he is teaching. Practice exams are a great way to prepare for exams. Don't start the problem sets late the night before they're due. And finally, do go to office hours--even if you don't have specific questions on problems or concepts, its worth it to just spend time discussing the bigger picture of what you're learning, since everything is all connected and all the connections can be initially confusing.
Easier to understand than MAT 201, but curve harsher as a result.

Even if you've taken linear before, save your sanity and take this over 204. If you haven't, it's really not as bad as people make it out to be. Just find a good lecturer and you'll be fine, I recommend Caraiani if she's still teaching.
Figure out what is the most time efficient way for you to learn linear algebra
Find a good teacher! Try to actually understand what is going on during the year rather than during reading period.
GO TO OFFICE HOURS
Get Greg Gauthier if he's back. Change preceptors if you go to the first one and he/she doesn't seem like they prepared for the lecture.
Go to Sunday review sessions, they're really helpful, especially for the true/false problems on the quiz/exams. They help you think over the concepts again in a different way.
Go to all the lectures and spend sufficient time on the assignments.
Go to class and do the homeworks. Watch the Adrian Banner videos online for extra review.
Go to class that way you do not have to try to read the book on your own.
Go to class!
Go to lecture. You often don't need to read the textbook if you take good notes. Ana Menezes is awesome.
Go to office hours, even if you don't have a specific question in mind.  You will probably think of a specific one while you are there talking about a general topic.

Go to office hours. Take it with Mihai Fulger or who ever the course head is. 

Do the past papers and study early.
Go to office hours. There is a lot of material that often overlaps and can be confusing.
Go to the Sunday review sessions! And really shop your preceptors - there are some stars in there!
Good course for learning how to use linear algebra.
Grading is very tough; make sure to go to office hours and review sessions.
Great course. Keep up if not ahead.
I didn't like this class; it is easier than MAT 201 by far but the curve is much worse and you can really get hit hard by that during examinations.

I had taken Linear Algebra before and I think this class presented the material very clearly / well. It renewed my confidence in math. For advice, the T/F questions are the hardest so practice for those!
I mean you have to take it, but just don't expect to gain too much useful information out it.
I probably would only recommend it if the student had interest in math or needed it to advance toward their degree.
I thought the material was pretty cool. Make sure you prepare for quizzes and midterms so you're not consistently behind and banking on the final like me.
I would only take this course if you are interested in learning about linear algebra or if it is a requirement.
I would recommend this class, especially if you have quantitative background.

I would say to try to go to office hours especially if you are not a person who is really good with theory, like myself. Make use of the true/false review sessions if they are still hosting those because those were helpful in preparing for quizzes. Also, there is a good repository of past quizzes, midterms, and finals, with which to study for these exams and would highly recommend these materials. Overall, the class is well-taught but can be confusing at times if you do not seek out help.
I would take this course even if you don't like most "math" courses. The information makes you think in higher dimensions and has broadened my perspective on theoretical math.

I wouldn't say this course is easy, but the content is very interesting, and I'd consider it one of my favorites as far as required BSE courses go. Definitely stay on top of the work throughout the year and go to any and all review session you can, and you should be fine overall.

I wouldn't take this course unless it is required. The material is fairly interesting and somewhat easier to grasp than MAT 201, however, the problem sets are a nightmare and the quality of some preceptors is very low. I found reading the textbook more helpful than going to class at times.
I'd say a more useful math class than most, especially if you're interested in computer science.

If they are still using Otto Bretscher's 5th edition textbook, know that the book is only necessary to know the problems they assign for problem sets. The teaching part of the book is really poorly written and not relevant to the problems they assign for the problem sets. Don't even bother reading it. The exams are fair, no incredibly hard curveballs. You learned everything you need to know for the exam. Eric Naslund is an ok preceptor, definitely not the worst, but he really just reads what he writes on the board, which while not exactly from the book, it can have that same kind of formal tone which may not be conducive to some who prefer more conversational teaching. The best way to prepare is to do as many practice tests as possible.

If you are BSE you have to take it. But if you are generally interested in maths it is not a bad course to try. There are lots of useful applications of linear algebra in computer science, economics, engineering etc.
If you are generally interested in math, but not enough to take 217, I highly recommend this course, but make sure to find a good teacher, because the teacher will drastically alter the experience.
If you don't absolutely have to take this course, run fast in the opposite direction. I'd say take it over the summer somewhere else, but the math department can be pretty nigglish.
If you don't have to take this class then don't. I did not enjoy the material, it is much more theoretical then the title would lead you to believe.
If you don't want to get a C or D on the final and hate yourself, I would recommend actually learning the material during the last two months of the course.
If you gotta take it you gotta take it, but its really not too bad.

If you have to take a higher level math for any reason, Linear is the best. It's a break from calculus, and starts out with the basic of the basic. Honestly, anyone who puts in the time and effort could do this course.

If you need to take this course, don't panic! It's different from other types of math you'll take, and at times it was even fun.  The material wasn't TOO challenging, and the instructors are all great at making sure you understand what you're learning.
If you need to take this you need to take it. Try and find a good lecturer (Aretakis is great.)
If you're in this class, it's because you have to take it. It's easier than 201, if it makes you feel better.
It doesn't hurt to take this course, and it's decently well-taught.
It is an easy class if you keep up with EVERYTHING!!! and there is a lot to keep up with.
It may be easier than Mat201, but the curve is worse and you basically have to teach yourself.
It's like high school math.  If you do the homework and pay attention, you shouldn't have to do much else to score As on the tests.

It's more theoretical than 201, but definitely much more bearable (the material is not necessarily easier, however the quizzes/tests are much more doable). Stay on top of the homework and you'll be fine!
It's tough, so only take if into math or engineer.
Just like any other math class: do practice exams over and over again.
Keep up as you go
Keep up the whole time or you'll have to do a lot of unsuccessful cramming right before exams.

Keep up with material week to week and if you're confused, don't struggle alone or try to skip the concept. Concepts build off each other so go to office hours/tutoring to resolve any unanswered questions.
Keep up with the chapters.
Keep up with work
Learn from Adrian Banner
Make sure to do practice exams!
Make sure you REALLY understand each theorem because the tests test the theorem's applications.
Make sure you attend class.  If you fall behind/miss a few classes, just get back into the groove.  The best way to learn is to listen to the professor.
Make sure you don't fall behind!

Make sure you get a good teacher. Also, the book generally has everything you need to know. I wouldn't call the course "interesting" unless you really love matrices, but it could be helpful for computer science.

Mihai. Fulger.  

Take this class for him.
Most students who take this course are required to therefore whether or not I recommend it won't really change it.
Much much much much better than 201, but it's still a Princeton math class and will be difficult.
Of course, take it if you need to. Requires a good spatial way of thinking, but if you like regular algebra, you should like this class pretty well.
Only if you like Linear Algebra, but workload is less than 201
Only take if you are required or have a general interest in linear. Stefanos was an excellent instructor, though he focused more on proofs than examples.
Only take it if you have to. Or if you're really interested in math.
Only take it if you need to
Only take this course if you have a serious interest in math or if required.
Only take this course if you have to.

Only take this course if you need to. If you're dead set on learning linear algebra, I'd recommend taking 217 instead - it's harder, from what I hear, but people have actually learned linear algebra there.
Practice true/falses a lot
Read the book and go to office hours.
Read the book! Do the psets, go to office hours, practice with old exams. Go to lecture.
Read the textbook
Read the textbook.

Really learn the concepts of the course, it's easy to get bogged down just on learning how to solve individual problems and not understanding the bigger concepts. However, you will not do will if you don't actually understand the broad concepts.
Start the PSETs early
Stay on top of your work
Students are probably taking this as a requirement, so enjoy!
Study study study
Take a more interesting math course.
Take if needed.
Take it as a requirement.  I don't know why anyone would take it that doesn't have it as a requirement.
Take it if it's a pre-req. If your interested in the subject, also take it.
Take it if you have to or if you reallllly like math. Otherwise avoid, it's quite hard.
Take it if you have to, don't if you don't.
Take it if you need it! It's fairly interesting.
Take it if you need to. Just study a lot and keep up. Don't fall behind. It's obviously super-abstract, but you'll get used to it.
Take it if you need to. There is a lot to appreciate in this material, but not everyone will be able to appreciate it.
Take it if you want to or have to! Take it with Fulger.
Take it if you're an engineer.
Take it only if you have to. Do a lot of practice exams before the midterm and final -- it's the only way to do well on them.
Take it only if you really have to.
Take it seriously.
Take it! You truly get out what you put in, which is not always the case in 201. I found 202 to be much easier and more enjoyable.

Take it!! I thought linear algebra would be uninteresting, but this class is great. Lectures are clear and well structured, the theorems/processes you learn are motivated and proven in lecture, and there are really great resources (practice exams and lecture notes) available on blackboard. For me, this was the perfect math course!
Take it. It's a fair class.
Take it. Not that bad if you keep up. You don't need to attend lecture as long as you read the lecture notes on blackboard. Those are incredibly helpful.
Take it. Pay attention in class and you'll be great.
Take only if it is a requirement.

Take this class if you must. Otherwise, it is not really worth the time and frustration of keeping up with yet another poorly taught intro level math course at Princeton. If you must take it, shop around for a lecturer that suits your learning style, or you will suffer greatly during the semester.
Take this class with Lucas Culler if you can.
Take this course if needed as a requirement.
Take this course if you need it for a requirement, but if you're just excited about math I wouldn't recommend it.
Take this course.
Take this course.  You will learn a lot
Take this course. Lots of support
Take your time with the problem sets, especially the more theory-based problems. Practice with true-false and past exams for your tests and quizzes.
Tests will be very, very hard. That is to be expected. Otherwise, read the textbook and do the problem sets and you'll survive okay.
Textbook alone does not explain everything; make sure you go to classes!

The style and quality of precepts varies, so be sure to spend time in the beginning trying a few to see which you prefer. Some preceptors will run extra review sessions, while others won't run any, so be aware of what is available.
The true/false questions are the ultimate struggle. If you're taking this class, it's probs cause its a requirement for you so do your best to enjoy it.

There are more interesting and easier classes if you're not taking it for a requirement. General consensus is that it's easier than MAT201, but it's the same set of people taking the two classes so the curve is harsher for this class. Stay on top of things because everything builds on top of each other. Your grade will be determined by quizzes and exams so the most important thing is to study hard by doing past quizzes/exams. Make sure you understand well the concepts behind every problem you don't understand so that you can extrapolate and apply to test questions. The true or false questions sometimes require that you think outside the box, there's not much you can do to prepare yourself but to learn the concepts and theorems really well so you can approach the question from all angles.
There is no curve.
Thinking in higher dimensions is a good intellectual experience.
This an application level course for linear algebra, and it is useful especially in science studies.
This class is a prereq for a lot of classes, so if you do anything stemmy, you'll probably need it.  It's not as bad as MAT 201, but the curve kinda sucks.  I had Lucas Culler and he was great.
This class is harder and the material is more boring than that of Mat 201. Thus, put more effort on it.
This course gives you what you put in; you can skate through it, you just won't really understand the material.
This course is alright. Stay on top of the work and ask questions and you'll be ok.

This course is fairly good. If you want to learn Linear Algebra, definitely take it. The work load isn't too overwhelming, nor is the difficulty of the content. The quizzes and exams can be a bit tough, but nothing too overwhelming. The curve is bad, however, as people generally do pretty well on examinations. Definitely easier than MAT 201.

This course is good to take if you need the foundation for future upper-level courses in other subjects. However, considering it on its own, I think there are probably other, more intellectually stimulating courses.
This course shouldn't be limited to BSE students because it is a requirement. It is an excellent course that has many uses, and is very interesting. Take it!
This course was pretty fair and the workload was manageable.
This is a fairly difficult course. However, it is probably less time-consuming that MAT 201.
This is a super important and well taught class! If you can choose, try to get into Lucas Culler's section. He was an amazing teaher!
This was a very fair class - I really recommend Mihai! His class notes were very clear.
Tough course. Smart kids also able to set curve high.
Try not to just study the day before quizzes and exams.
Try to get an actual professor, and not a grad student.
Try to read the relevant chapters before you attend the lectures.
Try to remain engaged and you will enjoy the class much more and get a lot more out of it!
Well most of y'all probably have to take it...

Well taught course   interesting subject (taught at not too high of a level). Very manageable if you keep up with the problem sets and textbook readings. Much easier/much smaller time commitment than MAT 203 (and I'm assuming 204).
Well, you have to take it so take it.
Work with other students to complete problem sets and to study

You can do well in the class if you put the time in by going to lectures, reading notes from the instructors, and reading the textbook. The exams were manageable but still challenging, and I found it a lot easier than 201.
You probably have to take it, so just do it. The course is better if you stop trying to picture everything. Just understand what's going on and don't confuse yourself by looking for a visualization.
You'll have to take this as a requirement, so just do the readings, pay attention in class, and study for quizzes

You're probably not going to take this class unless you have to. However, for a large math course, it's actually fairly well taught and organized (better than other math classes I've had). If you take it, spend just a few hours reviewing proofs/logical methods if you're not versed in it; it will help you on all of the assessments.
dont be afraid to take this course. its not really that tough. do the reading and youll be fine.
great class, great material, and i dont care if u are a genius, u will find some of the true/false questions challenging.
if you are interested in linear algebra take it, otherwise not a neccessity
its a math course at Princeton.
keep up with the readings because everything is very accumulative.
requires work but take it
very difficult and fast paced course.
you probably have to
prereqs: MAT104 equivalent..
descrip: Companion course to MAT201. Matrices, linear transformations, linear independence and dimension, bases and coordinates, determinants, orthogonal projection, least squares, eigenvectors and their applications to quadratic forms and dynamical systems.

title: Communism and Beyond: China and Russia
reviews: A very interesting course if you are at all interested in Russia or China.

Don't take if you have more than a moderate background in the USSR or the PRC. 3/4 of the class is background and it will only be interesting if you know next to nothing about these countries. Also, watch out for debate/Woody Woo types who tend to dominate this class. If they bug you in week 1, you will be absolutely miserable by week 12.
If you are interested int eh subject matter and want to have interesting discussions about it, take it!
Take it!  First half of the semester is a bit of review of HIS 362 and 325, but the approach is different enough to keep it interesting.  Professor Kaple is great!
Take this course.
This is a very good seminar, which you should take if you are at all interested in communism, Russia or China.
This is a very interesting course, and is a good introduction to the history and current state of two of the most important countries in the world.

This is not a sociology course! Keep in mind that the topic of Communism attracts a lot of Woody Woo/international relations types that will talk a lot about America and not a lot about Russian/Chinese society. If you're into politics, take this course; if not, don't.
take it
descrip: This course focuses on the communist experiment in the Soviet Union and China. The first half of the course presents the political, social and economic histories that characterize the USSR's and China's particular path to communism. The second half of the course focuses on the consequences of communism by examining each country's demographics, environment, social structures and so on.

title: Methodology of Spanish Language Teaching: Seminar and Practicum
descrip: This course is an introduction to key terms and ideas in the field of second-language acquisition and core issues in teaching modern foreign languages, with special attention to Spanish and Portuguese. Students will develop and practice skills and techniques of teaching foreign languages, selection of content and materials, evaluation of student performance, and self-assessment of their own pedagogical practices. The theoretical foundation will be applied to the teaching of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). The teaching of culture and the use of new technologies will be also considered.

title: Labor Economics/Industrial Relations Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: Be prepared.
Be sure to keep up. Playing catch up in ISC is brutal.
Best class ever. Take it if you dare.

Brace yourselves. This course kills your self esteem.

But then again, you'll be really tight with the other students and most professors are pretty cool. You'll learn a lot of stuff (the day before the exam) and feel pretty accomplished.

Find outside sources to supplement the lecture notes, and try to pre-empt each lecture with the background.  Shaevitz has no sympathy for lack of understanding and Yang doesn't know how to teach.  Start labs early, enjoy them.  Discuss problems together, but do the final write-up alone so you know how much you really understand.

I could not in clear consciousness recommend that anyone takes this course, even though I have not regretted taking it. What you give up: sleep, good grades for other courses, sanity, the feeling that you are even slightly competent, sanity. What you gain: love for the sciences, incredible knowledge, love for your classmates, amazing professors, TAs and preceptors. The best description I could give as to my experience with this class is that I hated every moment of taking this course but in the end I loved it overall. I'll definitely miss it. Now for some more practical advice: If you took ISC first semester, take this one too, it's worth it even though it goes faster and it's more difficult. You should already know to start psets early, go to office hours, do the readings, etc. Have fun with it.

I could write an essay about how important this course and the people in it have been to me. But I won't be able to tell you if it's right for you, so here's my advice: take it. If you drop it, then it's not right for you. If you survive, it will define your Princeton experience and be the best decision you ever made.

I strongly recommend against taking this course. I enjoyed the fall semester and felt that the hours I put into the class paid off from an improved understanding and maturity in science. The spring semester, however, had the opposite effect. I again poured hours of work into the course but ultimately regret taking this second semester. Professor Shaevitz trivialized our questions, which discouraged us from asking when we did not understand. He would never admit that he didn't know the answer to any question, nor did he ever say that any question was intriguing or even at all worthwhile asking. I came into Princeton motivated to do science and thought that ISC would be the place to go. The fall semester proved successful, but the spring semester discouraged me from pursuing science. Of course, I still believe that there is so much in science that is interesting but any interest and enthusiasm I have towards learning science is despite of, rather than because of, the spring semester of ISC.

I'd say its less work and less interesting than first semester. Additionally, if you really want to understand the material be prepared to use outside sources to do so (especially strongly recommend Griffith's for quantum, especially if you have a bit of background in linear algebra)
ISC is a fantastic course and you should definitely stick with it and continue to take the second half of the class. It's worth the effort and you won't regret your decision.

If you are passionate about science and research, this is the class for you. Do be prepared for a large workload (40  hours per week), but what you get out of the class is tremendous: you learn topics you would never touch on in an intro class (statistical mechanics, quantum) and really learn the fundamental physics behind what make chemistry and biology work. On top of that, you'll form an incredibly tight community with the rest of the ISC students.

If you do not already have a strong math, physics, and chemistry background, be prepared to devote most of your time to this class. It will be worth it, but choose easy classes to fill the rest of your schedule or you might feel overwhelmed. Five classes with ISC is something I STRONGLY recommend against. You'll get the most out of this class if you make it your life, since it comes along with a free side of social life.
If you took first semester ISC, you might as well continue. You're better at managing the workload by now. As you can expect, it's a lot of physics.

It's a fantastic course if you can manage the workload. Be prepared to drop the course, but if you can survive, the friends you'll make and the things you'll learn probably can't be matched by any other course. The second semester, at least for me, was even more interesting than the first, but it was definitely more difficult conceptually.
It's not a course for everyone. You will learn many things and will be exposed to a different approach to the sciences. I thought it was worth it. However, it is a big time commitment.
Second semester is heavily dependent upon multivariable calculus and some linear algebra.
See feedback to ISC 231. Extremely difficult class material wise, work wise and exam wise. A lot of stress. Incredible community around the class though.

Similar to first semester in terms of workload. Labs this semester continued to be generally well organized and interesting; throughout the semester you get to plan an independent lab project which you carry out as your last lab module, which is a worthwhile and fun experience. While the electricity and magnetism portion of this semester isn't necessarily presented in the most interesting manner, I really enjoyed the quantum material we covered, as well as some of the short interludes of biology. Unless the lecture notes are revised for next year, they will probably be pretty useless, at least for your first pass through the material, since they don't explain the material very well or thoroughly (though they're good as a summary or review). Consulting a real textbook instead would probably be helpful (definitely read Griffiths for quantum if you're interested in actually understanding the material!). Unlike last semester, the problems on the exams this semester seemed very different than the problems we did in problem sets or in class; while studying and reviewing the material in preparation for exams is beneficial for your own personal knowledge and learning, it probably won't make a lot of difference in terms of actually preparing you for the exam problems. You'd probably be better off finding problems from a textbook to practice as a means of preparation.

Take it, but watch out! Enter ISC only if your love of science, and desire to know, exceeds your tolerance for back-breaking work, struggle, and head-banging. It is a wonderful course, but be warned: your first year will be spent mostly on this!
Take the class seriously, and don't let the stress get to your head.

Take this course for the knowledge, not the grade. Your grade will probably be at least decent if you complete all the assignments. Be realistic about what you want out of this course when it comes time to decide whether you want to stay; don't be afraid to go down either route.
The 4 credits are appealing, but I'd advise to stay away. The friendships you make are great, but you can definitely take more science courses in other departments.
This won't be the first semester, unfortunately.
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multidisciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: W. Bialek, T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti (CBE); H. Yang(CHM); R. Sedgewick (COS); E. Wieschaus (MOL); C. Broedersz, J. Gadd, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session each week.

title: American Mysticism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Bodies in Cultural Landscapes
descrip: See website

title: Analysis of Big Data
reviews:
Absolutely take this class no matter the major. Great material. I have had experience with Machine Learning and stats for a while but the way it is taught in this class, it helps you internalize that information in a really intuitive way. Professor is the greatest. He adapts the pace of the class to the students. The rhythm was great: he claims that he covered more material this year but I never got lost during lectures. Homework is adjusted based on students feedback overall.
To top all of that, we have blogs to help for homework and a great course designers who responds to Piazza posts in 13mn on average.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the problem sets.
Best technical class I've taken at Princeton.
Definitely take it.  It's interesting and I learned a lot

Go for all the lectures, take careful notes. Make sure you understand everything. Collaborate with someone on the homework so you don't suffer alone and can learn from your classmates. Enjoy the class! It will probably be one of the best you'll have here.  Also you'll probably meet some of the smartest STEM kids at Princeton in this very class.
Go to lecture! This class doesn't have supplementary materials or a textbook, so going to lecture is extremely important

Han Liu is a very good and clear lecturer and he really tries to make sure you understand the concepts before he moves on. Note that there's no textbook and notes are not posted so you better come to all the classes! The problem sets were just the right difficulty and got you to understand the concepts he talked about in class. If you want to understand the mathematical basis of analyzing large data sets, this is the class for you.

Han Liu is an excellent lecturer who really wants to make sure you understand the material. The class isn't too difficult and the topics covered are very relevant if you're interested in data analysis.

Hey everyone. I pretty much don't enjoy any class ever but this stuff is really interesting and mind-opening. Han Liu is also incredibly helpful and sympathetic (when I missed lectures, he was there to help me catch up despite having no obligation to do so). Take it.
I strongly recommend this course. Prof. Liu is an excellent professor and his coverage of the theoretical material is solid.
I would recommend this course. It provides a very strong statistical framework. Best statistics course at Princeton.

It's not east, but if you;re interested in analyzing data and machine learning you have to take this course.  there are always opportunites for help, and if you stick with it you will learn how to think about analyziing data

ORF 350 was an amazing course.  Take it if you're interested in machine learning.  (I would recommend this course over COS 424, having taken both.)  Han Liu is a FANTASTIC lecturer.  First, I've never seen this material presented so clearly.  Second, Prof. Liu genuinely cares about the students and their learning progress --- in the middle of the semester, he lightened up the workload significantly in response to student feedback.  Third, he's very humble for a Princeton professor. I've had some professors at this school who would never ever admit that they are wrong or that they don't fully understand a concept.  Learning from those people is obviously very hard.  Han Liu isn't like that.  He welcomes questions from the class.

In summary: take this course.

Also: ORF 309 is not explicitly listed as a prerequisite, but it was certainly helpful.

One of the best ORFE classes I've taken. Prof. Liu really cares about the students and wants to make sure everyone understands the material. He will take pauses every once in a while to let the material sink in and give people time to ask questions. It will take a lot of time and work in R, but the professor and TAs simplified some of the more tedious parts of problem sets (i.e. code that takes an hour to run is now five minutes), so it is much more manageable.
Start psets early.

TAKE THIS COURSE. It is SO much better than COS 424. Han Liu is an amazing professor who really cares about teaching you the techniques of big data processing as well as the bigger picture of when and why you should use those techniques. The work load was pretty light and there was a lot of support on Piazza.
Take it if you want to truly learn big data/machine learning concepts. Tough but worth it.
Take it if you're really into the math. Take 424 if you just want to implement things.
Take it!
Take it! The lectures are incredible and the problem sets don't take too much time.

Take it, no doubt! Prof. Liu explains concepts very clearly in lectures. The TAs are very helpful in answering questions on Piazza promptly and the blog posts help a lot in completing homework. It's an excellent class overall.
Take this course if you're interested in the theory behind big data and what makes it tick. Very theory heavy.

Take this over COS 424; it is taught and organized so well, Han Liu gives great lectures and you will really learn all about how to analyze bug data. Be prepared for some coding and some proofs; nothing too terrible

The problem sets can take a really long time, anywhere from 15 hours and up.  Take this class with friends because it helps with the problem sets.  Go to every lecture and take diligent notes.  If you put the time, you will learn a lot. I highly recommend this course.  This was one of my five classes along with other COS/ORF classes in my schedule and I was able to handle it.  Problem were usually due every other week so plan accordingly.  Highly recommended course for all ORF and COS majors.

This course is really useful, and Professor Liu's lectures are fantastic. You absolutely cannot skip lectures. There are no precepts and no textbook, so going to every lecture is the only way to learn. Take good notes, and take advantage of all opportunities to ask questions in lecture. If you do that, it's not hard to stay on top of the material, and you will find that the class is not as intimidating as you thought it was going to be :)

This is a fantastic course! If you are interested in statistics and machine learning, then you should definitely take this class. Professor Liu teaches a unique framework that you won't find anywhere else. His lectures are very clear, and he does a great job explaining difficult concepts in a way that makes them easy to understand. While he doesn't avoid challenging mathematics, Professor Liu's goal is to provide intuition behind many of the concepts and methods of statistical machine learning.

This is a great course that would give you a very wide exposure to different concepts in Big Data / Machine Learning. Taught at a more abstract and theoretical level, it definitely helps you build a strong foundation for future studies.
This is one of the best courses in the ORFE department. I highly recommend it, and don't miss lecture!

VERY theoretical - if you don't want to do as many proofs consider taking COS424 instead. Prof. Liu is very flexible and if you take the time you can catch up with the material. No textbook and no lecture notes however, so studying for the exam is solely up to your class attendance and note-taking abilities.
You learn a lot of material, but you have to work really hard to do it. Only take it if you really want to.
take it but its probably much more theoretical than you expect
prereqs: ORF 245.
descrip: The amount of data in our world has been exploding, and analyzing large data sets is becoming a central problem in our society. This course introduces the statistical principles and computational tools for analyzing big data: the process of exploring and predicting large datasets to find hidden patterns and gain deeper understanding, and of communicating the obtained results for maximal impact. Topics include massively parallel data management and data processing, model selection and regularization, statistical modeling and inference, scalable computational algorithms, descriptive and predictive analysis, and exploratory analysis.

title: Psychopharmacology
reviews: Take it! I learned a lot and it was easy!
Take it.
This course rocks.

You'll learn a lot of interesting things, and a lot of random fun facts that are just interesting for every day life. Caveat emptor if you haven't taken Orgo and/or Biochem, though - you'll have a lot of new material thrown at you. As long as you remember the nuts and bolts of Orgo, and remember common things from Biochem like GPCR signalling, you'll be fine.
prereqs: MOL 345 or equivalent.
descrip: The molecular biology and biochemistry of pharmaceuticals and natural products that target CNS function will be examined. Specific topics include: the blood-brain barrier, addiction and tolerance, analgesia, treatments for mood disorders, cognitive enhancement, stimulants and ADHD, treatment of dementias such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease, psychotropic drugs, antipsychotics and the treatment of schizophrenia.

title: Contemporary Drama
reviews: If Professor Wolff is teaching this class, there is no reason why anyone should not take it.
It will be tough, but definitely worth it if you are interested in reading theater critically.
Take. This. Class.
Yes, but PDF it.
descrip: This course will look at a range of British and American drama from the second half of the twentieth century to the twenty-first, with an emphasis on the developments of the last twenty years. Questions will include the relevance of drama in a culture of mass entertainment, and drama as a response to history, place, and social trauma.

title: Master's Project II
descrip: Under the direction of a Bendheim affiliated faculty member, students carry out a master's project, write a report, and present the results in the form of a poster or an oral presentation in front of an examining committee.

title: Advanced Optimization
reviews: Challenging. Be prepared.
If you like attending office hours, you're just the kind of person that should take this class
Just study hard.
Must take!
Suitable for students who are interested in SDP.
teaching is excellent
prereqs: Prerequisite: linear optimization.
descrip: A mathematical introduction to convex, conic, and nonlinear optimization. Topics include convex analysis, duality, theorems of alternatives and infeasibility certificates, semidefinite programming, polynomial optimization, sum of squares relaxation, robust optimization, computational complexity in numerical optimization, and convex relaxations in combinatorial optimization. Applications drawn from operations research, dynamical systems, statistics, and economics.

title: Pro Seminar: Computation, Energy, Technology in Architecture
descrip: The pro seminar is offered to incoming PhD students in the PhD track in Computation, Energy, building Technology in the School of Architecture (open to other interested graduate students as well) and is organized as a research seminar to introduce the participants to scientific research methods in the context of design in Architecture and science in engineering. It is structured as a series of introductory presentations of exemplary methods based on case studies and a number of guest presentations from collaborating disciplines.

title: Foodways: Biocultural Aspects of Human Diet
reviews: Don't take if you aren't interested mostly in the nutritional aspect of food.

I started out really excited for this class; the syllabus looked promising, with the first half of the course covering different diets and archaeological/historical topics and the second half addressing cultural things.  In the first few weeks, Professor Mann gave presentations about hunter-gatherers, transition to agriculture, etc., which is his specialty.  The second half of the course really strayed from the syllabus onto discussions about the readings.  To be clear, the readings were largely enjoyable, but I felt like we often talked about the same topics over again.  The paper had no guidelines, so you can use it as an opportunity to explore whatever you wanted.
Take it if you are a health nut because you'll learn a lot of surprising things about what is healthy and what is not.
Take it.
Take this class if Mann is teaching it.  It is interesting and definitely an easy PDF for senior spring.
Take this course. Professor Mann is great!
Too bad professor Mann is retiring.
all class discussion

really liked this class and would recommend it. Sometimes the three hour span feels long but definitely a great class for people who have an interest in the anthropology, biology, and sociology of food and diet.
descrip: Foodways is a biocultural exploration of human food consumption. Readings and discussions will focus on both the biological and socio-cultural aspects of what humans eat and the ways human cultures conceptualize food and its consumption. Topics include the nutritional needs of humans, the differences between diet and cuisine, which foods taste good and why some foods taste disgusting, the evolution of human diet, how cultures define what is and what is not food, the symbolism associated with various kinds of food, and how cultures distinguish foods that are suitable for some members of the society and not others.

title: 20th-Century Japanese Literature
descrip: Readings in selected texts in modern Japanese literature.

title: Science, Society, and Health Policy
reviews: Highly recommend if you're at all interested in science or health! Provides great perspective.
Yi-Ching is great! I'd take the class again, and I see no reason not to if you're wondering about the class.
prereqs: A basic science course or permission of the instructor.
descrip: This seminar introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of science and society studies, which investigates how science both shapes and reflects social values, institutions, and policies. Drawing from diverse perspectives, including philosophers, historians, economists and scientists, the course will examine the relationship between science and society and provide critical tools and conceptual frameworks for addressing contemporary debates on how science should be practiced and disseminated for social benefit. The primary focus will be on the life sciences and health with occasional consideration of other areas of science and policy.

title: Elementary Arabic II
reviews: Arabic 102 is a challenging course but also a very rewarding one. If you are serious about learning Arabic and will commit time to it, I definitely recommend this class.
Be very careful in selecting your professors in this department.
Challenging with not a lot of support unless you really go looking. Loved the language and the professors but it is a lot of work.
Do all of the homework!

Early on in the semester the workload is tough, but keep with it and you will see a very doable pattern emerge. Make sure to keep up with homework too, its really what will make you learn quickly and can save your grade.
If you actually want to improve your Arabic skills, choose Ustaatha Anita, no matter how early her class is. It is also a bit of a step up from 101, so you should prepare for that.
If you are interested in Arabic and are willing to put in the work it takes, do it.  If you just want to satisfy a requirement or take a random language, don't do it.
If you like arabic, this is a no brainer. If you don't know if you do, definitely consider it. Just how much we learned over the entirety of just a year is remarkable.
If you want 101 to count, you have to take 102. You re-learn a lot of concepts that were taught in 101 in different ways. You'll be frustrated a lot, but it's worth it.
If you're willing to put in the effort to learn a language in the first place, Arabic is a great choice.
Language requirements suck, and this course is the wrong place to get it out of the way. Take arabic if you're interested, not because you have to.

Nancy is so understanding, and she'll help you out where she can! Take advantage of office hours and class time to ask any questions you have; she will be very clear in her answers. But make sure you stay on top of the work and know when the quizzes / tests are!

Prepare to make sacrifices in other areas of your academic life in order to keep up with the pace and rigor of the course. Also expect to do a good bit of review on your own in order to fully understand how concepts work.

Take Arabic! It is so rewarding and you will have a lot of fun in the process. That being said, this is a very hard course -- yes, it IS harder than ARA 101. You absolutely will get out what you put in, so if you're not prepared to put in a lot of hard work, you may be disappointed with your outcome at the end of the semester.
Take it if you like Arabic!
The Arabic department overwhelmingly focuses on reading and writing, and it is very hard to learn any spoken Arabic from 101/102. I would
prereqs: ARA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course continues the study of Modern Standard Arabic and spoken colloquial Arabic commenced in Arabic 101. Emphasis in class is placed on active use of grammatical points introduced in the book; reading and writing increasingly longer texts; further vocabulary acquisition, and continued practice in listening and speaking Modern Standard and spoken colloquial Arabic.

title: Contemporary Fiction
reviews: A great course! Read amazing literature and then talk about it with a group of your peers-- what else could you possibly want?
A lot of reading but good.
Amazing class! Definitely take this regardless of if you have experience analyzing literature. The reading list is great, and the lectures are very engaging.
Amazing class. All of the books are really interesting, and they won't disappoint. Workload is manageable, yet you learn a lot!
Be prepared for lots of reading, but the reading is also not very dense and was enjoyed by many students.
Go to every lecture because it really makes you think about the novel beyond what you have probably already been thinking.

I have mixed feelings about this class. On the one hand, take it: the readings are phenomenal, the precept discussions are generally good, the papers are short. What could be better? 
On the other hand, the lectures. Wow, those lectures. Just a bunch of pseudo-philosophical bull where Professor Chihaya rambles about postmodern narrative theory and "privileging the reader" and "authoritative performativity" and "raising important questions." We raised so many important questions, and never bothered to discuss any of them. The prof seemed lost up there at times, like being an english prof lecturing to 60 students puts her under the pressure of a brain surgeon. She'll hem and haw for a while and before you know it you can't even remember what question you raised and are about to not try to answer. These lectures are atrocious.
On the other hand, you don't have to go to any of them. So take the class?
If you like the books on the reading list, take it, because Professor Chihaya is great, but if they don't appeal to you, stay away.

If you miss reading books and want a chance to read some awesome ones with a professor who really understands them, take it! For people who like to read and enjoy contemporary fiction, it's a no-brainer.
If you're interested in the books on the syllabus, definitely take this course. As an engineer, it was a little difficult to write the papers, but the books made it worth it.

Lots and lots of reading - have to be strategic about what you ending up reading, because reading all is impossible. Worth it if you go in with a strategic mindset and know what you want to get out of it.

Lots of reading (average of a book per week), but it's not too dense; fiction reading can go pretty quickly.  I thought the reading was nice most of the time as a break from more intense types of work.  Other than the reading, not a whole lot of other work (short weekly reading responses and 5-page papers at midterm and final).
One book a week doens't sound like a lot of reading but it is.

One of my favorite classes at Princeton! I looked forward to doing the readings and I cherish many of these books very much. Also, the workload in terms of graded assignments is relatively low-stress and the work is fun.
Read the books.
Reading list amazing but the instruction of the class itself is a bit weak

Speaking as someone who has never taken an ENG course, this class had fantastic books, although there is a fair amount of reading. I wish I could've kept up with the class pace, although I'll definitely be going back and finishing some of the novels, if that's any indication to how interesting they are.
TAKE IT
TAKE ITTTTTTT (or forever experience the bitter pangs of regret)
TAKE THIS COURSE RIGHT NOW
Take it for the reading list.
Take it if you are interested in reading the best of late twentieth/twenty-first century literature

Take it if you're interesting in reading the books anyway. Sometimes felt like a book club -- not necessarily a bad thing. Lectures were okay but sometimes very theoretical (which could feel a bit pedantic).
Take it!
Take the course if it's a similar reading list!
Take this class! It's delightful!

Take this course! Lots of great books. However, a lot of readings. Chihaya is a great lecturer but you have to get used to lots of "x or y or z or 1 or 2 or 3" statements that leave you having to decide what is right or correct. If that sort of lecturing isn't your style, then you may not enjoy the lectures.
The books are fun to read, and you really only need to read 2-3 to complete the assignments for the course and skim the others before precept. But I'm not sure I learned very much.

These are books you probably want to read anyways and this class gives you a great way to understand and relate to them in interesting ways - I think it prepared me to be a reader outside the confines of Princeton much better than most other English classes I've taken here.
This class isn't too hard and is so much fun - honestly I felt guilty doing the work for this class because it was really just pleasure reading.
descrip: The past twenty-five years have ushered in an unprecedented era of change and reflection; from the end of the divided Cold War world to the new global circulation of the Internet, human modes of communication and expression have unfolded in dramatically different ways. We will explore novels written in English from 1990 to the present that reflect on change--cultural, political, technological, environmental--and in so doing, consider our position as twenty-first century readers.

title: Play, Leisure, and Sociability
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Art, Science and Magic
descrip: This class considers interactions of art, science and magic during the Early Modern Period (fifteenth to seventeenth centuries) in Europe. Topics include nature studies and natural history, collecting, art and magic, art and astrology, art and alchemy, and art and witchcraft. Students will also have the opportunity to pursue their own special interests.

title: The Composer/Performer
reviews: An interesting, laid-back class.  Steve and Jason are excellent teachers.  You'll learn about improvisation, and how to compose pieces based on that improvisation.

Get as much out of the professors as you can. This is your chance to grow as a musician but you have to push on the professors to hold you to a high standard. Be fair to the professors with the work you turn in, your classmates with what you work with them on, and yourself with what you compose and perform.
Highly recommend! Very interesting, probing class! Leaning more towards composers however!
If you want to write and play music, yah, take it. Donnacha's class is better, though. Don't expect to get much more out of this class than you put into it. You won't be particularly challenged.
It's a fun, interactive studio.  If it's offered again, please take it.
Take it because of the professors.
Take it if you want to casually explore music.

This class primarily focused on musical improvisation and composition. We discussed writing music from the perspective of the performer and the composer, and you got to try both. Be ready to engage yourself in this class. Don't expect to be spoon-fed information or be told exactly what to do because this course was about self-discovery. If you fully engaged week to week you could get so much out of it, as the professors have a lot to offer, however it was dependent on work you prepared and presented. If you come unprepared or don't take it seriously, you're wasting your time. Try things, ask questions, and get out of your comfort zone with this class.
prereqs: Permission of instructor by application..
descrip: The course will explore the connections between composition and performance in a group and solo context. It is the goal of the course to help the student find his/her optimal and personal balance among concerns including but not limited too: abstract compositional technique and practical performance values; organization and spontaneity, surface and structure, strengths and obligations, material and effect, aural and visual. Activities in the class will include analysis, study of compositional techniques, performing, improvisation, collaboration.

title: Modern Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: What is the Euro Crisis Really About? Political and Economic Perspectives
reviews: Participate!
Take it if you're interested in European economy and crisis in general. Only take if you're a junior/senior in ECO.
Take it. Anne is a great teacher.

The subject matter is very interesting and current, and the class is engaging...if you do the reading. The class allowed me to form opinions and evaluate complicated real-world issues at a fairly deep level. But there were a number of students who got very little out of the class because they didn't keep up with the material--it's easy to get by without participating but it's also a waste of time. The reading is usually pretty narrative and there are lots of news articles so it's not too much work.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 required.
descrip: European countries have faced sequential crisis episodes since 2008 and the euro area is now one of the few areas where the economy has not yet recovered. How have fiscal imbalances in Greece which weighs less than 5% of the Eurozone GDP put all the system at risk? Can the Economic Monetary Union (EMU) be completed? Or has the EMU come to its final limit and will soon disintegrate? This course will combine basic international macroeconomic theory and political science literature on the European integration to address these questions.

title: The Far East in the Western Imagination
descrip: See website

title: Roman History - Problems and Methods
descrip: A seminar that introduces graduate students to current methods and debates in Roman history and historiography. Provides a chronological overview of the history of Rome and her expanding empire from the early Republic (5th century BC) to the end of the empire in the West (5th-6th centuries AD), accompanied by the study of a wide variety of ancient sources, including texts, inscriptions, coins, material culture, art, and archaeology, and the methods commonly used by modern historians to analyze them. Students acquire the basic tools needed to do research in Roman history.

title: Graphic Design: Typography
reviews: A lot of fun, and relatively relaxed. You learn a lot, but it's a good way to try something different.
Great introduction to graphic design and typography, especially with a theoretical basis.
Highly recommend! Coursework is not too strenuous, and you learn a ton about design.
If you're at all interested in graphic design/typography, I would highly recommend taking the course, even if you don't have any previous experience.

Show up and participate! Don't be afraid to ask David questions about your work. He's more than willing to help and gives great advice. You may feel a little despair if he wants you to do something over, but I promise that it's for the best.

Take it!! David really helped me improve my graphic design skills, and even if he weren't teaching it the course material itself is interesting enough. Also, when will we get a chance to actually handset type?
descrip: This studio course introduces students to graphic design with a particular emphasis on typography. Students learn typographic history through lectures that highlight major shifts in print technologies and through their engagement in studio design projects. Class readings provide the raw material for hot metal typesetting in the letterpress print shop, photo-typesetting in the mechanical paste-up studio, and state of the art typesetting and design software in the digital computer lab. Overall, the workshop synthesizes hands-on graphic design skills with aesthetic awareness and a critical vocabulary.

title: Topics in Paleoecology, Paleoclimatology, and Paleoceanography - Mass Extinctions and Ocean Acidification
descrip: This course investigates biological and environmental effects of Deccan volcanism 66 m.y. ago in India that led to the KT mass extinction and delayed biotic recovery. Investigations include climate and environmental changes, weathering, ocean acidification and its effects on calcareous marine microplankton and the observed high-stress marine assemblages. The timing of major volcanic eruptions and the time elapsed between individual lava flows will be investigated based on red bole layers.

title: Earth's Climate History
reviews: Great class, interesting material, Professor Bender is great
It's a good class to take, but I was disappointed by the problem sets. If you're going to take it, you have to pay a lot of attention in lecture because all the material comes from there.
Stay on top of the work and go to lectures.
Take it!  Covers a lot of material, very manageable work load

Take this course if you want to learn more about how climate has changed over the past hundreds of millions of years. Prof Bender is a wonderful and accessible lecturer who wants all of his students to take away as much as possible from the course. Not too heavy of a workload either
This course is interesting, and as long as you keep up with the problem sets, it isn't too stressful.

This course provides a comprehensive look at topics in paleoclimate. As it was Prof. Bender's first year teaching this course, the organization of lectures was rather haphazard. But with some time spent connecting and reflecting on lectures outside of class, one can get a lot out of the course. Difficulty level was low, but do beware ? the midterm and final rely solely on rote memorization.
This is a really fun course! Professor Bender is really nice and approachable, and he makes lectures and the homework fun.
Very cool, interesting class for this with a general interest in climate change.
prereqs: GEO 202 and/or GEO 361, or permission of the instructor.
descrip: This course examines the nature and causes of major events in Earth's 4-billion year climate history, ranging from Snowball Earth to the "equable" climates, lasting hundreds of millions of years, when Earth was far warmer than today. We discuss the evidence for each event, and examine its cause by analyzing interactions between the ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere. The course integrates fundamental topics in paleoclimate, including biogeochemistry and stable isotope geochemistry. Three lectures.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Research Seminars
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; fourth-year students for 596; and fifth-year students for 597. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Masterworks of European Literature
reviews: If you're taking a whole lot of other reading courses, just consider whether you can fit 300  more pages a week into your weekly schedule. If yes, definitely take it!!
OMG seriously, best class at princeton-- maria is phenomenal and will open up your mind in ways you couldn't ever imagine. any class with her, including this one.

Start the readings early and speak up in class discussion. Don't be afraid to say something counter to the general frame of thought that the others are going down. Even if you decide to PDF, you can still get a lot out of lectures and the readings you are able to do.

Take this course if you are interested in European literature, but be warned that the readings can be too much at times. A really chill (but still very interesting class!) if you PDF it. Keep in mind that grading on papers is harsher than you would expect, but still fair.
Take this course when you know you will have time to do most of the readings.
descrip: In this course we will examine the major forms and themes of Western Literature since the Renaissance: the drama, essay, lyric and novel. We shall read major works by British, Spanish, French, German, Russian and American authors, considering the unique contributions of specific nations and languages and the transformations of themes and genres over a span of five hundred years.

title: America Then and Now
reviews: A good EC, but the course definitely needs some re-focusing
Be open to learning about new perspectives and ways of thinking.

Be sure to attend all lectures and really make sure you ask questions in precept in order to understand connections between the readings for the week and lecture. Try to do the readings, as it helps to follow along with the large amount of information presented in an 80 minute lecture. Good for an EC and fairly low amount of work.
Be sure to attend lecture and precept, and be ready to take a step outside your normal mode of thinking in order to more objectively analyze the topics brought up in the course.

Definitely take this course if you're at all considering doing AMS, or if you need an easy EC. It's a really interesting class that opened my eyes to a lot of present-day and historical problems that American society actively sweeps under the rug, and doesn't require a huge time commitment to still get a lot of out it.
Do the readings and take notes!
Do the readings.

Do your very best to do all the reading and save enough time for the essays, because they require a great deal of thought above and beyond regurgitating lectures or readings given that this is an EC course.
Don't be fooled by the 101, difficult class because of the amount of different topics that come together, hard to comprehend sometimes
Don't take it.
Don't try and take this class as an "easy A / just another large lecture" class. Take it to expand your mind and learn more about the world around you.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture and do the reading.
Go to lecture! The lectures are awesome and make you think about American history and identity in a completely different light. No other class is quite like it!
Good intro level course, interesting material and speakers. Covers a wide range of subjects in an interesting manner.
Great class - interesting readings, fantastic lectures, really can't go wrong by taking it!

I think that no matter what, your beliefs about America will be challenged in this class. If you want to hear lectures from some of the best lecturers across 3 departments, read interesting and immediately relevant materials, and have discussions about what it means to be American, I recommend you take this! It also really does count as an EC because of the amount of mental framework we do.
I would definitely consider this class.  Work is manageable.  A bit of reading, but definitely clarifies the material in lecture and precept.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who wanted to learn more about America as a place and concept. The lecturers and preceptors were all great!
I would definitely recommend this course. I am a BSE student and really enjoyed it. The workload was also very do-able.
I would say, do the readings and show up to class. That's really all you need to do well.
I've heard other students were more enthusiastic about the professors who taught in previous years. Overall not bad. There are easier ECs though.
If you have an interest in the American conscience, take this course.

If you're looking to complete the AMS certificate program, take this course. It's a good overview of American studies. It definitely favors breadth over depth though, so I think the department has a lot of other classes that are more worth your time if you don't need it for the certificate.
It was a good experience. It could have been better.
It's a great course, especially as a distribution requirement. Only problem is you can't PDF
It's an OK course. Professor Murakawa is amazing. If anything, take the course to hear her speak. Readings on Civil Rights are fantastic.
Its nothing like the course description leads your to expect.
Make sure to go to ALL lectures and precepts because they don't post the notes online and they are very important for the final.
Most interesting, diverse EC I know of. Not too difficult, but engaging. Definitely take it.
Neutral
Take it for a good EC credit, because there doesn't actually seem to be any "E" or "C". Though the class feels very disjoint and unorganized, the lectures are interesting.
Take it for your EC; it seems like a PDF class but it isn't! Take it with Elizabeth Bergman as your preceptor! She's the best; avoid Hartog.
Take it if you are interested in American Studies - this course is a decent introduction.

Take it if you want the AMS certificate. Wouldn't do it for the EC. Precepts differ vastly depending on instructor. The course needs restructured. the assignments come too close together and the final exam is a stupid way of testing the material.
Take it when you are an older student to get more out of it.
Take it!
Take it! and get Elizabeth Bergman as your preceptor!
Take the course! It's a great survey course!

Take this class if you can get James Steichen as a preceptor.  You will learn a lot and enjoy it.   Otherwise, it is a risk with another preceptor.  Class points out a lot of bad about America and not a look of good... not what I expected in an intro American Studies Class.  But if you're into that, go for it.
Take this course.
Take your time on the assignments. They aren't very long and demanding and are actually interesting if you try a little.
The class is so broad that it is difficult for both student and professor to identify themes. Good for anyone looking for an EC that is not philosophy but cultural criticism
The course was alright. It was not difficult, but some topics were a little dry. If you're interested in American history as well as current events though, you'll like this class.
This course is about Race in America, then and now. If that sounds interesting to you, go for it. Stay away if you want a course about America in general.
This course is not well-structured and I would not advise taking it.

This is an interesting class. However, Hartog's lectures are a bit dry and it was easy to not see exactly what point the class was trying to make. I think the thing that made this class good was Naomi Murakawa. The insight that she shared in precept was incredibly interesting and she is just a really great professor. I expected the lectures to be more evenly distributed among the professors but it was predominately Hartog lecturing. So, the class isn't incredibly difficult but without Professor Murakawa I wouldn't particularly recommend it.
This was the worst course I've taken at Princeton. It was completely disorganized. The professors obviously wouldn't plan ahead or make any efforts to make the material engaging for students.
Very interesting course to take. Your precept will make a tremendous difference in the enjoyment of the course.
You should take it if you haven't had the opportunity to read some of the foundational texts before.
You will not regret taking this course. Everyone talks about how it's such an easy EC and all that, but it truly is a wonderful class where you will learn a lot.
take it
yes. take this course
descrip: This course introduces a selection of signature ideas and debates that made the nation what it is today and what it is becoming. Objects of study range across multiple media, including texts, images, works of art, music, performance, and film, and draw from the diverse fields of literature, history, political science, art history, economics, law, cultural studies, and the history of science. The course attends to how knowledge about America has and continues to be produced, disseminated, and consumed, emphasizing the cognitive processes associated with the invention and delineation of America.

title: Intermediate/Advanced French
reviews: Do the homework, even if it's not checked in.
Good course. Keep on top of the homework as much as possible!
Great course!
Make sure you do everything in the course packet, even that which is not assigned
Most people who take it have to take it, but take it.
Practice outside of the classroom. Whenever you see a friend, speak to them in French.
Redo the CP exercises before the test. Keep a running list of irregular verb conjugations and grammar rules, it helps in the end.
Take it! Especially if you can have Meghan or Rachel as a teacher!
Take it, especially if Rachel and/or Meghan are teaching it! They're fantastic.
Take the course and take it seriously, language learning will be useful in the future.
Take this course!
Talk in class!
This is a great class. If you took 103, you'll probably find 107 significantly easier.
Work hard to participate at least once every class period
You will learn more if you put more effort into it- be sure to go to office hours.
good class
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103, or special permission..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while giving you a foundation for understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a selection of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material.

title: Water in the Atmosphere
prereqs: Background in atmospheric/oceanic sciences..
descrip: Despite the paramount importance of atmospheric water vapour for climate, our understanding of the processes that regulate its distribution and changes within a changing climate remains incomplete. This course analyses observations and discusses theoretical approaches, both basic concepts and novel ideas, to the problem. Course is for graduate students with a background in atmospheric and/or oceanic sciences, and students are encouraged to provide contributions from their own research experiences that are related to the course topic.

title: "Making Special": Everyday Experience And/As Art
descrip: See website

title: The Chinese Erotic Novel Jin Ping Mei
descrip: The primary aim of the course is to read a good part of the one hundred chapters of this work. To do so the course employs different editions, looks carefully at some of its illustrations, compares the novel with some of its source material, and investigates briefly a sampling of the novel's sequels and adaptations.

title: The Art of Light: A Creative Exploration of the Role of Light in Artistic Expression
descrip: See website

title: Costume Design
prereqs: This course is by open enrollment..
descrip: An exploration of the various aspects of Costume Design for the stage. Studio projects will be designed to coincide with other theater and dance courses and currently scheduled productions. Critical discussion will explore the relationship between dramatic texts and design ideas.

title: Topics in the History of Sex and Gender - Gender and Science
reviews: If your work concerns either gender or science, or you have a general interest in the topic, this is definitely a course worth taking.
Take the course.
This is great course that will help you to think through some interesting and important issues in the history of science.
This was a great course and I highly recommend it to others.
Yes, take this course!
descrip: The seminar begins by exploring classic scholarship centered on four historical periods, each posited as important moments in the origin of gendered science: medieval Christianity, the scientific revolution, the professionalization of scientists in the late-19th century, and 20th-century second-wave feminism. We then turn to a series of well-developed analytical tools employed by historians of science and gender, and finally to recent scholarship. In all cases, we will analyze the imbricated processes by which science as a social enterprise has been fundamentally gendered and the implicit gendering of the sciences of sex and sexuality.

title: Seminar on Education-Theory and Practice
reviews: This class does have a lot of writing assignments, but they are designed to help you become a better teacher.  Jason is the best.  Take this class if you are interested in teaching!
prereqs: Prerequisites: See Teacher Preparation Program requirements. Course requires admission into the Teacher Preparation Program. Enrollment limited to students doing their practice teaching (TPP 402) except by special permission from the program director..
descrip: Seminar taken concurrently with Practice Teaching (TPP402). Students investigate the processes of curriculum development and implementation, develop learning goals and rubrics for assessment, study national and local issues in education and their impact on schools, examine current philosophies and effective practices, reflect on their work and evaluate their performance as practice teachers.

title: Science Fiction
reviews: A fun and low-commitment English course. Great for a P/D/F distribution; there's a fair amount of assigned reading, but it's enjoyable and you don't necessarily have to do all of it.
Absolutely take this course.

Although the readings in the course are "fun," Professor Bendixen did not do a good job as a lecturer in organizing his lectures (he just stood in front of us and talked about the readings), and I found him too cynical for my liking. Try to get Rosalind Parry as a preceptor though, she is very kind and personable.
As long as you come to lecture and do the readings, then the class will be extremely interesting.
Be prepared for a lot of reading, but an interesting course
Definitely take it. It is a lot of fun, and as much work as you make it. (I made it a lot).
Definitely take this class if you have any interest in science fiction. It was really enjoyable and the reading is manageable. Professor Bendixen is a great lecturer and a funny guy.
Definitely take this if you are at least remotely interested in science fiction! The material is great and the workload is minimal aside from readings.
Definitely take this.
Don't neglect the reading!
Don't take precept with Matt Steding. He contributed little, if anything, to the course and did not facilitate discussion, leaving very long, uncomfortable pauses in discussion.
Fun LA. If you like reading scifi stories, I would recommend it. It's a fair amount of reading every week, but very enjoyable. Only two essays which are very doable.
Go to lecture and the exams will be super easy.  And the readings are fun (especially in the second half of the semester)
Great class.  Loved it.  Your really get to explore the best of scifi if you haven't already, but it's not overwhelming to those who haven't ever before.
Great, easy class. The readings are not too long or dense and are very fun.
Have fun.

If you are interested in reading good science fiction, then I recommend this course. Just be sure to go to the lectures, as what is said there will be crucial for doing well on the midterm and final exams.
