Interesting and easy.  Good regardless of your experience with English.
It is an easy but good class
It's a decent amount of reading but it is interesting reads.

It's a pretty easy, pretty fun course! Lectures can be a bit rambling, paper prompts are pretty relaxed and fun (one of them is to write your own scifi short story!), and the reading is great. If you're interested at all in scifi, even if you're not an English major, this course will be really chill and fun.
Make sure you get a good preceptor. My friends got a bad preceptor and the class was not as good for them as a result.

Perfect. Professor Bendixen is a character and will break down these works of SciFi (the syllabus is quite general, so you have probably already read about half of them) until you fall in love with the genre. Essays are short and you can choose wild topics: e.g. write a short story and analyze it, write a paper explaining the scientific underpinnings of a work, etc. This was easily my favorite class this semester. And don't PDF. It is an easy A.
Read the books and enjoy!

Science fiction is a great class for both long-time scifi readers and people who don't really know it that well. This is a really interesting class, and Prof. Bendixen has some of the greatest one-liners in the history of professors' jokes.
TAKE THIS COURSE if you're at all remotely interested in reading/science/technology/science fiction/etc. Great structure, lectures, and preceptors.

TAKE THIS COURSE. ENG 349 is hands-down the best class I have taken at Princeton. Professor Bendixen truly knows the material inside and out, and his incredibly entertaining lectures provide endless insights into the science fiction genre. This class is truly so much more than intergalactic travel and time machines; the themes conveyed within the pages of Orwell and Bradbury and Shelley are essential to grappling with the very world around us. Regardless of your major, do yourself a favor and enroll in this course--taking ENG 349 reminded me exactly why I chose Princeton in the first place.
Take if you are interested in sci-fi.
Take it - not hard, very flexible, not too much reading.
Take it if you enjoy science fiction! Professor Bendixen is a great lecturer.
Take it if you like science fiction.
Take it if you're into the reading list. The books and short stories were a lot of fun. That said, it's not a serious literary analysis course.
Take it only if you like science fiction. It's not a ton of work, but you also won't get much out of it.
Take it!
Take it!  It's fun and pretty low-work.
Take it! Fun, diverse readings and great for a more "relaxed" class that's actually really interesting and in depth. Assignment schedule is flexible and has a great variety of topics.
Take it! I did the papers early and I read all of the books/stories (which were really fun) and it was a pretty easy course.

Take it! Prof. Bendixen is amazing. And why wouldn't you want to spend the whole semester just reading awesome books. Obviously there's a lot of reading, but there is almost no work otherwise and all of the reading is very enjoyable, so definitely take it. Great for senior spring.

Take it! Reading list is amazing and Bendixen is one of the most interesting and funny lecturers I've had at Princeton. He's got a crude and somewhat twisted sense of humor though, so if that won't easily offend you, you'll like him.
Take it.  It sounds like a lot of reading but it generally goes by relatively quickly.

Take this class if you're remotely interested in the genre. The readings are really fun and not too time-consuming. Be prepared to write a lot in the exams, which can be a stressful due to the time limit.
Take this class!! It was so fun, and Prof. Bendixen really knows his stuff. Just had two 5-page papers and exams were not cumulative.

Take this course, for the love of [insert deity]. The readings are wonderful and the course helps present important elements of science fiction and fiction in general in a very approachable and entertaining manner. I'm no English major, but this was still far and away my favorite course of the semester.

The readings are great, and Bendixen is an engaging lecturer. He can digress and talk about politics, which can be a bit abrasive and annoying at times, but the lectures overall are great. 

The midterm is very long, so be prepared to write really quickly.

This course is great. Not too much work, entertaining readings, and Bendixen is an excellent lecturer. He says things with such conviction that I can't wait to learn more so I can intelligently disagree with him.
This course was excellent. It has been my favorite Princeton course so far.
This is a fun, relatively easy class! You'll never want to miss lecture because they are so entertaining!
This is a good class to PDF.

This is a great course if you have interest in science fiction! As with most English courses, this is a lot of reading, so get used to that. Bendixen is a very engaging lecturer but I don't recommend his precept, because it's basically a second lecture.
This is a wonderful opportunity to read and think seriously about some great books. Highly recommended.
This is an enjoyable class; the readings are interesting, the papers are fairly short, and overall it is a fairly low time-commitment.
This was a pretty cool class. The grading is not that predictable, but the content is quite interesting.
Yep.
Yes. Awesome.
You get to read a lot of interesting sci-fi works, and it's a pretty easy workload. Downside is that it's not the most stimulating course
definitely take this and any other class offered by Professor Bendixen
do the readings - you wont regret it and theyre very good
lots of fun. soooooo easy.
descrip: An exploration of the ideas, issues, and aesthetic values that mark the development of science fiction from the 18th century to the present, with particular attention to the ways specific texts confront the philosophical questions underlying scientific inquiry and invention, travel in time and space, the creation of life, robots and robotics. The ways in which this genre reframes the basic question of what it means to be human will be the foundation of our analysis of contemporary short stories and representative novels.

title: Topics in Differential Topology - Classification problems for smooth manifolds
prereqs: For advanced level undergraduates and graduate students. Undergraduates must request permission of instructor..
descrip: In the first part of course, we will study Morse theory, characteristic classes, and the h-cobordism theorem in higher dimensions. In the second part of the course, we will study problems for knots and three- and four-manifolds

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French
reviews: Be ready to work hard, clear time in your schedule to do homework every day.

Definitely read the course packet material and do the course packet exercises. The book homework is helpful as well. He doesn't check either homework, it's just for your own benefit. As long as you either do the book homework or the course packet homework, you will be fine.
Do some french review before taking this course! It goes fast.
I will suggest to take the class, because I believe that it was a perfect way to approach the language in short time but in a very effective way.
Stay on top of the homework assignments each night.

This course is very educational but also low-stress. Prior experience in french is recommended, but not necessary, although experience with romance languages helps. I would definitely recommend this course.
n/a
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Unmaking the Bomb:The Science &Technology of Nuclear Nonproliferation, Disarmament, and Verification
prereqs: PHY 101 or PHY 102 or PHY 103 or PHY 104. MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers the science and technology underlying existing and emerging nuclear security issues. Part I introduces the principles of nuclear fission, nuclear radiation, and nuclear weapons (and their effects). Part II develops the concepts required to model and analyze nuclear systems, including the production of fissile materials and the detection and characterization of these materials with radiation measurement techniques. Relevant applications are explored in Part III and include nuclear forensic analysis, nuclear archaeology, and nuclear warhead verification. Such case studies will also be part of the final projects.

title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified juniors if they have already taken COS 398. BSE candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Talking Politics
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Cuban Literature, History, and Politics since the Revolution
reviews: Do it.
Good if you?re interested in the listed texts, but don?t expect a more history-themed course.
Read about Cuban politics before coming to Cuba, because although you will get explanations here, it is neither a history nor politics course.
if you want a class on homosexual authors in Cuba, take the class. If you want a broader understanding of the reflection of gender and race in cuban literature and society, do not take the class.
prereqs: Fluency in Spanish.
descrip: The course will offer an overview of Cuban history since the 1959 Revolution though a selection of the most important literary works devoted to the period. We will start with an analysis of the Cuban Revolution, including the socio-political conditions leading up to the insurrection, and we will then examine how Cuba polarized Latin American intellectuals during the 1960s and 1970s: at the height of the Cold War, some continued to support Castro while a second camp denounced the regime's authoritarian and anti-democratic policies. Finally, we will discuss Cuba's situation after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1989.

title: Studies in 19th-Century Literature and Culture - The Art of the Plot
descrip: Though plotters and intriguers usually are up to no good their scheming is closely related to the art of drama and narrative. Storytellers and dramatists create entanglements, set snares and tie knots which then somehow have to be disentangled and untied. The Aristotelian notion of plot (mythos) as "construction of events" thus encompasses the two complementary operations of desis and lysis, "complication" and "denouement". The seminar will examine plot structures, figures of the intriguer, metaphors of intriguing and their transformation in tragedies and historical dramas from Greek antiquity to German literature of the early 19th century.

title: Practical Models for Environmental Systems
reviews: Ask questions early. Do the readings for Prof. Hedin's half of the course.
Be ready to do some math. But hopefully the preceptor will be there to help you through it

Definitely take this course if you're interested in how environmental issues can be quantified. Groundwater modeling was incredibly interesting and make sure you attend every lecture since there is no textbook or reference material.
Extremely interesting, but it will take a lot of time; also make sure you are good at calculus or it will be a struggle. Great profs, great course, but definitely hard.

Take this course as an introduction to modeling, but don't expect it to be a rigorous quant class. The models are all very simple, and many students have a limited math and programming background. The class isn't too much work, and the material is very applicable to pressing issues, such as climate change and agricultural development.
Tough course but very interesting for important environmental issues!
prereqs: Prerequisites: Mathematics equivalent to MAT 104 or instructor's permission; and Chemistry equivalent to CHM 202 or instructor's permission; and Biology equivalent to EEB 211 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Humans are increasingly affecting environmental systems throughout the world. This course uses quantitative analysis to examine three of today's most pressing issues: energy, water, and food. Each issue is examined from perspectives of natural and engineered ecosystems that depend on complex interactions among physical, chemical, and biological processes. The course is an introduction for students in the natural sciences and engineering pursuing an advanced program in environmental studies. We emphasize quantitative analyses with applications to a wide range of systems, and the design of engineered solutions to major environmental problems.

title: Seminar in Global Health and Health Policy
reviews: Definitely take this class! There is only one presentation you have to do throughout the entire semester and the weekly discussions/presentations are very interesting and engaging even at 7:30 at night.

Easy and interesting seminar, 3-hr a week of mostly student presentations. I wish there was more of an emphasis on discussion and guest speakers. You will get more out of this class if you stay engaged in the presentations and involve yourself in the discussions.

GHP covers many of the hottest topics in the field of global health today, from HIV and flu to drug development and patent law.  The class is predominantly student presentations with an occasional guest lecture from a professional outside the class.  Although the class is Thursday nights, expect a high level of audience engagement!  The professors are rockstars in the field, and although they did not lecture on their own, their comments during the presentations are definitely insightful.  The reading load is very manageable and the only assignment is a presentation.
Great class taught by some of the best professors on campus!
Participate. Don't be intimidated. I was.
Super chill.
TAKE IT! This is what learning is supposed to be like - hearing from your peers about important issues in global health!
TAKE IT. Participate and you'll learn!
Take it! It's an amazing class: low stress, very interesting material, and fun conversation!
Take it, it's pretty light in workload and a great survey of global health topics.
Take this class if youre on the fence and especially if you're a senior. Much more pleasant and less work than the corresponding disease and infections course.

Take this course! Having just one of the four professors teaching this course is wonderful! Having all four of them teaching the course is simply remarkable! Anyone interested in infectious diseases or global health should take this seminar at some point in their Princeton careers.

This class is awesome. Because there are no assignments, it is great to fully engage in the discussion and presentations and not worry about taking notes verbatim that would hinder  the ability to really inquire about the topic.

This is class is awesome. The presentations are a bit more challenging for underclassmen because of less experience but still rewarding in the experience itself. TAKE IT! Even though it was 3 hours at night, I was never bored and the guest lecturers as well the instructors have os much to offer in terms of their insight and life experiences. Do anything you need to in order to get into the course.
Very fun and informative course.
Very interesting and laid-back. Well-taught although sometimes students presented inaccurate information.
do the readings, prepare for your presentation way in advance.
prereqs: GHP 350 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This seminar will examine three major topics in global health. Potential topics include: the importance of patents in healthcare; AIDS in America; synthetic biology and biosafety; vaccine safety; the business of biology; the state of US healthcare; healthcare in emerging economies; and drug discovery and development.

title: American Constitutional Development
reviews: Do all the readings! This class is not one that can be done by skimming through material.
Harshly graded, lectures not engaging, don't take
If you are a POL major and used to taking classes in the POL department pay special attention to the fact that this course HAS an in class final
It's a lot of work, but interesting material. It's hard to get good grades. try to keep up with the reading because the final is in class
Keep up on the readings and force yourself to participate
Participate in class if you can, complicated as the arguments and ideas may be.
Take a lot of time with the short paper and remember that he grades on writing quality
Take it if you're at all interested in it, but know it'll be a decent time commitment.
Take it!
Take this class but PDF it. The tests are super hard and not worth your while. But it's an interesting and well-taught class, as well as a good complement to Civil Liberties.

This class will challenge you to be the best student of American Constitutionalism that you can be, but you must be willing to devote the time and effort into really taking advantage of what this course has to offer. Readings and exams are not easy, because they truly challenge you to think in ways that you probably have never thought in before.
Whittington is extremely boring. The only thing that saved me was the fact that I was in a precept with a grad student who was actually super engaging.
it's a fine course, you learn a lot of important info
neutral
descrip: A survey of the development of American constitutionalism, considered historically as the product of legal, political and intellectual currents and crises. Coverage includes the Founding, the Marshall and Taney eras, the slavery crisis, the rise of corporate capitalism, the emergence of the modern state, the New Deal crisis, and new forms of rights and liberties. Topics include the growth of Supreme Court power, the Court's relation to the states and the other federal branches, and the influence on constitutional understandings of economic developments, reform movements, wars, party competition, and legal and political thought.

title: Asian Wars, American Politics, Hollywood Cinema
reviews: Be ready to get your world rocked.

Definitely recommend this class!  It's a great way to approach East Asia, politics, and film with an analytical mind.  Try your best to keep up with the readings despite the intense work level (weekly films and journals) - you'll save yourself stress when it comes to the final exam.
Great course to learn about film and east asia. really fun.

I was taking it purely for a distribution, but found myself putting in a lot of effort. It was fun. Be sure that Leheny's lecture style and personality are amenable to you though - it's very distinctive.

If you are interested in East Asia, take a class on East Asian politics or culture.  If you are interested in film, take a film class -- preferably one taught by Prof. Diana Fuss.  Do not take this class.
Keep up with readings, get help on papers early to make sure you're answering the question properly.

Make sure to keep up on the readings because they will be on the final exam. It's a decent amount of work but it's pretty enjoyable so it didn't feel like a huge burden. Worth taking simply for Leheny's lectures.
Not much work but grading is tough.
Professor Leheny is a fun person and it was a fun class. It was, however, a little disorganized and while I learned a lot about the individual movies, I felt the course lacked an overarching message.
Professor Leheny is an incredible preceptor and lecturer. He is very thorough and fair.

THIS COURSE HAS RULED and I have learned SO MUCH about filmic techniques and challenging how histories and policies are constructed. It was fascinating. Take it if you have any interest in it whatsoever, you will be glad you did!
Take it!
Very interesting class taught by a great professor.
must take this course!
descrip: American cinema has long been one of the world's most important sources of entertainment, and has been examined both at home and abroad for the political messages embedded in its films. This course investigates the presentation of American engagement in Asia over the past half-century, examining depictions of the United States and of Asian allies and opponents alike. Our focus will be on public representations of international relations -- particularly through war and economic conflict -- but we will also ask how changing images of the United States, as well as evolving practices in the film industry itself, shape how Asia appears on film.

title: Research Program in Development Studies
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Beginner's German II
reviews: Do the readings from the textbook, memorize the vocab like no one's business, and legit try on the homework and you should be fine.
German is cool in the sense that you can pick it up quickly- something unusual and wildly satisfying in the realm of foreign language learning.
Give speaking in only German your best effort and try not to revert to English.
I would give it a try.
If you want to take German you'll have to take this course.
Spend a lot of time on your own on the class.
Study a lot, but have fun. German is a funky language, so enjoy it.
This class is great.
Try to get into Professor Rankin's class but this isn't a bad substitute.
take, at least if you can get kashi
prereqs: GER 101 or permission of instructor. About 12 students per section. Normally no credit is given for GER 101 unless followed by 102..
descrip: Continues the goals of GER 101, focusing on increased communicative proficiency (oral and written), effective reading strategies, and listening skills. Emphasis on functional language tasks: learning to request, persuade, ask for help, express opinions, agree and disagree, negotiate conversations, and gain perspective on German culture through readings, discussion, and film. Participants are eligible to apply for Princeton-in-Munich, GER 105-G, June, 2015. The afternoon section, restricted to graduate students, follows the basic syllabus with added emphasis on reading skills.

title: Ecology and Conservation of African Landscapes
reviews: GO ABROAD TO KENYA
Learn and absorb as much as you can.
prereqs: Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya.
descrip: Only six percent of Africa's land area (containing a fraction of its biodiversity) is protected, and these areas are rarely large enough to sustain wildlife populations. Mostly, wildlife must share land with people also facing survival challenges. This course will explore how wildlife and people interact in Kenya, where new approaches to conservation are being developed. Lectures will cover the ecology of tropical grasslands and first principles underlying conservation and management of these landscapes. Field trips and projects will examine the dynamics between human actions and biodiversity conservation.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Leadership, Management & Decisionmaking
descrip: A brilliant policy that suffers from poor leadership or bad management is likely to result in failure. This course is about best practices in leading and managing governmental and not-for-profit organizations in industrialized democratic societies. We will assume that the policy problem has been solved and will focus on the non-policy aspects of being a leader and manager. This is a case study course. The goal is to place you in the position of a senior leader, a decision maker--so that you can experience these challenges, as much as possible, in the way actual leaders experienced them.

title: Havana: Urban Culture in Latin America
reviews: Do it.
I recommend! Not like other courses at Princeton and involves fieldwork. A little scattered though.
This course pushes you out of your comfort zone in the best way possible.  I was able to talk with a variety of groups of people from all different walks of life.
prereqs: Fluency in Spanish.
descrip: This seminar will introduce students to Havana's vibrant urban culture. Theoretical readings will be combined with visits to Havana's main urban sites: architectural projects completed before and after the Cuban Revolution; public housing projects; a golf course turned into an art school after the Revolution; markets, parks, the waterfront malecon and other public gathering spaces. Discussion will focus on the uses of urban space, and the contrast between Havana and North-American Cities.

title: Art and Politics in Postcolonial Africa
descrip: This seminar examines the impact of the IMF's Structural Adjustment Program, military dictatorships, and political crises on artistic production in the 1980s, and the dramatic movement of African artists from the margins of the international art world to its very center since the 1990s. How familiar or different are the works and concerns of African artists? What are the consequences, in Africa and the West, of the international success of a few African artists? And what does the work of these Africans at home and in the West tell us about the sociopolitical conditions of our world today?

title: Selected Topics in Russian Literature and Culture - Contemporary Russian Culture
reviews: Be prepared to take Bykov with a grain of salt, he's another text to critique rather than a carefully worded pedagogue. Some things he says may be unpalatable, but he is an enourmous resource of world literature and culture. Also, make sure to talk with him outside of class, that is when you can fully engage with him.
Professor Bykov is a really interesting and thought provoking speaker, it's unlike anything else I have taken here and so very worth it.
don't expect a traditionally structured course. Not recommended for the easily offended.
descrip: The course will cover numerous aspects of contemporary Russian culture, including film and literature. Topics to be covered include the introduction of capitalism, the cult of Putin, nostalgia for the USSR, the new Moscow.

title: International Security Studies
descrip: Central topics in security studies, including the causes and nature of war, deterrence, alliance formation, military doctrine, civil-military relations, arms competition, and arms control.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Approach to Biochemistry and Neuroscience
reviews: Great professors, interesting subjects - take it!

I'm not sure who's reading this right now as this class is not gonna be offered next year and it's going to be significantly changed for the years after that. 

However, take whatever class Professors Rabinowitz and Murthy are teaching. They have different styles of doing things but they made this class very engaging and enjoyable.

So long, farewell. This course will be no more.
But if it ever does return, take it, especially if you've done the first year. Fast, but only the necessary materials are taught. I now have a solid quantitative background in biochemistry and neuroscience.
This course will never exist again to my knowledge. Your loss.
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to molecular biology, genetics, genomics, evolution, biochemistry and neuroscience. This course is designed as a sequence: 236 in the fall and 235 in the spring for the 2014-15 AY. Multiple faculty will be involved over the year: P. Andolfatto (EEB), M. Murthy (NEU/MOL), M. Singh (COS), E. Wieschaus (MOL), J. Rabinowitz (CHM). 2 hrs and 40 min of lecture, one precept (1 hr 50 min), one evening problem session.

title: General Physics II
reviews: Attend the Sunday problem solving sessions. Read through the chapters (examples and formulas particularly) and attend the lectures.
Avoid this class if possible. Its better than 103, but still an enormous pain to take.
Be engaged in the course if you're going to take it!
Be on top of your game!  You can't miss a day in this class.
Be ready for an easy year until the final
Be sure to go in and get help when you need it, it's easy to fall behind but keep your grade up, which can be a nuisance later in the course.
Circuits are really cool.
Definitely attend precepts and lectures. It's so easy to just get participation and you naturally learn the material at the same time. You don't necessarily have to read the textbook, but it helps.
Definitely keep up with readings
Do CBLI! and shop precepts, and go to lecture
Do a lot of practice problems and read the textbook even though it's awful.
Do all the readings and make sure you meet with your instructors. Well-designed course for a requirement.
Do as much practice as possible and go to office hours. Precepts are fast-paced and difficult to learn from if you don't understand the concepts being used at that time.
Do everything you can to keep up with the material. Otherwise you'll feel completely lost. You'll probably feel completely lost anyway, but at least you'll know you tried.
Do it. Take it with MAT 201.
Do learning guides
Do not fall behind in class! This is crucial! Study early and often! And study a lot for the final.
Do not get behind with concepts because they build on each other.

Do not take this class unless you have to. If you have to take it, my apologies and best of luck. Read the textbook before lecture and class, and perhaps things will make sense to you. It will never be explicit what you need to know. Hyper physics (online website) will teach you more than any instructor.

Do not take this course unless it is required. The workload isn't too bad but it is extremely challenging material and you'll have to devote a ton of time if you want to do well. Try to go into lectures having already read the textbook chapter.

Do practice problems and take advantage of the lecture slides and other websites with other ways to explain the material. You really have to explore the topic yourself in order to fully understand it.
Do take if your interested physics, take the class
Do the practice quizzes and exams!
Do the readings, do practice problems.
Don't fall behind. review everyday after class
Don't skip precept.

Don't take if you can avoid it. If you need it for BSE, you can definitely get through it if you do the homework assignments, pay attention in precept. As of the Spring 2015 PHY 104 semester with Chris Tully, lecture does not really help you learn anything. You should just go to get credit for the clicker questions. Be aware: There are two different labs (Classic and New lab). After taking Classic and being extremely disappointed with the poor level of instruction and irrelevance to course material, I'd recommend taking New lab because I've heard you're only graded on how much you are able to complete that day -- there's no set number of tasks you have to complete like in Classic lab. So it seems much lower stress.

Don't take it if you don't have to.
If you are a prefrosh engineer reading this try to study your asses off for AP Physics C to get two 5's and place out of this. Biggest regret of my high school senior year is not trying hard enough because PHY104 is hell compared to APC.
Don't take it unless you a. really love electricity and magnetism or b. have to because you're an engineer/physics major
Don't take it unless you absolutely have to.
Don't take it unless you get a good preceptor like Frey or Visnjic. Make sure of that.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take it unless you have to.  This class is pretty boring.  There's no midterm, but lots of quizzes.  The final is hard.  Definitely harder than PHY 103 but I'm pretty sure the curve is better.
Don't take it unless you have to. Horribly taught.
Don't take it unless you have to. If you do, suffer through.
Don't take it. If you have to, try to figure out which practice problems to do that will prepare you for quizzes; i was never able to figure this out.
Don't take the class unless you have to.

Don't take this class unless you have to for a requirement. While I like physics and think that 103 (mechanics) is a class worth taking even if you don't have to, this course is too difficult and not practical enough for the real world to be worth taking.
Don't take unless absolutely necessary.
Don't take unless required/you like physics
Don't take unless you have to - every poorly organized/run.
Don't take unless you have to.
Dont take this class unless you have to, and make sure to get a good preceptor!
Follow along with practice exams and textbook.
Get help if you need it.
Go to class and office hours
Go to class, read the book, and stay on top of the work!
Go to friday precepts.
Go to precept.
Go to the lectures and the precepts, read the book and practice, practice and practice.
Go to weekly problem review sessions and office hours. Do all learning guide problems   past quizzes. Write-up your own study guides with essential concepts and formulas for each chapter.
Good course. Takes a lot of time, but worth it and you'll learn a lot. If you're deciding between 102 and 104, take this one.
Hard, but a good class. Takes a lot of time.
I advise other students considering taking this course to make sure that they have a decent hold on calculus and integration techniques before taking this course.

I hope you're only taking this class a distribution requirement. It is tedious, and there is a ton of information to memorize because you are provided with nothing on quizzes and exams. I recommend working with a couple of friends in a study room, and just going through problem after problem from finals on a blackboard.
I really liked this course and I would recommend reading the textbook to supplement what you learn in class.

I think that any student taking this course should probably get the textbook, because many of the homeworks and quizzes were predicated on knowledge and formulas that were only easily discovered from the textbook.

I thought it was more interesting than PHY 103, and the demonstrations during lecture were pretty great (shout out to Omelan). Sometimes the homework could be confusing because it wasn't explicitly covered in class, but it overall wasn't necessarily a bad introductory physics course.
I would advise other students to pay special attention during the lectures and labs because those times offer good insight into your regular classwork as well.
I would only take it if you have to, and if so, make sure you don't fall behind on the material. It can really build up.
I would recommend this class if you don't feel super comfortable with math enough to take PHY 106 other than that the majority of students are first year engineering students.

I would say don't take this course unless you have to for BSE because I just don't enjoy lab courses and specifically am not a huge fan of physics. If you're AB and need a lab class, I'd take a different one.

I wouldn't have taken this class if I didn't have to take it as a BSE requirement. Try to keep up with the readings and attend office hours when you can. You'll survive the class but it may not be the most enjoyable or well-taught class.
I wouldn't have taken this course if I didn't have to.

If the course changes to be more like PHY103, have a good time! If it doesn't, just know that almost all of the sophomore engineers can empathize with you. Just deal with it and keep telling yourself that it will be over soon.
If you are interested in gaining a good knowledge of E&M physics, this is a good place to start.

If you are looking for an interesting / easy STL to take, turn around, my friend. Not only is this class very difficult and time consuming, but the material is rather dull. Unless you want to be an engineer (which this class is required for), don't take it.
If you don't have a reason to take this class, don't.

If you don't have to take the class or if you aren't a fan of physics, don't take this. It's not meant to be fun. However, if you do take it, don't slack off! There are a lot of little components to the grade that add up if you let them slide through the cracks.
If you like physics, take it. If not, you probably won't enjoy it.
If you need it for a departmental you have to take it, but it was also interesting to see the connection between my math class and this physics class
If you need to take physics take it somewhere else.
If you want to learn EM and have an interest in physics, take this class.

If you're BSE, you have to take this. It's a lot easier than 103. 103 is the worst. There are quizzes every 2 weeks and no midterm. I'd suggest doing the example problems in the book. They like to put spin-offs in the quizzes. Sunday sessions are helpful for problem sets. Utilize them

If you're an engineer, you have to take this course. Some of the material is pretty interesting and the math is a little more complex than in PHY103 (which makes it a little more exciting), but I would say that this course was not quite as well-organized as PHY103.
If you're interested take it!
If you're taking it, you probably have to, go to problem solving sessions with Visnjic if she is offering them.

If you're taking this class, it is most likely that you're doing it to fulfill a requirement. The material is manageable and not that bad. Textbook is not that great so go to office hours or ask your preceptor when you have questions!

If you're taking this class, it's almost definitely because you have to as a departmental requirement. Keep up with the material and ask questions right away if you're confused. Try to get Visnjic as a preceptor.
If you're thinking about being a physics major, take 106. Get a good preceptor and lab instructor.
It is challenging and you need to keep up with studying and lecture otherise you can get lost really quick.
It requires a lot of work
It's a fine course. Get Chaney Lin for lab if you can, and DO READINGS BEFORE PRECEPT IF YOU CAN.

It's going to be painful and if you don't have to, don't.  If you do have to, find someone to study and do homework with.  Going it alone is an unpleasant experience.  The instructor's are quite accommodating though, and from what I've heard, the course has come a long way from what it used to be.  Expect further improvements next year I'd say
It's required. E&M itself is very interesting.

Keep up with the material, and do practice questions! I did practice questions to prepare for quizzes, but I think I could have practiced even more in order to feel more comfortable with the material and more prepared for the different types of questions that could be asked on quizzes.
Keep up with the material. Set some time aside every week to just go over what you learned. The rest comes naturally.
Kind of meh course. Lectures are sorta useless but you have to go if you want participation points
Learn to use a breadboard now.
Lectures are cool, but you don't learn a whole lot from them. All learning is done in the classes. Be prepared to spend about 7 hours in physics class per week.
Lectures are worthless- don't go
MUCH harder than 103.
Make sure to read the book material and use the learning guides.
Make sure you are staying on top of things! I easily and continuously fell behind and it got harder to catch up every time.
Make sure you understand key concepts as the course progresses!
N/A
ONLY TAKE IF YOU MUST. Teaching quality is bad because they know that all BSE freshman have to take it. Homeworks and quizzes are nothing like what we learn in class.
Only if you have to, man.
Only take it if you are an engineer and have to.
Only take it if you need to
Only take it if you need to.
Only take this if you have to.

PHY 104 is one of those classes you take because you have to, either because you are a physics major or engineering student, or a pre-med student who loves unnecessary challenges. I don't hate this class, but I definitely did not love it. The content is interesting, but don't expect it to be something you'll actually "have fun" doing. Unless, of course, physics is totally your thing, but then you should probably be doing 106.
Pay attention in lecture, and make sure you study for the final.
Practice problems and keep up with material. Book was awful and did not really help me.
Prepared to do a lot of work and self learning to thoroughly understand the materials of this course. If you're taking it however, it probably required.
Pretty similar to 103. Get Visjnic as a preceptor if you don't have any experience with the material.
Read the textbook, don't fall behind, go to precept.
Stay on top of the material and attend office hours
Steven Jackson's lab was best part of course.  Course is difficult at times, but do not let this persuade you if you have general interest.  If you're BSE, well you gotta take it anyway.
Study hard and early!
Take advantage of the help they give, office hours, problem set sessions, go to class, etc.
Take if required or if major.
Take if you need the requirement or really like electromagnetism and problem solving
Take it if it's a requirement or you have an interest in physics.

Take it if you didn't test out. If you are not BSE and thinking about fulfilling your PHY requirement for med school or something, you might want to do 102 instead. The math gets pretty involved and hard to follow as the semester goes on.
Take it if you have to, otherwise probably don't.  Get a good preceptor, go to office hours, ask for help if you need it!
Take it if you have to.

Take it if you have to. If you're really interested in learning the basics of electricity and magnetism, take it, but expect to be frustrated with lab and sometimes struggle with complicated material.
Take it if you have to. This class is treated as one fulfilling a distribution requirement, not one meant to spark your interest. You will learn a lot but it will be arduous.
Take it if you need physics
Take it if you need to. Don't get too caught up in grades.
Take it only if you have to.
Take it only if you need to.
Take it! And embrace it! The more you embrace it, the more you will enjoy the beauty of the concepts, and the better you will perform.
Take it, but stay ahead of the class.
Take only if needed for requirement.
Take only if you have to
Take the course if you have to, but the textbook is your friend
The quizzes will be harder than you think
This class is alright, many people struggle much more than PHY 103 making the curve a lot better. It will work out; you most likely aren't taking this because you are interested in it.
This course is better run that physics 103 and gives a good grounding in electricity and magnetism. Take it if you need to, or if you have a general interest.
This course isn't as bad as everyone makes it out to be. Especially if you're interested in E&M, you'll be alright.

This is not a good course. At all. I didn't find the material interesting and the course is very disorganized. Lectures were quite pointless and the labs were for the most part boring. I enjoyed 103 but I really did not like this class.

This is the worst class I have ever taken.  There is absolutely no organization, so you will probably have no idea what you need to learn and will have no resources to learn the information.  This class stressed me out and made me miserable.  There is no excuse for a class being this horrendous, but you probably have to take it, so find people to study with so you can bond over the inevitable suffering.  In the end, don't worry too much (though this might be impossible) - everyone else is probably failing just as badly as you are.
Took it for departmental.  After taking it, I would take it had it not been required for engineering.  Great class.  Tully is amazing.
Tough class that you need to put time into to actually understand the material. Would probably only take if you have to.
Try to get Professor Ong for precept!
Try to place out.
Unless you are an engineer, do not take this class. the only reason you should take this class is if there is no getting around it.
Watch youtube videos!
We all take it, you'll do fine!
When you get confused in this class (you will from day 1) make sure you start going to office hours right away. You will very quickly be in over your head.
Work with others and seek help from other professors to understand material if necessary
You gotta take it man, good luck. Try to get a good preceptor and do the friday packets. Otherwise, lab, lecture, and precept is not really helpful at all.
You probably have to take this. Read the book and don't wait until the weekend to learn the materials.
You would only ever take this if you had to. But don't take it.
You're probably taking this as a requirement, so just pay attention, read, study,and you'll be fine.

You're probably taking this because you're B.S.E. I thought the content itself was actually very interesting and cool. However, quizzes are hard and demoralizing. The good news is that the curve is good and a big portion of your grade is based on participation, lab reports and homework. As long as you put in work you'll do fine in the end even if you feel like you're failing every quiz. A good foundation in calculus is necessary to understand the material. Best way to study is to do practice problems.
don't take this if you don't need to
dont take
if interested in physics, take it, especially if you care to benefit from extra demos / interesting stuff.
its an ok course watch out for labs though in that it is very easy to overthink what you are doing.
only if you are BSE, then i feel sorry for you as well.
only take it if you have to
take it , but make sure to keep up with the readings and go to office hours they help
take it only if it's a requirement
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This calculus-based course is primarily geared to students majoring in engineering and physics, but is also well suited to majors in other sciences. The goal of the course is to develop an understanding of the fundamental laws of physics, in particular, electricity and magnetism, with applications to electronics, optics, and new challenges in renewable energy sources.

title: Human Evolution
reviews: Although the lectures can be a bit repetitive, still go because Professor Mann loves to drop key points that you wouldn't get otherwise
Cool course if interested in human evolution.

Decent course. Prof. Mann is retiring so the course is bound to change but I'd recommend attending lectures--for sure. And go to precept to feel out stool tools; its pretty cool that we have these things in our classrooms. I'll never forget how the stone tool felt in my hand--could probably be inspired to attempt to take down a large animal.
Get ready for lots of unanswered questions!
Go to lecture!
Great class to PDF.  Light course load. Good fifth class
I would highly recommend this course for students who need an EC and also have general interest in human evolution.
I would say take it as your EC; there is no work outside of midterm/final/deans date paper

If only Professor Mann were still teaching this course next year...! I would certainly recommend this class for anyone looking for EC credit. The subject matter is interesting, and the workload is quite manageable.

If you're an anthro major, do NOT take this as an departmental. You're much better off taking a 300 level course in a subject that you're genuinely interested in. One of the poorest classes I've taken at Princeton.
Like any class, I expect you could get a lot out of it if you put in the work. (I did not)
One of the best ECs on campus
Take it if it's with Professor Mann and Monge! Learn the material from lectures well and start on your paper early!
Take it if you don't know much about evolution. Very straightforward class.
Take it!
Take it! Prof. Mann is a great lecturer. Very enthusiastic about what he was teaching. Pretty minimal workload.
Take it. Go to class and enjoy learning about the origins of humans.
Take this class with Prof. Mann!
Take this course, it is a lot of fun.
The class is wonderful, but make sure you schedule learning the supplemental material.
This is a really good class for anyone who is interested in Human Evolution. It is also a good way to fulfill your EC distribution requirement.

Very good course to pdf for distribution requirement. One midterm, one final paper and one final exam. The workload is not too much. It is unfortunate that Professor Mann is retiring, and I am not sure how the course will change.
Very ineteresting
go
descrip: An investigation of the evidence and background of human evolution. Emphasis will be placed on the examination of the fossil and other evidence for human evolution and its functional and behavioral implications. (See ANT 206B/ EEB 306 to determine the appropriate course for enrollment.)

title: Innovating Across Technology, Business, and Marketplaces
reviews: Don't take this class except for the guest lectures. The grading on responses is stupid. The normal lectures are kind of boring. I wouldn't take this class if I were you; I regretted taking it.
Go the lecture! (and start early on midterm/final projects)
Good class if you are interested in the business behind technology companies. Also it's a pretty light class in terms of workload.
Great course! Lectures are awesome with some really interesting guest lecturers! Also, the final project is a blast.
Great lectures and great readings. JP's talks are worth going to too.
Guest lectures are worth it. Rest of the class does not seem very well organized.
I would probably recommend an EGR course instead of this course to be completely honest.
I would recommend this class students in technology departments, especially in CS. And I think students can just come for the guest lecture if interested.

If you want an easy COS class that doesn't involve too much brain work, this is a good one. You still learn a bit and get to hear from cool people, but don't experience too much stress throughout the semester.
Interesting class - it really is whatever you put into it. You can come out of it with a marketable product and business plan, or you can pass/fail and do very little work.
It can be disorganized, but it's a good class to take if you have a project you want to work on anyway
Its a great PDF
Light workload, take this for the COS certificate!
Only take it if you really don't give a sh** or you're mad interested in entrepreneurship.
Spend time on figuring out exactly what they want in the write-ups and you will do great. Don't attend lecture if it's just JP.
Take it! Good class to PDF or  take normally, as long as you mesh well with your group members. Guest lectures were very interesting and JP is very experienced in the field. Good as a filler class.
Take it! JP is awesome, the guest speakers are awesome, the project is awesome, and it's not a whole lot of work.
Take it! You'll get more out of it if you follow the news (especially tech news) and do research on the speakers. Come prepared with questions! (It's also enjoyable if you don't have any questions.)

Take notes and really try to put yourself into the situation that you're studying, like dividing equity between founders etc because one day you'll be starting a company and all of this will come in handy.

Take the course if you need an easy COS departmental. JP's lectures are useless. Go to the guest lectures if you can; some of them are useless but others are truly insightful (especially the Box one). Readings are great but you can do that without taking the course.

This class was very meh. I was disappointed. It was definitely not much work, but all the work we did have was busy work. The guest speakers were generally good. The class was also incredibly disorganized for one that's been taught several times before.
This is a pretty textbook easy fifth-class type departmental.  I would not enter this class with the expectation of great learnings.
You're not gonna get much out of this if you've already taken an entrepreneurship class
a good amount of busy work. sometimes unclear expectations.
definitely take it if you're interested in startups and startup culture
easy. its clear no one cares about the course. guest lecturers make it interesting (sometimes).
take it - so easy and great COS class
take it. very cool course
useful for students planning on starting a startup, mostly thanks to the high quality of guest lecturers.
prereqs: COS 217 or COS 226 or equivalent..
descrip: Course teaches engineering students about issues tackled by leading Chief Technology Officers: the technical visionaries and/or managers who innovate at the boundaries of technology and business by understanding both deeply, and who are true partners to the CEO, not just implementers of business goals. Focus will be on thinking like a CTO (of a startup and a large company) from technology and business perspectives, and on software and Internet-based businesses. Industry-leading guest speakers provide perspectives too.

title: Materials in Civil Engineering
reviews: Attend all the lectures and do the readings; exams were pretty fair and referred exactly to the material covered; start lab reports well in advance of the deadline

Definitely get to know Claire. She is an awesome professor, and is extremely helpful when it comes to the material in this course. She also is really interesting to talk to, and has done some very interesting research in the department. Also start labs early - you'll regret it if you don't.

I would take this course, it is a little hard at first if you are a couple years out of chemistry, but then it gets a lot better.  Professor White is wonderful and I felt like I really learned the material

If you are a civil engineer especially a structural one you will have to take this class but it is a great departmental class and Professor White is an amazing teacher!  You won't regret taking the course and the work load is manageable because Professor White tries to give you at minimum 1-2 weeks between assignments.
Interesting and rewarding, but takes a lot of time.  As a departmental it's good, but don't take it for a fun 5th class.
Interesting course with a reasonable amount of work.

Lots of assignments, so budget time wisely. lab reports are especially time consuming, so start them early. Go to office hours for problem sets. Professor White wants to help, so be in contact with her if you have problems.

Making concrete in lab is so fun! An interesting class with good labs. Claire is very funny too. Do lab reports in advance and also take the opportunity to meet with Claire outside class at some point because she's really helpful and fun.
Put in the time to do well in this class, and you'll get a lot out of it. I recommend reviewing some Chemistry basics beforehand though, as the class starts at a quick pace.

Take the class, really try to engage with Claire in lecture as it will make you more interested in the material.  Try to convince yourself you really like concrete/cement even though you're probably a Civil/Environmental Engineer because you want to find materials that are better for the environment.
Take!

This course is a lot of work. Be prepared to spend ~20 hours on each lab report and know how to juggle several assignments at once. The coursework is very interesting, and you will learn a lot in the labs and problem sets.

This course is fun and non-major friendly as well (the fact that only CEE's take it is kind of disappointing; maybe advertise it better to get more people in it? or is this going to cause trouble in labs and such?). Claire's accent actually makes everything so much better. Plus she's a great professor, really connects with the kids.

Understand that the grading in this class is going to be super difficult for not very difficult material. You will not do well unless you're ridiculously thorough and include literally everything that could possibly be relevant to the prompts. Also this class is not a broad materials class. It is mostly about cement/concrete. So don't expect to learn much about anything else, and expect to learn an unpleasant amount about cement.
Unless you're really interested in learning about materials in civil engineering, you probably don't need to take this course.
if you're interested, definitely take it
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Lectures on structure and properties of building materials including concrete (conventional and low CO2), steel, asphalt and wood; fracture mechanics; strength testing; mechanisms of deterioration (corrosion; freeze-thaw cycles, pollution). Labs on brittle fracture, heat treatment of steel, strength of concrete, mechanical properties of wood.

title: Calculus I
reviews: Do your problem sets and pay attention to the examples provided in class.
Don't take this class unless you have to.
First half of the class is pretty challenging but it gets easier after the midterm. Don't quit.
Give yourself enough time to study for the exams. Don't leave problems sets for the last minute. And be careful when reading directions during the midterm and final.
Howard is an amazing professor. If you have a hard time with math, try to get into her class.
I would not take this class if you do not have to.
I would take this class with Tatiana Howard. I think she is pretty cut and dry and tries to prepare us the best she can.
If this is your one QR class, why not get it out of the way I guess. However, if you don't need math at all and want an even easier course, just stick with MAT 100.
If you took AP Calculus you should be fine in this class
It is a challenging course but if you go to lecture and supplement with the book you can succeed in the class. Do the problem sets and go in for help if you need it.
It is not very hard if you have calculus background.
Only take it if you need to.
Only take it if you need to. It's not fun but it gets the job done.
Problem sets are graded harshly, so put forth effort.
Read the section of the chapter before going to lecture.
Review Pre-Calc and Trig.
Set aside plenty of time for problem sets.

Straightforward math class. Obviously the tests and quizzes are pretty difficult, but it's curved, so as long as you pay attention and ask questions, you'll be totally fine. If you're interested/need to take it, I would recommend it.
Study hard, but not too hard, because at a certain point, studying wont change your ability to approach the impossible problems in the midterm, final, and quizzes.
Take care of problem sets in small pieces.
Take class if required.
Take if you have too--it's math at Princeton.

Tatiana is awesome! She's one of the best professors I've had, and she helps you during office hours as well. She'll explain concepts to you and help clarify if she wasn't clear during lecture. Also, study your notes and do previous exams/quizzes when studying. They're your savior.
This is a great course to take if you want a good fundamental understanding of calculus.
Try your best to keep up with the material
Work at math daily, finish homework the week before it's due and go to office hours religiously
avoid math unless its your passion or you need to take it for your major
do a lot of practice problems
prereqs: MAT 100 or equivalent. Solid knowledge of precalculus (standard functions, algebra, trigonometry) is assumed..
descrip: First semester of calculus. Topics include limits, continuity, the derivative, basic differentiation formulas and applications (curve-sketching, optimization, related rates), definite and indefinite integrals, the fundamental theorem of calculus.

title: Readings in Classic Chinese Short Stories
reviews: If you are interested in learning about Ming Dynasty short stories from Sanyan, definitely take this class. The Chinese department is unbelievable. The teachers are so dedicated and competent! And the workload is reasonable.
Take it if you love Chinese, and do the work!

This is a good course if your Chinese is quite good. If you read the stories in Chinese, it is a serious time commitment. Otherwise you can read them in translation, and the course is not as much work. Overall, it's a good class if you like literature.
prereqs: Prerequisite: three or more years of modern Chinese, or instructor's permission..
descrip: Focuses on reading and discussing selections from Feng Menglong's Sanyan, the most popular and well-known collection of Classic Chinese short stories published in the late sixteenth century. One class, two hours of discussion, conducted in Chinese.

title: Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: Do all the problem sets.

Either find some way to tape record Professor Sims or write down every word he says, because he is very hard to follow during class - you'll have to decipher it slowly afterwards. And his notes won't be enough.
No (not for undergrads)
Really try to read sims material multiple times.
descrip: This course is the second term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include classical and Keynesian theories of cyclical fluctuations; the determination of employment and real wages; credit markets and financial stability; and stabilization policy.

title: Artificial Desires
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Information Retrieval, Discovery, and Delivery
reviews: Do the textbook readings for sure!

Good basic course. Lectures can be a bit dry, but the Professor is friendly and helpful. The problem set and exams are well written and Prof. LaPaugh is good at giving help. The final project is a little too open ended though, it could use more guidance. A good, fairly relaxed COS course.
Great Senior Spring COS course.
I thought it was dry at first, but ended up loving this class. LaPaugh is a sweetheart
Pretty light workload. Start on the final project early.
Professor is a really sweet woman. Lectures are boring but relatively light workload.
Really boring. You will struggle to pay attention in class. It will not matter because the class is ridiculously easy.
Start your project earlier than what you think is early.
TAKE it. Very core concepts in this class taught albeit the courseload is a lot.
Take it if you want less work and enjoy the class.
This course is a great combination of interesting but not too conceptually difficult. If that's what you're looking for, take it.
This course is not too difficult, but the material is pretty dry.
good class
if you want a chill cos departmental, take it
not very hard. do it for the term project.
prereqs: COS 226 and some familiarity with linear algebra..
descrip: This course examines the methods used to gather, organize and search for information in large digital collections (e.g. web search engines). We study classic techniques of indexing documents and searching text and also new algorithms that exploit properties of the Web (e.g. links) social networks and other digital collections, including multimedia collections. Techniques include those for relevance and ranking of documents, exploiting user history, and information clustering. We also examine systems aspects of search technology: how distributed computing and storage are used to make information delivery efficient.

title: The Ethnographer's Craft
reviews: I wouldn't necessarily recommend this class for someone (like me) without a background in anthropology. While you will take away a good amount, it is difficult work, and clearly designed with anthro majors in mind.
Professor Rouse can have very unclear expectations but is great in office hours if you have questions/want to continue a conversation.
Try to take this course before you do your thesis research (like you're supposed to)! I wish I had.
prereqs: ANT 301A and ANT 301B will meet together. ANT 301A/B is open to all students who would like to have the opportunity to prepare for cross-cultural engagements or ethnographic human subjects research. ANT 301B is reserved for Anthropology juniors; all other students should enroll in ANT 301A..
descrip: What are social and cultural facts? And how do we identify these facts using anthropological research methods? This field methods course is for students interested in learning how to work with complex and often contradictory qualitative data. Students will examine how biases and beliefs affect the questions we ask, the data we collect, and our interpretations. Key topics include objectivism, interpretation, reflexivity, participant-observation, translation, and comparison. In addition to reading ethnographies, this class will use ethnographic films as a lens through which to explore the extraordinary power and limits of qualitative research.

title: Laboratory in Molecular Biology
reviews: Begin literature research early for the lab reports. Work on drafts early as well, and ask professors questions when they come up.
Bite the bullet, and you'll learn a lot about scientific writing. You can do it!

DO NOT TAKE THIS UNLESS YOU ABSOLUTELY HAVE TO. This class honestly made me (unjustifiably) dislike the MOL department. It was a lot of work, and at the end of the day you don't get much out of it. The professors are not supportive and do not give feedback on your lab reports, but somehow they still expect you to improve your writing techniques. They act in a somewhat unprofessional manner that makes you feel that you are a burden to them and that they don't have time/want to deal with you. DO NOT TAKE IT. EVER.

Disclaimer: this class might cause weight loss from the amount of stress you are put under. The topic is great, but the countless hours spent in lab, lecture, and a library writing the final papers are pretty crazy. Only take this if you are MOL and are forced to.
Do not take this class unless you are a MOL major or are ABSOLUTELY sure you are going to be.
Don't take this course if you don't have to.

I strongly disliked this class. Professor's expectations were unclear and lab reports were arbitrarily graded not based on your understanding of the material but on what minutiae the professors may or may not have told you to include in each section.
I would recommend keeping on top of the experiments and the rationale. Put work into the draft workshops and it will save you time later. Work on the draft far in advance and ask a lot of questions.

I wouldn't really recommend taking this class if you have the choice, but there's not really a way around it if you're MOL. The best thing to do is stay on top of your draft workshops and get as much feedback as you can from the instructors. It's all about really figuring out what they want in your paper, not necessarily about writing the best lab report according to literature standards. Staying on Snyder/Swope's good sides also helps.

If you are a MOL major, you must take this course.

If you are someone who wants a fairly comprehensive introduction to a lot of common techniques used in molecular biology, or someone who wants to really fine-tune their lab report writing skills, ***and you are willing to have this course be your primary activity for the semester***, then you should take this course. As they come around here, there isn't another course that will prepare you better.

If you do not fall into one of the two categories above, do not under any circumstances take this course.

Given this split, I am averaging the ratings and giving the course a neutral recommendation.

If you are a molecular biology major and are required to take this course, do not let it dissuade you from pursuing research in the future, as this course will most likely cause you to harbor many negative feelings. A lot of work is required and the environment is unnecessarily hostile. Read the lab manual ahead of time and pay attention to lectures to help you understand the flow of the project.

If you are taking this, you most likely have to, in which case it will probably be helpful for future research. It is a lot of work, try to stay on top of things. There are pop quizzes in both lecture and lab. Try to make use of the rough draft opportunities.
If you're MOL, you're taking it anyway.

Look, this class is not as bad as you have probably heard it to be. Yes, the lab reports are long and will take over your life the week that it is due, but you learn so much from this class! I know that I left this class with a much better understanding of how scientific research is conducted and presented, and I learned many lab techniques! People also say that this course is disorganized, but it's a semester long-project dealing with bio research, so yes, results may not work out now and then, but that's just science for you. Just keep up with the work, take the draft workshops seriously, and ASK QUESTIONS because that is probably the only way you will do well on the lab reports (trust me, I learned the hard way). Go in to this class with an open mind, and you will (hopefully) enjoy it! Also, Synder and Swope are great and have just the right level of sass.

Make sure to do a GOOD first job on the drafts and then see the professors with it. It's very difficult to write the lab reports well without a decent first draft written for the workshops well before. Keep your lab notebook constantly updated and make sure you stay on top of the lecture notes.
Make sure to start on the lab reports early and revise consistently.

Make sure you find a lab partner who you're compatible with and who you know you can depend on. A lot of my problems with the course stemmed from not having an engaged lab partner. If you're pursuing a neuro certificate, I'd recommend taking neuro core lab instead; I wish I had done so.
Never miss lab. Prepare for oral presentations. Work on lab reports ahead of time.
Only take if you have to!

Read the manual before class... all of it (not just the directions)! Write in your notebook as you go. Take draft workshops seriously. Submit in reports early to be read and given feedback on. Even if you've done research before, take this class seriously, even if it doesn't seem like real science sometimes. Enjoy it. (:
Start lab reports early.
Take advantage of any and all resources that are given to you. Start the lab report early.

Take the draft workshops seriously. Also, take advantage of the rough draft submission of the lab reports since you get direct feedback from the professors of your work. They will save you a lot of time and stress when it comes to submitting the lab reports in the end. Also, make sure you ask the professors questions! (My lab partner dropped the course midway through so I didn't have a lab partner for the remainder of the course. This meant that I had to have a really good idea of the assays and project since I had to work on my own.)
Talk to students who have taken this class before for advice on what is expected.

This class had a hostile atmosphere, thanks to both my classmates and the professors. I would not recommend this class unless you absolutely have to take it. Hopefully they have modified the class by then.
This class is a lot of work, but only at specific points during the semester (e.g. when papers are due). The papers are inherently subjective, so grading can be a pain.
This class will tear you down. You're taking it because you have to. You will learn to write a scientific paper through sheer trial and error, not from any structured guidance.

This. Class. Was. The. Bane. Of. My. Existence. Had I not already been assigned a thesis project I am excited about with an adviser I deeply respect, this course would almost be enough to make me switch majors. The professors have a weird God complex and like to watch us all scuttle around and make incredibly condescending and patronizing comments. The number of times they've contradicted themselves when giving answers to questions is more than I count. This class probably made me a worse rather than better science writer because it made me so paranoid about the way reports would be graded. Ugh. You're probably taking this because you have to. Prepare yourself - it's every bit as awful as every MOL major will tell you it is.

Too bad this is a required departmental. This is basically the hell that any molbio major have to go through. So just suck it up and deal with it the best you can. 
Make sure to not take too heavy a course load in the semester with Core Lab and start on those lab reports early and be serious about writing for the draft workshops.

Try to avoid this course if it is taught by Snyder. If you're MOL, the only way to do that is by taking NEU 350 and getting the NEU certificate. The grading is incredibly inconsistent and opaque. It will stress you out and ruin your life/GPA.
Unless the instructors for this course change, you're in for an awful time.
Very time consuming but you have to take it. It does prepare you well in common techniques that will cross over to independent work

You will surely learn how to write a lab report, but you will have to figure it out on your own. Be sure to ask the instructors EXACTLY what is expected of you, or you will be punished when you don't meet their "standards" that they have created.
You'll learn a lot but you probably won't like it and it definitely will not be fun.
don't be a MOL major, because core lab is not worth the stress, tears, or sleepless nights. Major in EEB instead.
don't take it unless you have to. unneccessary stress.
dowon dan kim stay away pls
prereqs: MOL 342 (or permission). This course is required for Molecular Biology Majors..
descrip: The major objective of the course is to introduce students to a variety of tools required to conduct independent research in the field of molecular biology. While completing original research, students will employ a number of techniques that are used by molecular biologists, molecular geneticists, and biochemists. Upon completion of the course, students should have gained an understanding of how, when and why certain techniques and skills are used in a research setting. In addition, students will learn to write a research report modeled on the scientific literature.

title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
reviews: Interesting material. The problem set sessions are super helpful for understanding everything.

Quantum computing is pretty confusing, but don't get too caught up in that; ask questions, focus on what you know, and work from that. And go to the TA problem sessions if you can; those are super helpful.
Recommend taking this class if you are strongly interested in physics/also studying physics; otherwise, will probably feel irrelevant.
Totally recommend if any interest in quantum computing. Hard to follow in the first couple weeks, but then you'll get used to quantum.
Use Berkeley's edX course as a resource.
prereqs: A previous quantum mechanics course will not be required. Requires sophomore linear algebra at the level of MAT 202, 204, 217 or the equivalent..
descrip: This course will introduce the matrix form of quantum mechanics and discuss the concepts underlying the theory of quantum information. Some of the important algorithms will be discussed, as well as physical systems which have been suggested for quantum computing.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Ideas versus Interests in Policy Change
descrip: Vested interests play a significant role in determining how policies get made and changed. But interests in turn are shaped by powerful groups' ideas about how the world works. So ideas of academics or policy entrepreneurs -- can be crucial in defining interests of political actors. We shall examine relevant theories and case evidence to understand the role that policy ideas play: how they originate, how they are disseminated, and what determines when they are politically effective. Cases will draw from various policy domains in advanced and developing societies and international relations.

title: Integrated Engineering Science Laboratory
reviews: A lot depends on your TA
Demand as much feedback as you can! Enjoy the labs and learn every piece of the puzzle - how to code, how to do Arduino wiring, etc. Get experience everywhere.
Don't start the lab reports at the last minute and make sure you're code is recording what you want it to record.
Don't worry about how bad your data is. You can still draw conclusions from it and it will give you things to talk about how your data is bad because of faults in the experiment.

Fluids labs were well-organized and relevant to material presented in MAE 222. Thermo labs were hit-or-miss. Labs are more interesting/rewarding second semester, but this means reports take much longer to write. You get to 3D print your own wind turbine at the end.
Get to know your TA's and use them whenever you need help. They are there and willing!

Grading is arbitrary.  Good luck trying to improve your paper based on criticism as different TAs grade different weeks.  You will get told to fix one thing for next week, you fix it, then you get a bad grade because the other TA was looking for something else.

I really enjoyed MAE 224 as a whole, but especially the spring semester. Sometimes you'll probably end up spending an absurd amount of time trying to debug something extremely simple, but overall the TAs are very helpful for whatever questions you  have or help you need. And using the Spark Core instead of the Arduino simplified things considerably compared to last semester. For the assignments, pay close attention to the rubrics for the lab report and spend the most writing on understanding the implications of your results and discussing the significance and explaining it in terms of content from lecture.
I'd be surprised if someone took this course who wasn't required to (especially since you need the MAE background to understand what's happening in lab) but even for that I liked the course a lot.
Learn from the TA's as much as possible, for the lab as well as fluid mechanics.
Not bad. Make friends with Mike, it'll pay off.
Obviously don't take this without it being necessary.
Probably taking it because they have to. Complements the thermo and fluids classes very well.
Spend time really learning about the experiments and why they work.
Start writing the labs during lab.
This is a good course and will complement your understanding of the concepts in MAE 222.

This lab is really fun! My TAs were very helpful in helping me understand the science and equiment so make sure to ask them questions. If you think critically about the results I think you can learn a lot about experimentation and fluid behavior! Just make sure to give yourself plenty of time in lab and to write the report (including processing data).
You have to
You're probably not taking this unless its a departmental anyway.
if you like labs
take it! its awesome to help understand.
