prereqs: MAT 104, MAT 202 (may be taken concurrently), MAE 222 (must be taken concurrently). Laboratory report grades from MAE 221 fall semester will be incorporated into final grade of MAE 224.
descrip: Students will conduct a series of prepared experiments throughout the year that will culminate in an independent project of the students' design involving fluid mechanics, thermodynamics and data acquisition tools. Concepts learned will be applied in subsequent labs involving expanding flows and lift and drag measurements. Experiments will include internal and external flows.

title: Photonics and Light Wave Communications
reviews: A class deserves learning
A good class.  More work than you might expect.  Prof. Prucnal is like, the nicest guy ever and he really cares about his students and the material.
Do take if you are interested in learning some more about photonics, or if you think Prof. Prucnal is a nice person and want to take his class!
Great second semester senior course, not too much work.
I think this course is best for someone with an optics background not because it is necessary but because one's understanding will be deeper and more accurate.

I would highly recommend this course to anybody even remotely interested in fiber optics or other photonic devices. It meshes very well with ELE 208 and ELE 201, so I would certainly also recommend even Sophomores taking 208/201 to give it a shot.
It's a good first course on fiber communications. Class work wasn't too heavy and Prucnal was very helpful.

It's a great course to take if you would like to learn about fiber optics. Professor Prucnal is amazing, and the lab/pset workload is about average. There's a presentation and paper instead of a final. Overall, I don't think I was ever really stressed over this course, which I can't say for many other courses!

Professor Prucnal is fabulous. But take this class not just for him, but if you actually are interested in fiber optics and photonics. Go to class, and pay attention, and you'll get a lot more out of the class!
TAKE IT!!!!!
Take it if you need a really fun, interesting, and manageable ELE departmental.
Take this course! Learn a lot, and not very difficult!
Very important course for those wanting to learn one of the most important technologies in this century.
definitely take it
descrip: This course provides a working knowledge of the components comprising fiber-optic networks, which form the backbone of today's communication networks, including the global internet, 4G wireless, home access (e.g., FiOS), and data center networks. The operation of lasers, fiber optics and optical routers will be discussed, as will current applications such as fiber to the home, the broadband wireless-optical interface, all-optical switching, signal processing and computing, and security in fibers. The course provides hands-on lab experience with fiber measurements and splicing, and frequent visits to the fiber optics lab and demonstrations.

title: Intermediate Portuguese
reviews: Always keep up with the work.
I would advise them to go to all the lectures, and to practice the language outside of classes.
If you know Spanish, take it!
Take it! It's incredibly well-taught, covers the most important grammar, and being able to read Azul-corvo makes you feel in command of the language.
Take it! Learning Portuguese is so much fun!
Take the class! Andrea is so much fun and your Portuguese will really improve.
Take the course because this is where my abilities really improved. I had an amazing experience and I think its because the Professor put a lot of time into the format of the class
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.

title: Junior Seminars
descrip: A special section of HIS 400 for sophomores intending to major in History and who intend to spend Junior year fall term or the year abroad. Normally required of all juniors in the fall term, the seminar serves to introduce majors to the tools, methods and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This seminar will concentrate on so-called "losers" in history--people without power, whose stories are therefore difficult to tell. The setting will be the Atlantic world between the 1760s and 1820s.

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - Comparative Ethnic Conflict
reviews: Prof. Aksoy is nice enough, and the material is interesting, but it's not a great seminar. Take the same material in the lecture course they offer and you'll be much better off.
Read
Take this course if you are remotely interested in racial and ethnic conflicts. Provides comprehensive theories necessary for any research in the field. Grading is hard though.
Take this course if you would like a more quantitative, technical look at politics.

This is one of the best politics courses I've taken here, and I highly recommend it for anyone interested in ethnic conflict or comparative politics in general. We discussed varying, sometimes contradicting, theories of conflict, and looked at so many different case studies that showed just how relevant the material was. Take it! You'll learn so much, and Professor Aksoy is great at what she does.
prereqs: Students who have taken POL 356 (Comparative Ethnic Conflict) should not enroll in this seminar..
descrip: This seminar introduces students to the main concepts and fundamental questions related to the study of ethnic politics. What are the sources of ethnic identifications? What are the political consequences of ethnic divisions? How do political institutions influence ethnic relations? These are some of the main questions we will cover. We will read and discuss sample work, which analyze the relationships between ethnicity, voting, political party competition, democratic stability, and political violence. Theoretical readings will be supplemented with empirical studies from developed and developing countries across different time periods.

title: Topics in Differential Equations - Global Solutions of Nonlinear Evolutions
prereqs: For advanced level undergrads and graduate students..
descrip: We will discuss the question of existence of global smooth solutions of certain quasilinear evolution equations. These equations include plasma models and the water wave problem. The main techniques include energy methods and semilinear harmonic analysis.

title: M.Arch. Thesis Seminar
reviews: Michael's laid-back style is not for everyone, but in this seminar about thesis-pondering I feel it was very appropriate. We could have done a better job of tackling the task of mapping architecture since 2000. I suggest you just think about it as a group of people to test your thesis ideas on.
Turn a critical eye onto all of one's interests and anxieties, resisting at the same time to certify work and thinking according to existing disciplinary histories or notions alone.
You will design ,you will fabricate, you man even have a client.
i highly recommend to take the course and try as much as possible to participate as much as possible.
prereqs: Open to students in the final year of the M.Arch. program.
descrip: This course will support students in the development of a broad range of thesis topics optimized to the faculty of the SoA. A series of exercises will guide students to identify the primary questions that currently structure the discipline and those extra-disciplinary concerns which architecture must engaged today. Throughout the work, analyses of these issues will be linked to contemporary architectural production. All work will be conducted by small teams and will harness the dynamic feedback between specifically architectural problematics and the general logic of contemporary culture in preparation for future thesis work.

title: The Passionate Eye: Documentary Film in East Asia
reviews: Definitely take it. Interesting films and Professor Chung's a chill guy.
Definitely take the course if you want to understand and see documentary films in a new way. The work load is not too much, but requires much self thinking.

Even though the documentaries were mostly extremely depressing, the wide variety gave a greater understanding of many issues in East and Southeast Asia. Prof. Chung is super laidback, though he does have high standards for thinking.

Just try to make sure that you turn in your responses promptly.  He is quite flexible, but don't take advantage! I would strongly recommend this course though! I really learned a lot about documentary film, and Professor Chung is a really cool and smart professor.
Loosely structured, but still a great course. I would take any course offered by Professor Chung.

Unbelievable class! It literally changed the way that I conceptualize of and analyze documentary films. Steven Chung is a dedicated teacher who is approachable and has a very deep knowledge of film making. He is engaging. All of the work assigned in this class is very meaningful. Between the final project which entailed making a 10 minute documentary and a day-long boot camp on documentary making led by a group of Japanese film makers (a once in a lifetime experience), he truly went above and beyond to provide students with the best learning experience possible.
Very interesting and well-taught class about Asian documentaries. Films were interesting and challenged how I look at documentaries.
descrip: The seminar will encourage students to think critically about the documentary as artistic medium and as socio-political practice. Some important questions will focus on the form itself: who has produced and watched these films and through what sorts of technologies? What are the codes through which documentaries make sense of their subjects and how do these change? Other questions will have wider scope: how can filmmaking impact politics and culture? How does it deal with the gap between reality and representation? What are the ethical issues of such work? What, if anything, is distinct about the life of documentary films in East Asia?

title: Eastern Europe: Culture and History
reviews: Defintely take this course if you are interested in Eastern Europe in general. It is a good general introduction, but don't expect to go into any one specific topic in too much detail.
Do the readings and participate in discussions because they can get very interesting.
Great course to further one's knowledge on Eastern Europe- Prof. Gross and Natalia are engaging and kind- definitely recommend!
Take this course and talk to Natalia Klimova - she is a great TA.

The best part about this course is the visiting professors from other departments. The next best part is the wide exposure you will get to so many topics in Eastern Europe. Prof. Gross is an amazing resource and wonderful professor. I beg you to not only take the course but also SPEAK UP in class because it really is more interesting when you do the reading and have an opinion. Take it, take it , take it.

The course is primarily discussion-based, so be sure to do all the readings and come to class with comments and questions. Take advantage of Professor Gross's expertise -- ask her questions! This course is very rewarding if you put in the effort. The subject matter is really fascinating, and the readings are excellent.
Truly one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Prof Gross is incredible, readings are interesting - lots of great guest lecturers,taking the certificate program as a result.
really interesting guest speakers, Professor Gross herself is an amazing speaker and has been there so it's a first-hand account of many events that have happened in Eastern Europe.
take this course-- Prof. Gross is wonderful and class discussions are provocative
descrip: The course will discuss the main trends in East European history and culture, concentrating mostly on 20th and 21st centuries. Each week will be devoted to one aspect of East European studies and the classes will combine theme-plus-methodology approach. There will be several invited speakers. The course is part of the track in East European Cultures and Societies (EECS), one of the two tracks for Certificate in Russian, East European and Eurasian Studies.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Students will engage in a semester!long composition project working toward a performance or recording by a professional, external organization such as a dance company, theater company, film company, or something similar. Objectives and content of the course will be determined by the student?s advisor in consultation with the external institution. The student enrolled in the course will submit monthly progress reports that will include the goals of the composition project and progress to date. The student will also submit any evaluations they may receive from the host institution, or published reviews of the final product.

title: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology
reviews:
-Study A LOT for the first exam--don't be cocky if you've taken AP Bio!
-If possible, do the readings before lecture; it will help your comprehension
-Go to the review sessions and do the optional psets
A fine class. It won't blow you away in any way. It can be interesting, its not too hard just a lot of memorizing, but is fairly time consuming. Lab is fun!
A lot of memorization and a big time commitment. Also, prior knowledge in biology helps a lot.

A lot of the material may seem familiar if you've taken AP biology. Try and build biological intuition if you haven't already and focus on the problem-solving you'll need to do the latter half of the exams. Don't stress out too much about this course, it's not bad at all as long as you are careful in understanding the processes covered. It's conceptual in a very manageable way.
Ask yourself, do I really want to be premed? before you waste your time in this class. As a side note, chem is almost always considered better than Mol Bio so really question yourself on that one.

Attend all lectures.  They are essential to your understanding of the material.  Try to do the optional problem sets, too, if you have time.  They do a good job of testing your understanding.  Start lab reports early so you can seek help if you need to do so.
Attend all of the lectures and read the required readings!
Attend the lectures, they are interesting!
Be a morning person

Be prepared to put in a very substantial amount of time and effort into staying on top and caught up with the material, and be prepared to go to all lectures and take notes. It is very manageable to do well if you take these things seriously, and the labs can become very interesting.
Be prepared to study a lot if you haven't had exposure to molecular biology before. But otherwise, this is a great course! Take it!

By FAR my favorite premed prerequisite of the past 2 years here. It's straightforward and the professors actually teach the material (the slideshows are super helpful, but also definitely go to lecture because they explain everything confusing). But because it's straightforward the exams are curved a little harsher. I think this class should really be considered the premed weeder course, not because it's super difficult, but because the most of my premed friends dropped it after they really weren't interested in this material. I loved it, so I'm definitely staying premed and majoring in MOL.
Course is necessary if you are planning to pursue biology or any biology related field in the future
Definitely take this class! Really interesting material, and both the lecturers were great.
Do all of the readings before lecture.

Do all the problem sets and go through every  lecture and review session slide when reviewing the course material. As long as you keep up with the lectures and review material at the end of each week, you should be fine!
Do all the readings, suuuuuper helpful. Go to lectures, and stick around after lab to ask questions to your TAs!
Do the optional problem sets! Go to review sessions!
Do the readings
Do the readings, ask questions to TAs and definitely try to go the review sessions whenever possible.
Do the readings, definitely go to lecture!
Do weekly readings and problem sets and go to office hours and youll be set. Make the time to study!!
Don't buy the textbook. Study hard and you'll be fine.
Don't sweat the reading, but pay close attention in lecture, and basically swallow all the lecture slides whole and be able to regurgitate them for the exams
Don't take it unless it's required. If (like me) you're better at math than you are at memorization, try to take MOL 215 instead.
Don't take it unless they move the time to later in the day, you will hate every minute
Don't take this for a distribution requirement. It is a good indicator of what studying a lab science is like.
Don't treat it like a 5th class, treat it like it's your hardest class. Then it'll be easy.
GO TO LECTURE.
Go to all of the lectures, do all of the readings, and do not procrastinate on the lab reports.
Go to all the lectures as well as read through the book readings to familiarize yourself with the subject material.
Go to lecture, spend time on lab reports, and if you took AP bio, you should be fine.
Go to lecture. Study the night before exams. Don't need to do readings to be honest. Take this course it's amazing!
Go to lectures, even though they're early.
Go to review sessions and office hours! They are so helpful! I made flashcards for all of the exams and they really helped me understand everything!
Go to the review sessions if your schedule allows and do the problem sets. Make sure you understand things, instead of just memorizing them.
Good class, but lots of studying before the exams. The labs are really cool.
Good course that is taught well.

Good introduction to biology. If you've never taken biology before you'll learn a lot and/or feel overwhelmed by the information. Most students have taken AP/IB biology before so the content is mainly review. Go to lectures and review lecture slides really well for the exams. Don't just focus on minute details but rather the underlying concepts and reasoning behind experiments, which will be important on exams. The required reading is unnecessary if you come in with prior experience. You'll do well as long as you put in the appropriate amount of work into it.
Good introductory course. May not go deep enough to be intellectually engaging but it covers a broad range of topics and gives you a good basis to build off.
Hard, don't take it if you don't have to.

I loved it! Lectures go by fast, but the material is so fascinating. Exams are long, and I'm still trying to figure them out, but its not because I don't understand the material, its because I spend too much time on some questions.

I strongly recommend taking this course if you are interested in life sciences at all. Although it is definitely a lot of work, the topics that are covered are incredibly interesting and can be applied to a multitude of other fields (physics, neuroscience, chemistry, psychology, etc.). Keep up with the readings and lectures and don't forget to ask questions if you are confused. USE PIAZZA! It is incredibly helpful and I would not have been able to do as well in this course without this Blackboard resource.

I would advise another student to review the material a few days after seeing it in lecture. It helps to reinforce the material after you do it, rather than right before the exam. I would also advise doing the problem set before the review session, because it really shows what part of the material you do not understand.
I would recommend the class if you are thinking about majoring in MOL or EEB
If Krystal Lum is a lab TA, do all you can to switch to that lab section.
If it's not something you're passionate about or haven't learned before in depth, don't take it.
If they don't change exams you'll be forced to extend what you learned to the real-world, which is not expected for intro bio at all.
If you are considering being a MOL major, take this course in freshman year so you can see how it is and get started with all the mol requirements early on.
If you can memorize stuff, you're good to go. Nothing crazy. Hard to do exceptionally well in
If you don't have to take it, don't. It's no fun and requires too much work. Plus, waking up for an 8:30 lecture is not easy.

If you have any interest in biology, take this course. It was so interesting that even at 8:30AM I was captivated. 

Again this depends on the person and your individual interests, but I got a lot out of this class. Granted I also went to all the review sessions and all lectures, as well as doing all the problem sets, so I put myself in a position to do well. If you take the time to put in the effort, you will succeed and you'll get more out of the class.
If you read over your notes every week, pay attnetino in lecture, and do the problem sets, you'll be fine.

If you think you are a Biology major or pre-med, you have to take this course anyway. I would say that if you are looking for an STL, you should avoid this class. The information is very rich, yes, but the cutthroat environment may turn you off. You may consider MOL 101 (I know nothing about this course, but you should check it out). That being said, if you are up for the challenge (still, vis-a-vis non-concentrators, non-pre-med), go for it.
If you're looking for an easy distribution requirement, this is not it. Only take it if you are really interested or if it is a departmental.
It is an exceptionally taught course. Take it only if you have the time to memorize a lot.
It's a great class with interesting material but I would suggest reviewing key concepts throughout the semester.
It's a pretty good course, but it is a lot of information to remember.
It's fairly easy. Do the reading, and keep up with lectures.
Keep up with notes and readings, so that by the time exams roll around, weak areas and problem sets just have to be reviewed.
Keep up, readings = lectures, do lab reports ahead of time

Knock knock.
Who's there?
Don't gopher.
Don't gopher who?
Don't gopher it!! (unless you have to)

Lectures are not helpful, but don't put off studying like I did. The lecture slides are very helpful as long as they are understood. Also, Piazza is extremely helpful in this class so take advantage of that.
Lot of memorizing and applying

MOL 214 is a great course. Unlike many intro-level courses, like Gen Chem, the professors are incredibly dedicated to the students and really want to see us thrive so do not be afraid to ask for help. Go to review sessions, do the optional problem sets, and take detailed notes in lecture (if you cannot go, have someone record for you). Required reading is not as important as the lectures.

Make sure to go to lectures because those three extra points on the final exam are worth it. The class is not about regurgitating information, but about being able to apply concepts to problems you've never seen before.
Most people who take this course do so because it's required. For those of you interested in just taking an STL, I would consider MOL 215 instead if you have a more analytical/mathematical mind.
Only take if required.
Only take if you need the premed requirement. Take 215 if you like a more numerical approach and less of the numb regurgitation.
Piazza is great. Always use it. Go to office hours. Both professors are so helpful!!
Premed or bio requirements, then take it. Otherwise, don't bother.
Prepare early, go to lecture even if it's super early, don't fall behind
Pretty straightforward class, it is kind of rough to have it at 8:30 though.
Quite a difficult course and the lab reports take a very long time.
Read the lectures, and do the optional problem sets.
Readings should be done at least once and attend all lectures.
Record the lectures!

Start studying for the exams about a week beforehand, and don't underestimate the amount you will have to learn. It's mostly just memorization, although I would say the more difficult parts of the exams are the application sections, so make sure you've studied enough to thoroughly understand how each concept works, not just the steps of the process. Take for a requirement, don't take for general interest.
Stay on top of your game!
Study a little bit every week and take notes on a computer or just make sure you take very good notes! Try to record the lectures if you can, it is very helpful for studying.
Study for the midterms!

Study hard before each exam. I was unable to do so for the first one because of other assignments, and that handicapped me for the rest of the semester. Focus on slides and do the problem sets, after which you can review the book if you have time (though it is unnecessary). I would recommend this class for PDF if you want a fun STL, but it was terrible for a premed like me.

Study intensely before the exam  - go over material again and again until you understand it.  People say you have to memorize material, but make sure more importantly to understand concepts and connect the bigger picture.  That itself will enable you to "memorize" the material.
Take 215 unless you hate math or have already taken AP Bio and done well.
Take if you need to take it. Sucks that its at 8:30.
Take it and go to lecture.

Take it if it's a pre-med or departmental requirement. Don't take it if you're looking for a distribution requirement. Even though you may think the content is easy, exams can be a pain. Use office hours and review sessions. Content is interesting but it is challenging.
Take it if you are at all interested in biology. There is a lot of information to learn, but it is a well taught and well organized course!
Take it if you like BiO
Take it if you need to. Apparently it's good prep for the MCATs
Take it if you're interested. Beware the curve.
Take it!
Take it! Be warned though, its not your typical run of the mill biology class. It has a very molecular focus.
Take it! It's an engaging course. Do the problem sets; don't fall behind in readings. Don't underestimate the amount of material in this course - it's a lot.
Take it!!!
Take it, but make sure that you dedicate time to the material daily if you do not want to fall behind! Overall, it is a very interesting course and an opportunity to learn a lot!
Take it, you'll learn a lot and it's fun.
Take it. especially if you took AP Biology in high school
Take notes during lecture and read the textbook.
Take the class it is very interesting!! Also, do some of the readings as it gives you more to study for on the exams.
Take this as your STL even if you don't need is a requirement, as long as you've taken AP biology before :)
Take this class if you have any interest in molecular biology. It's a fascinating course and great intro class.
Take this class! Especially if Notterman is teaching. It was my favorite class I've taken at Princeton so far.

The course is a really good overview of molecular biology and you can really tell that the professors are all trying their best to make it as good of an experience as possible for the students. Exams are poorly worded, however, and that leads to a lot of frustration, but grading is not too harsh.
The exams require a lot of memorization, but the material is extremely interesting and well-taught.
This class is what you would expect for an entry level MOL class. Not too bad, but don't slack off too much.
This course has lots of stuff to be learned and one must always keep up with the pace of the class.
This course is pretty interesting and can be a deciding factor to see if you would like to major in Mol Bio. Lots of premeds in the class, so don't expect a high curve on exams though.

This course is very good for a nice intro to molecular biology. If you're a MOL major or premed, you have to take it anyway, but it's nice that it's a good course by itself. Be warned though, 8:30am lectures are horrifying, so I'd recommend that you record the lectures in case you miss anything. Lectures are important--more important than textbook reading. The course was also very well organized and there are many resources out there if you ever need help (two profs as lecturers, one more for lab, another for weekly review sessions, and a lab TA).
This is a course that needs outside engagement with individual reviews consistently. Really stay on top of the course material you are learning every week.
This is a great course. It is very well taught and the professors are very helpful.

This is an excellent course. It gives you a broad understanding of Mol Bio while also give you an in depth knowledge of specific experiments. The focus on experiments really impressed me, especially in the first half of the course. The course has a lot of information, but if you go to lecture you won't ever feel overwhelmed.
Try to do readings because every once in a while there's a lecture slide you won't understand unless you have done the reading. It doesn't involve as much work as other science classes here might.
Very well taught, very interesting (even though I don't plan to major in bio/etc.) This course is one of the most well-organized at Princeton
Wicked easy if you have half a brain and can memorize some facts. Definitely take this instead of 215
You just have to get through it. Class material is interesting but you'll get screwed on lab reports and the exams. Don't expect a good grade even if you're really good at bio.
You probably have to take it, but don't worry, it's not as bad as CHM 202.
You probably have to take it. Not too bad
You're gonna need to memorize everything just to pass.
be prepared
don't take it unless you have to. it's very hard
don't take unless you have to - not very fun for a person that finds mol bio a little boring
great course! if you're not premed, you should still take it if you didn't take ap or ib bio.
it's ok.  not great
lots of work but worth it
not hard if you put in some time
only do it if you have to.
spend time to understand everything.
take 215
take for req only
take it if you have to
take the time to study. a lot. read the book. go to review sessions. talk to other people about the material. go to office hours. it is a lot of work if you want to do well
tougher than I thought it would be
descrip: Important concepts and elements of molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology, are examined in an experimental context. This course fulfills the requirement for students majoring in the biological sciences and satisfies the biology requirement for entrance into medical school.

title: The New Jim Crow: US Crime Policy from Constitutional Formation to Ferguson
reviews: AMAZING
Be prepared to have your world-view fundamentally challenged. Do the readings and if you have the time (I unfortunately didn't) talk to Prof Murakawa about this stuff because she really cares.
Be sure you are committed to staying on top of the readings. It is most definitely worth it and a wonderful class!

Cherish every minute of it.  This class goes by so quickly, but its amazing.  There will be a lot of hard work, but it is so incredible and will be worth every minute.
More concretely, don't be afraid to ask questions, even those that you might think are silly or obvious!
Come to this class open-minded, ready to read a lot, and know that to get a good grade, you may have to spit back what she believes rather than what you believe.
Do all the readings (or as much of them as you can) and go to office hours!!!!

I think this is one of the most politically relevant courses you might ever have a chance to take. You can sit in on some lectures in the beginning, but if you're really considering taking it, just enroll. Spaces will fill super fast.
I would highly recommend this class!
I would strongly recommend taking this course.  I would advise students to allow sufficient time to devote to the coursework.
Murakawa is a fantastic professor. I totally recommend this course because it'll help you to understand the really complicated state of race and American policy.
Murakawa is phenomenal! Take any course with her name attached to it!

Read wisely and efficiently. The reading load is heavy and much of the material repeats itself so read only what is necessary. many readings will get caught up in the details, but you have to be able to abstract the details into the big idea in order to do well in the course. If you can think this way well, you're good to go. All in all, it is challenging but a very worthwhile intellectual experience.
Stay on top of reading, because it is easy to fall behind.
TAKE THIS COURSE if you have any desire to understand the huge, multifaceted, and problematic but too often invisible issue of mass incarceration in America today.

THIS CLASS IS AMAZING. Naomi Murakawa is an angel sent from heaven to enlighten us all about how incredibly twisted our world and criminal policies are. Though the subject matter is somewhat depressing, I left this class feeling exponentially more knowledgeable about the inner workings of US society and ready to take action.

THIS CLASS IS SO GOOD. Professor Murakawa is brilliant on a whole different level; I was so excited to go to every lecture. You should make it a top priority to get her as a professor. This class was by far my favorite of the year, somehow managing to be both empowering and depressing at the same time. It truly changed my conceptions of crime, imprisonment, and the criminal, and made me see the bigger picture of how our society has been fundamentally structured around race.
Take it! Amazing course, amazing professor, and certainly relevant and interesting!
Take it! Everyone should take this! You won't regret it - lectures are mesmerizing. There's a lot of reading that you may or may not have to do.
Take it.
Take this class, do the readings, and get to know Professor Murakawa because she's pretty awesome.
This is a must take. Don't PDF!
Yes
You have to take this class.
descrip: This course explores the political development of America's racially disparate punishment regime. We trace the history of US crime policy, moving through US constitutional formation, Reconstruction and lynch law, and Jim Crow punishment in the South and urban North. We focus on punishment in post-civil rights America, and we devote special attention to policing, the death penalty, and the interconnected wars on crime, drugs, immigration, and terror. Our overarching goal is to understand the political construction of crime, colorblindness, and legitimate state violence.

title: Physics of the Universe - Origin & Evolution
reviews: If you've already taken cosmology/read a book on it this course may provide some new insights on selected topics (such as the early universe). If you have no prior knowledge of cosmology it would be a good place to start learning from.
Take good noted, do the readings, and attend all lectures. Ask questions of the professor and TA.
descrip: The course is the first of a two-semester survey (along with PHY 564) of fundamental concepts which underly contemporary cosmology. The first semester focuses on the nearly homogeneous evolution of the universe including the standard big bang picture, inflationary cosmology, dark matter, and the possibility of present-day accelerated expansion. The second semester focuses on the late stages in the evolution of the universe, when gravity results in the growth of large-scale structure, perturbations in the cosmic microwave background, gravitational lensing and other non-linear phenomena.

title: Government, Poverty, and Inequality in Modern America
reviews: Absolutely take this class. PFK's lectures are brilliant if you pay attention for the entire lecture instead of being distracted by Facebook and iMessage. I left every session with a new perspective on the relevant social issues surrounding the Mike Brown, Eric Garner, and Freddie Gray cases, among others. Her book, the "Hero's Fight" is fascinating; it will open anyone's eyes to a world that is seldom breached by the average middle to upper class Princeton student.
Always keep up with the readings
Be prepared to tackle big picture themes.
DON'T TAKE IT.

Definitely get to know PFK by going to office hours. She's really a great person and mentor. Do be prepared for it to be a bit disorganized, particularly the CBLI option. It is a great course overall though, and the material (particularly since it's based on PFK's own research) is really fascinating and important for everyone to know.

Depends on what you want to get from it. I would not recommend if you are choosing this as your most serious class because you may be frustrated with material and some of the laxness of other students in precept
Do the readings because it helps you participate in precept, and it will make life easier for the final.
Do the readings, go to lecture and precept
Do the readings. Go to lecture.
GO TO CLASS! You need to go to class. Going to class is necessary.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture and listen. Read the Hero's Fight.
Go to lecture and precept and try to have a good grasp of the reading as it will help for the midterms and finals.
Go to lectures, do the readings.

I would advise students to stay on top of the readings. The structure of the course can easily lead to many students procrastinating; don't do that. The more you pay attention, the better prepared you will be for the take-home exams and the more enjoyable the material will be.

I would recommend this course, if for no other reason than to understand why poverty and inequality exist in the forms they do here in the U.S. I grew up in an area where people were very much of the school of thought that everyone is self made, and that if you work hard you'll be able to get by. This class was the first time I really heard the reasons behind why systematic disadvantage is a real thing, and why it exists in the first place. It was eye opening for me.
I would take another course with her/pick this course if you're really interested in the topic.
If you are interested in the topic, take it. Also if you are good at BSing this class is perfect for you since it is only take home essays.
Interesting class, take it
It will get harder next year
It's an interesting class, whether you care about the subject matter or not. Relatively light work load; would take if looking for an easy PDF.
Just FYI, she has started to crack down on grading, it is not a joke class by any means, but an extremely manageable PDF. Plus. her book is actually pretty solid if you get the chance to read it.
Keep up on the blog posts because you have to do at least 3. Also expect tough grading on the midterm.
Light course, small reading load.
Make sure to do the readings.
Most interesting pfk class at the school
My advice? Take the course if you are generally interested. Not a lot of work. Be aware of very late grading...that was my only issue about this.
Not the best.
PFK is a great lecturer. Very passionate and honest. She is a true expert in her field and I highly recommend taking this course!
Read PFK's book.  It's pretty easy reading, and it's very interesting.
Read all the readings
Read the readings.
Recommend
Recommend it.
Stay engaged in course material.
Super easy - classic PFK course. Take it
Take It
Take it if the material sounds interesting to you. It's not a bad course just was not for me.
Take it with PFK as preceptor. She's making mandatory attendance now.
Take it! It's a great class
Take it.  It is not too much reading and it is interesting.  Along with great teachers.
Take this course for general interest! Try to get Melanie as a preceptor!
Take this course. Any major, any set of academic skills. It is very rewarding and necessary to understand for the rest of your life.
Take this course. The material was incredibly rewarding to read and PFK is a great professor that cares deeply about her students.

Take this course. This course was one of the better courses I've taken at Princeton, and it made me think a lot about poverty. Most kids just BSd their way through, but if you spend even a little time thinking about the discussions in precept or some of the easier readings, you'll find yourself questioning the system around us and really thinking about poverty as an issue. Grading was not - as everyone seems to claim - easier than other classes. The papers were actually pretty difficult to write if you wanted above a B . Definitely spend time on this course if you want to do well.

This course, while perhaps not the best organized, explores an extremely important topic. No matter which side of the political spectrum you fall on, a greater understanding of what it means to be poor in the United States is essential and you will probably find yourself talking about the course material outside of class.
Unless you want to be brainwashed, don't take this course
Very interesting, you'll enjoy reading pfk's book more than you initially anticipate.
Yes
You'll learn a lot about cities and poverty and race in America... I'd recommend taking it.
do not take this course or any PFK course
go to lecture and take notes
participate in precepts
take it for an easy class.
take it!!!!

take take tale
go to lecture
take this class as a filler, when you have a heavy course load, it is no work for a PDF and minimal work for a grade
descrip: The course examines poverty and inequality in relation to processes of globalization that have transformed the means of economic mobility for working people in the U.S. We raise questions about government institutions acting on behalf of different constituencies and according to varying criteria of economic "deservedness;" and evaluate vibrant debates about the role of democratic government in promoting social justice. Among the subjects covered are poverty and religion, social and cultural capital among the poor, and poverty, crime, incarceration, and entrepreneurship.

title: Art of Adventure, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Image Processing
reviews: Assignments can be a decent amount of work, but you'll learn a lot about image processing.
Doing the exercises in the lecture notes is good preparation for the exams. Ramadge goes into the math and explains it really clearly.

Great class! Ramadge is a great instructor if you haven't had him yet, and image processing is probably the most tangibly awesome application of some of the signal processing theory we've learned in EE.
Labs are good, and if you attend class I'm sure you can get a lot out of it
Take it!

Take this course if Professor Ramadge is teaching.  He took great care in improving the course.  As someone who has also taken COS 429 (computer vision), I can tell you that this course is much more well taught and you will learn A LOT.  The course starts out teaching basic Image Processing concepts, and then covers modern machine learning techniques in the second half.  The class is in Python, which is a plus. However, it is HARD and you will spend a lot of time on this class.

This was definitely an interesting course, and it goes into detail about how image processing is done (filtering, 2D convolution). We also spent a good portion of the time on machine learning and SVMs, clustering, probability, etc. The material was interesting, but the course was just a little disorganized. Definitely go to lectures if you want to know what's going on with exam information--logistics are never really posted anywhere on Blackboard.
Very interesting course. Slightly heavier work load, but at the end you can learn so much.
descrip: Introduction to the basic theory and techniques of image processing. Topics include image perception, acquisition, display, enhancement, restoration, compression, transformation, tomography, medical imaging, video coding and content analysis. Applications to HDTV, machine vision, medical imaging, etc.

title: Charity, Philanthropy & Development
reviews: Clark-Deces is a wonderful teacher. If you are interested in the subject matter definitely take this class!
Great class but really depends on the group of students you have (as with any seminar that's heavily based on student participation)
Prof. Clark-Deces definitely cares a lot, but the curriculum could have been more focused. Workload definitely manageable.
Take it if you are interested in the topic. Professor Clark-Deces is excellent. Be prepared for developing a critical and jaded perspective on making a difference though.

Take it, do the readings, participate in class, but most importantly, reevaluate your own thoughts on charity and development. Don't let the class get you down with all the talk about failure and the fall of idealism, but use the class to advise you what NOT to do.

Talk to deces re the final papers - know what she is looking for
Do the response papers early on
Indicating understanding of authors' viewpoints and the papers we have read is key

This class was rather depressing--it is not about the ways charity can help and more about the ways charity can fail, or even hurt. Prof. Clark-Deces is smart and nice, though, and it does teach you to think critically!
contribue to discussion because the class isn't fun when the same people dominate discussions.
prereqs: No previous knowledge of anthropology is required..
descrip: This course explores charity & philanthropy in global capitalism: religious charity reducing poverty and improving social/health outcomes locally & globally; religious philanthropy relating to capitalism; classic problems in the anthropology of religion, the person, the economy & the gift. While concentrating on Western charitable organizations, private foundations and small & large businesses in developing societies, we will also examine processes that give rise to forms of corporate philanthropy in the global South, particularly India. This will lead us to important questions about the nature and future of development & global capitalism.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Be prepared to study regularly
Lots of work but very engaging, especially if you care about Chinese thought and history.
None
Take it! The work load is not as bad as previous classes and the material is interesting!
Take this class!
this year, 2nd semester 4th year had a lot more variety. more movies and short stories. more oral reports too :O, but only one last a week and no ??s?
prereqs: CHI 403 or instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of 403. Reading and discussion of scholarly writings in the fields of Chinese literature and modern Chinese intellectual history. A weekly written assignment will be required.

title: Theory and Practice of Arabic to English Translation
prereqs: Minimum of two years of study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107), or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course trains students in the practice of translating Arabic texts from a wide variety of genres into English. Attention will be given to both theoretical and practical problems of translation for research and professional ends.

title: Physics for the Life Sciences
reviews: Always attend lecture!
Good course to take for an STN or if you are interested in physics/biology.
Great alternative to PHY 101/102 and PHY 103/104.
I imagine it's better than PHY101/102, so might be a good option. Not much work

I would recommend this course if you don't have a strong background in physics and need to take more for your major or for pre-med. There is not a large biology focus, however, so don't get your hopes up that this is going to be an easier version of biophysics.

I'd recommend this class if you need to take physics as a MOL requirement and want to know how to apply concepts to things that you will be working with directly. Professor Puchalla is pretty good, and he proved willing to change things according to student feedback to make this class work. I think this class will improve in the coming years.
Take it! Even if you don't need to, this will teach 95% of students all the physics they'll ever need in a clear and engaging manner.
prereqs: Spring 2015 pilot offering: PHY 101 or AP equivalent, or permission of instructor. Beginning in Spring 2016, there will be no prerequisites for this course..
descrip: A new one semester physics course designed specifically for life science majors. Selected topics in physical theory and experiment will be presented and highlighted using a range of examples.

title: Advanced French
reviews: A good language class for finishing that requirement!
Be prepared to do most of the learning independently, there is not much instruction in class.

Don't do the homework answering questions about texts (but do do the grammar) - otherwise you will be bored in class. It's a fine class and not very much work - it will prepare you to get into more interesting higher-level French courses.

From what I've heard from my friends in FRE107, FRE107 is a much less intensive course than FRE108 though they do meet every day of the week. Keep this in mind while making your decision. If you can take FRE107, do it.
Great teacher, a lot of fun and you learn a lot!

I would tell them to not do the grammar exercises before you go over it in class, but rather to do them as a review right before exams. That really helped me, personally, and brought up my test grades a lot. I would also say that attendance is very important and that if you want a good participation grade you need to do all of the readings and watch all of the movies. Besides, those are fun and Perrier leads very engaging discussions. They also definitely help the most with actual language skills.
If you struggle at grammar like me, print out multiple copies of the CP so that you can practice the exercises again in preparation for your exam
If you would like to commit to improving your French, this class provides an excellent structure for doing so.

It is manageable if you stay up with it. Stay up with the readings and grammar exercises. Do not wait until the last minute before the exam to review all the grammar. Come to class prepared and with questions.
It's a good class, take it if you'd like to become fluent in French!
It's harder than 105 by a lot.
Keep up with readings and homework. Go to class because you're graded on it.

Lots of grammar work based on the textbook, need to memorize every detail for the exam. The movies and videos were very engaging and interesting, but a big problem is that students don't really get to interact with each other and are more answering Q's in class.

Make sure that you get an instructor who you will like or pick the head of the course. It's hit or miss with grad students. The only reason why I recommend this course is because it is a stepping stone to other French classes and I believe, from my excellent experience last semester with 105, that the FRE department is amazing

Mme Perrier is a wonderful teacher, she's very invested in her students and the class is a great opportunity to work on your spoken French.  I would definitely encourage future students to participate actively in discussions.
Not too much effort, and it can be fun.
Only take it if you must.

Pay close attention in class. Everything you need to know will be said, but it goes quickly and there are a lot of small rules that you have to catch. Take careful notes of all grammatical rules and vocabulary. The vocab notes are very helpful when preparing for short answer/essay test questions or a composition.
Perrier is awesome!
Practicing/reviewing a lot helps for the tests
Read the textbook
Speak a lot in class, and do your best to be animated in discussions. It makes the class more fun!
Speak up! Participate as much as possible. Even if you don't feel comfortable, the only way to improve is to practice.
Stay on top of exercises. Ask questions.
Study a little every day--grammar concepts can't be crammed.
TAKE!
Take advantage of your professors, ask questions, do your readings.

Take this class if you must, but don't expect it to wow or to drastically improve your French. Keep up with the grammar exercises and you will do perfectly fine on the exams and final. Low time commitment, but not an extremely exciting class.
Take this class!
Take this course if your goal is to be fluent in this course.
There's no way you can escape any of the readings or homework since we take it all up in class, so as long as you follow the instructions and requirements, you'll be fine!

This class is good, but I personally found it hard to manage as an engineer. The class requires a decent amount of preparation for each class and for the assignments. Good class, but be conscientious of this. But overall an enjoyable course.
Yes, take it with Marie Sanquer!
do all of the readings and grammar book exercises even though they are optional
put time into it.
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Director of French Language Program..
descrip: FRE 108 is an intermediate advanced course, with a brand new syllabus. We'll take you on a journey through various periods of French history and culture and offer an opportunity to reflect on important questions at the center of controversial debates: national identity, immigration, relationships with the Francophone world and former colonies, the role of the State in the shaping of the nation, etc. We have selected a variety of authentic materials (films, videos, music, newspapers articles and literary texts) and carefully incorporated them into our curriculum so you'll develop your ability to communicate in French.

title: Topics in Economics - House of Debt: Understanding Macro & Financial Policy
descrip: Why do severe recessions happen? Could we have prevented the Great Recession and its consequences? And what actions are needed to prevent such crises going forward? We undertake an empirical exploration of these questions in this course and debate the various macro and financial policy questions that arise. Our discussions will be strictly disciplined by data and evidence. The course will analyze the role of debt in generating the Great Recession and the Great Depression, as well as the current economic malaise in Europe. The course is built around the new book, `House of Debt' by Mian and Sufi.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Race and Public Policy
reviews: I liked the class and would take it- I learned a lot. That being said, remember that you have a long paper and a final at the end. Also, remember that this class is really much more about A History of African-Americans in the United States- if you're more interested in the study of other races or societies I would not take this.
Important information to know and relevant to today, but overall pretty dry, would take a different course on race
Make sure to go to the lectures.

Material is interesting and extremely relevant, but lectures are boring -- you could get just as much by reading lecture slides on your own.  Thus, as an educational experience this class was extremely disappointing for me.  Furthermore, if you've taken classes on US history during this period in college (e.g. US History 1920-1974 with Kevin Kruse), there may be a lot of overlap with past material.
Paper at end of course is long.  Midterm was rushed for time but very fair -- by knowing lecture material, you could expect to perform well.
One of the most important classes I've taken at Princeton, maybe ever. A little disorganized, but the content is more than worth dealing with that. Take it.
Pay attention to lecture material - that is exactly what the midterm / final is on. Definitely recommend for woody woo majors for fulfilling the soc req
TAKE IT!
Take it!
Take it! This should be required for all students because it makes you understand how twisted the world is.

Take the course if you are interested in racial politics. Professor Massey is extremely knowledgeable, and he has a valuable perspective for students to listen to. Just be prepared that his lectures can be fairly partisan at times.
The 20 page paper isn't too bad. Definitely take the course.
This class is easy but the precepts are terrible and the lectures aren't very scintillating. It covers a lot of interesting material though.
Would strongly recommend to anyone who needs to fulfill their soc requirement for Woody Woo
take this class!!!!
descrip: Analyzes the historical construction of race as a concept in American society, how and why this concept was institutionalized publicly and privately in various arenas of U.S. public life at different historical junctures, and the progress that has been made in dismantling racialized institutions since the civil rights era.

title: Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Gandhi: The Making of the Mahatma
reviews: Definitely take it! I was originally only taking it for an HA but came to discover that this class is brilliant! Even if you're BSE like me and don't have a good gauge for history, take this class! It's so well taught that anybody can enjoy it!
I'd recommend taking it if you have an interest and background in India. Prof. Prakash is great, and the readings are interesting.
If you are interested in Gandhi at all, take this class. If you are interested in political movements, South Asia, nationalism, nonviolence, anything, take this class!

One the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Made me wish I'd been a history major. Take this course. Professor Prakash is one of the most eloquent and interesting professors I've come across, but he's also very approachable and likes undergrads. He has a way of making the conversation flow, and there are never any awkward silences. He really gets students to engage with the materials and with each other. The course has quite a bit of reading, but it's all very manageable, and you don't have to read everything for every seminar (2 out 3 readings, for instance, is fine).
Take it!! Definitely worth it, even if you're not a history major.

Take this course even if you have no background in Indian history or Gandhi. Professor Prakash is a fantastic guide and teacher, and you will learn a lot about very interesting subject matter that's rarely covered in other courses.

This is a really great course! Prakash is a great professor and the workload is no more than average for a history seminar.  If you're interested in learning more about Gandhi, I would very strongly recommend this course.
take it!
descrip: The seminar examines Gandhi's political life extending from his campaign for the rights of Indians in South Africa to his leading role in the struggle for Indian independence from British rule. In doing so, it focuses on those historical processes that turned M. K. Gandhi into a major 20th-century figure -- the Mahatma. Issues relating to imperialism and nationalism form the context in which the seminar looks at Gandhi's life and seeks to understand Gandhi's thoughts on the modern nation, community, religious state, and sexuality.

title: Compiling Techniques
reviews: A lot of time wasted on insignificant details. Exercises require a great deal of time, with little benefit. I think the course has good potential, but it misses its goal. It would not draw you towards pursuing the work with compilers.
Consider more reading sources except recommended for the course.
Course was well-taught but is quite hard (as expected)
Definitely take it. August is awesome, you learn a bunch of cool things, and it's not terrible in terms of workload (although the last few assignments were pretty challenging).

Do not take this course!! It came back from a revamp this year, and came out far worse for the wear. The lectures are slow and dreadfully boring (e.g. two 80-min lectures on DFAs, with the same detail as 126) and are in no way connected with the assignments which are brutally difficult due to the lack of guidance and use of an outside technology (LLVM). If you do take it, start the assignments early so you have plenty of time to debug. Read the book instead of lecture (most lecture slides are photocopied from the book anywar).
Go for it! It's significantly more difficult than the  other (standard) systems classes (333 and 461), but way more rewarding.  Definitely the most mind opening COS class I've taken here.
If you are into computer system and architecture, definitely take this course. It is very well structured, and the lecturer (Professor August) is very good!

Not recommended. While August is a fine lecturer, the assignments in this course are just plain bad. They are far too time consuming (even by COS assignment standards), and they are hardly related to the class material at all. Assignments are about digging through documentation trying to hammer out tiny details of a task (e.g. printing a string) that have nothing to do with the focus of the course. If you are excited about compilers, this course will be fine for you, but if you just need a systems requirement, there are better ones out there.
OS and Networks are much better Systems departmentals.

Revamped this year to use LLVM instead of an ML based compiler.  I enjoyed the assignments, but spent a lot of time just figuring out LLVM.  Nice thing is that this could actually be useful in the future, which wasn't true in previous offerings.  August does a good job of making the lectures entertaining even when the material is dry.
Take another system class unless you're really interested in compilers. This is a good class but too time consuming and assignments are too hard
Take it if you are interested in compilers. You don't really need to know anything before, but having taken OS will prepare you for the difficulty of some of the assignments.
Take it if you are interested in the material. It's a very interesting systems course.

Take it if you're interested in compilers because you'll learn a lot about them, but be prepared for difficult material and programming assignments. Also, the class focuses more on the "theoretical" side of things, but the programming assignments are very pragmatic (we use "real" compiler building tools like LLVM/yacc/flex) so there's a good balance there, although sometimes it feels like the assignments and lectures were a bit disconnected.
Take it if you're interested. It uses the tools used in modern research compilers. But the last assignment is impossible
Take it with August!
Take it! Professor August's lectures are really interesting and the class material is a nice intersection of theory and practice. The course material is really cool too!
Take this if you're interested in how code gets compiled.
The lectures are very theoretical.  The assignments seem overwhelming at first, but they're very well-written.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Understand the design and construction of compilers. Concepts include syntax analysis, semantics, code generation, optimization and run-time systems. Translation of imperative languages (such as C), functional languages (such as ML), and object-oriented languages (such as Java) will be studied. Students will implement a complete compiler for a small language.

title: Pre-Columbian Peoples of Tropical America and Their Environments
reviews: If you want to go to Panama, this is not the reason that you should not go. However, just be prepared for a pretty easy, non-departmental, kind of boring class. (Boring unless you like archaeology! Then it's awesome because the lecturers are world-famous).

Note that this class doesn't count for a departmental, only an SA (even if you finished them). Just a warning too that this course is pretty disorganized, and communication (about what was happening, when and where we needed to be place, what we needed) was terrible. Also, as scientists the work/material will seem a little silly. Make sure to push for the field trips with both professors as those were the most educational and fun parts of the course. All that being said, this course is part of a great program, and it was a nice break from fast-paced research classes.
This is disorganized and frustrating. Prepare to be patient.
You don't exactly have a choice if you study abroad.
prereqs: Prerequisites: 211, and 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring Semester in tropical ecology program in Panama..
descrip: The pre-European history of Amerind cultures and their associated environments in the New World tropics will be studied. Topics to be covered include the peopling of tropical America; development of hunting/gathering and agricultural economies; neotropical climate and vegetation history; and the art, symbolism, and social organization of native Americans. Field and laboratory experiences will incorporate methods and problems in field archaeology, paleoenthnobotany and paleoecology, and archaeozoology.

title: Introduction to Metaphysics and Epistemology
reviews: A great introduction to philosophy. We cover some really interesting topics (free will, determinism, induction), and the workload quite reasonable. Definitely recommended if you're personally interested in the topic.

Definitely take it if you're marginally interested in those late night conversations you have with other people in your hallway about the universe, the existence of God, time travel, personal identity, free will, etc. It's not a huge time commitment, and it is definitely interesting.
Definitely worth taking--you get to think and read about very interesting questions, plus it's not a whole lot of work.
Depends mostly upon preceptor.
Do the readings that interest you
Do the readings.
Easy
Either do the readings carefully or attend the lectures; there is no need for both.
For a requirement maybe

For the papers actually write them and ask for feedback. You can come up with a B-range paper off the top of your head but with just talking to the professor / one of the preceptors you can probably get it up to an A. No reason not to try.
Fun and easy class.
Go to office hours and figure out how to write a philosophy paper long before you begin to write your papers!
Good class to PDF
Good course
Good, fairly relaxed course. Honestly not that much work at all, considering you only have three papers. If you pdf the course it becomes a breeze.
Great course that's interesting without being stressful. Take it!
I would try this class out.

If you are interested in taking an introductory philosophy class, this may be the right one for you! The one good thing it does is teach you how to write a philosophy paper, which is a very concise form of writing. Recommended.

If you are taking this for a grade, really do meet your preceptor regularly before your paper is due and fine tune your essay. 
If you are not taking this for a grade, sit back and relax.
If you like philosophy at all, I would definitely recommend this course.
If you need an easy PDF and are interested at all in very meta questions then this is a great class.
Interesting material, straightforward essays, and good preceptors. Take it if you're interested in philosophy.
Interesting topics, very easy course
It is an extremely easy class if you either know how to write a philosophy paper or are willing to ask your preceptor to read your essay before it is due.
It isn't necessary to do the reading in depth except for the pieces on which you want to write essays.

Its an easy class that covers the distribution requirement with very little work on the students part. However, there are so many other much more interesting courses at this school. Take them instead.
Just go to precepts. The material is interesting.
Make use of office hours.
Not the best structured course...
PDF for your EC requirement
Pretty easy/chill class. Low commitment.

Prof. Kment seems like a good guy, and the reading is interesting, but it isn't the best philosophy class out there. I am a philosophy major, and I am not sure I would have been as interested in philosophy if this had been the first course in the department I took.
Read the material if interested. Otherwise go to office hours for assignments.
Really think hard about your papers!  The material is interesting but it's up to you if you wanna go to the lectures.
Spend more time on your papers, they're fun concepts to think about.
Take if you want to have a class where you do literally no work.

Take it and be willing to be open to weird concepts. Easy EC requirement that requires that you go to only the lectures that you plan to write about for papers, and you actually cover interesting material.

Take it if you don't mind interesting subject matter and a boring lecture. Precepts will probably make the class either way. Sherif is a great preceptor! Get him if you can. I hear Rosen is teaching it Spring 2016, in which case TAKE IT!!! Sherif (my preceptor) came here in '08 and said Rosen was a fav professor in the Phil department. Def take it if he's teaching it. It will be 1000X BETTER.

Take it with Dasgupta, because Kment isn't a great lecturer. Not a very rigorous class, so if you're looking for a class that really challenges you to think, I would think again on what you would really want to take.
Take it with someone besides Kment. It's a great class, just he's not the most fascinating lecturer.
Take it! It's a good course, especially if you have the time to actually do the readings. While it's a good PDF course, I would recommend taking it for a grade and save your PDF for other things.
Take it, its perfect for PDF.
Take this course if you need a distribution, but do not expect to be that engaged.
Take to see what philosophy is like and get an EC.
This class is an intro class. You (can if you want) do the readings then they talk about it in lecture. The grading is mostly just the 3 papers, which aren't bad.
This course offers a strong, engaging introduction to metaphysics and epistemology.
This is a basic intro to philosophy course.

This is a great class to take on top of a heavy courseload.  It doesn't require too much work and isn't that complicated.  Some of the concepts are interesting, others aren't.  Overall it's fine though.

This is a great course to take if you are at all interested in philosophy. If you are like me and cannot concentrate very long to someone just speaking at you, the lectures are absolutely awful. But if you do the readings, you will be fine.
This is a great introduction course into philosophy that covers a broad spectrum of ideas, especially if you are like me in the sense that I had very little philosophical background.
Yes I would recommend this course especially if you want to get your feet wet with philosophy,
You will enjoy this class!
chill
go to lecture instead of doing the readings
take it only if you're interested in philosophy
take this
very good class to take for an easier distribution requirement
very neat topics, can write papers on anything which is great! go to lecture!!
descrip: An introduction to central questions of philosophy, such as: Does God exist? Is there an external world full of material objects, or is this belief based on an illusion? Do human beings have free will (so that they can be held morally responsible for their actions)? In the past, bread has always nourished and never poisoned us, but do we have reasons for thinking that that will be true tomorrow? How can we ever be sure that the future will resemble the past? Are human beings material objects, or immaterial souls, or something else altogether?

title: American Political Institutions
descrip: This seminar is part of the two-course sequence of the core curriculum in American politics and provides an introductory survey of American political institutions. Provides an overview of the various problems for which institutional solutions are sought (e.g., problems involving collective action, delegation, and social choice) as well as a detailed assessment of some of the scholarly literature that investigates political institutions.

title: God of Many Faces: Comparative Perspectives on Migration and Religion
reviews: Do the readings and go to lecture/precept and you'll learn a lot!
Fairly interesting and the workload is small. There's only 3 grades and no week to week assignments.
I heard wonderful things about PFK. I can confirm they are true.

I would encourage another student to take it if he or she has an interest in any of the topics under the course description. Readings are good and the course is manageable. You will come out of the course learning something and thinking, even if only a little, more about the topics' relation to you and society.
If you are majoring in sociology or have a general interest in religion and sociology take this course.
If you're looking for a good SA, take the class! Try to get into Fernandez-Kelly's precept.
It is a very interesting subject.  PFK's lectures can be difficult to follow and place in context of the course but the readings and precept discussion can offer a lot of development.
It's a good course but not quintessential to your Princeton career... I've heard that PFK uses the same readings in all of her courses....
Make sure to do the readings necessary to understand the basics of the course. Without those, you don't have a fundamental basis to function in the course.
Prepare well for precepts
Really awesome and interesting class.  Definitely take it!!
Super easy, classic PFK course
Take good class notes; these will be useful for the exams.
Take it for a nice, interesting fifth class
Take it! PFK is the best - she is so fun to talk to and a very engaging lecturer.
Take this course! It teaches some interesting information about immigration and the use of religion as a means of culturally adapting to different aspects of the world.
The course is very discussion-based, so if that and the topic interest you, go for it!
take it!
descrip: Immigrants often experience discrimination in areas of destination. Religion can strengthen their sense of worth, particularly when the circumstances surrounding departure from the country of origin are traumatic, as with exiles and refugees. We take a comparative approach and use examples from the United States, Asia, Europe, and Latin America. The course broaches questions such as: how does religion transform (and how is it transformed by) the immigrant experience? When is religion used to combat stereotypes? Are there differences between the way men and women or dominant groups and racial minorities understand religion?

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Social Entrepreneurship for Policymakers
descrip: Over the last 20 years, the emerging field of social entrepreneurship has taken new approaches to problems in education, waste management and global public health. This course focuses on types and stages of different social enterprises (non-profits/hybrid organizations/for-profits), will evaluate nature of capital available from grants to patient capital to market-return investments. Course seeks to equip students with a framework for understanding how: 1) social enterprise can complement traditional provision of public services and 2) new markets are being created that deliver clear social benefits while generating returns to investors.

title: The Brain: A User's Guide
reviews: A fun, easy, and gentle introduction to neuroscience.
Attend lectures and pay attention to detail even when he says you don't have to.
Average course.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS unless you really enjoy memorizing extremely specific and unimportant factoids for an exam.
Do not be fooled by Barry.  The quizzes are hard
Do not be fooled by anything Prof Jacobs says - the in-class quizzes and midterm/final will be totally based on tiny details from the textbook and class slides, not general concepts.

Do not take this course if you are thinking about it on a whim.  It is not interesting.  The professor is a terrible lecturer and does not teach you anything.  He tells you not to worry about the details and that you don't have to know that information, and then tests you on it...  If you like teaching yourself from a textbook this is the course for you, otherwise stay away.
Do not take this course unless you need the EC credit.
Do not waste your time.
Don't take it - either take an interesting psych class or an interesting and technical neuro one, but if you're looking for either of those then this is not it.
Dont take if you dont want to get crushed by random little facts

Easy enough material to introduce you to the brain and its workings. But prepare your stomach for a disturbing level of comfort with animal  experimentation. The entire neuroscience field seems to have no qualms about attaching little animals to electrodes. By the end of the semester your tolerance limit might be surpassed.

Fun class. No PDF, but the material isn't too bad. Just make sure you read the book and pay attention to detail, as the exams are very detail oriented. I felt as if I learned a lot while not being bogged down by the science.
Good for a distribution requirement. Not a lot of work, easy concepts.
I WOULDN'T recommend this course. It's not well taught. Take NEU 258 instead. This class is too ambiguous in terms of its expectations.
I suggest reserving a lot of time to study the course around exam time.
I would take this class if you are interested in Neuroscience and don't want to take PSY 258. For the exams you need to know a great level of detail even though the professor says you don't.
I would take this class if you're interested in psychology. It's very basic and interesting. I would just say be prepared for multiple choice and possible disappointment grade-wise because of it.
If you havent taken a neuroscience course, this could be great. If you have taken any type of neuroscience, this will feel very redundant and not special.
If you want an interesting class on the brain, take the neuron sequence instead.

If you want to know something about biological psychology, this is indeed a fun course, in terms of the topics given and some nice reading materials. But it might not be so good considering it is appearing on a transcript.
If you're interested in psych (or are a psych sandbagger like me), this is a non-science major psych overview class. Just be wary that there will be very intricate details on exams.
It is very interesting and I would recommend it. However, be warned that the exams are much more challenging than what is required during the semester.
Its a good class to take if you do not want to deal with problem sets but you make up for that in the exams.

Jacobs says that you don't need to study for the lecture quizzes, but if you're new to psychology, you should actually brush up on your notes the night before each lecture. Keep up with the textbook readings, and don't forget to post online.
Judge your success in this class on how often you can incorporate its material into general conversation. If you can, you will sound very smart. Excellent way to fulfill a distribution requirement.
Keep up with the textbook readings. You will learn better if you are concurrently reinforcing this information via the lectures.
Make sure you have a true interest in psychology or neuroscience if you take this class. Otherwise, it will be a waste of time and difficult to keep up with.
