Not much structure or guidance in this class - the book you have to read for precept is excellent, but otherwise not much flow and too much information.
Only take this class if you are good at memorization or are very interested in the material. It is not PDF so you have to be committed to the course.

Only take this course if you are interested in figuring out how the brain works and are willing to put a decent amount of time into the readings every week. The book is extremely helpful and you cannot succeed without reading it, despite what Professor Jacobs says sometimes.
Perhaps just jump straight into the entry level neuro class for a more comprehensive understanding of the brain.

Prof Jacobs is alright. His expectations for course material are ridiculous, as he says you dont need to read the book in the first couple weeks, to saying you should know very broad concepts in the next few weeks, to then having more than 50% of the midterm test explicit details from the textbook readings that go way more in depth than his poorly organized lectures.
Read both books.
Read the book and take notes

Read the freaking text book. I knew to do it because of course evals and friends who took it last year. Read closely and you will get an A.  If you don't you won't do well. It's not just another psych class, there is a lot of material to stay on top of, and the way Jacobs explains what you need to know is deceptive. You need to know a lot more for the test than he makes you think.
Read the textbook. The midterm is way more detailed then I thought it would be. Go to all lectures and precepts.
Recommend.

Take it but make sure you read the textbook because everything is reasonable to be tested on. The class tests HEAVILY on details. However, it does a good job of picking out the important parts of the huge field of neuroscience. It's very much a survey course, in every sense.
Take it for sure. It will fit into any schedule, even as a fifth course in a relatively full semester.
Take it if you're willing to at least do some of the textbook reading every week. Lecture is not enough to be successful.
Take it, but be ready for the quizzes being fairly hard.
Take notes on the lecture slides and pay serious attention in class.
Take this class if you're interested and not too worried about your grade, but in my opinion the testing is unfair.
Take this course if you want a basic foundation of how the brain works.
The exams are deceptively challenging in comparison to the lax nature of the lectures. Don't take this class if you just want an easy grade.

The material for this class is interesting, but tests are based heavily on textbook memorization and lectures are not very engaging. Definitely not a must-take, but if you're interested in the subject you may enjoy it.
The material is interesting but it is not presented in the most interesting way.
This a cool introductory class, so if you're interested in the brain and want a fun class, you should definitely take this.

This is a good course for peaking your interest in psych/neuro, but it is not necessarily "easy." You will have to study a take notes from the textbook and lectures and you might not get much guidance on what is on the exams.
Try to read the textbook every week. Enjoy precept and ask any questions you may have to your preceptor. Try to make a reading group with other students to go over the textbook material.
Way harder than you think it will be and no PDF. Avoid.
Wouldn't suggest it.
entertaining and interesting

if you take it and want an A, study every week, study a lot for exams as well. so much information. don't miss precepts/quizzes. not as easy class for the distribution requirement but it's interesting so it's worth it.
read the book. go to lecture.
take book notes as you go along during the week because it is a lot of information
descrip: The course provides a basic introduction to neuroscience, especially as it impacts upon practical issues: mental disease, drugs, neurological disorders, development, learning, memory, etc. It is intended for students who are not planning to concentrate in the life sciences. It is hoped that some students may get stimulated by this course and decide to concentrate in aspects of psychology, biology, philosophy, or engineering as they relate to mind and brain.

title: Topics in Organic Chemistry - Contemporary Methods in Organic Synthesis
reviews: Attend every class and make sure you understand all the basics so you can apply them to the problem sets and exams.
Keep up with the material.

This course is totally worth taking if you have taken 530 (or some other graduate level o-chem course).  It is very different though-- not as in depth, but much broader in scope. It exposed me to many areas of research/methods that are interesting/useful.

Don't obsess with details when studying like in CHM 530-- here the bigger picture is what matters the most.
Three hours of class at night is long, but there are always cookies.
definitely should take for organic students
prereqs: Completion of CHM 530 or special permission of instructor required..
descrip: This course provides an overview of contemporary methods in synthetic organic chemistry for first year graduate students and advanced undergraduates. Special emphasis will be placed on understanding the mechanisms, scope, limitations, and selectivities of some of the most important synthetic methodologies developed in the 21st century. Selected topics will include advances in cross coupling, olefin metathesis, pi acid catalysis, organocatalysis, photocatalysis, pi allyl chemistry, hydrogenation, C-H activation and hydrogen-bonding catalysis.

title: Psychopharmacology
prereqs: Biochemistry 345 or equivalent.
descrip: The molecular biology and biochemistry of pharmaceuticals and natural products that target CNS function are examined. Specific topics include: the blood-brain barrier, addiction and tolerance, analgesia, treatments for mood disorders, cognitive enhancement, stimulants and ADHD, treatment of dementias such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease, psychotropic drugs, antipsychotics and the treatment of schizophrenia.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Course offers a broad treatment of macroeconomic theory and policy issues, using the formal methods of modern macroeconomics. Topics will include long-run growth and development, labor, consumption, savings and investment decisions, the role of expectations, short-run fluctuations and stabilization policy, inflation and unemployment, trade and exchange rates. The course is advanced, so that: (i) having had some introductory course in macroeconomics is a prerequisite, and an intermediate-level one is best; (ii) the course requires a solid command of microeconomic theory (511 c or d) and good comfort with algebra and calculus.

title: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
reviews: Basic knowledge of physics and some basic math is required.
Prof. Lieb offers incredibly insightful information. Though the lectures can occasionally be difficult to follow, you will most likely learn some useful techniques.
descrip: An introduction to mathematically rigorous methods in physics. Topics to be covered include classical and quantum statistical mechanic, quantum many-body problem, group theory, Schroedinger operators, and quantum information theory.

title: What is the Scientific Revolution?
reviews: Be prepared to read, but don't be afraid if you find the readings difficult; that's what precept is for, and Prof. Rampling makes it as comfortable as possible! Would strongly recommend if you have any interest in the intersection between history and science.

Fascinating material, and accessible for the non-historian and the non-scientist alike. Access to an excellent educator and tremendous scholar in the field. I forewarn them that the grading can be somewhat harsh, but that shouldn't be grounds for not taking the course.

I would tell other students considering taking the course that, while it may not be the best history class to take to get a good idea of what the history department is like at Princeton, it is a decent class to PDF.

Professor Rampling is awesome and the lectures are really great, so go to them.  This class is a really solid HA but it is fairly sciency so if you're a science person and want to do something totally different then you might want to take something else.
This course was fascinating. It is particularly great for science majors, because you can learn about a lot of what led up to what you are learning in your other courses.

This was a good course to take as and HA requirement. There was not too much work and the topic was interesting, especially if you want to learn about how modern science developed through the 16th and 17th century.
descrip: Something "happened" to science between 1450-1750. The sun replaced the earth at the center of the cosmos, Europeans encountered new worlds and new peoples, and heaven and earth shook to the impact of new technologies like telescopes and heavy artillery. Yet how much was really new? Did all these changes merge into one phenomenon that we can call "the scientific revolution"? And were there many such revolutions -- or could the very idea be a modern invention? From optics and anatomy to alchemy and magic, this course will ask exactly how natural knowledge was shaped, challenged and exploited between the late Middle Ages and the Enlightenment.

title: Independent Work
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
reviews: I would tell them that if the course continues in its current format to use the time to focus on rotation work and try to learn neuroscience that way.
I would tell them they're not going to get much out of it.
Interesting, broad content that is a good overview, but doesn't go too much into detail.

This course is perfect to get an overview over a lot of different topics in Neuroscience while getting into enough details on particular topics. However, the course requires to have some basic Neuroscience and Psychology background.
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501A or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format that covers experimental and theoretical approaches to understanding how the brain works, spanning from the molecular and cellular to the systems and cognitive levels of analysis. It is organized into modules, each of which focuses on the neural mechanisms responsible for a specific subsystem or process, including perception, attention, learning, memory, decision making, executive function, motor control, emotion and motivation, and brain development. This is the second term of a double-credit core lecture course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: International Trade II
descrip: A continuation of ECO 551, with emphasis on current research issues. Topics vary from year to year.

title: Early Modern Japan
reviews: Great survey of early modern Japan!
I think that the coursework is incredibly interesting, as was the professor.

If you need to fulfill an HA or have any remote interest in history in general, definitely take this course. Professor Marcon is really funny but also very insightful. There is a decent amount of reading, but the other coursework is pretty light. This course really changed the way I look at the past and event he present. If you want to take a fun class and meet a really cool professor, don't hesitate to signup. This has been one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.
Take it if you like Asian history - it's a cool class and Marcon is a very nice teacher.
Take it if you're interested!
Take it!

Take this course if you have even a passing interest in Japanese history. No, it's not really about samurai duels or warring domains (that all happened before the events of this course), but I found the actual material was just as interesting. It definitely helps that Marcon is a fantastic lecturer and a genuinely funny guy. No Japanese required, but it certainly helped me remember some of the key terms.
The professor (Marcon) is awesome and so funny! Makes the class very fun and interesting.
This is a course you don't want to miss.
if you have  any interest in Japan then this is a great course to take
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the history and culture of Japan in the seventeenth through the late nineteenth centuries. This was the age of samurai rule, in which many elements of modern Japanese culture took familiar form. It was also the time when the roots of Japan's emergence as a modern state were laid.

title: Social Movements and Contentious Politics
descrip: Explores the study of social movements as well as other forms of unconventional collective action aimed at achieving or preventing social and political change (riots, demonstrations, strikes, terrorist movements, etc.). After examining various approaches to the field, we will investigate a number of issues of abiding concern within the field: repertoires, violence, repression, and the transnational dimensions of mobilization. Finally, we will turn to empirical applications, focusing in particular on the study of revolutions.

title: Introduction to Augustan Literature
reviews: Be ready to tackle some very long, often tedious assignments.

Good course to take for anyone who took Latin in high school at the AP level or equivalent. Nothing spectacular, pretty much a standard Latin course, but worth taking if you're interested in the material.

Great Latin course. Take it with Melissa Haynes, she really cares about her students and has a great talent for teaching seminar size courses. In terms of work, it is typically 100 - 150 lines a week of poetry (depending on the difficulty of the work) and    5-8 paragraphs a week for prose. Quizzes every week to keep you sharp. You'll leave with a comprehensive overview of some big names in the Augustan Age. Highly recommend it.

Haynes is extremely engaging, quick, and fun in class - she is an awesome professor. Plus, she picks the really interesting parts of each of the texts to read. Definitely take this class if you like Latin!
Take it
prereqs: LAT 108 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: A reading course in Augustan prose and poetry. The chief objectives are (1) to develop an ability to read and to appreciate Latin literature; (2) to become familiar with some of the literary themes of the age; and (3) to learn about the social and cultural world of Augustan Rome.

title: Special Topics in Performance Practice - Krzhizhanovsky and the Soviet Fantastic
reviews: I don't know if this class will ever be taught again, but if it, TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
Take it. It will give you a whole new perspective and you will have SO much fun
This is a neat course with two great profs. Take it if you're interested in theater, philosophy and Russia.
take
descrip: Sigizmund Krzhizhanovsky (1887-1950), a phantasmagorical prose-writer with active experience in theater (original plays and adaptations), went almost unpublished during his lifetime. His work began to appear and be translated only in the post-Communist era. This seminar-workshop investigates the theatrical potential of his prose against the cultural background of the Bolshevik 1920s and Stalinist 1930s. Participants will dramatize scenes from Krzhizhanovsky's stories.

title: Topics in Analysis - Topics in geometric nonlinear functional analysis
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor. Basic functional analysis, complex analysis, and measure theory.
descrip: This course covers selected sections from the book "Geometric Nonlinear Functional Analysis" of Benyamini and Lindenstrauss and quickly proceeds to further recent developments related to the topics of this book, including Lipschitz extensions and bi-Lipschitz embeddings. More advanced topics may include uniform homeomorphisms and Ribe's rigidity theorem, differential theorems,and Hilbert's fifth problem in infinite dimensions.

title: The Gothic Tradition
reviews: Absolutely.

I don't really know. If you are really interested in the gothic tradition to the point that you would consider your outlook on life to be somewhat gothic, you will probably get a lot from this course, otherwise, it might be difficult to prioritize in your course schedule.
Take the class if you're interested to read the books and discuss them!

This class is about the development of the Gothic mode from the 18th century into the present day. You will learn about not only literature, but also history and even architecture. Prof. Alliston is great in helping us draw connections across time periods and cultures.
descrip: The purpose of this course is to analyze and understand the cultural meanings of the Gothic mode through a study of its characteristic elements, its historical, aesthetic, and political origins in eighteenth-century English and German culture and thought, its development across Western national traditions, and its persistence in contemporary culture, including film, electronic media, clothing, social behavior, and belief systems, as well as literature. Films, artifacts, web sites and electronic publications will supplement readings.

title: Global History: The Modern Middle East
descrip: Although the Middle East is often seen as exceptional, it is part of our globe: through connections and in being part of worldwide processes. This seminar's double goal is to study the Middle East from this perspective, and thereby also to explore how the modern world emerged. We will use Irye, Osterhammel, and Rosenberg, ed., A History of the World, 2 vols., covering 1870 to the present, as the backbone of the course; and in parallel read case studies on the Middle East in the world, including global cultural patterns, social webs, economic ties, imperial action, state building and international system, and the spread of political ideas.

title: Civil Wars and Political Foundations in Early Modern French Literature and Philosophy
descrip: From 1550 to 1789, France faced a period of extreme civil unrest (the Wars of Religion, the assassination of a king, the Fronde, the Revolution) and concurrently witnessed the foundation of a powerful, yet often dysfunctional, modern centralized State. We will adopt a historical and sociopolitical contextualizing approach to question how experiences of civil unrest are addressed and echoed in a broad range of literary, philosophical and political texts (Montaigne, Hobbes, the Edit de Nantes, Corneille, Pascal, Rousseau). We will discuss the conceptions of the modern State and of civil society that have stemmed from these experiences.

title: Religion and Law
descrip: A critical examination of the relation between concepts of "religion" and "law," as they figure in the modern state. The course will survey theoretical tools for thinking about these issues and their historical development before applying them to case studies in Europe and the Middle East. With the benefit of these comparative studies, and a new historical and philosophical insights, we will then address religion, politics and law in contemporary America.

title: Natural Disasters
reviews: A good STL if you are very wary.
A great STL.
As long as you study the content at face value, you should be fine
Best STL out there.  Take this class, pay attention in lection, work hard in the labs.  You will have minimal work outside of the classroom (about an hour a week) and you will succeed.
Eh. Find something that takes less work and is more engaging.

For anyone broadly interested in earth science or questions of public policy, I think this course is a great fit. The instructors are well-aware of the student composition of their course, and will work with you according to your expressed level of interest. I would recommend this course to a student searching for an STL that is not too time-consuming, but still relevant and useful.
Go to lecture
Good way to fulfill STL.
Keep up with the readings and do your labs properly.
Only take if seriously interested in GEO!
Only take this course if you really love the topic or are desperate to fulfil the STL requirement.
Take it
Take it if you need a lab.
Take it if you need to get an STL out of the way.  It's not that hard and fairly interesting.
Take this class if you are not a science person.
Take this course, or you may be sorry.....
Take this course. Easy, didn't do the readings often and lab grades can really boost your grade if you're struggling in other areas.
This class is great!

This class seems like an acceptable, if not particularly exciting, STL. Though this is true, it is more boring than you would expect. Labs are dry, lectures are uninteresting and held bright and early three times a week, and exams are surprisingly challenging. Unless you are actually interested in the subject matter of this course, you are likely to be disappointed by it.
This course if great for an STL!  You will learn new things and the material covered is rather interesting and very relevant.
This course is best to PDF. Interesting and requires little math/science background.
This is a decent way to fill your STL, but be prepared for boring labs and lots of busywork.
Try to pay attention in lecture even though it's boring. A good way to fill the distribution requirement. Labs are easy and fairly fun. Okay to pdf.
Worst class ever taken. Do not take it, even if you intend to pdf it.
attend lecture
do the readings and go to lecture
go to class, attendance is part of participation
take this course!!!!
descrip: An introduction to natural (and some society-induced) hazards and the importance of public understanding of the issues related to them. Emphasis is on the geological processes that underlie the hazards, with discussion of relevant policy issues tied to reading recent newspaper/popular science articles. Principal topics: Earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunami, hurricanes, floods, meteorite impacts, global warming. Intended primarily for non-science majors.

title: Designing Sustainable Systems - Applying the Science of Sustainability to Address Global Change
reviews: A pretty easy but interesting class to STN. Really ended up liking the group assignments by the end of the course because I got to learn a lot from my group-mates! Also loved having the guest lecturers come in.
Don't be afraid to go to office hours, they are very helpful

Forrest is an awesome person and this class continually kept me engaged; the first half is very different from the second half of the semester; be prepared to do some work (albeit easy work); this is the best choice for an STL
Good STN course. Prof. Meggers and the TAs are very nice and helpful. I hope that the assignments are not group assignments because there are many free riders who do not contribute.
I would recommend it for a STN that you want to PDF. was very easy PDF class. Lots of group projects if you're into that.

I would take it if you're interested in sustainability and thinking about energy, water, food, etc in terms of systems. It is a little disorganized and you have to be proactive if you want to learn a lot.

If you have taken multiple environmental studies classes, this class may be a bit repetitive with respect to the content. I would have rather done/learned more hands-on tools and skills like the name of this class would suggest.
It looked interesting, pretty good class overall
Not easy if you don't have any interest in design (I didn't), but a really engaging course. Meggers is great and so helpful.
Really interesting class. Really glad I took it. Will likely be better because it's a new class and they're figuring out how best to structure the class.
Take it to learn something new!
Take this course as a distribution, but there are probably other more engaging and better-structured courses to take.

This course is an STN, but Forrest still wants there to be a design component, which is difficult since many people have no design experience or time to spend outside of class learning those skills. BUT it's also super easy, especially if you're PDF-ing and in general you don't stress about the relative lack of organization or clarity on assignments.
Very disorganized and frustrating class, but not that hard.
definitely take the course.
not that hard of a course, but choose your group wisely if you can, it will make a big difference because about half or more of your grade is based on the final project.
descrip: The course presents anthropogenic global changes and their impact on sustainable design. The course focuses on the mechanistic understanding of the underlying principles based in simple concepts from natural and applied sciences. Based on a reflection of successes and failures, it indicates the feasibility of the necessary changes and critically discusses alternatives. The material is presented in 2 parts: 1) Global Change and Environmental Impacts: studying our influences on basic natural systems and cycles, and 2) Designing Sustainable Systems: studying potential solutions to these challenges through an applied design project.

title: Economics of Health in Developing Countries
descrip: Examines health care policy formulation focusing on developing countries. Theory and practical lessons on how policy is, or isn't, translated into programs. Global epidemiological threats to the infrastructure and financial stability of health care systems will be studied, in addition to: 1) how alternative health care finance and reform strategies facilitate or create barriers to achieving policy objectives; and 2) explores the role of governments, WHO, NGOs, and donor agencies in setting the agenda for health policy.

title: Reason and Religion
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Growth, International Finance & Crises
descrip: This is a macro, international finance-oriented development course, which will focus on the political economy of policy decisions. It will cover the following themes: 1. GDP growth and volatility; 2. the size, composition, and influence of international capital flows; 3. sudden stops in capital flows and financial crises; 4. the domestic and multilateral response to crises, including the role of fiscal adjustment, external financing, and debt restructuring; 5. We will draw on several country case-studies and students will be encouraged to undertake short research assignments to deepen their own policy interests.

title: Combustion
descrip: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, oxidation of hydrogen, hydrocarbons and alternate fuels, pollutant chemistry and control, transport phenomena, laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames, turbulent flames, ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena, flame stabilization and blowoff, detonation and blast waves, droplet, spray and coal particle combustion, principles of engine operation.

title: Computer Music: Compositional Applications
descrip: Electronic Instrument Design: This course will explore the issues and challenges of designing instruments for live electronic music performance. Participants will also be working on developing their own instrument for live performance.

title: Advanced Economic Theory II
reviews: Recommended if interested in the topics.
descrip: Topics vary from year to year. See 511.

title: Milton
reviews: Be prepared to work hard and do all the readings, and make sure you go to office hours - Professor Smith is very willing to help students, and helps you a lot with the papers and understanding the class.
Do the readings and go to office hours if you have questions! It's interesting if you do the work.
If you have an interest in literature and theology, take this course.
Paradise Lost is epic.
Take the course for Milton! Make sure to visit instructors during their office hours.
do the readings. really engage with the text, because it's worthwhile to do so.
descrip: We will explore John Milton's entire career, largely as poet, but also as prose writer and thinker: a lifelong effort to unite the aims of intellectual, political and literary experimentation. In doing so Milton made himself the most influential non-dramatic poet in the English language. We will spend much time with Paradise Lost, regarded by many as the greatest non-dramatic poem in English or any modern language; we will encounter Milton's profound, extensive learning and his startling innovations with words, and in ideas of personal, domestic and communal liberty.

title: Econometric Theory II
reviews: Enjoy these lecturers!
Make sure to do all the problem sets.
Work hard during Professor Watson's half! I wish I would have worked harder!
descrip: This course begins with extensions of the linear model in several directions: (1) pre-determined but not exogenous regressors; (2) heteroskedasticity and serial correlation; (3) classical GLS; (4) instrumental variables and generalized method of movements estimators. Applications include simultaneous equation models, VARS and panel data. Estimation and inference in non-linear models are discussed. Applications include nonlinear least squares, discrete dependent variables (probit, logit, etc.), problems of censoring, truncation and sample selection, and models for duration data.

title: Medical Spanish
reviews: Awesome course and incredibly useful!

I definitely recommend this course!  Everyone in the class was interested in medicine (mostly planning to go to medical school) and had various levels of Spanish.  The emphasis is on helping students gain the ability to talk to patients and discuss medical issues in Spanish, regardless of overall fluency.  Of course, all of the practice helps with grammar and speaking ability as well.  Professor Moscardo is a wonderful professor!  She keeps everything organized but also makes the class really fun.
I highly recommend using Word Reference and linguee.com for the written assignments. Give yourself enough time to study for the quizzes. And don't be shy; participate as much as you can.
If you are thinking of going into medicine, you should definitely take this course! It will definitely help you improve your Spanish and learn how to speak Spanish in a medical setting.
If you're interested in medicine and Spanish, this is a great course for you!
TAKE THIS CLASS
Take it! As as premed student who could take a 200-level Spanish course, this course was amazing in teaching me both medicine and Spanish. Paloma is also an amazing professor too! You'll love her.
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission) or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP 5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: An advanced level Spanish course on health and medical topics. Its main purpose is to provide the students with vocabulary and linguistic skills to discuss medical issues, and to prepare them to interact with Spanish speakers in a healthcare environment in the U.S. or Latin America. The course is focused on both oral and written skills. It will also explore some aspects of the Spanish-speaking culture in the fields of health and medicine through authentic documents, visits to clinics and health fairs, and contributions of guest speakers.

title: Documentary Filmmaking
reviews: If you're interested in learning about filmmaking and have no prior experience, this is a great class to take.
It is an awesome class.
Su is pretty mean, but it's kinda tough love. kinda.
Take Su's advice, and talk to her outside of class! She's brilliant--a gifted filmmaker and also a source of wise editing advice.
You'll find this course interesting even if you don't think you're interested in documentary.
descrip: This course introduces students to documentary film production using digital video, with an emphasis on the practical challenges of working in the real world. While students learn the traditional methods of production, they are also encouraged to range widely in their thinking about how to document daily life. Production of videos will be augmented by screenings, readings, and visiting filmmakers.

title: Leadership Development for Business
reviews: ABSOLUTE MUST TAKE! You will learn what awaits you in industry and how you can modify your behavior to tackle all kinds of situations and maybe even be a better leader. Many people might say some of the things covered in this class are 'common sense' and obvious. These people have probably not had internships where they have to deal with politics and fractious personalities. I have not taken a class at Princeton that has helped me understand my own self (and other people) as much as this class has.

Be genuinely engaged with his ideas if you want to make the most of this course. It is a privilege to be taught by someone as successful, insightful, and moral as Denny so make the most of that opportunity!
DEFINITELY TAKE IT

Definitely take the course if you will be working in the real world in ANY way. It was great to have real world examples provided by the former CEO of Verizon - definitely a once in a lifetime experience.
Definitely take this course! Such a nice change from other academic courses and the leadership lessons you learn can be applied to any context.
Denny Strigl's stories and guest speakers were highlights of this class and really made it wonderful.
It's very easy but don't get lazy or you will get nothing out of a course that has a lot to offer.

Really interesting if you like learning about why some businesses fail and others succeed - and how it relates to their leadership team. professor Strigl is great. Would definitely take it while its still around.

Recommend if you?re interested in learning about business leadership (well yes, as the name suggests...), but also if you?d like to hear from Denny Strigl and the guest speakers that he invites. Consider if you haven?t taken a Keller Center class before!
Speak up in class
TAKE IT.

Take this course - you'll find yourself making comparisons to your own team-dynamic interactions, whether through organizations, clubs, jobs, or team sports. You will also have reinforced and refined the values that underly your own decision-making ability.

Take this course! Especially if you are a senior: The readings are really interesting and really help you transition to thinking about professional life after Princeton. One of the best classes I've taken.
The class is engaging and interesting, and not very difficult. At the same time, some of the ideas presented feel a little simplistic.
The most practical course at Princeton. Has real world application
This is a good course to transition you from the academic focus of college to the business/ngo/political focus of post-college life (if that's what you're going into).

While the course is advertised as a means by which to become a better employee (and even a leader), Professor Strigl will actually teach you invaluable lessons which will help you to become a better person and live a more fruitful life. His mantras (e.g., 9 reasons why leaders fail, shadow of the leader, true to yourself) will really heighten your introspection. Taking a yearly inventory on your life (as shown by Coach K) is of high value.
great class very applicable to general life
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The Leadership Development for Business course deals with the strategic, organizational and leadership challenges that global corporations face. The course provides students with a unique perspective on leadership vision, and how leaders recognize and capitalize on opportunities. We will focus on how leaders achieve results and make things happen working with and through others. This course presents innovative, practical and field tested methods used by successful business leaders to achieve sustained results. Classes will consist of a mix of classroom lecture, case study discussions and guest speakers.

title: The Philosophy of Plato - The Relation Between Virtue and Knowledge
descrip: This is a seminar on the relation between virtue and knowledge in the Platonic dialogues. It will focus on Protagoras, Republic and Theaetetus, but with some reference also to Euthydemus, Sophist and Philebus.

title: Macroeconomics: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: A fairly straightforward course, but it is much more math-oriented than 310 (in my experience). I found 310 fairly easy, but 311 was, for me, rather more difficult.

AVOID THIS CLASS LIKE THE PLAGUE. ECO310 is "recommended"? That's an absolute lie, take it prior to this class or else be prepared to be thoroughly destroyed. I took it concurrently, and trust me you'll still be at a significant disadvantage compared to everyone else. Professor refuses to deal with psets during office hours, so pray that you won't have class during the preceptors' office hours (there are only two of them too, so I hope your schedule's really flexible because their office hours sure aren't). Take it only if you want to learn the true meaning of apathy. Psets take forever, lots of MAT majors wrecking the curve, honestly just not worth the pain and trouble.
Be sure to take advantage of office hours.

Class is like 50% A's, according to Moll, so you don't have too much to lose. 

Macro is like comparative religion - you get a bunch of models that each make a bunch of assumptions, but at the end of the day, the lessons you learn from each are the same. So everything is just memorizing assumptions and then a bunch of algebra. Not too difficult at all.
Don't be afraid to take this class if you're majoring in economics, even if you didn't love 310. The math is cool and the curve is pretty good.
Get prepare for a challenging course. Do all the readings on time. Professor Moll does not insist on them, but they are important for the tests. Take ECO 301 if you want to enjoy the class more.
Hard class, but very rewarding. Make sure to take it with Ben.
I would recommend this class to students who grasp concepts quickly and want to understand macroeconomics on a more theoretical level.
If Moll is teaching, this course will be hard, but it will be decently interesting and you will get more out of it than you would if you took ECO 301
If you have to take this class, it's not the worst class to have to take. If not, only take it if you have a strong interest in the subject matter.
It is an interesting course, especially if you need it for Econ.
It was alright. I didn't like it as much as 310. Ben Moller is a great prof if you're gonna take it, it is hard though make sure you understand the underlying math of every model

Justin put it best. This class is here so that we can figure out the math behind models, and realize that they can tell different stories due to different assumptions and mechanisms. At first I hated the "pointless" algebra to figure out basic intuitions about macro econ, but Justin's advice that now we never have to go through circular reasoning (this leads to this, which leads to this, etc etc) is pretty cool. And this is coming from someone who hates math and  is probably going to do pretty poorly in this class.
Know going in that this course will be challenging and definitely more quantitative than 301. However, I felt that I was challenged (but not so much so that I was discouraged) and learned a lot.
Many ugly equations which yield even uglier ones as results...
Not much you can do to prepare for exams/problem sets. Not miserable but not a fantastic class.
Only take it if you have to...take ECO 310 instead if you aren't an econ major and are still interested in the subject.
Only take this class if you have to obviously. Very difficult.

Professor Moll is a great person and his lectures are extremely engaging, and he brings current issues (Piketty and income distribution this year) right into our problem sets and exams at a level where we can manage it.
Take this if you don't mind doing a lot of algebra and multivariable calc or if you're interested in models and theories; if not, 301 might be a better fit.
The class was a good introduction to macroeconomic models but too often the course material devolved into tedious algebraic manipulations. Moll is a great guy and his lecture notes are great.
The midterm grades were sticky but the professor implemented an expansionary grade policy in the final.
This course is very difficult, but try it. Take with some friends.

This is a math class. Every lecture is entirely about manipulating equations and it's easy not to think about the Econ. These equations can also be very complicated, but you are still just generally doing optimization and taking derivatives like most Econ math- definitely much different from GDP formulas in intro level. This class is essential to prepare for Econ grad school or if you just really like math. But otherwise, I actually think I could have (just speculation, since I didn't take 301) learned more Econ and been better able to defend macroeconomic opinions in english rather than math better if I had taken 301. Overall, this class is probably just not worth it unless you want to go to Econ grad school. Ben Moll is a great professor, though.
This is a very difficult course so go to lecture and precept. Don't let yourself fall behind because all the topics build on each other and you will feel like you have no idea whats going on
Yes, take it if you feel smart
You should take this course if you're committed to learning macro, but it's unfortunately nowhere near perfect. But it's essential if you're doing macro.

You will learn various macroeconomic models that are popular or historically important. Solow, neoclassical growth, new Keynesian, etc. The work is mostly lots of algebra. You read some economics papers which can be interesting. Not sure this would be of much practical use, but good to get a sense of what economists work on, and if you're interested in economics research.
dont major in econ
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 and MAT 200 or MAT 201..
descrip: This course examines the determinants of long-run economic growth, short-run business cycle fluctuations, and the conduct of monetary and fiscal policy. The first part of the course develops a framework for the analysis of households' consumption and savings behavior and firms' production decisions, and uses that to analyze long-run growth and financial crises. The second part of the course extends that analysis to examine business cycle fluctuations, including inflation, unemployment. Current issues in macroeconomic and financial policy are discussed throughout.

title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
reviews: Attend precept and do the readings.
Definitely take the class!  It's not overly demanding, and the material is interesting.
Definitely worthwhile, but if you're genuinely interested in linguistics, take it seriously and put more than the bare minimum time into it
Do many practice problems!
Easy fifth class, but expect to be a bit unfulfilled after taking it, especially if you want a deep introduction to linguistics. Good survey course though.
Go to lectures and read the textbook!
Great course. Linguistics is a very cool field.
I strongly recommend this course- the material is very interesting and concepts are novel. It is well taught.
I would only take this course if you have interest in linguistics or you really need the distribution req.
If you don't have a particular interest in the subject matter, It's a fairly interesting and easy EC. And if you do have an interest, you'll probably enjoy the course immensely.
It is a great class! Do no hesitate to take it!!
It's ok
Keep and open mind and be prepared to explore an academic area you may have never even known existed!
Make sure you want to learn about speech.

Ozge and Cory were excellent instructors who really cared about the material and their students. I don't think they'll be here next semester, but learning about linguistics was quite engaging and the course was an easy EC. Definitely take!
PDF this course. That way you do not have to worry about grades (the lack of a transparent grading system causes this worry to detract from learning).

Possibly the easiest EC you'll ever find. Definitely the easiest class I've had at Princeton. Take it if you really can't find an EC you're interested in, just don't expect the material to be fascinating.
Read the textbook and go to lecture.
Study hard for the exams. because those are the only ones you'll be able to take.
Take a different EC. This one is poorly taught and frustrating.
Take it before leaving this school!!
Take it if Ozturk teaches,
Take it if you're looking for an easy EC. The material is pretty interesting too.
Take it with Fellbaum; I hear she's great.
Take it!
Take it.
Take the course!  Really fun :)
Take this if you want an easy EC, just pay attention in lecture/precept and you will do well

The class was too easy and taught too much stuff that was common sense. (I wanted to learn more about syntax and semantics!) This class had three midterms and dropped the lowest out of three. I didn't go to any precepts and studied for 1.5 hours before the second one, and still got an A. I don't recommend taking this with Prof. Ozturk and Cory; I didn't learn much. (Sorry!)
The lectures are interesting

The subject matter is really interesting and it is not an especially difficult course. If you put in the work, your grade should reflect it. I read the textbook because I was interested in the material but you can get away with just attending the lectures and precepts and you should be fine.
These evaluations probably don't matter because new prof will be teaching next year
This class was very easy.
This course is a great way to get an EC. It's interesting and not too difficult.
This is an easy EC that requires little to no effort.
This is fantastic and relaxed course. If you want an interesting class with little work, take this.

This is one of those rare classes that are both very easy and very interesting. You learn a lot in lectures, but there is very little work required outside of class. It tends to be a favorite of COS majors for some reason. #enjoy

This semester, this was a light course on a fairly interesting topic, expanding (lightly) on how to think about language and how we use it. Prof. Ozturk is a visiting professor, though, so I can't say for future semesters.
You don't have to work too hard and can easily get something out of this class. It was very interesting and I highly recommend it if Ozge is the professor.
none
descrip: An introduction to the scientific analysis of the structure and uses of language. Core areas covered include phonetics and phonology, morphology, the lexicon, syntax, semantics and pragmatics, with data from a wide range of languages. Topics include the biological basis of language, language and cognition, the neurology of language and language disorders, and first and second language acquisition.

title: Theory of Algorithms
reviews: An excellent foundational course in algorithmic design and analysis taught by a major contributor of the field. Applicable in many fields beyond computer theory.
Better than the alternatives as far as theory courses in the COS department go.
Cool follow up to 340, great staff this semester. Tarjan was very nice in office hours and TA's were helpful as well.
Don't take

Good.  Not a huge time commitment, only 6 problem sets and no exams.  You survey different classic algorithms and generally learn a lot by working on the problem sets in your group.  However, the problem sets are essentially graded so that each problem is all credit or none of it.  This means the median is around 100 for all the problem sets and you just have to be careful not to mess up.

I struggled mightily in COS 340. I put in adequate work for this course and am headed for my best grade at Princeton. It is very difficult to objectively judge the difficulty of this course based on what others say; it also doesn't help that the material is not consistent from semester to semester

If you are considering taking this course, it's most likely because you are a COS major that needs a 2nd theory requirement.  I found this class to be a lot less time consuming than COS 340.  Problem sets were due every other week instead of every week and they were about the same length as the COS 340 ones.  There are a few psets that are no collaboration but they are easier than the rest. The final problem set (more of a take-home exam) is no collaboration and takes a lot of time to complete. Like 340, only 3 to a group were allowed.  This was one of my 5 classes this semester, and it was very doable.  Don't wait till senior year (when you're lazy) to take this class.
If you have the opportunity to learn from Bob Tarjan don't pass it up.
It's not too difficult as compared to the other computer science theory courses and the problem set problems are occasionally pretty interesting!
Lectures are super boring but the problem sets are interesting. It's harder than 340 but not as much as people say. Definitely doable and it's nice because the problem sets aren't very often.

Many people say that they learn from the problem sets. This is true - but because they require you to reexamine the lecture slides. Many people say that Professor Tarjan is not the best lecturer, but I think it's more because the material he is teaching is complex - he will really try to help you understand it. Coming in, I did not feel very comfortable with the class after COS 340; however, I feel like I really learned a lot and that this was a valuable experience. The problem sets are also really nice because we were given more than a week to complete them, which actually gave enough time to really think about the problems and come up with solutions. If you need another theory course, I would recommend this - the material I learned probably will be useful later on, particularly some of the algorithm design tricks.
Not too much work. Not too hard. Relatively manageable compared to other COS classes for someone like me who's not that cos-oriented
Ok for a theory requirement
Problem sets can be hard. Lectures can be disorienting. Prepare yourself. But ultimately one enjoys the class.
Take it if you need a Cos Theory class without too much work. Otherwise, avoid.
Take it if you're interested! It's a variety of topics, and not overly stressful.
Take the class with Professor Tarjan, and go to office hours whenever possible.  Pick a good group for the group Psets.
Take this class! The material is fascinating, and Professor Tarjan is a great lecturer if you pay attention! Also, read through the slides before lecture.

This class is an easier version of 340, with slightly different material. There are fewer problem sets, and the grading isn't quite as strict. At the same time, I felt the lectures weren't quite as strong. But, if you need another theory, don't be put if off by it. After 340, it will seem like a cake-walk in some ways.
This course is very heavy with graph problems. Be prepared if your intuition isn't used to thinking about graphs---the problem sets might take a while.
This is a challenging, but very rewarding class! If you're interested in theoretical computer science, definitely take it!
it's hard. time consuming. lecture/book are not really necessary. a lot of it is googling about related papers online.
take this not for the lectured material but rather to ask tarjan questions
prereqs: COS 226 and 340, or permission of instructor.
descrip: Design and analysis of efficient data structures and algorithms. General techniques for building and analyzing algorithms. Introduction to NP-completeness.

title: International News - Local Impact, Global Reach
reviews: Even if you've never thought of being a journalist, you should take a JRN class. We surround ourselves with media and depend on what other people say and write to find out what's going on in the world. Do yourselves a favor and take a JRN class here at Princeton. I still don't think I'll be a journalist, but I know that my career and daily interactions will benefit from what I learned in this class.

It's a shame that she's a visiting professor because I think as many students as possible should talk to Professor Thrupkaew. She invested in us and our success, and for that, I will always be grateful.

It's different each year because of different professors. But probably always good! Be prepared to do journalism - it's different to other classes (you have to actually talk to people in the real world which is scary!)
TAKE IT this is the best class I've taken so far!
This is a very thorough journey into the world of international-focus investigative journalism. Take if you have an interest in global issues, journalism, or simply becoming a more critical thinker.
prereqs: Enrollment by application. See http://humanities.princeton.edu/journalism/courses..
descrip: Through writing local stories with international implications - pieces about national-security policy, human trafficking, and migration and economic inequality - students will hone the immersive reporting skills and the big-picture mindset crucial to foreign correspondence and to critical thinking outside of journalism. They will learn to bulletproof their pieces through documentation, cultivate sources, consider ethical and security issues, conduct effective and sensitive interviews, and structure compelling stories that reveal how ostensibly far-off conflicts are manifested in local contexts.

title: Diffuse Matter in Space
reviews: Go to lecture, read the book, profit.

Make sure to do the readings ahead of time, even if you don't understand much of what you're reading; it will greatly increase your comprehension of the lecture, having once already seen the material.
Reading the text book before/after class is good way to understand more.
What you get out of lectures really depends on reading on your own and asking questions.
descrip: Subject of course is the astrophysics of the interstellar medium: theory and observations of the gas, dust, plasma, energetic particles, magnetic field, and electromagnetic radiation in interstellar space. Emphasis will be on theory, including elements of: fluid dynamics; excitation of atoms, molecules and ions; radiative processes; radiative transfer; simple interstellar chemistry; and physical properties of dust grains.The theory will be applied to phenomena including; interstellar clouds (both diffuse atomic clouds and dense molecular clouds); HII regions; shock waves; supernova remnants; cosmic rays; interstellar dust; and star formation.

title: Fourteenth Amendment, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Do a project that really interests you; you're stuck with it for the entire semester.
Take it but make sure you are motivated to go through with it
prereqs: EGR 250.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Foreign Aid Policy: Design, Programming & Implementation
descrip: This class examines foreign aid policy from a practitioner's perspective, it examines the 'nuts and bolts' of foreign aid, including: What is the aid 'architecture'? How are aid priorities established, how is aid structured? How are programs designed and implemented? What is the relationship between donors and recipients? What are some of the 'big ideas' shaping the aid community? Students will gain a deeper understanding of how the aid community works and learn to think critically about which forms of assistance are appropriate given country constraints and opportunities.

title: Emerging Micro and Nano-Engineered Technologies
descrip: See website

title: Homer
reviews: If you can make it through CLG 105, you can thrive here.  Plus it's more fun.
If you like Greek, take it. Homer is very different than Plato, and in my experience far more enjoyable.

If you've enjoyed Greek so far, take this course without a doubt. Your Greek will improve significantly, and reading Homer is wonderful. Something that may be useful to know is that compared to Plato, Homer's syntax is easier, but there is more vocab to know plus Homeric forms to recognize and keep track of.
Take it.
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: An initiation into Homeric poetry, this course is intended to provide students with fluency in the language, meter and cultural sensibility of Greek epic. We will read significant excerpts of the Iliad and Odyssey, as well as seminal scholarship and essays about the nature of Homeric epic.

title: Colonialism, Post-Colonialism and Islam: North Africa (1830-2011)
reviews: Do all the readings and think critically about them and pose difficult questions in class.
If you are interested in government, development, or political violent in northern Africa I highly recommend this course.
Take it if you're interested in North African history and colonialism - and if you enjoy small class settings
Take this if you're interested in North African history, post-colonialism, the colonial period, etc.
descrip: This course explores the history of North Africa, an area undergoing radical political turmoil since the beginning of the Arab spring in January 2011. It analyzes the colonial and postcolonial transformations of the Maghrib from the 19th to the first decade of the 21st century. Through a range of secondary and primary sources, the purpose of the course is to give an overview of the colonial effects and legacies on and in North African societies, but also to start questioning the colonial period as a framework of analysis.

title: Creating Collaborative Theater
reviews: Take it. It is so liberating just getting to experiment and take acting risks (at times it feels unfair--it's so fun that it seems like you're just goofing around). Easily one of the most enjoyable classes in my time at Princeton.
Take this class!

This is a really fascinating and once-in-a-lifetime kind of class. If you're at all interested in the theatre industry, even if you don't think you'll do it after college, play around with Aaron and your classmates. You'll come up with something really cool that you couldn't have made alone, and the class is basically a stress-reliever. And if you do think you'll do theatre after college, it's basically imperative that you take this.
descrip: How are directors and actors the co-authors of a live performance, and how can anyone contribute text to a work that seeks its own unified vision? How can design play as integral a role as text? This class is open to people who are seasoned performers, writers, directors, composers, filmmakers and designers, as well as those who appreciate a good risk and are willing to take one now. Over the semester, we will work together to make something new, look at examples from theater and other disciplines of real collaborations and partnerships, and present in-progress what we have at the end of the semester.

title: Special Studies in Modernism - The Avant-Garde
descrip: This course examines the major avant-garde movements of the first half of the 20th century--Futurism, Dadaism, Surrealism, Constructivism, etc.--as well as proto avant-garde movements. The seminar's methodology will be comparative and transnational, bringing together texts and artworks from a range of linguistic and national contexts. The seminar will also have a strong theoretical component and will integrate and evaluate theories of the avant-garde.

title: Atmospheric and Oceanic Wave Dynamics
reviews: Even (or especially) if GFD I felt hard, GFD II by Sonya is a good way to consolidate your GFD knowledge.
Great class
Take it! Expect a very clear and helpful presentation.
Very useful course, please take it!
descrip: Observational evidence of atmospheric and oceanic waves; laboratory simulation. Surface and internal gravity waves; dispersion characteristics; kinetic energy spectrum; critical layer; forced resonance; instabilities. Planetary waves: scale analysis; physical description of planetary wave propagation; reflections; normal modes in a closed basin. Large-scale barclinic and barotropic instabilities. Eady and Charney models for barclinic instability, and energy transfer.

title: Selected Topics in Condensed Matter Theory - Topological Matter
reviews: An awesome physics departmental. Lectures are very clear and insightful. Andrei is the man. Very little workload, and the material is interesting.
Bernevig has an aggressive lecturing style.  Be prepared for that.

Excellent course which gives you the possibility of further doing research in the field. Prof. Bernevig was great. He is extremely funny and engaging and manages to make quite difficult concepts easily understandable.
I'd take it!
Interesting

Very interesting class on a cool area of research. Material is great and Bernevig is a good lecturer, if a bit fast. However, make sure that there will be problem sets. We didn't have enough students for the class to be assigned a TA, so we had very few problem sets, which made retaining the material difficult.
You learn cool stuff you won't see in any course, but there was hardly any homework and no tests so I didn't learn much outside of lecture
prereqs: PHY 208, PHY 301 and PHY 305.
descrip: This course serves as an introduction to the rapidly growing field of topological insulators and superconductors. The course will present old topics such as band theory, insulators, metals, ferromagnets, superconductors, but emphasis will be on the new topological phenomena that these systems are now known to harbor. Many experts in this field are home-grown on Princeton soil, and this course provides a unique opportunity for students to interact with them. There are ample opportunities for research in both theory and experiments.

title: Seminar in Music Composition
descrip: A workshop environment for composers to share their creative work with one another. All collaborate in shaping the discussion so as to cultivate an open and fruitful exchange of ideas. To open the door to a discussion, we'll touch on "individuation and association," exploring compositional idiosyncrasies alongside resonances with established conventions and familiar discourse(s). This is not an inventory of influences so much as an exploration of the ways we simultaneously form and are formed by musical experience and how our awareness of being "planted" or not, may inform our work.

title: Moroccan Colloquial Arabic
prereqs: Prerequisite: successful completion of ARA 107 or the permission of the department..
descrip: This course will develop students' skills in Moroccan Colloquial Arabic (darija), with an eye to future study in Morocco. In addition to the textbook, students will encounter the language through a variety of contemporary media forms such novellas and telenovelas, ads, music videos, comics and blogs. Topics covered in the course will range from perspectives on personal matters to views on socio-cultural issues. While the main objective will be communicative, emphasis will also be placed on pronunciation and advanced grammatical structures that have been preserved in the Moroccan dialect.

title: Forms of Literature - Literature and War
reviews: Do your readings
Don't come in with pre-conceived notions about war lit
Great class. Do the work. Be honest with Professor Martin.
I recommend this course to students interested in literature and war.

The topic is really interesting and I learned a lot about WWI and contemporary conflicts. There was also a lot of interesting literature and some really cool visitors. However, it was mostly about the soldier experience rather than about the war/about "the other side" experience, but I think that might change in the future. Would recommend.

This course is a lot of work reading wise, but it is so worth taking. The subject matter is incredibly interesting and Prof. Martin is a great teacher. Opened my eyes about a lot of things related to war and its representation in literature.

This is a great course, and Professor Martin is an amazingly kind, approachable professor. She really listens to the students and responds to our feedback. For instance, a lot of reviews of the first version of the class complained about reading load, so she worked really hard to cut down a huge amount of readings. She's also really flexible and will make sure that deadlines fit well with students' schedules, and she's very easy to talk to during office hours. This was the first literature course I have ever taken here (I'm a WWS major), but I never felt out of place or overwhelmed. The readings and movies are all really great, the course is well-organized, and the discussions really get you to engage with the material in creative, interesting ways. Take this course! Even if you're not an English major, it's definitely worth your time.
descrip: How is The Iliad related to "The Hurt Locker"? What does "The Charge of the Light Brigade" have to do with an online combat blog? This course will explore the desire and failure to record the experience of war. What can the techniques, tropes, and tragedies to which we have become accustomed teach us about the way war is represented in literature and film? We'll read poetry, novels, memoirs, comics, blogs, and watch documentaries and films about both the First World War and the contemporary conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan to think about media, representation, and the literature of conflict then and now.

title: Advanced Heat and Mass Transfer
reviews: Don't take it if you can avoid it.

I would recommend this course to other students interested in extending their knowledge about transport phenomena. I found the instructor to be interesting and informative, however I do feel that at times the topics were rushed through at the determent of understanding.
Maybe get a second textbook to accompany Deen in lieu of an instructor. Don't ask questions because they won't get answered anyways.
Read books other than Deen because Deen will be covered thoroughly in class. Read the papers
descrip: A survey of modeling and solutions methods for processes involving heat and mass transfer. Topics will include convective and diffusive transport, conservation equations, scaling principles and approximation techniques, forced convection, multi-component energy and mass transfer as well as buoyancy and turbulent driven transport.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students & post-docs.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: A great introduction to Asia and investing. Professor de Swaan also really cares about teaching and about the students.
Good if you want to know what is happening in asian financial markets, but you should be well versed in technical finance terms.
If you don't like participating in class, don't take it, that's the point of this. If you do or even if its not your thing but don't mind, take it
If you have any sort of interest in economics, take this course.
If you're not into finance, you'll have to suffer classmates very much of the finance stereotype competing for participation points, but de Swaan makes the class very accessible by avoiding jargon.
One of my best econ classes ever at Princeton, hands down
Take it if you are passionate about Asia or markets. Good PDF. Hard to thrive if you do not know a lot about rates, currency, capital markets, etc.
Take it! It's a bit intimidating with how many students have done finance internships or jobs, so they can more easily understand the more jargon-heavy lectures and in-class discussions.

You MUST take this class. Swaan is such a gift to Princeton, and it has been such a privilege taking his class. Just by listening to him speak I have learned more about economics and finance (and the world) than from the three core economics classes COMBINED. I am so shocked, thankful, and humbled that someone like Swaan would voluntarily spend time out of his life, ride the terrible NJT multiple times a week to speak to students like us. I have so much respect for this man I can't even put it in words. He is funny and caring too -- a genuine person of deep, deep quality. Swaan's class has been the most important academic experience of my Princeton career so far and I wish I could become half the man he is.

This class is difficult to do well in. The best of the best in Econ, ORFE, and M. Fin all take this class because it is amazing. Don't let it deter you. The things you learn from Swaan is worth more than any grade. I've said this to multiple people and I truly mean it: if I were guaranteed a C in the class no pdf, I would still take it.  Swaan is a gift from the gods. Take this class.
do the readings
prereqs: For those who are unable to register because the course is full, please contact Professor De Swaan directly (jdeswaan@princeton.edu). Juniors need special permission from instructor to enroll..
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course explicitly considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system and its implications, as well as the potential revival of Japanese capital markets.

title: An Introduction to Engineering
reviews: Can be helpful to find out about the department, it is not very time consuming and is interesting.
Do not take this class if you're looking for an easy class. It is easy, super easy, it has no work. But you're just wasting your time.
Do not take this course unless you have absolutely no idea what engineering is.
Hardly any work except in the very beginning, good lectures and labs half the time (if not the other half). Great fifth class.
If you are still deciding which engineering department you want to join, this course might help you!
It's a good class for indecisive people. The workload is light, the labs are fun, and Prucnal is an excellent speaker.

Take it you have no experience in engineering disciplines that you would be interested in. There was rarely any coverage of ORFE, and CEE had second least coverage (about 3-4 classes, no labs). Worthwhile if you are still finding your engineering path. Do not take if you want to get ahead in tech classes.
Take the course. Is manageable as a fifth course and can help if one is on the fence about what engineering major to take.
Useful and easy fifth class that doesn't satisfy any requirements but presents a very chill introduction to the BSE departments.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the various disciplines of engineering. It is a project-based sequence (Energy Conversion and the Environment, Robotic Remote Sensing, and Wireless Image & Video Transmission) that covers engineering disciplines and their relationship to the principles of physics and mathematics.

title: Geometry and Architectural Representation
reviews: I would definitely recommend this course.  It is very interesting, and it gives you an insight into the worlds of architecture and drawing that you don't get anywhere else.  The workload really depends on you and how much work you are willing to do for it.

I would say that this course is perfect for a student interested in architecture who has no prior experience with the subject. A student who has done previous architectural work may find this class unnecessary.
It's a lot of work.  But if you are willing to put in the time and you like to draw and design, it's a great course, especially if you are interested in an architecture major.
Start the projects early. You're going to have to do each project multiple times most likely, so don't stress if it doesn't come out right the first time. Have fun with each project.
Take it!
Take this before ARC204 and be prepared to learn Rhino on your own; Michael is a really cool dude though
Take this course if you are interested in learning about Architecture!
prereqs: This course is designed primarily for freshman and sophomores who are interested in gaining introductory experience in design and drawing. This course will help prepare students for ARC 204 and upper-level studios..
descrip: This course sets out two goals: the first is to understand the theories and techniques of geometry in architectural representation; the second is to develop the student's drawing sensibilities through 5 thematic drawing projects engaging both digital and manual techniques. Each new theme will be introduced through a lecture, tutorial, and discussion including a number of specific readings related to the topic at hand. The second class will be an individual desk crit to discuss the development of each drawing project. The third class will consist of a group pin-up review of each drawing experiment.

title: Seminar in Musicology - The Pluralities of Modernism: Vienna 1890-1920
descrip: Examines currents of musical modernism in Vienna, including those outside the traditional canon of the "Second Viennese School". Course surveys the broad spectrum of musical innovations and analyzes their relationship to important challenges of modernity, including revolutions in recording, film, and communications technology, new conceptions of time, rising ethnic and religious tensions, and gender and sexual politics, and how these momentous transformations affected notions of form, phrase structure, orchestration, performance practice, and genre.

title: Molecular Basis of Cancer
descrip: We will explore the molecular events leading to the onset and progression of human cancer. We will review the central genetic and biochemical elements that make up the cell cycle, followed by a survey of the signal transduction pathways and checkpoints that regulate it. We will discuss oncogenes, tumor suppressor and mutator genes that act in these pathways and review the role of viral oncogenes and their action on cells. We will investigate the role of cancer stem cells and the interaction between tumor and the host environment. We will explore specific clinical case studies in light of the molecular events underlying different cancers.

title: Climate and the Terrestrial Biosphere
reviews: Attend the lectures and ask questions when you are confused about something. Stop by the office hours to get help on the problem sets because they can be time consuming. Having prior coding experience will make your life much easier, especially having a grasp of Matlab.
If you are intrested in the subject material, this is a really good class
If you're interested in the subject matter, you should definitely take it!  Look on blackboard at the past year's syllabus to see if you like the topics covered. Very manageable workload.

Prof. Medvigy is an outstanding teacher. He sets high expectations, and one must be adept at reading scientific literature and connecting disparate concepts to get much out of this course. That said, he strikes a good balance between pushing and supporting students. I would recommend this course for anyone interested in earth science methods, land plants, and/or climate change.

Take this course to gain a much greater understanding of the environment. It is especially valuable to those interested in doing environmental research. Experience in data analysis (Matlab or a similar language) is very useful.
You should take this course if you are looking for a good way to apply knowledge in climate science, and for a better notion of the scientific process.
prereqs: GEO 202 or equivalent.
descrip: Earth's climate is tightly coupled to the terrestrial biosphere. In this course, we will explore the key mechanisms that link climate (e.g., cloudiness, rainfall, and temperature) with the terrestrial biosphere, and how these mechanisms are altered by humans. We will review land-atmosphere exchanges of energy, water and carbon dioxide. We will then analyze the processes controlling the land carbon sink, with a strong focus on seasonality. We will investigate the potential impacts of climate change on vegetation seasonality and the land carbon sink. Assignments will include analysis of observational datasets and climate model simulations.

title: The Eagle and the Dragon: Comparing Ancient Rome and Han Empire
descrip: Flourishing contemporaneously between the 3rd century BCE and the 3rd century CE, Rome and the Han controlled much of the Eurasian landmass. What does juxtaposing the two reveal about each and the possibilities of historical comparison more broadly? By focusing on common themes (including kingship, administration, society, material culture), we draw upon a range of approaches to introduce both empires and a core problem in historical enquiry. Unlike most comparative histories, we also pay close attention to how ancient participants in empire perceived, portrayed, and theorized their worlds, and the ways ideas shaped their imperial projects.

title: Financial Econometrics
reviews: Good class but covers aq lot of material which can be hard to pick up if you havent done it before
Learn some core material and techniques for a career in finance.
Make sure to reread notes regularly
Solid econometrics course that covers a lot of different material
Very helpful and interesting course. Good professor.
descrip: Econometric and statistical methods as applied to finance. Topics include: Asset returns and efficient markets, linear time series and dynamics of returns, volatility models, multivariate time series, efficient portolios and CAPM, multifactor pricing models, portfolio allocation and risk assessment, intertemporal equilibrium models, present value models, simulation methods for financial derivatives, econometrics of continuous time finance.

title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior
