reviews: Definitely to attend the seminars, as they're very interesting and open your mind to various parts of neuroscience.
Great to get a sense of most recent research topics in Neuroscience.
Its a great opportunity to explore the types of research in neuroscience.
good background material / experience attending lectures
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior. For a list of speakers please see the link below.

title: Special Topics in the History of Science, Technology, and Medicine - Global Science
reviews: Do it.
I would recommend this course to everyone.
Take the course.
Take the course. Even if you are not entirely interested in the field, you will learn new ways of learning and writing, and you won't want to miss the opportunity to work with Professor Gordin.
What is there to consider? Take this course!
take the course
descrip: A distinctive feature of science (in its multiple designations in different cultures) is its geographical unrootedness. Historiographical schools over the past fifty years have experimented with designations for science's trans-local qualities - national styles of science, international science, cosmopolitanism, the Republic of Letters, and so on - with varying degrees of success. This graduate seminar explores the utility of taking a global approach to the history of science. We will explore recent scholarship on topics spanning from colonialism to translation, oceans to hygiene, nationalism to military technology.

title: Computer and Electronic Music through Programming, Performance, and Composition
reviews: Definitely take this class, especially if Jeff Snyder is teaching it.
Having coding experience definitely helps as does having musical experience. You could probably get by fine without either but on a significantly steeper learning curve.

I can't recommend this one enough, especially if Jeff Snyder is teaching it. Classes are very chill and always entertaining. You'll either be learning new tricks for you to play with in composition, or you'll be watching your classmates demo their latest assignment. These assignments are always fun and leave you feeling very accomplished. You'll learn a ton about electronic music, and you'll have a great time doing it. My only caveat is to have some exposure to programming and general CS before taking this course.
If you like music and programming, definitely take this course!!! Jeff is fantastic, the workload is totally reasonable, and it's pretty interesting. By the end, you can make some pretty cool stuff.
It was a fun course! Have at least some knowledge of programming going in (and a little music knowledge helps), and you'll be fine. This would also be a really good class to PDF for fun.

Take it if you know what computer music is and you think it is cool. A lot of stuff that you do/listen to will make your ears bleed until you get used to it. All in all a pretty easy course though. Make sure to get a good group for the programming assignments.

Take. This. Course. It's easily the best course I've taken here. Snyder is also one of the best professors. I only wish I'd taken it sooner so that I could have spent more time working on the subject before graduating.
take it!!
take notes on the specific languages, their syntax and objects and commands, and write down whatever jeff says, since he tends to talk fast about important things
prereqs: Instructor's permission. Application available in the Music Dept. office..
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of computer and electronic music. The music and sound programming language ChucK, developed here at Princeton, will be used in conjunction with Max/MSP, another digital audio language, to study procedural programming, digital signal processing and synthesis, networking, and human-computer interfacing.

title: Independent Research Project
prereqs: Students MUST sign up in room 121 during course selection period..
descrip: Independent research or investigation resulting in a report in the student's area of interest under the supervision of a faculty member. Open to sophomores and juniors.

title: Introduction to Ballet
reviews: An incredible course - Tina is a fantastic instructor and makes everyone feel comfortable in class! A must take.
It is a very accessible course to anyone whether you have dance experience or not. For beginners, you will be able to advance your ballet skills immensely. Plus, it's also a lot of fun!
She is the bomb.

TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU CAN GET IN OMG. Tina is a phenomenal professor- funny, kind, intelligent, engaging. It was a delight to get to spend 4 hours a week with her and I'll miss her over the summer. Plus ballet is really fun!
TAKE THIS COURSE. Tina is amazing, the live piano music is relaxing, and you really do improve at ballet!
Take it if you can.
Take it! Great class! Lots of fun!
Take it!!!
Take the course!
This class is awesome because dancing ballet is so much fun and because Tina is just a wonderful person to be around.

This is a fantastic way to spend four hours a week moving, laughing, and engaging your brain in way that you might not in other classes.  It's a fun, low-stress way to gain an introductory understanding of ballet and dance in general.
descrip: From grand plie to grand jete, Introduction to Ballet is for students with a curiosity for the study of classical ballet. No prior dance experience necessary and beginners are welcome. In this studio course students will learn the fundamentals of ballet, gaining an understanding of its physicality, artistry, and principles of alignment. Students will examine the historical origins of ballet and its absorption of cultural influences. Live music will be featured in this class and key in exploring the inextricable link between music and dance.

title: Advanced Persian Reading II: Modern Persian Prose
prereqs: PER 107 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course focuses on modern Persian prose. It is the continuation of 302, and is designed to improve the student's proficiency in the reading and comprehension of Persian texts. The emphasis is on reading, understanding, and translating modern prose. The class is conducted in Persian.

title: Statistics and Data Analysis for Economics
reviews: As someone who's taken both ECO 202 and WWS 200, you should take ECO 202. If you want to actually understand the math and concepts behind stats, ECO 202 is the right class for you. It's not overwhelmingly difficult and Prof. Mueller does a great job of making stats both approachable and dare I say, even interesting. Also, ECO 202 satisfies more requirements - including the Political Economy certificate (which I sadly learned WWS 200 does not satisfy).That said, if you want to learn to code stats in R, WWS 200 might be better (Although realistically, I'd recommend just taking COS 126 and figuring out R on your own. When I took WWS 200, the coding aspect was really not well taught and super frustrating because you had to learn most of it yourself anyway.) So in short, take ECO 202, not WWS 200.
Attend lectures and take all old exams given for practice.
Best stats class available. That said, precepts are useless and don't bother downloading STA
Better than other stats options. Read the textbook and you don't need to go to class.
Definitely don't take this if you don't have to. Muller's lectures are long and boring but he does a really good job of teaching you in lecture.
Do every practice quiz.

Do it because you have to, or because you want an introduction to statistics. It's good enough, and probably better than the other courses. Don't buy STATA, use Excel. Problem sets don't help you for the exams, only the practice exams do.
Do the problem sets
Don't procrastinate on studying! Actually try and understand what you're doing on the psets.
Don't take if you don't have to.
Don't take it if you don't have to
Don't take it if youre not an econ major
Don't take it unless you have to
Don't take it unless you need to.
Don't take it unless you really really have to
Don't take unless you have a stats background.
Easy class but Professor Mueller is awesome.
Even if you don't need to take it, this is a super useful class! Not too difficult either.
Go to lecture, start the homework early, do a lot of practice exams, and don't let your guard down because of the easiness of the homework.
Go to lectures and hopefully different preceptors will be more helpful.
I strongly reccommend this course
I would advise that they study mostly from lecture notes and lecture slides, not as much from the book.
I would recommend that they read along in the textbook so as to give the lectures more context.

I wouldn't take this class just for fun--do it if you need the prereq. Mueller does his absolute best to make statistics relevant and fun (which isn't easy) and I really appreciated that. Definitely not an easy class, but doable.
I wouldn't take this unless you're interested in statistics or need to take it.
If you are trying to get the statistics requirement done, take this class! It covers the material very well and it is not too hard.
If you have to take it, you've got to do what you have to do.

If you need a statistics course to fulfill a prereq, this is the course to take. It essentially repeats AP Stats if you've taken it in high school, but Prof. Ulrich goes into much more depth especially in terms of mathematical proofs. Knowing a bit of calculus would help with understanding some of the material, but you don't really need it. No need to buy STATA at all--the first few psets could have been done using Excel, and the second half didn't need to bother with either.
If you want a class in statistics it is a good class to get a overview of the key concepts.
If you're not a mathy person, but still want to learn statistics, this class is for you.
If you're taking it, you're probably an econ major. Precepts are helpful but not at all necessary if you know what's going on.
It is a really well taught statistics class and I really enjoyed the material.
It's a good stat course, if you really need to learn the material.
It's a great stats course - really understand material, not just memorize.
Its easier than ORF 245
Keep up with the p-sets and attend lectures. Try not to fall asleep.
Know what you're getting into. Take this class if you must, or if you're very interested in statistics.
Make good use of the Piazza website

Make sure you have done math recently and that you feel VERY comfortable with derivatives, and manipulating equations.  If you simply need a stats requirement, DO NOT take this course (you'll just be making yourself unnecessarily miserable).
Not that hard of a class. Lectures are nice and the professor is really passionate about the material
Only take it if you have to
Only take it if you have to.
Only take this class if you need to for a distribution requirement
Pretty helpful course for future statistics work.
Really work through the psets, they're very important for learning what you will be tested on.
Relatively easy but still extensive introduction to statistics.
Standard stats course.
Stay on top of the material!
Study a lot for the final!
Take if necessary, but so, so boring.
Take if you have to. Not great
Take it if you have to. It's better than all of the other stats offered.
Take it if you like math, have an interest in statistics, or need to take it as a req. Otherwise, I would avoid.
Take it if you need it. Professor Mueller is fun and interesting, does a good job of making the material interesting.

Take it if you need to take stats or just have an interest in the topic. It might not be very challenging if you have any previous knowledge though. If you have none or close to none (like me), it is still not really hard as long as you keep up with the work.
Take it only if you have to. Pretty dry course, not particularly difficult though.
Take it with Ulrich Mueller. He makes it pretty interesting and is funny
Take it, if you need it!
Take it. It is difficult but worth it and you will gain a very good understanding of statistics.
Take this if you're good at math.
Tests are pretty straight forward, only take it if you have to. ORF is more intense for those of you that are more quantitative, I might recommend that.

The best quantitative class I've taken so far at Princeton, and I'm a engineering student in her junior year. Prof Mueller is very engaging and funny - the lectures are very organized and easy to take notes in.
This class is great for intro to statistics.

This is a difficult class and I would really only recommend it for people who need the prereq, but anyone in need of a Stats class should choose this one over any of the others. Prof. Mueller is an excellent lecturer with a sense of humor and will partly make up for the challenge that will be found in any stats class you take. Stay on top of readings and attend all precepts and you'll survive.
This is a good intro statistics class. It doesn't focus on programming like many of the other statistics courses offered, so students can really understand the concepts by the end of the semester.
This is a relatively easy stats course, if you need a stats course
Woody Woo majors: take this for your stats requirement.  Basically just a step up from AP Stats
Work with others on psets.
You have to take in order to become a economics major so make sure you get something out of it.
You should not take this course unless you have to. Or unless you like theory a lot.
Your taking this cus you have too. Don't get too behind!
do the textbook readings they help a lot for exams
don't choose CJ Verbick as the preceptor
go to lecture - it helps!
if you want a good intro to stats class, i recommend this one.
its fine, not sure why people don't see that the material is useful and interesting
keep up with the concepts
stay on top of it
take it.
yes!
prereqs: MAT 103.
descrip: An introduction to probability and statistical methods for empirical work in economics. Probability, random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation and hypotheses testing, introduction to the regression model.

title: Linguistic Semantics
prereqs: LIN 201.
descrip: An introduction to central issues and leading theories of linguistic semantics for natural languages. Analysis of specific linguistic phenomena (including: anaphora, quantification, and tenses) will be used to illustrate the interaction of syntax and semantics, the relation between language and the world, and the role of linguistic meaning in communication and understanding.

title: Islam Across the Indian Ocean
reviews: Don't complain. Do the readings. If you don't know about something, look it up in Firestone. And don't take it easy just because the professor is nice. Take it seriously.
The amount of readings assigned can be overwhelming, but the important thing is to be familiar with each of them - not necessarily to have read them all word for word.
descrip: This seminar will consider Islam and mobility across the Indian Ocean, discussing ways that Southeast Asians, Africans, and Indians have created their distinct communities while nonetheless declaring themselves to be of one discrete entity: the Umma. Alongside discussions of knowledge creation, orientalism and nationalism, the seminar will also explore issues relating to global projects for religious and political reform, using Indonesia as a primary example.

title: Architecture Without Antiquity
descrip: The rediscovery of classical antiquity has been the central narrative of Renaissance art history. This class takes the opposite tack to consider how early modern architects reacted to challenges when ancient architecture offered no precedents. How have architectural responses to particular conditions shaped the modern world? We will examine a set of institutional types that developed in the Renaissance and Baroque periods - including libraries, hospitals, orphanages, city halls, observatories, and fortifications - to consider how the absence of historical models prompted structural and stylistic experiments in building form.

title: Introduction to Formal Analysis
descrip: Introduction to the primary projective systems that form the foundations of architectural representation and serve as essential tools of formal analysis and design. Coursework will be derived from a structured examination of key primary sources by Gaspard Monge, Brook Taylor and Girard Desargues.

title: The Psychology of Environmental Decision Making
reviews: Definitely consider taking!  It has a very manageable workload and the concepts you learn are applicable in many concepts.

Definitely take it. The material is really interesting and super important for everyone to know. It's a lot of fun and not too much work--you get to select which readings you want to do. The project is amazing. Sander is extremely knowledgeable about the field.
If you have any interest in the issues, absolutely take this class.  Sander is awesome, the issues are incredibly relevant, and material is interesting.

It's a wonderful course if you're interested in what motivates people to help the environment. You learn a LOT, and Sander's own research is SO COOL. Do be ready, however, to learn some more esoteric psychology jargon and methods.

TAKE THIS COURSE. In fact, take any course taught by Sander. You won't regret it. The topic was interesting, the lectures were engaging, and the written work/feedback was really good. It was a moderate amount of work; definitely not an overwhelming amount.
Take it! Sander is great and the material is really interesting.

This course gives a good introduction to environmental psychology and applications to behavioral change and policy and is good for students from a wide variety of backgrounds/departments. Course will improve with time--hopefully more applied stuff in future years. Somewhat time-intensive final project

This course is a great overview of psychological theory as it pertains to environmental issues. I would recommend doing the readings but more importantly just going to class. Sander explains things very clearly, even if they don't make sense in the readings.
This is an excellent course for students interested in environmental studies, policy management and psychology.
prereqs: Junior and Senior undergraduate students please contact Instructor with the appropriate form..
descrip: An introduction to the field of behavioral science and how it is used in practice to study and change how people make decisions about environmental problems. We explore how people psychologically understand and process environmental risks and how such perceptions influence behavioral decision-making. Students explore the social-psychological foundations of pro-environmental values, attitudes and norms and how to design public policy interventions to improve environmental decision-making. Public understanding of science and behavioral strategies for effective environmental science communication and engagement are also discussed.

title: Analysis I: Fourier Series and Partial Differential Equations
reviews: A good introduction to ideas in analysis, plus a lot of interesting applications to several areas of mathematics.
A good introduction to more rigorous, proof based courses in mathematics. Physics implications are mentioned and exposed.
Amazing course if you have background in analysis. Otherwise might be a bit difficult but it's totally worth it
Don't take it just for Stein -- if you aren't already interested in Fourier, it won't be an interesting or rewarding class.

Excellent course when taught by Prof. Stein. The workload is below-average for a math departmental, and the problem sets are good at reinforcing the ideas in the section. My only complaint is that the exams are focused on memorizing parts of the text.
Great course with Stein. The book is very good, and the problems aren't too difficult (for a Princeton math course).
I didn't find this course terribly interesting, though it was well taught. However, I had already taken Real Analysis, so it was a bit of a step backwards in some ways. The text book is very good.
I don't think it will be taught again by Stein!
I found it pretty difficult and graded pretty harshly
I would strongly recommend taking this class while Professor Stein is teaching it. The problem sets are at a very reasonable difficulty for a math class.

If you are taking this because you think it might be fun, I would recommend Complex instead. Take this because you are interested in the applications of Fourier series into physics, because that is what Fourier analysis is good for.

It's generally a good class. I would recommend it to someone who is looking for a relatively painless way to fill the real analysis requirement. If you intend to take things like 425 (Stein III) later, this course is probably unnecessary. With Stein teaching it, it feels very similar to Complex Analysis (again, with Stein), but the subject matter lacks some of the appeal that the latter has.
Stein is a great explainer. Lectures were good and problem sets were interesting. Make sure to seriously study for the exams.

Stein is able to go super slowly, explain everything in depth, stop for every question, and still manages to finish all the material. Even if you have no interest in Fourier analysis, this is a good class.
Take it if you have taken 215, and also read the lecture notes before class, even if for 20 minutes, and annotate the lecture notes.

Take it with Stein if you are lucky enough too. Also, start problem sets early. They are not bad at all, usually like 8 exercise (not problems) for stein's book and 2 or 3 will be challenging. Get the other 5-6 out of the way early in the week, and the rest over the weekend for pset due tuesday.

Take it with Stein. He's amazing.
Work with others on the homeworks.
Take it! Take it in freshman spring and follow Prof. Stein.
Take it, especially if Professor Stein ever teaches it again.
Take it. Stein is cool, the course is good. Study for the midterm, it will probably determine your entire grade.
Take only if you are interested in fourier analysis
Understand that this is a difficult course for non-math majors, and expect to spend some time on the problem sets. Great course, nonetheless, especially with professor Stein.
Very interesting and useful topic. Prepares you well for other analysis classes
prereqs: MAT215, 218, or consent of instructor..
descrip: Basic facts about Fourier Series, Fourier Transformations, and applications to the classical partial differential equations will be covered. Also Fast Fourier Transforms, Finite Fourier Series, Dirichlet Characters, and applications to properties of primes.

title: High-Energy Physics
reviews: A very manageable course for undergrads, even without QFT, though it helps. Professor Lisanti was a great lecturer.
I would strongly recommend this course if you are interested in high-energy physics.
Plead for shorter assignments, or less frequent assignments.
Take QFT before taking this course. Also, if you've taken a hep course before, you probably won't see anything new. If you've never taken a hep/pheno course before though, it's worthwhile taking!

Take this course if you do not have a strong QFT background, but still want to learn the Standard Model. If you know QFT, take this class if you want to see it applied to the world we observe. Overall great lecturer who was very helpful and great class, though the back to back lecture could be draining.
The workload is high but rewarding. If one does not do all the assignments, I doubt if he/she would learn as much.
descrip: An overview of modern elementary particle physics and the Standard Model. Specific topics include: weak decays, W and Z physics, deep inelastic scattering, CP violation, neutrino oscillations, Higgs searches, with an emphasis on areas of current interest.

title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry - Arithmetic Algebraic Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebraic Geometry. Specific topic details provided when course is offered.

title: Materials Science and Engineering
reviews: Don't take it unless you have to. It's not an easy class.

I might be a little cautious if you're just planning to take it for a fun elective, but if you're in it for the certificate program, it's a good introduction to materials science.  Go to the problem sessions; they will help you.  If you're taking it with Dr. Soboyejo, be advised that he wrote a textbook of his own that helps to elucidate the stuff that isn't in the main textbook.

I think the other Materials class in the MAE department would be a better choice than this one if Professor Soboyejo was teaching this class. The class was rather disorganized and the problem sets were either trivial or impossible in general. However, I did learn about materials and material properties, so if you do have to take this class I think you can do well and learn if you put in the effort. There may just be more enjoyable ways to learn this material.

I thought Professor Soboyejo did a good job of trying to introduce many disparate fields of materials science in one semester. He's very willing to listen to students' concerns and help out with understanding concepts after class. He likes to emphasize big concepts rather than minor details so it's worth keeping that in mind when preparing for exams. When he says the exams are gonna have the same format as the problem sets, take his word for it. The first half of the final exam was questions out of the midterm exam and problem sets word for word with minor changes.

I would encourage them to put the time in. Knowing that most students taking this course probably have a tough workload, they need to understand that they need to manage their time and set aside a good amount time to understand this material.
Lots of work but take it
Materials is better than you think it will be. Soboyejo is a fun lecturer. Can be a challenging course if all the concepts are new to  you.
Study. Soboyejo is kind of all over the place, so make sure if you have questions you ask.

Take it! Prof. Soboyejo is wonderful, and his lectures are entertaining. Even if you learned nothing, it would be worth taking the class to hear all his stories, but you also learn a lot that's applicable to all varieties of science/engineering.
Take this course if you have an interest in materials science. It's very useful to a wide variety of majors.
The class moves quickly so make sure you keep up with the material. Overall it's an interesting class and you learn a lot.

The material is interesting but you'll have to do quite a bit of self-study to understand the concepts, especially if it's your first time taking a materials course. I wouldn't take it just for fun but if you're interested in the material, it's not a bad course!
prereqs: Calculus, physics, and chemistry. Course will expect some level of organic chemistry; students to carry out some basic derivation of equations. Freshmen should speak with course instructor for approval to enroll..
descrip: An introduction to the structure and properties of important current and future materials, including metals, ceramics, semiconductors, polymers and composites. Emphasis will be placed on the phase behavior, processing of materials, and how the structure of these materials affect their physical, mechanical, electrical and thermal properties.

title: Creating Documentary Performance
descrip: See website

title: Greek Prose Authors - Readings in Greek Historiography
prereqs: CLG 105 or CLG 108.
descrip: This course is an introduction to Greek Historiography. By reading selections from the Greek historians Herodotus and Thucydides, we will try to answer the following questions: Was the ancient Greek conception of writing history essentially different from ours? How did history relate to rhetoric and other literary genres? What were the main methods of writing history? The emphasis will be on reading passages in the original, followed by discussion of issues.

title: Black to the Future: Science, Fiction, and Society
reviews: Take it! This course taught me so much, and Professor Benjamin was a great discussion leader and facilitator. My favorite course at Princeton so far. Social justice sci fi is mind blowing.

This is a great course-- Professor Benjamin is engaging, provocative, approachable, and a lot of fun in class. I think those that did most well in the class got a head start on assignments and came prepared with questions.

This was the college-level class I never knew I was always looking for. It is both quintessentially Princeton (in terms of the high quality of the instructor and her ability to illuminate the class material), and decidedly anti-Princeton (insofar as it troubles the white, elitist, hetero-normative power structures of which we are so frequently reminded). Take it for the vastly diverse material. Take it for the superhero that is Prof. Ruha Benjamin.
prereqs: Please contact the instructor if you have taken no prior social science course related to race-ethnicity..
descrip: Designer Babies. Ancestry Tests. Organ Regeneration. Biometric Surveillance. These and more comprise our 21st century landscape. This interdisciplinary course examines the values and politics that shape science, medicine, and technology, asking who bears the risk and who reaps the benefit of innovations? Social inequality is legitimized, in part, by myths about human difference. And while course participants grapple with past and present stories that shape science and technology, we also apply a sociological imagination to the future, exploring how contemporary hopes and fears may give rise to "real utopias" that are more equitable and just.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Ah, EPICS.  Time team baby.
Join the Joseph Henry Team! We make science exhibits for kids.
Take it. you will learn a lot and really enjoy it.
Take only if you'll be engaged in the course. Otherwise not really worth it.
You get out what you put in to this course -- a very different Princeton class, but one of my favorites.
sdf
prereqs: Completion of EGR 450.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Introduction to German Philosophy
reviews: Absolutely take this course! I wish I had taken it as an underclassman. Unlike most of the courses available in the philosophy department, this course does an excellent job of presenting hugely important texts without drastically reducing their arguments, focusing instead on what is compelling about them and how they have proven influential. I would recommend this course to anyone even vaguely interested in the history of philosophy.

Definitely take this course. The lectures are very engaging and the material is intellectually stimulating. The reading is very dense and often complicated, but the class is such that it does not expect complete mastery of these difficult concepts. If you're at all interested in philosophy or are unsure of your level of interest, take it.
Do take it! It was a lot of reading and work, but I highly recommend it.
Do the reading-- it's hard but worth it, and go to precept, it will help.

Go to lecture with a clear mind so that you can focus and take good notes. Try to absorb as much as you can from the professor and don't listen to your classmates too much, as they will mislead you and further muddy the waters. Read as much as you can bear, and if you enjoy a certain text, go above and beyond with office hours and independent research to enhance your understanding.
Highly recmmend
I have recommended this course to several friends of mine.
If Professor Lande is still teaching it, then expect disjointed lectures that do little to enhance the texts.  Expect to tackle them on your own (which is more achievable than one might expect).
Interest in reading lots of dense material, and taking time to not understand and get frustrated.

It's a great class, excellent overview of German philosophy, Don't underestimate the time it'll take you to do the readings, but do them as much as you can because it'll help you engage in lecture and precept a lot more
Take any class with Lande! Do the readings.
Take it!
Take it! I took it as an EM that I thought I would PDF but I found it to be one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Princeton
Take the class, don't worry if you don't understand the reading, the lectures will help explain.
Take this class if you are prepared to spend the time necessary
This course is very good for gaining a basic knowledge of these authors. Be prepared for a lot of reading!
This course it not the best fluffy AB course; there is more reading than I had anticipated, and it is difficult to really understand the material without reading it.
stay on top of the reading
descrip: An introduction to the German philosophical tradition from the Enlightenment to the present through the study of its major figures (Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Adorno, Wittgenstein). This course offers a survey of German intellectual history, which engages directly and closely with the original texts. Domains to be explored include metaphysics, aesthetics, the theory of knowledge, political philosophy and philosophy of language.

title: Topics in Macroeconomics
reviews: Basic financial accelerator models, intro to money and banking models, some open economy stuff. Highly recommended.

Interesting subject and you get to learn a little bit about theoretical economics. Apparently a good stepping stone for grad school, if that's what you're in to. Prof. Kiyotaki is really nice, and grading is pretty lenient.

Kiyotaki is brilliant, but take this course advisedly -- he is rather disorganized, and you end up paying the price for that (the homeworks are always a mess). The material makes this class worthwhile to those who think they might be interested in macroeconomic theory. If taught by Kiyotaki, be aware that this is not a general set of "topics in macro" -- but rather a selective exploration of what Kiyotaki finds interesting. That happens to be awesome, but you should be aware of that.
Very good, a challenging macro class but very interesting
prereqs: ECO 300/310 and ECO 301/311 or the consent of the instructor..
descrip: This course uses economic theory to study credit boom, financial crisis and public policy. The topics include historical overivew of financial crises, credit and asset price booms, banking crisis, balance of payment crisis, sovereigh debt crisis, and monetary, fiscal and macro prudential policies.

title: Pragmatism and Religion: James and Dewey
reviews: Absolutely take this course. Changed the way I think about almost everything. Prof. Glaude is one of a kind--this is the kind of class you should be taking at a school like Princeton.

Definitely take this, but be prepared to REALLY do the readings or else you will not be able to participate in the discussion or get much out of this class. Incredible discussions though with a great group of people.
Professor Glaude is an amazing professor!

Take it, but only if the enrollment is <8.  I think the value of a course like this is getting to intimately understand the concerns and thoughts and personalities of the people in the seminar.  Any larger than 8 and I think you would lose much of what made the class great.
descrip: This seminar will examine the works of two important classical pragmatists, William James and John Dewey, and their views about religion. Several questions will guide our efforts: how do James and Dewey understand and respond to evil and death? Is a conception of God important to their thoughts about religion? Attention will be given throughout the course to the concepts of nature, experience, and piety.

title: Introduction to Islamic Law
reviews: Not too heavy a workload, and the readings were accessible and interesting. Sometimes difficult to hear Prof. Modaressi so sit close
Take it. The Professor is master of this field.
The readings are interesting for those with an interest in religious law.
You can't really be sure to get an A or B, just transcribe whatever he says in class. Readings aren't really helpful for the grade.
descrip: A survey of the history of Islamic law and its developments, and the attempts of the Muslim jurists to come to term with the challenges of modern times. It will focus on issues in constitutional and personal laws that have the greatest relevance to the modern era.

title: Junior Independent Work
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, and an oral presentation will be required. Students generally spend 15-20 hours per week on the independent project.

title: Topics in Automorphic Forms - Automorphic forms and special values of L-functions
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will cover some recent applications of the arithmetic of automorphic forms to questions about special values of L-functions. Particular attention will be given to L-functions of elliptic curves and modular forms.

title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
descrip: Macro implications of micro imperfections. The "cleansing" effect of recessions and the impact of allocative versus aggregate shocks. Recent models of consumption and empirical tests of risk-sharing. How the distribution of income or wealth affects aggregate growth and fluctuations. Role of imperfect credit markets, distributional conflict and political economy. Endogenous, skill-biased, technological change and human capital accumulation; implications for growth and social mobility.

title: Devotional Objects in Medieval and Early Modern Christianity
reviews: Actually look up the objects before class so you know what will be discussed
I will suggests to take the course, as an essential step to became a better scholar in Early Modern art.
I would strongly advise people to take this, or any, course with Professor Bynum. She is an admirable and prolific scholar and an exemplary teacher.
Never, ever miss an opportunity to take a class with Professor Bynum.
Professor Bynum is one of the nicest, smartest professors I've had at Princeton. Definitely take a class with her.
Take it and be willing to put forth the intellectual effort.
descrip: Religious objects from ca. 1200 to ca. 1600 mostly in northern Europe: what religious "charge" they carried and what responses they met during the Reformation. Examples of what we would today call "art" - panel paintings, miniatures, statues - will be studied in the context of other sorts of things (e.g., saints' relics, the Eucharist) that also expressed divine power through their materiality. The course will raise theoretical questions about what "art" is; its relation to "craft;" what iconoclasm or resistance to images means; differences between museum display and sacred space; responses to images (universal or local and temporal).

title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music
reviews: A good opportunity to get involved in chamber playing. You'll need to be proactive about preparation because you need a formed group to audition, but it's definitely worth the effort.
Absolutely take it if you have the opportunity.  It's a much smaller time commitment than a typical Princeton course and I learned so much from my teacher.

Be careful what piece you choose to learn over the semester, and with which group members! It's not as much time as you think to prepare an entire chamber work, and if you start running into conflicting opinions about how to play certain passages, group strife may ensue.
Definitely a great way to get credit. Just make sure that you are with a group of people that you really enjoy, because that is what makes this class really worth taking.
GET A GROUP! TAKE THIS COURSE!
Great course - you get to play music and learn from excellent professional musicians. What more can you ask for?
Great experience to work with Francine on the piano. Couldn't ask for more during a semester's training and learning in musicianship and ensemble music making.
Hope you get a good coach(es).
If you like playing music and aren't unnerved by PDF only classes, take it.

Make sure you actually rehearse starting early in the semester. Also make sure that if the ensemble in residence doesn't have a musician who plays a similar instrument to those in your ensemble, you find a teacher for your instrument. Having a tuba instructor as a teacher was SO helpful; since So Percussion is a percussion ensemble, they weren't really able to help us with problems specifically related to our instruments.
Take it!  It's really easy to do as a fifth class and you won't regret it.

The practice time required for this course is substantial, so be prepared to dedicate yourself to the piece and the group! It is super fun and I would recommend it for anyone who wants to keep up their instrument in college or wants to concentrate in music (or get a certificate).
The rigor of the class highly depends on who your coach is. Some require a lot of time, some are very relaxed about it. The whole class is rather unstructured.
This is a great class, but only if you get along with the other members in your group.
You get out of it what you put in. A good course and it's awesome to get credit for something as fun as playing music with your peers.

You should definitely consider taking it if you play an instrument and enjoy playing with a small group! All of the coaches are excellent (whether or not they specialize in your instrument) and will give you helpful musical guidance. The entire process was very rewarding, but the class is very much what you make of it and how much time or practice you put into it. I would recommend having set rehearsal times with your group to make sure everyone is equally committed to the class.
You will get as much out of this as you put in
take it
prereqs: Auditions in November TBA.
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.

title: Fundamentals of Nanophotonics
reviews: If you are an undergraduate you should take it, if you are graduate who doesn't spend lots of time in the lab then I would also suggest you should take it.
If you are working on photonics, you should take this class.
Very intensive course but delivered by a very good professor. Recommended.
a new to look at optics
prereqs: Knowledge of basic linear algebra and differential equations at the undergraduate level is assumed. Prior knowledge of quantum mechanics is not required, but helpful..
descrip: Introduction to theoretical techniques for understanding and modeling nanophotonic systems, emphasizing important algebraic properties of Maxwell's equations. Topics covered include Hermitian eigensystems, photonic crystals, Bloch's theorem, symmetry, band gaps, omnidirectional reflection, localization and mode confinement of guided and leaky modes. Techniques covered include Green's functions, density of states, numerical eigensolvers, finite-difference and boundary-element methods, coupled-mode theory, scattering formalism, and perturbation theory. The course explores application of these techniques to current research problems.

title: Graphic Design: Circulation
prereqs: This course serves as a complement to VIS 214 Graphic Design: Visual Form and VIS 215 Graphic Design: Typography, but can be taken independently..
descrip: The practice of graphic design relies on the existence of networks for distributing multiple copies of identical things. Students in this course will consider the ways in which a graphic design object's characteristics are affected by its ability to be copied and shared, and by the environment in which it is intended to circulate. Through hands-on design projects, readings, and discussions, students will delve into different material forms of distribution - the public newspaper, the community newsletter, the course packet, the PDF - and investigate the particular attributes of each.

title: Born in the U.S.A.: Culture and Reproduction in Modern America
reviews: AMAZING CLASS AND PROFESSOR HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
Definitely take it! This class is very interesting. Also you should do the readings.
Definitely take this course! It's incredible

I would absolutely advise taking this course. I haven't taken many GSS classes at Princeton, but I would advise any students interested in women (as opposed to feminist theory, for example) to take this class. Professor Armstrong herself is amazing, very funny, and always willing to meet with students to discuss papers, readings, and so on. Although there are several assignments, the papers are largely self-directed and as a result interesting to write. I loved this class!
It's very interesting, especially in terms of life skills and knowledge that will be applicable to your personal life down the road.
One of my favorite courses at Princeton--will love you if you are at all interested in reproduction/women's health.
Take it! You will learn so much and you'll never look at reproduction, medicine, or American culture the same way again.
Take this class! It is so interesting and I took so much from the class.

Take this class! Professor Armstrong is amazingly engaged, the papers are all fun, the readings are interesting (and while there are a lot, you can get away with just reading a couple carefully each week), and the material is important to everyone who lives in America -- regardless of your gender, sexuality, or y/n on wanting to have children eventually, thinking on how our culture views reproduction affects everyone.
Take this if you want to learn more about sexual and reproductive health culture in the US. It's an incredibly informative and mind blowing seminar, and Professor Armstrong is amazing.

This course is always rated highly and it's totally valid! It's a wonderful course and it is one of its kind. Definitely take it, and for male-identified students, I encourage you to take it- typically the course is female only and I think a mixed gender class would add to it. Still, the course is wonderful and really illuminates a lot about how we perceive reproduction in the States. It really challenges and intrigues you.
descrip: Reproduction is a basic biological process, as well as a fundamental one for all societies. While the biology of human reproduction is universal across time and place, cultural norms and social institutions powerfully inflect and shape the experience of pregnancy and childbirth in every society. This course investigates the history and sociology of reproduction, focusing on the contemporary United States, but with an eye toward other societies for comparison. How, why, and for whom does birth matter? How do reproductive practices reflect gender, race, and class? The course examines the culture, politics, and economics of reproduction.

title: The World of Late Antiquity
reviews: An excellent distribution requirement and Tannous is a great lecturer. Take it!
Definately take this, Tannous is awesome
Definitely go to Professor Tannous' office hours. When he says he wants to meet you, he really means it. Do it and get the extra 5 points on your final exam as a result. Great intro course.

Definitely take this as a distribution requirement. Tannous is an awesome lecturer and an even more amazing person. He really tries to help everyone succeed in the class, and is so much fun to just talk to. The workload is relatively little (compared to other history classes) and the material is super interesting. Also try to get Stefan as your preceptor if you can!
Dr Jack Tannous is amazing. Go to his office hours and try to get his precept. Easy course if you go to lecture and take good notes

Even if you have no interest in Roman/Byzantine History, Professor Tannous is amazing and this course tackles a really interesting part of history. There's a little something for everyone, war, religion, family, society, economics, politics, even linguistics, art, and agriculture. Definitely go to his office hours for bonus points on your final and to meet him! He really wants to know his students. Also try to get Molly Lester as your preceptor, she's super smart and really wants to help you understand the material, even if you are only taking the class as a distribution requirement.
Excellent course for those who aren't in the humanities; well organized for an intro class, great professor, easy grading.
Focus on the one main reading per week and do the others (if there are others) if you have time. Go to Dave Jenkins. Go to office hours. Go to lecture and don't sleep (its actually kind of fun).
Go to office hours. They're a lot of fun and you'll probably learn something invaluable.
Good course to take if your thinking about history. Prof. Tannous really helps you out if you need it and doesn't want to fail you, just wants to see you work
Great history course
Highly recommend taking this course. Try to get into Prof. Tannous' precept.

I absolutely loved this course! Jack was a really good professor and though his classes might have seemed boring initially, the topic of the class and his humor made it really great. You can see his passion for the course. I also thought the readings were all pretty interesting--they were translated primary sources and written like stories and weren't generally that long. I loved precept too. We really engaged with the readings, which was fun...but make sure to do the readings!

I recommend this course if you need a distribution requirement, or if you simply like history. It is a good course, it is well planned, and you learn about a very interesting time period of which I knew nothing about.

I recommend this course. Prof. Tannous is a wonderful teacher and person. The readings are reasonable. The exams require following the study guide and reviewing lecture notes but are pretty straight forward as long as you study.
I would advise them to go to all lectures and to take concise notes.

I would highly recommend this class to any student.  As an engineer I was slightly worried and shouldn't have been concerned at all.  I learned a lot and as Tannous says himself, this class was "the no stress express".
I would recommend if looking for an HA
I would recommend this course to anyone, and advise students to not be scared of taking an HA. I was a bit nervous in the beginning, but this has been one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
I would strongly recommend this course.
If you are interested in the Eastern Roman Empire and Late Antiquity, this is the course to take.

If you are looking for a good HA, this is the one! It's engaging without being too demanding. Professor Tannous cares a lot about his students and knows a lot about his subject matter. You don't necessarily need to read everything, but read most of the primary sources that are assigned for the precepts because they come up in the final. Also, take good notes. Tannous gives a lot of details that appear exactly on the final, including the essay question.
If you do not take this class, you have made a huge mistake. Best class I have taken here without a doubt.
Pay special attention to precept readings and take notes as fast as possible because he talks fast.
Please read above statement!

Professor Tannous is a wonderful human being, and everyone should get a chance to get to know him! I found his intellectual and personal perspectives incredibly refreshing and atypical of other academics. I would DEFINITELY recommend this!
Really great history class.
Stay on top of the readings.
TAKE IT!!!!!!!!!!!!!! YOU WON'T GET A BETTER PRINCETON CLASS!
TAKE IT. Such a good class and professor Tannous is the best. Not too hard and very interesting. Try to get Dawn Lavalle as a preceptor-- she is awesome.
Take it
Take it as your first history class, because it's good for students who are not experienced in university-level history.
Take it if you want an easy class that doesn't require a ton of work. Tannous is awesome and super laid back!!
Take it!
Take it! Prof. Tannous is one of the most generous, kind people you'll meet (he has this thing called the "No Stress Express"). You'll learn a ton, and this course won't make you lose sleep at night.

Take it!!! Take it!!! Take it!!! Professor Tannous is SUPER interested in his students! He wants you to come to lecture and visit office hours. If you go to the latter, you'll get a 5% bonus on the final!!!

Take it, Tannous is an awesome teacher.
Make sure you get a good preceptor though.
Take it, and it will be one of the best courses you take here.
Take it.
Take it. IT is super interesting.
Take it. Pretty easy and doesn't require a ton of work.
Take it; having Tannous as a lecturer is well worth it. If you put in the effort, you can definitely earn an A, but you ought to pace yourself to do all the reading.
Take short notes on all of the precept readings.
Take this class!! It is fun, interesting, and awesome!  You will learn a lot and have a great time!
Take this course because Prof. Tannous is amazing and will help you with basically everything, both with courses and applying to fellowships, etc.
Take this course for a fairly easy history class (although the readings can be difficult), and a very interesting professor.
Take this course if you want to learn how to think about complex and oftentimes foreign problems.
Take this course!
Take this course! I actually found reading the text after the lecture it was assigned helpful in terms of solidifying the material.
Take this course!!! It was a really great class, Tannous is a great lecturer, and the readings aren't too difficult. If you like history, or just need an easy HA, this is a great class to take.
Take this course, you will not regret it. Jack Tannous is a boss.

Take this is a great fifth class, especially for freshmen who want to take five classes during the semester they have writing seminar. Take advantage of office hours, not just because you get extra credit, but because Professor Tannous is awesome and really cares about getting to know his students. He also is very helpful about finding a topic/primary sources for the paper, so definitely talk to him if you are struggling with that. It goes without saying you should attend lectures and take notes: you don't want to miss Tannous' great lectures and also he gives hints for the exams/papers (i.e. "this would be a great question to ask on the midterm," "this would be a really interesting paper topic," etc.). Can't recommend the class enough.
Take this! So good. Esp. if you're interested in the Roman Empire, Xtianity, Islam, barbarians, gold, or really anything.

Tannous is a fantastic lecturer and a very interesting guy. His passion for the material is infectious. Love the set-up of the course and his openness to meeting students. Definitely go talk to him. An excellent course for its purpose -- a "gateway" into more advanced history courses.

Tannous is a really nice guy and exactly what you want from a professor - engaging and willing to help you outside of class. The lectures can meander from topic to topic, with random flashbacks across centuries and jumps where Tannous remembers some travel story or random piece of information, sometimes you don't know where it's going but isn't that part of the fun? If that all sounds terrible, don't take it. If you don't mind, it makes a nice HA.
Tannous is hilarious and a super nice guy. The material is interesting, and it's not a very hard course.
Tannous is one of Princeton's treasures. Take a class with him if at all possible
The course provides a basic but thorough contextualization of events and issues related to Late Antiquity.
This is a great class to take. It is very accessible to anyone, and it is very possible to succeed if you put in the work and do the readings. This is also a very interesting era of history.
This is a really interesting class. Professor Tannous is engaging and cares a lot.

This is an excellent course. Whether you need an HA, are interested in the topic, need a History departmental/pre-req, etc, everyone should take it. It is not that difficult (Tannous calls it the low stress express and it really is), but you learn a lot and Tannous is a fantastic professor and really chill. Go to his office hours, you can learn so much from him!
This was an excellent course that bridges Roman history and Near Eastern history. This is an great framework with which to see the foundations of both "Western" and "Islamic" civilizations.
To attend lecture and take good notes
Try and get into Professor Tannous' precept!
While the topics are interesting at times, Professor Tannous' presentation dulls the excitement. Lots and lots of dull and long readings.

You learn a lot about early Christianity, the Eastern Roman Empire, and Islam. The readings are quite good if you're into that kind of stuff. Professor Tannous is a funny guy. Workload, readings, are fine, nothing exceptional.

You should totally take this class if you are looking for an HA and also want to take something fun and interesting! Just know that the readings take a while, but you can get by without doing all of them.
do the readings and go to lecture!
take it
descrip: This course will focus on the history of the later Roman Empire, a period which historians often refer to as "Late Antiquity." We will begin our class in pagan Rome at the start of the third century and end it in Baghdad in the ninth century: in between these two points, the Mediterranean world experienced a series of cultural and political revolutions whose reverberations can still be felt today. We will witness civil wars, barbarian invasions, the triumph of Christianity over paganism, the fall of the Western Empire, the rise of Islam, the Greco-Arabic translation movement and much more.

title: Readings in Chinese Literature - Classical Chinese Commentary
descrip: Analysis of the modes, genres, and boundaries of commentary in the Chinese tradition.

title: Journeys in Portuguese: Studies in Language and Culture
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.

title: Europe in the World: Monarchies, Nations, and Empires from 1776 to the Present Day
reviews: A great class, lots of readings so you learn a lot. Quite broad so you can get away with a certain amount of BS
Be sure to take notes of the supplemental readings (brief summaries); these will be critical when preparing for the final exam.
Completely recommend this class!
Definitely go to all the lectures and try to do the reading, but it's not entirely necessary to complete all the readings
Do the readings!
Extremely easy if you know anything about 19th century history.
Go to lectures and that's prob enough to get you a passing grade (at least I hope so lol)
Good course, very interesting, but a ton of readings (and most of them are redundant)
Great course, definitely take it and attend lecture even if you don't do all the readings.
Great professor
Highly recommended.

I would highly recommend this course.  Sir Professor Cannadine is fantastic and a pleasure to listen to.  He truly knows his information and as a fellow Briton, his personal input makes the class all of the better.
I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in history and wants to learn more about Europe or government systems in general.
If you like European history and have decided to major in history then take this course. If you are not majoring in history then don't take this course because it is a lot of reading and work.
Keep up on the readings, and participate in precept.
Pay attention in lecture and read precept readings!
Stay on top of all the readings.
Take it!
Take it!  Cannadine's lectures are wonderful.
Take it! Cannadine is great. Standard difficulty. Go to lecture and do most of the reading and you will be fine.
Take it. Enjoyable, fun, yet incredibly educational. Not often you have fun in lecture and precept and still get challenged by the work.
Take it. Great course which covers a broad history of monarchies all around the world.
Take this course. It convinced me to major in history.

This class covers a lot of ground, but as such it doesn't go into great detail about any given topic. More like a high school history class than I'd expected -- lots of memorizing, no independent research. Take it if you're looking for a good survey course in history.
This class is fantastic, and Cannadine is an amazing professor with so much knowledge on the subject. The reading is also very manageable, though it is important that you do it. Take the class!
This is a good introductory, survey course.

This is a pretty good 200 level history course for a distribution requirement. Professor Cannadine gives very interesting perspectives on monarchies, and I came out with a very different opinion than I came in with. The lectures are scripted (he just reads them), but engaging overall, and the readings are managable and pretty interesting. Overall, this is a class that is little work besides the reading. There is a take-home timed essay midterm, and a timed essay final, but for me that was perfect.

This is a really interesting class that looks at monarchy in a new way. Even though the subject matter was not what originally drew me to it, Cannadine made the class engaging. The workload was reasonable and the way in which the information was presented was great.
Very interesting to learn more about monarchies.
definitely recommend for history and even nonhistory majors
take this course
prereqs: P/D/F option not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course offers a global history from an unusual perspective: that of the nations and empires ruled by monarchs and emperors (and sometimes empresses) across the years since the American and French revolutions, which are often seen as the events which ushered in the modern world of republicanism and democracy. To be sure, many thrones have crashed and crowns have passed away since then; but monarchies are still with us today, from Japan to Britain, Swaziland to Sweden. This course will explore both the anti-monarchical trends that have thrived since 1776 and 1789, but also the surprising extent of royal resilience.

title: German Intellectual History - Labyrinths of Literature
reviews: If you have the opportunity to take a course with Professor Inka Mulder-Bach, absolutely take it!
Prof. Muelder- Bach is an intellectual force of nature. Take a course with her if you can.
Take it! Take it! Take it! Prof Bach makes the class come alive.

Take this class. It was easily my favorite class at Princeton. Professor Muelder-Bach is engaging and always willing to help you understand the texts and how to navigate them if you just put in the necessary time.
descrip: In literature and art, dance and architecture the labyrinth delineates a path which has been interpreted in various ways, as a figuration of the polarity of chaos and order, for example, or as a trajectory of initiation symbolizing the experience of separation, desorientation and rebirth. On the basis of selected pictorial material as well as selected readings of the myths of Theseus and Dedalus, the seminar will focus on the relation between the structure of the maze and narrative structures in 20th century German literature.

title: Principles of Quantum Mechanics
reviews: Ask questions after lectures and try to get a deep understanding of this material by thinking about it a lot after class. Don't just do problem sets to get things done. If you're doing a problem and you see some tangential issue that doesn't make sense to you, ask the TAs or Verlinde, and you will probably end up learning 3 other aspects of the material a lot better than you did before. That's how you will come out knowing the material really well.
Be prepared for decent lectures and a bit of your own study.
Challenging. Go to office hours and really make sure you understand the material!
Definitely go to problem sessions and office hours.

Go to all lectures, do all the homework, make use of the professor's office hours (not just TA's), and consult problem solving tutorial videos on YouTube to really learn a derivation without any skipped steps.

If you are looking at taking PHY 208 you probably have to.  Really make sure you understand what you're doing on the problem sets.  Try and do as much of the math yourself as you can, no mathematica or anything.

If you are taking this course out of general interest, don't. Verlinde makes the course unnecessarily difficult and you won't get much out of it other than another math class. If you want to learn about the interesting things QM can do, read a book or look online. If you must take this course, be prepared to work hard, devote a lot of time to the course, and think "outside the box". Reading the textbook and doing textbook problems and practice exams is not enough.
If you're a PHY or AST major, you need to take it, likely in the spring of sophomore year. You'd better hope Verlinde isn't teaching it though, he's an absolute nightmare.

If you're like me, you're excited to take this class because quantum mechanics is amazing and cool and awesome--be warned, it is not as beautiful as you might perceive it to be. A lot of it is cranking integrals. I think the main purpose for taking it is in order to take Quantum II, so if you're thinking about taking it just for kicks, maybe hold off.

It is wise to read the assigned readings before the lectures, and take advantage of all the problem sessions and office hours that the professor set up. Be sure to find a good study group to handle the problem sets with (while also giving yourself some time to work on the problems alone for the sake of experience).

It was H. Verlinde's first time teaching the course, so he was a bit disorganized and didn't do many computations on the blackboard. The textbook didn't help much either, but if you look at problem sets on the internet that are similar to past midterms, you should be able to do well. Problem sets were not that time consuming - 5-6 hours a week.
It's a classic, basic course. Verlinde's not a bad lecturer, and he is quite useful in office hours.
It's probably required for you if you're taking it. It's a lot of work and it helps if you go to the PSET solving sessions.

Lectures were awful. Professor Verlinde spends the first 20 minutes talking about random things and writing nothing on the board. Then he proceeds really slowly through a small amount of theory and never does any example problems. Now we're behind so he tells us to read and understand a bunch of the theory on our own. Then if we want to see example problems we have to go to an extra 3 hour problem session from 7-10pm. The problem sets were laughably easy, and then the exams were insanely hard. This class was taught very poorly and now I'm a physics major who feels like they don't really understand much at all about quantum mechanics.
Overall, a solid physics course. The material was great if you like physics. The lectures were decent if you came prepared. The psets were fine if you started early.
PUT WORK IN

Quantum mechanics, baby.  It will blow your mind.  Beware, though: it is filled with nerds.  That said, it is an awesome conceptual journey, though I wish the course had stayed conceptual through the very end, rather than focusing on applications.
Read the book for sure, and definitely go for office hours.

Start the problem sets early, and go to all the problem sessions. The book makes it very difficult to understand the concepts, but the lectures definitely help. Use external sources on the Internet when you don't understand. #infinitesquarewell

Take it! It's very demanding and will probably make you question your previously-held notions of how the world works, but if Professor Verlinde is teaching again the lectures are great and the topic is just so fascinating.
Take it! This is an interesting course with a relatively light workload. Verlinde is super nice, as well.
Take this class only if you are interested.
Take this class! After taking it, it feels empowering to understand some quantum mechanics.

This is a great course for anyone who wants to learn about QM and has a decent math background. Obviously you have to take this course if you want to be a physics major, but even if you don't, it's very interesting and worth considering.

This is a really cool course!  I liked Verlinde, and thought his lecture style complemented (not mimicked) the textbook.  I felt like I got a lot out of the class and really enjoyed learning it!  The psets can be fairly challenging, but I found it easier than 205.
Verlinde is a confusing lecturer, but the topics are interesting.  Be sure to read the textbook before class.  This course is not easy and also not very organized.
You need to take it.
prereqs: MAT 204 or MAT 217 and PHY 205 or PHY 207. If PHY 104, PHY 106, or ISC 234 have not been completed, one of them must be taken concurrently..
descrip: This is the Physics Department's introductory quantum mechanics course. Its intent is to present the subject in a fashion that will allow both mastery of its conceptual basis and techniques and appreciation of the excitement inherent in looking at the world in a profoundly new way. Topics to be covered include: state functions and the probability interpretation, the Schroedinger equation, uncertainty principle, the eigenvalue problem, angular momentum, perturbation theory, and the hydrogen atom.

title: Found Sound
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Rights and Security in the War on Terrorism
reviews: A lot of reading but very interesting and timely subject matter. If you are interested in law- highly recommend.
Absolutely amazing class! Well worth taking if you're interested in national security and civil rights issues.

Excellent overview of the hot topics in national security law, with very interesting reading materials. The assignments were very fair, although very open-ended, and the seminars were very discussion-based. Prof. Hafetz was great at tying in his personal experiences working in the field with the weekly materials, and invited some great guest speakers.
I thought the supplementary readings were far more interesting that the actual case law; I'd recommend doing those if you are pressed for time.

One of the highlights of my Princeton experience thus far.  Professor Hafetz is a very skilled instructor, and he is an expert in the field of so-called national security law.  The subject matter is fascinating and entirely relevant to our lives as young adults.  So take this class - you won't regret it.
This was my favorite course.  Take it if interested in law
descrip: The struggle against terrorism raises some important legal and policy issues. The issues have taken on particular significance since 9/11, and the initiation of the war on terrorism. This seminar examines this rapidly evolving field. It explores key controversies such as those over indefinite detention, military trials, torture and rendition, targeted killing, and government surveillance. Discussions will be framed against a backdrop of broader legal and constitutional questions such as the separation of powers, the balance between protecting individual rights and national security and the relationship between domestic and international law.

title: The Environment: Science and Policy
reviews: *Take it - very good course.
Decent core -- but not hugely engaging.
Definitely take it if you're curious about the subject or need an STN. Beware, lots of senior woody woo students who score very highly on exams etc. The curve will likely not be in your favor.
Definitely take the course if you're at all interested in environmental issues. I found it to be a fun course that provides a lot of insight into environmental policy.
Don't take it unless you have to. Not a painful class, just really boring and vague.
Eh.
Go to lecture and take good notes!
Good class to fulfill the WWS requirement
Good way to satisfy the WWS science requirement. Lectures are good, if a bit dry, and assignments are short and fair.
Grading felt pretty arbitrary, but probably one of the better WWS science policy departmentals.
I definitely recommend this class for students who wish to fulfill their WWS Science requirement.
I didn't learn very much as someone already interested in the issues, but I think that for someone who knew nothing going in about env. issues, it would have been good.
I think that this course is a good choice for a science policy requirement for WWS. There are interesting policy frameworks that are discussed, though it can get dry.
I think this is a good option for an STN.
I would recommend this course as an intro to a public policy course. The workload isn't too heavy except for the readings. There were a lot of readings.
I would strongly recommend this course for people with a general interest in science policy and the environment.
If there's another departmental you can take to fulfill the environmental requirement, take the other one.
If you need it for a woodrow wilson requirement take another course that fulfills this requirement.
If you take this class, make a reading group. The readings are not directly tested on the exams so individual, in-depth reading is not necessary.

If you're interested in environmental issues, it's a pretty basic but interesting course that focuses much more on the policy issues than the science. If you're not and you have to take it anyway, well, best of luck in staying engaged.

If you're reading this, you're likely trying to pick which Science Policy class to take. This one is very fair on the workload, grading can be a little random, but great intro into environmental issues. Take with Wilcove and Oppenheimer.
It's not a lot of work at all. They warn you if the weekly assignment is going to take more than 15 minutes...
Only take it if you're interested in policy.
Only take this course if you have to for a requirement.

Pretty straightforward and easy for getting the science policy requirement out of the way for WWS. Oppenheimer and Wilcove at least keep you awake most of the time and the material is not hard to grasp. Interesting integration of environmental policy.
Readings aren't important but go to the lectures.
TAKE THIS COURSE! It's not too difficult and you'll learn a lot.
Take a different science policy departmental. This one is easy but too boring to be worth it.
Take it
Take it and learn to be responsible and a critical thinker.
Take it as an underclassman.
Take it for a requirement- not bad for a woody woo science policy class but I wouldn't take if not for a requirement.

Take it!! It's a great introductory course to environmental policy. As someone who had never taken an environmental science course, I found this really interesting. Oppenheimer and Wilcove were both enthusiastic and knowledgeable. Definitely gave me some perspective on the real issues facing our world, and I'm glad I took it.
Take this class if you are interested in gaining broad knowledge about environmental issues. It is a great distribution requirement.
Take this course if Wilcove and Oppenheimer are teaching - such interesting material, not much work at all, awesome lectures.
Take this!
This class was enjoyable.  The right amount of work and they made policy easier to understand.
This course has almost no science in it and the policy is fairly sensible. Do not expect to learn anything substantive about climate, but do expect to be told that the environment is important.

This is a good course. While I do believe that the Science Policy component of WWS is unnecessary, I believe that the environmental issues taught in this class are of the most interesting to WWS students. Take this course, review the lectures for the midterm and final, and you should do fine!

This is a good introduction to science policy. Don't expect to learn as much about the actual science as about the policy and regulatory frameworks, but you should still come out with a basic understanding of the science at hand.
This is a terribly boring course. Don't take it.
This is an extraordinarily poorly-constructed course. It should not be a departmental requirement for WWS majors until the quality of the instruction is vastly better than it is now.

This is interesting, especially if you're interested in environmental issues.  It is important to take even if you're not.  Very engaging lecturers.  It is more policy-focused than I expected so I'm glad I took ENV201 (Intro to the Environment) to learn more about the issues in a scientific way.  Great science policy departmental.
Worst class I've taken at Princeton - very poorly structured and made me uninterested in the material, even though I'm very passionate about science policy!
Would HIGHLY recommend taking this as your science policy requirement for WWS!
You definitely learn to consider things from a science/an environmental perspective but not as much policy as there could be
You have to take it for science policy so it's fine.
You learn about material that is quite relevant and can come away from the course with a good understanding of how to think about environmental issues.

Yup, take it. You're not going to get two more experienced and interesting professors in a room together and talking about the cool stuff they do. If you're a WWS student I would recommend this for the science requirement.
alright
try and keep up with reading
very interesting and well designed course... not repetitive of ENV 201
worth taking as a departmental, but nothing special.
descrip: This course examines the ways domestic US and international environmental regulatory frameworks adopt, interpret and otherwise accommodate scientific information. The course focuses on several case studies, that provide insights into the science-policy interactions which emerge from managing natural resources and environmental risk. Topics include air pollution; climate change; ozone depletion; managing the world's forests, fisheries, and ecosystem services, and global trade in wildlife. Students will explore the science underlying these issues as well as current policies and the range of future policy responses.
