title: Water, Savannas, and Society: Global Change and Sustainability in Africa's Hallmark Ecosystem
prereqs: Assignments will entail some analytical work involving geographic information systems and statistics..
descrip: Savannas have played an important role in shaping human societies, including our evolution as a species. That role will grow, as savannas must be increasingly harnessed to meet growing demands for food, fuel, and fiber. Starting with a primer on savanna ecology, this course will examine the ecological and societal issues surrounding our use of African savannas. A key focus will be to explore tradeoffs between agricultural development, ecosystem services (e.g. carbon storage), biodiversity, and existing livelihoods, how those tradeoffs can be optimized to achieve sustainability, and how climate change will complicate such efforts.

title: European Politics and Society in the 20th Century
reviews: Definitely more geared towards students who have some European background or previous interest in European politics.  But still interesting material nonetheless and worth taking if you're interested in understanding how the modern developed world has emerged out of the two world wars.
Do your best to engage in discussions
Don't take it unless you already know a ton about European politics, because you won't learn much
Easy class but boring.
I would say you should definitely take it; it's one of those courses that broadens your understanding of the world around you in a way that a lot of courses don't.

If you're one of those Model UN or IR kids who already know everything about Europe then you'll be fine, but don't take this to "learn more about Europe" - we barely talk about the actual events and talk more about the implications of the events (I still don't know why WWI happened). Also I HATED THE READINGS because they're all long narratives so it's hard to figure out what the authors are exactly arguing and it's therefore hard to make arguments ourselves in the exams

This is a great introductory course to European history and society. It does a wonderful job of putting today's current debates and problems into context and of covering both Western and Eastern European developments. Professors Muller and Mehnert are also a pleasure to work with and to learn from.
take it!
descrip: The course covers the critical political and social developments of twentieth-century Europe, in particular the consolidation of democracy. It will deal with the legacy of the two world wars, Nazism, Stalinism, the Cold War, decolonization, the development of the European Community, as well as the rise and fall of the welfare state. The course will also address present-day challenges to European countries and the EU: immigration, democratization of the EU, the rise of the far right, and the fate of the Euro. Students will acquire skills of historical analysis as well as research tools associated with political science.

title: Optimal Control and Estimation
reviews: A solid overview of optimal control and estimation.
If you need lectures to learn math, this class isn't bad. But otherwise you might end up getting bored.
If you want to be a good controls engineer, then you should take this course and spend as much time with Professor Stengel as possible.
Prepare well for every lecture beforehand.
Try to keep up and read the book. Start working early on the project!
descrip: An introduction to stochastic optimal control theory and application. It reviews mathematical foundations and explores parametric optimization, conditions for optimality, constraints and singular control, numerical optimization, and neighboring-optimal solutions. Least-squares estimates, propagation of state estimates and uncertainty, and optimal filters and predictors; optimal control in the presence of uncertainty; certainty equivalence and the linear-quadratic-Gaussian regulator problem; frequency-domain solutions for linear multivariable systems; and robustness of closed-loop control are all studied.

title: Advanced Programming Techniques
reviews: A great course to take if you don't have much background in webdev or appdev, it brings you to a state where you can put things together and get them working.
A great way to get practical experience in software development, and you'll become more aware of so many different things about software engineering
A very good course if you're interested in web or app development.
Actually get started on really really working on the project early! It is a lot of work.

As many have said, this is perhaps the most practically valuable course in the COS department. The project is the cornerstone of the course and was one of my favorite experiences at Princeton. The value is not so much in learning how to program an app as in working with a team on an extended project. Thrown into that type of environment helps you develop important skills like task management, conflict resolution, and work delegation. The lectures for the course seem a bit disconnected but Kernighan is insightful and hilarious. The guest lectures were awesome (we had Bjarne Stroustrup, creator of C  , our year). I wouldn't say that this course really teaches app development but instead throws you into an environment where you have to figure a lot of things out on your own. If you are excited by that challenge, then I highly recommend taking it.
Be ambitious and thoughtful, and don't be scared to try new things.
Be ready to prioritize this class as your #1 most time-consuming class. Find your group early on and be ready to pivot to another project idea if your initial one doesn't work out. Have fun.

COS majors: take this class. COS certificate people: take this class. Everyone: TAKE THIS CLASS. It?s fun, engaging and interesting. You'll learn a great deal about web-development and working in teams with other people (which is a critical skill to have in the field of CS). As usual, make sure to start assignments relatively early, and (if possible) try to come into the class with an idea of the final project you want to do -- the sooner you start it the better! Overall, the class is awesome -- you definitely won't regret taking it!
Class isn't great because of lectures or assignments, but only because its Kernighan and you got to work on a practical project.
Cool assignments and cool course for working on a project, but you can do that on your own and not be subject to subjective grading standards

Definitely a worthwhile investment for students to take. This class will really inspire you to learn on your own. We had a very clear goal for our project and I learned as much about my section of our project (databases and scraping) as I would in a class that was focused on just the topic. And being able to teach myself this information was awesome!
Definitely take it.

Definitely take it.  I think this is one of those courses everyone should try to take if they have the chance at Princeton as it is one of the best that approaches the technologies currently being used in industry and also Kernighan is awesome not only as a professor, but just stopping by and talking he is a super awesome guy to know!

Definitely take this course. COS333 is such a good experience and you'll learn so much from it. I didn't have any web dev experience going it but the process of making a website is incredibly valuable and doing it for a class is even better. Only word of caution, make sure to pick your group members carefully. There's always gonna be those people who just scrape by and do nothing and end up sharing the same grade as you, and you can't really help it so stay away from them if you can. But don't be afraid to be someone new. Just don't be that person who does absolutely nothing.
Do it. If you want to learn anything about what it's like to build a real project/app/product, you have to take this class.
Do not take it expecting to learn anything about app development. You will have to do this on your own...
Do not underestimate the difficulty of the final project.
Don't put off the project till the end
Don't slack off on the final project. You will lose friends.
Find a good group early for the design project. Most people come into the class already knowing who they want to work with.
Find a good group of students to work with, and start all assignments/projects early. Also communicate with your group members (more than you think you need to).
Find a good group to work with - not necessarily your friends. I was not happy overall with my group, and it made the past 6 weeks much more stressful than they should have been.

First, don't take it. Waste of time. If you do, make sure you figure out how exactly the project work is going to be divided beforehand. My teammates were really busy with other work and so I ended up doing most of the work on our "team" project, which nevertheless ended up pretty crappy because hey, only one person worked on it and he was supposed to be just doing backend, not writing Django and HTML.

Get a good group for the final project. It needs to be people that you are close with and that are good at programming. Also, take this class later on, not as a sophomore, because it's better to take it after you have had an internship and know how to develop an app as a team.
Go into this course with some knowledge of the project that you would like to do. A little bit of background in the programming languages (HTML, CSS, etc) will go a long way for the final project.
Great class! lectures aren't very helpful for assignments or final project though.

Great class. Don't stop going midway through because Kernighan cold calls in the second half of the semester. But it's great motivation to go, and the guest lectures are actually really interesting and inspiring!

Great course. The assignments are pretty easy, and the final project is super fun to work on. If you want to force yourself to work on something and build it throughout the school year, do this! Moretti is a super fun helper as well.
Highly recommend taking it! You'll learn a lot of useful topics, and gain practical experience.

I would 100% recommend other students, specifically those interested in computer science, to take this course.  I would advise students to attend lectures and pay attention, and also not be hesitant to go to office hours.

I would suggest taking this class if you are interested in learning what it's like to build a product from 0 to 100. Especially I would suggest this class if you want to learn new programming languages that will actually be useful at an internship.

If you are at all interested in COS you should take this class. For the less experienced coders, you will learn how to apply your knowledge and actually create something. For the more experienced programmers, it will be essentially like a semester long hackathon you can dig deep into and make pretty.

If you don't know what 333 is, then you're late. The weekly assignments are auto-graded and suck. The group project is what you make of it. The TAs (read as Moretti) are really harsh. Kelvin is really sweet, though. Start early. Play it a little safe, don't try to learn a million new things to complete the project, because you will fall short

If you have any interesting in computer science, I would strongly recommend taking this class. Definitely find your project group early and remember that these people will be largely responsible for your sanity for about 8 weeks. Also, if you can take this in a less heavy-workload semester, that would be better because I think I could have gotten much more done if I wasn't spending so much time on COS 340 every week.
It is a very fun class. Step 1) find good, motivated teammates. Step 2) make a team meeting schedule, and stick to it. Step 3) profit.
It's a good course for getting exposure to real life programming. You should definitely take it if you get a chance.

It's important to work together, weekly and in person, on your project. You'll be more productive and won't have to scramble at the end. I'm pleased with what my group and I accomplished by the end of the course.
It's the closest class you'll get to actual software engineering, so take it if you'd like a job in that field or if you'd like to build a software project.
Kernighan's great. Take this course if you are considering going into industry. Also, get started on your project early.

Kernighan's lectures are okay, but not terribly exciting. Most people just end up not paying attention anyway. The assignments are cool, and how much you get out of the project largely depends on your group. Overall, I suppose it's a useful course if you want to learn something about web dev and servers and databases, but I dislike web dev, so I didn't really get much out of it.
Make sure you have a group where some people have software dev. experience.
One of my favorites. Should be a required course for COS majors. Nothing else will give you a better experience building something (but definitely take it with friends if you can!)
One of the hallmark courses of Princeton Computer Science, a must-take. Take it with a group of friends or people you know you can rely on for the final project.
Pick teammates who will actually help. PICK TEAMMATES WHO WILL ACTUALLY HELP. This may mean NOT choosing your friends.
Professor Kernighan is one of the best professors at Princeton. Take this class if you want to gain hands on experience with software development.

Professor Kernighan is pretty great -- take it! I would go into the class with a rough idea of who you want to work with for the final project, because much of your experience will depend on having a good group.
Start the project early.  The second part of the course flies by.

Start the project early.  Theres no consequence for not paying attention the second half of the course. But if you pay attention the knowledge will benefit you in the future.  Also, don't build a webapp for your project.  You'll learn a lot about team management, but not that much actual programming.
Start the project early. Spring semester is really fast-paced.

Start thinking about the final project early - would even be good to go into the course with people who you're planning to work with. Pay attention to the lectures, especially the ones on languages/skills that you don't know - Kernighan's expertise in a lot of areas is useful.
Start working early on the project and try not to make your group too big.
Such an awesome class with an awesome professor. The group project gives you invaluable experience in terms of working in a team.
Take it and learn how to code in the real world
Take it if you want to be forced to make a big project.
Take it to build a project you can be proud of. Pick your teammates wisely.
Take it! Just make 100% sure that you select a group for your final project that is composed of dedicated students who won't shy away from the required work.

Take it, especially if Professor Kernighan is teaching it (though still take it even if he is not). It is a great class, and it is the closest thing to a software engineering class we have at Princeton. I gained a lot of real-world skills. Lastly, choose your group project partners wisely.
Take it, especially if you have a group in mind going into it. This kind of stuff isn't really my forte, and I had a good time with the class.
Take it.
Take it. Whether or not you're a COS major. If you don't you're missing out on a crucial part of life.
Take notes in class - they're valuable.
Take the course!

Take this class if you have any desire in coding in the real world. It's not lame assignments but instead an actual project using real languages and frameworks and the end gives you something cool.  And Kernighan is a boss..

Take this class. Especially if you've had an idea you've always wanted to build or if you want to learn python. The first 6 weeks are like a normal class since there is an assignment due every week. The second half of the class is very relaxed up until 2 weeks to your presentation. Then it is grind time.
Take this course! Very practical overview of software engineering - useful for any career that you're planning on pursuing.
Take this course, especially if you haven't built anything before! You get what you put into your project!
Take this course, especially if you want to try building something!

Take this course, it's a great experience. Kernighan is amazing, you need to get to know him. When choosing partners, make sure that you know for certain that they are competent. I chose to work with some people who are working at prestigious tech firms as developers, but they turned out to be horribly ineffective. Choose wisely.
This class was so much fun! Kernighan is a great professor and the project is a blast!

To a large extent, this course is what you make of it. Personally, having had a fair amount of web experience in the past and using a very similar stack on our project meant that our group made a lot of progress quickly, but I didn't learn as much as I would have otherwise. It's a good way to get a systems requirement.
Try hard to make sure your prospective group members will actually pull their weight.

Very fun class that I learned a ton from.  In lecture, you don't cover any one topic in a ton of depth, but briefly cover a ton of different important programming concepts. Then for the project, you learn a ton about a few specific things as you build your app.

Very good course, much more practical assignments and final project than other COS courses. Interesting material, covers a lot of material but not particularly in depth. Start the final project early!
Would recommend. The final project is a lot of work, and you definitely get what you put in.
YES there is no reason not to.
You're on your own for the project. Make sure you have a good team.
absolutely take it.

take it
kernighan is awesome
take it for the project
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: This is a course about the practice of programming. Programming is more than just writing code. Programmers must also assess tradeoffs, choose among design alternatives, debug and test, improve performance, and maintain software written by themselves & others. At the same time, they must be concerned with compatibility, robustness, and reliability, while meeting specifications. Students will have the opportunity to develop these skills by working on their own code and in group projects.

title: Gender and Development in the Americas
descrip: This course examines gender as an integral component of socio-economic development in the United States and areas of Latin America. We give attention to processes of industrial restructuring on a global scale that have increased the participation of women in the labor force and transformed men's employment alternatives. The relationship between gender inequality and social order is a central focus. We give special attention to liberal and Marxian approaches in economics.

title: Environmental Law and Moot Court
reviews: Definitely do the readings because they are very interesting. Also make sure to put time into working with your moot court team to have an effective litigation. It is a little more work than you think, though the overall course load of this class is very manageable.
Definitely take it if you're interested in attending law school!

If you are at all interested in law or the environment, take this course. You will better understand how the bedrock environmental laws of this country are written, how they've been challenged, and how they've been used.
Really engaging and informative class - really worth taking, especially if you want to improve as a public speaker and legal writer.
Take it!

Take it!  Even if you are not interested in environmental law specifically, you'll learn a ton about being a lawyer and will begin the process of honing valuable oral and writing skills that will come in handy in the future.  Professor Hawkins is a truly great teacher and discussion facilitator, and his many career experiences allow him to provide fantastic insight over the course of the semester.  One of the best and most unique courses I've taken at Princeton.

This is one of my favorite classes I've taken here and I would strongly recommend it to anyone who's thinking about going to law school (especially so for those who are thinking about environmental law, obviously).  The moot court exercises were unlike anything else I've done at Princeton and though they were challenging (public speaking is not my forte) they were actually quite fun.  The class itself is fairly low-key, as is Professor Hawkins himself.  However, since most people don't have much of a background in law, you'll definitely still learn a lot.  Overall, 8.5/10, would recommend.

You will learn a lot from this course. And don't be too worried about the workload, it really isn't too bad because your two moot courts will be at least a few weeks away from each other. This course will sharpen your skills of argumentation and your speaking skills.
take this course!!! hawkins is such an an interesting guy. you have a lot to learn
descrip: Examining the relationship between law and environmental policy, this course focuses on cases that have established policy principles. The first half of the seminar will be conducted using the Socratic method. The second half will allow students to reargue either the plaintiff or defendant position in a key case, which will be decided by the classroom jury.

title: Cyber Security
reviews: A great introductory course to cyber security! The workload is very manageable, and the material is interesting.
Take it if you have background or are prepared to do some independent learning on the material to supplement the readings and lectures.

do not take this course.  take ELE 476 - without a doubt the best "cyber security" course offered at princeton in the ELE department and Prof Mittal is a wonderful professor.  clearly describes complex ideas, breaks down topics into easily comprehensible diagrams and then puts them back together.  do yourself a favor and dont waste a credit on this course.
prereqs: No prior security knowledge required. COS109/EGR109 or equivalent. Graduate students without security background are welcome..
descrip: This course surveys the technology underlying secure transactions and safe interactions in cyberspace. Topics include cyber security needs such as confidentiality, integrity, availability, access control, authorization, authentication, non-repudiation, trust, privacy and anonymity. Case studies include smartphone and Cloud Computing security, denial of service attacks, viruses and worms, social networks and cyber-terrorism. Related policy, social and economic issues are also discussed.

title: Education and Inequality
reviews: Highly recommend. Be sure to do the readings to contribute to discussion.
Take it.
There are better classes out there
descrip: In Education and Inequality, students examine the relationship between inequality and public schooling in the United States. Students explore the educational practices and organizational structures through which inequality is produced and reproduced inside schools and how social class, race, ethnicity, gender, and other social differences shape educational outcomes. Additionally, we consider students' different experiences in schools and the ways in which individuals and groups respond to inequality. With a few exceptions, the focus is on K-12 public education with emphasis on urban schools in low-income communities.

title: Ethics - Recent Work in Metaethics and Moral Psychology
descrip: This course will focus on topics in metaethics, normative ethics, moral psychology, and moral epistemology.

title: Current Topics in Theory and Analysis - Theories of African Rhythm
descrip: A review of major theories of African rhythm, including those by Hornbostel, Jones, Arom, Locke, Kubik, Nzewi, Anku and Toussaint. Each theory is considered from the point of view of its internal structure, the ethnographic data upon which it is based, the extent to which it incorporates indigenous perceptions, and the kinds of representational pressures exerted on the theorist by the academic culture for which s/he writes. An analytical paper on a repertory of your own choosing or a comparative critique of existing theories will be required.

title: Plato's Statesman (Half-Term)
descrip: Plato's Statesman remains relatively neglected in political theory and in classical philosophy alike. This course elucidates its relevance to key topics in political philosophy, including: the nature of politics as a science, art or craft; its relationship to other arts and sciences that contribute to society and political life; the relationship between knowledge and law; the relationship between ideal theory and non-ideal regimes. We proceed via a close reading of the dialogue in sequence, with Greek texts to hand and used by those with the ability, but Greek not required to participate, and selected secondary readings.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: This is a continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. The total grading of the course is based 10% on oral presentation and written "poster" communication skills and 90% based on advisors evaluation of the semester's work.

title: Econometric Applications
reviews: A lot of work but very helpful for independent work. Would recommend taking sophomore year if you can.
Definitely take it to learn for your JP and improve your Stata and econometric skills
Definitely worth the time.

Econometrics is a really great skill to have, but the course is a lot of work. A lot. Probably the most work I've ever done for a single course. Well worth your time if you are willing to invest the effort, though.
Great for JP.

I took this as a sophomore and can already tell it's going to be super useful for my JP. WE counted, and we basically wrote the equivalent of 5 JPs over the course of the semester. Also, I get to skip a JP workshop on Stata because I took this, so that's nice. Would definitely recommend you take as a sophomore.
It is a time commitment, but very rewarding. If you are thinking about doing interesting empirical work in economics, take this class. You'll spend a lot of time with it, but also learn a LOT.
It was a course I'd take again. It was painful. but worth it.

It's a LOT of work. 5 page paper single spaced plus tables and figures after analysis every single week. It's like a JP minus the lit review...But it's very worth it. I learned so much. I feel much more prepared to write my thesis, and when I was working on my JP, it felt like just another 313 assignment.

Only take this course if you are interested enough in the material to make doing weekly 10 page problems worthwhile.  If you put in the work though, it will very much be worth it in the end as you will learn a lot. I felt much more prepared to write my JP as a result of taking this course.
Start early on the problem sets.
Take this class if you want to gain proficiency in Stata and data analysis.
This will prepare you for thesis. However, it is a lot of work and many people dropped it because of that.
it's a lot of work but there is no other class available that is as practical or helpful as this course
it's a lot of work!
prereqs: ECO 302 or ECO 312. Additional prerequisite: Calculus.
descrip: This course provides hands-on experience in the art and science of econometric analysis designed to help students to acquire and master the skills necessary to carry out their own empirical research in economics. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable economic models, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. A range of applications will be presented and discussed in class and on problem sets.

title: Portfolio Theory and Asset Management
reviews: Good
Interesting, engaging course if you're at all thinking about going into asset management.
Pay attention in lecture and do the homework!
Take this course if you're interested in finance.
prereqs: ECO 202 (formerly ECO 200), or MAT 222 or ORF 245, ECO 310 (formerly ECO 305), and ECO 362 (formerly ECO 317)..
descrip: This course covers a number of advanced topics related to asset management and asset pricing. Topics include mean-variance analysis, CAPM, APT, market efficiency, delegated money management, stock return predictability, bubbles and crashes, social interaction and investor behavior, security analysts and investor relations, and mutual fund performance and organization.

title: Interacting with Data
reviews: A great opportunity to learn practical side of coding and interacting with data sets. Theory is hard and not really tackled in assignments.
After an entire semester I'm not sure what I retained from this course. Barbara does a terrible job explaining the math behind the models. Don't take it.
Attend all classes and listen carefully.
Avoid avoid avoid. Incredibly poorly structured, and lectures were uninspiring to be kind about it.
Awesome intro to machine learning, definitely take it.
Basically you couldn't get much out of the lecture, so just focus on the assignments.

Basically you will learn nothing from this course, especially from the lectures. You can take this course if you just want a grade; it doesn't take too much time. ORF350 is known to be much better than this course (but also harder). If you are just interested in Machine Learning, you can watch the online courses taught by Andrew Ng at Stanford. (There are two different versions: one on Coursera and one on Youtube.)
Be prepared to do the learning on your own.
Definitely more interesting if you have a little bit of machine learning/research background already.
Definitely take it if you're interested in data science. Lectures are fast-paced, but assignments are not too bad as long as you don't start them the night before they're due.
Do not take this course unless you have to. And if you do, take it with a different instructor.
Do the math by yourself if you want to understand what is really going on. Once you do, you will realize the beauty of this subject.

Experience with Python, or R, will put you ahead of the curve. Be ready to do your own independent review of any methods for which you want a deep understanding. But it will give you pointers to a impressive arsenal of data analysis tools.
Great class but lectures are not good right now. Hopefully will improve.
Have a statistics background or you wont be able to follow the lectures.
I don't think you can really be a computer science student without taking this class. If you're ORFE, however, you've probably seen everything in this class at least once before.
I dropped the class. I think that the projects are not well planned. It assumes knowledge of python but TAs are not proficient in python. Classes should have better examples.
I dropped this class because I found it assumed a great deal of python programming knowledge/ability
I recommend this course for students interested in any kind of data analysis, especially those who want to learn more about probabilistic machine learning.

I took this course purely out of interest and was disappointed. 
Compared to Blei's offerings this course was much more applied, which in my opinion is a good thing. Overall, it has the potential to be a great course, but clearly needs to have kinks worked out of the lectures, and some refinement to the assignments. As it stands currently, I found myself consistently frustrated from the general disorganization and learning more from online resources than I did in lecture. I would recommend skipping the next offering of the course and taking it in 2017 if possible.

I would probably recommend against taking the course unless you just want to get your feet wet with a little applied data science. I have been told of other courses which are more involved and do a better job of actually teaching ML.
If not required, I would recommend other students to consider taking other courses.
If you have a strong background in probability theory math and are a comfortable concentrating on long math-focused lectures then you can actually learn a lot from this class.

If you have the time/energy to engage with the lecture material, do so. You might not get much out of the course otherwise, but you can definitely get by by focusing all of your attention on the projects.

If you want more theory and a better taught class take ORF350. If you want to apply a lot of methods and use R/Python and have a final project to show for, take COS424. This was Professor Engelhardt's first class at Princeton so I hope she improves her lectures, but felt like she talked at students instead of teaching students. Han Liu in ORF350 focuses a lot more on teaching students and making sure students are learning.

If you want to be able to predict the future, take machine learning! If you want to take your guessing abilities to the next level, take machine learning! If you want to learn how to look for and take advantage of patterns in the data around us, take machine learning!
Maybe take a statistics course before taking this class.
If you work with large datasets, take the class!

If you're actually interested in machine learning, take a more theoretical course and learn R / scikit learn on your own time (just google ipython notebooks).

If you want an easy A in exchange for 3-4 hours of work per report, scrambling to think of quiz answers, and googling how to use scikit learn, take this course.
It will satisfy your AI requirement.
It will take a lot of time to understand everything covered in the lectures, which is not necessary to be able to do the projects. The projects themselves were fun and does require much work.
It's ok. Machine learning turns out to not be as interested as the media would have you believe. Take it if you have some general level of interest.
Learn by doing in this class. A solid practical introduction to modern data science techniques. Lectures are so-so but you get a lot out of doing the assignments earnestly.
N/A
Neutral.

Not the most time consuming COS class around. Still challenging. Take if you want to know how to do machine learning, but pay attention if you want to actually understand it. Englehardt is good enough as a lecturer.
Prepare to put in a lot of time commitment.
Recommended to those who really want to learn the basics behind the machine learning;
Spend time reading all of the texts and reviewing the slides to make sure you get all of the specifics learned for each method and when it is applicable.
Start the projects early! They will provide very good experience.

Take ORF350.  Literally better in every single way -- more theoretical, somehow more practical, more well-taught, smarter classmates, and an infinitely better professor.  I took ORF350 and decided to get the COS perspective and instead got a haphazardly slapped together course with random assignment grading and no testing of actual concepts
Take it! It's a great course.
Take it. You'll learn a lot.
Take this course, especially if you want to know what is machine learning and you want to use it practically, not mathematically, later.
The material should be very helpful, but maybe take it with another professor
The math isn't that bad. Probably two or three lectures are math intensive but if you miss those two three lectures, it is usually difficult to catch up.

This is an amazing class for anyone interested in machine learning/data analysis. There was a good balance between concepts/theory and practice. Assignments were interesting, and the earlier you start, the more you can get out of it and you get to expand the limits of the challenge. I think the quizzes were a good motivation for doing the readings and going over the lecture slides. The grading seems generous, but I believe it's the type of course from which you gain as much as you put into it, depending on your motivation and interest.
Would definitely recommend this course if you are interested in the field of data analysis.
Yes, if you want to learn something about big data and data mining, I recommend this class.
You don't need to understand all the material in order to do well on the assignments, but it definitely helps.
okay class, assignments aren't too difficult
take since ml is interesting.

this is a course that you could learn nothing in if you don't force yourself to. that said, the projects allow you to gain some good experience if you care about them. i learned a lot about scikit learn but not much about what i was implementing.
prereqs: MAT 202 and COS 126 or equivalent or permission of instructor..
descrip: Computers have made it possible, even easy, to collect vast amounts of data from a wide variety of sources. It is not always clear, however, how to use those data, and how to extract useful information from them. This problem is faced in a tremendous range of business and scientific applications. This course will focus on some of the most useful approaches to the problem of analyzing large complex data sets, exploring both theoretical foundations and practical applications. Students will gain experience analyzing several types of data, including text, images, and biological data.

title: Integrated Building Systems
reviews: As stated above, be super smart about dividing up the work and finding a way to make sure everyone chips in somewhat equally. Also be super smart about time management!
Be prepared to have a lot of work during finals.
Enjoy the labs! Be less ambitious with the building project.
I advise you to have fun in this class because it has very high fun potential especially lab sessions. Educational too by the way.
It's excellent course to get real!
descrip: An introduction to building systems and the methods of construction used to realize design in built form. First half of the course will be an overview of the primary systems, materials and principals used in construction of buildings and the fabrication of elements, through lectures and accompanying lab sessions. The second half will be an explanation of the means by which information is communicated from designers to fabricators, current standards in the practice of architecture, and practice's relation to changes in methods of fabrication and project delivery.

title: Intermediate Urdu II
prereqs: URD 105 or equivalent proficiency. See instructor..
descrip: This is a continuing proficiency-based course which refines and expands previously acquired linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Focus is on expanding vocabulary, mastering more complex grammatical structures, and acquiring idiomatic expressions. Use of authentic Urdu materials from print and electronic media, literature, and films. Equal emphasis on all skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). Various aspects of the target language culture will be integrated with instruction. Activities will be conducted in Urdu and classes will be interactive.

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Take it and do your best!
prereqs: CHI 405 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Continued reading and discussion of scholarly writings on modern Chinese literature. This course also exposes students to the social issues China has faced in recent years, while discussing various aspects of contemporary Chinese society.

title: Oil to Ozone: Chemistry of the Environment
reviews: By far the worst class I have taken at Princeton.  Anne's lectures are good, but Morel is the worst teacher I have ever had.  Also don't expect to learn any chemistry.
Collaborate with other students on the problem sets because not much guidance is given on how to complete them.
Easy class
It's a fairly easy course, but don't be afraid to ask questions.
Overall a cool class

TAKE THIS COURSE FOR THE LOVE OF GOD. The professors are fantastic and the information you learn makes you an informed citizen, which is crucial to our democracy. Everyone at Princeton should take this course.
Take it if you are interesting in how the world is affected by people, very interesting.
Take it if you're interested in global warming and atmospheric chemistry
Take it if you're interested.  The material is not difficult.
Take it.
There are better chem classes.
This class is much more appropriate for GEO or ENV than CHM.

This class is very interesting, but grading is very sporadic and often makes no sense. If you need to, take it, but grades were often lower than they should be. Not because students weren't knowledgeable, but because of arbitrary rubrics that were not made known to the students at the time.
This is an interesting course and can be a good introduction to environmental science. There is not too much chemistry.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or equivalent. (Consult instructor.).
descrip: The chemical background of environmental issues. Topics include energy and fuels, global change, ozone, air pollution, chemistry of natural waters, pesticides, and heavy metals.

title: How the Tabby Cat Got Her Stripes
descrip: See website

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Basic)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. Focus is on the determination of macroeconomic variables - such as output, employment, prices, and the interest rate - in the short, medium, and long run, and addresses a number of policy issues. Discusses several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Twelve Ecologies of the Envelope
descrip: This seminar is aimed to develop and discuss a new theory of the building envelope, able to replace the historical disciplines of the facade. The focus lies between technology and theory and the method will be research driven. The hypothesis of this seminar is that the envelope's performance occurs primarily through material embodiments rather than through superficial, ornamental representation. The discussion will depart from the concept of facade material assemblage, which addresses the evolution of artificial ecologies as a method. We have identified 12 facade assemblages to structure this theory, and we will devote one session to each.

title: Computational Neuroscience
reviews: Definitely take it.
Fun, informative, and not much work. Take if you're interested in how the brain carries out computations. Essentially every model is based on large systems of differential equations.

Great course to take if you have a quantitative  background and want to see how mathematics is used to model neuroscience. We do not deal with computational issues like algorithm runtime or proofs of correctness, so if you're looking for more hardcore computer science topics look elsewhere.
I would definitely recommend the course. It will give you a great look into computational neuroscience and the instructor and preceptor are amazing.

It is a fairly relaxed course with little workload if you have some background in programming (matlab specifically). The more time you spend doing the readings and participating in class discussions, the more you will gain out of this course.
Look at the paper figures.
Read papers thoroughly and go to lab

TAKE IT! The material itself is not easy (though fascinating), but the course itself is very doable. You will learn to understand quantitative papers from start to finish in great detail, which is incredibly rewarding!

TAKE THIS COURSE, TAKE IT, TAKE IT. 
It might be scary at the beginning because the papers are so hard, but stick with it and it will be worth every minute. Professor Brody and the TA Alex are simply the best. I never though a Wednesday night lab could be fun, but I guarantee you it was great! Keep up with the labs though, it kinda sucks to have to write 5 reports all at once. And do take the time to read the papers, it'll be so much more enriching and engaging
Take it if you're interested in learning how to actually read a neuroscience paper.
Take this course (especially if Prof. Brody and Alex are teaching it)! This is definitely my favorite engineering/modelling course that I've taken thus far at Princeton!
You won't regret taking this course. It is mind blowing.
prereqs: Basic linear algebra, probability, ordinary differential equations, and some programming experience, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Introduction to a mathematical description of how networks of neurons can represent information and compute with it. Course will survey computational modeling and data analysis methods for neuroscience. Topics will include representation of visual information, spatial navigation, short-term memory, and decision-making. Two 90 minute lectures, one laboratory. Lectures in common with NEU 537

title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.

title: Queer Utopias: Culture, Fantasy, and the Formation of Sexual Identities
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of reading and engage fully and critically. If these are subjects you're interested in, it's very worthwhile.

I would recommend this course because Dr. Minto is a great instructor, giving small lectures at the beginning of class on the history of the period we're reading about as well as participating in and facilitating engaging group discussions. The readings, though the load is rather heavy, are very interesting, and it was a great class!
Minto is a nice guy, but his lecturing style is a bit dry. He also doesn't make much effort to incorporate some diversity into his syllabus.
Take it.
Take this course. It is fantastic. The reading is demanding, so don't do this with a 5-course semester (which was my mistake), but I highly recommend this class.

The class is worth taking if you're interested in queer studies/history or gender studies. You definitely don't have to be LGBT to take and enjoy this class though! Sometimes the reading felt arbitrary and the energy of discussion largely depended on if anyone actually did the reading. The end assignment of choosing your own queer utopia was pretty cool and Dr. Minto is a pretty cool guy, so I firmly believe the course will be better the second time around. Overall yes, take it.

The course is fascinating and will give you a look into queer history that you won't get anywhere else.  It's still in its infancy and will undoubtedly get better with time; Dr. Minto is dedicated to making the class relevant and inclusive, and takes student suggestions for the syllabus.  But don't expect a very standard, rigidly organized curriculum.

This is an excellent course. Professor Minto is a great lecturer, selects consistently engaging readings and is a genuinely kind person. As someone with less experience in the department, I found the course very welcoming and eye-opening.
take it!
descrip: This course explores the role of culture and fantasy in the construction of lesbian, gay, transgender, and other queer individual and group identities over the C20th. What material conditions have allowed queer utopias to be conceived and by whom? In what ways have dominant cultures imposed themselves on queer fantasy lives? How has queer world-making blurred the boundary between the real and the ideal, the social and the imaginary, the personal and the political? Each week we will focus on one or more period texts--diaries, photos, stories, songs, plays, or films--analyzing what they evidence about queer imaginations and communities.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: 259 is definitely tougher than 258, but more interesting in that it's more problem solving than rote-memorization. Start studying for the tests in advance, and don't let the open-book policy fool you-- you really don't have time to search through your notes.

Be very meticulous with the lectures, take good notes and maybe even record lectures and write down the time that corresponds with the slide. Go to office hours or to coffee with Professor Niv, she is an awesome person and very easy to talk to! Make cheat sheets and review your notes very well before exams so you know where the info you need is written.
Decently interesting lectures, zero homework if you're in the precepts. Tests are open-note so a really easy p/d/f.
Disappointing after 258
Do not take unless you have to.
Dont take it unless you really like neuroscience
If you have an interest in Neuro you may enjoy this course but I thought it was poorly taught.

If you liked 258 and are more into high level systems vs. molecular neuroscience, take this class. Very good overview of all the exciting and fun areas of cog sci and also a very good compliment to 258. Manageable, interesting, fun, and makes you philosophize all the time. Definitely form study groups before quizzes and tests - it helps immensely.
If you're at all interested in the subject, take this course!!
It's an interesting class. Tests are long so you pretty much have to think and write at the same time, which isn't the best thing ever.
STUDY for the quizzes and final even though they are open book - STUDY STUDY STUDY otherwise you won't do well - USE PIAZZA it can help your grade
Take it if you're interested.
Take it! It's really cool, they do everything they can to help students do well.
Take it! This is a fantastic course and Yael is a fantastic professor.

Take it. Definitely much more interesting than NEU 258/201 since you actually learned about current research going on instead of just biological mechanisms that are hard to understand. Also I like the fact that Professor Niv lets us do open note exam because you don't have to memorize all the details and instead get a greater understanding of the materials
Take the class but also read the textbook and you have to spend a lot of time to do well in the class. But it was enjoyable.
The book is a lot and the readings are listed as optional, but it is super-helpful to at least skim a lot of portions, especially for lectures you didn't understand as well.

The class is very interesting for anyone who has interest in neuro. It may be somewhat repetitive from 258, but I didn't take 258 and I enjoyed the class! Either record the lectures or pay attention.The book has many of the graphs/studies in the lecture slides, so you can always refer back. To study for the exams, make sure you understand every single study, the IV, DV, what they were testing, why they did the variables the way they did.
Unless you really really know that you are interested, don't take this course. If you are, I'd recommend taking it with the other lecturer that alternates years with Yael.
Would only take this course if you have to for the certificate.

Would take it with the other prof tbh. Heard that teaching style and exam format was more in tune with Graziano's.. It's difficult coming into 259 when you're accustomed to Graziano's teaching style and straightforward exams..
only do it if you're pursuing neuro.
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention, language, memory, learning and decision making and executive functions of the frontal lobe. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed. Precepts will discuss primary literature pertaining to the topics covered in class.

title: Imagining Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Algebra
prereqs: Undergrads must request permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebra. More specific topic details provided when the course is offered.

title: Olmec Art
reviews: Take it! This is a wonderful course. Professor Just teaches very well, and you will get lots of opportunities to examine objects from the PUAM collection.
Take this if you're at interested in archaeology, art history, or Mexico.
very cool opportunity to get up close and personal (you get to touch the art) with ancient art.
descrip: This course surveys Olmec and related material culture spanning roughly 2000-500 B.C., including architecture and monumental sculpture, ceramic vessels and figurines, and exquisite small-scale sculpture in jade and other precious materials. Of central theoretical importance is the question of how we understand and interpret art from a distant past, especially without the aid of contemporaneous written records. We will focus on original works of art, including works in the Princeton University Art Museum and in regional collections. Issues of authenticity, quality, and provenance related to these works will also be considered.

title: Interpretation - Experience
descrip: A genealogy and a practicum. The course will explore the varieties of experience from Montaigne and Bacon to Dewey and Agamben, with attention to epistemology and aesthetics, science and religion; readings will guide a series of practical experiments in the transfiguration and/or instauration of knowledge, and of the classroom as a home for it. Our shared project will be to imagine how humanistic inquiry might hold itself open to the demands of a concept that refuses concepts.

title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
reviews: A lot of readings, but they are all important
Do not fall behind on the readings, it is so hard to catch up.
I would, but only if they were interested in the particular field.

If you have even the slightest interest in politics, or even more generally in questions about development, democracy, ethnic conflict, etc., absolutely take this class. If you do all the readings and engage in lecture, you will come away with a tremendous breadth and depth of knowledge about comparative politics. Try to get Grigore as your preceptor; he's a great guy and precepts were always fun and very informative.

If you take this course, be prepared for a lot of reading each week. I would suggest doing the readings as they can help you to understand the different debates which can also help you craft an effective argument for your final paper.

If you're at all interested in the domestic politics of countries outside the United States, this is the perfect course for you. A lot of people get comparative politics and international relations switched, so watch out for that! This is a really great course to take for the WWS politics requirement. The workload is very reasonable, and the professor is very organized and presents concepts well. I felt like I learned so much in this course, and it really aligned well with my interests. Take it!
It's okay - pretty broad  class / covers a lot of themes, wasn't my favorite politics course here but contains important concepts to learn for future classes

Make sure to do all the readings. They contain the core of what you will discuss and be tested on. Also, this is a very broad course, so only take it if you are interested in gaining a wide perspective on the discipline of comparative politics.
Only take it if you are strongly interested in the subject matter.
Really enjoyed this course.
Take it - but make sure to get Gpop as your preceptor.
Take it if you're in any way possibly interested in politics. But keep in mind you'll have a solid 3 hours of readings each week.
Take it. It's a fun politics course that isn't to hard. Yes, a lot of reading but the exams weren't too hard and the paper wasn't that bad. Overall, awesome experience. Now I might major in politics.
Take this course even if you are not a politics major!

This course is interesting and Professor Pop-Eleches is a good lecturer. The majority of the readings are political theory readings. There is a Dean's Date paper and take-home final at the end of the semester so be aware of that.

This is a fine course, but be warned that there are a lot of readings and they are all very theoretical. Examinations are also very hard and don't really test the content of the course so much as your time management skills, which can be really frustrating. But, if you are interested in the subject matter, you may end up really enjoying this course, and it is fairly manageable.

This is a wonderful course! It gives you a lot of fundamentals necessary for deeper understanding in other politics courses and the professor is very kind. The readings were do-able and the exams were easy to prepare for as well.
Wonderful class. Take it, even if Politics is not your thing. Great professor and material!
good class
take it if you are interested in the subject. other then that its pretty hard.
take it. Lots of readings though
descrip: This course surveys institutions of government and explores the role of government in economic and social affairs in developing as well as advanced industrial countries. The overarching theme is the relationship between capitalism, democracy, and economic development. The course also provides an introduction to the comparative method: using some major books in Comparative Politics as examples, we will explore how different scholars use cross-national comparison to gain insight into political dynamics.

title: The Ottoman Empire, 1300-1800
reviews: Highly recommended.  You will learn a lot about a very interesting period from a very kind and very smart professor.  You will also learn a lot about how to do history.
I would strongly recommend this course.
This is an interesting course. It is a lot of reading, though.
descrip: This course surveys the history of the world's most enduring Islamic state, the Ottoman Empire, from its beginnings in the fourteenth century through its decline in the early 1900s. At its height, the Ottoman Empire ruled over the Middle East, the Balkans, modern day Turkey, Central Europe and much of the Mediterranean. The history of the Ottoman Empire is one essential to understand the modern Middle East and the Balkans.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese II
prereqs: JPN 305 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, listening and speaking. Reading materials include novels, essays, etc. Video materials are also used to enhance listening skills. The goal of this course is "advanced" level according to the ACTFL/ETS guidelines.

title: Dostoevsky
reviews: Definitely take if you have an interest in Dostoevsky-I would recommend a relatively light course load otherwise, since the reading can be a lot at times.
Definitely take it if you have any interest in Russian literature!
Dostoevsky changed my life.

I highly recommend this course for anyone who loves Russian literature. Professor Chances is great and if you are in a class with an engaged group of students, the discussions can be exciting and very fruitful. Of course, the readings are great!
TAKE THIS COURSE. It's a lot of reading, and you can't do it all the night before. But it's so much fun
Take it! A lot of reading but it's one of the most intellectually stimulating courses I've ever taken.

This is an amazing course! Definitely take it. The books get longer as the semester goes on, so be aware that as your other class work picks up, so will the reading. When this class is offered in the Fall, I would think it would be a good idea to read one of the longer books (Brothers Karamazov, Demons, or The Idiot) over the summer. Take it! Prof. Chances is really great and there was never a dull moment in seminar. The workload is very manageable, especially if you're conscious of how many pages you have to read for the following weak and plan accordingly. There are two papers of very doable size and class participation. Take it!!

This is the best literature class at Princeton. You should definitely take it. The readings are very interesting, so although there is a lot it is manageable. Make sure the people you're taking it with are cool.
descrip: The goal of the course is to acquaint students with the evolution of Dostoevsky's writings. A multi-faceted approach is used for coming to grips with the works. The focus is on stylistic, ethical, religious, philosophical, and political dimensions of his art as well as on ways in which Dostoevsky fits into the cultural milieu of his time. Both non-Slavic Department and Departmental students are welcome.

title: Sociological Theory
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of reading.  You may not be able to finish it all, but I'd recommend trying.  It's actually pretty interesting once you get used to reading dense, theoretical arguments.
Be prepared to read and write a lot.
Do the readings well the first time and go to lecture and take good notes. That's all that's needed to do well.
Go to lecture and take notes.
I would take it if you're interested in sociological theory and soc classics; if not, you will be bogged down by the reading and likely not enjoy yourself.
If you know that you want to be a soc major, take this class sophomore spring.
If you take this class, make sure you dedicate enough time to the readings as they are lengthy and complex. Also participate in precept! Take this course if you are interested in philosophy.

Keep up with the readings and talk to Professor Gross in his office hours. If you're engaged more than the rest of the class, you'll have a fun time. A lot of SOC majors take this just for the requirement, and that's a shame - Professor Gross is a gift to this university, and more people should take it for the incredible works that are taught in the class.
Professor Gross is awesome, it is a lot of reading though so be prepared! Really rewarding class.

Take it if you must, Neil did a great job. But it's a hard subject matter to grapple with if you just wanna take it for general interest you will be way deeper in fine detail than you might have wanted.

The precept is highly disorganized and unhelpful despite highly dense, unrealistically long readings which leaves many students feeling lost and frustrated. Only take it if you are a soc major and have to take it.
The theories taught are interesting and definitely worth knowing, but be aware that a less than stellar professor can make for a kind of awful experience.

You have to take the course as a Sociology major, and I think this information is foundational for a Sociologist. But the work expectations were too high for such a new and unfamiliar way of thinking about Sociology.
descrip: This course introduces students to sociological theory through a study of classic contributions to the field. Although we will pay close attention to the social and intellectual contexts in which the theorists covered developed their ideas--and thus to the circumstances in which sociology was born--our main focus will be the ideas themselves. These remain indispensible for understanding modern society.

title: Photographic Imagination, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Composing Opera
descrip: A look at what it means to write opera today. Works such as Glass's Einstein on the Beach, Reich's The Cave and Ashley's Private Lives have exploded the conventions of opera. Meanwhile, narrative operas employing librettos and operatic singers continue to abound and to push the genre forward. Examples include operas by Adams, Ades, and Saariaho. The seminar will examine the various approaches towards composing an "opera" today, including how commissioning structures and production issues may influence the type of work that results.

title: Topics in Music from 1400 to 1600 - Renaissance Music
descrip: The sacred music of Josquin Des Prez (c.1455-1521): masses, motets, musical styles, reception, performance practice, analysis, aesthetics.

title: Financial Accounting
reviews: *If you're interested. You learn some interesting aspects of finance / accounting.
A great class to take! It teaches you the ABC's of thinking about business and the corporate world. Good for anybody no matter what concentration.

Definitely take it if you're considering, as the knowledge is very useful and this the only accounting course at Princeton in the sense that it is not theoretical and very much applicable to what you would do when working in business, much like a business school course.
Do not take this class.
Don't take it
Easiest way to learn accounting is taking this class. Better off learning it now, especially if you're going into finance or corporate management.
Fantastic class. You might think it would be dry, but Professor Weil makes it interesting. Applications of the material are very useful.
I would strongly recommend this course. Professor Weil is excellent and makes accounting interesting. The material is useful and taught well.
Not a good PDF. Too much work and you will get lost.
Prof Weil is incredible. Must take class for anyone even considering finance-related field. Do not be deterred by the 3 hour class - he keeps it very entertaining and the time flies by.

Roman Weil is one of the best professors I've had - not just in knowledge, but in wisdom. I definitely think I understand companies on a business level better now, especially with regards to the accounting that is glossed over in 362 and 363.

He says the class is difficult, but he's very transparent, which in my experience makes classes much less stressful. Highly recommended, and I hope Professor Weil returns.
Take it if you want a solid background in financial accounting for a finance internship.
Take it if you work in corporate finance (e.g. investment banking), you'll need the accounting foundation.
Take it. Especially with Weil. If you plan on holding down a job in the future, you will probably come across some accounting.
Take it. Roman Weil is an amazing instructor.
Take the course if you want to learn more about accounting for internships/later in life.

The course is fairly chill, and the assignments are not hard especially since you already have answers to all of them (book questions). The material covered is interesting and accounting is a fantastic skill to have. But the class is a little inefficient time wise since you could learn a lot more in the same time. Also, Prof. Weil is great, he is really quirky and funny. I would say take it if you want a chill class, but getting a good great is extremely easy so you could pdf as well.
This course will definitely be a little easier if you are an Econ major or if you have some basic knowledge of/background in finance.
This was my favorite course this semester. Although challenging at first, the material becomes easier to understand as the semester goes on.
do the practice problems
n/a
prereqs: ECO 310.
descrip: The course deals with the judgments required to analyze and communicate information about economic events of a firm through financial accounting. The first several classes deal with concepts of asset, liability, owners' equity, revenue, expense and the accounting processes that lead to the financial statements. Next follows an analysis of the components of financial statements: long-term liabilities, revenue recognition and income management, inventories, long-term assets, impairment and leasing chaos, off-balance sheet financing, and current controversies such as income tax inversions. Rudiments of financial analysis and valuation.

title: Tibetan Buddhism
reviews: Boring lectures, mandatory attendance, no laptops allowed. You're going to be bored.
DEFINITELY TAKE IT! Fairly easy in terms of work yet mind-blowing in terms of the content and the way it's taught!! You'll get a lot out of it!
Definitely take this course. If you need an EM, this is the best course for that if you want a chill course.
Do it!!
Do your readings and you will be fine.
Easy PDF
Easy PDF and not too hard to get an A in if you put in any effort at all.
Fairly interesting. Good way to fulfill EM requirement. Weekly postings and class attendance sign-ins make it not ideal to P/D/F.
Fairly lightweight class.
Go for it. Read the readings!
Good EM.
Good for a 5th course, not too much work
Good for a different perspective on the world, but meditation is more important to understand these concepts.
Good introduction to a foreign religion if you're interested. Pretty laid back PDF structure if you're just looking to meet your EM requirement.
Great class!

I strongly recommend this course if you're looking for an EM or just an interesting class that will teach you about another culture.  The reading load was very manageable, and I found the readings and lectures to be very engaging.
I would take it if Buddhism interests you
If you are interested in learning about Buddhism it is worth taking this course.

If you're really interested in Buddhism and want to learn more, this class could be worth taking. It's not fantastic. If you're just looking for an EM, I'd say keep looking. Even though I really enjoyed the material it could be a struggle to sit through the lectures (attendance mandatory) and the first half of the semester is a lot more interesting.
Interesting class. There are many facets to buddhism, so I would suggest taking a more broad buddhism course before diving into the particulars.
Interesting course! Do the readings and you will actually learn something.
It is a fun course if you are interested in the topic. Don't take it if you are not really interested, in that case it becomes dry.

It was okay. Not the greatest thing, but definitely nowhere near bad. It'll be interesting as long as you have any interest in Buddhism. It is also very different from other forms of Buddhism, so sometimes it can get really surprising and fascinating.
It's not very hard and pretty interesting. Go to lecture because it's really helpful for the midterm and final.
Keep up on reading and participate in discussion.

Knock knock.
Who's there?
Gopher.
Gopher who?
Gopher it!
Make sure to do the readings carefully.
Not much work and very interesting material

Prof clearly doesn't like PDFing students, so if you want to take it PDF for the distro (ie most people in the class) find another class to take. If you're genuinely interested in Tibetan Buddhism, have at it...
Stay on top of the readings.
Super easy and fairly interesting.
TAKE IT!
Take it as an interesting EM.
Take it if buddhism interests you.
Take it if you need an easy EM course and consider PDFing it. It's not the best course, but it does provide some interesting perspectives.
Take notes on the readings and bring questions to precept.
Take summary notes on each of the readings and films; this way, it'll be easier to find and compile information needed to answer the prompts for the exams.
This class is boring but fairly straightforward. If it helps, the information/readings are actually quite helpful.

This course was terrible. The lectures are mandatory and extremely boring (like the professor physically passes around a sign-in sheet.) They also didn't seem to delve deeply into the subject and were lacking a lot in passion. It was just superficially learning about something new from week to week, but never really adding to a worthwhile core understanding of what could be, and should be, an interesting subject. The work assigned was trivial but mandatory, even if you were PDF'ing. I thought the professor handled some things very unprofessionally. I definitely DO NOT recommend this class. It was awful, and way more work than it should be for what you can get out of this class. And PDF'ing does not make it any better--trust me.
This is a good class. You'll learn a lot about Tibetan Buddhism and it's not a lot of work. I recommend it.

This is a really interesting course and teaches you about a culture you probably have little knowledge on/misconceptions.  Some students may not like the no technology and attendance marked at every precept and lecture, but I didn't mind these protocols.
go to lecture and take good notes
i would take it. its easy limited work and if you get a good precept its not that bad.
it's a good class but i lost interest in it by the end of the semester
maybe take this class as a PDF
not hard but hard to stay focused in class
solid class to pdf
stay on top of weekly posts
take it!
take it! you'll learn a lot and won't be stressed about it
descrip: This course is a survey of the Buddhist traditions of Tibet, focusing on the doctrines and practices associated with the main schools of tantric ritual and meditation. Topics covered will include: the origins of the distinct forms of Buddhism in Tibet; Buddhist responses to historical challenges; the special relationship between politics and religion in Tibet; the role of Tibetan Buddhist scholars and scholasticism; Tibet through the lenses of the Chinese, and the West; and Tibetan Buddhist art.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
descrip: Methods, sources, and problems of research in Chinese thought, including examination of some broad interpretations of intellectual development of China. A reading knowledge of Chinese or Japanese is required for the study of selected problems areas through seminar discussion, oral reports, and research papers.

title: Poetics - The Black Radical Tradition
descrip: This seminar will sketch the contours of what Fred Moten calls "the Aesthetics of the Black Radical Tradition": a resistance born at the intersection of avant-garde music, radical politics and a philosophy of blackness. Evie Shockley identifies such work as part of a "renegade poetics": one perpetually rebelling against both the canons of "African-American" and "avant-garde" literatures. Accordingly, the class will aim to complicate, confuse, and provocatively prod such categories, with implications for how we have told--and how we are going to be telling--literary history.

title: Seminar in History of Photography - American Art Photography from Pictorialism to Modernism
prereqs: Open to all graduate students and to undergraduates with permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar, organized around a major exhibition devoted to American Photo-Secessionist Clarence White planned for the PU Art Museum, questions the dichotomy between Pictorialism, an art photography movement stereotypically associated with soft focus and sentimental subjects, and modernism. Topics include the politics of the Arts and Crafts movement; the development of advertising photography during World War I; and women photographers in the Clarence White School. Students work extensively with White's archives and prints in the PU Art Museum. There is a cyanotype and gum print workshop during spring break.

title: Risk Analysis
reviews: Class = all ORFE majors, and the concepts are almost all covered in ORF309.  It's a simpler version with word problems applied to civil engineering, but the midterm is incredibly poorly written, so you may very well get a bad grade :(
Definitely take it if you are interested in probability and statistics.
Don't take it unless you have to. It was not a difficult PDF option for the EMS certificate though.
Great ORFE departmental. Not too demanding and interesting material.
It's an okay class.
Make sure you understand the homework assignments.
Take ORF 309 before!
Tried to get started on the project early.
Very interesting and some great supplemental information
textbook helps but not too much.
prereqs: Basic probability and statistics course..
descrip: Fundamentals of probabilistic risk analysis. Stochastic modeling of hazards. Estimation of extremes. Vulnerability modeling of natural and built environment. Evaluation of failure chances and consequences. Reliability analysis. Decision analysis and risk management. Case studies involving natural hazards, including earthquakes, extreme winds, rainfall flooding, storm surges, hurricanes, and climate change, and their induced damage and economic losses.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: A.M. Homes is really fun and creates a great workshop/classroom environment. I love how honest she is with her feedback. Definitely try to get her as your professor.
A.M. is a great teacher to study with! Take her workshop!
A.M. is very easygoing and very helpful via office hours and general comments. There was quite a bit of work but classes were fun.
Always take a cwr course.
Creative Writing classes have been my favorite at Princeton, and Professor McGrath is outstanding?talented, insightful, and incredibly friendly. You will definitely improve as a writer!
Creative writing classes are FANTASTIC but Professor McGrath is not the most exciting professor.
I highly recommend this course. Patrick is a great instructor and will provide very helpful notes for your stories. He also has a great voice, which never hurts.
I would not take this class with Patrick McGrath. He's a nice man but not a great professor.
If you take it with A.M., do it.  She's really great at running a very collaborative workshop.
Take it seriously and this will make you a better writer. Strongly recommend
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level fiction courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of fiction for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Intellectual History of China from the Ninth to the 19th Century
prereqs: A prior course in East Asian Studies is desirable but not required..
descrip: The course centers on the changing role of the intellectual elite -- how they were recruited, their relationship to holders of powers, their attitudes toward the past and their cultural heritage. The aim of the course is to provide a clearer understanding of the burdens and privileges of intellectuals in Chinese society.

title: Beginner's Greek: Attic Prose
prereqs: CLG 101 or Permission of Instructor. CLG 101-102 are a unit. CLG 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. CLG 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year short selections of Attic prose will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Numerical Algorithms for Scientific Computing
reviews: Don't expect too much from the lectures, but the problem sets and final project make the course a worthwhile learning experience.
