Interesting course. Covers lots of material very fast.
This is a very useful and important course if you want to do computational science.
Very helpful experience. Assumes basic coding experience (preferably in C or Fortran) and knowing what a Taylor series is.
descrip: A broad introduction to numerical algorithms used in scientific computing. The course will begin with a review of the basic principles of numerical analysis, including sources of error, stability and convergence of algorithms. The theory and implementation of techniques for linear and nonlinear systems of equations, and ordinary and partial differential equations will be covered in detail. Examples of the application of these methods to problems in physics, astrophysics and other disciplines will be given. Issues related to the implementation of efficient algorithms on modern high-performance computing systems will be discussed.

title: The Soviet Empire and Successor States
reviews: Absolutely.
As I'm sure is noted in other reviews, the reading load is heavy. Might be a better choice for second year PhD students who have fewer requirements in other courses.
Highly recommend.
If it is impossible to finish the readings, at least skim those that you cannot complete.
descrip: This seminar covers the history of the Soviet Union from inception until dissolution and slightly beyond. The readings are exhaustive and comprehensive, with particular attention paid to institutions, empire, the cultural foundations of politics, and the world context.

title: Financial Modelling
prereqs: ECO 525/FIN 525 and ECO 526/FIN 526 (526 may be taken concurrently)..
descrip: Advanced asset pricing and corporate finance including a selection from: models of financial crises and bubbles; interaction between finance and macroeconomics, derivative pricing in incomplete markets; tests of asset pricing models and associated anomalies; models of investor behavior; financial econometrics, including tests of asset pricing models and methods for high frequency data. Pre-requisites: ECO 525 and 526 (526 may be taken concurrently).

title: Econometrics and Public Policy: Applications: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: WWS 507B.
descrip: Provides hands-on experience in the application of econometric methods to policy issues. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable hypotheses, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. The course will be taught using a set of cases in which students apply quantitative methods covered in WWS 507b to data in order to answer specific policy questions. Emphasis will be placed on interpreting and writing about results.

title: Elementary Korean II
reviews: Definitely take this class! If you enjoy learning languages and are interested in Korean, this is the class for you. The teachers are really chill and understanding and engaging. The workload can be a little long sometimes, but it's never very difficult.

Definitely take this course. The professors are phenomenal. However, be prepared to learn a language that is different from the ones you have already learned if you do not know any character based languages.
Do your homework and everything else on TIME! Then the class is super easy to manage and fun at the same time.

Go to Korean table! It's really fun and not at all intimidating. Plus a free meal if you're an upperclassman. Korean is super fun and the professors are all really really nice. A wonderful course to take freshman, sophomore, or senior year (maybe not so much junior year). You become quite conversational in a very short time, unlike some other beginners language classes. It is a big time commitment, though, so make sure you really want to learn the language.
I would advise students to take the class if they are interested in getting a introduction in Korean.
If you took 101, it's basically the same.
KOR department here is boss. If you took 101, take 102. I have certainly learned a lot, but don't expect to be on some next level amazingness in terms of your Korean skills after this class

TAKE IT! The korean department is incredible and you will learn a lot even in one year! Be ready to work hard though! There are two quizzes each week and homework every night. The tests are also difficult so beware.
The workload is very manageable!
? ??? was a great teacher for the drill sessions!
prereqs: KOR 101 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 101. Continued development of proficiency in basic communication.

title: Introduction to English Literature: 14th to 18th Century
reviews:
-Do the readings but don't exceed more than 4 hours a week on them; skim reading is okay. Also, do the reading early so you will have more time to write the weekly exercises! 
-The weekly papers are tricky--they are short but demand a lot of reflection. Do not write them in a night! Start two or three days before.
Anyone who's interested in English should take this course!
Do all the readings
Don't be scared off by Chaucer ! Stay for Faerie Queene, Paradise Lost, and Othello.
Don't take it unless you want to major in English or are very interested in a survey of British literature.

Don't take this course if you're simply exploring the English department. The material is old and stale and the assignments can get obnoxious. Take one of the other 200-level courses; they're much better.

For its faults, in the heavy lifting that you'll have to do, this course is worth your time and effort. There is a reason that these texts are so highly revered, and Professor Dolven presents them with impressive poise and knowledge.

I took this course wondering whether I wanted to major in English, hoping this would persuade me.  It is actually a really interesting course but the readings difficult (at least for me - I hadn't read any of the books before).  If you're just taking English because you're interested in it, I'd suggest taking a different class in an area you like.  This class is mostly sophomore English majors.
I would advise that they make sure to keep up with the reading, because otherwise the final exam is very overwhelming.

I would recommend taking this course to see if you would like majoring in English. Also Professor Dolven is an excellent lecturer. Know that the reading is heavy. If you can't read a whole book, it helps to at least read some key chapters.

I would strongly encourage every student to complete the readings for this class. Reading the material definitely makes it easier to participate during precept. It also makes the essay writing much more enjoyable.
I wouldn't take it unless you're trying to be an English major, but if that's the case you have to and it is fine if you do the reading.
I'm definitely not a fan of this period of literature, but I still found the readings enjoyable. Probably don't take this if you're not an English major or really into older lit.
If you are a prospective English major and need to take this course, you will learn a lot and enjoy the readings and assignments.

If you are considering becoming majoring in english, then you have no choice but to take this class. And for that, I am incredibly sorry.  If not, then I strongly recommend you consider another class within the english department.  Not only were lectures incredibly boring to the point that I have trouble looking back and putting my finger on even one concrete thing that I took away from them, there is an absolutely stupid amount of busy work that legitimately adds no value to your life besides wasting your time.  Not only do you have to do a blackboard post every week (standard) the professor also assigns weekly 2 page assignments that are an utter waste of time. This in addition to two papers, PLUS a final exam.  Add in the fact that you're not allowed to use your computer to take notes (because it's 1950, right!?) and you'll be ready for an awesome semester! Do not take this class unless you're going to be an english major.

If you are considering being an English major, take other English classes, and if you like them, declare and THEN take this course. don't worry about the "this is mandatory to declare" requirement, if you have taken 2  other English courses, they will let you declare.

If you are not considering being an English major: unless you LOVE 14th-18th century literature, don't take the course.
If you think you will like the readings, definitely take this course. Professor Dolven is a great lecturer and I loved all the readings

If you're a rising English major, you'll need this class, so obviously take it. What's more important though, is put in effort to learn from and enjoy this class. Try to take it with Prof. Dolven - he'll make it fun and engaging. For non-English majors, give it a try, it turned out to be much more fun than I thought it would be!

If you're an English major, enjoy: this can be a very good class. Make sure to do the exercises early in the semester.
If you're not, take a class on Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, or Milton instead of this.

If you're considering the English major, take this. I mean, you have to no matter what if you pick the major, but I felt like it was a good indication of whether or not the major was right for me. Dolmen was wonderful. If you're just interested in the foundations of English Literature, also take this!
If you're not an English major and you don't have to take it, I wouldn't. Take a seminar instead.
If you're not planning on majoring in English, there probably isn't any pressing reason to take this course.
It is essential that all readings must be completed.

LEARN YOUR PRECEPTOR! Sometimes the things they expect from a paper are totally bizarre i.e. mine wanted no thesis, "pose more questions than you answer," no argument, and no big words. Learn what your preceptor wants and do it.

Also, keep up with the readings. Duh.

Lectures can be slow but the readings are awesome and Dolven gives you extremely reasonable chunks to read at a time which is rare for ENG classes. If you're trying to take a "just for fun" ENG course, pick one of the big elective-y ones -- this is the core ENG course that all majors have to take, so there's a ton of work. Weekly blackboard posts, bi-weekly two-page exercises, a midterm essay, a final essay, and a final exam. That said, I don't regret spending the time on these works and do have a new literary appreciation for all of them. A lot of that is thanks to Matt Rickard though, who is probably the best preceptor in the ENG department -- if he's precepting this class, take his precept. Basically, if you're here because you're an ENG major and you have to take it: you have to take it, so don't worry about the evals. You'll survive/have a fine time. If you're not an ENG major and need an LA, you'll probably have more fun taking something else.
Not bad for a pre-rec! Definitely gives you a new found respect and appreciation for the classics... they definitely aren't as dry as you'd think.
Only take if you need to for English. Don't take to fulfill your LA; there are better courses.
Please don't take it for your own sake. If you're an English major-I'm so sorry you have to take this class.

Professor Dolven is a great lecturer. Even if you generally don't find older texts as interesting, he presents them in an approachable and enjoyable manner. As a pre-req you have to take it as an English major and so I would recommend taking it with Professor Dolven. If you are not an English major, take it if you enjoy reading older texts, otherwise there are more interesting classes provided by the English department.
Take it only if you need to for the English requirement. The readings are very dense and can take up a lot of time.

Take it! The course is surprisingly fun and engaging for a department prereq.  Make good use of your precept time and plan your exercises widely, and the course will be really rewarding without taking over your life.
Take this if professor dolven isn't teaching it. He's great as a person and a professor but NOT in this context.
The readings were great. There are a LOT of assignments, but it's manageable. The lecture style wasn't for me (very theatrical), but some people like it.

This course is great as an intro to literature, but it is definitely not representative of the way that most English courses work (at least, the way that Prof. Dolven teaches it). Definitely take it if you're thinking of majoring in English. It's better to take it before you're in deep.
This course was great. While it was hard to get through all of the books, I think that it is worthwhile in the long run because these books are the basis for a lot of modern day references.
You have to take it, so take it. The literature is great and so is Dolven.

You learn a lot and cover a wide range of material. But it is a lot of work because in addition to weekly Blackboard posts, there are also six short close-reading essays over the semester, in addition to a final exam and two papers. I think the extent of work for this course really tests one's determination to major in English.
do the reading
prereqs: First-year students welcome. ENG 200 is a prerequisite for the concentration in English, but is open to all..
descrip: An introduction to reading earlier literature in English, from the Canterbury Tales to the eighteenth-century novel. The course aims at a first encounter with some of the great writers in the English language, and explores a set of analytic concepts and strategies for making sense of their works. Questions we will consider include: genre and form; allusion and influence; rhetoric; metaphor and allegory; narrative; gender and sexual politics; also art, beauty, romance, free will, God, sex, and death.

title: Seminar in American Politics - Interest Groups, Social Movements, and the Politics of Inequality
descrip: Examines interest groups and social movements as agents of representation and political change in U.S. politics and policy. Uses primary and secondary sources to explore a broad range of organizations and movements, emphasizing ones representing marginalized groups such as women, people of color, lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people, and low-income people. Considers issues including the impact of interest groups and social movements; the intersections among movements' agendas, identities, and participants; and the relationships between movements and more conventional forms of politics such as elections, parties, and institutions.

title: World Drama
reviews: Definitely take this. You probably aren't familiar with any of this literature and it's pretty much as important to other countries/continents as Shakespeare is to us. Especially as someone with any interest in theatre, this gives you an understanding of the world that's both profound and just the beginning of accessing these other cultures. I arguably learned more about Indian/Chinese/Japanese/African history and culture through this class than I did in any of my general education.
I would definitely recommend this course, if not for the material, then for taking a class with Professor Sandberg
If you are interested in drama or theatre, I think this course is great for the diversity of styles and traditions it will expose you to. I strongly recommend this course.
Interact with the texts and other students outside of class. It will make the group work much easier if some ideas are already shared and you're not all strangers.
Take it! Prof Sandberg is amazing and there were so many really interesting plays from a variety of places and time periods. Great discussions.
Take it!!!!!!!!
descrip: This course is a survey of classical and modern drama from Africa, China, India, Japan, and Latin America. Topics will include Noh and Kabuki, Beijing Opera, Sanskrit theater, Nigerian masquerades and a variety of selections from the rich modern Indian and Latin American canons. There may be trips to NYC or locally to see new theater works.

title: Organic Chemistry II: Foundations of Chemical Reactivity and Synthesis
reviews: A good course. Will enjoy it even if it is required.

Although a continuation of CHM 303, CHM 304 is very different in regards to the type of subject matter. In all honesty, it's harder to cram as it's more memorization of mechanisms. While there still needs to be understanding of the concepts, the mechanisms are the crux of the class. Consistent studying with orgo is the best way to take on orgo and while it still doesn't guarantee anything in regards to the grade you'll in the class, it's the sustainable approach with respect to staying on top of the material and not feeling hopeless.

Always study Prof. Sorensen's notes after each class.  Don't let the material accumulate before each exam (which comes up more quickly than you think).  Start homework and lab reports early so that you have enough time to get help at office hours.
Amazing lectures, you learn a lot!  Tough class but great class
Consistently review and practice the material. It's really difficult to cram.
DO THE PROBLEM SETS. They're not required but DO THEM
Definitely go to office hours/the resource center if you need help.
Definitely go to precept if you have a good preceptor. Look for a good preceptor if you don't.
Do a lot of practice synthesis problems.
Do as many practice tests as you can!
Do as many synthesis problems as you can. This course moves fast fast fast?don't fall behind, and try not to skip if you can.
Do exercises and ask questions.  Explain mechanisms to other people and ask questions if you're not sure.  Try teaching the notes to you peers and have them teach them to you.

Do the homeworks!!!!!!!
I regret not doing them.
Do the problem sets even though you don't have to hand them in, go to the McGraw sessions, and don't fall behind throughout the semester. It felt impossible to catch up when I started to slack off.
Don't fall behind. Review notes thoroughly.

Don't let things build up. You miss one lecture, it's probably gonna be tough understanding the next one if you don't read the lecture notes beforehand. Next thing you know it's May and you never learned carbonyl chemistry. Keep on top of it.
Don't take it unless you have to or you love it.
Don't take this unless you have to but they know what they're doing. This class will rule your life.
Erik Sorenson is one of the best science professors I've ever had- He makes Orgo lecture fun and entertaining. I would definitely recommend his class!
Get ready for a lot of studying and hard work. You will learn a lot of organic chemistry, but it will not be easy.
Go to lecture, do the problem sets.

Great course, Sorensen presents the material very well and makes you actually enjoy organic chemistry. If you survived 1st semester organic chemistry, you might as well take this class, I feel like you actually learn organic chemistry in this class.
Hard but dont be scared
I really, really enjoyed this course. Sorensen is one of the best professors I've ever had and he made Organic Chemistry one of the most exciting things I've taken.
I would definitely recommend this course, but it takes a lot of self studying and work.
I would strongly recommend this course to all students, especially chemistry majors.
If you have to take it you have to take it

It is definitely a challenging course that will take a large chunk of your time, but it is valuable to learn and professor Sorensen is wonderfully helpful and engaging. His lecture notes are beautiful and really teaches you well. The textbook isn't all that necessary.
Keep up with the notes and attend lectures.
Make sure to study the notes on a week by week basis, as the material is extremely cumulative and voluminous.
Make sure you look through all the available resources like McGraw's notes, preceptor's notes, etc. Practice as much as you can!
Make sure you read the notes and study for all exams its worth it!
Makes sure that you keep on top of reading notes, doing problems, and going to precept or review sessions. You can not cram for this course.
Read Professor's notes. They are very helpful.
Review every lecture every time after class. If you are premed you won't have a choice.

Sorensen is one of the best lecturers I've had, and his lecture notes are like the bible. If you read them, practice doing the problems in the notes, and seek help if you need it, you'll do fine. The last thing you'll want to do is either memorize everything, or memorize nothing. It takes a particular balance between memorization and intuition to do well on the exams.

Sorensen is the best lecturer. After 303b, I was not feeling good about orgo at all. After Sorensen, O-chem is my best friend! Absorb his passion for the subject! Be wowed by the transformations! Take this over CHM 304b!

Sorensen is the best! So enthusiastic! His lecture notes are gold. Read them and memorize them!! then you'll do well on the exams. doing well in orgo = putting in enough time to practice. lab was better than last semester.

Sorensen's great, but you will have to study quite a bit in order to do well on exams. The content and amount of what you study will depend a lot on whether they allow a cheat sheet for the year. Just be prepared to delegate a couple hours every day for a few weeks prior to an exam if you really want to do well, and possibly more if you have a difficult time memorizing reactions, mechanisms, and reagents.
Stay on top of lecture notes
Study hard, study weeks in advance before each test, read the lecture notes, go to lecture.
Study psets in detail.

Studying a little bit everyday goes a long way.
Don't slack behind, plus why would you when Prof. Sorensen teaches organic chem. is a really exciting and engaging manner..

TAKE SORENSON!!!! I am pre-med and it makes no difference in terms of material, even if you think you are bad at synthesis. Sorenson teaches it so well that if you work hard you will get better. Also, lectures are actually interesting and the Sorenson-Gingrich duo is entertaining. Sorenson truly loves organic chemistry and teaching it and really wants you to understand it. Don't even consider taking it with Semmelhack. Sorenson for life.

Take CHM 304. You will learn a lot but the material is interesting and Sorensen is great. Try to do as many practice midterms as you can and don't wait till late to study. During the exam, devote much time to the lecture part of the exam and less on the lab.
Take it for Sorensen. But be prepared to either take a hit to the GPA or actually put in an hour or two a week to study (wow, the thought?!!?!) instead of cram the 48 hours before the exam.
Take it if you have general interest in majoring in chemistry, or if you have to go through the rough premed cycle.
Take it if you have the slightest interest in chemistry.
Take it! Engage with it!  You will love it!
Take it, but only if you genuinely like chemistry. If you don't you'll hate it. I loved it though.
Take it. Prepare to allot a good amount of time to study. Get to know Professor Sorensen.
Take this class if you have to.
Take this course with Professor Sorenson. He is the best. What a great experience! But remember to study!

Take this course. It is a lot harder than 303 but you will learn a lot, and even if you don't remember all the reactions we covered you will gain a good basic comprehension and intuition about organic chemistry. Please try and put effort into this course that is proportional to the work your instructors put into it. This is a course that should be worked several times every week. I wasn't able to put in as much effort and time as I would have liked and I regretted it. Go through Professor Sorensen's notes carefully. Start lab reports before the day before, because they're longer in this course.
Take this section!! Do the Problem Sets!!
This class is challenging, so put in a lot of time into it. Sorenson is a great lecturer.

This course is absolutely fantastic! A must take. I came in as a WWS student and left a CHM major. Erik brings so much passion and love for the science that it is hard not to have some of it rub off on you. I strongly recommend this course.
This course is taught very well and Professor Sorensen is an excellent lecturer.
This is a very well taught second semester Organic Chemistry course.
This is definitely the better of the two organic chemistry courses at Princeton.
Work hard and early, weeds out the weak students.
be prepared to put time into this course. a lot. of time.
don't get behind.
don't take unless you have to, and then if you do use all resources available
start early, keep up with the material, so easy to fall behind
you have to take orgo II with sorensen! he is a fantastic professor!
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303.
descrip: This course begins by discussing the chemical consequences of conjugation and the Diels-Alder reaction. After a coverage of aromaticity and the chemistry of benzene, we then move into the heart of the course: the nature and reactivity of the carbonyl group, a subject that is central to both mainstream organic chemistry and biochemistry. Throughout this course, an effort will be made to demystify the art of chemical synthesis. This course is appropriate for chemistry majors, premedical students, and other students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Inventing the English Novel
reviews: Come prepared to class every day with a section of the reading that you want to discuss.
Excellent.
If you are interested in literature from a writer's perspective or in the form of the novel, you should take this.
Make sure to do the readings carefully.  This will help in both discussion and on assignments.
TAKE IT. AMAZING COURSE
Take it!
prereqs: Students with a strong interest in creative writing preferred..
descrip: The first novels were written in English around 1700 and quickly became the most popular literary form. We read from early experiments like Robinson Crusoe to the genre-making masterpiece Pride and Prejudice. We see key aspects of the novelist's craft emerge: voice, point of view, setting, character, plot. The course is aimed at fiction-writers and well as readers--we'll learn how novels are made as much we'll come to understand why they were made then, and what novels did that no other literary form had been able to do. Students are encouraged to have strong interest in creative writing as well as literary scholarship.

title: Dante's "Purgatorio" and "Paradiso"
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of confusing readings.
Don't miss an opportunity to take Dante with Marchesi. He is the world expert, and one of the best professors at Princeton.
Have fun!
It is a milestone if you're considering majoring in Italian or any other European literature.

This class is a MUST for any Italian student. Marchesi is the best professor in the department and Dante is really his element. On top of that, the Commedia is just an incredible work -- it will stay with you for weeks and weeks.
prereqs: Course will be taught in Italian. One Italian 200-level course or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: The course provides an occasion for the collaborative study of Dante's Commedia in its totality. Equal time will be devoted to each "Cantica" including a thorough review of "Inferno". "Vita Nuova" will be read over the the break.

title: Intensive Intermediate Chinese
reviews: Definitely take this course! However, be warned that this is a course where you can't leave everything to the last minute, especially the weekly quizzes. Don't let that deter you though because the teachers are great and you'll have a really fun time in class!
Great class, take it

Keep up with the class and practice, practice, practice! You will put in a lot of time and effort but you will see the results of your work as your language skills will improve immensely over just one semester.
Keep up with the readings and make sure you are prepared for class every day!
Participate in class and don't be afraid to talk to your teachers; they're nice people!
Worth taking, for sure. Your Chinese will improve immensely. At the beginning it seems a crazy hard step up from CHI 103 but you get used to it really quickly.
prereqs: CHI 103 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: An intensive course covering 105 and 107 in one semester for students who have finished 103 which covers 101 and 102. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills and the analysis of grammar. After 108, students are ready for third year courses.

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese II
prereqs: CHI 301 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion in Chinese traditional philosophical thoughts and historical issues. Texts and essays written from Tang to Qing dynasty. Class discussions will be conducted in Mandarin Chinese.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Economics of the Welfare State
descrip: All advanced countries have extensive "welfare state" programs that provide insurance against economic losses, support people with low incomes, etc.. But these programs vary widely in extent from the relatively small US welfare state, to the larger welfare states of much of Europe, to the generous programs of Scandinavia. At the same time, there is heated controversy about the effects of such programs. This course surveys welfare state programs, including health care systems, across various countries, analyzes the debates over their economic effects, and looks at the political economy of reform in the US and countries such as France.

title: Microeconomic Policy
descrip: oh, dear

title: The Literature of the Past
reviews: Expect a lot of reading and to be let out 10 minutes late from every lecture. But if you do the reading and pay attention, you should do well.
Feldherr is terrific. Fascinating course with great readings. It's a lot of work but it's worth it.

If you are even remotely interested in ancient history, historiography, or the philosophy of history, take this course. The readings are incredible and the course was not too difficult. Perfect for classics majors and engineers alike.

It was a privilege to take this class. Professor Feldherr was one of the best lecturers I've had at Princeton, and the precept experience was also great. If you're interested in the material and don't mind keeping up with the readings, I highly recommend taking this class.

It's about some of the greatest ancient works, so actually read them.  I can't stand it when students don't read their assignments even though they signed up to take a class when its purpose is to read this stuff!
Take if you are willing to put in the time to read the books! If not, it is pointless. Feldherr runs over on lectures sometimes, so schedule a close class after this one.
Take it!
descrip: We will investigate how and why ancient historians and epic poets wrote about the past, and how the answers to these questions change over time. We will read the Iliad and the Aeneid, and substantial selections from the major Greek and Roman historians: Herodotus, Thucydides, Sallust, Livy, and Tacitus (in English). No previous knowledge of Greek or Latin, or classical civilization, is required. The course is equally appropriate for classics majors and those seeking an introduction to the great writers and great events of antiquity.

title: Spectral Thinking in Modern Chinese Literature and Film
descrip: 'Spectral Thinking' examines what may be characterized as supernatural, fantastic, and anomalous in twentieth century and contemporary Chinese film and literature. Through the lens of spectral thinking, this course introduces a modern Chinese history replete with phantoms, dreams, and nightmares of the modern era. These include science fiction and horror films from early twentieth century, wuxia imagination (martial arts genre) in linking fractured Chinese communities in the Cold War era, the phenomenon of' 'nostalgia' in post-socialist Chinese film and literature, female revenge story, postmodern mysticism, and virtual fantasy.

title: Philosophy of Art
reviews: Definitely take this course.  Nehamas is as engaging of a lecturer as you will find anywhere, and he will give you something no textbook or website on philosophy of art can: a unique personal philosophy of art.  Attend all lectures and precepts, and I highly recommend taking advantage of Nehamas's office hours.  He is extremely friendly and open, and getting to discuss the material with distinguished philosopher and human being like him is a rare opportunity.
Engage with the material -- It will really change how you interact with and look at art.
Great course for an introduction to philosophy and specifically aesthetics. Nehamas is an interesting, informative and engaging lecturer. Subject matter is fantastic.
Great course, really interesting information.
Hands down one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. If you're remotely interested in this subject matter, take the class--you will not regret it.
I cannot recommend this course strongly enough. One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.

I didn't take advantage of the opportunity to have discussions with Professor Nehamas in lecture. He is really open to the possibility! I thought the days when students would fire questions at him to challenge him were fun and interesting, even though not all of the questions were that great.

But also, if you're taking this course just to take a course with Nehamas and you're not sure if you're interested in aesthetics, Nietzsche might be a better bet.
I would recommend this course if you want to take a philosophy class that is not heavily analytical and/or if you have an interest in aesthetics.
I would take this class. It was not too much work and it was very interesting.

If you are interested in aesthetic philosophy as opposed to moral or logical philosophy or are generally interested in pervasive but often unsung significance of the art come let Nehamas try to tell you of it all.
It's a good course. Go for it!
Make sure to do the readings and seek lots of help for the papers
Take it! Do all the readings!
Take it, without a doubt.
Take it.
Take this class if you enjoy art and/or philosophy.  Do the readings!  They will make lectures and precepts much more interesting and beneficial to you.

Take this course!!!! Lectures are amazing - informative, insightful, amusing, and Nehamas might even make you cry. He has a really interesting conception of how art relates to life that is very enriching.

Take this course. Professor Nehamas is awesome and I loved gaining an understanding of his world-view and some of the most important writers on the philosophy of art. If you want to add a little romance to your semester, study with Nehamas.
descrip: Beauty, Art, and Ethics: Ever since Plato's REPUBLIC, the arts have been the target of ethical criticisms. Beauty, in particular, has been looked at with deep suspiciousness. We will examine these criticisms, discuss whether the aesthetics status of art renders it immune to them, and consider in detail the case --not of the fine but-- of the popular arts, in particular, television, which gives such criticisms an unexpected immediacy and leads to many of the most important problems of aesthetics.

title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
reviews: Challenging if you haven't done that much reading in Hindi/Urdu. But the readings are really interesting, so definitely worth it.
Definitely take it.
If you want to keep going with hindi/urdu, definitely take it.
This class is all about participation. This is the friendliest and most helpful environment to force yourself to speak more Hindi/Urdu. Make use of it!
prereqs: HIN 301 / URD 301 or equivalent proficiency..
descrip: Close reading of selected literary materials, generally short stories, with additional focus on historical and social context, literary styles and trends. Literary texts supplemented with viewing of film, documentary, and author interviews, as well as germane poetry and music. Reading and writing assignments are provided in both Hindi and Urdu. Students choose their preferred format. In-depth classroom discussion and analysis of all materials.

title: Applied Quantitative Analysis
reviews: Ask for help whenever you can, because coding/programming is a very delicate task.  However, enjoy it, because it is such a cool tool to have on your belt.
Be ready to learn a lot on your own.

Definitely take it. POL 345 (or an equivalent) is a good introduction, but POL 346 is a great opportunity to hone your coding skills and improve your statistics knowledge. It is very worthwhile and challenging, in a way that will make you improve each week.
Definitely take this course if you want to improve upon your statistical analysis skills from previous statistics classes.
Great, close knit, fun class.
I would definitely take this course.  There's a lot of cool applications of statistics to politics, and you'll learn a valuable programming language (R).
If you liked POL 345 and want to broaden your understanding of stats, definitely take this course.
Make sure you take advantage of office hours.

Only take the class if you have the motivation and time to really teach yourself a lot of the material. If you are not genuinely interested in statistics and becoming literate therein (which you really should be), I wouldn't recommend it. If you are interested though, the payoff is very big.

Read the textbook, and reach out to Professor Wasow and other preceptors as often as you need help, because they will respond within the hour! As long as you focus and stay on top of the course, you can do well.
TAKE THIS CLASS. So helpful in so many ways, and Wasow is the best professor.

Take this course!!! Wasow is a beast. Go for office hours. This class will teach you how to apply statistical concepts and, more importantly, how to present your findings. It will also teach you R -- if you don't know R, don't worry. You'll pick it up. I did't know R coming in. And you'll learn how to write very nice statistical reports. Very useful for JPs and might even spark an interest in pursuing statistics in the social sciences ...

The lectures were not amazing, but it was great fun creating an original research question for the final.  Professor Wasow was also very cool and fun to talk to -- charismatic and funny! I now feel much more prepared to incorporate quantitative sections into my independent work.

This course takes you so much farther than POL345. Professor Wasow is excellent, so if he's teaching I would definitely recommend the course. The only caveat I have is that the coding can be difficult, so if you don't have previous experience you'll need to put in a little bit of extra time to work through that.

This is a great course to take to really dive into R and have a great grasp on statistics, especially going into junior and senior independent work.  I really enjoyed the class and would highly recommend taking it.
Very important in preparation for statistical analysis in junior papers and senior thesis. Take it, especially if Professor Wasow is teaching.
You'll learn a ton of stats.
prereqs: POL 345 or equivalent.
descrip: In a world awash in data, how can we identify signals amid the noise? This course focuses on developing an intuition for statistics and applying it through data analysis, regression models and a final project. We will wrestle with what makes a good research question, play with data to see how statistical methods can help us make sense of real world concerns, and work at communicating quantitative findings clearly to broad audiences. Particular attention will be paid to applying these techniques in Junior Papers and Senior Theses. Coursework involves using the R statistical platform.

title: Property, Wealth, and Equality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Princeton Atelier - The "Peer" Review
prereqs: Applications are required; for applications and more information, see the Princeton Atelier course webpage or contact Ellen Goellner with any questions (goellner@).
descrip: This course is a practical examination of Henrik Ibsen's epic play "Peer Gynt". Through close examination of scenes from the play, the internationally acclaimed director John Doyle aims to develop a new adaptation. Professor Doyle will lead course participants through the play and, in collaboration with them, try to determine how "Peer Gynt" strikes a modern audience, how the text may need to be adapted, how we might begin to devise a visual and verbal language that will be equal to the immense theatricality of the original.

title: Contemporary Chinese Society and Culture
descrip: This course surveys "contemporary China." It begins with Maoist Socialism between 1949 and 1978, and focuses on the tremendous changes of Chinese society and culture from 1978 to the present. Using ethnographies along with documentaries, this course demonstrates major trends and contradictions through people's lived experiences: decentralized social life under the state power, overall life improvement along with increasing inequality of consumer society, the rise of individual desire amidst conflicting memories of socialism, reinvention of traditions under transnational influences, and so on.

title: The Bible as Literature
reviews: Definitely take it if you know the Bible or are interested in learning about it. The barrier to entry is not super high, especially for the actual written work, so if you're worried about diving into the Bible, don't be. Also, Professor Schor is awesome.

I highly recommend this course to students interested in literature, whether or not you have a religious background. Professor Schor is an excellent lecturer and the readings for this class provide well-rounded knowledge of the Bible. The essay topics are very interesting and easy to work with.
Take it if you're interested at all in learning the Bible's stories. Don't worry if you haven't read the Bible before. Professor Schor does not assume any prior knowledge which is really great.
Take it. It helps if you have some prior familiarity with the Bible, but you don't need to. Professor Schor is great and really cares about helping you do well in the class.
Take this class! It's interesting, not too difficult, and you get to read the Bible for homework! What could be better?
Take this course. It is so much fun.

Very difficult if you have never read the Bible before. I would say 90% of students had experience. But rewarding nonetheless and perhaps a good PDF if you want to read the Bible - which you really should if you want to understand a great portion of the Western Canon
descrip: The Bible will be read closely in its own right and as an enduring resource for literature and commentary. The course will cover its forms and genres, including historical narrative, uncanny tales, prophecy, lyric, lament, commandment, sacred biography, and apocalypse; its pageant of weird and extraordinary characters; and its brooding intertextuality. Students will become familiar with a wide variety of biblical interpretations, from the Rabbis to Augustine to Kafka and Kierkegaard. Cinematic commentary will be included--Bible films, from the campy to the sublime.

title: Global Air Pollution
reviews: Definitely take it! Zondlo is awesome, and this class is very easy if you just go to lecture and pay attention. Minimal studying required, and problem sets aren't too bad. Go to office hours.
If with a geo/chem background, be prepared to study a lot of application. Very interesting class.
If you're ever deciding between this class and CHM 333, TAKE THIS. Similar content in many ways, but this class is so much more fair and more organized.
It's not terribly interesting material if you ask me, but Prof. Zondlo is a very good lecturer. The problem sets are hard, so definitely work with other people on them.
Take if you are interested in the environment and in terms of atmospheric stuff more specifically. Definitely a well rounded course by a great professor.
Take it if you're interested in the topic/have a background in chemistry. Don't be scared off by the engineering aspect.
Take it!
Take this class.  It is not hard and Zondlo is a great teacher.

The course material is not conceptually difficult, but it can be difficult to do well on the exams because missing simple details can be very costly. It's useful if you have an interest in atmospheric chemistry.

This course was definitely a mixed bag. Zondlo is a very solid lecturer, providing as much clarity as a BSE student can hope for in a heavily quantitative class, but he's also the stereotypical absentminded prof. Cancelled a couple classes, brings his kid to work every other class, and in general seems rather disorganized and harried. Workload is also really heavy, with tedious psets, 2 midterms AND a final AND a final project. Take if interested, stay away otherwise.
prereqs: CEE 303 or CHM 303/304 or Instructor's Permission.
descrip: Students will study the chemical and physical processes involved in the sources, transformation, transport, and sinks of air pollutants on local to global scales. Societal problems such as photochemical smog, particulate matter, greenhouse gases, and stratospheric ozone depletion will be investigated using fundamental concepts in chemistry, physics, and engineering. For the class project, students will select a trace gas species or family of gases and analyze recent field and remote sensing data based upon material covered in the course. Environments to be studied include very clean, remote portions of the globe to urban air quality.

title: Ebola in 2014: The Science, Society and Politics of a Modern Epidemic
reviews: Amazing class. Definitely take it if it is offered! You get to meet a ton of really cool speakers/people involved with the outbreak.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in epidemic control and/or the current Ebola epidemic in West Africa.
Do the readings - they enlighten the course. Ask for help!
I don't think they're offering this course again, but it was amazing.
LOVE LOVE LOVED. the professors are awesome, if interested in epidemics I think you'll love the class. Neither too much work nor too little.
Take this class if they offer it! You will get a really interesting perspective on the epidemic, and it will really teach you how to apply the skills you learn in GHP core classes
Take this course if Emmanuel will be there. The assignments were fair and fun.
take it!
descrip: The course will focus on the current Ebola epidemic in West Africa. It is organized into three themes including the public health science of Ebola; the social aspects of the epidemic; and the national and international politics related to the response. The course will be led by public health professionals who have participated in the response and will include guest speakers.

title: Politics of Intimacy, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Translation Workshop: Spanish to English
reviews: If you are at all interested in Spanish language take this course.

If you're interested in language, writing, and/or Spanish literature, you won't regret taking this class. Prof. Wimmer is lovely and obviously very accomplished, but she gives great feedback and is always willing to talk with you about your work. One of my favorite classes at Princeton so far.

TAKE IT!! I've never been more engaged with a single project that I was with my translation project for this class. Translation is such a rewarding challenge, I strongly recommend this to anyone with an interest in the intersection of Spanish and English. Also, Professor Wimmer really cares about her students' work and will always give you honest, thoughtful feedback. This class is all about the real practice of translation - nothing super theoretical - and it's an amazing experience to finish your own translation of a Spanish text that's never been translated in English before. The feeling of ownership and accomplishment is awesome. Take it!!

Take it! Do know that it is very much about your ability to write in English as well as understand the Spanish so it's a lot of editing in English. If you like that this is the course for you! I loved it! Professor Wimmer is great and she has lots of interesting experience to share.
Take this course if you're at all interested in literature or creative writing! Not really a "spanish" class.
Take this if you have any interest, but only take it if you are willing to commit fully to the class because otherwise you will detract from the experiences of the other students.

Wonderful course, one of my favorite of all time! Really enjoyable to translate whatever you want and then get peer edits. Don't be intimidated by the 3-hour seminar, it flies by and is super interesting. Lots of discussion and interaction, a relaxed environment. If your Spanish is up to par, definitely take. You'll find you're better at translation than you think. Prof. Wimmer is awesome.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission. Reading knowledge of Spanish. Brief English-language writing sample required (2-3 pages of fiction, essay, or critical writing); submit directly to instructor (wimmer@princeton.edu) by December 2, 2014, including class year..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the practice of literary translation from Spanish to English and an exploration of the questions that the act of translation inspires. After a series of translation exercises, each student will select an author and work to be translated as the central project for the class, and embark on the process of revising successive drafts. Close reading of the Spanish texts is required, as is a deep engagement with the translations of fellow students. Subjects of discussion will include style, context, the conventions of contemporary translation, and the retranslation of classics.

title: International Monetary Theory and Policy II
descrip: Advanced topics in monetary economics, with an emphasis on open economies. Money demand and currency substitution; price-level and exchange-rate determination under alternative monetary policy rules; real effects of monetary disturbances; exchange-rate policy and macroeconomic stability; welfare consequences of inflation and exchange-rate stabilization; advantages and disadvantages of monetary union.

title: Latino History
reviews: A great course and Lozano is a dynamic, fair, and understanding teacher. The workload is ideal and the content is rich.
Definitely take it, You won't learnt this information anywhere else.
Definitely take this course!
Do all the readings, and go to office hours.
Great course, great professor. Would definitely recommend.

I highly recommend this course! Prof. Lozano is an amazing professor who is very committed to her students and the subject matter. While the class is challenging, it is very rewarding and the focus of Latino history is so important.
If you are at all interested in Latino History, this is a fun course to take
In lecture there is a lot of material that is covered so make sure you take notes quickly.

Make sure to complete outlines and study key terms (context and significance) for quizzes

Lozano is super easy to talk to, so don't be afraid to ask questions about anything during office hours

Alo keep readings organized and highlight stuff that relates to questions in weekly reading guides because it helps with precept and helps with midterm
TAKE THIS CLASS!!! You won't regret it!
Take it!
Take it.

This is an amazing course with an amazing professor. Professor Lozano is one of the most hardworking professors on campus and actively works to get to know each of her students. The material is exciting, particularly because you get a sense of how new the field of Latino history is and how much is yet to be explored. Grading is fair, and exams are useful for organizing your thinking about the material in the lectures and readings. Papers allow for lots of creativity, and I actually really enjoyed writing them.
You have to go to lecture in order to keep up with the class.
descrip: The course follows the major themes surrounding the history of Latinos in the United States, enabling an understanding of how Latinos became a group. It seeks to explain the historical origins of the continuing debates over land ownership, assimilation expectations, discrimination, immigration regulation, intergroup differences, and labor disputes. The course looks transnationally at Latin America's history to explain shifts in public opinion and domestic policies in the US. While the course examines the impact of Latinos in many regions of the country, it will particularly focus on those in the Southwest -- largely Mexican Americans.

title: English Constitutional History
reviews: Go for it. My preceptor will be gone. That should make it better. You won't regret taking a class with Bill Jordan.
I put in the same amount of work I would for a STEM class and failed both tests.  Jordan is an incredible lecturer, but even the PDF option might not save you unless you are a history genius.

I strongly recommend this very rewarding but very demanding class. Jordan could be the best lecturer I've had at Princeton. He's engaging, witty, and makes history come alive. That being said, I would avoid his precept. He's an extremely harsh grader and tends to ramble about off-topic issues. Because the course's emphasis is on the development of governmental institutions and common law, the material is largely theoretical, so it's quite hard to predict what will be on exams; this is not a typical history course that focuses on events, people, etc. Be sure to take very good notes in lecture, as the readings don't really go in depth about law and governance in the second half of the semester. Overall, definitely take this course if you are interested in English history or want to better understand the foundations of American govt. You will learn a lot, but be ready to work.
I think any history concentrator should take this course, and anyone interested in going on to law school or a career in politics should take this course. This is not a course to take for an easy HA.

I would definitely take this class if you have an interest in English and/or legal history. The lectures are absolutely necessary, because  you will not find the perspective given by Professor Jordan in the course readings. Lectures were interesting and Jordan is entertaining. I thought it was worth waking up for at 9 am.

It can be a little technical at times, but you get to learn English history through the lens of legal and constitutional procedures. If you are a history major I definitely recommend it, if this is your first history course it might be a little challenging but it is very rewarding.

Make sure to do the readings, and take note of which events in history Professor Jordan highlights in his lectures. Also, feel free to ask questions. Professor Jordan is wonderful and makes this otherwise dull-sounding class exciting!!!
Prof. Jordan is a fantastic lecturer, but the exams are tough. If you want a crash-course on English history or our considering a legal career, this is the course for you.
Take it!
Take it, but be willing to put time into it.
Take it--the best course I have taken at Princeton with one of the best professors on the faculty
Take this class and stay up to date with the readings.

Take this class for Jordan, he's great. If you're taking this class expecting it to be like a law school course, you may be disappointed. It's definitely more of a history course that happens to focus on law.

Take this course seriously. It is amazing, extremely well-taught, informative, and rewarding, but you will have to work for your grade. Do not take the exams lightly, they will kick your butt! Know your stuff, and you will be fine- just make sure that you understand what everything means and the larger patterns that Jordan brings up. You will get a lot out of this course, but only if you commit to it.

This class is one of the best I've taken at Princeton; anyone who cares about the development of limited government needs to take it. Professor Jordan is a fantastic lecturer, and one of the smartest Professors whom I have ever met. Be aware that he expects precision.

This course requires a lot of effort due to the readings assigned, but it is definitely worth the time you put into it. Professor Jordan is an engaging and entertaining lecturer (probably one of the best I've had over the course of my entire Princeton career), and the material covered is extremely valuable for those who want to better understand the history behind the American legal system or who study the United Kingdom.
it is hard, and very much a legal and administrative course rather than a course on the english kings or english society. but it is very very interesting and useful stuff
some work but doable via pdf.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: To explore the development of institutions and theories of government in England from the Norman Conquest to about 1700.

title: Genetics of Eukaryotic Organisms
reviews: Don't miss it. The one of the best courses I've ever taken.
I would advise them to take it.
It will come together, and try. The material may be brand new but these professors do such a good job at explaining it. Ask your questions because these people know how to answer.
Prepare to put in a lot of time commitment for this course.

Read the papers, read the papers, read the papers, read the papers, and be organized.  Deadlines will creep up on you otherwise, and nothing is worse than reacting to a question or assignment like a deer in headlights.  You will learn a lot from this course, but the price for this is having to put in a lot of work.
The class is a good assortment of genetic techniques in variety of model organisms. Both Mark and Liz do an excellent job of explaining the material and helping students.
descrip: This course presents the genetic tools and logical framework used in the study of eukaryotic organisms, from the major model organisms (yeast, Drosophila, C.elegans, mouse and zebrafish) to humans. Discussion and readings frrom the primary literature focuses on basic cell,developmental, and quantitative biology. Material emphasizes genetic approaches building from classical methods to modern molecular genetics and genomics. Topics include suppression synthetic lethality epistasis, mutagenesis, mosaics, transgenics, BS cells, knock-in technologies and cell-type specific gene expression.

title: Advanced Syntax
prereqs: LIN 302 or by application.
descrip: How Chomsky's minimalist program has revolutionized syntactic theory and the study of language more generally. Explication and evaluation of minimalist approaches to syntactic derivation and representation, including the role of economy and other principles of efficient computation. One focus will be the empirical basis of these proposals.

title: Introduction to African-American Intellectual Tradition
prereqs: The course presupposes a familiarity with issues in African American studies..
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar introduces graduate students from many departments to the African-American intellectual tradition. Particular attention will be paid to black radicalism, in both the U.S. and the African Diaspora, with a focus on issues of class and gender alongside race. A broad set of topics are discussed, including: racial formation; slavery; empire; and social movements.

title: Seminar in Golden-Age Literature - Case studies from Spain and the New World: Bodies of evidence
reviews: Don't shy away at the page count or at the difficulty of the language (there are numerous older variants of written Spanish that can be difficult to navigate clearly if unacquainted with the literature of these eras). Patience pays off!

I would suggest to them to take the course because it covers many topics that are foundations to understand literature today. In addition, Professor Brownlee motivated me through challenging questions, and she always made herself available for any questions.
descrip: Bodies of evidence, bodies of knowledge, the body politic, bodies--inviolate to mutilated, saintly to criminal-are figured in Medieval and Early Modern Hispanic literature in ways that reveal not only cultural paradigms, myths and obsessions, but also some widely divergent cultural inscriptions involving marginal social groups, the history of the senses, sexuality and gender. The relationships between bodily and cognitive systems will form the basis for our analyses of such texts and authors as: El Cantar de mio Cid, "Libro de buen amor", "Celestina", "Don Quijote",Sor Juana.

title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: Attend lectures (lots of information brought up there that may not be on the lecture slides). Reading can be useful for problem sets, as well. Attend precepts! Really helpful, and you usually solve actual problems there that can help with problem sets
Be prepared for a very dry and challenging course.
Be prepared to have to generate some of your own interest in the topic, and especially use the textbooks to supplement the economics that are presented in lecture.

Classic ECO requisite: in other words, it's horrible. Lectures will be the dullest thing ever, talking about all these vague theories and nothing about actually applying them, screwing you over for the exams and psets. GO TO PRECEPT. Honestly, you can skip lecture and only go to precept, that's literally the only time you ever learn anything anyways.
Do not underestimate them

Don't take this class just because you want a finance certificate. In other words, don't just try to get a finance certificate b/c you think it looks good on paper. If you enjoy economic reasoning, then this class is great!
Don't take this unless you're interesting it.
Don't take unless you really want a finance certificate. Lectures are boring and so are precepts. It's mostly math.
Extremely boring. Very little new economic material on top of ECO 100. Most of the class was just computation. If you don't have issues with calculus, this will be an easy class.
Go in with the mindframe that's it's calculus with some cool economics applications, and you won't be disappointed.

Go to lecture, and stick through it. It's not going to be fun like ECO 100/101, but you have to get through it if you like econ. Judge your actual passion for the subject by the satisfaction that you get from solving a problem (or from reading the Economist), not from how much you like Morris' teaching.
Go to precept.  You should keep up with reading.  Good luck on that finance certificate.
Go to precepts and be thorough with homework. Problems on tests tend to be significant variants on the types of problems found there.
I love Prof. Morris'lecture although sometimes his monotonous voice can make me feel sleepy. Get Ben Young for precept. He is super awesome.

I took this class as a physics major because I wanted another problem set class, but all it did was make me hate economics because of how boring the material became. Only take if you have to or actually like economics.
If you must take this class as a distribution requirement, then go ahead. Otherwise, it's a decent course that is quite difficult.
It's a good course to take and gives more insight between the bridge between mathematics and economics.
It's fairly interesting, I really appreciated the mathematical approach. The math is not too hard, but I like that you have a quantitative idea and not just a qualitative understanding
It's useful and necessary, but don't take it out of interest
Keep up with the readings and work!! Stay on top of it every week and you'll be fine for tests.
Lectures aren't worth it. Read the book. Psets are graded check-check-plus-etc. so do them for completion only, then study the solutions greatly to do well.

Lectures with Morris are dry but the material is interesting. With a solid ECO 100 background, this course should not be too difficult; problem sets are basically taking ECO 100 material and adding calculus. Not much else work required besides completing problem sets.

Lots of people stopped going to lecture. I went, but it wasn't the most helpful thing on its own. Professor Morris' notes will make no sense unless you go to class though, because he writes down math without the economical interpretation. Make sure to read the book. Take the class if you like the more math-y track of econ / want the finance certificate. Otherwise take 300. If you do take it, try to get Ben as your preceptor, he's really good.
Make sure you're interested in economics or its going to be difficult to stay engaged.
Morris can be a dry lecturer but if you have a strong math background and know some econ you will be fine.
Morris' lectures are dry as a bone and very hard to learn from, but the material can be interesting.  Be prepared to teach yourself and make sure that you prepare for the tests really thoroughly.
Not as bad as you might think
Only do it if you're trying to do finance.
Only take if it if you need it.

Only take if necessary. There are other much more engaging classes. The class needed better organization, the homeworks were only graded for completion and effort (check, check plus, etc.) and often incorrectly graded, and no one went to lecture.
Only take it if it's a requirement. If you're interested in econ, skip this, it's not worth it.
Only take it if required.  Honestly, this class kind of sucks, but it's one of those things you have to get through.

Pesendorfer is easier, Morris is better. I'm also in 311 and several times I've known something that no one else did because I had Morris instead. But to get there you have to sift through a lot of pointless math.
Strong background in math and economics will help.
THIS IS THE WORST CLASS I HAVE TAKEN AT PRINCETON.
Take if you can self-study and if you're econ major. Lectures are useless so don't go. Go to precept if you want more help. Everything can be done at home.
Take if you need to.
Take if you want to do finance certificate. Morris is an okay professor - preceptors make a huge difference.
Take it because it opens many doors to other econ courses and is good general knowledge.
Take it if you have a strong interest in this area of economics
Take it if you have to for Finance or for your Econ track but beware that this is a boring and bad course.
Take it only if you have a strong foundation in math and if you need to.
Take it only if you must. Out of interest its kind of not worth it.
Take this class if you have to
Take this course
Take this course. It is tough, but if you go to all of the classes you will learn a lot and enjoy the content.
The professor and preceptors really make or break this class, choose wisely when and with who to take it.
This class can be pretty difficult.
To do well on the exam, you should take precepts and problem sets very seriously. The lectures help with general understanding of the background information and economic theories.
Unless you are pursuing the finance certificate, do not take this class as an ORFE major.
Work on the psets early. Get ready for some crazy/annoying algebra.
don't take
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 200 or MAT 201. Not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.

title: Techniques and Methods of Social Science
descrip: This seminar has three objectives: 1) to introduce students to different social science research methods (including survey research, experiments, ethnography, historical and comparative analysis, text analysis) and to provide them with an understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of various approaches; 2) to introduce students to the types of research Princeton faculty members are currently engaged in; and 3) to familiarize students with the components of a strong empirical paper and to prepare them to identify a topic and data for their empirical paper.

title: Genetics of Human Populations
reviews: A good course for upperclassmen with a solid background in genetics. Low in-class time commitment (but a very large amount of reading outside of class).

It was a really great class that helped to understand primary literature and the tests and analyses that are being done in the field today. Very interesting if you're interested in genetics and research.
Take this class! While it may seem like an arduous task (3 hours on 3 papers), Andolfatto does a great job helping you build your scientific literacy.

you will learn an enormous amount about how to actually interpret genomic experiments and data and statistics, which is super valuable for anybody who wants to go into research, but you really need to be intrinsically motivated to learn or else this class would probably suck.
prereqs: EEB 309, EEB 320, or MOL 342, or CHM 236/COS 236/MOL236/PHY236. Strong familiarity with genetics and molecular biology..
descrip: This seminar will survey the evolutionary history of modern humans and the genetic basis of variation in our species through reading and discussion of classic and contemporary primary literature. Topics include the evolutionary origins of modern human populations, signatures of natural selection in the human genome, and approaches for discovering genetic variants that affect disease susceptibility and variation in normal traits. Significant emphasis will be placed on very recent advances made possible by the human genome project.

title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
reviews: Be sure you have a good base in Spanish before taking this course, because we move quickly through Portuguese.
Its important to study everyday and take all the assignments seriously if you want to learn the language.
Megwen is wonderful, and the class is a relatively light courseload and a lot of fun.
Take this course! Really straightforward, but actually engaging and really fun.

The best class I have taken at Princeton. I am a junior CS major who had never considered taking a language, (protip: Engineers, totally consider taking a language) but decided to on a whim because a friend had said that the POR department at Princeton was uber-chill and awesome. He was totally right.
Megwen did a fantastic job of engaging every student into the class, independent of skill level. I came into the class without a strong Spanish background, and struggled a bit with listening in the beginning, but was able to (somewhat) seamlessly integrate into the class by the end of the semester. I am very happy and proud of myself that I am able to speak a new language with pretty decent proficiency after only one semester. Even with all of these good things, the class is not an inordinate amount of work, and by working for just a small amount every day, I was able to stay on top of my work with relative ease. ? POR 108 ?
This class is pretty easy, and will teach you substantial Portuguese if you already know Spanish pretty well.
Unfortunately, Megwen is moving on from Princeton, so future Princeton POR takers won't be able to be taught by her. But I've only heard good things about the POR instructors ? definitely take this!
You can gain a good proficiency in a new language! Megwen is high-energy and this is a good course to take even as a thesis struggling senior.
do the MLL. Study a lot for the exams and quizzes.
take it!
take this class, specially with Megwen, she's great!
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.

title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature and Culture - Memory and Modernity in the Age of Progress
reviews: Definitely take this class if you like French literature.  The readings were engaging and fun, class usually had an interesting discussion, and assignments were not only reasonable, they were actually fun to write.
Do it!
I would highly recommend this course to students who love french and french literature. It is a great change of pace from other more rigorous courses and a great chance to read good books
Nice course. Loved the professor's accent. Most of the readings are interesting. But make sure you can speak French fluently and think on your feet in seminar discussions.

This is a great course to take if you want to spend your time reading books and talking about them. It gives some great insights into the time period (19th c France), and is not altogether too much work.
prereqs: A 200-level French course or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course examines the rise of a culture of memory in 19th century France in response to the stresses of modernization - including the Revolution, the growth of industrial capitalism, the rise of democracy, large-scale urban changes, and French colonial expansion. We will read memoirs, historical novels, science fiction, naturalist novels, and religious history by authors such as Chateaubriand, Hugo, Balzac, Verne, Zola, and Renan, which tap into and often fabricate memories (personal, cultural, national, prehistoric) to help forge poetic responses to the shocks of modernity.

title: Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Absolutely take this course, especially with Dr. Rowan Phillips.  He comes up with really fun assignments and will help you become a better poetry writer no matter what your level of expertise is.  You'll also probably make some friends in the class as well.

Absolutely take this with Tracy K. Smith if you can: she strikes the perfect balance between honest and encouraging.
This class has something for everyone: whether you are looking for a PDF-only LA, or are considering the CWR certificate, or have always wanted to give poetry a try but never gotten around to it -- you will not be disappointed! This is a genuinely engaging, low-stress course that you can get a lot out of if you put the time in. Hands down my favorite class I've taken at Princeton!
Actively participate. Take it if you actually care about writing/poetry, otherwise don't bother wasting everyone else's time.
Be ready to read and write. Take it seriously.
Definitely take it if you're considering it! You'll learn a lot about writing, especially poetry.
Definitely take this class!

Definitely take this course. If you love poetry and haven't had the chance to participate in a creative writing workshop to gain feedback on your writing, this course is perfect! Coach M is a phenomenal teacher/person/poet!
Depends on the teacher
Dickman is great, and the intro poetry workshops are a blast and help you think in a new way!
Do all of the readings so you can get the most out of the class. Really put effort into critiquing the work of your peers.
Do it! Take it with Dickman if at all possible
Don't be afraid to try something new and break your assumptions.
If you are interested in poetry at all take it. Also, if you need a class that isn't very work intensive and no pressure take this class. Try to get Tracy Smith she is great at what she does.
If you don't think poetry is for you, then maybe you are right, but maybe you aren't, and if you take this class with Michael Dickman, you'll have a good time.
It's a fun class. Try to vary your poems each week.

It's an awesome course for all levels or experience with poetry. Coach Dickman is really good at presenting feedback in ways that aren't abrasive or stifling and getting you to write things you didn't think you could at the beginning of the semester. Definitely, take this.
Like everyone says, poetry classes are wonderful, and even better if you put the effort into them. Rowan Phillips is full of energy (even at 9am) and gives great feedback.
One of the best class choices I've made. Ben Lerner will blow your mind. Repeatedly. Snidely.
Participate 100% and give it your all.
Put as much effort into this course as you can. Challenge yourself. Professor Youn is a fantastic instructor and poet, and her critiques of your work are extremely valuable.
Read the books! They are really interesting.
Really great course, Lerner creates a great atmosphere for discussion in the class and gives really helpful and interesting feedback for your written work.
Regardless of whether or not poetry is your primary passion, this class will mold you into a better creative writer. For that, I am eternally grateful.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT PLEASE TAKE IT.
TAKE IT, even if you don't have much prior experience. Professor Phillips was terrific and made everyone feel at ease. Such a refreshing 3 hours of the week.
Take
Take it if you're serious and dedicate time to it and you'll learn a lot.
Take it with Monica Youn! You will get a lot out of it.

Take it with Tracy if you want someone to take your work seriously!  Find some way to borrow the collections at the beginning of the semester so you at least always have the physical book to bring to class.
Take it!
Take it! You can't go wrong with creative writing and Professor Phillips is really great.
Take it!!! Coach is amazing. You will truly grow as a poet.
Take the class with Coach Dickman. He's amazing and your poetry WILL improve :)
Take the class, it will help your writing and appreciation of other modern poets. Professor Smith gives helpful, encouraging feedback.
Take this class if you want to work on some poetry with an amazing professor and fellow classmates.
Take this class with Monica! She is amazing and you will get to write poetry all semester.
Take this class with Tracy K. Smith if you can! She speaks in verse and is so kind about helping you out in every way possible!
Take this class! A great way to experiment with poetry for any majors.
This course is rewarding as long as a student is motivated to enough to make time for writing and reading poetry, rather than rushing through everything.

This is a great class! Definitely take it if you're interested in poetry. It's very much what you make of it - you can spend almost no time each week or hours depending on your level of engagement, and you'll get out of it what you put into it. Take it with Tracy if you're interested in working with forms.

YES YES YES TAKE THIS COURSE. and if you can, take it with coach dickman!!!! He is hilarious and a really great teacher. The workload is always light but interesting! My favorite class at Princeton so far. Also, you don't have to know anything going in! just try!
You get as much out as you put into the course.

You will get out of the course exactly how much you put into it. If you even have a slight interest in poetry it is an amazing class. However, if you want to take it just because it's a PDF only and looks easy, there are much better courses suited to those purposes.
You'll get as much from a creative writing course as you give. So really try on your assignments, because you'll appreciate the end result of having grown as a writer.
do the readings
take it, I recommend it to even those not (yet) interested in poetry
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing Program application (please visit the program website) by attaching four pages of original poetry or (optionally) a paragraph explaining their interest in the course..
