descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. This class is open to beginning and intermediate students by application.

title: Introduction to Later Sufism (ca. AD 1200 to present)
reviews: Definitely take this course! The ideas are extremely interesting -- I found myself explaining Sufi concepts to friends many times throughout the course. There is not a significant amount of outside reading/writing, as the focus is placed on fully grasping the conceptual themes from lecture.
If interested in the topic of comparative religion or mythology, or even Islam in isolation, very worth taking. Take it seriously though.
Michael Barry is a great Professor and Sufism is very interesting.
Michael Barry rocks! Any class with him is great.
Pay attention, the stuff is actually interesting
Prof Barry is phenomenal
TAKE IT. Go to his office hours!
Take it
Take it if you are at all interested in an easy fun EM
Take it! One of a kind class at Princeton.
Take it! Super interesting.
Take it.

Take it. Absolutely take this course--I can't recommend it enough. The stress involved is little to none, with few writing assignments and breakdowns of the readings in class--but more importantly the material itself and the knowledge of Professor Barry are absolutely priceless to learn and study. This class is the only I can confidently claim has challenged my reasoning ability and outlook on life. The unusual nature of the theories being studied are both fascinating and eye-opening. I wish every student could take this course, there is so much to benefit from.
Take it. Go to every class. Go to his office hours and have fun! Challenge him.
Take this course and you are not going to regret it. Eye opening, truly.
Take this course. Barry is one of the best lecturers at Princeton and the content of the course is absolutely fascinating. It's really great to explore an NES topic that isn't about politics or war.
This course is amazing, Barry is a fantastic lecturer who cares deeply about the topic. I loved going to class
take it

take it! barry is one of the best lecturers i've had at princeton. he narrates the material with amazing eloquence and his passion is obvious. a sufi master who elucidates concepts because he wants you to learn.
descrip: Popularized through translations of world famous poets like the 13th century Rumi, the Sufi mystical strain pervaded Islamic culture for a thousand years and played a major historic role in furthering friendly relations between Muslims and other religious communities through endorsement of spiritual tolerance. The Spring session of this two-term course addresses the overwhelming influence of the Spanish-Muslim Ibn `Arabi (d. 1240 AD) on all subsequent higher Islamic mystical speculation and poetical literature - as far as India.

title: Latinos in American Life and Culture
reviews: Consider taking with another professor if possible. My impression was that both the quality of the course and the content of the material we studied depended enormously on the professor and varied accordingly from previous years.
Do the readings, go to class - super interesting especially when you are engaged in the discussion.

Excellent I would recommend to anyone, as this is not a class just for Latinos or those interested in Lattino studies, I think it is important for anyone interacting in todays society to understand how the issues Latinos face interact in our daily lives as they become increasingly important especially, and in many ways reflect U.S. society as a whole.
Its a lot of reading, so if you really want to be an expert on Hispanics, this is a great opportunity.
Make sure to do the reading and participate in class
Take
Take this course!! Professor Tienda is so animated, invested in her work and her students, and the material is incredibly engaging and relevant.
This is a really interesting class that covers many topics on Latino studies in a short time. Would strongly recommend if interested in the field of Latino studies or looking for a sociology class.
descrip: This course will consider how Latinos are transforming the United States socially, politically, and culturally, even as they themselves change in the process. Topics to be examined include meanings of "Latino" and "Hispanic" as ethno-racial categories, where Latinos fit in the American social and economic hierarchies, cultural identities, immigration and assimilation, the significance of Hispanics' unprecedented geographic dispersal, and their myriad impacts on mainstream music, literature, and language.

title: Health Psychology
reviews: A great course. I enjoyed it a lot and got a lot out of it. Definitely take it if you have any interest in health, psychology, medicine, etc.
Absolutely! The Section on stress and stress management was especially interesting.
Attend every lecture
Chill class, just copy down EVERYTHING she says and RECORD LECTURES. You will ace both midterms if you just recall everything she said, because that is all that is being tested (via multiple choice).
Come to every lecture and stay alert when taking notes.

Do not bother with the textbook. Go to lecture and take notes on the details of the studies she presents that may not be on the slides. Fill out the review sheets with great detail and you will do well on the exams.
Don't just study stuff on the study guide- know all of the material.
Easy class, though much of the material is commonsense.
Excellent course for pre-meds seeking to understand the role of the mind in medical problems/diseases.
Fun, very little work, learn a lot.
Great course if you're interested in medicine because it's very applicable to that field of study and offers an interesting perspective.

Great course. Some topics are repetitive for psych majors (especially if you've taken social psych, psych 101, research methods) and global health certificate students, but exams are straightforward and grading is fair. Three exams, weekly posts, and a final paper. Not bad.
I recommend this class.
I would recommend any of Keiko's classes to anyone.  She teaches to a broad audience and you do not need a lot of psychology background to enjoy the course.
Interesting class, pretty straightforward, nice professor.
It's a good idea to take this course if you're pre-med.

Make a chart with all of the studies and their IV, DV, and results. And a short note about the methodology. Your performance in this class is largely evaluated by your ability to regurgitate this information.
Psychology is incredibly important as a determinant of health. If you are interested at all in a health-related profession, it's a solid course to take.
Really interesting, but hard to do well in because of multiple choice nonsense
Study guides are very helpful. Not hard to do well in. Provides good general info about health
Take for general interest!
Take it as an interesting enough psych class that requires not much work.
Take it if you have any interest in thing such as global health medicine. If you are a pre-med student the class provides a relaxing change from your usual courses, yet still has much relevance.
Take it!
Take it! It's interesting material and has a pretty low workload.
Take it! It's not a hard class and the material is engaging.
Take it! You learn a lot, the material is so well organized. Just take detailed notes during lecture and the exam will be much more manageable.
Take it. Very little work, nice straightforward exams (they don't try to trick you). Such a relief. And Keiko is a great lecturer.
Take this class! really interesting! great lectures.
Take this course! It's easy and interesting!
Take this course. You will learn valuable information.

This class is good if you're interested in both psychology and health. A lot of the content is very intuitive and common sense though, so it can get kind of boring. Good chill class, but if you're deciding between this vs. something that you're really interested in, go for the other thing. Prof. Brynildsen is great though!
This is a good class if you need an SA, or are premed and want a relatively chill but interesting lecture to supplement other science classes.

This is a good course for anyone interested in psych, health, or premed. Even if you don't fall into those categories, it's still an extremely well-organized and well-taught class with straightforward exams that won't surprise you if you just go to lecture (one of the best I've taken) and take good notes.
This is a really interesting, not too difficult course.
it's a solid departmental. interesting, not too much work. Keiko is an engaging lecturer.
prereqs: One prior psychology course..
descrip: The objectives of this course are to understand the psychosocial processes that influence health and health care delivery. Topics to be examined are the psychophysiological and sociocultural bases of health and illness; pain; adaptation to chronic illness; stress; personality and illness; death, dying, and grief; substance use; health promoting behaviors; patient adherence; physician-patient communication; health care; and medical ethics and utilization.

title: Tropical Biology
reviews: Be prepared for a very physical course!
Intense field course, with little opportunity for feedback. Relevant if interested in ecology for graduate school.

Start thinking of projects early. Try working with a partner in the field - it makes data collection a lot easier. Make use of all the help they provide by asking for feedback on your ideas - especially early in the class, when you are still refining your methods.

Tropical Biology was my favorite course in this program. Yves is the best! He has so much experience in the rainforest and in research; don't be afraid to ask questions, anything that comes to mind even if it isn't related to your individual project. Try to think of a project early on and quickly. Keep it simple because research in the rainforest is harder/more taxing than you think, and the pilot day is extremely important because you don't have much time to change methodology in the middle of collecting data. Make sure to keep checking in with Yves or the TAs throughout the project.
You will love this course.  You will be exhausted, but you'll love it.
Yves has great passion for the subject which is infectious. Working in the rainforest is very interesting but intense and repetitive at times. This is the most work-intensive class in Panama.

Yves is not that great of a lecturer, but an amazing person to be with when you are out in the field. He can explain lots of ecological processes which you don't notice right away, and really helps you develop a research question with his brisk schedule.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester tropical biology program in Panama..
descrip: "Tropical Biology" is an intensive, three-week field course given at four sites in Panama, examining the origins, maintenance and major interactions among terrestrial plants and animals. The course provides the opportunity to appreciate (1) floral and faunal turnover among four rainforest sites (beta-diversity); and (2) floral and faunal turnover along vertical gradients, from ground to upper canopy, at two rainforest sites (vertical stratification). Students carry out individual projects at the sites. Fieldwork is supported by six orientation walks that introduce participants to common orders and families of plants and arthropods.

title: Mechanics of Fluids
reviews: Ask questions outside of class and get to know the preceptors and Professor Hultmark. Stay caught up with the material because many of the concepts build on each other.
Don't take it unless you have to. The material was pretty boring to me.
Dont take it unless you have to
Even if you don't think lectures are that helpful, go because Marcus is hilarious. If you get Yuyang as your preceptor, go to precept because it'll help with your homework.

Go to office hours. Sometimes the textbook is a little difficult to navigate and I personally found some things hard to conceptualize, but I felt like office hours were considerably helpful, so I would highly recommend going.
Great class for departmental. Go to office hours for Marcus.

Great course, gives you a solid introduction to fluid mechanics. Workload is on the lighter side for engineering courses, and psets and exams are pretty fair. Highly recommended for MAEs, CEEs, CBEs, and anyone else who likes to go with the flow.
I loved lectures because Marcus is so great. Get a head start on psets so you can go to office hours...all of the TA's are very helpful and are there to make sure you understand everything going on.
I would take this class if you need to - it won't be super interesting if you are not MAE or CEE but Marcus is easily the best lecturer I've had here.
If you are an engineering or STEM major, take it, but it can take some time out of your day.  Otherwise, how did you get the prereqs for this?!?!
If you are interested, it's a good basis, but be prepared to not understand everything fully.

If you want to be able to build an awesome paper airplane, take this course. Fluid Mechanics is interesting; sometimes the problem sets were difficult and seemingly unrelated to lecture. Hultmark is a funny dude if you pay attention.
Lectures are important. Go to them.
Loved this class. You learn a lot and it is very rewarding.
Make sure you understand psets and the practice exam, pay attention in lab.

Marcus Hultmark is a great professor! He makes fluids fun and is a really amusing professor.  Problem sets are not too bad especially if you read the textbook but make sure you put in the time on the take home practice midterm and final as they are hugely helpful.  Overall, you'll get out of this class what you put in.  You can skate by and let the equations get you through without ever understanding how fluids actually behave but if you put in the work to actually understand the way they behave on an intuitive level, it is really rewarding.
Marcus is a very cool person and a fun professor.  But unless you're really excited about Fluid Dynamics I wouldn't take it unless it was required.
Memorize the Navier Stokes equations and understand continuity amd momentum!

People say it's the easiest of the sophomore departmentals for MAE. Not sure how true that is. Do your work, do practice problems on your own because Marcus and the TAs won't do any on the board, and pay attention.
Probably taking it because they have to. It's a good class!
Read the textbook - very helpful!
Stay on top of the problem sets, and find a good group to do work with! especially a group with people from different precepts!

TAKE! One of the best hard-core quantitative BSE courses you'll find here, and the most approachable of MAE courses. Marcus is the BOMB - energetic, young Swedish dude who is at once incredibly knowledgeable, engaging as a lecturer, has masterful command of the material, and funny, yet also approachable and down-to-earth. Truly a great guy and great professor - dude is super young too so he's super energetic and relatable. Mark my words you won't regret taking a class with Marcus!!! What are you waiting for??!?!?
Take it if you have to! It's good, but I don't see anyone taking it who's not getting a major that involves the material.
Take it if you're MAE, otherwise may not be worth your time
Take it with Marcus
Take this course if it is relevant to your major/studies. You will learn a lot and it is interesting!

The course is interesting and I feel very useful for a lot of different fields of future work. The lecutures are derivations so be should to read the book to understand how to work with the presented material.
This will give you a good introduction to fluids.
You'll likely need to go to precept to know how to solve the problems, the book is useful for reiterating theory from the class but alot of the time that's about it.
take it
prereqs: MAT 104 and MAT 202. MAT 202 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Introduction to the physical and analytical description of phenomena associated with the flow of fluids. Topics include the principles of conservation of mass, momentum and energy; lift and drag; open channel flow; dynamic similitude; laminar and turbulent flow.

title: Mathematics in Engineering I
reviews: Attend lecture.
Be sure to ask questions. Whether you attend class or not, office hours will help you. Also, form a study group--a group to complete problem sets with and to study for exams.
Consider taking the class in the fall - it will be more challenging I hear, but overall I think you'll come out with a stronger foundation

Differential Equations is a really interesting and applicable topic. Many people take it just for the requirement (that's what I did) but I encourage you to be open to learning some really interesting things if you stay focused and keep the whole picture in mind.  In comparison to MAT 201, I thought this was far more applicable and fun in terms of a calculus class so if you were disheartened by math- fear not!
People rave about Professor Stone but I would not write off Yannis Kevrikedes. He was very clear, tried to make stand we always understood the bigger picture and very excited about the material. Stay focused and try to listen to him and you will really be rewarded. He is also very helpful in office hours. Matt Williams was the head TA for this class and he was also awesome. He was a great teacher and ran great review sessions so take advantage of him if he is still involved. 
The midterms were very fair and straightforward, budget your time. The final was hard- prep well! 
Overall, it is not too difficult of a course and is fairly interesting and straightforward. I would recommend it.
Don't fall behind! It could be so good otherwise!
Don't plan on going to lecture, but between the precepts and the book you will learn lots.

For those who have the option of taking this course in the fall or in the spring, take it in the fall with Howard Stone. It's definitely easier in the spring with Yannis (my roommate took diffeq in the fall and it took her all week to do the problem sets. I took it in the spring and it took me one day to do the problem sets), but you'll barely learn anything in the spring. Diffeq is such an important topic for many other classes and applications, so this is actually a class where you want to do yourself a favor and learn the material.
Fun class if you enjoy math.
Go to Matt's precepts!
Go to OHs and review sessions all the time!
I think that taking this course is essential for all students studying engineering.
I'm not sure how many years Professor Kevrekidis has been teaching but he is not the best at getting the material across the first time in lecture. His midterm exams are not as demanding however.
If required, take. If not required, maybe.
If you have to take this class it should be fine.  I would not take it otherwise.

It isn't as difficult as you would think a 300 level Math class would be. But it is extremely interesting. Please take it. Professor Yannis is criticised by many but I think he is wonderful plus even if you don't like him, you'll definitely like Matt Williams and you can always read Professor Stone's notes.
Keep up to date with the material.
Kevrekidis is still pretty good (although people seem to prefer Stone). You can definitely still learn a lot in the class.
Kevrekidis' version of MAE 305 is easier than Stone's version, but you'll probably learn more in the latter.
Not a particularly difficult course, but Stone is a much better lecturer.
Not terrible, just stay engaged
Read Stone's notes.
Read the book and professor stone's notes
Start psets early.
Take if you have a general interest.
Take it as you need to
Take it if you are an engineer.
Take it if you have to. I hear that taking it in the Fall with Prof. Stone is a nightmarish amount of work, while Yannis is much more fair and lenient.
Take it in the fall.
Take it with Stone in the fall.
Take it: its worth learning
The material can be a little dense if you're not very interested in it. It's not a bad course at all, but the lectures don't help all that much if you are not motivated to pay attention to them.

Though people say 'take it with Howard Stone!', taking diff. eq. with Yannis is not a bad idea at all. Don't feel bad if you can't take it in the fall - the spring is almost as good. You focus on slightly different things.

Very conflicted feelings about this course. It's useful for many engineers, and it's meant to be an applications course. If you're MAE/ELE you should definitely take it. Taking it with Prof. Kevrekidis might not be what you expect  though. He's definitely running an easier course than Stone, and goes over more or less the same content with the same notes, but his psets are straight from the book (aka very easy), his lectures aren't as engaging, and his exams are very straightforward. Probably better off taking it with Stone in the fall, but that'll definitely be more challenging and probably help master the material better. Kevrekidis will teach you the stuff, but at a lower level of proficiency and an easier pace. The choice is yours.
Yannis is brilliant and funny. His lectures are entertaining and informative, although sometimes they get a bit too repetitive on the simple concepts.

Yannis is great and a very interesting professor. He cares a lot about his students, so if you are lost, do not hesitate to ask questions! His lectures are not always easy to follow, but if you read the book and ask questions, you should be able to keep up. Homework difficulty is very fair. Midterms are also very fair...not too hard at all. The final exam, however, is a different story...the final is a lot harder than the midterms. Prepare yourself.
You can excel at this course by reviewing the notes you take in lecture on a daily basis and by starting the problem sets early. The textbook is pretty much unnecessary.
You will not learn anything with Professor Kevrekidis, take it with Professor Stone instead.
You'll know if you need to take it. Yannis is not a bad lecturer, and his class is probably a little easier than Stone's class.
nah
prereqs: MAT 201 or MAT 203 and MAT 202 or 204. Open to freshman with instructor's permission only..
descrip: A treatment of the theory and applications of ordinary differential equations with an introduction to partial differential equations. The objective is to provide the student with an ability to solve problems in this field.

title: General Chemistry II
reviews:
-Read the textbook as much a possible, perhaps even before lecture because it is such a valuable tool
-Be prepared to teach yourself most of the material. Lectures can be helpful but not often, plus they often skim over material that you need to know, so the book is your best bet. 
-Don't work with other people, honestly. It will help you in the long run if you don't try to get other students' help and seek individual tutoring if you're struggling. You should try to understand it on your own.
A ton of work. Only take if you have to.
Apply yourself IN LECTURE. This is where the majority of the necessary information will be given.
Ask questions and don't be afraid to seek help.
Attend all of the lectures.
Do all the readings outside of class, even if you think you understand the materials, because the text book will actually turn out to be very useful.
Do the textbook readings and understand what you're doing on problem sets.
Do tons of practice problems!
Doing a thorough job on the problem sets will set you up well for success in the course.
Don't be scared of taking the course, it's not that bad as long as you understand the material and psets given.
Don't do it if you don't have to.

Don't go to McGraw study hall or the weekly review sessions, because sometimes the information they give you is incorrect and may confuse you more if you have a question that needs clarification. 

Question yourself further than what they cover in lecture material.

Read the explanations for the demonstrations in class after you are fairly familiar with the subject material and understand the mechanisms behind the demonstration.
Don't take for fun; take for interest or requirement
Don't take if you got a 5 on the AP exam. Redundant and may be a bit boring since the material is so familiar. This class was easier than my AP class.
Don't take it if you don't need to.  There are a lot of tests.
Don't take it unless you are premed.
Don't unless a prerequisite

Even if you don't go to lecture, definitely go to precept because that is when all the loose ends/lingering questions people have had during the week get tied up and things begin to click. You only have one problem set a week, and a lab report write-up every few weeks. So while it may be time consuming just by the sheer number of hours you are in lecture/precept/lab, the content is not as difficult as other intro math/science courses like PHY 104 or MAT 201/202. Totally manageable.
Go to all of the lectures and adequately prepare for the lab practical and written finals.
Go to all of the review sessions with Colleen, and establish a study group to help you get through the problem sets.
Go to lecture and don't take Tao as a lab TA.
Go to lecture, then read the textbook if you don't get it still.
Go to lectures, precepts, and review sessions. Review your problem sets before tests. Read the assigned chapters from the textbook.
Go to review sessions and make sure you do lots of practice problems.
Good for a requirement
Great course that will help develop and nice overview of chemistry

I enjoyed this course a lot, even though I was apprehensive because I didn't take CHM201. It was well-structured, and well-supported. Professor Chan and Professor L'Esperance were engaging lecturers who really knew what they were talking about, and the course is structured so that by the end, you had a holistic view of Chemistry. I enjoyed the course, and would recommend it to students who are planning on taking orgo or any other future science class.
I recommend this class for anyone interested in learning the fundamentals of chemistry.
I think that this class is boring and the material is not presented in the best way. Tests can be all over the place. Only  take it if you have to.
I would advise another student to stay on top of the reading and to go into office hours if they have any questions on the material.
I would advise any future student considering taking this course to stay on top of the textbook readings.

I would advise anyone to take this course if it is a requirement or if they love chemistry. I would also advise students to get to know their Professors and TA's because they will be key to your success/survival in this class.
I would advise other students considering taking the course to read the book whenever possible because it offers a conceptual background that makes understanding the course much easier.
I would advise them to attend all lecture and read the textbook after lectures but before doing the psets.
I would advise them to pay very close attention in lectures, and to go to office hours.

I would recommend future student to continuously do the reading from the text book. Also, each preceptor is different and learning how to manipulate your studying skills or asking questions to have your preceptor help you in the best way that works for you is critical.

I would recommend that students make sure to review their notes everyday and practice different problems everyday. I would also suggest that if the student has not taken chemistry, to devote much of their time learning it.
I would recommend that they read the book

I wouldn't recommend this class to someone who doesn't have to take it as an essential requirement. I found that reading the book and asking questions during precept was the most helpful way to understand and learn the material. I would also recommend going to office hours if any problem comes up with the lab reports. The Lab TAs are super nice and helpful. Definitely don't procrastinate on the lab reports, some of them are ridiculously long.
I wouldn't take this unless you have to and definitely search online for notes to supplement your learning
If you can place out of general chemistry, do it. It's not a bad course but it is not intellectually stimulating in any way, shape or form.
If you have to take it, take it. I think the first semester for chem is better though.

If you love chemistry, this class is an excellent introductory class.  It will reinforce topics that you learned in high school and teach you new, challenging material.  If you are looking for an easy STL, this is not the class for you.  This class demands and rewards hard work.
If you want to do when in the class, make sure you do the readings before lectures in order to help you understand.

In order to really get as much out of the course as possible, I think it is crucial to really go through the problems within the textbook and then come to the precepts to go over the material. This will truly help facilitate your knowledge of the material.
It is a big time commitment, but if you stay on top of your work it is manageable.
It is what it is, Gen chem teaches you chem in depth more so than high school, but don't expect anything too exciting.
It's a good class to take because it lays the understanding of a lot of things that happen in physics and biology. Plus, Chan is pretty entertaining. Also, it's required for CBE and premeds.
Just do the readinfs and keep up
Keep up with the material and ask for help if you need it.
Keep up with the readings and go to lecture. Demonstrations during lecture help understand some concepts. If you need help, do not hesitate to contact your preceptor or other faculty.

Keep up with the syllabus. Read the assigned textbook chapter(s) for each week before coming to class. If you don't keep up with the textbook, you will have no idea what the professor is trying to explain during lecture. Don't leave problem sets for the last minute. Work with your friends if you have to. Study for tests ahead of time (e.g. study your notes a few hours a week). This makes it less stressful to study for exams. Labs reports are easy if you use the lab webpage (link can be found on Blackboard). This webpage tells everything you need to do for each lab report.

Lectures can be boring, but Garnet likes putting lecture questions on exams. Make sure you do the problem sets and practice exams because that's where RPL likes to get his exam questions. Labs were somewhat enjoyable.
Liked it more than 201. As far as grading and difficulty, nothing changed really.

Make sure that you read your textbook because it is very helpful. Also, keep up with your problem sets because you can ask questions about it in precept if you don't understand something. Also, Professor L'Esperance is very nice and very helpful if you don't understand something, either from his lectures or Professor Chan's lectures.
Make sure to go to lecture and read the textbook! If you do, you'll definitely do well.

Make sure you go over the psets after you get them back and really understand what you did wrong. Overall the course gives a fairly comprehensive understanding of acids/bases, electrochemistry, bonding, etc.
Make sure you understand every concept before moving onto a new subject! Go over all the problem sets and don't be afraid to ask questions when you're confused.
Not fun, but if you have to do it, it's not bad as long as you study.
Not that hard if you took high school chemistry.  Do the readings and you should  be fine.
Obviously, take it if you have to, but I wouldn't bother going to Chan's lectures.
Only take it if you need it for a requirement. Read the textbook and redo all problem sets/practice exams before tests.
Problem sets and lecture notes were all very relevant to exams / doing well in the class
Read the chapters before lecture, or at least before your precept so that you can ask questions during precept.
Read the notes, that's where most of the exam questions come from. The reading is helpful, but if it wasn't covered in lecture, it's not going to show up on the exam (learned this the hard way).
Read the textbook. It often helps more than lectures.
Read the textbooks for understanding the material.
Read your chapters!
Review the material to solve the problem sets, study notes/psets/textbook/old exams.  Go to lecture and don't stress about labs - as long as you analyze your results correctly, you'll do fine.
Some people say that Professor Chan is disorganized and doesn't explain clearly. Very false. He's your best shot at liking chemistry if you don't already.
Start problem sets early in the week, go for help when you need it, read the sections in the book
Stay on top of your readings and really try hard on the problem sets.
Stay with the material each week.
Study hard, and really take the time to concentrate on it.
Study, go to lectures and it'll be fine
Take advantage of all the outside help you can
Take if you have too--keep up with all the moving parts
Take it if you need it.
Take it if you need the class to fulfill a requirement.
Take it if you want to learn how stuff works.
Take it if you're premed
Take it only if you have to. Not recommended for non-science majors trying to fulfill a STL.
Take it! Very interesting and positive tone.
Take only if needed
Take really good notes on the textbook and review problem sets.
Take this class if you're interested in chemistry or need to take it before organic chemistry!
Taking Chm 201 prior to this course would be recommended. I tried to do it off of AP credit and had a hard time refreshing myself on old chemistry knowledge.
This class was much better than CHM 207.  The lectures were more interesting, and the class was better organized.  The class requires substantial time and effort, but it is enjoyable overall.
This course demands a good amount of time to study for the exams
This is a course in which you need to review regularly and go over material on your own outside of lecture and classes. Basically, stay on top of the material yourself.

This is a nice class to take as a requirement or if you just have a general interest in the sciences/chemistry. Professor Chan is a great lecturer who will make you become interested in Chemistry and will teach you how to view the world around you through the eyes of a chemist. The labs are more interesting than in 201/207, and overall you do not need to put in tremendous amounts of effort or time to do well in this class.

This was a fairly easy introductory course. The lectures were interesting and the precepts helped clear up any confusions you may have with the lectures. As long as you keep up with the work, you should not feel too stressed.
Utilize your resources and do not waste (too much) time.
Very well taught class that requires a lot of effort.
Work hard. review the material before it piles up. Go to the review sessions. They are really helpful
You probably have to take it.

You'll probably take this if you have to anyway for your major or for premed - I would take a different class for your STL if that's all you're looking for.  But it's a good class, and you learn a lot without having to do too much work.  Just generally pay attention in lecture, and study for the tests.  There's not too much work - just a reasonable p-set every week.  Basically just stay on top of it and it's fine.
You're probably considering taking this course because, for whatever reason, you have to. With that in mind, it is not too tough, nor is it too easy. Just attend lecture to get by well enough.
be prepared to do a lot on your own. I found videos to be most helpful
go to lecture it helps
if you have time read the chapters in the textbook before there is a lecture about them that way you will have an initial exposure to the material
learn the basics of chemistry well
take it if you need it, but not just for a distribution requirement.
prereqs: This course is a continuation of CHM 201; also open to CHM 207 students. Students must have an AP score of at least 4,
descrip: Continuation of 201. Principles of chemistry; introduction to chemical bonding and solid state structure; chemical kinetics, descriptive inorganic chemistry; laboratory manipulations, preparations, and analysis. Fulfills medical school entrance requirements in general chemistry and qualitative analysis. Three lectures, one class, one three-hour laboratory.

title: Remembering the Future
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
reviews:
CBE 346 is the core CBE class.  I was amazed at the resources that are used on this class. Just looking at the lab, the amount of TAs, teachers, and materials used on this lab is really pretty cool. That being said, it was a great class - because it showed me that I don't want to be a chemical engineer.  It is sad that this class comes so late in the CBE program because it is really the first introduction to what chemical engineers do.  And frankly, measuring hot fast rods heat up or how dye moves through a polymer isn't how I imagine most people want to spend their jobs.  

In terms of grading, the course is so subjective it is comical.  The difference between professors is huge and whoever is the grader makes all the difference. Another huge difference is the TA you get for each lab, some are very helpful, others not so much so it really influences your grade.  But back to subjectivity, you will work hard for a presentation to have it be argued that you had lines on a graph where there shouldnt be and one of the two professors didn't like that.  It's sad that most of the time, the professors would rather not help the student and criticize them for not understanding material during a presentation or lab report instead of trying to help the student understand the material before hand. It's almost like the professors specifically don't try and help the student so they will be able to criticize them later.  

My best advice is to choose a partner that you know you will get along with and will get the work done and don't take it too seriously. You will be working late nights, you will spend way too much time on your lab reports, you will lose time you normally spend on other assignments for this class, and yet, you will be criticized for things you would never know or have thought to think about and you will be criticized for stylistic things that don't actually matter.  So, have fun in the lab, order pizza for late night lab sessions, and blast some music.. and DON'T take it too seriously.  Pretty soon it will be over and you won't have to worry about if your error determination was displayed just too much or too little (there is no correct amount you will find out, only too much or too little).
I mean... you're only taking it cuz you have to. Start lab reports like 3 days before they are due. Read the lab manuals before you get to lab.
It is a required course and will take up a lot of time.  Even so, you learn a lot about the practice of chemical engineering that previously has only been touched on in lectures.
It's core lab. You're stuck at this point. It's gonna suck, a lot. But you get a nice sweatshirt at the end. That's worth your sanity and health, right?
It's really not that bad. Lectures aren't very useful, but you learn a lot about the best ways to present data through your reports and presentations.
Its one of those classes you have to get through.

Lol good luck. At least you'll have two nicely written papers and a poster to show for it. Just note that this class will take up a lot of time. Start the lab reports early. The one nice thing is that you finally get to see the concepts you learn in other core class in action.
Make sure you analyze your data after every lab session, this will help you out when it comes time to write lab reports and prepare presentations.
Not nearly as bad as it is made out to be.
Pick a good lab partner.
Plenty of work, but not the worst CBE course. Just try to do something creative with each lab.

Spend a lot of time early on analyzing data. Reports take longer than you think to do well. Think critically and quantitatively - go above and beyond what's expected from you as stated in the lab manual.
Stay on top of the material - it takes a lot of time every week. Some weeks are lighter so make sure to keep up to date.
Stay on top of work and analysis throughout the semester. Pick a partner you know you'll work well with.
Take it because you have to.

Talk about error in everything. Everything. 
Think really heavily about your working style and your partner's working style before finding a partner. Find someone who you would match well with (not necessarily a friend).

There is a difference between giving helpful, constructive criticism and being downright mean. Unfortunately some of the professors seem to prefer the latter and like to bully the students with, for example, presentation questions that are merely asked to put the student on edge and make the student flustered and are completely irrelevant to the analysis and discussion of the data.
Understand how the labs work and make sure you got a plan for each day.
Well you have to take it as a CBE departmental

Work comes in waves. Weekends you have lab reports due, expect to do nothing but them. Not as bad as I was expecting, but still a lot of work. Grading seems pretty arbitrary. Make sure you work well with your lab partner.
You have no choice to take it but you will learn a lot of invaluable skills.
You have to take it, so just put in the time and don't procrastinate! Pick a damn good partner.

You have to take this. However, this course really isn't painful at all if you just stay on top of analyzing your data and don't wait until the last minute. It's a lot of work occasionally, but, again, manageable if you budget your time well.
start writing your report early and talk to your professors about what they want in the report because the manual won't tell you
prereqs: CBE 246, CBE 250, and CBE 341 or equivalents..
descrip: An intensive hands-on practice of engineering. Experimental work in the areas of separations, heat transfer, fluid mechanics, process dynamics and control, materials processing and characterization, chemical reactors. Development of written and oral technical communication skills.

title: Intermediate Hebrew II
reviews: Expect a decent amount of work, as the course is every day, but very manageable and will learn a lot.
If you have interest in Hebrew, I would recommend it.

If you want to learn Hebrew then this is what you take...if you're just looking to satisfy a language then Spanish or another romance language will probably be easier. That said, this is a really cool and fun class and Anna has an amazing understanding of languages, so if you're interested in linguistics/translation/etc or that sort of thing then you will have some amazing conversations with her. Also Anna sees Hebrew for the beautiful language that it is so she's really enthusiastic about it which is really important if you're learning a language from someone.  Take it.
Take it!
prereqs: HEB 105 or equivalent.
descrip: This course is designed for students who have completed elementary modern Hebrew language courses, and aims at further developing their reading, writing, speaking and aural comprehension skills. Emphasis will be placed on grammar and syntax, on conversational skills, and on creative writing. By the end of the spring term, students will achieve mastery of the Hebrew verb patterns, and proficiency in constructing complex sentences, and will be able to read and analyze literary works, discuss various media contents, write essays and make presentations.

title: Jesus of Nazareth: Ancient Controversies, New Interpretations
reviews: Do all the readings because this is what will make or break your engagement in the discussions, which is the main part of the course. Take this course! Regardless of what faith you practice or don't, take it! She is an incredibly insightful professor, very passionate, and she is pretty much as neutral as any professor can be in a course like this. AMAZING!
Highly recommended for any students interested in the life of Jesus, or biblical studies.
Take it. Professor Pagels is wonderful and the material is fascinating and eternally relevant.
Take the class and be open to engaging with the questions that will be raised.

This is a great course, as long as you come with an open mind. Professor Pagels is an absolutely phenomenal teacher and person, and you will be exposed to texts and viewpoints that may challenge your own notion of Christianity. An absolutely fantastic course for my senior spring.
descrip: We'll investigate the earliest known sources about Jesus--New Testament gospels and "gnostic gospels", including the Gospel of Thomas, Mary Magdalene, and Philip; then check sources written by Jewish and Roman outsiders to the movement to see what they say about the actual historical context and how various people interpret Jesus (as revolutionary, healer, rabbi, prophet, magician, God). We'll also look at interpretations of Jesus in film, art, theater, fiction, and other contemporary sources, including those suggested by seminar members.

title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema
reviews: Absolutely do it, Fantastic class and not too hard
Absolutely take this class! It's awesome!

Be patient if it takes a while at first to write the movie responses. I found I had an easier time writing the response if I watched the whole movie. Also be aware that the average level of the class is intermediate ? there will be beginners who will struggle, and people with more advanced / fluent backgrounds who might feel awkward.

I would recommend doing some review of basic tenses just to get Spanish flowing in your mind. I would highly recommend this class if you are looking to improve your speaking skills and have a fun and intimate class environment.
I would recommend this course. The movies were all very good and Gorka is a really great teacher. Lots of work at times but by no means unmanageable.

Lots of movies and lots of presentations, but good practice in speaking Spanish and helpful review for the less intuitive grammar structures (and thankfully not solely focused on grammar). I think it's good if you want to keep your Spanish up and you're done with the 100-level classes.

Overall this course really helped me increase my fluency and go from the level expected at SPA 108 to a more advanced speaking and writing level. 
The weekly blog posts are graded strictly in regards to grammar, but I felt this was helpful in making me revise my writing and understand the grammar mistakes I was making.
There were 5 spoken presentations throughout the semester, and 3 of them and several other assignments were in the second half of the semester. Therefore, for the spring semester at least, the second half of the semester is very work heavy and can be difficult to manage.
Also, some of the movies have very violent and graphic scenes of war, abuse, and other difficult topics. They are cinematographically well done, but I just wished I had been warned the extent of this kind of content. I would advise taking a look at the movie list and looking them up on imdb if this is a concern for you.
Otherwise, Gorka is a fantastic teacher who really cares, and this was a fantastic class which really improved my proficiency.

Practice your spanish in class! That's the best way to improve. Also, actually look at the feedback on your written weekly posts/compositions. If you incorporate the corrections on the next assignments, you will actually see an improvement in your writing/in your grade as well.
Pretty interesting, nice change of pace from reading or writing. The movies are decently interesting
Take this course if you was a relaxed environment to help improve your speaking skills. The movies are a fun break but you can still get a lot our of the course.

The course is a fun and engaging way to learn Spanish, but do not kid yourself that it will be easy.  The course hums along unassumingly for the first half and then unleashes hell in the second half: you have only two weeks or so to watch an additional two supplementary films on top of one film per week and weekly posts or presentations, and you have to do three presentations over the last five weeks or so, as well as a composition and a four-person interview discussion.  Take it if you are really serious about the language, but be warned that it's a lot more work than it should be (and you can't BS any of it -- all graded very strictly).
The expected Spanish skill can be scary in the beginning of the course, but stick with it! It's a great class.

This class has a reasonable workload, and the material is also pretty interesting. You'll be doing a lot of presentations and a decent number of short written assignments (300 words weekly posts and two papers).

This course has students watch some really good movies. It's a great way to work on your Spanish. There are a good number of assignments that help to serve this end, notably students give a number of presentations.

This is a good class. It's a little bit time consuming because a lot of the movies are 2  hours. Still, if you engage in class, you'll improve and have a great time. I think I would have gotten way more out of it if I had talked more, so TALK!
Timing consuming

Very fun Spanish class for someone who wants to keep up or improve their speaking and writing skills without taking a rigorous course intended for people pursuing a degree. I suspect that it was easier for me than some of my classmates as I had already taken Spanish 207 (which was thoroughly unenjoyable and tedious but did give me a good foundation on grammatical structures).
Whatever grade you get on your first assignment is the same grade you'll get all year. Take it as a blessing or a curse.
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission) or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or a satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: A course designed to improve speaking abilities while learning about Hispanic cultures and cinema in context. The course aims to provide the students with lexical and grammatical tools to allow them to engage in formal and informal discussion on a variety of topics informed by the films provided. Additionally, there will be several writing exercises throughout the semester that will help students improve their writing abilities. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of all linguistic skills, especially listening comprehension, fluidity and accuracy in their speech.

title: Economics of Food and Agriculture
reviews: A pretty easy departmental - only 4 problem sets and you can drop one. However, lectures are very boring. Professor Weyerbrock is helpful if you need it and wants everyone to understand, but doesn't do a great job lecturing. Class feels a bit disjointed, but doing the readings helps as a of the lectures come from the assigned readings
If you're really interested in the topic then take it but not the most exciting professor
It's a chill class.
Lectures can be a bit dry, but the material is really interesting and useful, and Professor Weyerbrock is one of the nicest profs I've had!
Take it, it's a cool class and the Professor is really great if you ever have any issues
The material is fairly interesting, but there is not much more to be gained from the course than the is contained in the readings. Recommend/neutral, leaning recommend.
You'll have a good time; it's not too hard!
easy class, but a little dry. learn about food/agricultural system through applying econ 100/101-300/301 material.

weyerbrock could not be nicer, and is organized, but she is super quiet, which makes it hard to pay attention.  good for if you are an econ major, pretty chill, but despite its name, not good if you are taking it for general interest
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 required. ECO 300 (or ECO 310 or WWS 300) recommended. We will study both theoretical economic models and review empirical papers to help us understand concerns and controversies related to food and agriculture. Knowledge of and ability to use microeconomics tools are particularly important..
descrip: Hunger and under-nutrition are widespread in poor countries while an obesity crisis is growing in rich countries. Rural-urban income inequality occurs throughout the world and farming and food industry practices everywhere have significant adverse effects on public health and the environment/climate. What are the economic causes of these problems? Are agricultural, food, nutrition and environmental policy measures currently proposed to deal with these problems effective? This course uses theoretical and empirical economic analysis to study the agricultural and food sector and related government policies in rich and poor countries.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing wtih the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students/post-docs.

title: Introduction to Engineering Dynamics
reviews: Anyone taking this probably has to, just be warned that it's a pretty time consuming class.
Do the readings and start the problem sets early.
Don't take it unless you need to because it is very time consuming and not an easy course, however if you need it or like the material it is interesting and well taught.
Enjoy the class - read the book, force yourself to have a strong foundation on this. Don't push studying off.

Follow the notation Kasdin uses and just let the math do all of the work.  Also give yourself  more time to crank the math as the semester progresses because the problems become much more progressively involved with the last three psets taking up lots of time to work through the math.
Go to lecture!  Start the problem sets early, they take longer than you think!
Great class, use office hours.
Great course. A little slow at first but very challenging towards the middle and end. Kasdin is great. Would recommend
It's a good course, but the end of the course is really hard and can catch you by surprise.

Out of the required courses for MAEs, I would have to say this was my favorite lecture-based class so far, mainly because, although the content is still considerably difficult, it was taught in a well-organized way, and Prof. Kasdin and the TAs were always there to help.
Read and use the book!
Start on the psets early.
Start the psets early
Stay on top of the material. Workload builds pretty intensely through the semester, and you can easily get overwhelmed if you fall behind. Class material is interesting but can become time-consuming.
TAKE IT. Go to office hours and do the readings before class.
Take if necessary, but this class is definitively a headache.
Take the course but don't underestimate the difficulty of the material towards the end of the course.

This class is just algebra.  All that you learn that is actually new is an algorithm that only works well for complex 3D problems, and two simple equations.  Other than that, you do algebra and lose points for mis-notating stuff.  You rarely lose points for actual dynamics.
This course is well designed and will teach you a lot about dynamics, however, be prepared to give it a lot of time.
Watch your notation and go to lecture.
You have to take it if you're MAE. Otherwise, I'd save myself the 5  hours a week on P-Sets

You have to take it, so suck it up, go to precept, and go to class. Yes, it's at 8.30. Yes, you will regret not getting up when exam time rolls around. Problem sets are graded very tough, so sweat the details, because they'll matter. Kasdin's awesome, though.

You'll probably only take this if you have to, but I like Kasdin a lot and enjoyed this class. Be prepared for a mild obsession with formatting, but also with a lot of cool examples and demonstrations.
You're going to need to get help with this course, figure out what office hours you can go to, get a group together to work with, don't leave psets to the last minute.
take it if you have to
prereqs: MAT 201 and PHY 103. MAE 223 or CEE 205 recommended. Freshmen may take the course with the instructor's permission..
descrip: Formulation and solution of equations governing the dynamic behavior of engineering systems. Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics. Two and three dimensional kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies. Motion relative to moving reference frames. Impulse-momentum and work-energy relations. Free and forced vibrations of mechanical systems. Introduction to dynamic analysis of mechanical devices and systems.

title: Directed Research II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research II has to be taken before the General Exam.

title: Popular Music in Japan from the 19th Century to the Present
reviews: Don't take it if you're interested in J-Pop. It wasn't a very exciting/interesting course. Only a few units were engaging.
descrip: What does popular music tell us about the social history of Japan? This course examines music from the beginning of Westernization to the present, including children's songs, military marches, enka, jazz, rock, hip-hop, reggae, techno, Okinawan pop, J-Pop, anime/video game music, and protest music. Through close listening, analysis of translated lyrics, and readings, we consider the role of music in forming national identity, supporting social movements, and defining subcultures. We also analyze musical aesthetics, including the ways they are shaped by language and technology.

title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)
reviews: NA
No excuse for not taking it.
Rotations are a good idea. Rotations help you find out if you like the lab in terms of both the people and projects.
Stick it out and you'll learn a lot about yourself and what you are able to do. Pick new and exciting rotations to learn new skills.
descrip: Students perform research in the laboratories of potential faculty advisors.

title: The Just Society
reviews: Ehh. Maybe take something else.
Good foundation for economic political theory, but a bit dry/tedious
I have recommended this course to certain peers of mine interested in politics.
Switch your preceptor if you know that he's not helping you understand the reading.

Take this class if you are even remotely interested in economic justice. I would especially recommend this class for students who have never taken a qualitative approach to understanding the concept of economic justice. This class will make you a more informed member of society by teachings you how to engage social and moral debates in a rigorous manner.
Take this if you are interested in theories of social justice, not present day policy questions.
Take!
This is a great class to take for an EM if you're at all interested in political theory!  The lectures are great and the workload is very manageable.
This is an okay class. Patten is a solid lecturer, but readings will be dry if you're not terribly interested in the topic. An okay EM.
descrip: An introduction to theories of social justice and examination of their implications in areas of contemporary social and political controversy. The first half of the course introduces the problem of social justice and examines two classic positions, as articulated by John Locke (whose name is associated with liberalism, property, and capitalism) and Karl Marx (whose name is associated with the critique of capitalism). The second half of the course focuses on contemporary theories of justice. We will read authors such as John Rawls and Robert Nozick, and examine controversies over poverty, taxation, equal opportunity, and environmental justice.

title: Music since 1945
reviews: Be willing to listen to music which isn't pleasant, especially at first. It gets better after the first half.

Donnacha is a GREAT professor. He is very knowledgable and also an easy person to be around. Every lecture and precept was well prepared and although we moved through material quickly, he always made sure that everyone was following. There were weekly listening reports and 2 listening quizzes in the semester that could be a challenging weekly workload, but are worthwhile. I definitely recommend this class, however some musical background is necessary. Your ears will learn to become much more detailed listeners in this class as well.
Listen
Professor Dennehy is a really interesting and engaging composer himself, and it was really interesting to hear his take on each piece and composer.
Take it if you need a good music departmental. A little obscure if you're just interested in contemporary music.
Take it. Even non-musicians can get by and learn tons... Can be life-changing for people.
prereqs: Students should be able to read music..
descrip: A look at the wide range of musical styles and personalities since World War II, including avant-garde and experimental approaches, the effects of technology, and influences from non-Western and popular idioms. Emphasis will be on listening and discussion, with the goal of understanding the attitudes, objectives and achievements of individuals and groups as well as their interaction with the culture at large.

title: Literature and Society - Where is Now? The 21st Century Novel
descrip: This course will consider the state of the novel, post-2000. The diverse texts we will examine explore shifting narratives of global circulation, historical change, technological development, and environmental disaster, among other concerns of the new century. We will also consider selections from contemporary critical and theoretical investigations into these issues.

title: Fundamentals of Biofuels
reviews: Definitely pay attention and keep up. It has a lot of biochemistry that I was not prepared for.

Do not take this class even if you have an interest in biofuels. Lectures are awful because Professor Avalos just reads off the slides. Exams are hard to study for because the handouts have so many extra details that it's hard to know what the main point of anything is. This was the most poorly taught class I took at Princeton. I lost my interest in biofuels after sitting through these lectures.
Don't take it
Don't take this course. The professor does not care and the subject matter is all over the place.  Least favorite Pton class
Go to all the lectures or you will get lost easily
It was Prof. Avalos' first course so it was still a little rough around the edges.  Hopefully in a year or two it will realize its full potential, being about such an interesting and pertinent topic.
Its an okay class.  Study for the quizzes and tests.
Take it if you're a CBE with interest in biofuels or biological engineering in general.

Take this course if you're interested in both energy and biology. The first half of the course focuses more on energy and the second more on biology. I think having biochem experience would create a deeper understanding of the material. Avalos knows that most people don't have a biochem background, but he still goes into detail about pathways and techniques that are unfamiliar to most of the students. I feel like this class has a lot of potential, but because it's his first year teaching it, it wasn't as great as it could have been. Avalos is very knowledgable, and is always willing to help, but you have to schedule private appointments through email.

This class requires almost no time outside of lecture, and also very little prerequisite knowledge, so definitely a good 5th class. I really enjoyed the material, although it wasn't organized very well.
Try and pay attention in the lectures, he gives you a lot of neat information

Very comprehensive overview of biofuels. You get out of the course what you are willing to put in. First time this course was offered, and while Prof. Avalos was dry and boring in lectures, you will learn a lot if you endured through it. I predict the course will only get better with time, as he learns his way around Princeton and the department. Try the course out and don't let the negative recommendations here dissuade you. He is also one of the nicer and friendlier professors in the department. I enjoyed it.
prereqs: CHM 301/303 Organic Chemistry, MOL 345 Biochemistry, or MOL 214/215.
descrip: This course defines biofuels, and explains why we should make them. It presents the challenges and opportunities of sustainable biofuels, addressing issues of land use, and competition with food production. It describes production processes of first generation, and cellulosic ethanol. It covers microbial engineering to improve production, or make new advanced biofuels. It describes the use of photosynthetic organisms such as algae, which fix carbon directly from the atmosphere to make biofuels. It addresses the environmental, economic and societal impact of biofuels, and how they can fulfill their promise as a renewable source of energy.

title: Topics in French Literature and Culture - L'homme et la machine: Labor, Value and Technology in the 21st Century
prereqs: 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will examine the historical relation of humans and machines from the Enlightenment to the present. The exponential transformations in machine intelligence and power that have occurred in the last decade force us to ask: do humans no longer wield prosthetic tools to increase their power over nature, but are instead becoming, as Marx famously predicted, the mere prostheses of machines? In a contemporary context in which by current estimates some 47% of all human labor - material and immaterial, low- and high-wage, `First-' and `Third-world,' - may be automated in the next two decades, how must we reconceive the human itself?

title: The English Drama to 1700
reviews: Be involved in the discussions-you'll make the most  of the class by steering discussion where you want it to go.
Cadden will talk for 3 hours straight if no one interrupts him or asks questions, so speak up with contributions or if you want to know more.
Definitely take courses with Professor Cadden - he has a wealth of knowledge and experience that will enlighten you and enhance your appreciation of the subject material.
I definitely enjoyed this course and would recommend it to anyone with an interest in the origins of modern drama.
Take it. Be prepared to read and talk a lot.

This is definitely a class that you need to be invested in. It is generally quite small, so you have to get the reading done and I would recommend taking the course only if you are actually interested in the topic. That being said, if you are interested definitely take the class!
prereqs: None, but a working knowledge of the following Shakespeare plays would be useful: Hamlet, The Merchant of Venice, Richard II, Twelfth Night, The Tempest, and Romeo and Juliet..
descrip: A study of English drama from its medieval origins to Restoration comedy, with special attention to major non-Shakespearean Renaissance playwrights such as Thomas Kyd, Christopher Marlowe, Ben Jonson, Thomas Middleton, John Webster, and John Ford. We'll study the theatrical conditions that gave rise to this body of dramatic literature, its characteristic thematic obsessions (gender, sexuality, power, revenge, and magic--as well as theatricality itself), as well as the ways in which the plays are performed today.

title: Modeling Tools for Cell and Developmental Biology
reviews: An excellent class for learning about quantitative fundamentals of cell and developmental biology.
It's a great course to take if your general interest lies on this subject.
The class is only worth it if you read the relevant papers and participate!
This is a very interesting course. You discuss papers every week and have a few assignments that aren't that bad, but you don't receive any feedback on them.
To brush up on your linear algebra and differential equations.
prereqs: Undergraduate differential equations and molecular biology.
descrip: The course provides students with conceptual and technical methods for constructing and analyzing mathematical and computational models of processes in cells and tissues. The course covers models of cell cycle, metabolism, and signal transduction. We will cover the basic ideas of dynamical systems, biochemical kinetics, and stochastic processes. These tools will be applied to explore dynamics in systems such as bacteria infected by viruses and animal embryos. Students will also work on research projects based on the publications that demonstrated how experiments and theory can be successfully combined in studies of biological systems.

title: Economic Development II
prereqs: ECO 562.
descrip: Selected topics in the economic analysis of development beyond those covered in 562. Topics are selected from the theory and measurement of poverty and inequality; the relationship between growth and poverty; health and education in economic development; saving, growth, population, and development; commodity prices in economic development.

title: The Sociology of Crime and Punishment
reviews: Good course, especially if you're interested in criminology. Really not too much work
Great class- definitely take.
I would definitely recommend taking it!
If you have any interest in theories of crime and/or deviance, take this. Professor Chancer is an amazing teacher and she will make sure you understand the material when you leave the class.
TAKE THIS COURSE! favorite class I've taken. very interesting.
Take this! It's a very interesting course, and Professor Chancer is knowledgeable, enthusiastic, and willing to help. There is a lot of reading, but the material is worth it.
descrip: This course seeks to provide a sociological account of crime and punishment. Why do people commit crime? How should we respond to crime? How has crime policy changed over the past several decades? What are the consequences of recent crime policy? By reading classic and contemporary sociological research, policy analysis, and media coverage, we will explore the themes of crime and punishment in contemporary society.

title: Organic Chemistry II with Biological Emphasis
reviews: Accept you're gonna spend a lot of time, and you can do well.
Be proactive. Attend lectures. Try to enjoy the material.
Be ready to work hard. Go to lecture and take all the practice midterms. Writing your own set of notes based on the lecture notes and the textbook readings is very useful.
Buy "Chemistry as a Second Language" (the second semester edition).
Comparable to CHM 303

DO NOT, I repeat, DO NOT take this course if you are a freshman. Enjoy your first year and don't harm your academic standards. As for the rest of you, this course is HARD. You've probably read other evaluations saying that if you work everyday and try to enjoy what you're learning, you'll get a lot out of it and feel very satisfied academically. Take that advice, and mine, with a pinch of salt - every person learns and experiences differently. Personally, this course was a never-ending struggle mainly because the style of teaching and exams were too difficult to actually enjoy the content. If you're pre-med, you obviously have to take it. Just don't kill yourself while doing it. Attend lectures, do the readings, go to review sessions, and most importantly, form study groups. DO NOT try to do this on your own, do not be cut-throat competitive about this. It is a hard course and everyone struggles no matter what they try to portray themselves as. Learn to work together and delegate parts of the readings or problem sets to one another. That's how you'll make your next two semesters more bearable.
DO PRACTICE EXAMS OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER.

Definitely attend and be attentive in the lectures. I would recommend reviewing the day's lectures as part of your daily homework. It is easy to forget about it once class is over but the tests come up VERY quickly and it is extremely difficult to learn and synthesize that amount of information quickly enough to get a good amount of studying in. Also, do well on the first two exams.  The third one and the final are usually the hardest tests.

Do every single practice test. Make sure you understand the fundamentals of chemistry when approaching a new question such as reactivity, stability of intermediates, etc. That will get you much farther than blind guessing. Professor Semmelhack drops your lowest midterm, but do NOT get behind and do NOT just "drop" a test and choose not to take it because it is very easy to get behind. If you study hard for each of the midterms, you will not really have to study for the final. Organic chemistry is cumulative. 

ALSO, if you did well in 303 stay with Professor Semmelhack in 304B! If you are considering switching professors ask an older friend for advice or ask someone  about the different exam styles because Sorensen tests focus a lot more on synthesis (obviously), but the material is also tested in a slightly different way that I found very difficult.
Do not fall behind on lecture material. Don't be afraid to use TAs as resources.
Do not take this class unless you have to.  It is extremely hard and extremely boring.
Do not take unless premed.
Do the reading, go to lecture. Take advantage of all the resources and you will do great! All instructors are great!
Doing the practice exams multiple times is a good way to study for the exams.
Don't do any work for this class other than taking the tests, but study hard for those by taking most of the practice tests.
Don't fall behind!! It is very hard to catch up.

Don't go in determined to hate the class because it is a pre-med requirement. Don't go in afraid of the class because it has a reputation of being difficult. Try to savor the material and take advantage of all the tools they have to help you succeed, and I think you will really enjoy the course, because when you stop trying to memorize your way through the notes and stay engaged and on top of things, organic chemistry is a really fascinating class. And go to Professor Semmelhack's office hours!! They are super helpful and pretty fun, in my opinion.
Don't take it unless you have to. If you love chemistry, there are so many better taught and generally more engaging courses that you can opt for.
Don't take this unless you have to.
Don't take unless you have to. You know who you are.
Go to office hours! Professor Semmelhack is more than willing to re-explain concepts taught in lecture.

I liked 1st semester orgo so I thought I'd like this- I was wrong.  It's much more work and harder work.  Semmelhack's teaching also really goes downhill- he explains things much less, and practically stopped writing out mechanisms because "the mechanisms should be obvious" to us.
I loved organic chemistry and it is completely manageable.
I really enjoyed orgo, despite what other people commonly think of it. If you like solving puzzles, this is a class for you!
I've heard Sorenson's section is a bit easier in respect to the actual content they cover, however he doesn't allow any open notes during exams so pick your poison.
If you don't know what you're doing, find a friend who does. Not so hard once you can start predicting how mechanisms will proceed

If you want to get a good grade, do solve all
the past exams again and again.
It was extremely well organized and provided a lot of resources. You can always rescue a bad midterm grade.
It's a time-consuming class, but it's very well-taught. Lots of support available.
It's hard but do the work and put in the time and it's definitely acheivable.

It's tough material that you'll be able to learn if you're motivated enough to put in the time on your own and at the numerous review and help sessions that are available. Take advantage of those review opportunities!

Keep track of all the mechanisms you learn! No one else will for you, but you will be tested. Even if you understand every mechanism, it's REMARKABLY helpful to have a comprehensive list, esp in synthesis. I'd also strongly recommend investing in the Organic Chemistry as a Second Language series & skipping the book. The series is much cheaper and MUCH more informative.
Keep up with the material, attend lectures and precepts, try not to fall behind. It is a very rewarding subject, so you should take it!

Make sure that you stay on top of the topics and attend lecture! It will help you so much if you don't have to learn everything right before the exam. Also do all of the practice tests for every test.

Make sure you are super engaged in the course. Make sure you do all the readings, go to all the lectures, do all the problem sets, do lab reports early so you can ask for help, do all the practice tests! Don't save anything for the last minute! Treat this course like your job and you will get a very high grade!
Orgo is hard, but if you put the time in you'll be fine.

Orgo is inevitably a lot, but they do a good job of making it as smooth as possible. By second semester, the 3 2hr exams plus the final is a bit much, but there are so many resources to help, so use them! I would study by scanning over the lecture notes and/or study guide if he makes them, reviewing concepts you don't understand, and then diving into the practice exams. You'll survive, I promise.
Precept can be helpful sometimes, but not crucial. Get Dave. He's the man. Or Jon.

Study hard. 

Actually, go to McGraw sessions and study hall, work on problem sets with others, study with each other. This is a hard class and it is definitely beneficial to help each other understand the material better. Don't feel like you have to do everything yourself because that will be difficult. There is a lot of material in the course so take it bit by bit.
Study your butt off for the final!
Study. A lot.

Take advantage of all the resources (precept worksheets, practice exams, problem sets, study guides, office hours) that this course offers! The amount of help this class gives is unparalleled to any other course at Princeton, and organic chemistry is definitely less painful than what its reputation makes it seem.
Take it elsewhere in a program whose primary interest is not challenging the top students while everyone else struggles to grasp basic concepts.
The best advice I can offer is figure out what works for you early and start practice exams early. No one will stop you if you gradually fall behind.

There is a heavy biological emphasis by the end of the term - the B in 304B certainly counts.  The course is still awesome, but I felt it diverged from my interests a bit in the second half. I think 304 would have been a better choice for me.
This is a very challenging course. Probably more challenging than 303. Don't underestimate it and don't fall behind.
