This was one of my favorite courses at Princeton so far. The class was interesting, well organized, and challenging. DO ALL THE PRACTICE TESTS.
Try to keep up with learning the weekly material because the second semester accelerates exponentially and becomes very cumulative in the material
Would only take this if you have an extreme interest or you have to. Definitely not easy, but definitely rewarding and interesting material occasionally.
don't take it if you want to stress from pre-med students, because there are a lot of people taking it for the medical school requirement.
if you're not premed and like to study, take it
it's ok.  study practice tests
put the time into it, really focus in lectures
study hard. stay on top of it--make sure you understand the lecture each week. do not fall behind.
take it because it is really manageable and i feel smarter now
take it if you have to
there is no reason to go through this pain
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303. Course is open to freshmen..
descrip: The concepts introduced in CHM 303 will be extended to the structures and reactions of more complex molecules, with an emphasis on how organic chemistry provides the framework for understanding molecular processes in biology. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry will be illustrated, as often as possible, with examples drawn from biological systems. Appropriate for chemistry and engineering majors, premedical students, and students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Special Studies in the Nineteenth Century - Strong Narratives
descrip: This seminar will focus on Victorian texts that have shaped the way we understand the period and its attendant cultural meanings. Each text is associated with a paradigm that characterizes Victorianism or a Victorian legacy for subsequent generations of readers and scholars. We will read these texts as fundamental to the creation of the field of Victorian Studies in the mid-20th century and in conjunction with exemplary critical statements (Leavis, Williams, Eagleton, etc). Students will introduce recent criticism that reshapes our understanding of these texts and the period.

title: Special Topics in Dance History, Criticism, and Aesthetics - Mobilizing Bodies/Dancing the State
reviews: Get ready to move your thoughts and your body.

I strongly recommend taking this course. Professor Hamera is brilliant and extremely supportive. This class completely changed how I conceive not only of dance but the movement of bodies in our society. I loved this class.
I would tell them that they absolutely must take this course, regardless of their field of interest or experience with dance.

This class is a nice space that contradicts some of Princeton's general academic prejudices, and you should certainly take it if you are in the humanities, and should probably take it if you are in anything else.
This is an amazing course. Dancers and non-dancers should be required to take it. Don't be afraid to participate as Prof. Hamera will help you with your half-baked ideas.
descrip: This course investigates dance as a theoretical model for, and a practice of, mobilization and identity construction, with special attention to the ways these practices have been used by a range of nation states. Forms studied include hula, Soviet ballet, modern dance at the height of the Cold War, Indonesian classical dance under the Suharto regime, and hip hop in contemporary France. The seminar meets once a week; activities include dance assignments, readings, discussions, and viewings of performances. Guest artists will conduct studio sessions in a number of the dance forms. No prior dance experience is necessary.

title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
reviews:
ALWAYS DO THE READINGS BEFORE LECTURE -- that was you know what to expect and what to listen for,
but Prof. Blinder will really help answer questions, so don't be afraid to reach out
Alan Blinder is an amazing lecturer who knows his stuff and history and how to tie them up together.
Be ready to do a lot of algebra.
Be willing to do the readings. Be willing to spend time on problem sets. Be ready for a B.
Definitely a good class to take if you're at all interested in how our economy got to where it is today, or want to be more informed about economic policies.
Definitely relevant, sometimes interesting, not too difficult--would highly recommend.

Definitely take macro with Blinder! He's a great lecturer! Although, be aware that you have to read an entire book and write 2 essays at the end of the term. Also, try to get into Cristian's precept! He's super helpful and makes worksheets for students that summarize all the most important points!
Do all of the readings!
Do all the readings and study.
Do the readings and p-sets. The exams are heavily based off the readings and p-sets.
Do the readings and start the Psets early

Do the readings. Brace yourself for the true false questions on the exam, they'll often ask about very specific things from articles you were supposed to read. Occassionally they'll ask about things you've never heard of, but just suck it up and try to use your introductory course level intuition I guess. Or sacrifice a goat and pray. Who knows. Office hours are pretty helpful too, and Professor Blinder seems like a nice guy.
Don't stress about it.
Don't take it with Blinder.
Easy, Prof. Blinder is a great lecturer. If you do anything in the course, read his book After the Music Stopped. A must for understanding the past 10 years of the US economy.
Get Blinder. Get in his precept.
Get Cristian Alonso as your preceptor!
Gives an excellent overview of the macroeconomy and some policy issues. Well-balanced workload, take it in freshman/sophomore year if you can!
Good course to take for PDF and requires very little work. But to learn the material fully, be prepared to put in the work.

Great course for anyone who wants to have a basic understanding of topics like inflation, GDP, monetary policy, exchange rates and other terms you read in the newspaper. Professor Blinder is a fantastic lecturer, and it's a real treat to learn from someone with the experience he has. The problem sets take very little time. Overall the course is light on workload.
Great for getting a general understanding of economics

Hard class to take for just general interest, but Alfonso is a good explainer. IT's a really hard course though and Blinder gives quite a bit of extra work in terms of Dean's Date assignment and reading his book.
I highly recommend taking this class. It is a manageable amount of work, and concerns topics that everyone should have a fundamental understanding of.
I learned a lot in macroeconomics. Blinder is a great lecture and he is an even better preceptor. Definitely take macro with him.
I really enjoyed this course. I got to learn a lot about the financial crisis. Prof. Blinder's lectures were very interesting.

I think that this is a course that everyone should take, regardless of concentration, as it provides a general knowledge of concepts that are applicable to everyday life. Definitely take it if Blinder is teaching.
I would advise students taking this course to keep up with the readings to understand what is being covered as well as possible.
If you are hoping to PDF, perhaps take it with a different professor.
If you can take this course with Blinder.
If you don't have an economic background, you should at least take this class.
It's ECO 101.  If you're gonna take, you're gonna take it.
It's a pretty straight forward and bland economics course. Good to take if you're considering economics as a major.  It convinced me not to do econ...
It's an easy class and the knowledge you will gain is invaluable.
Just stay on top of the concepts and you'll be fine
Keep on track with the readings. Seek out extra practice material so you are better prepared for the exams.
Keep up with the class and the material.
Keep up with the readings.
Keep up with the textbook readings
Lecture and precept are worth going to.
Read each week
Read the book
Read.
Really useful in understanding current events.
Take it if you need to or if you're interested in being a bit more informed about how economies work.
Take it!
Take it!  Everyone should know basic economics.
Take it! Try to get Blinder as a preceptor if possible. Try to go to class and do the readings ahead of time if possible.
Take it. But it is not an easy course.
Take only if you need it as a requirement for your major, otherwise take ECO 100
Take the course if you want to be an informed citizen.
Take this class. You will establish a great foundation in macroeconomics from an expert in the field.

This class is relatively easy as long as you don't slack off on the weekly readings. The concepts build on each other. Also, doing the problem sets is a crucial part of learning the material. You can read the material and think you understand it, but you'll not really know it until you apply the concepts in a problem.
This class is what you expect with more reading.  If you pay attention and go to precept you will be fine.  Pedro Olea is an amazing preceptor.
This course is really not so interesting and it is a lot more work than I expected. It's not particularly hard...it just takes a lot of time.

This course, while good for those who need it for their major or who are considering certificates that require it, is also useful for anyone who just wants a better background in macroeconomics and who wants to learn how the economy works.

This is an easy course to take as a distribution requirement, but it can also get you thinking about the conflicts between politics and economic policy. If you have strong arithmetic skills most of the coursework is a breeze.
This is knowledge every educated citizen should know. Take it for your sake and for the sake of your country.

This was probably the best course I had this semester. The design of the course screams of experience and professionalism. Everything is amazingly streamlined and, compared to my other Econ course (ECO100 with Professor Reinhardt), this was designed and executed almost to perfection.
To go to lecture, because the connections to real historical events are interesting.
Very interesting, well taught, and well organized course. The material taught is also useful in understanding real world macroeconomic events.
Yeah, worth taking econ because it's econ... but maybe not with Blinder.
You should definitely take it if you have an interest in economics.
You should take it if you find the macroscopic view of the U.S. economy and the world (In some sense) interesting.
ask questions in precept
chill class. Not too difficult. Keep up with the readings because they appear on the midterm and the final exam. Not time consuming at all. It is an easy fifth or even sixth class to take.
do all the readings
do not take this out of curiousity
follow the textbook
fun
give it a try
take it if you want to major in economics, if not, don't bother.
prereqs: ECO 101 is offered both terms and may be taken before or after (or simultaneously with) ECO 100..
descrip: Analysis of the operation of the national economy, with emphasis on the causes and consequences of recessions and booms, inflation and unemployment--and possible policy responses to each. Attention is also paid to the banking and financial systems, the financial crisis, and international influences on the U.S. economy.

title: American Economic History
reviews: Bogan Great as ever. Take it.
Bogan a great lecturer for this type of class, which is admittedly difficult. Nikhil Gupta (preceptor) was great, he knows his stuff. Good amount of readings about good stuff.
Bogan is incredible. Go to her office hours and get to know her.
Do readings carefully for midterm and enjoy class discussions! Super engaging, really enjoyed this course. Not difficult, though readings can be long
Do the pequod readings - they're interesting and you'll also be held responsible for them on the midterm and final
Do the readings
Get into Nikhil's precept! Best precept I've ever been in.
Great!
I found it pretty dull, I'm sure there are more interesting ways to fulfill such a requirement
I like it!
If you are interested by American Economics, take this course. If not, it will be more difficult to get through it.
If you're interested in history and economics, this is a great mix.  Prof. Bogan is one of the best.
Memorize the slides for exams
Nikhil Gupta is the best preceptor I've ever had. The class has a good amount of reading but very useful for understanding the economy and society of today in general.
Professor Bogan is a freaking badass. Take her!
Professor Bogan is great. Take.
Professor Bogan is quite over-rated as an Economics professor. If you really like history, take it. If you're taking it because you're interested in Economics, don't.
Take it! Just keep up with the readings and lecture notes!
Take it.

Take the course.  I am terrible at humanities courses and was looking for an HA.  This was a fantastic choice.  It's one of the few history courses where quantitative skills might actually be helpful in understanding the concepts.  The exams are a bit nit-picky but are curved accordingly.  If you didn't enjoy or do well in ECO 100/101 though I would not recommend it.
Take this class for a good overview of how to apply macroeconomic theory to historical events and problems.
Take this course if you have any interest in American history or economics! Professor Bogan is probably the best teacher here. She has a real passion for teaching that is refreshing here.
Take this course. It's a great way to learn about economics and American history all in one class.
Take this course. Professor Bogan is great and goes out of her way to get to know students.
The textbook reading is not relevant.
This course is extremely interesting, probably one of the best that I have taken so far. The workload is fairly ok, and the readings are extremely interesting. Highly recommend!
Too much memorization about history tested on exams instead of general thematic stuff.
good course
its a lot to talk about
take it! do all the packet readings
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. These are firm prerequisites, NOT co-requisites. This course counts towards WWS disciplinary perspectives requirement..
descrip: Modern economic theory is used to analyze growth and fluctuations in U.S. output from colonial times to the present. The course examines the role of labor markets, property rights in land and labor, financial institutions, transportation, innovation and other factors in economic growth. Before examining twentieth century fluctuations, a week is spent on business cycle theory. Then particular emphasis is placed on The Great Depression and its relationship to the recession of 2007-2009.

title: Writing, with Pictures: Logographs, Texts and the Image
descrip: Non-alphabetic writing was once considered a primitive stage from which "proper" i.e., phonetically-based writing systems evolved, displacing such "picture writing." This course studies writing from the perspective of such "ideographic" or logographic systems and returns to the question of how writing and the image continue to interact even in putatively phonetic written contexts. Students will investigate Egyptian and/or Mayan hieroglyphs as a case study but engage as well with theoretical discussions of writing in the work of post-Structuralists and art historians.

title: Special Topics In Urban Dance - Hip Hop Dance Practice and Culture
reviews: Anyone and everyone should take it! Physically-demanding but worth it
Fun, engaging class. I would definitely recommend it to other students who love hip hop.
Go to the studios! They are very helpful and you learn a lot.
Great class. Awesome LA.
Take it to learn about hip-hop, b-boying, or just culture and music more broadly! Also to expand your movement vocabulary and the way you think about dance.
Take this course if you're interested in hip-hop dance. It's great and the professors are really nice and knowledgeable.
of course take it. this isn't even a question.
prereqs: Faculty permission and application is required. Please apply at the following link: http://arts.princeton.edu/academics/dance/dance-courses/. The application deadline is December 1st at 12pm.
descrip: This special topics course gives equal weight to the scholarly study of and embodied practice of various forms of urban dance. Hip Hop Dance Practice and Culture will explore the history and cultural context of different forms of hip hop such as b-boying, uprocking, popping and locking. Practice will center on breaking, but related forms such as house dancing and its subsidiary forms waacking and voguing, will also be explored. With an emphasis on non-commercialized dance forms, students will view videos and performances of hip hop cultural practice and read related texts that give historical and theoretical perspectives to the studio work.

title: Material and Human Landscape Literacy and Pedagogy
descrip: This course provides tools for understanding material things and landscapes that humans created and lived in over time, enabling us to unpack the social and historical logic embedded in small- and large-scale artifacts and to devise ways of teaching through these objects, built and unbuilt environments and the work processes that shaped them. Transcending periods and specialties, and supplementing textual and iconographic approaches to understanding and teaching history, this methods course is especially relevant to students interested in history of urban and rural environments, technology, cultural construction, work, and everyday life.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Guy Nordenson is a joke. I can't say he's the worst studio instructor, because that would be calling him an instructor.
Only if you are very interested in the specific issues of coastal resiliency
Press Guy to answer questions of structure.
Try to take it later.
descrip: Part two of a two semester sequence in which fundamental design skills are taught in the context of the architect's wider responsibilities to society, culture and the environment. Students acquire a command of the techniques of design and representation through a series of specific architectural problems of increasing complexity. Both semesters are required for three-year M.Arch. students.

title: Introductory Physics II
reviews: Apparently the professor has proven that self studying is more effective than teaching the course. So you'll be doing a lot of self studying, try to keep up with the material and do practice problems outside of class. Hope that it's taught differently when you take it.
Be prepared to teach yourself, and set aside time to do so.
Don't stress about clicker questions. Show up prepared for group work in precepts!
Don't take.

For a required course for premeds, this really wasn't awful in terms of how much you learned and felt like you got out of the course. However, curves are tough because the majority of students are premeds.
Go to office hours and work through problems outside of the packets.
Highly recommend Vikram as your preceptor Awesome preceptor! Really cared about the students learning more and always willing to go the extra mile to help students.
I

I heard there's a new professor in charge of the class next year and the organization of everything will change. Maybe that will be better.

Honestly, though, you're probably stuck taking this class anyway. Sorry.
I liked the course, but lectures and precepts aren't really as helpful as PHY 101.
I mean it wasn't terrible, still probably wouldn't recommend unless you have to.
I would definitely use and read the textbook when studying! It gives you details that you would otherwise miss from the Coursera videos or in precept.

If it's flipped-classroom format again next year, watch (or play in the background) all your lectures on 2x speed, answer the embedded questions as they come up, and read your textbook in the meantime.
If you need to take it, you're going to. Get Vikram as your preceptor. If you have more physics background, take PHY 103/104. It'll be more engaging probably.
It's a lot of work but teaches you a lot. Many topics are covered very quickly!

It's not so bad. Understand the concepts and do the problems that you're given. This semester is a little more difficult because the concepts are more abstract than the first semester. If you can, get Vikram; he's super helpful.
Make sure to stay on top of the packets and to make sure you understand the questions

Make sure you devote time to studying for weekly quizzes. Not horribly difficult, but still a good deal of work and because of weekly quizzes you can't really slack in this course.
Only take it if you need to.
Make sure you understand problem sets. If pre-med I recommend taking the course elsewhere
Not an easy course, but definitely better structured than 101!
Not too difficult as long as you keep up with the material each week. And the class is structured in a way that you have to keep up -- weekly quizzes, coursera videos.
Only take it if you're doing so for pre-med. I wouldn't suggest taking it for fun unless you're really into physics.

Only take this course if you have to-- also be sure to read the book on your own and do lots of practice problems, since precepts and lectures are not nearly enough to get a conceptual understanding of the 102 topics.
Only take this if you have to. Much more difficult than 101.
Read the book; everything makes sense after you read it.
Read. Take the time to prepare. Don't fall behind.
Really try to understand the concepts rather than only doing practice problems as this will prepare you for the exams.
Study for the quizzes and you won't feel as overwhelmed when the midterm/finals come around.

This is a tough class. Have no illusions about it. Physics 102 is hard. The midterm was absurdly difficult and the curve was harsh. The quizzes are not easily ace-able, and require routine problem-solving EVERY DAY of the week to do well on. This is a hard class, I repeat. Attend all precepts, and correlatively do NOT sign up for 9 AM precept. You need to be there to understand the concepts. Meet regularly with your preceptor. Try to actually understand the demonstrations during lecture. Use one evening a week to read the chapter, and another 4-6 to practice. Good luck, and study very hard for the exams. There is no other way.
This is probably a requirement for you, but don't let that fact keep this course from being fun! (Also, you want Vikram as your preceptor. He's hilarious and has the best office hours.)

Unless you have to take it as a pre-req (which is usually the only reason anybody takes it), I wouldn't take it. It wasn't particularly difficult, just annoyingly time consuming and frustratingly organized.
You get out of this class what you put into it. The class requires a lot of hard work, so remember to keep up with the material.

You have to take it because you are pre-med, but I am ashamed that this is a class at Princeton.  You are taught nothing and learn nothing except on your own, and if that is true, I don't understand how Princeton is the best undergraduate education in the country.  Take the other Physics for pre-meds.  I don't know if it is better, but it literally cannot be worse.
You should take it

You're going to have to take it if you're a premed. Don't worry too much about the class--it's pretty well structured and you'll already have PHY 101 under your belt by then. Take PHY 102 over 104 though unless you need 104--I know of premeds who started on the 103-104 track and switched back down to the 101-102 track. It's better for the MCAT anyway.
You're probably only taking this course because you have to. Don't expect to learn much of anything from the professors or preceptors - you're basically on your own.
avoid at all costs. this course laughs at you while it steals away your time and flushes it down the toilet. for the love of god and all that is holy, DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.
don't take it unless you are pre-med, because people will be fighting to get great grades.
go to lectures, participate
take it if yo have to. It won't be fun.
prereqs: PHY 101.
descrip: This course presents an introduction to the fundamental laws of nature, especially optics, electricity/magnetism, nuclear and atomic theory. These are treated quantitatively with an emphasis on problem solving. The laboratory is intended to give students an opportunity to observe physical phenomena and to gain "hands-on" experience with apparatus and instruments.

title: Sources of Terror in American Literature and Culture
descrip: See website

title: Orchestral Music: Analysis and Performance
reviews: Definitely take it :)

Interesting material, pretty light workload, nice in that regard. We got to go see Aida at the Met, which was very exciting. The class is small enough that other students will heavily affect the experience of the class as a whole, so that's something to consider.
take this class if you can. You will love it.
prereqs: Open to members of the Princeton University Orcherstra and Glee Club..
descrip: Using the Princeton University Orchestra's spring 2015 concert programs as the primary focus, the course will explore the composers Giuseppe Verdi and Ottorino Respighi. The core repertory is Respighi's Pines of Rome and Verdi's Missa da Requiem. Lectures and discussions will explore composer biography, historical context, and music analytical insights for each work. In addition to the central repertory, other works by Respighi, Verdi's operatic output, related choral repertory, and Italian music culture will be discussed to frame and better appreciate each composer's artistic achievements.

title: The Philosophy of Kant
reviews: Definitely take this course if you're interested in Kant's ethics! Professor Hogan is hilarious and so chill, and we got into so many engaging philosophical debates.
Good class to learn about one of the greats in philosophy from an expert.
Maybe consider how extroverted you are before taking it, or any seminar. But if you feel like you're the kind of person who likes to contribute to class discussion, I'd say take it.
Take it.  Prof. Hogan is super smart, and also funny and a nice guy.
prereqs: At least one Philosophy course..
descrip: An examination of Kant's ethical doctrines.

title: Environmental Challenges and Sustainable Solutions
descrip: Course focuses on environmental challenges and sustainable solutions related to interrelationships between constructed and natural processes. The format of the course is experiential learning with problem-solving research projects, lectures, and discussions. A central theme of the projects is to track the impact of land use and sustainable practices on the ecological balance of environments in and around Princeton's campus.

title: Intermediate Twi II
prereqs: TWI 105.
descrip: This course expands on the language skills acquired from TWI 105 and continues to focus on the communicative approach to studying the language. It includes specific socio-cultural settings and events. Speaking, reading, writing and listening continue to form an integral part of the course and students will build on their grammatical skills. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Novice High and Intermediate Low.

title: Formal Political Analysis I
descrip: A rigorous introduction to choice theory, social choice theory, and non-cooperative game theory. The course serves as the first formal theory graduate course and draws on mathematics at the level of POL 502.

title: Epidemiology
prereqs: This is a required course for graduate students in the Health and Health Policy certificate program..
descrip: Course covers the basic concepts and methods of epidemiology and demonstrates how these can be applied to improve population health and reduce health inequities. Topics include: measuring the health of the population, understanding the causes of poor health, developing interventions for improving health, translating evidence into practice, and evaluating the impact of policies and programs. Key epidemiological concepts such as association, bias and confounding are covered, as well as the main epidemiological study designs.

title: The American Dance Experience and Africanist Dance Practices
reviews: Definitely take this course!
Great class! Definitely take it!
Take it! Super fun, written work is easy, you gain a respect for the dancing, and it's a workout!
Take it. It is fun and you learn a lot about different forms of dance and how they are related and the history/interconnectedness.
Take this course! Especially if you've never danced before. You have to experience this class before leaving Princeton.
Take this course!!
Take this for a fun and chill class within which you can learn to move your body!
This course was super fun and stress-free
prereqs: Some form of social dancing, good, natural movement aptitude, or former dance training. This is an OPEN ENROLLMENT course..
descrip: A studio course introducing students to American dance aesthetics and practices, with a focus on how its evolution has been influenced by African American choreographers and dancers. An ongoing study of movement practices from traditional African dances and those of the African diaspora, touching on American jazz dance, modern dance, and American ballet. Studio work will be complemented by readings, video viewings, guest speakers, and dance studies.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Brazilian Cinema Novo and Beyond
descrip: A close examination of the most important Latin American film movement, Brazil's "Cinema Novo" (New Cinema), an explosive blend of innovative cinematic style and political critique from the mid-`50s until the early `70s. Simultaneous developments in the visual arts, theater, music and literature will also be addressed.

title: Democratization and Human Rights in the Middle East
descrip: This course explores the dynamic relationship between state, society and the economy in countries such as Egypt, Morocco, Tunisia, Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia and Yemen. It provides a review of the theoretical and philosophical underpinnings of the democratization and human rights literature as it pertains to the Arab world and encourages students to examine how state institutions and civil societies (positively and negatively) shape a variety of political phenomena and outcomes in the Arab world, including reform policy and democratic transition.

title: The Great War in Irish Theater, Literature and Art
reviews: Just be very engaged
Take this. You won't regret it. O'Toole's an amazing lecturer and a very friendly person in general. You actually learn things from this seminar and it's so much fun.
descrip: The Great War of 1914-1918 was a defining experience for the modern world. Ireland was no exception: around 40,000 Irishmen died. But unlike in other cultures, the memory of the war was largely suppressed in Ireland, in part because it conflicted with the nationalist uprising that began in 1916. Writers who tried to represent it often found their work suppressed or ignored: most famously, Sean O' Casey's play The Silver Tassie was rejected by the Abbey. In this course, we excavate forgotten memories and explore a fascinating tension between remembrance and amnesia.

title: Personal Genomes, Medicine and Algorithms
descrip: See website

title: American Scriptures
reviews: Definietly take it! Very managable

Fabulous! Professor Perry is extremely enthusiastic and loves what he teaches - it's so much fun to be in class with him. Big final project, but on a week to week basis the reading is interesting and manageable. Highly recommend it.
If you don't take this course, you're foolish.
It's a well-taught course with a fairly light workload, so if you think the material is interesting then take it!

One of the best (maybe the best?) class I've taken at Princeton. You want to meet Seth and study these fascinating texts. This is the only morning class I've ever actually gone to because it is THAT good.
Read as much of the scriptures as you can, and read with an open mind. You can't dismiss anything because it's ridiculous-- that leads to pointless discussion.
Really interesting course, great professor, relatively laid back-- take it!
Take it! Truly interesting day in and day out.

Take it!!! I learned so much and the class was full of awesome conversations. Professor Perry is wonderful and is genuinely interested in what students say in class/precept - considers us equals in the discussion. Honestly I loved it.
This class is a fun, engaging, informative SA that is perfect for people whose schedules are filled with LA classes. Take it if you  have ever been curious about new religious movements in America.
take this course! its awesome!
descrip: The relative novelty of American scriptures allows us entry into the most essential questions of scriptures' meaning, function and use: What is a scripture? How does a text become one? We will discuss selections from The Book of Mormon, Science and Health, Message to the Blackman in America, and Dianetics, along with several other new-world scriptures and, by way of comparison, the American histories of some old-world scriptures. Emphasis will be on reading and reflecting on these texts as primary sources, investigating their internal logic, discursive influences, and rhetorical effects to think about how communities have formed around them.

title: Taboo and Transgression
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Empire, Slavery, and Salvation: Blackness in the Atlantic World
descrip: An exploration of portrayals of blackness in literature, travel writing, painting, and autobiography from Spain, England, and the Americas. Students become versed in debates surrounding the emergence of human distinctions based on religion, race, and ethnicity in the early modern era as they analyze a variety of historical representations of blackness. Understanding these debates and the history surrounding them is crucial to participating in informed discussion, research, and activism regarding issues of race, empire, and colonialism across time and space.

title: Syntax
reviews: Give it a try
I don't really know what to say.

Only take this course if you are really interested in linguistics, particularly syntax. Having said that, this course is fun with a very manageable workload. The problem sets and exams are definitely challenging but not inordinately so. The professor is always willing to help and goes at the class' pace (not the syllabus').
prereqs: LIN 201 or 212, or with instructor's approval..
descrip: An introduction to the syntax of human language, focusing on the mechanisms of sentence construction and the general principles that determine their operation. The focus is on the structure of English, with some side trips to other languages. Designed for students interested in a scientific approach to human language and a better understanding of its structure.

title: PhD Seminar: Research Design
descrip: This is a research design course. We will discuss some issues in the philosophy of science, analyze questions of conceptualization, proceeding to problems of descriptive inference, objectivity, and causal inference, including role of causal mechanisms. The seminar will continue with analysis of how to avoid bias, tackle issues of historical change. Students will present their own research designs and critique their colleagues. Emphasis will be on qualitative research, but the argument underlying the seminar is that the same basic principles of inference apply to qualitative and quantitative research.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Civil Liberties
reviews: A great course and a must-take. It is challenging, but highly rewarding. It taught new ways to approach highly complex issues, and the value of boiling debates into their essential philosophical and moral elements.
ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS CLASS.
Always show up to lectures: you're missing out a lot if you don't, as you don't get nearly as much from the readings if you don't come and listen to Prof George.
Definitely take it. I had never taken a course that presents both sides of an issue and is completely fair to both sides. I learned so much.
Definitely take it. I had to PDF because of other courses but still learned a lot and had fun doing the assignments.
Do it. Do the readings. Talk to the professor.
Do the readings

Everyone should take this course! Professor George is a legend - the way he crafts arguments and explains the material is unparalleled. The preceptors are all incredibly knowledgeable about the subject as well. It is a lot of reading (I did enjoy reading Supreme Court cases and the supplemental reading), but what you get out of it is so worth it.
Find a preceptor whose style you like.
Good
Good POL course, but there are definitely better.
Grading is tough, but class is awesome. Work with your preceptor to know what is looked for on the midterm and final exercises.
Great PDF! Very interesting lectures.

I think Professor George is an excellent lecturer. This course was always interesting and challenges you to really think through your opinions. The only negative aspect was the precepts, which I wish had been more of a forum for discussion. I had Russ Nieli as my preceptor and I found him to be both offensive and unhelpful.
I would recommend this course, especially if you are interested in the constitution, supreme court cases, and the development of changing laws in America.
If you interested in politics, history, law, and philosophy, take this course!

If you like philosophy / constitutional theory, this would probably be very interesting.  Beware though that it is not a discussion of the moral implications of interesting issues but instead a theoretical discussion of constitutional interpretation.

It is a difficult course in the sense that you are graded on the basis of precept participation and a midterm and final paper, which are not graded easily. It's a course that is challenging, but I believe it is worth it. I put in a fair amount of effort and got a lot out of the class, and I think the way it changed my thinking was really valuable.

It's a good way to learn about the topics that are controversial in today's society and their constitutional backgrounds, as long as you don't mind the pretentiousness of Prof. George and the preceptors.

It's a great course, and Professor George is a great lecturer (very intelligent and well-spoken). If you've taken Constitutional Interpretation - which I consider to have been the better of the two classes - you may not want to take this because it will feel pretty repetitive. If you haven't though, definitely consider taking this class or the other with Prof. George. It's important to get some sort of understanding of how our Constitution has been/is being interpreted.
It's a truly exciting class. Parts get repetitive at times but this is probably the best crash course on Supreme Court jurisprudence over the past 150 years that you can get in 12 weeks.
Keep up with the reading, and come to class  prepared, but open-minded!

Lectures were long and kind of boring (they didn't seem very helpful).  Precepts were engaging and we just discussed the readings.  You should try to think about your opinions about different cases and come ready to talk.  Jason Iuliano was a good preceptor.

Lots of readings and the assignments are challenging (albeit interesting and thought-provoking), but the material is very engaging and interesting. This course is a very good overview of fundamental and landmark civil liberties cases in the U.S., and great if you are interested in a comprehensive overview of important U.S. cases! The workload isn't as difficult and heavy as Constitutional Interpretation, so definitely advisable if you want to take a class with Professor George and preceptors with real legal experience, but don't want as heavy a workload!
Madigan's a good preceptor. George is a bit overrated.

No matter what your political ideologies are, this course is great. George conveys conservative arguments in a logical and appealing manner, and also portrays the opposing sides. Great lectures but you don't need to go to be able to do well in the class, a lot of my friends didn't. If you are in George's precept your papers will be graded hard.
Pick a good preceptor and you will have a lot of fun.
Prepare to go through a lot of readings, but it's worth it!
Prof George can take a long time to say very little, and often prefers to lecture about "light" philosophy, but the subject material is fascinating and relevant
Prof. George is interesting and a pretty well-known scholar, so if anything, he's a reason to take the class.
Take it!

Take it! Robbie George is a good professor and it's interesting to hear a rigorous and intelligent perspective on the other side of the political spectrum (I'm a liberal.) Contrary to popular wisdom the grading/evaluations didn't seem unfair or unusually harsh.
Take it, why not? Explore the ideas/cases and really force yourself to examine both sides.
Take it. it's challenging, but ultimately rewarding.
Take this class if you want to read really interesting material and have minimal amounts of work.

Take this course regardless of what your major is. It will better ground you in any contemporary or historical American debate, and you will learn to make more informed judgements about the world. Be warned, this class is not a walk in the park, but I am so very glad for having taken it.
Take this!!!
The grading is very difficult.
The rumors about hard grading are true and the preceptors are sub-par but the material is interesting and makes you think.

This course was probably the best choice of my semester. Professor George is a fantastic lecturer, and the material is very interesting. I did not have any particular interest in the Supreme Court or its relation to civil liberties before this course, but now I am definitely going to take Professor George's other course, Constitutional Interpretation, next time it is offered.

This is a great class that will give you a solid understanding of moral and legal issues regarding civil liberties, but I would not recommend it if you've taken Con Interp, as they are too similar. On the other hand, if you've done Con Interp, this course is a breeze. I found the readings and papers to be fast and easy, but they would probably be tough if you've never read Supreme Court opinions before. Prof. George is great, fair, and engaging, and you should take this class if you're interested in law or ethics.

This is a great course with a great professor! It does help to have a background in philosophical thinking or in reading court cases before this class, although it's definitely doable even if you don't. (For the record, I took Con Interp with no background in law and ended up doing fine and this course is lot more laid back than Con Interp.)  I would recommend waiting until sophomore year or later to take this though. It's a lot for a freshman.

This is a great course, touching on many thought-provoking topics and it is a great way to hear the best pro and con arguments on controversial moral and legal issues. Prof George is a great lecturer and readings are carefully chosen.

This is an excellent course for both majors and dabblers alike! If you're taking it on a PDF basis, it doesn't involve too much work and you still learn a huge amount through precepts/lectures. And of course, the subject matter is extremely relevant and important for everyone.
This is course is very interesting and presents material on very important issues concerning our day. Everyone should take it for this reason. The lectures are excellent as well.
Without Professor George, the content is much less interesting - so consider waiting until 2016-2017 to take it.
Work hard.

You must take this class, whether you are interested in politics or not. The course is a course in learning to reason--a skill university institutions are failing to provide. Lectures were the actual highlight of my week the entire semester. Professor George is a top-of-the-line professor, highly accessible and an incredible individual.
easy- take it
get ready to talk about abortion as 'infanticide' a whole lot
take it! not too hard and really interesting
take this course
descrip: An inquiry into the value of liberty and of particular civil rights and liberties. The course considers competing theoretical justifications for rights and liberties generally, as well as particular problems concerning freedom of speech and the press, religion, sexuality, abortion, and discrimination. Supreme Court opinions regarding the constitutionality of legislation in each of these areas will be discussed and criticized.

title: The American Civil War and Reconstruction
reviews: A good history course with lots of reading. Don't expect to learn about individual battles because Karp covers the causes, course, and consequences of the war in the class in roughly three equal parts. Karp is in his third year teaching the course and occasionally fumbles in lecture but his lectures will only improve. Written work isn't ground-breakingly interesting nor difficult but I enjoyed the class overall.
After taking this course, I have come to understand that anyone who wants to understand American history has to know the Civil War. Take the course if this applies to you.
Amazing course
Definitely take this course even if you're not particularly interested in the Civil War and Reconstruction!
Do the reading - the assignments necessitate it.
Highly recommend this course - very interesting and learned a lot.
I highly recommend this course for anyone with a general interest in history.
I recommend
I would definitely advise going to as many lectures as possible and reading as much of the material as possible, because they were both extremely interesting and thought-provoking.

I would definitely recommend the course to fans of American history. It definitely brought to light interesting aspects of an often glossed-over seminal event in American, and as I took away from the course, world history.
I would take this course if you are either a History major or particularly interested in the Civil War.
I'd take this course. I'm BSE and really enjoyed it. Readings and assessments are reasonable, and the lectures are incredibly engaging. Go for it

If you're interested in the civil war, take this! You'll learn a ton. Unless you're willing to put in a lot of time memorizing details for the papers and exam (which requires doing the readings), however, PDF it. I kind of wish I had.
Nice class if you need a history distribution requirement
Take it
Take it!  Professor Karp is a great, fun, and extremely knowledgable lecturer!

Take it! Without a doubt this is my favorite class that I've taken a Princeton so far. Professor Karp is a great lecturer and I came away with a much deeper understanding of the Civil War in the wider context of American and world history.
Take this class. Reading is interesting, Karp is a great lecturer, and the assignments are reasonable.
Take this course if you love history, but dont expect a military history course!

This is a great course! Prof. Karp is a great teacher and his lectures are always worthwhile. The class is very straightforward and fair, with a lot of great material. This class was a "can't miss" part of my Princeton experience.

This was an excellent course and the best history course I've taken at Princeton. It covered the Civil War from every angle and made me curious to learn more. The lectures are engaging, Prof. Karp is great, and my preceptor was awesome. The readings were also very interesting (primary and secondary source documents) and not overwhelming but were skimmable if necessary. As a second semester senior MAE, I took the course PDF, but it's also a great course to take for a grade.
You learn a lot about one of the most important periods in American history and the roots of many issues we still have today.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: Why did the flourishing United States, by some measures the richest and most democratic nation of its era, fight the bloodiest civil war in the 19th century Western world? How did that war escalate into a revolutionary political struggle that transformed the nation--and then, almost as rapidly, give way to a reactionary backlash? This course will explore the causes, course, and consequences of the U.S. Civil War and Reconstruction, keeping in mind the ways that America's greatest conflict also represented a major event in the history of the global 19th century, and a landmark moment in the making of the modern world.

title: Music and Lyrics: Italy in the Eyes of its Pop Singers
reviews: It's a great course. I developed my Italian a lot and got to listen to great music.

TAKE THIS CLASS. It is extremely interesting for all students, no matter what your background is. You get to learn important parts of history through music videos and lyrics (and honestly rather little work), and class passes by super quickly because you never get bored. What more could you ask for?
Take this class!! It is fun and completely doable at any level of Italian.

You will listen to some great Italian music, without which it is impossible to understand the 'being Italian'. You will learn a lot about the history of post-war Italy and everything will be put in the world context. You will have great conversations in class. I think these are pretty good reasons to take this class. I enjoyed this class a lot and I could not wait to go to lecture.
prereqs: Prequisite: ITA 107 or permission of instructor. This course is taught in Italian. The course accomodates students who have just completed the language requirement sequence or come from the summer intensive course in Macerata..
descrip: This course is designed to introduce students to the rich tradition of Italian songwriters active between the 1960's and the present. Working at the crossroads of American influences and the tradition of Italian political songs, the cantautori merge popular appeal and literary sophistication. For at least three generations, their songs have provided an engaged soundtrack to Italy's turbulent social, political and cultural transformations in the post-WWII years. As lyrics on the page, as music to be listened to, and as performances recorded in video, Italian canzoni d'autore are part of the Italian identity today.

title: Shakespeare II
reviews: Attend every lecture, and do all the readings. You will love it, and I strongly recommend that every student take Shakespeare.
DON'T TAKE IT WITH CORMACK. There are WAY better British foundations courses to fulfill the departmental requirement

Do not take shakespeare with Cormack. He will teach you nothing of the themes of each play and instead rambles on in a disorganised manner about extremely specific linguistic details, which would be fine for a precept, or if he ever spoke about broader points of importance for the plays, but fails to draw any interest in this context
Do the readings! They're worth it.
Good if you want to move quickly through the best of Shakespeare.
Highly recommended.  This is a superb class--great readings and a wonderful professor.
Make sure to read the plays enough to get to know them.  This will allow you to appreciate Professor Cormack's insights and to write the essays more easily.
Make sure you have time to read the plays more than once. Start early on papers. Attend lectures.

Read the plays at least two times; each reading offers new insight. Also, go in for office hours frequently. Professor Cormack is brilliant but also extremely approachable and helpful. I wish I could have taken greater advantage of office hours this semester.
Take it if you like Shakespeare!
Take it!!
Take it. Take it especially if you have read very little Shakespeare. Keep up with the readings, it's way more enjoyable that way.
Take this course, and go to lectures !! You will get so much more out of it. I wish I had gone to Professor Cormack's office hours, and he strongly encourages it, so you should!

The professor cares a lot about making this course fun and not stressful, and his lectures were great. Of course, Shakespeare is great to read whether you're an English major or doing something completely different. It's fun!
The reading load is not too too heavy. I'd say take the course if you have an interest in literature, because it's not the easiest LA, but it's very interesting material.
This is a great class!  The plays are engaging, and the writing assignments are pretty fun.
Watch the plays online to help you get through them. It's honestly a better way to read the plays.
this course is very challenging but if you love shakespeare you NEED to take it
descrip: This class covers the second half of Shakespeare's career, with a focus on the major tragedies and tragicomedies/romances.

title: Higher Spin Theories and AdS/CFT (Half-Term)
reviews: Take this course if you are interested in the subject. Useful for any hep-theorist as a matter of general background.
descrip: This course is an introduction to higher spin gravity theories and the recent advances in understanding their role in the context of the AdS/CFT correspondence. Topics include: free equations for massless higher spin fields in flat and (A)dS space; introduction to Vasiliev interacting higher spin theory in (A)dS; review and checks of the AdS/CFT dualities between higher spin gravity in AdS space and vector model conformal field theories.

title: Stochastic Calculus
reviews: Don't miss it!
Excellent class. Challenging (as all the ORFE classes...)
Follow the professor well.
I strongly recommend this course as long as you meet the prerequisite. The lectures are excellent and the professor is approachable. It is quite hard but rewarding.
Take the course
Very good course if students want to understand Brownian motion and the construction of stochastic calculus.
Yes

van Handel is a great professor. This course will give you a much better, deeper understanding of the workings behind stochastic calculus from a rigorous standpoint, although you need to take 526 first which can be a bit dry.
van Handel is fantastic. If you are at all interested you should take it with him.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ORF 526 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to stochastic calculus based on Brownian motion.Topics include:construction of Brownian motion; martingales in continuous time; the Ito integral; localization; Ito calculus; stochastic differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; martingale representation; Feynman-Kac formula.

title: Topics in 20th-Century Literature - The Future: A 20th Century Problem
descrip: Modern, German-language literature, from the turn of the century through the 1970's, has been shaped by the problem of how to think and write the future tense. The end of the 19th century coincides, in the German-speaking world, with the end of a teleological approach to time that views history as a journey toward future fulfillment. The question of how to affirm a tempus that need bear no meaningful relationship to the will--and thus also the question of whether purposeful change can still be legitimately narrated or staged--determines technical innovations from Hugo von Hofmannsthal to Thomas Bernhard.

title: Philosophy of Mind
reviews: Only take this class if you have had prior experience reading analytical philosophy papers.

Take the class if you are interested in the material and willing to do the readings. It's a small class, so it's nice if you feel confident enough to participate during discussions. The subject matter is fairly difficult though, so I'd be a bit cautious about taking it.
This course is a strong, well-structured introduction to philosophy of mind.
prereqs: One previous philosophy course.
descrip: This course will offer a comprehensive account of current work on the problem of intentionality - the problem of how it can be that our minds are about things in the world - in contemporary philosophy of mind with reference where appropriate to the historical background. Topics will include: internalism vs. externalism about mental content, the language of thought hypothesis vs. connectionism, the naturalisation of content, causal and teleological theories of mental content, conceptual role semantics, eliminativist materialism.

title: Themes in Islamic Culture - Middle Eastern History
descrip: This semester the course will be a chapter and paper clinic. Each participant will be expected to submit at least one draft chapter or paper to the seminar, and will receive intensive comments and suggestions on both form and substance from the other participants and the instructor. Chapters and papers may relate to any period or aspect of Middle Eastern or Islamic history.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: Policy Issues and Analysis of Nonprofits, NGOs, and Philanthropy
descrip: Examines policy issues at international, national and local levels. Provides groundwork on nonprofits, NGOs, and philanthropy that can be followed with specialized courses on management and program evaluation. Emphasis on understanding how philanthropy, nonprofit, and NGO sectors operate, their niche alongside private and public sectors, revenue sources, impact on society, and converse effects of society and its institutions; the policy making process. Explores impact of reliance on government or overseas support for Third World NGOs; faith-based service provisions: accountability and transparency; advocacy; and government regulations.

title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
reviews: Expect to work hard on the problem sets and expect to be confused on the subtleties between some of the material, for example coherence and entanglement, but also expect to really appreciate the nuances of quantum mechanics. Specifically, being able to show that collapse of a wavefunction can be reinterpreted as unitary time evolution was a mind blowing moment for me.
I strongly recommended this course for experimentalists.
If you are a chemist major in theoretic chemistry, I strongly recommend you to take this course.  I will learn a lot.
The problem set is given weekly.
descrip: This is a one-semester course in advanced quantum mechanics. The emphasis is on systems with more than one degree of freedom: dynamics, mixed states, entanglement, measurement, coherent states, decoherence, resonance, exchange, Hartree-Fock, Dirac equation, other topics.

title: Special Topics in Operations Research and Financial Engineering - Stochastic Methods for Quantitative Finance
reviews: If you're interested in stochastic calculus, take this. I think this should be required before 335, so that you can understand it more.
Take this course if you really liked the Ito component in 335.
Take this course if you want to learn more about stochastic calculus! Organized, and well-taught!
This is a nice course to take. You learn a lot! It also overlaps a lot with 335, and I would recommend taking them together. They complement each other nicely.
prereqs: ORF 309.
descrip: This course is an introduction to stochastic calculus at the undergraduate level with applications to financial models. The emphasis is on computational and practical techniques. Topics include: Brownian motion; Ito's formula; stochastic differential equations; partial differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; simulation and finite difference numerical methods; implementation in Matlab; applications in finance.

title: Analysis III: Integration Theory and Hilbert Spaces
reviews: Dafermos is a great professor
Go for it.

If you're a math major, you should take this course.  You have to do some sort of real analysis, and I would take this over Fourier.  If you're into analysis, take both.  But it's just really classic essential stuff.  You shouldn't graduate with a math degree and not know anything about measure theory.
prereqs: MAT 215, 218 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of Lebesgue integration in n-dimensional space. Differentiation theory. Hilbert space theory and applications to Fourier Transforms, and partial differential equations. Introduction to fractals. This course is the third semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Defense Policy Analysis
descrip: Covers types of analytical frameworks for evaluating military issues. Methodologies range from simple quantitative methods for understanding combat to structured use of military history to defense budget calculations to simple assessments of military tech. Address 7 topics: terrorism, modern air-ground warfare; infantry combat including guerrilla war, peace enforcement, urban warfare, mountain & jungle warfare; missile battle/missile defense; military transport, supply, logistics; effects & implications of weapons of mass destruction; budgetary & econ. issues in defense planning; military tech., future of warfare.

title: Elementary Hindi and Urdu II
reviews: Great teacher!
I would suggest that they study the language "activity" instead of leaving most your studying later in the course (like right before a quiz or final).
TAKE IT!
Take Hindi. Just do it. Take Hindi.
Take the course.

This is a great language class, and I'm very glad to have taken it. Fauzia is a fantastic and easy-going teacher. She definitely makes the language seem less scary and challenging to native English speakers.
take this class!!!! its such a great experience and Fauziaji is one of the nicest, most understanding, most helpful teachers.
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course provides the second semester of training in Hindi and Urdu, allowing students to acquire linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Equal emphasis is placed on both Hindi and Urdu, including writing systems, vocabulary, and culture. Course will focus on using language for genuine communication. Students will be able to read and write both Hindi and Urdu scripts, communicate in social situations, and narrate in all three time frames: past, present and future. Classes are interactive.

title: Introduction to PDE
prereqs: Introduction to Real Analysis (MAT320) or equivalent, or consent of instructor..
descrip: The course is an introduction to partial differential equations, problems associated to them and methods of their analysis. Topics may include: basic properties of elliptic equations, wave equation, heat equation, Schr\"{o}dinger equation, hyperbolic conservation laws, Fokker-Planck equation, basic function spaces and inequalities, regularity theory for linear PDE, De Giorgi method, basic harmonic analysis methods, existence results and long time behavior for classes of nonlinear PDE including the Navier-Stokes equations.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Words vs. Music: The Song in Modern Times
reviews: A good class to take if you are interested in learning about contemporary musicians (Dylan, Paul Simon, Springsteen, David Bowie, The Beatles, U2, etc.) I found the subject material incredibly interesting and often found myself researching independently through wikipedia. The only drawback was that Nigel Smith's lectures were not the greatest. He brought in a lot of guest lecturers, some good and some bad, to break up the monotony. Such great subject matter deserves great lectures and Nigel hasn't reached that point yet. The workload for this class is only concentrated during the midterm and finals period. The rest of the year you don't have to do any readings or assignments. Overall, I'm glad I took the class to have a much better understanding of many of the artists discussed above.
Absolutely take it, especially if you like music.
Chill course. Not too much work.

Definitely take if you are interested in music of all genres. Nigel tries to structure the musical content of the course based on past reviews, and some of the songs can be strange. But it is a generally easy LA.
Do it. It's a great, fun course.
Do the listenings.
Do the readings.
Easy class, pretty interesting subject.
Enjoy it! Stay on top of vocabulary so terms don't escape you when you're completing the take-home exams, and reach out to preceptors for feedback.
Focus on taking thorough notes in class as well as having lots of specific song examples for the tests.
Fun and easy class! Take it if you're interested in listening to music, analyzing song lyrics, and writing about them.
Go to lecture and take detailed notes if you want to have a good study guide and do well on the exams.

Go to precepts- Professor Johnson is very thorough. She is enthusiastic and more than willing to help if you reach out to her. It is evident that she puts in a lot of thought, time, and effort to prepare for the precepts. I have missed a couple of lectures. Honestly, it really does not make a significant difference.
Good class for a distribution requirement!
Good class, interesting way to get an LA
Good course. Not too hard and very fun precept discussions.
Great class for MUS/ENG course if you are not used to the departments and it's your first time within it.
I definitely recommend this course if you enjoy music or struggle with literature as this is a great way to fulfill the LA requirement.
I think the course has potential for improvement, so I would state my experience but not influence any which way
I wouldn't really recommend this course -- It's not difficult, but you also don't really learn anything and the lectures are boring.
I wouldn't recommend it

If you like rock history, take the class. Basically, the class is about the divide between music and lyric in songs, and about bridging that divide somehow. Some of the conversations in precept got kind of artsy and, at least to my engineer's mind, pointless, but lecture really stayed on track and was more about history and culture. You definitely don't have to do the readings to do well; just show up at lecture and precepts. Prof. Smith is a really interesting guy, and tells great stories if you pay attention.
Its an easy LA but I would only take it if you have interest in music/the artists studied in the course.
Light load of work, can be a good intro to some musical history. Ideal PDF.
Not a lot of work for an interesting look at music
Not what I expected but okay.

PDF for an LA. Course needs to be restructured. Smith's lectures are like trying to make sense of an acid trip. He has good information but cannot present it in a coherent way. His examples are outdated. Precepts are good though. Don't expect to get anything from lecture.
Participate in class.
Participate in precept and put a lot of work into your papers.
Pretty easy and fun. Very chill!
Super interesting and fun class. Take if you enjoy music and/or poetry and/or writing about either or both.
Take for an easy class, fairly interesting material
Take it
Take it, easy, don't waste a PDF on it
Take this class.
Take this course if you are interested in music! When else do you get to learn about Springsteen and the Beatles.
Take this course if you are interested in music. It provides a good historical/social background for modern music. Do not take just to cover distributional requirements!
Take this course if you're interested in pop music. It's that simple. Nigel is an amazing lecturer and you get to listen to cool music.

Take this course if you're looking for an easy english class where the papers are fun and engaging and you don't want to attend lectures or do readings. You also learn a lot about how to really listen to music and consider it in the context of the culture that produced it.
Take this course only if you are very interested in modern music not as an LA requirement
Take this course! It is interesting and the workload is manageable.

The class surveys popular music since the War. It's really easy if you've enjoyed some exposure to classic rock, and you do not need to attend lecture because you can write about whatever you like in your papers. The readings are very interesting, and you should try to get into Colette's precept.

The readings were a bit longer than advertised but the lectures covered all that material. The course was super interesting and I would definitely recommend taking it if you are interested in the subject.
This class is easy but not worth it.  The only thing this class has done for me is opened my eyes to the fact that I shouldn't be wasting my time at Princeton taking classes like this.

This is a very chill and fun class.  Yes, there's two papers and two take-home exams, but they're very straight-forward and the precepts prepare you for them very well.  The classes are light and Prof. Smith has a dry humor that works well for the material.  The grading is fair, but it is true that you have to enjoy and appreciate varieties of music to get the most out of this class.  But... if you are interested in music, I'd give this class a try.
Try to engage as much as you can. At least skim the readings and listen to the music once. Engaging in precept makes the class a lot better.

While the content of this course is very important, relevant, and interesting, I am not sure that the lectures and readings were similarly so under Professor Smith. That is not to say the course is not well run; the preceptors do create a very welcoming and open atmosphere. I think this course is best fit for musicians who already have a prior interest in late 20th century popular music as the topics covered are very specific. I will say that the visits from outside musicians was a very unique experience.
deffinetely take for an LA
don't take unless ready to engage yourself
go to the lectures they are very cool
good
take the classs
descrip: Why do songs mean so much to us, and how do they deliver pleasure? Do lyrics matter? It is often assumed that poetry was originally always sung. This course interrogates the collaboration between words and music, and entertains the notion that each is potentially a threat to the other. We will consider popular song in many modes and some art song since 1945, as well as the broader relationship between literature and music in these years, and the role of song in historic events. We will investigate recording technology and will be visited by songwriters, recording engineers, electronic musicians, and the odd rock star.

title: Independent Study
prereqs: Students MUST fill out the Independent Research Project Proposal form and get it signed by the advisor & the dept rep. Hand in to E-211 E-Quad by the first week of the semester..
descrip: Independent research in the student's area of interest. The work must be conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and must result in a final paper.

title: Electronic Materials
reviews: Please take this course if you are at all interested in the development of certain materials involving semiconductors that you encounter in everyday life *and* wish to better understand their physics. Professor Wagner is a wonderful professor, although as far as I know he is soon retiring, which is unfortunate, for I wish he could continue teaching this course!
Take it.
Take this course!
no more offering
prereqs: A course in solid-state or semiconductor physics, or in solid-state chemistry..
descrip: By expanding their capability and performance, semiconductors keep expanding into new applications. We will study recent device developments such as X-ray imaging arrays based on selenium and on cadmium telluride, back-lit silicon CMOS sensor arrays, solar cells with higher than 40 percent efficiency, power devices based on gallium nitride or silicon carbide, the generations of white light with inorganic or organic emitter, and quantum dot phosphors. We will emphasize technologies that are in application or close to it. Students will be encouraged to identify their own subject for reading and presentation.

title: Statistical Learning and Nonparametric Estimation
reviews: Must-taken course for students who are interested in machine learning and statistics.
One of the best ways to learn Statistical Learning would be taking this course. However,be prepared to do a heavy job.
This course covers a lot of material very quickly. Assignments are few and far between, but each one is quite demanding.
prereqs: ORF 524: Statistical Theory and Methods or instructor's approval..
descrip: A theoretical introduction to statistical learning problems related to regression and classification. Topics covered include: Principle Component Analysis, nonparametric estimation, sparse regression, and Classification and Statistical learning

title: Myths and Religion in the Spanish Speaking World
reviews: I strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in a Spanish class of language arts class. It is very manageable, work wise and the professor is amazing.
I think students should take this course, it's not horribly difficult and it serves as a good transition course from the intro level spanish.
I would recommend being proactive about all of the work.
It's a great class if you like Spanish and are interested in discussing religion, and Prof. Lee is a great professor.
Participate in class! Lee is so great!
Professor Lee is great. The workload isn't bad, but it definitely helps if you have an interest in the subject matter.
Take the class! but do the readings...
prereqs: SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course surveys the practice of beliefs in Spain, Latin America, and in Hispanic communities in the United States. It explores how "Catholic" folk piety was established and developed in Spain and what happened to it when it transferred to the New World. By surveying the diverse configurations of religious practices through written texts and visual media, it inquires how identity and social relationships define a person's relation to the divine and vice versa. Emphasis will be given to the refinement and further development of spoken and written Spanish.

title: Building Real Systems
reviews: Actually one of the ELE classes that I enjoyed the most. It is manageable if worked on steadily and have a reliable partner who always contributes.
Although many nights were spent in lab, this was honestly my favorite class so far here at Princeton! It's the core of ELE - what's cooler than building your own things?

Awesome class. You're gonna have to take it, and it is very sweet by the end. During it sometimes you will hate the class,but at the end, looking back, you will be proud of what you've accomplished. So glad for this class, probably the best ELE class out of them all since you actually get to build a sweet independent project for hwatever you want.
CARLAB IS AMAAAAZING!

Car Lab is life changing. Yes, it consumes your life, and yes, it consumes every fiber of your being on weeks with due dates. Yet, the feeling of getting something work work is so fulfilling; nothing could give you a warmer and fuzzier feeling inside. Car Lab has been my favorite ELE course, and favorite course at Princeton, up to date.

Don't make your groups too large if you can help it. Try to pick a partner who'll be able to be in the lab at the same times as you, or be VERY INTENTIONAL about keeping one another on the same page. It is really best if you can both be present when getting significant work done, though.
Get started on everything early
Great course. Required for ELE majors, but I would really recommend it for anyone outside the department who has taken 203 and understands circuits and wants something more challenging to do.
If you're ELE, it's a great class and you should enjoy it. It doesn't feel like work because it's fun, but you're at lab all the time. Great class bonding. It's required. IDK why you're reading this.

If you're taking this class you don't have much choice in the matter.  It can suck to be in lab for 20 out of 24 hours leading up to deadlines but if you time your working well it'll be okay.  While 75% of the time you spend working on it will feel like banging your head against a wall, once you get past the major humps and have a functional system, the last 25% is actually really fun (i.e. just fiddling with it and making your car as awesome as possible).
It is THE course for ELE majors. Take it!
It's a lot of time, but you have fun! Just make sure you budget enough time for it, and assume your car will break the night before so you have time to deal with it.
Start early on the independent project part and dream big!
Start thinking of ideas for independent project early. TAs who just took the course are really helpful because they've been through the course and encountered a lot of similar problems.
Take it.
Well you're stuck with it no matter what
Well, all ELE's have to take it. Lots of work but you learn tons and get to know all your classmates quite well!
Work often and try to take it with only 3 other classes.
prereqs: ELE 206 and ELE 301. Permission of instructor..
descrip: Comprehensive, laboratory-based course in electronic system design and analysis. Covers formal methods for the design and analysis of moderately complex real-world electronic systems. Course is centered around a semester-long design project involving a computer-controlled vehicle designed and constructed by teams of two students. Integrates microprocessors, communications, and control.

title: Intensive Elementary Arabic II
reviews: A really good intensive course, but since it is intensive, be prepared for lots of homework!
Arabic is hard but really rewarding
I would advise against enrolling in the course with the current instructor.

Professor is friendly and wants everyone to succeed, but there just wasn't enough time in a 3x per week class to cover all the material with instruction, so you have to be quite self-motivated and able to teach yourself a lot of the time.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 103..
descrip: A continuation of 103. The second semester of a full-year language course designed specifically for students who already have some familiarity with any dialect of spoken Arabic. Graduate students who are primarily interested in learning to read Arabic are also welcome. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills.

title: Intensive Intermediate German
reviews: Be prepared for Professor Rankin and GER1025 to change your life. The course is structured in such a way that it becomes a dominant part of your life. You're being exposed to so much German on a daily basis that failure to advance and learn is near impossible. Dive in!

Be prepared to put more time in than you would for a non-accelerated course -- not so much because of an increase in work but more so because of the long class periods each day and the number of final assignments.
Come to class willing to participate, it makes the class go faster
Do it!
Don't take it at 8:30. Be prepared to write essays like you would in an English class, but in German.
