I would definitely recommend this course. It can get exhausting to spend 80 minutes a day in german class, but there is no better way to learn quickly, and you will be surprised at how much you have improved by the end of the semester.
If you are passionate about German, take this course. Although there is a ton of work, the progress you will see in your German language abilities will be reward enough.
If you get bored by grammar and excited by reading interesting literature, then definitely take this course rather then 102.

Jamie Rankin is the best. Also, German is a pretty cool language. Just don't peek at all the grammar you haven't learned yet, because that's scary. When you take it by steps though, it's really fun and interesting, and you get to see lots of relations and stuff between German and English.
Make sure you push yourself to participate in class discussion as it will drastically improvement your language skills and make you comfortable speaking in front of others.
Make the most of it!
Please, do yourself a favor and take this course.
Professor Rankin is excellent! I feel like I have learned a lot of German.
TAKE IT. Do the ddd program!
Take German at Princeton, particularly if you can get Professor Rankin. If Professor Rankin were to teach Icelandic, I would take it in a heartbeat.

Take it if you love languages and want to learn one quickly.  If you want to complete the language requirement sooner it is also good but beware because it is tough, especially if languages are not your forte.
Take it!
Take it! But be mindful of the workload as it is an accelerated course.

Take it! It's fun learning German so fast. It does take an hour and a half to two hours per night (so be prepared), but it is definitely worth it. Rankin is an awesome professor, but I've heard good things about the others as well.

Take it! The German department is amazing and 1025 is a great course. It's a time commitment but really not that much more work than 102. You'll see your German get exponentially better and it'll be completely worth it. Professor Rankin is amazing!
Take it! The workload is not insurmountable, and is actually incredibly light considering that it counts as 2 courses.

Take over 1025 - get to go to Munich and you are surrounded with the best students who want to study German seriously. Try to see which class Rankin is teaching, because he is really amazing. Tough class though. Really picks up by the end of the term.
Take the course! The Der Die Das curriculum means you'll have a huge vocabulary range. The professors are excellent! The film and play were excellent supplements!
Take this course!
Take this course; it is the best class I took at Princeton. The German department is amazing and the German language is fascinating.

The homework takes a lot longer than you would expect, anywhere between 1 to 3 hours a day, and is everyday, including the weekends.If you really want to learn German, be prepared to invest a lot of time in this course. Also, be aware that a lot of the course, particularly during the second half of the semester, involves reading and discussing literary texts. Take it if you feel that this is the best method of learning German for you.

The workload is heaver than most other courses, but it gives two credits and it is not bad at all. Solid course. Be aware that in GER1025, you do not just learn grammar and vocabulary but also have to read literatures and do analysis on them.
This class is amazing, as long as you kep up with the easy daily assignments you should be ok.
Try your best to keep up with the grammar in the first half of the course
keep up with the vocal and grammar, and be present mentally during class.
try to spread out the learning, and review a lot
prereqs: GER 101 and permission of instructor. Enrollment by invitation only, following an interview with the course instructor; interviews are normally offered to students in GER 101 attaining a grade of A or A-..
descrip: Intensive training in German, building on GER 101 and covering the acquisitional goals of two subsequent semesters: communicative proficiency in a wide range of syntax, mastery of discourse skills, and reading strategies sufficient to interpret and discuss contemporary German short stories, drama, and film. Intensive classroom participation required. Successful completion provides eligibility for GER 107 or, in exceptional cases, for 200 level courses. Participants are automatically eligible for the Princeton-in-Munich program (107-G), June, 2015.

title: The Improvising Ensemble
reviews: I don't know if this course is being offered next year, but if so it might well be a good thing to take. I do hope there is an added emphasis on improvisatory technique, though.
It's definitely an easy pass for an LA, but I'm not quite sure how much I got out of it.  I did make a couple of really good friends in the class, so maybe you will too.
Take it!
prereqs: Application and permission of the instructor..
descrip: A course designed to provide instrumental and vocal students with opportunities to reimagine the process of creative music-making through the use of improvisational concepts and activities in group collaboration. Course will feature several guest lecturers/performers and concert presentations focusing on the creation of collectively improvised performances.

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: (Half-Term) - Critical Debates in Evolution and Forensics
descrip: This six-week graduate seminar exposes students to major theories in biological anthropology in order to challenge popular misperceptions about what makes us human. Weekly discussions will focus on evolution, race, population, language, genetics, and diet. Students will also learn how physical anthropologists use evidence by studying the politics around the Philadelphia Move forensic investigation. Finally, this seminar focuses on post-genomic debates about race, epigenetics, and contemporary behavioral studies inside and outside the discipline.

title: Dance Technique and Anatomy of Movement
reviews: Do the readings for your own benefit.

If you like to dance and want to think about dance from a more academic standpoint, this is a good course for you. If you like to dance and really just want to dance, take a different dance course with more studio time. Overall, a good and informative course.

Interesting course but it is NOT pdf only and there is a lot of weekly work.  It might be difficult for people who are not concentrators to adjust to the expectations of this course.  I took it to improve my dance technique but ended up with a lot of assignments and reading to do.  Still, Stuart is AMAZING and it might be worth it to take this class just for him.

Really think about the subject matter outside of class and try to apply changes to your body on a regular basis. The class is primarily about taking the knowledge of somatics and applying it to your body. Also, don't be afraid to let your body guide you in ways that may differ from other students in the course.
Take this course!
prereqs: Must have taken DAN 207, 209, 219, 220, 319, 419, 420, 431, 432 or equivalent dance experience..
descrip: This course provides laboratories and cross-genre dance technique to facilitate a somatic understanding of kinesiology. Students identify limitations and expand individual expression. Technique class will integrate ballet and modern techniques while emphasizing values of exploration and risk-taking. Movement labs will integrate research in functional anatomy/kinesiology and diverse systems of somatic education to understand both the potential of neuro-motor development & physiological systems. Classes will provide freedom of exploration in all genres of dance and give students knowledge to strengthen physicality and movement repertoire.

title: The Gothic Cathedral
descrip: This course surveys the great trans-European architectural movement called Gothic, from its origins in the Paris basin in the 1130s until around 1500. Lectures will range from close examinations of specific monuments to broader engagements with architectural forms as they cut across time. Issues include urbanism, regionalism, patronage, the role of the "architect," structure and engineering, the multi-media ensemble, and cultural identity.

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - American Environmental History
reviews: I mean... just read the books on your own, you don't really need the class.
I would definitely recommend this course - touches on major works in American environmentalism and offers an interesting approach to American history
Take it for an easy A but be prepared for long discussions.
The professors are engaging, kind people and the class is both interesting and relaxed.  The work load is reasonable.
Try to read the books. Enjoy the professors debating the material and learn from it.
descrip: Explores the diverse connections between America's national development and natural environment. It examines how the U.S. originated, then expanded to cover a continental land mass, and the ways that expansion changed the nation. It analyzes how, why, and with what consequences major parts of the U.S. economy--for instance, farming, energy, services and government--have grown or in shrunk. It looks at how and with what results the U.S. has incorporated different ethnic and racial groups. It shows how, why, and with what outcomes it has historically globalized and conducted its foreign policy, and offers insights into current landscapes.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Sociological Perspectives on Inequality
descrip: Course covers theory and research on social stratification, the major subfield in sociology that focuses on inequality. We begin by reviewing major theories, constructs, and empirical work on inequality. Weeks 2 -6 focus on institutions that mediate the transmission and reproduction of inequality, including families, schools, neighborhoods, labor markets, and the criminal justice system.

title: Indigeneity
reviews: -work consistently throughout the semester

A mus. Exceptional professor teaching a topic that isn't discussed nearly enough in the academy, perhaps because of the criticisms it launches on the academy itself. All the more reason to engage with it. Professor Ellison will inspire you to think through and across complex, contradictory, and controversial questions in a classroom setting that is certain to engage every student in the room in a way that makes for one of the most meaningful seminar dynamics during your time at Princeton.
Definitely take this course if you have an interest in either anthropology or indigeneity! Professor Ellison is great, and the material is very interesting.
It's very anthropological, but Ellison is a phenomenal professor and the topic is interesting.

This was a really good course! Professor Ellison is great and it brings up some really interesting questions about anthropology and indigenous populations. The one thing was that discussions got really lofty so beware if there are grad students in your class if you aren't super knowledgable about anthropological theory.
descrip: Indigenous peoples have been both pathologized and endowed with mystical abilities, cast in timeless Noble Savage fantasies, and mourned as teetering on the brink of extinction. These representational extremes have political consequences, and fail to do justice to the lived experience of indigenous peoples, who are actively crafting futures for themselves and their communities amid real political, economic, and environmental challenges. This course examines the politics, theories, and conditions of indigeneity from an anthropological perspective, covering issues ranging from settler colonialism and sovereignty to environmental movements.

title: Britain 1815-1945: Empire, Democracy, and War
reviews: As with all history courses, only take if you're interested in the subject matter. Prof. Colley is a competent lecturer, and it should be a good class if you're invested in it.
DO THE READINGS.

I wouldn't really recommend. The class isn't about the British "Empire" as you would assume but mostly about the British Isles during the time period. Didn't learn much about the colonies or anything that I was interested in learning. The assignments were brutal in the end and I eventually got tired of the lectures, which weren't really that interesting to me.
If you have pre-knowledge and interest in British history, this class may be for you. It's not a great course but doable.
If you're interested in the subject.
It is an interesting course that has good lectures. The subject matter is mainly on British politics and culture during the time period and less about empire and war.
Just know that if you don't have any background information on british history, this will not be as informative a course as you may like
Not terribly hard, but get a good preceptor and you'll get a lot more out of the course if you read the set books.
Professor Colley is an amazing lecturer. Take this course.
Take it if you like British history of if you're considering doing British history.
Take it!  The reading can be a but dense at times, but Professor Colley is a phenomenal lecturer!  It's SO worth it!
Take it, easy, educational, and fun. Great PDF
Take it.
Take this class! It is a really interesting and great class. Also, perfect if you are looking to do your HA requirement.
Take this course! Professor Colley is a great lecturer, and the course material is extremely interesting as well.

There are a few lectures early on that are not the most interesting - but she is an excellent lecturer and makes them worthwhile - once she gets into the 20th century, WWI, WWII, they were honestly the best lectures on campus. Midterm exam is a takehome and it is not too bad - I wrote the paper for the final and it was not awful after having written a thesis, though I imagine 20 pages can be rough for others. Overall I recommend it.

There is no relationship between what is said in lectures, precepts, and readings. The WEEKLY READING RESPONSES due the day before precept are not mentioned on the course description. Neither is the existence of a $46 pequod packet with one extra reading per week. DO NOT TAKE THIS AS AN HA.
This is a good course for a broad analysis of  British history. The readings were hard to manage, but you can choose to write a final paper.
Try to keep up with the lecture reading because its hard when you have to do it all before the final!
Very good survey course.
Very little work required until the end, easy to let all the readings and material slip by throughout the semester. Not bad, but you could probably find something a little bit more engaging.
great for PDF and interesting material!
take it, really interesting and well taught course
yes
descrip: Since Britain's empire contained a fifth of the globe's population in 1820 and--on paper--reached its widest extent in 1945, this course embraces both national and global history. We explore how the UK became the prime economic and imperial power, and look at its competitors and those resisting it. We look at Britain's social, cultural, intellectual, gender, and political workings, relations with Ireland, and at the impact of war. We consider the ambiguities of world power status and the meanings of national decline.

title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style
reviews: Enjoy it, it's a great class. Meet with him before your revision of your papers are due to make sure you know what you need to do to fix it.
Especially great course if you're interested in Spanish language and contemporary culture more than history and literature.
Great course. Alberto is great. Above average workload, but it is worth it. Alberto is an awesome professor and your spanish will definitely improve.

Make sure to be very very careful with grammar and little errors on your assignments because he takes them seriously. Think about readings ahead of time and have valuable things to say because he pretty much just tells the class to have a discussion. Spend a lot of time on the assignments and make sure they're very polished. Otherwise very caring and passionate professor.
Take it
Take this course. Don't let the words "grammar and style" scare you. This class is super organized and engaging.
There are definitely more exciting and interesting Spanish courses out there, but Alberto is still a great professor
This is a hard course that requires a lot of consistent effort.
Your grade will be correlated to the effort you put in
take it with Alberto cause he is the man
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course. Students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score can take the course only with instructor's permission..
descrip: SPA 307 is an advanced language course. Its main purpose is to develop and reinforce accuracy and fluency in both writing and speaking Spanish. Students will also learn to identify linguistic features that characterize different genres, as well as social and cultural factors that aid in the interpretation and understanding of different texts and types of speech. More specifically, the course aims at providing the tools for discourse analysis, raising awareness of the social and ideological values that permeate discursive practices, and developing autonomy and proficiency as an advanced learner of Spanish language.

title: Financial Crises
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 202 or equivalent..
descrip: This course will consider market bubbles and financial crises from two distinct angles. The first half will focus on bubbles in the public equity market, with particular emphasis on the productive role that financial speculation can play in the development and deployment of innovative technologies, complementing the role of the state. The second half focuses on the economic theory and empirical evidence related to the major bubbles and crises in the past century and with a particular attention on the recent crisis that began in August 2007.

title: Topics in Mathematical Physics
prereqs: Undergraduates must request permission of instructor..
descrip: Spring 2015: In the first half the term, the course will focus on the theory or random operators, and in particular on the spectra and dynamics of operators with random potential and in the second half, the discussion will focus on the critical behavior in some of the basic models of mathematical statistical mechanics, scaling limits of their critical states, and the random fractal structures which emerge in the resulting continuum theories. Presentations/lectures by A. Aizenman, S. Warzel and H. Duminil-Copin.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Architecture, Globalization, and the Environment
reviews: Definitely take the course if the subject seems interesting. Great lectures.
Engage in precept discussion, and take notes in class! It is very well-structured so it is easy to follow, but it is always useful to keep a tab on the small yet important themes.
Find ways to apply this information to your experiences in everyday life. You will then find the readings and paper requirements become far less challenging.
Interesting material, but a little more than work than I thought it would be, especially towards the end (final paper AND final exam...)
It's a fun-ish class
One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. Lectures are very worth going to.
Only take it if you are really interested in the topic
Take it! Great course; Professor da Costa Meyer is fantastic. However, a fair amount of reading to keep up with. The final paper plus written final is a little bit rough.

Take it! My favorite class this semester! Great for counting towards the Urban Studies certificate. Note that it is a double-dipper at the end (take-home essay exam plus a final research paper), but it's worth it - and I wouldn't say that about many classes.
Take the course and get the lecturer as your preceptor.

Take this class, especially if you're interested at all in about how humans interact with the environment. This class was surprisingly comprehensive - you cover a boatload of materials beyond architecture, although the introductions to the big names of the architecture world was great as well. Professor Meyer is friendly and passionate and incredibly articulate. Definitely opened my eyes to a lot of issues I had never considered before. Readings are interesting and of reasonable length. Workload is minimal except around finals where the 15 page paper and the final exam weigh you down a bit. Precepts are more blah, but not bad - since the architecture department is combined with the ART department, you may get a preceptor who doesn't specialize in architecture, like I did.
This course has a minimal workload for the information you get out of it. I found the topics captivating and the discussion fueled. I recommend taking this course.

This course is a broad introduction to the problems of the world. It contains little information about architecture, globalization, or the environment, but rather seeks to throw topics at the student with little context. Moreover, Esther speaks as though the answers to certain questions are evident to anyone paying attention, while in reality there are many complexities. Students taking this class can expect to be frustrated by such a reductionist approach, while gaining an appreciate for the variety of interconnected issues facing Earth.
Try to take ownership of the material as best you can so it's more meaningful. If you don't have the time or effort to spare ont hat end, use it as an easy extra class.
Very chill, interesting material that added a lot to my understanding of architecture and environment in the modern world. Appreciated this class quite a bit. Not hard.
Yes
descrip: This course analyzes contemporary architecture and its relation to climate change and to social problems having to do with urbanism. Special attention will be paid to the erosion of public space, whether it is due to gentrification, gated communities, outright segregation, or to the devastating impact of war in urban zones in many parts of the world. We will study issues of sustainability, as well as climate justice and environmental racism. Architecture's complicities with regard to global warming and its squandering of fossil fuels are central to our approach.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Policymaking in Diverse Societies
descrip: This course investigates how ethnic diversity influences the policymaking process in democratic societies, with a focus on Europe and the United States. We will first address why and how ethnic diversity shapes individuals' and groups' beliefs, preferences, and behaviors in ways that shape the formulation of policy. Next the course will examine the consequences of ethnic diversity on policy areas that all societies confront (such as redistribution and economic development) as well as policy areas that emerge as a result of diversity (such as affirmative action or immigrant integration).

title: Studies in French Language and Style
reviews: An overall good course with a hefty amount of reading.

Be warned, it's a fair amount of work, but Nicolas is en extremely knowledgeable teacher who will improve not only your understanding of French literature, but also of language and literature in general.
Do the fiche de lectures as you go along- this will help for exams.

Do the readings and watch the movies! Obviously because you need to but also because they're mostly interesting. I really liked this class - it exposed me to a range of French writers and I got to watch sci-fi movies!
Engage in each discussion that happens in class.   It is the best way to not only improve your spoken French but to understand the material very clearly.

Going from 108 to 207 I was worried it might be too difficult, but it was definitely at a good level. The topic (le fantastique) was really interesting to me, so if you like fantasy/utopia/dreams/monsters/etc., definitely take the class.

If you're trying to study French at Princeton, only take this course if you have to improve your skills before other 200- and 300-level French courses. If you're already at the 200-level, though, skip this course.
Much harder than FRE 107. That said, it is still a great class.
Only take this if you want to slog through an intermediate french course.

Pretty basic language course, not too different from 108 in terms of workload but definitely more advanced. Decent amount of work (readings and grammar for every class), but you'll improve reading/writing skills.
Put in extra effort to understand the readings.
Take it if you need it for certificate or what have you, but otherwise not too interesting. Just a necessary step towards better classes.
Take it if you're interested in French beyond the language requirement! It's pretty easy and fun content. Not a lot of readings.

Take it to develop language skills while reading engaging texts and watching movies related to "le fantastique"--science fiction, the supernatural, the magical, etc. Engaging class discussions. Fun, collaborative project at end. Reasonable work load.
definitely take it
take it if you have to - it is manageable - don't expect to be particularly engaged
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion. Film series. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.

title: The Everglades Today and Tomorrow: Global Change and the Impact of Human Activities on the Biosphere
descrip: See website

title: Geological Constraints on the Global Carbon Cycle
descrip: This course explores global geochemical cycles through the use of simple numerical models. Topics covered range from box models of the geologic carbon and oxygen cycles, planetary thermostats, and atmospheric oxygenation, to box models of Cenozoic seawater chemistry (Mg and Ca), to 1D diffusion-reaction modes of the dynamics of carbon and oxygen in sedimentary systems. Previous coursework in differential equations and MATLAB are highly desirable but not absolutely necessary.

title: Approaches to American History
reviews: Course is functionally a U.S. History seminar.  Strongly recommended.

Definitely take it, especially if you are thinking about majoring in history. The format for the papers is unusual, but you'll become much more confident at working with primary sources and thinking like a historian. The lectures aren't crucial to understanding the material, but give you with a good sense of what the different faculty in the history department have to offer. Professor Kruse is fantastic.

Definitely, definitely take it. Don't be scared away by people saying it's too much reading. It's a fair amount but it's actually surprisingly do-able, especially with the two precept a week formula, and you will not regret it. And this is coming from someone who almost always chooses "easy" classes....
Do the reading as best you can. That's the point of the course.
Do the readings
I would recommend taking this class although it is very challenging.
I would recommend that students view this course as a learning process and really focus on finding methods of active reading that work for them.
If you are thinking of majoring in history, you should definitely take it.
If you want to study history at all, take this class. You'll learn a lot!
It was a very different kind of class than the kind I was used to, in terms of the readings and style of writing, but it was very useful and stimulating so I would recommend it to other students.
Make sure to attend lecture. You'll get to hear from a number of renowned history professors

Prof. Kruse is better in lecture than in precept in my opinion (he's also a hard grader). Not my favorite history course--go with a seminar instead if you can. I also didn't feel like it significantly bettered my writing or made me more comfortable with the research process.

Really try to do all the readings, and GO TO THE LECTURES because they're really interesting and you'll get to see which History professors you're interested in taking classes with. Great class to give you an intro to independent work in history.
TAKE IT!! It's a lot of work but it's totally manageable! Also, only three papers and NO tests.
Take it! Even if you're not that into history, there's so much stuff here. Race, gender, America. It's good stuff.

Take it, and know that it will be the good kind of challenging course! Write summaries of every reading, just a sentence or two. It will help you SO much when you have to go back and reread things for the papers.
Take this class!!!

Take this course! you will learn so much about the writing process, which will definitely help you in the future. Keep up with the readings -- if you don't, starting the papers will be extremely difficult!!
Take this if you're interested in history. I think everyone who ended up majoring really enjoyed the class.
You must take this course if you want to learn how to do history right.
prereqs: First priority is given to Sophomores..
descrip: An intensive introduction for history concentrators, particularly those who plan to take their independent work seriously. Students will immerse themselves in documents of three events: the Little Rock school desegregation crisis of the 1950s; Native American policies and the Dawes Act of 1887; and the Salem witch trials of 1692-1693. Interpretation of documents, framing of historical arguments, and construction of historical explanations will be stressed. Lectures introduce a basic vocabulary of analysis.

title: Environmental Challenges and Urban Solutions
reviews: Absolutely take it. Some of the two best professors on campus, and the trip to Brazil is really eye-opening. So much knowledge to be drawn out of this class.
Bruno and Mario are both powerhouses, and taking a class with the two of them is super interesting. This is a great class for anyone interested in cities at all. Plus, like, you get to go to Brazil.

If you have any interest in the relationship between city and nature, take this class. It will change how you think and will give you a chance to intervene in the issue through a really cool design project for dean's date.
Make sure you bring to it exactly what you want to bring to it: tailor the class to YOUR interests.
Make the most out of it by talking to the profs a lot - they are both super friendly and helpful and intelligent and fun. Have fun in Brazil!
Probably one of my favorite classes at Princeton thus far. I enjoyed the fact that it was so flexible, so that we could tailor the class to suit our personal needs and interests.
Take it!  The teachers, material, and trip are all awesome - you will learn so much!
Take it. The material is really interesting, the work can be time consuming and engaging without being impossible, and the trip to Brazil is life changing.
prereqs: International travel required. The course includes attendance to the conference "Sao Paulo as Fluvial Metropolis: Infrastructure, Meta-projects, Imagined Futures and the City as Home" to take place in March 2015..
descrip: At the beginning of the 20th century, 10% of the world's population lived in cities; today, more than half live in urbanized areas. As part of our search for solutions to climate, water and energy challenges in a urbanizing world, it is crucial to understand and reassess the role of cities in the environment. This interdisciplinary course aims to add historical, theoretical and cultural dimensions to scientific, technological, and policy aspects of current environmental challenges, to bridge the environmental sciences, architecture and the humanities, and to rethink traditional city/nature dichotomies.

title: Peacemaking
reviews: Don't.
Gen. Nash is nice and has great stories. Topic is pretty interesting but discussion and readings can get repetitive.
General Nash is an awesome professor. Definitely get to know him in office hours!
General Nash is one of the best professors I've had at Princeton. He's a great teacher, and just a fun person to enjoy a conversation with.
If you like the subject matter, I would take it. Gen. Nash is a great guy, and his experiences really ground the readings and add to them. That's rare for a course, even at a place like Princeton.
Learn as much as you can, and go to office hours.
Take if you are very interested in the subject or know something about current events. Otherwise you will die of boredom. Nash is a great guy, however.
Take it, great class, you learn a lot, Prof. Nash is awesome
Take it: You will learn, you will engage with the experience, and you will have a great time in class.
This class has a lot of positive reviews, although I thought the class did not live up to my expectations. Probably would not have taken this class again if starting over.
descrip: This seminar will assess the history, objectives, and effectiveness of international peace operations including peacemaking, peacekeeping, peace enforcement, and peacebuilding efforts. Informed by current and recent operations in places such as the Balkans, Africa, and the Middle East, the class will assess progress by the international community in its ability to respond effectively to the political, economic, and social transitions in post-conflict societies. The seminar will also study the development of U.S. policy toward peace operations.

title: Beginner's French II
reviews: Do at least a little bit of French everyday.
Do the syllabus work and try to learn vocabulary as you go along.
Dont take it unless you have to
French is an interesting language
Great course, but super dependent on who is your instructor.
Great course, take it to learn French.
I think FRE102 will be a bridge to improve real French. I strongly recommend other students considering taking it.
I think if you have to take a language class this is a good one to take.
I would advice them to take it.

I would encourage every student to complete all the readings and to participate in class. This was sometimes very challenging for me as I was not comfortable with making mistakes. But I would suggest that every student spend time practicing out of class, and try to participate during class.
It's a great class, and you will definitely learn a lot of french!
Keep and open mind.

Keep up with the homework and daily assignments and even try to get ahead.  Attending class and doing in-class work is not enough to truly excel in this class - you need to do work (and maybe even find extra practice assignments) on your own.

Knock knock. 
Who's there?
Gopher.
Gopher who?
Gopher it!
Like 101 the course moves quickly but if you stay on top of the grammar it is not difficult to do well
Make sure to do the daily homework and not fall behind.
Necessary!
Practice everyday and learn the vocabulary
Read the textbook and go to class.
Stay current on the textbook assignments in the syllabus - they'll really help you get the most out of each class, they're not time consuming, and you'll need to review less when exams come around.
Stay on top of your grammar because it is cumulative.
Study everyday.
Take it if you have to or want to.
Take it.
This is one of the easier and straightforward and fun language courses, but it's still difficult and will require work.
Try as hard as you can to immerse yourself in the language as much as possible outside of class. And go to office hours!
Try to get into Meghan Gottschall's class
You gotta want it
goood
stay on top of work
you probably have to take this class for a language, its fine
prereqs: FRE 101 or Permission of Instructor. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless FRE 102 is successfully completed..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to enable you to achieve intermediate communication proficiency in French. All four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing will be actively practiced in realistic communicative situations, through a variety of activities designed to help you strengthen newly acquired vocabulary and grammatical structures. You will learn to talk about events and people, construct narratives in French and develop reading and writing skills that will be a foundation for literacy in the target language. There is a wide use of authentic material from France and the Francophone world throughout the course.

title: Approaches to Islamic Intellectual History
descrip: This seminar provides a broad-ranging introduction to and assessment of approaches to pre-modern and modern Islamic intellectual history. How, and with what success, have scholars tried to place particular developments in their varied intellectual, political, socio-economic, and cultural contexts? What constitutes the relevant context and how should one try to mediate among competing ways of accounting for particular intellectual developments? What assumptions - historiographical, sociological, normative - have guided recent work and how do they compare with an earlier generation's scholarship? These are among the questions we address.

title: Econometric Research Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Directed Research I
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research I is normally taken during the first year of study.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Asset Pricing II: Stochastic Calculus and Advanced Derivatives
reviews: Best course.
It's very clear and useful. A little bit hard and requires solid foundation in math.
Nice course, too bad she is leaving Princeton.
Solid quant finance course
Very good class for applying stochastic calculus in pricing all sort of financial derivatives
make sure to work through the examples in the slides
descrip: Course covers the pricing and hedging of advanced derivatives, including topics such as exotic options, greeks, interest rate derivatives and credit derivatives, as well as covering the basics of stochastic calculus necessary for finance. Designed for Masters students.

title: Calculus II
reviews: Adam Levine is a great lecturer, would recommend him.
Avoid is possible but if you cannot, take it with Adam Levine.
Be prepared to do a lot of the teaching/learning at home!
Depending on the professor, it would be worthwhile. Get started early on the readings and problem sets and definitely use friends as a resource.
Do it, but just know it's a long hill.
Do not take unless you have to.
Do the homework, never skip a class
Do the work every week and don't get behind.
Don't take it if you don't have to. It's not very interesting.
Don't take this class unless you have to
Get Adam Levine if he's teaching it.
Get help when you need and don't fall behind because everything is related and its hard to catch up at the end

Go to Adam Levine's office hours, use McGraw tutoring if you need to and do all of the practice problems online. This class is not impossible but there are a lot of techniques that they expect you to master and it is so much easier if you understand the techniques rather than just memorize them.
Go to Class.
Go to McGraw and office hours
Go to all of the lectures.
Go to every single precept.
Go to office hours!
Good
Hard material but very well thought. Take it if you don't want to start with 103.
I think that what can make or break this class is the professor, so read reviews for them before you sign up for a section. Adam is great, and I've heard one of the best ones.
I would say to try to get a section of this course that is taught by a professor and not a graduate student.

If you are an engineer, you have to take this class. So if you do, I'd try to get into Peter Humphries section. If you are AB, I'm not sure I would recommend this course for you. Regardless of the quality of the instructor, the class is difficult. I'd take an easier math for your QR, or possibly COS.
If you want to take this course do so with Adam Levine. He explains all the concepts very well and is easy to approach.
It's a good course but read ahead/keep on track or you'll sink behind

It's not terrible and Professor Levine is a bro.  It's math, so it probably won't be the most riveting thing you've ever taken, but it does have immense carry-over to any other STEM course, and if you're an AB, I would say it's not a bad set of skills/thinking patterns to have.  Plus, it's not an overwhelming time commitment if you're okay with a B.  An A... well that could suck up a lot of time.  But B's are doable
Make sure you go to class if book study isn't your thing. Do as many problem sets as is reasonable, since they help the most with preparing for quizzes and exams.
Make sure you know the homework problems extremely well so that they feel easy that way when the exam comes you are better equipped to handle tougher problems

Make sure your teacher is a good one. Having someone with a  very firm grasp on the material at the front of the classroom, who was able to teach very well, made all the difference when reviewing notes before exams.
Necessary to complete practice exams to prepare for quizzes and exams.
Only take it if you have to.
Rely on the book, use Calculus lifesaver and online resources.
Start early on homeworks so you can understand the problems better.
Start the problem sets early, and ask for help if you need it. It is very very easy to fall behind
Study. Do problems.
Take it for BSE or if you really like Math. Challenge but not overwhelmingly so.
Take it if it's a prered.
Take it if you have to or are interested in kind of lame (but probably very useful) math.
Take it with Prof. Levine. Otherwise don't take unless you have to.
Take the course, and take it seriously.

Take this class! Go to the review sessions, and try to understand why, when, and what are you doing. Also, take this class with professor Mehdi, since he will cover problems from the past examinations, which is really helpful, since one becomes familiar with the expectations of the math department for that class.
Take this course if needed, but would not recommend if you do not have an interest in  calculus.
Take this course if you are interested in the subject, and do not hesitate to ask questions or you will be at risk of falling behind.
The content of the class is not that bad but the  tests are pretty difficult so you jave to atudy for them.
This course moves rapidly so to avoid cramming before the midterm/final make sure that you put extra time to fully understand the content as you go.
Try to get Professor Levine's class and do the problem sets.
Try to place out if you can in hs. Class is very hard. Folks who took BC in high school have an unfair advantage

if you're struggling it definitely helps to take additional notes from the book or calculus lifesaver or even just reading the section in the book

always correct your homework problems and review them before quizzes

if you search Mat 104 Upenn notes, those are like powerpoint notes and they're pretty helpful, sometimes more so than TA or book or lifesaver but overall they're pretty similar to what you learn in class
keep on top of your work, go to office hours.
make sure you stay on top of learning the material. there is a lot in this class, and if you can't keep up it will be very hard to learn
only take if you have to or looove math
read the textbook. it will help when class moves too fast
take it if you need it, but there are better QR distributions
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Continuation of MAT103. Topics include techniques of integration, arclength, area, volume, convergence of series and improper integrals, L'Hopital's rule, power series and Taylor's theorem, introduction to differential equations and complex numbers.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - The Writer's Room: Creating a Dramatic Series for the New Television
reviews: Amazing class. Professor Konner is wonderful. I would strongly recommend this class to anyone with any interest in writing for film or television.
If you can get excited about creative writing, take this course!

The first three weeks are pretty dense and tiring but afterwards the class is so much fun! You don't learn a lot of technical screenwriting, but the plot-building and character-building skills you get are universally helpful
This was a great class -- fun, really enlightening. I enjoyed going to class every week. Prof. Konner is incredibly knowledgeable. I mean, he wrote on the Sopranos. He's the man.
prereqs: This course is limited to advanced writing students who have previously completed at least two 200-level writing courses. This course cannot be audited. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information.
descrip: Television series on premium cable have, in the last decade, featured more sophisticated writing than on network television and in most feature films. These series afford a writer a heightened sense of character, more complex plots, darker subject matter, frequent surprises and non-linear storytelling. In this class we will create and write a series of this nature, organized around the same principles as a professional writer's room. Students will become the members of the "writing staff" and will write the pilot and bible for the show. Classes will include occasional guest writers/directors/producers, and will focus heavily on writing.

title: Tokyo as a Literary Topos
reviews: Helpful in situating select pieces of literature and film within the context of Japanese development and history since Meiji era.

If you are going to take this class, be ready to talk!! It's a very small class so you should expect to contribute substantially to discussion each week. You also need to be dedicated to doing the reading and watching the films. It's all fiction, so it's very fun and worth it. Give yourself credit for doing the work -- if you read/watch the material for the week, don't be afraid to talk about it!! Prof. Ueda will never shut anyone down for sharing his/her opinion.
If you want to learn more about Tokyo, take this course!

This is a great course if you want to learn about Japanese literature and the history of modern Japan (particularly Tokyo) at the same time. Professor Ueda does an excellent job of combining the two, and helps us engage with the readings and films very thoroughly.
descrip: In this course, we will examine the varying representations of Tokyo thematized in literary texts written since the alleged beginning of modern Japan. We will pay attention to the transforming metropolis, its repeated destruction and reconstruction, its changing roles in the lives of the people living within and without Tokyo. We will see how Tokyo at once becomes a site of nostalgia and suffering, desire and struggle. Our inquiries will also extend themselves to differing social status and gender roles in the city.

title: Topics in Literature and Philosophy - The Commodity and the Concept
descrip: This course explores major theoretical derivations of our working concepts of the commodity and the concept, before investigating the dynamic relation between them, including: the dependence of the former on the latter, the "transformation" of the latter into the former, the asymmetry of their mutual productivity, and the production of history from their relation. Readings in economic and conceptual philosophy and literary works in which these processes are narrated.

title: Statics of Structures
reviews: Branko is an amazing, understanding, and friendly lecturer. If you're deciding between this and Finite (as an MAE), definitely take this. Just make sure that you submit your problem sets on their FIRST deadline and then use Dean's Date for RE-submissions .
Can be tedious, but Branko is great.
Definitely recommend for MAE majors - take this instead of finites! Professor is super engaging, problem sets are manageable, exams are largely similar to problem set questions.
Definitely take this course, but be sure to leave time for the homeworks.  Don't leave them all for the redo date!
Don't miss the last lecture at Streicker bridge! Who cares what grade you actually get on the psets/exams if you don't actually know how to apply it to real life.
Don't take this class unless you have to do so.  There are 0 concepts to be learned in this class. Instead, it's all about tricks by hand to calculate things that are easily evaluated by computers.

Go to lecture and ask Branko if you ever have questions. Don't bother with the preceptors. Always go to the precept before the exams because Branko will teach you everything you need to know for the test.

Go to lecture, and don't buy the textbook. Enjoy the course, as it is well taught. It starts out a bit slow, but speeds up at the end. Try to get yourself very familiar and comfortable with the early material.

Go to office hours, and try to go to as many lectures as possible, even though they are early You understand the material a lot better when you hear it taught by Branko, although lecture materials are always posted after the fact.
Go to office hours.
I enjoyed this course overall. Professor Glisic is awesome. As long as you stay on top of the problem sets you should never have too much of a problem.

I personally LOVED this class. I thought Branko was amazing, the grading is really nice (like, it's not an easy class, but with enough work it's possible to do REALLY well).
But of course, you'll only like it if you're actually interested in Statics.

I would definitely take this course.  It is definitely difficult waking up for it, but Branko is a great lecturer and professor in general.  The pace and work isn't too bad until the last 2-3 weeks when it actually gets quite hard and missing even a part of lecture makes the problem set impossible
If you've ever thought about how a suspension bridge works, this is an interesting class.

It's a good class for a sophomore/junior. Material is clearly presented and it doesn't require too much work to do decently. Don't take it as a senior though because you'll lack the stamina needed to persist in these engineering classes. Eventually they start to take a toll.
It's an interesting class. It gets you thinking about the behavior of structures and not just the calculus. The problem sets do take a good chunk of time but we could re-submit for grades.
Take it if you have to, or if you're particularly interested in structures, which I am not.
This class is hard to engage in, you will never go if it is still taught at 8:30 and probably just fall behind on the work.

This course is a lot of work but Branko will give you all the support you ask for and the skills are very helpful to the field of civil engineering especially because many of the topics are not even taught at other schools, yet provide incredible insight when combined with other techniques like finite element analysis.
To MAEs: While this class is okay, if the quality of Finite seems to be on an upward trend, I would take that instead.
Very reasonable class and Branko is good at explaining things.
You learn a lot in this class easily. The problem sets are very time consuming.

great class if you stay on top of the material. it's very easy to fall behind, especially after midterms. Go to lecture, even if it's at 830am because it's so worth it. Also, try to actually commit to the weekly psets, which can be hard since you can always resubmit. Putting them off will lead to a very sad/stressful reading period.
only take if you're really interested in the material. otherwise the work will become very dry
prereqs: CEE 205 or MAE 223.
descrip: Develops notions of internal forces and displacements, and instructs students how to design and analyze structures. Presents the fundamental principles of structural analysis, determination of internal forces, and deflections under the static load conditions, and introduces the bending theory of plane beams and the basic energy theorems. The theory of the first order will be developed for continuous girders, frames, arches, suspension bridges, and trusses, including both statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Basic principles for construction of influence lines and determination of extreme influences will be presented.

title: Advanced Questions in Photography
reviews: Every year this class is different based on the students, professor and focus. I loved it with Kathryn Almanas (who won't be here next year) because she encourages us to leave our comfort zone in order to pursue questions we were interested in. It is PDF only which is really nice for people who love photography but don't like the seemingly arbitrary way of grading. Photography classes always take time, and we had a lot of assignments, but it's fun time and if you love it you won't mind it. Try new things and enjoy it!
Great course with lots of flexibility in terms of how you want to work. Take it if you can

I would absolutely recommend this course if you have a strong interest in photography and want to take your work in your own direction. However I can only speak for the class as it was taught by Kathryn, who is by far the best photography professor/teacher I have ever had (I've had many) and unfortunately I hear she will not be teaching here again. If she does come back, do not miss this class!!! Or take any class with Kathryn!
I would highly recommend this class for anyone interested in exploring photography!
TAKE IT FOR SURE
descrip: This class will investigate the idea of "manipulation" in photography and examine different approaches to controlling form and content. Class lectures will look at the work of such artists as James Welling, Collier Schorr, Arthur Jaffa, and Boris Mikhailov, among others. Demonstrations on lighting will address different methods for giving visual and psychological texture to images. Classroom discussions and lectures will focus on representation, the body, environment, and situation. Students will be expected to engage in research and discussion on the topic and produce a substantial body of work for presentation and final critique.

title: Introduction to Dance Across Cultures
reviews: Definitely take this class. Professor Hamera is amazing and the subject matter was incredibly interesting and fun.
I highly recommend taking this course. You will be writing and reading in this class, as well as dancing, so keep that in mind, but still take it with Professor Hamera!

If you are looking for a super easy course with basically no work, this is not for you.  You will work, and read, and think and grow in this course.  That being said, this was a fantastic course and I learned a lot from it.  I would highly recommend it.  Really make sure to try to keep up with the readings though. But if you want to learn more about dance and how it functions worldwide, this is the course for you.
Take it! You dance only every other week but the assignment to write an ethnography on a campus dance group is really fun and interesting. Also, Prof Hamera is so profound and insightful sometimes.
Take this class if you're going to be genuinely interested in the cultural backgrounds of dance forms and if you're willing to engage with the readings. Field notes are not too much work.
Take this course if you are interested in ethnography/anthropology. There is definitely more reading than is expected from a dance course.
Think thoroughly about your field notes because they are important for your journey.

This is the best course I've taken at Princeton. It's amazing. Be prepared for difficult, thought provoking material about dance. It really is an anthropology course, not just a dance course. If you care about the topic, then it will be a really wonderful experience for you.
prereqs: No prior dance experience is necessary to succeed in this course..
descrip: Bharata Natyam, Butoh, Hip Hop, and Salsa are some of the movement practices that will have us travel from temples and courtyards to clubs, streets, and stages around the world. Through studio sessions, readings and viewings, field research, and discussions of live and filmed performances, this course will introduce students to dance across cultures and historical periods while questioning categories such as classical, traditional, ethnic, folk, and world dance. The course includes sessions solely devoted to studio practice. Guest artists will teach different dance forms. No prior dance experience is necessary.

title: Early Modern Philosophy
reviews: Definitely take this class if you're interested in the material! Professor Garber is THE CUTEST, and class is so enjoyable. It's rare to be able to think about the Scientific Revolution as deeply as we did in this class.
Take it! Professor Garber is very knowledgeable.

This class deals primarily with the history of science during the 17th century, although science and philosophy were one and the same back then. I was expecting readings to be more philosophical, but if you have any interest in what science was like in the 17th century, you should definitely take this course.
take it!
prereqs: Open to upperclassmen without prerequisite; though previous coursework in philosophy, or history of science would be helpful..
descrip: This course will focus on philosophy and the Scientific Revolution of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. We will read a mixture of philosophical and scientific texts, as well as some contemporary tests in the philosophy of science. We will discuss both the relations between science and philosophy, as well as the way these historical episodes are reflected in more recent philosophical literature.

title: Themes in World History, 1300-1850
descrip: This seminar covers classical and contemporary debates and historiography of world history, from the making of world systems, to the rise and fall of empires, to global revolution and the onset of modernity.

title: Energy and Health: From Exhausted Bodies to Energy Crises
reviews: If you are interested in the politics of energy and the environment. Take this course.

Most students in this class seemed to have prior experience with the subject. However, having limited prior knowledge myself, I didn't have too much difficulty keeping up, and Bharat is a great instructor!
Take this class if you're interested in energy or health. This is one not to miss.

Take this course!! It's great for those who aren't necessarily Anthro/GHP people. I am an Economics major and felt that I could still engage with the material quite well and add in my perspective. Prof Venkat is great and this class is one I will always remember!
The professor is wonderful.

This is a great class for anyone who has a genuine curiosity about energy. Do as much of the reading as possible and even if you don't make sure to attend the seminars because the discussions are always fascinating.
take it!
descrip: In this course, we will consider how the production and consumption of energy are linked to questions of health. We will examine how philosophers, public health scholars, filmmakers, anthropologists, historians and even novelists have thought about energy. This class will treat energy as a broad concept, ranging from the metabolic productions of the body to the carbon fixations of democracy. We will also examine what energy sustainability might mean in the face of repeated infrastructure failure and the concurrent loss of life. Finally, we will look to the past and present of nuclear energy as a course of hope and a looming threat.

title: Honors Analysis (Single Variable)
reviews: Be prepared to spend a lot of time every week on homework.
If you want to be smarter, take this class.
It is a difficult and time consuming class but you can learn a lot from it, if remotely interested in the topic / considering (econ) grad school
Make sure to spend a lot of time with the material

Prof. Case's final exam just came out of nowhere. Was brutal. Should've taken his previous course evaluations seriously. Very nice person though, otherwise. 
I think the subject itself is very interesting, and if you aren't afraid, then you should take it. I have no theoretical math background, and a not great GPA, and honestly am afraid to find out my grade. But no regrets?
This class. Is so hard. Oh lord. P/D/F if you're not a math major.

Would recommend if you have to take it for grad school. It builds up from the bottom and assumes very little outside information. It's easy to get lost and fall behind, but there are resources to make sure you stay on track. Take advantage of them.
maybe dont
descrip: An introduction to the mathematicsal discipline of analysis, to prepare for higher-level course work in the department. Topics include rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Rieman integral, conditions for integrability of functions and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.

title: Topics in Probability, Statistics and Dynamics
prereqs: Undergraduates must request permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Probability, Statistics and Dynamics. More specific topic details provided when the course is offered.

title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering
reviews: Go to the seminars
Read the abstract beforehand and decide whether or not it will be a good presentation.
Required
n/a
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies - Literature of the Environment
reviews: Definitely take a class with Prof. Price!
Do all the readings and come to the seminar ready to engage and participate!

Rachel Price is a very smart and very kind professor. This class is fine, however, be aware that the class is solely about the environment. To me, that got a little restricting for the course. It is generally a good/fine course but be wary of taking this class if you think the environment might not be something you can read about for months.
Take it! You'll love it!
Take this course if you want to practice fairly advanced Spanish on a specific topic
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: The earliest Latin American literatures reflected both indigenous manipulation of, and exchange with, the natural environment, and European astonishment at new flora and fauna.Today Latin American writers and artists are taking on the mounting crises of climate change, deforestation, land grabs, pollution. Beginning with a colonial text, we will move to modern and contemporary readings of these problems, including oil extraction on indigenous lands, science fiction about rising oceans, writing on the Amazon, poetry about disappearing species, etc. Novels, stories, essays and documentaries by various authors.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Public Finance II
reviews: I would recommend it
Prepare for the class meeting and be engaged. You can learn a lot from asking good questions.
descrip: The course presents recent developments in the theory of social choice, fairness, equality of opportunity, inequality measurement, well-being measurement, and their applications in public economics. Recent developments in the analysis of collective risks, future generations, fairness in taxation, behavioral economics, and interdependent preferences are covered.

title: Acting and Directing in Musical Theater
reviews: Don't miss this course. I almost dropped it because I was worried about taking five classes this semester, but it can be as little or as much work as you need it to be and just being in the room with Rando teaches you a ridiculous amount as a director. Honestly, the way you really learn from this class is a director -- as an actor you benefit from the time you get to work with him, but that's really only going to be for about a half hour every week or every other week depending on how many pieces you do. As a director, watching him work with people is invaluable. He is brilliant, sensitive, professional, and so seasoned it feels like it rubs off on you.
Have some amount of singing experience before going in. Like at least the rudiments. Have a general sense of the history of musical theater, not just the last 10 years.
If you get the chance, take this course!
John Rando is not only an incredible director but a fantastic teacher.  If you have any interest in musical theater, I would highly recommend this course.

The quality of the course is, I think, somewhat dependent on the class of students you're working with. Make sure you like a decent percentage of the students so you have people to work with. John is AMAZING, though, so even if you don't know people it's probably worth it just for his insanity and brilliance.
You must take it if you any interest in musical theatre. One of the best courses I have taken here.
prereqs: THR 201, THR 301, THR 311, THR 335 or THR 411 or MUS 241 or significant experience in the musical form. Please contact the Program Director, Tim Vasen for more information at: tvasen@princeton.edu.
descrip: A practical, hands-on introduction to acting and directing in musical theater. The course will require students to prepare songs and scenes from selected musicals with an eye to how best to approach the particular challenges the scene presents.

title: What's So Funny? Forms of African American Humor
reviews: I would encourage every student to complete all the readings and to participate in class. This was definitely a very fun class for me, but it was only fun because each student was very involved and participated during discussions.
I would say go on with an open mind. Everyone has something interesting to offer.
If you love comedy, this is for you.
It's interesting but the reading is absolutely impossible to cover, the grading is harsh, and honestly you should probably just watch stand up in your free time instead
TAKE THIS COURSE! It's fun and intellectual at the same time!
Take this course! You won't be disappointed.
descrip: This course examines resources for and strategies of African American humor from the early twentieth century to the present. We will survey a wide range of cultural expression, including folk poems, literary satire, and stand-up comedy, and we will consider the historical circumstances under which African American humor has flourished. Supplemental reading in the philosophy of comedy will allow us to reflect on the cognitive and affective pleasure that is realized in laughter.

title: Intermediate Japanese II
reviews: An excellent way to continue in Japanese

By now, you should have an idea for how much work Japanese classes are at Princeton (read: a lot). That being said, you should also have a sense for how much learning this language means to you, and how much you are dedicated to its study. If you at all continue to have an interest in the language, do take this course. I found 107 to be much more enjoyable than 105, primarily because you start to read authentic texts, and as such you grow very quickly to understand some of the actual usage of the structures you are learning. The instructors are amazing as always.
I think they should realize they need to devote time to take this course, but they will be rewarded heavily.
If you took JPN 105 you know what to expect. Tobira is more work than Nakama, but the overall class is much the same.
Japanese gets more intense with the new textbook, but if you're serious about learning the language you should keep going.

Take Japanese!!! The professors are wonderful and you learn at such a fast rate, it's hard to believe at the end of this course that you've been studying Japanese for only 2 years. You won't regret taking this course! It's a lot of work, but it's totally worth it.
Wonderful class, though it requires a lot of time and dedication. Don't be afraid to talk to the professors for any help that you need!
prereqs: JPN 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: The course aims at a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points covered in JPN 101, 102, and 105. It is also intended to give students advanced vocabulary and expressions through aural-oral drills, readings, and written exercises. Emphasis will increasingly be on reading, but oral work will still comprise fundamental aspect of the course.

title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Current research and issues in sensation, perception, and cognition. Ongoing research by seminar participants, research methodology, and current issues in the literature will be discussed.

title: Agriculture and Food Security
descrip: This course provides an understanding of the complex and challenging public health issue of food security in a world where one billion people are under-nourished, while another billion are overweight. Topics explore the connections among diet, the current food and food animal production systems, the environment and public health, considering factors such as economics, population and equity. Lectures, discussions and case studies will examine these complex relationships and alternative approaches to achieving both local and global food security and the important role public health can play.

title: Topics in Labor Economics
reviews: For a grad student, no recommendation should be needed. For an undergraduate interested in economics at the graduate level, I would say this is a good way to be exposed to some topics and the later years of grad school, but that an introductory-level class will give them a better idea of what to expect and how to prepare for the admissions process. (And that it would yield a higher benefit in the admissions process to have taken and passed a first-year grad class.)
I would recommend it
Stay engaged in the material and try to prepare for the lectures.
descrip: The course surveys both the theoretical literature and the relevant empirical methods and results in selected current research topics in labor economics.

title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: A great class if you are interested in entrepreneurship and starting a business. The workload for this class is pretty light, but know that the class is rather competitive. Class participation counts for a very large part of the grade and other students in the class tended to compete with one another for airtime. The midterm project requires you to write a short paper. The final project was one of my favorite parts of the course. You and a parter have to research a start up company and then give a funding pitch as if you were the company's founders. It was a cool experience to actually pitch our researched company in a real venture capital office operated by professor Keunne. I can't imagine a better experience to help prepare you for the business world.
Even if you come from a non-technical background, this class will show you the ropes of entrepreneurship.

Good class, worth taking. The first half is ok since it's foundational but the second half is awesome when you start talking about brands and what really *drives* a business. The projects are alright; the final is cooler than the midterm project. Professor Kuenne is smart and engaging
Great class to take at some point, regardless of your background or interests. Not too difficult, very accessible material, and filled with very generalizable lessons.
I will rave about this course for years to come. It is an unforgettable, once-in-a-Princeton-career kind of experience - you won't regret it!
I would 100% recommend this course! Be engaged and participate and you will love it.

I would definitely take this class if you are at all interested in entrepreneurship. It is one of the best at Princeton.  Kuenne is engaging and a great lecturer, and the course material is interesting, varied, and useful.
Interesting introduction to entrepreneurship, but you could probably get a similar level of understanding from other materials online and in print. Don't know why you can't PDF

TAKE IT. But if you're quite introverted like me, then talk to Kuenne early about what he expects participation-wise, otherwise his comments about your participation halfway during the year will take you by surprise.
Take it if you're interested at all in entrepreneurship.
Take it!!!!!!! But make sure you participate at least 2-3 times per class because participation grade is huge.
Take it, do all the readings, and be fully engaged, and in return, Professor Kuenne will will inspire you to and will teach you how to start a business.
Take it.

Take it.
Kuenne is fantastic, and simply a great person to know. I knew nothing about entrepreneurship before, and had a pretty steep learning curve. So much fun.

Take this class if you want to discuss the basics of entrepreneurship with the bulk of content coming from other students. Very interesting topic, but sometimes frustrating in that participation grade pushes people to voice every single opinion.

Take this class!!  It's not an easy A by any means, but it is so interesting and far more rewarding than many of the other EGR classes.  It is structured like a Harvard Business School class and you discuss interesting cases and get to hear from extremely successful and talented individuals (including the professor himself!!).  Really really glad I had time to take this class before graduating - do it!!!

Take this course! Professor Kuenne is an expert and his passion and experience makes him an awesome teacher. The class is modeled like a Harvard Business School class so the HBS cases are interesting and teach you a lot. HE also brings in guest lecturers about every other week who are related to the cases and that adds a whole dimension to the material. The midterm and final are really awesome experiences. The midterm was a written analysis of a company and the final was a pitch to Kuenne about a company as well. These felt like a great way to apply our knowledge. My biggest critique is the semi-competitive aspect which was generated by the fact that participation is such a huge part of the grade. Try to raise your hand a lot but say things that matter- quality over quantity!
Take this course. It's definitely the best and most real-world applicable course I have taken here.
Take this if you can!
This course is a very good introduction to business. It allows you think about a business ecosystem in detail and teaches you how to solve business problems. If that interests you, take it!
best class, an absolute must take
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application bit.ly/ELE491App, deadline is December 1..
descrip: This hands-on course introduces students to analysis and actions required to launch and commercialize a tech company, through the use of Harvard Business School cases, visits from entrepreneurs, and two "field assignments". You will learn conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques for evaluating technologies, markets, and commercialization strategies. Additionally, you will learn how to attract and motivate the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners and venture capital), prepare business plans, structure relationships, refine product-market fit, and create and grow enterprise value.

title: Macroeconomic Policy
reviews: I learned a lot, but you really have to get used to Iqbal's lecture style and pick out what is really important. Overall, it is not a lot of work and the grading is generous.
Know going in that you will learn a lot. That being said, the course is quite challenging and covers material that is often only discussed in graduate study.

The topics are mostly very interesting (related to policy models, fiscal/monetary interactions, open economy stuff). Professor Zaidi is also somewhat flexible with his syllabus, so the class can focus on what you find more interesting or pertinent.
prereqs: Two main prerequisites are Intermediate Macroeconomics (ECO 301 or ECO 311 concurrent enrollment is acceptable) and Calculus of Several Variables (MAT 175 or MAT 201 or equivalent must be completed in advance). Those courses have their own prerequisites, which you must have completed..
descrip: The course focuses on fiscal and monetary policies to promote high-quality growth with price stability, but some attention will also be given to sector-specific policies and other aspects of macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform, including tax and financial sector reforms, external competitiveness, and public and external debt management. We will study various macroeconomic models, including models used by central banks for monetary policy analyses.

title: The Literary South
reviews: Alex Vazquez is amazing. I don't know what it's like without her.
Alexandra Vazquez is an amazing professor, and the subject material is really interesting.
Best class I have taken at Princeton.
Dive deep into the books, push the boundaries of your thought, and enjoy

Professor Vazquez made this course fantastic, but even with another professor, I would still recommend it. The spring '15 reading list was great, and I went from not particularly looking forward to the diasporas departmental to discovering a region of literature that I really love.
This class was great because Professor Vazquez clearly cared about everything we read a great deal and wanted us to succeed in discussing and thinking about the topics in the class.
This class was pointless
take it if you can! 100%
descrip: The American South is a setting that is at once locatable and elusive, difficult and quaint, a site of violence and a generative literary milieu. This interdisciplinary seminar will examine the American South as an actual and imagined location in literature from the early 20th century to the present. Through nuanced attention to its legacies of conquest, slavery, and empire, we will discover how the American South fails to properly fit within the racial and geographical logics assigned to it.
