Students will read key texts in U.S. Southern literature, and, recognizing the region's porousness, from throughout the Atlantic world.

title: Topics in Recent and Contemporary Philosophy - Recent & Contemporary Philosophy
descrip: The class will cover contemporary issues in perception and social cognition, and their relation to metaphysics.

title: French Literature: Approaches to the Language of Literary Texts
reviews: Do all the readings. Read the theory readings carefully. Some are hard, but all worthwhile. Participate in class discussions. It's no fun if no one talks.
I would highly recommend this class and advise students to expect a wide variety of material.
If you are interested in literature and literary theory, this is the one that gets you into the door.
prereqs: FRE 107 or FRE 108 or Permission of Instructor. Course conducted entirely in French..
descrip: This course is meant to introduce students to great works of French literature from a range of historical periods and genres and to provide them with methods for literary interpretation through close reading of these texts. The course syllabus is organized around major topics in literary theory and criticism. This course is invaluable preparation for more advanced and specialized 300-level literature courses. Classroom discussion and free exchange encouraged.

title: Subcultures
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Japanese Print
reviews: Absolutely take it! Professor Watsky is super knowledgable and the discussions are great. And buying a print is really fun and rewarding!

I HIGHLY recommend the course, even if your interest in Japanese art is not huge. You spend about half your time in the museum sharpening your skills of visual observation, which is incredibly valuable whether or not you're an art history major. The final paper/presentation can be on so many different topics that it's very easy to find an angle most interesting to you. Most of all, selecting a print for the museum to purchase is probably one of the coolest things you can do at Princeton. And, Prof Watsky is really great, and very helpful. His focus on using actual objects for the course is wonderful, and his background in galleries is often very instructive. He really knows his stuff.

I would highly recommend this course! I had taken many art history classes before, but none focused on non-Western art so I was very curious to see what this class would entail. Professor Watsky is extremely knowledgeable and engaging and he made the material accessible, interesting and challenging. I particularly loved the hands-on aspect of the course- we spent a portion of every class working directly with objects in the museum. The highlight of the course would definitely have to be the opportunity to purchase a print for the museum's collection, an incredible opportunity that I have not heard about in any other class on campus!
If you are interested in Japanese culture and art, this is a no-brainer to take. Very special course.
absolutely take it if your interests even come close to this realm.
prereqs: At least one lower level course in art history or Japanese studies, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar examines Japanese woodblock prints from the 17th through the 19th century. We will consider the formal and technical aspects of prints, the varied subject matter, including the "floating world" of the brothel districts and theatre, the Japanese landscape and urban centers, and the links between literature and prints, especially the re-working of classical literary themes in popular prints. The seminar will emphasize the study of prints in the Princeton University Art Museum; students will also research Japanese prints at an art gallery in New York and recommend one to be purchased and added to the collection of the Museum.

title: Topics in Cinema and Culture - Unsettling Encounters - Colonial Latin America in Film
reviews: Expect more of a literature class with emphasis on visual representation. Grading is a little harsh, definitely proofread.
This class was a lot of fun and I definitely hope they have a similar class in the future.
This course really forces you to write a lot in Spanish and learn how to analyze film.
prereqs: One 200-level course above SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: An exploration of foundational texts of colonial Latin American literature in conversation with films by American and European directors. We will engage questions of how, when, and why images recall historical moments, and will consider the possibilities and limitations of using film to represent history. Students will learn and practice techniques of textual analysis and film criticism while discussing themes such as visual literacy, cultural imperialism, and economic colonialism.

title: Cell and Developmental Biology
reviews: A lot of people freak out about Cell Dev because of the sheer amount of memorization. But try to enjoy it; it really is a fascinating course. Read the textbook! It helps so much!
A ton of memorization.
Attend all lectures!

Be glad this is a department for molbio. Well taught and covered really interesting material. Both the professors and preceptors were really invested in helping students do well and understand the material. But make sure to attend the lectures and precept and work with others on psets to discuss the concepts involved.
Considering that it is a departmental, this is a good course. There is a lot of content involved, but they're not difficult concepts. Overall, nice course.
Digest the material after every lecture. Study for the final in advance.
Do P-sets early

Do it! It's interesting, and especially if you have Biochem background there will be a decent amount of overlapping material. If you are absolutely terrible at memorizing the names of random mRNAs and transcription factors, though, you might want to consider improving on that prior to taking the course or it'll take a Toll on your performance come exam time.
Do the readings and work with others on the problem sets.
Dowon Dan Kim do not take this course. read the lectures
Frequently review your notes
I'm really like the material, but the course is so hard.
If you are really interested in molecular biology, this class can be rather interesting. Just make sure to do well on the participation and PSets since the exam curve is rather rough.
If you're taking it it's probably because you're a MOL major
It is a lot of material so stay on top of it throughout the semester.
It's a lot of material, but very interesting. It'll help to use the clicker quizzes to stay on top of the material.

It's not a bad course, but it's not a great one either. If you have to take it for MOL, it won't be as bad as some other courses, but there are far better courses (electives!) in the department as well.

It's so easy to get behind on material for this course. Spend time reviewing the previous lecture before you attend the next one. Make sure you really understand everything that's going on. Also, team up with others to work on psets with early!!
Just go to all of the classes and print out the lectures so you can take notes on the lecture notes. Memorize everything and you'll be fine.
Keep up with material. Go to lecture and precept.
Keep up with the material.
Keep up with the readings and go over notes after every lecture.
Lots of material. Very challenging to keep with everything.
Lots of memorization and professors are inaccessible. Lots of work
Not incredibly difficult, but a lot of memorization

Of course, only take if you have to. It really is two courses in one. The course is not based on concepts but rather on memorizing the specifics of pathways and processes that will be useless to you in the future. Cram for the exams, not much else you can do. Hope that they change the course or get rid of it before you have to take it.
Only take if you need it. This course moves very fast.

Since they've remade the course I think cell dev is no longer the nightmare/fear of all MOL majors it once was. Class was interesting, useful, and entirely doable. You can now take this class for interest without fearing for your GPA/sanity
Take it (you already have to if you're a MOL major).
Take it only if you have no other choice; this course is no fun.

Take this class if you're at all interested in development. It's a very well-taught class and definitely not as scary as some people make it out to be. Prof. Devenport is a great lecturer! This class honestly got me interested in developmental bio. and a lot of the stuff we learned was just so cool.
Take this course! It is a lot of memorization but the material is very interesting.

The amount of detail in this course is really appropriate for mol majors or people with very strong passions for cell biology.  It is a lot of work to keep up with since there are daily quizzes.  However, this forces you to stay on top of the material which in turn makes problem sets and exam preparation much easier. I LOVED this course, and a true passion for the material made it a lot easier...not that it was easy. There is a LOT of memorization.
There is a ton of material, non of which is particularly interesting. Lectures were mediocre at best, and problem sets were incredibly ambiguous.

This class is so much material. It's all about keeping up with the lectures and staying on top of the readings. Use your preceptors to answer questions, because it's pretty hard to cram for this class.
This is a difficult class. It covers a lot of material, but everything you learn builds a super useful fundamental understanding in molecular biology.

This is a time-consuming class, since you're presentation with a lot of information at each lecture. The problem sets are reasonable and you are allowed to work together. It would be nice if they provided more support, such as office hours or review sessions.
You gotta take it so you gotta take it. It's about what you'd expect for a required class.
study
descrip: The mechanisms that underlie development of multicellular organisms, from C. elegans to humans, will be examined using biochemical, genetic and cell biological approaches. The course will investigate the roles that gene regulation, cell-cell communication, cell adhesion, cell motility, cell death, signal transduction and intracellular trafficking play in the commitment, differentiation and assembly of cells into specialized tissues.

title: Topics in Social and Personality Psychology - Developmental Origins of Life Outcomes
reviews: Be prepared to discuss and read lots of scientific articles!
Casey Lew-Williams is really engaging and inspiring in the seminar setting. He chooses fascinating readings and topics and allows us to think openly and critically on the subject matter.
Casey is AMAZING. Take this class, the discussions are student-led. You grow through making presentations and discussing big problems through the lens of psych. Fun and eye-opening.
Do all of the readings, and spend time working on your group project. This class works really well when you give enough time to the nonprofit group that you are working with.

If you are interested in developmental psychology, this is an excellent course! It ties together social policy with psychology and parenting. You will learn about intervention and what works/doesn't. It is very practical and gives you hands-on experience with working with an NGO.
If you like the idea of seeing psychology, economics, policy, environment, biology, and sociology in action, it's great!

TAKE THIS COURSE. Really, take any course with Casey Lew-Williams. He is not only perhaps the best professor this university has to offer but also one of the most genuine, kindest, caring people in the Orange Bubble. He uses emoticons in his emails, takes time to ask how your non-class-related life is going, meets every student for free ice cream and coffee, answers emails promptly, and is an incredibly clear and exciting teacher of information. Most importantly, his enthusiasm is impossible not to love. He cares so deeply about his subject, and he cares just as deeply about making sure his students are learning.

Beyond Casey's amazingness, this class is unique in its focus on outside group projects for local nonprofits. If you are feeling sick of exam- and paper-heavy classes, take this course, make an actual difference in the community, and feel better about yourself for having helped a nonprofit while your friends are studying for their exams. Meaningful work, very fulfilling, and tons of fun.

Would recommend in the highest.

This class is awesome because your schoolwork isn't meaningless - you get to actually help a nonprofit in the area and take pride in how your schoolwork is profiting the lives of children in the area.

This is a good class! The readings are good and the class right now is mostly based on student presentation and then some discussion of the material. The CBLI component is currently not totally enmeshed with the rest of the class, but is still a very good idea as it shows how psych research may be practically implemented. Casey is a great guy too.
This is an amazing class! Casey is a fantastic professor who cares so much about the subject and his students. I was a non-psych kid and I really liked this course.
do it. and commit to do your best work.
prereqs: Course registration by application only. Please email Leslie Savadge at lsavadge@princeton.edu, 3-5 sentences as to why you are interested in this seminar along with class year and major. Applications will be accepted until Friday, December 5th..
descrip: Does infancy predict the rest of your life? This seminar will use ideas, methods, experiments, and theories from developmental psychology, cognitive psychology, communication sciences, education, and public policy to evaluate the cascading consequences of early childhood in shaping who we become and what we are capable of. Students will venture out of the Princeton community and gain on-the-ground exposure to two organizations focusing on early development, one in New York and one in Philadelphia.

title: Senior Project with Design
reviews: Choose your adviser wisely.
Select an adviser who will keep you on track, inspire you to follow your passions throughout your work, and will be accessible to you any time you need.
There aren't actual classes here.  Simply make sure you pace yourself, go into lab a decent amount of times, and make sure you have a project you're engaged with, and you'll be fine.

Work on a team if you can, it makes the workload for independent work a lot lighter especially if your project has a design component. Besides that, it teaches you how to work with other people, which is just an important life skill.

Working in a group for thesis is good because you'll always have someone to push you to do the work and you can't procrastinate as much. Of course, you'll need to handle the interpersonal issues, especially when the project lasts for a whole year.
n/a
descrip: Similar to 444 with the principal difference that the team or group project must incorporate aspects and principals of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior project with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Thesis Studio
reviews: Pick a good advisor
prereqs: One course is required for all M.Arch. students. Completion of Pre-Thesis Workshops is required for entry into Thesis Studio..
descrip: The Master of Architecture Thesis is an independent design project on a theme selected by the student. The student begins with a thesis statement outlining an area of study or a problem that has consequences for contemporary architectural production. Marking the transition between the academic and professional worlds, the thesis project is an opportunity for each student to define an individual position with regard to a specific aspect of architectural practice. As an integral part of the design process, it is intended that the thesis project will incorporate research, programming and site definition.

title: Creativity, Innovation, and Design
reviews: Definitely take this course.  It's unlike anything else at this university and my fellow students in this class can agree on that.  It teaches you to think in a way that I believe will make you more successful than what you might take away from a lot of the other courses here.

Drop whatever you're doing and take this course. I don't care if you want to do entrepreneurship or not - this course will change your mind/the way you think forever. And, you CANNOT do without it. It'll be the best decision of your Princeton experience!!

I'm an engineering student and I took this course based on the reviews - they said it was a great course and one of the few to teach thinking the way it did. 
This course is an avenue for the professor to disseminate his opinions on creative thinking. Grades on papers or comments on projects will be related to the opinions of the teaching staff, not to any factual reality. Comments will almost always be positive - expect lots of people all telling each other that they're all great, regardless of the actual quality of ideas being presented. "Talk much, say little" is the theme of this class. 
That said, the final project (attempting to come up with a solution to a real university problem - in my year, sexual assault) was a great experience. You just have to decide if you think this class is worth suffering through to get to that point. 

You may think this is just the sour grapes of someone who didn't like the professor. But I'm telling you - I was in your shoes.The reviews looked great. But the nonscientific, wishy-washy, hand-wavyness of this class was something I just couldn't get past no matter how I tried. Do not take this class.
If you take it, take it with the professional designers.
Its fun, but more work than you'd expect. Definitely the weirdest class you'll take at Princeton.
Not a very academic course, but that's why it's so great. It's geared more towards teaching you real life skills that academic skills. Definitely take it, you can't go wrong.
Pretty interesting class and you feel very accomplished at the end and invested in what you have made.
TAKE IT
TAKE IT!
Take it if you have a lot of time on your hands.
Take it! But be prepared to invest a LOT of time into your project. Pick a group with people you like working with!
Take it! Very different from most other classes here at Princeton.

Take it! While this course is a big time commitment, the returns are are well worthwhile. Professor Lidow is excellent. This class is fundamentally different from other offerings at Princeton. It will change how you think and view the world.
Take it. It's a very different class structure but well worth it.

Take this class if you want to learn more about your ability to interact with the world and with other people; it's a totally new way of thinking that you probably won't have really experienced before, and that is truly awesome.  It's not often that Princeton gives you something so non-conformist.  Take the opportunity!! It's an amazing class and you come out the other side feeling way more prepared to take on the world.
This class will change how you perceive the world and will dramatically enhance your understanding of innovation.
This course requires a bit of work, but you definitely will walk away having developed and implemented your creative and innovative skills.

This is an incredible class! If you are in the session taught by Sub Rosa, you will meet an incredible group of guest lecturers from the company (it changes every week). Cookies and coffee during class was a major plus as well :) While this course is a huge time commitment (5 hours of class a  week   1-3 hours for readings and your creativity journal   1-3 hours per week for team meetings in addition to upwards of 5 hours a day while you are preparing your final group project), you should definitely take the class for the people. In addition to the lecturers, the people who take this class are amazing, and you get to know them really well, especially your team mates. It's a really inspirational class that teaches you how to think differently.

You get as much out of this class as you want to / put into it. If you're really serious about building your creativity, innovation, and design skills, Prof. Lidow will give you the individual attention that you need to nurture your strengths/skills and improve on your weaknesses. This class is particularly good for people who love entrepreneurship and design.  If you're not going to be 100% engaged in the course, don't take it - leave your spot to someone who is genuinely passionate about the material. This class is just too valuable.

You will learn a lot the first two weeks. It will then get a bit monotonous but the final project that starts after spring break is well worth it if you choose an interesting topic. And you get to meet inspiring people from Sub Rosa.
descrip: The class mission is to give students an understanding of the sources and processes associated with creativity, innovation, and design - three interdependent capabilities essential to our own well being, as well as to the well being of society. We will study the internal and external factors that relate to our own ability to create, innovate, and design. We will also understand the factors that impact a group's ability to act creatively, to innovate, and to produce practical and appealing designs. The class will consist of readings and case studies as well as individual and group projects.

title: Investigative Journalism - Fundamentals of Investigative Reporting
reviews: Favorite class this semester. Investigative journalism taught me not only how to be a journalist, but how to search for truth, find it, and then use it to create change.
Take advantage of meetings with Professor Steele-- he is clearly invested in every students' progress, and will offer great guidance/ feedback if you seek it out.
Take advantage of the professor's accessibility; always meet with him and discuss your work. It is an incredible opportunity.
Take it!

Take it!! It will help you appreciate the power of journalism, and Prof. Steele's guidance will help you get out of your comfort zone and bring your stories to a higher level through documents-based research and interviews. Amazing guests come to most of the seminars  - Pulitzer-prize winners from NYT, Rolling Stone, and a number of other important publications.

if you ever have a chance to take a class with Professor Steele - TAKE IT. HE IS AMAZING!
And this class has some of the best content I have ever experienced at Princeton.
DO IT!
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu/journalism/courses.
descrip: This seminar will be a practical introduction to investigative reporting, its history, its techniques and its role in democracy. Students will learn to research, organize and write investigative articles, and will explore investigative reporting's unique position in journalism and the ethical and legal challenges that often arise from controversial reporting. Award-winning journalists will participate as guest lecturers, and students will visit a newsroom.

title: International Political Economy
descrip: An introduction to the subfield of international political economy, covering basic topics in the politics of both trade and finance.

title: Evolution and the Behavior of the Sexes
descrip: This course, designed to capitalize on diverse student backgrounds, will use principles of evolutionary biology and behavioral ecology to examine mating strategies and their effect on social systems. We will draw examples from vertebrates, with an emphasis on group-living mammals, particularly primates and elephants. Topics will include mate selection, ontogeny of sex differences, sexual diversity, social bonds and cooperation, and intersexual conflict.

title: Complex Analysis with Applications
reviews: Aizenman is engaging and good at explaining the big picture behind the math, but he's also poorly organized, which can cause him to get bogged down in the calculations of an example and let out class late.
I would highly recommend it!  If you can get past Aizenman's disorganization and his loss of train of thought in lectures, this is a really fantastic, interesting, useful, and well-taught class.

Michael Aizenman is a great lecturer and taught the course very very well during this semester. His notes were well organized (except during the last 2-3 weeks). The course is not super time-consuming and preparation for exams is straightforward.
Professor Aizenman isn't bad and it's obvious that he tried for this class and cares for his students. The class itself is probably the easiest upper level math class I have taken.

Take this class if you're interested in appreciating some beautiful and simple theorems, or if you need it for your physics major, but you are not confident about doing the other complex analysis course.

The textbook by Brown and Churchill is incredibly helpful. Refer to it as much as possible.

Practice problems and full mastery of proofs are the key to success.

This is an interesting course. Very natural given the prerequisites and it is by no means a frustrating stretch of the mind. The professor is a great person and the material is very useful. Most people will end up taking it because they have to, I feel, but don't go into it scared. There is no reason to be.
prereqs: MAT 201 and MAT 202 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of functions of one complex variable, covering power series expansions, residues, contour integration, and conformal mapping. Although the theory will be given adequate treatment, the emphasis of this course is the use of complex analysis as a tool for solving problems.

title: Advanced French Language and Style
reviews: Definitely take this class! I great step after FRE 207, and the variety of compositions that you write is really fun (from a cover letter and CV to descriptions of people to dialogues). Really helps you develop your writing skills in both French and English! Know that it is a heavier homework load than 200 level classes, but it is worth it. Professor L'Hermitte is great, if he is teaching again.
Definitely take with Murielle Perrier!
If you want to improve your French and get a nice intro 300-level, take it.
Its a lot of fun and not too heavy of a workload.
Low commitment, easy class and good learning curve in French writing.
Make sure you read over your papers several times on the computer, print out a copy, then edit even with a red pen, and then submit the final copy.
Take this class if you want to learn how to write properly and expand your knowledge of French.
Take this class to bump up your French composition skills and master different forms and styles of writing.

This is a good course for improving primarily stylistic and writing skills in French. Sometimes the work can feel a little mechanic, so watch out. Try not to do things last minute, because you might be able to get by doing just mediocre but will learn a lot more if you put in real effort into the course. It's not difficult (a lot of compositions, but short) but pay attention to the final project and think about the readings as you do them.
You cannot BS this work-- this is a serious french class.
you should take it if you really want to get proficient in french but it's not an option to not do the work
prereqs: A 200-level French course or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: To improve spoken and written French through attentive study of French grammatical and syntactic structures and rhetorical styles, with a variety of creative, analytical and practical writing exercises, and reading of literary and non-literary texts.

title: Computer Networks
reviews: A good survey of the history and current state of computer networks. Most concepts are covered pretty shallowly, but there is a great breadth of topics.

Be prepared to spend a lot of hours on the later assignments.  The second assignment on making a router was the longest, with an estimated time of 50 hours, however we got about 2.5 weeks to work on it. Good if you want to learn more about networks. The exams were really long and tedious and difficult. This year we had a new professor so I'm not sure how the exams were in past years.
Be sure to start assignments early!
Do all readings/watch Feamster's videos/study hard. Go to office hours with TAs and instructors. Post on Piazza. Be direct in asking for clarity.

Even though I realized that I wasn't that interested in computer networks, the course was extremely well-taught and I learned a lot. I'd say take it if you have any interest in computer networks, and even if you don't it's still a very informative and practical class.
Great for learning all about networks! Gives you a strong overview, and fundamentals for how the internet works.
I recommend it.

I thought the course was interesting.  It was very convenient (both after missing a lecture, and to review for the final) to have a YouTube playlist covering most of the key concepts in the course.  My biggest complaint is the examinations.  Both the midterm and final were VERY long--I couldn't finish the in the time allotted.  It was frustrating to be tested on writing speed as much as knowledge of the material.
I would definitely recommend this course. The assignments are challenging but it is a good way to learn how the backbone of networks is built and operated.
If you have any interest in learning about internet and security, take this.
Interesting material, okay lectures, assignments are unclear, and help doesn't come on time on Piazza.
It could be better taught/structured, but the material is interesting.
It's a good system course. Not as hard as OS but still tough nevertheless.
It's an okay class. If you start assignments early you'll be fine.
It's pretty interesting. Take it. But make sure you know C.
Its okay as far as a systems class goes
Learn about the internet! It's pretty dope!
Lot of work but you learn a lot as well.
Maybe just my opinion but I thought this class was pretty interesting. Would recommend.
Not a bad way to fulfill the Systems requirement for COS majors. Not easy but material is good to know.
Only take if actually interested. Material isn't coherent enough to teach you well at this moment since you don't practice what you're learning. Shoutout to sandra for being awesome!
Pretty easy systems course, although OS is more interesting.
Router and TCP are somewhat time consuming so you should start early.
Start assignments early and read everything on Piazza. Overall a great Systems class and Feamster's videos online are probably more important than his lectures.
Start the assignments early, this is a pretty hard class, certainly harder than 217. That being said, Feamster is a great lecturer and there's a lot of really interesting material here.
TAKE it. Very core concepts in this class.
Take it if you're interested in networking or a COS major. These are useful skills to know.
Take it if you're interested in networks. I loved it. BEWARE the assignments are very long, start them early.
Take only if you must. The assignments are not that great, precepts are terrible, and tests are poorly worded and confusing. Take OS instead.
Take the class!  It's a lot of work, but it's a more conceptual systems class than some of your other options, and Professor Feamster is very committed to the success of his students!
Take the course if you are interested in Networks. You don't really need OS, but taking OS will make all assignments for this class look easy.
The assignments are not too hard. But they take some time to finish. In general you will learn a lot yourself while doing the assignments.
The lectures were fantastic, and the material is both interesting and easy to understand.  Highly recommended.
This class is a good introduction to networking. There aren't too many assignments, but they do take a while so start early.
Useful content, but disorganized and often frustrating. Do not take if you are uncomfortable not having good textual resources to learn from.
Would not recommend it if Prof. Feamster is teaching. His lecturing skills could use some work.

You learn how the Internet works and it's really interesting. Prof. Feamster's videos are a very efficient way of learning, even if you don't read the textbook (which is quite good) or even show up to lecture, you should watch the videos. Assignments are pretty fun. Very good for PDFing because you can ignore tedious error checking and handling of rare cases on the assignments. Not many assignments (4.5), only 2 are long.

Your grade will unfairly depend on the precept material. Try out several precepts, and make sure to internalize material that the preceptor didn't get to - you'll be responsible for it on assignments and exams.
prereqs: COS 217.
descrip: This course studies computer networks and the services built on top of them. Topics include packet-switch and multi-access networks, routing and flow control, congestion control and quality-of-service, Internet protocols (IP, TCP, BGP), the client-server model and RPC, elements of distributed systems (naming, security, caching) and the design of network services (multimedia, file and web servers).

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: (Half-Term) - Evidential Regimes in Development Theory
descrip: This six-week, graduate seminar questions the evidence used to make claims about how to make the world a better place. In particular this course weighs the anthropological evidence about culture and experience against the claims made by development experts about social progress. Do states need experts to manage development? Or are humans innately capable of effectively managing their own destinies without expert knowledge? Discussions will also focus on the role of power and authority in shaping people's expectations for the future.

title: Modern Korean Fiction
reviews: Great class to read good literature! Might be helpful to have a bit more knowledge towards Korean language/culture especially during the 1970's-2000's.

If this class isn't filled up by the time you are doing course selection, you should sign up. If it is filled, you should email the professor and ask to get in it. If you don't get an answer, you should go anyway and make sure you get in this class.
If this course is taught again, take it. Even if you have no idea about Korean culture, that shouldn't be a deterrent from taking it.
If you are interested in Korea (North and/or South), take this course. Do the readings and show up to class. Professor Chung will remember if you speak in class.
If you have an interest in Korean/Asian literature, enjoy chill professors, Chung is your man.
Take a class with Professor Chung!
Take the class, do the readings, participate, and have fun!
This is a great choice for a LA if you have an interest in Korea!
Worth taking and highly recommended even if readings and weekly responses were time consuming.
descrip: This is a survey of modern Korean fiction from the last decades of the 19th century to the present. Given the myriad transformations and conflicts of this period, the scope of readings will be wide, encompassing primary and critical texts, as well as writing from South and North Korea, Japan, and the United States. Closest attention will be paid to the literary works themselves. Thematic concerns will encompass modernity, colonialism, ideological division, democratization, gender, and diaspora. All texts in English.

title: Metals in Biology
reviews: If you are interested in learning about the function of metals in biology, take it! Not too much work and very interesting.
Take something else.  This was not as good as I was expecting.
This is a reading course. You will get more out of it if you read the papers that they cite.
Try to know the topic before the class and review on yourself
prereqs: Prerequisites: CHM 301/302 or CHM 303/304.
descrip: Life processes depend on over 25 elements whose bioinorganic chemistry is relevant to the environment (biogeochemical cycles), agriculture, and health. CHM 544 surveys the bioinorganic chemistry of the elements. In-depth coverage of key transition metal ions including manganese, iron, copper, and molybdenum focuses on redox roles in anaerobic and aerobic systems and metalloenzymes that activate small molecules and ions, including hydrogen, nitrogen, nitrate, nitric oxide, oxygen, superoxide, and hydrogen peroxide. Appreciation of the structure and reactivity of metalloenzyme systems is critical to understanding life at the molecular level.

title: Advanced Turkish: Selected Readings in Historical and Literary Texts
prereqs: Students are expected to have a sufficient command of Turkish language intermediate/upper intermediate level) to fulfill the reading and writing assignments. See instructor for further information..
descrip: This course introduces a wide variety of reading material (newspaper, memoir, letter, short story, diary etc.) to strengthen students' abilities in understanding and evaluating modern Turkish texts. Information on selected authors and their works will provide a general view on the Ottoman/Turkish cultural, literary and historical panorama. The analysis and discussions of the texts in class will serve to build fluency.

title: Introductory Printmaking
reviews: Definitely take this class if you are good at drawing (this helps in printmaking).  It really helps develop new skills.  It is incredibly time consuming so beware!

I would encourage any student interested in more remote and original forms of visual arts to take this class. It is an amazing opportunity to be able to take printmaking at Princeton, as it is rarely offered in schools and will likely not be accessible in the next steps of my life.
If you like art, take this class!! Professor Heyman is great, and printmaking is a very interesting process that makes you really think about art in a new way.

It's a wonderful course. It's a great way to develop your artistic imagination, challenge yourself to develop new skills and take a break from academic work. It's a lot of work, but it's fun and highly rewarding. And you get a bunch of prints at the end.
so much fun!
prereqs: MUST have taken: Any one 200-level VIS course..
descrip: This course introduces techniques of copper plate etching, and relief printing. Assignments focus on applications of various printmaking techniques, while encouraging independent development of subject matter. Critiques will occur throughout the term. Students are encouraged to draw regularly outside of class to cultivate themes and content applicable to their prints. Field trips to the University museum and the library's graphics collection will complement class work. Additional independent workshop hours required.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Internet Law and Policy
reviews: Be prepared for a less structured class, but very interesting material.
I would definitely recommend the course to cs students who are cares about applications and practical stuff
If you like law/COS or the intersection of the two, take it! Don't be intimidated by the number!
It's a good way to become more informed about the legal and political issues that could impact a startup or entrepreneur.
prereqs: No pre-existing legal or technical knowledge is required..
descrip: This course looks at how courts, legislatures, and regulators confront the major legal issues that the Internet poses. The fundamental challenge is that law comes from governments and other institutions in specific places, but the Internet is global and virtual. The material in the course ranges from the foundations of cyberlaw, developed during the e-commerce boom of the 1990s, to current leading-edge questions around social networks, user-generated content, location-based services, cloud computing, and data privacy and security.

title: Ethics of Persuasion, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Soviet Culture, Above and Below Ground
reviews: Reischl is a very understanding professor.  Make sure you participate!
Take it if you are at all interested in Soviet Culture or in culture in repressive regimes.
Take it! It'll make you wanna declare Slav by the end. Great great class.
Take it!!!!! DO IT.
Take this!  It is a fabulous course for Slavic and non-Slavic concentrators. Prof. Reischl is superb!
The course is phenomenal, and she is an excellent professor. She presents the material in the most engaging manner.  She is in my opinion the best professor I've had at Princeton.

This is an awesome course for anyone interested in the Soviet Union (or even if you're not interested in the Soviet Union--you will be once you take this course!). I think it prioritizes deep engagement with texts and materials over reading a massive amount (quality over quantity!) so you'll really get a lot out of the experience. And Kat Reischl is the bomb.com.
descrip: This interdisciplinary survey explores Soviet literature, art, theater, and film after the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917. We will explore the works of avant-garde authors and artists, official writers and painters, authors who wrote "for the desk drawer", and those whose creative works were circulated in the underground. In our analysis of Soviet artistic production, we will focus on major cultural topics in and around the increasing pressure of shifting political landscapes, ideology, propaganda, the publishing market, and the role of the writer in Russian society.

title: Topics in Development - Making Government Work in Fragile States
descrip: Reformers exist in many fragile states but few are able to produce sustained improvement in service delivery or in the operation of core government institutions. This course focuses on a set of governance traps that appear to subvert fragile state turnarounds and strategies for escaping these. It also addresses handling of principal-agent problems in remote areas. At a broader level, it engages participants in thinking about patterns of state formation in 21st century, focusing on scaling up of reform in urban centers. We use biography and case studies to spur thinking, plus theory drawn from economics and political science.

title: Special Topics in Film History - World Cinema in a Global Context
descrip: This course will provide a survey of 21st century world cinema as an investigation into the institutional and theoretical frameworks that inform its production. Texts studied will include "art" films (Martel's The Headless Woman), popular cinema (Bollywood, African video films), and everything in between (Meirelles's City of God). Theoretical topics to be considered include the relationship between global/local markets and audiences, cinematic constructions of national or post-national identity in global age, evolving approaches to reception and interpretation, and shifts in representation and distribution brought about by new media.

title: Advanced Physics (Electromagnetism)
reviews: Definitely do the readings because Purcell's textbook is a very great and beautiful one. Though this class is definitely a challenge, it is not impossible. Make sure that you are on top of things from the very beginning since concepts tend to pile up over time.
Definitely take if you love Physics. otherwise, 104 is a better choice for requirements.

Definitely take this if you want to major in physics. However, DO NOT fall behind. Make sure you understand everything and if you are working together with others on problem sets do not let them carry you. It is imperative that you understand the problem sets on your own.
Do extra problems outside of class, and don't expect the precepts to teach you the problem solving techniques you'll need for the tests.
Go for it. Not terribly difficult.

I have a lot of strong feelings towards this class. During the semester, I absolutely detested this class, was afraid to start problem sets, was afraid to take the quizzes that inevitably always turned out to be on the rather impossible side, was afraid to go to lab and sit through three torturous hours, was generally just afraid for my soul to tear a little each time I looked at Purcell, I was afraid of all of this, but now after taking the final and looking back, I realize that despite all the fear and suffering, I'm glad that PHY 106 had taken a part of my soul, and I'm glad that I walked out of the final knowing just a little (or a lot) more about electricity and magnetism, and I'm glad that I was able to peer, if only just slightly, into the beautiful realm of physics. So if you're strong, take this class, let it consume you, immerse yourself in the beauty of this world, and when you come out, you'll be glad you did, even if you had to sell your soul along the way.
I highly recommend this to anyone with an interest in physics.

I strongly recommend this course to anybody interested in physics. It's a fair amount of work (though I'm not sure how much more time consuming it really is compared to PHY 104) but it pays off very well.

I took this class because I had already taken AP Physics C E&M and thought I would be okay. Also because it was offered at an earlier time than 104. Was I wrong. Peoples reactions when I told them I was taking PHY 106 should've been a warning to me.

If you are planning on majoring in physics or astrophysics I would definitely take this class over 104. It covers plenty of stuff you probably haven't seen before like AC circuits and Special Relativity, specifically how magnetism can be deduced from Special Relativity and coulomb's law. So far it is my favorite physics class, and perhaps my favorite class at Princeton. Yes, it is more work than 104, but it is worth it.
If you take this course, then be prepared to spend a lot of time on it. That is all. Precepts with Hasan were not helpful but Meyers is excellent. The labs are fun.
If you want satisfaction from your intro physics, take 106. If you just want to fill a requirement, take 104.
If you're interested in physics, take it. Otherwise, don't.
If you're serious about learning physics and really love physics, this is the course for you.
It is a class for physics majors. If you are not thinking about physics as a major I would recommend 104 instead.
It is challenging but you will learn a lot from this class
It is challenging, but if you put work into it, you should be able to succeed.
It's a great course, especially with Meyers. E&M is a very fascinating topic. A fair amount of work, but not terrible.

My advice to freshmen who probably had more daily physics assignments in high school - even though this course assigns problems only once a week, I highly encourage students to practice problems regularly on your own to maintain and hone your problem-solving skills. I personally wish I had done that more while taking this course. Also, use the problems that have been worked through already in the back of the book - they're helpful for seeing how to approach different types of problems.

PHY106: While PHY105 was challenging, I found this one to be significantly more difficult, primarily due to the material presented. If you want to go forward with physics, definitely take this course. You'll have to work hard and struggle at times, but it's definitely a journey on which you should embark. If Professor Meyers is taking this course, definitely take it. Oh man...Professor Meyers. Professor Meyers is, for lack of a better title, The Man. He is by far and away the best physics teacher I have had here thus far. After every weekend, I would look forward to the one Meyers lecture from 11:00-11:50 that we would have of the week. I really cannot recommend this course enough if Professor Meyers is teaching it: it is already quite great, but he just seals the deal
Take if you want to be more than just a human calculator.
Take it. It's a lot of work but you come out appreciating physics more.
Take this class if you're interested in physics and looking for a challenge.

This course is hard but very interesting. If you are thinking of majoring in physics, you should take it. However, do not take it if you are not familiar with multivariable calculus. Professor Meyers is an excellent teacher!
This course is not for anyone with casual interesting in physics; the material is difficult, and requires a lot of interest, and effort outside of class to process.

This is a strong course in E&M. You will learn a ton about the subject, and the special relativity part is very very interesting. But it is rather inefficient if you want to proceed on to upper level classes as soon as possible, since not every nuance in EM will be useful in more advanced classes. You basically only need a general picture.
This is a very good course, but it's not for the faint of heart. If you don't really like physics, I wouldn't recommend it. But if you do, don't take 104 instead.
You definitely can take it without taking 105. You definitely CANNOT take it without knowing multivariable calculus. Take if you are interested in physics and willing to work at it.

highly recommended
try taking it with meyers, he is great
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105..
descrip: This course features the classical theory of electricity and magnetism, with emphasis on the unification of these forces through the special theory of relativity. While the subject matter is similar to that of PHY 104, the treatment is more sophisticated. The topics also include DC and AC circuits and the electromagnetic behavior of matter.

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: Senior standing is required for enrollment in this course..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. A student may propose a topic and find a faculty member willing to supervise the work. Or the student may select a topic from lists of projects obtained from faculty and off-campus industrial researchers, subject to the consent of the faculty advisor.

title: Electronic and Photonic Devices
reviews: An interesting class. I didn't really see where it was going for the first few weeks, but it came together a bit before the midterm and was really interesting after the midterm. The last few lectures on devices are worth the buildup. The labs are very practical and you'll learn a lot of skills for the cleanroom. Make sure to attend the 'optional' precepts, which will be the only way to do the psets if a set of lecture notes isn't introduced next semester.
Attend lectures, participate a lot, and get to know Professor Gmachl!

Claire is a fantastic person, but the lectures are very unorganized. The flipped lectures are good though, but there is not much help available in the class in the sense of much office hours or a good book. But Claire is working on getting a new book or writing notes, and the precepts in the class are pretty decent. Arvind is quite good.

ELE 208 is required for ELE students. However, it is really a relatively enjoyable experience. Professor Gmachl is the nicest person ever and she is so flexible and understanding about everything. Go to lecture, listen, take notes and don't be afraid to ask questions. She gets to know each student and it will only help you if you are engaged. The biggest problem is that the class is very conceptual so if you don't do these things, you can easily fall behind. Problem sets are kind of annoying but exams are very, very fair. I think the class is graded pretty generously so just do your best and you will do well. The labs are awesome and don't really require outside work which is so nice. Go to precepts (especially if they are run by Arvind and Debbie) because they really clarify everything. Overall- recommend: Not too difficult and really informative about how devices work on a atomic level.
Go to office hours. Go to precepts, those were great.
Go to optional precept with Arvind!
Good qualitative intro class to devices
If you enjoy hands on labs, this is an awesome class. However, do expect to spend quite a bit of time on psets.
It's pretty easy to get an A if you do the work. I find the material to be fairly interesting, but others might disagree.
Make sure you understand what happens in lecture (as in, actually go to class). The labs are a lot of fun, and the stuff you learn in lecture actually applies to exactly what you are making.

Overall I'd say the course is fair in regards to the problem sets, labs, and lectures. While it may not be the most structured course out there, it seems like the instructors and TAs are all interested in making the course better so maybe it will be better for you than it was for me. The material is interesting, and would recommend taking if you think you're at all interested in ELE (if you don't mind the relatively high class time commitment).
Precepts are *not* optional, no matter what they say. Ask the TA as many questions as you can so you have all the information required for problem sets.
Take if you are interested. Not too demanding, and Professor Gmachl is one of the best.
Take it if you have any interest in semiconductors. It will be great!
Take it if you want to learn how semiconductor-based devices like LEDs, solar cells, and transistors work, and how to make them. Prof. Gmachl is really nice!
Take it, you'll learn a lot and it's a ton of fun!
The labs are great. Be ready to provide your own structure for the course, since not very much organization is given.
The workload is not too bad and Professor Gmachl and the TAs are wonderful. You really learn WHY you do certain things and come out with a better understanding of devices and device fabrication.
This class is fun if you are interested in the material.
This course is very interesting and at times enjoyable. Make sure you attend every lecture and most of the precepts or you will not know what is going on.
Use the TAs, they know a lot.
interesting course and very fair for an ELE course.
prereqs: PHY104 is a Pre- or Co-requisite. SEAS chemistry, physics, math requirements or equivalent. Elementary knowledge of circuits is helpful. Pass/Fail not available to EE majors..
descrip: Explores ways in which semiconductor devices harness and control electrons and photons to generate, store or transmit information. The basics of semiconductor electronics and photonics are introduced. We look at diodes, transistors, LEDs, solar-cells, and lasers, which form the foundations of integrated circuits, microchips, displays, cameras, etc. Nanotechnology, a recent addition to devices and systems, is introduced. Laboratory: fundamentals of micro and nano fabrication and fabrication of Si integrated circuits, semiconductor light emitters, quantum devices. There will also be optional review and practice sessions.

title: Biomolecular Engineering
descrip: A study of the design and engineering of biomacromolecules. After a brief review of protein and nucleic acid chemistry and structure, course will delve into rational, evolutionary, and computational methods for the design of these molecules. Specific topics to be covered include aptamers, protein and RNA-based switches and sensors, unnatural amino acids and nucleotides, enzyme engineering, and the integration of these parts via synthetic biology efforts.

title: Honors Linear Algebra
reviews: Beware the curve?i.e. the lack thereof. You need to get 93% or above on the mditerm/final/problem sets to get an A in this class.
Challenging but good.  Take it.

Challenging, yet fascinating course! Few students will ever get the opportunity to learn linear algebra in this way, from the mathematical perspective, in a truly rigorous way, deriving everything from scratch so that you understand everything you are doing! Though the course is quite challenging, I loved it, and learned a lot--I highly recommend this for anybody who loves to learn things rigorously, from the ground up, especially a subject which stands above all others in importance in any mathematical, scientific, or engineering field!

Definitely start your problem sets early if possible. They can be very time-consuming and long, but they are important if you want to really understand the material. Do the readings too - the book is very clear.
Definitely take it! At least for Sarnak
Don't fall behind. Start problem sets early. Go to review sessions. Don't miss any lectures.
Don't hesitate to ask questions. Take advantage of Professor Sarnak's nearly endless knowledge and understanding of math and really get to know him...something I hope to in the future.
Find some practical grounding. Can be hard sometimes to deal with linear algebra in only triple indices and everything. And go to office hours and homework sessions always!

If Professor Sarnak is teaching this course, take it by all means! He might be one of the best mathematics lecturers you will ever encounter: smart, funny, puts everything in the right perspective. Take this course rather than 204. Definitely teaches you more about the concepts and the calculations become much more easier once you know the concept.
If you are interesting in taking about a proof-based linear algebra course, this is an appropriate course.  But be prepared to work extremely hard on problem sets and examinations.

If you're at all interested in math, I say take it!

Go to office hours, work collaboratively.
If you're interested in mathematics, it's a very interesting subject and a good course. I recommend it.

If you're thinking of taking this course, realize that this is very different from MAT215 and is on a much different level. While you probably had some sort of intuition for 215 just by virtue of taking AP Calculus, 217 is completely different on the level that it is much, much more abstract and is, of course, an introduction to algebra, which not many high schools teach students. So if you take this class, realize that you will be completely lost when Professor Sarnak talks about winding numbers and dual spaces and double duals, you will suffer through long problem sets that don't seem to make any sense, you will pull a 5-day continuous all-nighter finishing the take-home midterm, you will doubt your own intelligence and your sanity, you will see hell. Yes, you will do all of this. But you will also come back, and you will be a new person, and you will know what isomorphisms and conjugate transposes are, and you will have found a new way of thinking about life, and you will have formed friendships that last a lifetime, and if that does not turn you on, as Professor Sarnak might say, then I don't know what can.

Interesting and useful material, and a fairly manageable workload (esp in comparison to 215). If you don't want to start the psets early, definitely at least identify the hardest problems and get help during the review sessions or office hours. The grading is very fair. Definitely don't miss lecture--you'll need it, and if you have Sarnak then it can be pretty interesting.
Not a big fan of Sarnak teaching it this year, but if he teaches it again, he will have a better idea of what to teach. Obviously you should take this class if you are a math major, though
Only if  you like math.
Take it if you have nothing else ever to do
Take it if you like math
Take it with Sarnak; he's a legend. Linear algebra is slightly more formulaic and less intuitive than analysis.
Take it!
Take it! You'll learn a lot. Go to office hours and take good notes. The UCA review sessions are not very helpful.
Take it.
Take the time to go through lecture notes and the reading to make sure you fully understand all of the details and indices. The details are important.
Wasn't the perfect class, but if you're trying to decide between this and 202 or 204, it's a no brainer: take 217.

Well, well, well...here we are at the end of MAT 217 ready to be transformed (ha!) from the wee MAT 215 children we were. Honestly, the only downside of this course is the book: my attention couldn't span (ha!) the entire chapters assigned. But it didn't matter, because Professor Sarnak (and more importantly, Gauss) were there to save the day. Oof, Sarnak is the best: he not only made all the lectures really fun and interesting, but too did something that I found somewhat surprising: covered the bases (ha) for both the theoretical and practical aspects of the subject. Most math courses seem to disregard the practical aspects, but I found that these were quite important for a first year course, which made Sarnak a very interesting teacher. Thus, the material and lectures were both incredible. As with 215, the problem sets are oftentimes challenging, but rewarding. Working with others through the night is an experience you will definitely have this semester, but one you probably won't regret either. Overall, thus, this course is a great course, especially if you have it with Sarnak, and one you should definitely take!
recommended for sure
descrip: A rigorous course in linear algebra with an emphasis on proof rather than applications. Topics include vector spaces, linear transformations, inner product spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, Jordan form, the spectral theorem for normal transformations, bilinear and quadratic forms.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Political Economy of Education Finance
descrip: Providing primary and secondary education absorbs over 20% of state and local government expenditures in the U.S. The magnitude of spending needs and the large disparities in economic capabilities across school districts create great challenges for financing public education. Financing schools has become an arena for debate not only about education but also about redistribution. Course studies the political, legal, and economic challenges involved in education finance and the diverse ways being attempted to cope with them.

title: Rethinking Truth and Objectivity in History
descrip: See website

title: Topics in Latin American Literature and Ideology - Politics of Memory and Human Rights in Global Latin America
reviews: Ask clarifying questions in class if you don't understand the material.
Definitely take this class if you want to gain a deeper perspective on Latin America's history.
Definitely take. It's unlike any course I've taken at Princeton.
Good class. Be prepared for a fair amount of material/readings but you have a lot of choice in what you write about and can cater to your interests.
If you are at all interested in this topic, TAKE THIS COURSE! Susana is brilliant and there is a lot of reading but the graded work is actually super chill (because Susana is super chill).
Take the class if you're passionate about the subject matter - Draper is a great professor!

Take this course if you want a new way of looking at modern democracy in Latin America. The way in which countries and their people memorialize violent histories has so many bearings on current day society. It can get a little abstract, but Professor Draper is great, and she is very passionate about the material and willing to clarify concepts.
This is an amazing course! Professor Draper is really kind and the material is extremely interesting.
Try to understand the main points of the readings.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course explores recent cultural and artistic productions that deal with human rights and political violence issues in contemporary Latin America, focusing on the politics of memory behind representations of the past in the context of a "global" marketing of memory. By working with literature, testimony, film, photography, truth commissions, and processes of museification, it analyzes different modes of figuring the past as well as the areas that these languages leave aside when memory becomes the target of a "global market" and "trauma tourism."

title: Corporate Finance
descrip: Introduction to corporate finance covering theories and empirical evidence about principal-agent models of firm managerial structure, takeover bids, capital structure, corporate governance; regulation of financial markets; financial markets and institutions with a focus on asymmetric information, transaction costs, or both; dynamic models of market making; and portfolio manager performance evaluation. Pre-requisite: ECO 525.

title: Topics in African American Literature - African American Literature and the Law
descrip: This course will investigate the contours of the troubled and troubling relationship between the law and African American literature. Exploring the archives of both traditions and their canonical texts, we will ask how each informs the other's formal and aesthetic modes. We will map the literary and legal histories of the seminar's primary texts. And finally, we will inquire into the political efficacy of the literature's engagement with the law - how have the texts of the African American literary tradition shaped, and shaped themselves in response to, the law's (in)ability to read the narratives of black Americans?

title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Social Psychology
descrip: Introduction to graduate level social psychology for first year graduate students in psychology. This course will serve as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.

title: Tropical Ecology
reviews: See if you can talk to students that had taken the course in the same location previously and get advice on study design. Ideally you could continue a project that was already started so that you have a good chance of getting a sufficient sample size.
descrip: This course includes an intensive three week field study that takes place during January in a suitable tropical locality. Readings, discussions, and individual projects. The content and location are varied to suit the needs of the participants. Students provide their own travel funds.

title: Topics in Russian Literature or Literary Theory - Tsvetaeva and Pasternak
descrip: This seminar is devoted to poetry and prose of the poets Marina Tsvetaeva and Boris Pasternak, and raises questions about auctorial identity in the context of the culture of the time, emigration, and the soviet state.

title: Politics and the Media - The Political Economy Beat from Twitter to Long-Form Narratives
reviews: Continually revise / edit, and don't be shy about trying it if it's completely new to you.
David Wessel is a winner, so any course with him is bound to be a good one :)
Definitely take a journalism seminar at some point. It is a great way to get insight into the field and opens a up a very practical direction that most people otherwise ignore.
Even if your schedule is filled, find a way to take this class. It's incredible.
If Professor Wessel ever teaches at Princeton again, definitely take a course with him. He is a master of his craft.

Take the class if you are interested in the economy and actually understand it already, but don't take it if you are trying to learn more about the economy or are just interested in a journalism class because then it will be hard and not very interesting. Overall, though, I liked this class and would highly recommend it.

wessel grades on the process not on the end result. i felt frustrated because my end grade was not based on the quality of the work but rather on wessel's feelings consulted enough for the writing process. wessel is the type of professor that needs to feel needed and valued--aka if you don't schedule one-on-ones then you will be penalized. first drafts do matter, despite what wessel says.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http:// humanities.princeton.edu/journalism/courses ..
descrip: This course will focus on the craft of writing clearly and intelligently about the economy, fiscal and monetary policy, living standards and inequality, election campaigns and controversy, reporting vs. analysis vs. opinion. It will emphasize ways to make the complicated simple and the important interesting. An interest in economic issues is a prerequisite; a basic macro-economics course helpful, but not required.

title: Introduction to Latin American Cultures
reviews: Always read.

Do the readings! For the essays choose one small detail that you found interesting and expand on that. Don't try to repeat some idea you discussed in class. She wants to see you develop an argument on your own.
I would suggest taking this course if you are interested in reading literature from all over Latin America and the Caribbean without too much stress.
It's a great class if you want to improve your Spanish and are interested in Latin American culture/history/literature. Prof. Price is helpful and friendly.
Take it.

Take this course if you really want to improve your writing, but your speaking won't get better. Rachel Price is nice and really tries to get the entire class interested and involved. Take it if you want to improve your writing.
This is good course. Take it with Prof. Price. She is really nice and willing to help you.
take it if you're just starting with spanish literature. not very demanding class.
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course offers an introduction to modern Latin American literature and culture. It focuses on the complex ways in which cultural and intellectual production anticipates, participates in, and responds to political, social, and economic transformations in the 20th and 21st centuries. Through a wide spectrum of sources (essays, fiction, poetry, film, and art), students will study and discuss some of the most relevant issues in Latin American modern history, such as modernity, democracy, identity, gender, memory, and social justice.

title: Instrumentation and Performance
descrip: The course is a study of the characteristics of individual instruments, including extended contemporary techniques and writing arrangements for chamber ensemble and for orchestra. Special attention is given to problems of combining voice and instruments. The arrangements written for this class are performed by the Composers' Ensemble at Princeton and the Princeton University Orchestra, and problems of performance involving notation, rehearsal, and conducting are dealt with.

title: Concepts in Early Modern Architecture
descrip: The rediscovery of classical antiquity has been the central narrative of Renaissance art history. This class takes the opposite tack to consider how architects reacted to challenges when antiquity offered no precedents. How have architectural responses to particular conditions shaped the modern world? Beginning in the twelfth century with a special focus on France and Italy, we will explore key problems in the history of architecture, including how new technologies and theoretical shifts affected practice. We will examine a set of institutional types to consider how the absence of historical models prompted experiments in building form.

title: Dynamical Logics in Architecture
reviews: It's a fun class, but also easy to forget about. You end up doing most of it last minute. But its fun, you sit around a table with Jesse (and sometimes Axel) and talk about weird models.
Make sure to prepare enough time working on physical models as they are not easy to be finished in one night. Also be prepared to fail many times on doing tests.
Pick a material / approach and test it in many ways.  A fun exploration.  Remember that design seminars take a lot of time!
descrip: This course is designed as a workshop in architecture derived from material logics. Students will engage in a series of intensive design projects organized around exploring the new implications of the relationship of the part to the whole, force integration, analogue modeling, mass customization, the generic, etc. Ultimately, each project will work through the architectural performance of the complex interplay between material organization, program and form. The primary emphasis of the course will be the development of individual design/research projects, supplemented by background readings.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: The senior thesis is an independent study for individual students. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Students develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Students develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Students submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Introduction to Environmental Engineering
reviews: Definitely attend lectures because they'll help you a lot with the homework. For your final project, you'll have to focus on a pollutant. Pick your pollutant and stick with it, because all of the homeworks will have questions about your pollutant that'll contribute towards your final project.
Definitely start problem sets early.
Definitely take it :)
Don't take it unless you have to.
Fairly easy, just start the final project early.
I would recommend it as a good starting place for studying pollution.
If you are interested in the movement of pollutants and their effect on the environment/health, this is a good class to take.
It provides a good technical foundation for environmental thinking!
Make sure you understand the week to week topics because they do vary and after one problem set you are moving on to the next topic.
Pay attention during lecture!! Especially when the professor is solving out example problems. I don't know who is teaching the course next year, though, so the structure may be different.
Peters isn't teaching it anymore, so hard to say but for an engineering course, the material is pretty straightforward.

Peters won't be teaching this next year, so I don't know how the class will change, but this semester I found it was a lot like a high school class. If you do all the work and reading (which is manageable), it should be an easy course. The topics are interesting and relevant to modern problems.
Stay on top of the work in this class and go to office hours if you can. Don't leave the final paper to the last minute - it is much longer and more challenging than it seems.
Such an awesome understanding of environmental modeling coming out of the course-do take it! Sadly you won't have CAP who is the bomb.

What a disappointing introduction to the CEE department!!!!!! If you're in the environmental track, this class is IT: intro to environmental engineering, taught by the dep rep, first real env. eng class, but man did this class fall flat. Lectures were tedious and sleep-inducing, instruction was haphazard and unreliable, assignment submission on blackboard was unnecessarily annoying, and exam curves were downright dreadful. Also felt like students were for the most part left to fend for themselves - trying to stay afloat in the polluted waters that they're taught to analyze. Mark my word and STAY AWAY. That said, new prof will be teaching it next time so it'll be a crapshoot. Peace.
Would not take unless departmental
prereqs: CHM 201 and MAT 104 (can be taken concurrently), or permission of the instructor.
descrip: The course introduces the basic chemical and physical processes of relevance in environmental engineering. Mass and energy balance and transport concepts are introduced and the chemical principles governing reaction kinetics and phase partitioning are presented. We then turn our focus to the applications in environmental engineering problems related to water and air pollution.

title: Readings in American History: World War I to the Present
reviews: A textbook knowledge of 20th-century American history is strongly recommended. Reading is heavy and challenging, but always reasonable. Be prepared, however, that this is more than just a readings course. You will be challenged to think critically and to work through your own narratives of the period. I could not recommend the course more strongly. It also worked well as a companion seminar to a generals field in the subject.

I highly recommend it to Americanists of all eras, but also to anybody interested in thinking about issues of pedagogy in academia. I also recommend it to anybody doing 20th century (non-USA) history, given quite how important the USA has been as an historical force right across the world in the last century.

I highly recommend taking a seminar with Professor Canaday. She is always kind and thoughtful, without sacrificing academic rigor. In my opinion, she is the ideal professor. 

In approaching the 'readings' course Canaday prefers to dive into individual books rather than sweeping across the century and covering everything, which some other professors prefer. While you might not come out of the course an expert on everything twentieth century America, you will come out with a deeper appreciation for current historical scholarship on the field.
If you are at all interested in the area of study, you absolutely should, Professor Canaday will provide an amazing introduction to the major themes of the field. You won't regret it.
Superb.
Yes, absolutely. Essentially any course with Prof. Canaday.
descrip: Fourth in a sequence of core courses in United States history, this course is designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to the literature and problems of American history since World War I.

title: Introduction to Jewish Cultures
reviews: At least watch the movies, they are really cool!
Go to lecture, do the readings.

I think the course was good for Jewish and non-Jewish students, because for Jewish students they could compare their own experiences with the subject matter and non-Jewish students got a broad sense and introduction to Jewish cultures. The course is obviously very broad and sometimes focuses on more specific subjects such as Jews in Baghdad because it is impossible to cover everything, but I thought it was done well. Professor Levy is interesting and leads good discussions, and I thought the readings were well picked.
I would tell them to make sure to read the materials before every class because you really only get knowledge out of the lecture class or the precept if you prepared the materials for the week.
It is a good survey of Jewish culture across different times and places.

Take it! Go to class. Watch all the movies. Skim the readings you don't really like, do the ones that look intriguing. You'll have plenty to talk about in precept. Even though I'm a Jew, I definitely feel that I learned a great deal in this class and it's definitely been one of my favorite classes at Princeton so far.
The content of the course is interesting, the structure and format of the course make it hard to appreciate that though. You get as much out of it as you put in.

This is a great class full of interesting readings and fun topics. It's a fantastic way to learn about Jewish cultures through history and into the present. Workload is very manageable and papers are not graded so harshly. Lectures can be a little dull.
descrip: This introductory course focuses on the cultural syncretism and the global diversity of Jewish experience. It provides a comparative understanding of Jewish culture from antiquity to the present, examining how Jewish culture has emerged through the interaction of Jews and non-Jews, engaging a wide spectrum of cultures throughout the Jewish world, and following representations of key issues such as sexuality or the existence of God in different eras.
