The course's interdisciplinary approach covers Bible and Talmud, Jewish mysticism, Zionism, Jewish cinema, music, food, modern literature, and graphic arts. All readings and films are in English.

title: Biology of Coral Reefs
reviews: Amazing course. Well taught, tons of marine field work, and really allows you to understand the nature of working in the water and collecting data. Definitely a must-take if you are interested in a semester abroad and if you are interested at all in marine biology.
Be so excited about this course.  It is incredible.
Best course for EEB Panama Study Abroad!
My favorite class in Panama. You will see some amazing fish in the water as well as learning about the fascinating structure of reefs. Coiba and Bocas del Toro are beautiful.
Start working on the Bocas paper early - you don't have much time to write it up! During your first few days at Bocas, try to pilot your methods in the field.
This course is incredible! It's a lot of physical work, being in the water for ~4 hours every day, but so much fun.

This is one of my favorite courses in the program. Maria is an amazing professor as well as researcher; she's also very relatable, so ask questions! She knows so much and can still relate to students, so her explanations  make so much sense to us. Advice: buy a full-body rash guard. You don't need a wet suit; most of the time you won't be in cold water. Make sure your flippers fit perfectly and the mask works because it's going to be miserable if your equipment isn't sufficient. Enjoy the time away from wifi, enjoy the water, the sun, and marvel at the amazing world under the water.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: This field and lecture course provides an in-depth introduction to the biology of tropical coral reefs, with an emphasis on reef fish ecology and behavior. Each day begins with a lecture, followed by six to eight hours on the water, and ends with data analysis, reading and a discussion of recent papers. Students learn to identify fishes, corals and invertebrates, and learn a variety of field methods including underwater censusing, mapping, videotaping and the recording of inter-individual interactions. Each year group projects will vary depending on previous findings and the interests of the faculty.

title: Special Topics in Computer Science - Information Technology, Law and Policy
descrip: This course presents an overview of the key regulatory and policy challenges that information technology and the Internet pose for society. The course will explore the technologies, actors and law that frame online activities. The course will address various methods of regulating the Internet, territorial jurisdiction, network management, privacy, intellectual property, and intermediary liability. The course will emphasize the interdependence of legal and technological rule-making and will conclude with a look toward the future of the Internet from the perspective of law.

title: The Artist at Work
reviews: Definitely take this course if you're at all interested in contemporary art or art history. Wonderful use of my time.
Do the readings and be prepared for in class dicsussion.
Have a background in Art History.
If you are serious about contemporary art and enjoy being challenged to think critically and carefully about it, take the class!
Make the most of the trips! Ask the artist and listen to what they say, the trips are really unique opportunities to engage with inspiring people in the industry.
Take it.

Yes, absolutely I would. I took this class on a friend's recommendation and have absolutely fallen in love with the material. The studio visits were truly inspiring. I hope that this course continues for many years--now I feel keenly aware of how the conditions of the production of an artwork (or a piece of literature) inform not only the work but also the ways in which the work is received. Production inflects reception directly. This class has been truly eye-opening.

You need to take an art history class prior, and probably one of Irene Small's. You are expected to know how to interact with objects. But also take advantage of the amazing visits that you get the chance to go on!
descrip: What are the environments, fictions, fantasies, and ideologies that condition the artist at work? This course takes as its investigative locus the artist's studio, a space of experimentation and inspiration, but also of boredom, sociability, exhaustion, and critique. Structured around visits to the studios of multiple practicing artists in New York City, the course tracks the trope of "the studio" from the Renaissance to the present, with emphasis on the concept's reconfiguration and reanimation in contemporary art. Lecture with discussion and field trips.

title: Directed Research
descrip: During the third semester, each student writes a research paper under the direction of a faculty member.

title: Reading Race and Gender as Publishing Praxis
descrip: In this interdisciplinary class, students of race and gender read deeply and broadly in academic journals as a way of learning the debates in their fields and placing their scholarship in relationship to them. Students report each week on the trends in the last five years of any journal of their choice, writing up the articles' arguments and debates, while also revising a paper in relationship to those debates and preparing it for publication. This course enables students to leap forward in their scholarly writing through a better understanding of their fields and the significance of their work to them.

title: Sustainable Development in Practice
reviews: Ask a lot of clarifying questions.
Could be a good class IF IT WAS TAUGHT BY A PRINCETON/COLUMBIA PROFESSOR!!!
Do not take this course. This course has to be seriously revamped before it is offered again.
prereqs: EEB 321. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: This course studies the theory and practical application of sustainable development in East Africa. Students learn about the administrative and sociopolitical structures of Kenya, history of the United Nation's Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and the agriculture, education, infrastructure, water, and health issues in urban and rural areas. Discussion with communities, field work, practical problem solving, GIS tools, e-tools, modeling, and understanding local constraints form the foundation for this course.

title: Microeconomics Theory Workshop
reviews: Attend the seminars if you are interested in theory.
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Creating the Universe: Buddhist Science, Ritual, and Art
reviews: A student shouldn't take this seminar unless they have some prior knowledge of the basics of Buddhism.
Hard, but if you're interested in the material this is a good course.
I learned very little about Buddhism in this course and having such a negative experience with Professor Huntington has turned me off from wanting to learn more. Do not take it.
Take this class! You will learn a lot and have a lot of fun!
descrip: Much of Buddhist art can usefully be thought of as ritual technology-physical pieces that, when arranged systematically, make a given ritual effective. This class is about the Buddhist scientific perspectives underlying the production of such visual art in Tibet, Nepal, and India. The course is organized around cosmological and biological topics such as physical models of the universe, the types of beings that dwell in the world, and the cycles of life and death. Within these topics, we will investigate the relationships between sacred texts, ritual practices, and visual arts as the material culture of religion.

title: Systematic Ethics
reviews: Great introductory philosophy and ethics course. Really taught me to think critically and I really appreciated the breadth of topics covered.

Great way to fulfill an EM. This class is relatively easy - although it has a lot of readings, listening in class is enough to get back. Would still recommend doing readings - they will make you challenge your preconceived notions about morality.
If Professor Harman is teaching it, I'd advise against unless you're very interested in the material.
It's not great, but you'll get a great background in moral philosophy if you do the readings diligently. You don't really need to go to lecture.
Prof Harman's lecture is realy boring, but precept with Adam Lerner is definitely worth going!
Read carefully and take detailed notes.
Take it for the material, and try to get a grad student for precept, because Harman isn't great.
Take it if you're interested in the material.

There is not a lot of work involved in the course and it is an interesting survey of ethical issues. However, do not take it if Professor Harman is teaching the course. Do not miss it if Adam Lerner is teaching it.
This class may not require as much work as other classes, but can be meaningful if you really do the reading on your own and contribute in precept.
n/a
descrip: A survey of major issues about the nature of morality. Two lectures and one precept per week.

title: The New Testament and Christian Origins
reviews: Decently interesting, but didn't always hold my attention. The class was really unstructured, and it wasn't always clear what was expected. It definitely made me question the foundations of Christianity and other religions and gave me basic knowledge. Wouldn't recommend.

I loved this class not because it was easy, but because the material was enlightening.  This was the first class that pushed me to talk with other students outside of class about the material.  It was also the first class I have taken that made me want to continue studying the material after the course ended.

If Gager is teaching this class again TAKE IT. You will not regret it. Also try to be in his precept, as it is so interesting and a lot of fun! He is a fantastic professor and a great guy to get to know.
If you have time for a heavy reading load, go for it! Expect a survey of historical theories of ancient Christianity more than a rigorous engagement with primary source material.
Interesting introduction to the New Testament. Don't do all of the reading.
It is a good fourth or fifth class that is easy to manage.

TAKE THIS CLASS (especially if Gager ever teaches it again). If you have an interest in religion (especially Christianity) and if you are a Christian, this is a must-take to help challenge and expand your faith and really understand the roots of Christianity. A wonderful PDF and option for engineers who need an HA. Does not take much time.
Take this class, especially if you can snag Gager. He is great, and the class, while not a lot of work, was incredibly interesting.

Take this course! Approach it with an open mind. Regardless of your religious creed, this course will challenge your beliefs and assumptions about Jesus, the New Testament, and Christianity. But you'll finish it wish such a wealth of knowledge you'll actually know what you're talking about!

This is an excellent HA to have.  Some experience with the bible is assumed.  But Gager is an engaging lecturer, and you'd be surprised how interesting the New Testament is.  Also, it's not going to kill you with work.
descrip: To trace the origins of Christianity from its beginnings as a movement within ancient Judaism to its gradual transformation and emergence as an independent religious movement in the Roman Empire and beyond. To read the New Testament with a critical eye, i.e., as a collection of documents illustrating differing emphases and stages in the growth of early Christianity.

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences
descrip: This course cover fundamental papers on the Geosciences of Iceland. Topics include deep mantle plumes and spreading, basaltic volcanism, volcanic aerosols, seismicity, geothermal power, microbial ecology of hot springs, glacial geology, and the impact of global warming on Arctic permafrost stability and greenhouse gas release. Weekly meetings include presentations on these topics among others by students as preparation for a 10 day field trip to Iceland during the summer. Participation in the field trip includes student on site presentations.

title: Inequality, Mobility, and the American Dream
reviews: A solid course. Readings are interesting, Professor Lawrence's lectures are good. It's a great introduction to economic and sociological views of inequality and mobility.
Do the journal entries early so after the midterm you can focus solely on your final paper.
Do the readings and attend the lectures
Do the readings.

I highly suggest taking this. Professor Lawrence does a great job of lecturing and I left each lecture and precept feeling like I'd learned something fantastic. Worth it if you have a general interest in the area.

I thought this was a great class if you want to learn what the current literature is on inequality and social mobility. You go over what these terms mean and how sociologists (and sometimes economists) measure these two ideas and the correlation between them. The class was a bit more quantitative than I thought it would be, but Prof. Lawrence focuses more on the ideas rather than the equations. He knew almost everyone in the class by name (30-40 person lecture) and is very interested in what everyone has to say.

If you're interested in the technical, research side of inequality and mobility, then take this course. If you wanted a class that had readings that were more personal and engaging, then this would not be the class.
It's light workload and relevant. Professor is good.
Prof. Lawrence is the coolest dude alive. Take this class/any of his classes if you get a chance!

Prof. Lawrence won't be here next year so I don't know who will be teaching it - I mostly took it because he was teaching it.  But the material is incredibly relevant to American society today so it is still worth taking.
Take this class with Matthew Lawrence. Try and get into his precept if possible.
Take this class with Professor Lawrence!

Take this course.  The topics it covers are extremely important and thought-provoking.  Even if you are not interested in sociology or know nothing about it, you will find that the course is relatively easy, especially the second half of the semester.
descrip: This course is an introduction to the sociological study of how income and wealth structure opportunities within and across generations. We will discuss research about two distinct topics that are often conflated: economic inequality and social mobility. We will consider associations between these measures, how each has changed over time, and how the US compares to other countries. We will also explore challenges of producing research about these topics. Students will learn to become critical consumers of academic research, public commentary, and social policies related to these subjects.

title: Practice Teaching
reviews: Student teaching is inevitably challenging and very time consuming (you really don't have time for anything else).  TPP does an excellent job supporting you in the classroom and makes this the best experience you could possibly have. If you are considering teaching at all, please do it through TPP!  You get so much individual attention, support, and a wonderful set of resources.
prereqs: Admission to the Teacher Preparation Program is usually required. Application for fieldwork placement must be made in advance. Completion of Pre-professional portfolio..
descrip: Supervised practice teaching (a minimum of 12 weeks) in a secondary school. Teaching is done under the supervision of an accomplished teacher and a program staff member who regularly observe and discuss the student's practice teaching. Students gain firsthand experience in developing teaching strategies, planning and implementing instruction, assessing student learning, and classroom management. Must be taken concurrently with TPP 401.

title: Studies in Later Persian Literature 1200 - 1800 A.D.
descrip: Course acquaints students with the literature of the second great classical language of Islam and its legacy of epics, chronicles, lyric poems, mystical writings and imaginative tales from the traditional Persian-speaking world - including not only from present-day Iran, Afghanistan and Tajikistan but also from Anatolia, Central Asia and the Indian sub-continent. Continuation of NES 539. Treats the literature from 1200 to 1800.

title: Eighteen Sixty-Eight: Telling Japan's Modern Revolution
descrip: Students will strive to interpret primary documents of the period as well as various narratives of the Meiji Restoration produced throughout the twentieth century. Four different themes will be woven together: 1) the reconstruction of the event of 1868 through primary documents and secondary studies; 2) the reconstruction of the history of the interpretations of 1868 in modern Japan; 3) the analysis of one of the most influential retellings of 1868, Shimazaki T?son?s Yoake mae (in the English translation by William F. Naff); and 4) a meditation on narrative, memory and fiction in the production of historical knowledge.

title: Senior Independent Work
descrip: A one semester study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written report required.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced French
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of work! Learning a language is never easy and covering this much ground in a single semester can be overwhelming at times. But this class is definitely worth it.
I first expected this class to be a lot of work, but it turned out to be really manageable and fun. Take it!
It is a lot of work, but very doable with Rachel. She's always willing to stop and slow down or compromise to make sure you understand.
It is not as scary as your FRE 101 teacher or your interviewer may have implied.  I most likely would have preferred it to 102.

It should be emphasized that this class is meant for those who seriously wish to pursue French as a concentration. Yet because this wasn't the case for me, it is still alright to take this course with the intention of learning more about French and developing / sharpening your language skills. However, there is a lot of material, so be careful in keeping up!
Make sure you pay attention in class because that will go a long way.

Stay on top of the grammar, and make hand-written study guides for the tests - they help your muscle memory remember writing certain words certain ways, and they are super helpful when prepping for the final. Also, when doing readings for homework, take your time and read them out loud, slowly, so that you practice pronouncing words that can be more challenging.
Strongly recommend it!
Take it. It is not as hard as it is advertised. Very, very fun and rewarding.
Take it. The workload isn't significantly more than 102 but as long as you keep up with what you are assigned your progression will be much better.

The material is very extensive so the class is helpful for people who want to excel in a language at a quick pace. A lot of the readings and movies were boring and seemed unnecessary. The class covers a lot of material, so it is is easy to fall behind. However, the professor was great with meeting with students who were struggling.

This is a great course for people who want to make progress in French quickly and are willing to stay dedicated to their work. The work load is a bit intense, but it's worth it and professor Hart  is an amazing teacher.
take the class if you hope to improve it fast
prereqs: FRE 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: FRE 102-7 is an intensive double course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Focus will be on reading and listening comprehension, oral proficiency, grammatical accuracy, and the development of reading and writing skills. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be introduced to various Francophone cultures through readings, videos and films.

title: International Relations
reviews: Be prepared to put a lot of work into class. It is really interesting though!
Be ready.
Be wary - lots of readings and dense information. Only take it if you are truly interested in politics or economics
Definitely take this class!!! It was so interesting, but it was a lot of work. I would recommend taking it freshman or sophomore year because it's a bit hard to do with independent work.
Do some of the readings. You don't have to do them all but its good to do some. Also watching the videos is actually very beneficial. I would do that over the readings. Study key terms for the final.

Do the readings
Prepare for the simulations - they provide a great learning environment
Do the readings and try to be engaged in the material. You can take a lot out of this course!

Do the readings! Seriously. 

Don't miss lecture.

Don't go in expecting an A. The assignments are tough and you have to go in knowing that there's a strong possibility of getting a B. But you learn so much that the hit to your GPA is worth it.

Don't take as a fifth course
Best if you come into the class already with knowledge of European history 1800s onwards

I would advise someone considering this class to be ready for a lot of reading and a decently large workload.  However, even though this class was a lot of work, I would highly encourage them to take it.
Keep up with all readings, be active in precept and don't be afraid to speak up, and go over all lecture notes often!
Make study groups to split up readings and discuss course material! Talk with preceptor! Talking is way more efficient than reading on your own.
Make sure to do the readings and engage in active participation.
One of my favorite courses at Princeton so far. I would highly recommend, especially if you're a Politics major. Moravcsik is very knowledgeable.
Take it if interested in IR.
Take it if you are interested in politics.

Take it if you're in for a challenge and like/want to learn about politics and international affairs. This will be your "hard" course for the semester. Actually do the readings. You need to know all of them.
Take it. There are a lot of readings-- form a study group. But you'll learn a lot, especially if Moravcsik is teaching it.
Take it. You'll learn a lot about history and economics along with the material itself, which is super interesting.
Take this class if you want to do anything regarding foreign affairs. As Professor Moravcsik said, "Policy needs theory." It is a solid foundation for a future in international politics.

Take this course for an awesome intro to international relations! Take good lecture notes and pay attention to the points Moravcsik emphasizes. Do the readings before lecture to get a much better grasp on them, and it might be useful to split them with classmates.
The hardest course I've taken here so far in terms of reading and expectations for the midterm/final, but very interesting nevertheless.
This class is a lot of work. Be prepared to do a lot of reading and put in work to develop a firm grasp of concepts but overall the class is worth the work

This class is an enormous time commitment and by far the most difficult 200 level class I've taken, but incredibly worth it if you are interested in IR. It provides very clear and in-depth overviews of major IR theories, history, and politics, as well as current policies, and teaches you to analyze them well from a multi-disciplinary and multi-theoretical approach.

This course is very heavy with policy and theory.  It is not what I expected in an IR course, but it is a good indication of what majoring in WWS would comprise.  Also, no one told me when I signed up for the course that there are simulations in precept? WWII simulations, trials, etc.  Just a heads up.

This course is very interesting and informative but it is a TON of work. Know that you will be reading at least 200 pages per week and often preparing for in-class simulations. If you are really interested in the topic that's fine but if you're not it's way too much work to be worth it.
Tough class with lots of reading but worth it.
Very very difficult, but you learn a lot
do your readings on time! Don't procrastinate!
descrip: This course is an introduction to the causes and nature of international conflict and cooperation. We critically examine various theories of international politics by drawing on examples drawn from international security, economic and legal affairs across different historical eras from 10,000 BC to the present. Topics include the causes of war, the pursuit of economic prosperity, the sources of international order and its breakdown, and the rise of challenges to national sovereignty, and such contemporary issues as international environmental politics, human rights promotion, global terrorism, and the future of US foreign policy.

title: Russian Folklore
descrip: Explores Russian oral traditions and oral literary genres in English translation: Traditional life-cycle and seasonal rituals and songs associated with them; superstitions, charms, oral narrative poetry (byliny) and prose (skazki); chastushki, jokes; present-day popular culture; and relationships between folklore and literature. Focus on the role and meaning of Russian folklore as expressive culture and how it informs contemporary society.

title: Princeton Atelier - Performing Environmental Stories
reviews: Do the readings because they're very interesting! Have fun and be creative.
I don't think it is offered again, but if it ever was, don't miss out!
If it is offered again, definitely take it! Prepare to be actively engaged and creative.

If this class is ever offered again, I would suggest it be either a little more like an academic art history course, or more swayed towards performance. The mix didn't seem to settle that well, and our final project did not seem to reflect much of what we had learned earlier in the semester. I appreciate the idea to do a cross-disciplinary course, but I think it could have been a little better thought through.

In its current state, I'm extremely disappointed to say that I think that this class causes more stress than benefit. I would advise looking elsewhere to find your inspiration for combining art and nature.
Take an Atelier course.
This is an atelier, so I don't expect it to be taught again.  I do encourage people to take classes that merge environmentalism and the humanities like this one.
prereqs: This Atelier is open to all students from all disciplines with interests in environmental issues, performance art, public communication, collaborative work and/or media strategies. Students interested in social activism central to art works that cross into public spheres are encouraged to apply. Brief application required. See the Atelier webpage: http://arts.princeton.edu/academics/atelier/atelier-courses/.
descrip: The term "social practice" refers to an increasingly popular form of public art that takes a participatory and often lighthearted approach to urgent social and political issues. In this Atelier, we will create an eco-corps that focuses on environmental issues. Students will design interactive projects--for example, tours, games, hoe-downs, dances, podcasts, installations--that encourage the audience to experience, perform, and reimagine environmental problems and solutions.

title: Special Studies in the 18th Century - Jane Austen and the English Novel
descrip: In many histories of the English Novel, Jane Austen's work is what the novel rises to (Watt) or begins from (Leavis), in short the epitome of the English novel itself. By situating Austen's work within that of her predecessors and successors, we will ponder Austen's pivotal place both in the history of the novel and in the history of how the novel thinks about Englishness.

title: Politics of Inequality and Redistribution (Half-Term)
descrip: Study of policy preferences, differential rates of political participation, voting behavior, legislative process, political communication, urban politics and role of race in US political life are central to study of inequality in politics. Though the American case will feature prominently, we will approach issues from a comparative perspective. Thus the course provides introduction to comparative study of welfare states and political economy of advanced industrial countries, including regulation of labor markets and relationship between wage inequality, income distribution and policy preferences for redistribution and social protection.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew
descrip: Students will achieve a basic ability to read the Hebrew Bible/Old Testamtent in its original language. During the semester, students will study the grammar and develop their vocabulary. Upon completing the grammar textbook, students will read large passages from the Bible from all genres.

title: Advanced Topics in Fluid Mechanics I - Advanced Turbulence
prereqs: This course is a second course in turbulence and presumes that the student has considerable familiarity with the subject. Completion of an Introductory Turbulence course should meet this requirement..
descrip: Focus is on advanced concepts in turbulence, especially relating to turbulence at different scales of motion and in both statistically stationary and non-stationary situations. Emphasis is on homogeneous turbulent flows, with particular attention to the spectral equations of motion. Classical theories of turbulence, especially similarity laws, receive considerable attention and critiqued in light of recent research. Statistical methods are discussed in some detail with particular attention to POD and spectral analysis.

title: Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Extramural Teaching Internship
descrip: One-term teaching internship at a host institution to perform teaching directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports are required. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: Race Is Socially Constructed: Now What?
reviews: ABSOLUTELY TAKE IT.  Don't think twice.  You will get so much out of this class and will be eager to go to lecture, it's that good.
Be prepared to learn a lot of new sociological concepts... take notes of them as you learn them -- your strength of analysis is cumulative!
DO IT. This is probably the best course you will ever take at Princeton. Try your hardest to get Professor Benjamin as your preceptor.
Definitely take it! It is one of the best courses I have taken here at Princeton. I took it out of general interest, and I think I got a lot more out of it than I thought I would.
Definitely take this course! It changed my perspective on Princeton and society more broadly.

Definitely take this course! It was my favorite course I've taken at Princeton thus far and it would not be too dramatic to say that my life perspective has been forever changed. I would recommend anyone to take this course- It is definitely manageable with no Sociology/race studies background and you definitely won't regret it. Prof B is an incredible professor who not only cares deeply about her students but about society.
Do all the readings. Every example helps.
Do it. Dive into this class and be open to having your mind blown.

Do not take Patricia Fernandez Kelly's Race and Ethnicity class (SOC 227). That class is horrible, and the department should stop offering. it. This course is far more nuanced, expectations are clearer, the course material is more engaging, and the teaching team is better. The earlier you take this course the better for you will be exposed to information that most students don't learn until their junior and senior years in upper level courses and you will have the opportunity to develop a relationship with an amazing professor.
Great course. Very straight-forward and you will learn a lot. I encourage you to take this course!
Have an open mind. Stay engaged. Ask questions. Enjoy!

I can look back and point to this class as one of my favorite parts of my week.  Not only was I interested in the topic of race, but I was also excited to learn, to think, and to engage in meaningful and relevant dialogue.  This class challenged me to ask question and to truly understand and apply the concepts relevant to the course topics.  
TAKE THIS CLASS, YOU WON'T REGRET IT!
I would advise that students start their final papers early. I did so and it really helped when it came to thinking through some of the difficulties I ran into with it.
I would highly recommend this class!

I would tell them to most definitely take the course because you will not forget it. Ruha Benjamin is one of those professors that you have to take a class with at Princeton. Do the readings and stay up to date with the class concepts because we do have pop quizzes from time to time. If you put time and effort into this course, you will get so much out of it!
If you do not take this course or at least one course with Prof. B., you are doing yourself an injustice.
It is a wonderful and fair course with amazing teachers - take it
Not too hard, engaging, important material.
Please take this course. The world needs you to take this course. It will change your life.
Read as much as you can.

Read the material. Even if it seems that the class covers basic elements of race (and that you don't need a book to tell you about race), read the material anyway because you'll learn a lot and will probably pick up useful information. Pay attention in lecture and go to precept. Also, go to office hours. I wish I had gone more but I know that Professor Benjamin and the preceptors are extremely accommodating and willing to answer questions.
Read the readings as they are assigned. Pop quizzes are very specific, so if you don't read, it's hard to pass.

Read the textbook!  Takes a little more time each week than expected to do a close readings but totally worth it!  You will take away so much from this class (although admittedly the quizzes don't really test this) if you put in the time with the textbook and are constantly participating in precept and listening/engaging in lectures.
TAKE IT. Ruha Benjamin is a god. Everyone should take this class.

TAKE IT. TAKE IT. TAKE IT.

This course should be a requirement for all students to take while at Princeton

TAKE THIS COURSE! One of the best classes I've had the opportunity to take at Princeton, this was the kind of learning experience I thought I'd be having as a college student. This is really not just a class where you learn information, it is an experience during which you are taught WHY you think the way you do and HOW to think. A truly eye-opening, life-changing class whether or not you think race is a relevant part of your life.

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! The material is relevant and super interesting, especially when you think about the current state of race relations in America. Professor Benjamin is a tremendous asset to Princeton, and I think every student should take this class if they had the opportunity. Although there is a lot of reading, and weekly Blackboard posts can get a bit tedious, the work is really not that bad, especially for getting an SA out of the way. The material is challenging but in a fun way, and you will look forward to every minute you spend in lecture and precept!

TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Benjamin is the BOMB DOT COM. Professor Benjamin is a powerful lecturer and you can tell that this class is more than just a class to her because of the relevance of the topics discussed in class to real-world events. This class gave me the words and thus the voice to discuss racial inequality in a way that I hadn't been able to do previously. I will be forever indebted to Professor Benjamin for endowing me with the knowledge and the tools to change the racial landscape within American society. I would highly recommend this course to anyone looking for an interesting SA to take or anyone looking to find a new perspective in life.

TAKE THIS COURSE. This is so far my favorite class from Princeton, and Professor Benjamin is so amazing. It will make you think and learn about many important matters. This course is important. Take it.
Take it no matter what major you are! It's not a super challenging course, and the issues are so relevant it's hard not to find all of the work intriguing and beneficial to do.

Take it! Professor B is a good lecturer, and you will learn a fair amount for not very much work. Beware, however, if you have a lot of background in race issues or sociology, because it is relatively introductory.
Take it.
Take it.  I'm an engineer and loved it
Take this class if you have interest. It is not too difficult, extremely engaging and the final paper is not stressful to complete at all.
Take this class or really anything with Ruha Benjamin. She is intellectually stimulating and an overall BA.

Take this class! It is a side to the story of race in America that you won't often hear but is very true and affecting our realities daily.Literally Prof B is so passionate and so socially conscious that you walk out not only more educated, but a better person.

Take this class!!! Prof B is amazing, the preceptors are carefully chosen, and all students are generally more engaged than I've seen in other classes. Quizzes are easy if you do the reading. Everyone should have to take a race class when in college, and this is a great option.

Take this course!!! The experience of listening to Ruha twice a week alone is worth your enrolling in this class.  The readings are pretty manageable and always interesting, and you'll walk away with a deeper understanding of the way our world works.  Many of the things you learn about will be discouraging, but they're important to understand and Ruha prepares you to take on a more activist role once you leave the classroom.  Don't be scared away by the pop quizzes (they're very manageable) and commit to the course; you won't regret it.

Take this course!!! This course was the most important one I took during the year, and I would not be surprised if it is the most important course I take during my four years at Princeton. Prof. B. is a wonderful professor -- she is smart and cares deeply about what she is teaching and for her students. She always pushes us to stretch our minds and think more critically. I have learned so much about race and racism in America, a topic that is so important for understanding U.S. history and society today. The key part of the course is the "now what" and it is so helpful to think about how we can change the state of race relations in the U.S. and combat the racism that exists in today's institutions. Take this course -- you will learn about how race affects every aspect of life from education to the criminal justice system to intimate life (relationships, families, etc.). Also, don't let the idea of pop quizzes scare you away! They are not very difficult as long as you do the reading.
Take this course, please.
Take this course, you will learn more about yourself and American history than you ever have before.
The information taught in this course is essential for everyone to know! Prof Benjamin is extremely engaging and most readings were extremely interesting.
Yes, take this class or any other class with Professor Benjamin.
descrip: The truism that "race is socially constructed" hides more than it reveals. Have Irish Americans always been white? Are people of African descent all black? Is calling Asian Americans a "model minority" a compliment? Does race impact who we date or marry? In this course, students develop a sophisticated conceptual toolkit to make sense of such contentious cases of racial vision and division as the uprising in Ferguson. We learn to connect contemporary events to historical processes, and individual experiences to institutional policies, exercising a sociological imagination with the potential to not only analyze, but transform the status quo.

title: Mythmakers, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: American Revolutions
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Tonal Syntax
reviews: Listen to/play Bach
Take it
Take it ? wait a year though, because Dan is going on sabbatical!
This course is challenging, but very rewarding.
prereqs: MUS 205 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: MUS 206 begins by making relevant connections between the modal counterpoint of the 16th century (studied in MUS 205) and tonality as it evolved in the 18th century. Fundamental tonal concepts will then be explored in later music including Chopin and Brahms.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: The Culture of Art Deco: Paris, 1920-1939
reviews: An amazing class about Art Deco!
Beautiful objects, an exciting time period, and a passionate professor: very good.

I highly recommend this course to anyone interested in French history, printmaking, and sociocultural studies, in addition to all the disciplines to which the course belongs as per its course distribution.
If it's still student-led, it will be an alright experience at best. Professor da Costa Meyer is amazing though so it's OK
If you enjoy art deco design and are interested in being challenged to develop a truly needed scholarly literature, take this class!
definitely take it
yes
descrip: This seminar covers the emergence of Art Deco in Paris between the wars and its connection to the visual arts, architecture, film, and fashion. We will analyze the ways in which its sophisticated forms and materials responded to new conditions of urban living, the mobility of modern life through speed and travel, the rise of the film industry as a mass medium, and the appearance of women as producers of decorative art. Special emphasis will be given to the multiple and conflicting concepts of the modern object in an age that both embraced and rejected mass production.

title: Ghosts, Vampires, and Zombies in Irish Literature and Theatre
descrip: See website

title: Topics of Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Climate Change: Science and Policy
descrip: Designed to improve students' skill, confidence and judgment in use of science in policy applications. Using case studies, real-world examples, and in-class exercises, in the areas of atmospheric and energy policy, the emphasis is on preparing both non-scientists and scientists to use, understand, and critique science in environmental policy applications. Exercises are scaled to the student's background.

title: Japan Anthropology in Historical Perspective
descrip: The course considers Japan studies in the context of theories of capitalism, personhood, democracy, gender, and modernity. We will be discussing issues of fieldwork as method and "area" as a unit of analysis. We will also consider the place of Japan in American social thought.

title: Portfolio Theory and Asset Management
reviews: A good course to learn more about different approaches to investing beyond the usual CAPM taught in other courses.
Attend lecture
Class is fairly easy.
It is a good class if you are interested in the topic but it is not challenging.
Strongly recommend.
Study the practice midterm/final carefully.
Very easy
Very good class for an intro to portfolio management theory
Very good.
Way too easy course, don't really learn anything
very useful course
prereqs: FIN 501 and FIN 522..
descrip: Covers a number of advanced topics related to asset management and asset pricing. Topics include mean-variance analysis, CAPM, APT, market efficiency, delegated money management, stock return predictability, bubbles and crashes, social interaction and investor behavior, security analysts and investor relations, and mutual fund performance and organization.

title: Computational Methods in Plasma Physics
reviews: Be prepared for more theoretical background and less applicable examples
Depends who is teaching and how interested you are in material.
More heavy on the algorithm side and less on the actual coding.
This is a good class to take.
Work out your own examples from class, and try to implement them in your own programming for practice.
prereqs: Graduate students and seniors only..
descrip: Analysis of methods for the numerical solution of the partial differential equations of plasma physics, including those of elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic, and eigenvalue type. Topics include finite difference, finite element, spectral, particle-in-cell, Monte Carlo, moving grid, and multiple-time-scale techniques, applied to the problems of plasma equilibrium, transport and stability. Basic parallel programming concepts are discussed.

title: General Plasma Physics II
reviews: A strong introduction to MHD.
Come to class!  It's well worth it.

I'm sure future lecturers will do the topic justice, but it's a pity that next year's students won't have Amitava for this course. I encourage them to take his class focusing on space plasma physics. In general, students should take ample time with the homework--it's where most of the learning takes place, no matter how good the lectures are.
descrip: This is an introductory graduate course in plasma physics, focusing on magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) and its extension to weakly collisional or collisionless plasmas. Topics to be covered include: the equations of MHD and extended MHD, the structure of magnetic fields, static and rotating MHD equilibria and their stability, magnetic reconnection, MHD turbulence, and the dynamo effect. Applications are drawn from fusion, heliophysical, and astrophysical plasmas.

title: Environmental Microbiology
reviews: Absolutely take this course, even if you feel that you have little knowledge of microbiology. Bess seamlessly bridges the gap between geochemistry and biology, making abundantly clear to her students that we cannot completely understand one without the influence of the other.

I wasn't a big fan. The lectures are mandatory and pointlessly boring. There's no real buildup of material, so you're left at the end of the course with a bunch of facts/figures and no knowledge. Hw was alright but boring.

It doesn't require much prior knowledge of the subject. Take it if you want a very very broad overview of the field. Do not take it if you want to learn about bacterial metabolism and diversity in detail.
Take it if you want to learn microbiology. Bess is a very good teacher and works to make the workload easier on students. (i.e. a lot of assignments aren't due at peak due times.)
Take this course! It's excellent.

This course was a fast-paced survey of marine microbial life that assumes moderate to advanced knowledge of biological and chemical concepts. I went in with only high school bio and chem, and felt woefully unprepared (though everything worked out, and Bess is patient with students). The highlight of the course was the emphasis on reading and presenting primary literature, which was done in groups. Highly recommend for EEB majors; less so for GEO majors (unless you have a strong interest in oceanography).
This is definitely a great foundation course in environmental microbiology.  The readings help to reinforce what is taught in class.

This was one of my favorite courses at Princeton! Bess is an outstanding professor who really cares about getting her students to learn as much as they can. She is also a great lecturer. If you like the topic and format (class presentations once a week, which are actually really fun to give and listen to), then you shouldn't hesitate about taking this class. Do it!
go to class, read the papers
having a good background in biology will be the most helpful!
prereqs: One 300-level course in chemistry or biology, or instructor's permission..
descrip: The study of microbial biogeochemistry and microbial ecology. Beginning with the physical/chemical characteristics and constraints of microbial metabolism, we will investigate the role of bacteria in elemental cycles, in soil, sediment and marine and freshwater communities, in bioremediation and chemical transformations.

title: Introduction to Movement and Dance
reviews: A great class! It is really something different from more traditional classes offered at Princeton. :) Really enjoyed it

A stress-free way to kill 4 hours a week. Interesting readings and viewings, and Aynsley is wonderful. You are given the freedom to do whatever you want and there is no real technique to be learned but unfortunately sometimes this translates to feeling like you are not getting anything of substance out of this class at all.

Aynsley was so great! She definitely made the course and encourages you so much to explore movements and things you otherwise might've been too afraid to do. It's not a course that blows you away immediately, and halfway through you may get a bit discouraged, but at the very end, looking back, it's AMAZING how much you grow in terms of dance and understanding movement.
Great

Great class to take for a busy semester. Aynsley is so enthusiastic and supportive of anything you want to do and this is a great chance to explore movement and what constitutes dance/art. There wasn't as much dancing as I thought there would be in the traditional sense. About two hours of reading and journaling for each class.

I take it because I want to learn to dance since I've never had professional training before. I definitely gained more confidence in dancing after this course, but not in my techniques or movements. I would have enjoyed the course a lot more if I actually invested more time in the dance assignment but I did not really have time. Would recommend taking it if you are a senior because you can be invested in the class and will enjoy it much more.
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT.
Take it :) took me a while to warm up to it and it's definitely a bit more time than I thought it would take, but it's worth it!

Take it!  Aynsley does a great job of making everyone feel comfortable dancing around each other.  It doesn't teach specific dance moves, but it was a great break from the day-to-day of Princeton and went a long way to relax me.  Final performance is intimidating, but ended up being fun!
This is a great course to fill an LA and you learn a lot about dancing and how you move.
descrip: Designed for people with little or no previous training in dance, the class will be a mixture of movement techniques, improvisation, choreography, observing, writing, and discussing. Students will investigate their own movement patterns and delve into many facets of dance and the cultural questions surrounding it. We will explore the role of dancer, choreographer, audience member, and critic in relation to such topics as aesthetic questions, politics, identity, religion, and complex views of the human body.

title: International Trade
reviews: Found the subject matter to be incredibly frustrating and unengaging, though not difficult. Super abstract with very poor support for problem sets and test preparation. Redding is an excellent lecturer, but this is definitely one of my least favorite econ classes i've taken to date, out of like 11...
Go to lecture and take good notes.
Go to lecture and take notes and you'll do well.
Go to lectures and understand the graphs
It is an easy course that has some interesting ideas
Professor Redding is a phenomenal lecturer- clear, concise, and engaging, though the material can be dry.
Redding is one of the most dedicated and professors I have seen at Princeton who cares soo much about his students. Definitely take this course with him if you can!!
Take it for econ bc it's interesting for not a lot of work
The material is more geared towards theoretical topics, but still interesting
This gives you a good foundation in understanding the economics of international trade. Problem sets can be tricky but there are only 4 of them and only 2 count. Exams are very straightforward.
This is a very easy, introductory class on International Trade. I think if looking for an easy, second departmental in a tough semester, consider taking this.
clear, interesting, easy to follow - good departmental if a little dry. easy to do well if you attend the lectures
if you're already interested in the topic, this is a great and relatively relaxed course to take, but watch out for a ton of material to study for in the final
take it. if you go to lectures you will know everything you need to know.
prereqs: WWS 300, ECO 300, or ECO 310.
descrip: This course examines the causes and consequences of international trade. Why do countries trade? What determines the goods that a country exports and imports? Why do only some firms export? Who gains and who loses from trade? To address these questions, the course develops a number of models, which shed light on several related public policy issues: What are the implications of the growing trade from China and other developing countries? Does international trade explain rising wage inequality? Should governments use trade policy to "pick winners"?

title: Latin: An Intensive Introduction
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of work, but don't be intimidated by the content.  Try to study on a regular basis so that you retain the language.
Be prepared to spend three hours per day seven days a week on the material - it's no joke.
Fast, effective, (generally) painless way to learn Latin.

If you need to learn latin, for whatever reason, take this class - professor Baraz is beyond awesome and will guide you through what is a tricky language. I don't consider myself a language person, and yet still did very well in an accelerated class because of her excellent teaching.

You learn a lot in this class, but do not take it unless you are prepared to work hard. 2-3 hours of homework a night learning vocab and doing translations plus the grammar. If you want to learn latin quickly, this is a great way to do it, but be prepared to spend a lot of time on this call.
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to the Latin language: LAT 103 covers the material of LAT 101-102 in a shorter time through increased class time. Students completing the course will be prepared to take LAT 105.

title: Physics of Plasma Propulsion
descrip: Focus of this course is on fundamental processes in plasma thrusters for spacecraft propulsion with emphasis on recent research findings. Start with a review of the fundamentals of mass, momentum & energy transport in collisional plasmas, wall effects, & collective (wave) effects, & derive a generalized Ohm's law useful for discussing various plasma thruster concepts. Move to detailed discussions of the acceleration & dissipation mechanisms in Hall thrusters, magnetoplasmadynamic thrusters, pulsed plasma thrusters, & inductive plasma thrusters, & derive expressions for the propulsive efficiencies of each of these concepts.

title: Topics in Modern Italian Cinema - New Italian Cinema: New Media (in English)
reviews: A wonderful course for anyone passionate about European movies and/or Italian culture!
Gaetana is a gem
I liked this course quite a bit! Just be aware of the fact that it's slightly challenging at times -- It's not a lot of work, but definitely not a slacker class!
It's a treat for those interested in European Cinema in general and in Italian Cinema in particular
TAKE THIS COURSE! It's fun, interesting, and not too much work. Best combination.
Take it! It's dope.
Take it. It's awesome.

The readings aren't necessary in general for the Italian precept at least; the Italian section was super chill; take it for a fun way to practice Italian. The movies were all really enjoyable, and the grades weren't too hard. Take it if you're interested in more artsy movies, especially Italian ones!
prereqs: No knowledge of Italian is required to enroll. Course open to freshmen. Precept 2 is in Italian..
descrip: This course looks at the way Italy has expressed its cultural, political, and social individuality in major cinematic works from 1968 to the present. Directors such as Bertolucci, Moretti, Tornatore, Ozpetek, and Benigni offer a panorama of a generation of filmmakers that has contributed to the renewal of Italian cinema. Topics will be drawn from current issues, and will include the Holocaust and questions of memory, terrorism, political violence, migration, gender ideologies, the Mafia. Emphasis on film style and techniques.

title: Remembering the Future
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Electromagnetism
reviews: A worthy course to take for people interested in physics.
Do all the readings, go to office hours a lot (!!!), consult YouTube or other online videos for derivations that don't skip any steps whatsoever.
Griffiths book is great. If you've taken 208 and enjoyed learning from that, you'll enjoy this class too.
I found that this course is more entertaining and rewarding than intro quantum, that I take concurrently.
It's intriguing material and a class that physics majors should definitely look forward to taking.
It's not the most interesting subject in my opinion, but if you're interested in EM, it's a great class.
Not much work for a physics class. Just read the Gospel According to Griffiths and you'll be fine.

Romalis is a good teacher with insightful perspectives on problems and topics in the book, as is evident in his disagreement with and contradicting explanation of topics such as radiation reaction and hidden momentum. Take the course with an eye toward engaging with the material more than what griffiths has to offer.
Take it! You will be surprised how much you learn. Also, keep up with the material!
The class is not exactly like 106; it's definitely more rigorous and challenging. That being said, it's a relief after quantum and thermo.
The problem sets take about 6 hours so be careful to do them in advance. Also make sure you do the example problems in the textbook. It's an awesome class overall.
Tough, but you have to go through it.
You probably have to take it
don't take unless you have to
prereqs: PHY 104 or PHY 106 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Electromagnetic theory based on Maxwell's equations. Electrostatics, including boundary valve problems, dielectrics, and energy considerations leading to the Maxwell stress tensor. Magnetostatics and simple magnetic materials. Electromagnetic waves, retarded potentials and radiation. Familiarity with vector calculus is assumed.

title: Afghanistan and the Great Powers, 1747-2001
reviews: Anyone interested in learning more about the Middle East must take this course.
Awesome professor!

Definitely take this course. Going to lectures isn't entirely necessary to do well on the papers, but I would recommend going nonetheless as Prof. Barry has some incredible stories to tell and fascinating analysis to give.
Definitely take this course. Professor Barry is a wonderful, caring, and knowledgeable professor!!!
Go to all the lectures, and try to pay attention rather than going on Facebook for 3 hours. It'll save you a lot of time when you write the essays.
I would strongly recommend this to anyone interested in the subject or the NES department.

If Barry ever offers this course again, you must take it. He has a wealth of experience in the region, is a phenomenal lecturer, and is always prepared to answer questions both inside and outside of class.

If you are looking to learn about Afghanistan's incredible history from one of the foremost experts, take this class. Lectures are long but fascinating and keep you interested and the papers aren't crazy hard.
Interesting material at a reasonable pace that can be taken by people of all knowledge levels looking to learn more about conflict in middle east.
Outstanding lecturer. Fascinating professor.
Prof. Barry has a very different style of teaching than many courses I have taken so far( I'm a junior). If you just go to the lectures and listen to him, you'll learn a lot.

Professor Barry has a truly incredible story and this is a very cool course. Workload is not bad either, although I do feel that you would be well served--for personal edification, not necessarily evaluation--by going to office hours and absorbing as much as possible, as you definitely come out of the class with a hugely broadened perspective. Evaluations feel a bit arbitrary, but I can forgive Prof. Barry for that--after going from dodging mortars on horseback in Afghanistan, I can imagine that quibbling over  the distinction between A-'s or B 's seems trivial.
TAKE IT!!!!
TAKE IT. Little work, but Friday lectures are very long
Take it

Take it! Michael Barry is a true scholar of the field, and knows all about the middle east. He has lived many years exploring and working in Afghanistan. He is probably the best lecturer I have had at Princeton... and he integrates Afghanistan's history with that of the world extremely well.
Take it, Professor Barry is one of a kind and you should take at least one course under him in your time here
Take it. Barry is incredible.
Take it. You will learn, enjoy, and appreciate.
Take it. friday class sucks, but it'll be interesting.
Take this case. The best class I have taken in Princeton so far.

Take this class if you want a chill way to learn about one of the most important modern international issues of our time. Wait to buy course materials until you figure out what you actually need and are interested in.
Take this class!

Take this class, Professor Barry is fantastic and so interesting both as a lecturer and as a person. Take your notes by hand. You can definitely keep up, you will listen more, and the material is genuinely fascinating when you listen. Drifting in and out, the narrative of the course will not be clear, and thus will not be interesting.
Take this course and put a good amount of time into reading the sources. The lectures are great but the readings help you dig deep into the history.
Take this course! Prof. Barry is amazing!
Take this course!! Michael Barry is one of the best lecturers at Princeton and really brings Afghan history and culture alive. Do the readings, they are really fascinating.

This is an interesting course with pretty easy grading, but it is rather disorganized. I definitely recommend taking a class with Professor Barry, but of all his courses, I would recommend the Sufism courses over this one. I feel that the 3 hour lecture style did not fit well with a history course, whereas it is more effective for courses like NES 323/324.
This was one of the best courses I have taken here.
Yes! Take it! It is a very chill class that you can still do exceptionally well in.

You don't have to do all the readings or go to every lecture to do well in this class. Definitely do the first reading, though (the anthropological study). Definitely go to Michael Barry's office hours - he tells great stories about his time in Afghanistan.
take it, amazing history and culture
descrip: Renewed in depth, NES307 traces the great powers' struggle to control the Middle East through the prism of Afghanistan, focusing on its social and tribal background and emergence as an independent kingdom in the 18th century, on the rivalries between Russia and Britain in the 19th century ("The Great Game") and those between the Soviet Union and the US in the 20th, concluding with study of Washington's support in the 1980s for Pakistan-based Islamist groups fighting the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, and the consequent rise of the Taliban movement allied to al Qaida from the 1990s to today.

title: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
reviews: Absolutely take this for a basic understanding of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
Definitely worth taking, no matter your perspective or how much information you have coming in.
Good Luck and have fun with the material
Great opportunity to learn about a topic that is extremely important in the world today. Gribetz is a nice guy and a good lecturer. Try to get into his precept as well.
I would advise that they participate in precept as much as possible and go to office hours.
I would definitely recommend taking this course. It is a great introduction to the conflict.
Its hard to believe how many students didn't do the precept readings. DO THEM. And take the professor's precept.
TAKE IT! TAKE IT! TAKE IT!
Take course and be engaged.
Take it if you are interested in the conflict. It is a very good introduction!
Take it if you wanna learn about the Arab-Israeli conflict. I went from knowing absolutely nothing to being able to contextualize anything very easily
Take it!
Take it.

Take this course! I think that this course would be much better as a seminar format, but as it stand Gribetz is a great professor and has much to teach about the Arab-Israeli Conflict! Great class for anyone trying to brush up on their history for their future political career and  I'd even recommend it for a more seasoned expert on the current-day politics.
Take!
This is a very interesting class

With Prof. Gribetz, it's a great class! Really presents both perspectives of the Arab-Israeli conflict in an objective manner. Just be prepared for a lot of reading, but otherwise, the workload isn't too heavy.
strongly recommend
descrip: This course will examine the history of the encounter and conflict between Jews and Arabs in and around Palestine/Israel from the late 19th through the late 20th centuries. The story is at once fascinating and tragic, the meeting of ancient peoples and cultures in a wholly new political and ideological environment. The course follows the history of the modern conflict over the Holy Land from its inception in the Late Ottoman period through the present with an eye to the evolving causes of the tensions, the numerous attempts to resolve them, and the various forces and factors that have thus far precluded a comprehensive peace.

title: Graphic Design
reviews: A good class for beginning to experiment with graphic design.
Definitely take it.  A tough class, but truly one of my favorites.

Don't take it if you expect it to be an easy A. It will require a lot of work and time outside the classroom, in addition to the entire day taken up by the studio. But if you are actually interested in typography and graphic design, this is the best intro class ever.

Make sure to stay up-to-date on the projects, and make sure to seek extra help from Alice if you are confused about anything. Also be prepared for the class to take a significant amount of time both in-class (5 hours on Fridays) and outside-of-class (working on and updating several on-going projects at a time.. for me, personally, design work takes many, many hours, and especially so when there are several projects at once). I would definitely recommend taking this class, but only if you have an interest in design to begin with and enjoy working on design work (I can't imagine putting so so much time into the studio projects if I didn't love actually doing design--if I didn't enjoy the work this class would have been a lot harder to get through for sure).
Take any course Alice teaches. She's wonderful.

Take your first graphic design course at Princeton with Alice. The amount of work (quite a bit) and number of revisions gets you to improve quite a bit, even though there isn't a lot of guidance and critiques are toned down and not always consistent because of the wide range of experience and ability of different students. The course put me in what I thought was a good position to be more engaged in the other, more theoretical or conceptual graphic design classes here.

This class will take up a lot of time and effort. Not very friendly for beginners or people with only a mild interest. Can be helpful for determining if you don't actually want to do design, because it will push you very hard.
descrip: This studio course will introduce students to the essential aspects and skills of graphic design, and will analyze and discuss the increasingly vital role that non-verbal, graphic information plays in all areas of professional life, from fine art and book design to social networking and the Internet. Students in the course will explore visual organization through a series of focused, interrelated assignments dealing with composition, page layout, type design, and image. Hands on production will include an array of do-it-yourself printing and distribution technologies, from letterpress and mimeograph to photocopying and websites.

title: Roman Lyric and Elegiac Poetry - Horace's Odes
descrip: We will read The Odes of Horace, including the Carmen Saeculare. We will also survey scholarly approaches to the corpus.

title: Environmental Chemistry of Soils
reviews: A good GEO course for CHM majors.
If you're interested in the material, it's a great class, very interesting, and you realize at the end you've learned way more than you thought along the way.
prereqs: Prerequisites: CHM 331, or any other basic chemistry course..
descrip: Focuses on the inorganic and organic constituents of aqueous, solid, and gaseous phases of soils, and fundamental chemical principles and processes governing the reactions between different constituents. The role of soil chemical processes in the major and trace element cycles, and the biogeochemical transformation of different soil contaminants will be discussed in the later parts of the course.

title: Dynamical Systems
prereqs: For advanced level Juniors and Seniors. Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will discuss new Variational Methods for the study of Hamiltonian Dynamical Systems, with a view of obtaining results about Arnold Diffusion.

title: Topics in Medieval Greek Literature - Abused, Repentant, Transvestite, Holy Women in Byzantium
descrip: In this course we will read a selection of stories about a new social and religious figure, the female saint. Translated from medieval Greek, these "Lives" of holy women from the later Roman and Byzantine world combine social realism (wives fleeing brutal husbands, girls escaping prostitution, women disguised as monks in order to gain entry into male preserves) with a Christian idealist piety. We will attempt to understand how such literature evolved and why the figure of the female saint escaping the plight of her gender resonated in Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages.

title: Reading Is Not What You Think
reviews: If you are an English major, I would recommend it.

If you want an easy A, then take this class.  If you have any respect for the study of literature, however, then stay away from this course.  I am a lit major and an aspiring professor of literature, but this class almost made me hate reading.
Take it if you are willing to engage individually with the interesting ideas and strategies he highlights.
Take it if you like discussions about readings texts.
Take it!  Do the readings and you will learn a lot.  Professor Baer is a true intellectual- he lends a fantastic vibe to the class.
Take this course if it's with Prof. Baer! You won't regret it, you'll learn so much and it's a relatively easy EM. If you like literature at all, then take it!

Three-hour seminars felt very long, and sometimes it could feel like we were just talking about literature for the sake of talking, but in the end I really have noticed that I'm reading and thinking in new ways. If you can keep yourself engaged, it pays off.
descrip: In this class for students considering majoring in Comparative Literature, we ask what happens when we read literature? How do we read? And what are the ethical questions and problems that we rehearse when we read? Is reading all about finding the reflection of myself in the text, or do we find something else? What does it mean to read a culturally different novel or poem? How might it teach us to imagine others not like ourselves? As well as workshop-style practice in reading literature closely, the class also raises the question of literary reading as a transferable skill: how does it help us to read the wider world?

title: Molecular Spectroscopy
descrip: A survey of atomic and molecular energy levels and the Hamiltonians that describe them. The interaction of radiation with matter, including multiphoton effects and nano-optics. Examples include electronic and nuclear spectroscopy of molecules and crystals, electron spin resonance, microwave spectroscopy, and the uses of lasers in modern spectroscopic research.

title: Neuroimmunology: Immune Molecules in Normal Brain Function and Neuropathology
reviews: Definitely take it! So interesting!!!
Definitely take the course! It's a bit of hard work but you will learn volumes that will help you in the future with JPs and thesis work. I really glad I took this class!!!
Dive in and enjoy it!

Don't take this course. It's a waste of time and it's one of those courses where participation is worth so much that students ask pointless questions to get points and waste everyone's time. I don't believe I'll be getting a bad grade to motivate this feedback, I just really don't want other students to waste a course spot on this class. While I definitely got better at reading scientific papers more critically, this could've been done more effectively in conjunction with actual classes taught by the professor.

Great! If you really want to get something out of this class, spend a significant amount of time really trying to understand the text and figures. It will be difficult at first but throughout the semester, it will definitely get easier. Also, really think about how to convey the results of the papers in a layperson's language--this will really help you see what you do and don't understand.
I learned a ton about how to read papers!
MUST TAKE...very helpful for those who may not know how to read scientific journal articles when coming into the course.

Meet with the assistant early on for help with the write-ups.  
Expect to spend a lot of time each week on the readings.  Two primary papers might not seem like much work, but you will spend a significant amount of time trying to gain a thorough, informed understanding of the papers.
Not a lot of work and really interesting subject so definitely take it! Classes are student-driven and students present throughout all classes, making for great discussion.
Take it.

Take it. As someone who has taken the hardest courses and the easiest courses on this campus, I can say with confidence that this course strikes a very happy middle ground. The topic is complex and relevant enough to be quite interesting, and you don't necessarily need to have a science background beyond a basic understanding of biology (the course will teach you what you need to know), but the course is also not going to consume your life and make your semester miserable (as some higher level MOL classes here have a reputation of doing...).

Overall: 10/10, take it if you have any interest at all.
Take this class- it'll change the way you approach scientific articles and will help you in becoming a good scientist.

This is a very good MOL/NEU elective. I highly recommend it, given that Professor Boulanger not only teaches you a lot about the field of neuroimmunology, but also about how to analyze the primary literature.

This is an amazing course! But, this is not a course where you will be lectured about topics in neuroimmunology. Instead, you'll have papers to read each week relating to neuroimmunology and you'll just discuss the papers during class, which, by the way, is very enjoyable. The workload is not too crazy and the class itself is obviously very interesting. Keep in mind though, that you're just talking about the papers for three hours. But, it's still super fun and interesting and Dr. Boulanger keeps the conversation lively. You'll definitely come out of this class with a better appreciation for scientific writing and research, and your skills in these areas will improve too!
This was a really difficult course. You do learn quite a bit but expect to be very challenged.
prereqs: MOL 214 / EEB 214 (Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology)..
descrip: In this course, we will explore the diverse and complex interactions between the brain and the immune system, from the perspective of current, cutting-edge research papers. In particular, we will focus on the molecular mechanisms of these interactions, their role in normal brain development and function, and their potential contributions to neurological disorders including autism. In the process, students will learn to read, critically evaluate, and explain (in written and oral form) the content of articles from the primary literature.

title: Black Politics in the Post-Civil Rights Era
reviews: Attend all of the lectures.
Definitely take this class!  It's a super interesting and analytical way to look at current events.
I would recommend if you're interested in the topic, hopefully it'll be better organized in the future, as professor grows more comfortable with course
Take it! A good introduction to black politics after civil rights movement--readings are interesting and very managable
descrip: This course focuses upon the evolution, nature, and role of black politics within the American Political System, in the post- civil rights era. The concern is with black people as actors and creators and initiators in the political process. Specifically, this course will examine various political controversies that surround the role of race in American society. These controversies or issues, affect public opinion, political institutions, political behavior, and salient public policy debates. Thus this course will assess and evaluate the contemporary influence of race in each of these domains while also exploring their historical antecedents.

title: Laboratory in Principles of Neuroscience
reviews: Always come to class prepared and don't get too discouraged if things don't go right in the lab. It's a learning process.
It was a very chill course. You just have to write the figures well and do the papers well.
It's a huge time suck and you're learning "how" more than "what" or "why".
NEU core lab takes up a chunk of class tine but is a good and interesting class. Be patient during the labs--you may not get data but that is ok! Professor Gelperin and Anthony are great!
Not super demanding but kind of stressful because the grading is pretty subjective.
TAKE THIS COURSE! Top 3 of courses Ive taken here - so freaking cool.
Take, it will turn into a great course, especially if you want any knowledge of neuro lab techniques.
prereqs: Course open to students completing requirements for the Neuroscience Certificate and other students with the permission of the Instructor..
descrip: This course is designed to introduce undergraduate students to modern methods of analysis applied to single neurons, the synaptic connections between neurons and the dynamics of networks of neurons underlying learning and decision making.
