The course will include mammalian cellular and system neuroanatomy and the influence of experience on the production of new neurons. Students will learn modern methods of microscopy and the application of optogenetic approaches to analysis of neuronal function. Basic neuroscience concepts will be studied using both invertebrate and mammalian CNS preparations.

title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation II
reviews: Take it! Homework takes a lot of time, but the course is overall chill and engaging, and you will learn a lot.

Take this course if you want to continue studying Russian. You will learn a lot about some of the most famous Russian authors and, in turn, learn a lot about Russian history from their biographies and especially from their poetry. You will watch films, which is a fun way to practice Russian.
The course is necessary to continue improving your russian

This class is incredibly time intensive and somewhat vaguely executed. We read biographies and poems of some really incredible Russian poets and we watched two Russian movies. The workload is demanding ? the movies require 300 words a night and the readings take between 2 and 4 hours a night. It could be organized better, it could have a little bit more orientation, but the content of the class is really interesting and your Russian will improve, you spoken Russian in particular (which is great).

This course is based on interesting and culturally relevant films, poems, and literature and will enhance your understanding not only of the Russian language, but of Russian culture and history as well.
solid continuation of russian
prereqs: RUS 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 207. Reading and discussion of the literary texts (20th-century poetry) and the poets' biographies; review of selected grammar topics; work with two movies.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Be very smart about managing your digital files, because they become huge and difficult to deal with! Try to be productive every day, because otherwise you'll fall behind.

I would recommend that students working alone opt to form pairs. The discussion between partners, motivation to produce, and the ability to problem solve technical issues that a partnership produces is crucial to the production of a strong project.

Professor Jaque's course is well worth consideration. Though the pedagogical method provokes a certain discomfort for some?a reality that Jaque is in fact aware of?it is a productive discomfort, likely necessary for the expansion of one's critical eye toward a world of objects previously "hidden in plain sight."
Strongly recommended. The load of work is huge, as it is the reward.
This studio is best paired with courses with a lower workload, such as theory, as the production expectation is very high.
This was an intense studio. It was demanding, ambitious, and very challenging, and if you can align your interests with the studio it could be very good.
very rewarding.
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem in civil and environmental engineering. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a two-semester study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Beginner's Spanish II
reviews: Always study the vocabulary for quizzes and tests. Continue to speak and participate in class because it will improve your spanish skills greatly.
Ask a lot of questions!
Be ready for a decent amount of work.
Convince Regina to continue teaching

Definitely take this course. Profesora Zetterstrand is one of the best teachers I have had since coming to Princeton, and I learned quite a bit from her. As a whole, the course expects a lot out of you, and you learn new tenses, the subjunctive, and grammatical concepts at a rapid speed. However, if you take this course, just remember why you signed up to begin with, and it becomes a lot more manageable. Also, explore the language tables and have fun with the course!
Do all the homework and go to class.

Do all the homework, stay up to speed so you know what is being talked about in class.. Be prepared for a very tough grading scale and a huge, very hard-to-cross gap between an A and an A-. Also, there is daily homework (written and online) and quizzes/tests/essays and you have to literally be present in class each day of the week, so be prepared to dedicate a lot of time each week to Spanish.
Do all the homeworks and review vocabulary and verb tenses.
Do not miss a class.
Do not procrastinate in learning the vocabulary and grammar.
Do practice outside of just homework.
Do the readings and homework every day in order to keep improving in the language

Don't psych yourself out, and make sure to speak regularly in class. I'm not sure how that works into your grade, but it's the only chance you really have to practice speaking before the oral exam. It's easy to let other people talk, but the practice really helps when you get to the end of the course.
Don't take unless you have to. It does move fast, and you'll probably end up teaching yourself everything and cramming. Annoying that it's every day.
Excellent course, exactly like Spanish 101.
Give the class 100% effort. It is worth it.
Great class without an excessive amount of work.  If you decide to take the course, take full advantage and participate as much as you can.
Great course. Try to get Professor Naudi or Olander, but I heard everyone is great.
Have fun with this course.
I learned more in one semester here than I did in multiple years of high school language instruction. Do yourself a favor and take this course--you'll be amazed by the transformation.
I mean you're probably taking this because you have to..
I would advise another student to put a lot of effort into each assignment of the course. Although they don't take a lot of time, it is very important to take each one seriously
I would recommend that a student considering taking this course practice speaking Spanish outside of class as much as possible as it is very helpful.
If Professor Byrne is teaching, take her class.

If you have never taken Spanish or are not fluent in another language get a tutor right away because it is basically impossible to catch up to the students who have taken Spanish for a long period of time.
If you want to get a grade that is less than you deserve then take this course.
If you want to learn Spanish, it is a good introduction
It is a requirement so do all the work and stay on top of the work. The end of the semester is rough but continue doing the work
It is a requirement so you have to take it

It's a lot of textbook activities, so manage your time well. You can't exactly get out of the course if you need to fulfill your distribution requirement, but hopefully you will get an excellent teacher who will not make it feel like a burden.

It's introductory Spanish. You'll have class everyday, homework everyday, and lots of assignments that can be annoying on top of other work from other courses. Nevertheless, depending on your professor, you will learn a lot and can easily become much more fluent in this language.
Its a lot of work
Keep on top of your vocab and don't cram right before the exam.
Keep up with the material in the textbook and the vocabulary.

Make sure that you mesh well with your instructor and that you are putting in the work that you are asked to do. It is a very grammar based course and if you do not stay on top of it you will fall behind very quickly.
Make sure you keep up with the grammar and vocabulary. Don't cram the night before the exam!! It might work at first but in the end it's way too hard!!
Make sure you take it with Sylvia Zetterstrand!

Not much different from SPA101, except, in my opinion, there is more work (project wise and everything). Take Sylvia's section! She's delightful. Other than that, it's Spanish. Put in the time, and you will do well.
Participate and it will be easy.
Practice listening to Spanish outside of class.
Practice speaking, and don't be afraid to make mistakes. Read the instructor's feedback on your homework assignments, essays, etc. Enjoy learning the new language :)

Read the book. Use Quizlet. Watch Sol y Viento. Go to class and talk to the professor if you have a problem. Try not to miss dates for projects because they are worth a great deal of points. Try hard on the papers and larger homework assignments because that's really where you'll get your points. Unless you're particularly interested in Spanish and want to study in Argentina, I recommend another introductory language course that you couldn't take in high school. Profesora Baranski is fun though so you have to take it, take it with her.
SPA102 is a chill class. Just do the work and you'll be fine. I enjoyed my professor more than anything.
Spanish is a fairly easy language to learn.  Anna's a great instructor!
Spanish is super fun and everyone should be learning it. I recommend it wholeheartedly.
Stay on top of the reading and the concepts and participate in class so that you are ready when the tests come around.
Study in advance for tests!
Study more than the night before exams. Also, ask teacher about acciones
Study vocabulary after every class and be proactive in looking at lesson objectives to avoid cramming before exams
TAKE IT. Be prepared for work though- you will need to work everyday- but it is very rewarding and alot of fun!
Take Spanish but not just Spanish. Take Spanish with Sylvia.
Take it if you have to.
Take it! Fun. Will help you learn spanish.
Take the course right after lunch so you aren't hungry and can engage in class.
Take this class if you want to learn Spanish. Help is there if you need it.
Take this course if you have to take SPA 102.

Take this course with Luis if possible. He is a phenomenal professor in his teaching and is overall a very fun professor to have. I highly recommend taking his section - he is what made Spanish as good and fun an experience as it was.
Take this! There is no reason not to learn a new language in college - this is a very fast-moving curriculum and you get a lot of practice in a semester.
The spanish program is great. I encourage yall to take it
This class is so easy. Just participate and do the homework (which are usually worksheets and papers).

This is kind of a necessary evil if you're set on learning Spanish at Princeton. Your experience in this class is very teacher dependent (Rina is decent, but I don't think she's coming back next semester?) so shamelessly shop different sections to avoid getting stuck with a bad one. Expect to do a lot of teaching yourself, and to be pretty bored.
To be engaged in class
You should take this course with Rina if you can!
it's pretty easy and doable if you just do your work and stay on top of things
just take it...and get ahead on your work
take it if you have to
take it if you want
take it only if you have to
prereqs: SPA 101. No credit given for SPA 101 unless followed by SPA 102..
descrip: The second course in the elementary Spanish sequence for students with little or no previous knowledge of the language. With its emphasis on the four basic skills (speaking, writing, reading, and listening), SPA 102 continues to provide students with the linguistic, communicative and cultural foundations to engage in basic daily life interactions in Spanish. Hispanic cultures are introduced through a variety of texts, including readings, music, art, video clips, and film. All of these sources provide the basis for classroom activities.

title: Drug Discovery: From Snake Venoms to Medicines
descrip: See website

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Poverty and Public Policy
descrip: This seminar will provide a survey of trends in U.S. poverty and how public policy has responded over time. Examines the range of benefits and services that comprise the social safety net, including refundable tax credits, housing subsidies, nutrition programs, cash assistance, and Social Security benefits. Also reviews past and current debates over the effectiveness of these programs, with a particular focus on welfare reform. Assignments are designed to provide students with practical experience in how to present ideas to policymakers and a broader public audience.

title: History Beyond the Written Word: Unconventional Historical Sources and The Historian's Craft
descrip: The course focuses on unconventional historical sources and approaches including oral, spatial, computational, and digital history. Conventional written sources typically reflect the biases of a small elite. Oral history can be used to recapture the history of individuals, groups, and phenomena that written sources have erased. Spatial history (through the use of Geographic Information Systems or GIS), digital history, and computational history greatly enrich the study of the past by adding new types of data and by offering platforms to integrate a great variety of sources in new multi-dimensional, multi-media, and interactive formats.

title: Bioethics: Clinical and Population-Level
reviews: Do the readings! You will get more out class discussions.
If you have an interest in bioethics, definitely take this course, though be prepared to do all of the relevant reading.
If you're in the sciences, this is a great class to take. It'll give you great perspective on a lot of issues related to the work you'll do now and in the future.
Start the papers far in advance.

Take it! Professor Frick is a very clear and engaging instructor, and is a great person to elucidate the complex issues that this class tackles. I looked forward to the seminar every week because of the thought-provoking discussions. Anyone who has an interest in bioethics should sign up regardless of major or prior exposure to this fascinating and highly relevant field. You should come in with at least one philosophy course under your belt, since otherwise writing the papers might prove too much of a challenge, though you will be fine even if you have no prior knowledge of moral philosophy.
Take this course if you want to take a philosophy course that is very accessible and relevant. These are topics that everyone should be thinking about regardless of major! Great readings.
Take this course! You will get a lot more out of the course if you read the readings before class and can follow what's being talked about in seminar. Don't be afraid to speak in seminar.

This class is amazing, Professor Frick is a great instructor and a really cool guy, and you will definitely learn a lot and participate in interesting discussions. The readings are a bit overwhelming, but manageable, and it is generally advised that you actively participate in the seminars. Goods for non-philosophy majors with an interest in philosophy and policy making.

This was hard in the beginning to take without a philosophy background, but in the end everything we read tied together and really gave me a good understanding of the topics in this class. This class would be really good for premeds to take, in addition to anyone interested in health policy.
You learn a lot.
descrip: This seminar aims to introduce students to a range of philosophical debates in clinical and population-level bioethics. Among the topics in clinical bioethics that we may discuss are physician-assisted suicide and euthanasia; abortion; and the ethics of genetic enhancement. In population-level bioethics, questions we may discuss include the definition and measurement of health; cost-effectiveness and disability-discrimination; the significance of health inequalities; personal and social responsibility for health; treatment vs prevention in the fight against HIV/AIDS; and standards of care in clinical trials in the US and abroad.

title: Readings in Modern Korean II
reviews: Do the readings carefully because they're gems.
Don't be afraid to speak up!
It's a lot of work, but if you want to improve your Korean and take it to the next level, definitely take it! Professor Suh is amazing!
Take it
Take it if you want to practice your Korean. Just take it. First show up and then see if you don't like it.

This is a work-intensive course, and certainly not a fourth or fifth class to add onto your workload. As long as there is enough time to prepare and do the readings, though, it'll prove to be very enjoyable

the quality of this class will largely be determined by the people who are taking the class and the quality of their comments. KOR 407 was sometimes disappointing because there was one person who consistently made comments (often abruptly without even being called on) that were not at all constructive to the discussions we were having as a class.  I often felt very unpleasant because of this student and was enraged that the quality of my education was being undermined by the mere presence of this inconsiderate student. Other than that, Prof Suh was awesome as always; she is very engaging and will make sure you are never bored.
prereqs: KOR 402 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course is designed: to advance students' literacy skills to the Superior level (near native-like); to promote a deeper understanding of the Korean language, culture, society, history and literature; and to further develop their critical thinking through reading and writing in Korean. Focusing on change in the Korean language in relation to history, society, and culture, the course covers a wide range of sociolinguistic and sociocultural issues through various media resources as well as documents written in Middle Korean, literary short stories and poems, traditional and modern.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Analyzing Popular Music
reviews: It's a seminar on popular music.  Take it.
prereqs: MUS 105 and 106 or equivalent. MUS 205 is recommended..
descrip: This course introduces students to the issues involved in analyzing popular music, including rock, soul, funk, hip-hop, reggae, and electronic dance music from the late 1950s to the present. Listening closely without a score, we will discuss form, timbre, production, harmony and voice leading, rhythm, and music videos. Each week, we will read analytical articles dealing with a particular theoretical issue and analyze two to three songs in class.

title: Introduction to Graph Theory
reviews: A good intro class.

As far as math courses go, this class is fairly straightforward - since Professor Chudnovsky is an excellent lecturer, it's definitely worth taking if you have an interest in graph theory or want to satisfy the discrete math requirement. But if you're already familiar with the topic, it will probably be too easy for you.
Definitely take it! Maria Chudnovsky is a great lecturer.
Have fun

I loved this class.  Incredible topics, and the professor is just an absolute pleasure.  Proofs themselves are so much more...fun than any other math class that I've taken!  It's the topic ? graph theory is just so cool.
If you like puzzles, this is good. Doesn't require a lot of math background, just a keen sense of reasoning and ability to follow others reasoning.
If you're a non math major who's very interested in math, this class is perfect for you and you'll love it.
Prof. Chudnovsky is amazing! You should take this course if you are interested in graph theory. Some proofs are tricky but once you get the hang of it they are not too hard.
Take it! It was my first completely theory course, and it wasn't too bad.
Take. It. Now. Prof. Chudnovsky is a fantastic lecturer. She keeps the class engaged and makes sure everyone is on the same page. The homework problems are fun and the workload isn't too heavy.

This course is very easy for a math departmental.  Time commitment near zero.  The material is interesting and you learn a lot despite it moving pretty slowly.  However, graders will comb over your proofs in detail.  This makes the grading harsh and the curve quite atrocious.  So be careful.  It would probably be a great class for someone trying to get a feel for higher level math but doesn't want to take 215/217 because they are too time consuming.

Very interesting material. All proof-based. I suggest taking COS 226 before taking this course. Graph theory has many useful applications, and the class will give you a strong understanding of the theoretical aspect. #perfect
Yes! Unless you don't like math.
very interesting class and you can definitely do well in it, teaches you a lot about proofs in general
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204 or 217 or equivalent..
descrip: The fundamental theorems and algorithms of graph theory. Topics include: connectivity, matchings, graph coloring, planarity, the four-color theorem, extremal problems, network flows, and related algorithms.

title: Religion and Conservatism in the United States Since WWII
reviews: Don't take this course if it is with Professor Frank. He's biased, a little snarky, and would sometimes pick on students in front of the class. He would make comments about people's religious and political beliefs that were not appropriate for a classroom environment. Once he said that "conservatism is a white people thing." A couple of us talked outside of class about how we felt like we could not fully share our opinions for fear of being shut down by him in precept or in the gradebook.

Take the class. It's not too difficult and Gil Frank is really easy to talk to and work with, especially if you go to him for help. He was always willing to talk over materials or papers. One of the top 3 courses I have taken in 4 years here. If you don't take it, you're missing out on an interesting and fairly easy course.
Talk to him outside of class-- very interesting conversation!
small class size meant you had to do work and participate, but worth it- interesting
descrip: This course examines the development of the Religious Right since 1945 by studying how conservatives from different religions engaged with postwar liberalism, reshaped their own denominations, and responded to the civil rights movement, second wave feminism, and gay liberation. Topics include: conservative theology, institution and culture building, and electoral politics. Readings include primary texts and documents and recent scholarly works.

title: Sociology From E Street: Bruce Springsteen's America
reviews: Amazing class, amazing professor, amazing class guests! Take it whether you're a Springsteen fan or not. It's an experience you can't regret.
An interesting and fairly easy course
Attend the lectures.
Consider taking it if Duneier is teaching it, but definitely do not if Portelli is teaching.
Cool music oriented class
Definitely take it. This was the first sociology class I have ever taken and loved it.
Do not expect this to be a class entirely about Bruce Springsteen. Be ready to tackle sociological theory as well as a more literary/interpretative approach to his songs
Do not take this is Portelli is teaching for an entire half of a semester.
Do the readings on time.
Do the readings.
Don't expect to get that much out of it.
Don't take it
Duneier was great, Portelli was awful
Give it a shot. I can't imagine there are too many other classes quite like it.
Good distribution requirement filler!
Great class but not and easy A but a great way to introduce yourself to SOC.
Huge waste of time. Very easy though...
I would not recommend taking the course unless Professor Duneier teaches the entire year. Make sure to find out about this before enrolling in the course.
I would not take this course again if Professor Portelli is teaching part of it.
I would recommend anyone take this course, it was not very stressful and was interesting. The Springsteen songs that were chosen are great songs, musically and lyrically.

If Mitch is teaching the whole course, absolutely you must take it. I feel like pretty much anyone in the universe would enjoy it. However, be wary if the course is co-taught because the second professor may be less fabulous. If Sharon is precepting, be in her precept!

If you like Bruce Springsteen (not that you need to know many of his songs, I myself didn't), or that style of music, you'll enjoy the course. If you don't like that sort of thing, you probably won't.
If you're expecting to learn about sociology, you're gonna have a bad time. Strongly recommend against taking this course if Portelli is teaching the second half.
It's a great course. I enjoyed it a lot.
It's a very interesting and fair Sociology course, even if you aren't familiar with Springsteen's music beforehand. Definitely take!
Make sure you attend the lectures and understand how they relate to the readings. As long as you know the main ideas of the readings, you will do well on the exams.
Make sure you know if Portelli is teaching the second half again, if he is, don't take it.

Make sure you understand how the readings relate to the songs and lectures! Actually, in general ensure you not only understand each piece of material, but the relationships between each component of the class.

Most ridiculous course I've ever taken. Requires little to no work, since it's certainly not necessary to do all of the readings to get a decent grade. Mitch is a pretty good lecturer. However, the guy they flew in from Italy to teach the second half of the course, Portelli, was awful. You won't learn much at all about Springsteen or sociology or anything at all really from this course. It's kinda a miracle that this course exists/counts as a real course to be honest, but if you need an SA or would like the be dumbfounded on a regular basis, I suppose this isn't the worst class you could take.
Not really what I was expecting; I would recommend only if Duneier is teaching the whole course
Only take if Mitch is teaching solo
Only take it if Mitch is teaching the whole thing, our guest lecture transformed the class into something much less interesting
Participate in lecture and do the readings!
Professor Duneier was awesome--not as much of a fan of Professor Portelli.  Definitely take it if Mitch is teaching it!!!!

Really interesting integration of academics and pop culture. The "interview days" 
(Wednesdays) were my favorite. Not too much work but a thoroughly enjoyable experience.
Sure, take it. It's pretty easy. Most of it is not actually about Bruce Springsteen, but rather just uses his songs as a springboard for discussing sociological ideas.
Take if Mitch is teaching it. It's not too hard.
Take it as a fifth.  Not the most organized class by any means.  Alda is a great preceptor.  Very easy workload, but it got annoying by the end.
Take it if Duneier teaches the whole thing.

Take it if Portelli isn't the guest professor. It's a bit disorganized and you may feel like you're learning stuff that's all over the place, but it's interesting and you get to hear musical performances almost every lecture.
Take it if its offered. Don't even think twice about it. In fact, take a year off school just to make sure you are here when it is offered again
Take it if you want a course that is fun at times... not the most engaging in the world
Take it with Mitch, but SOC is the only cool part of this course. Not so much the song analysis.
Take it!
Take it, but be prepared to be a little bored if POrtelli or someone other than Duneier teaches it.
Take it...overall it's interesting!
Take the course, but expect a bit of a slump in the second half.
Take this class

Take this course for Mitch and because you learn so much about a topic you might not otherwise. I really enjoyed lots of the lectures and readings and while Portelli was a little confusing and hard to hear, it is still a worthwhile course.
Take this course!  The workload isn't too heavy, but you will still get a lot out of it.  The lectures, readings, and precepts are all very interesting, even if sociology isn't your thing!
Take this course, it is very interesting, but be prepared to do a lot of reading if you want the A.
The material is very interesting, but I would not recommend the class if Portelli is lecturing.

This course had a lot of potential to be absolutely fantastic, and I think in the future it will be worth taking. However, this semester was rather disappointing, largely because the second half of the semester (taught by a guest professor) did not focus much on sociology and completely changed the pace of the course. The guest interviews stopped, and there was a lot more focus on Bruce Springsteen's lyrics and the meaning of living in the United States. In other semesters, I imagine the pattern established in the first half of the course would carry through to the end of the semester, making it a much more rewarding experience overall.

This course is really not that good, despite all the other reviews. The professors (Duneier and Portelli) were generally uninformative and seemed like they were pulling things out of nowhere to say during lecture just to fill up the 50 time slot. If you want a class where you can skip all the lectures and not miss out on learning, take it I guess. Otherwise, stay away. Dissapointing

This is extremely easy, but fans of Springsteen or people who want to feel like they're accomplishing something should be wary of this course. Virtually no written work, but the lectures are extremely varied in quality.
Too much sociology, not enough Bruce
Try to stay on top of readings, understand connections between materials, and have Mitch lecture the whole semester.
Unless the course is only taught by Duneier, don't take it. Given the second half of the semester, I would not recommend this course to friends.
beware that the midterm and finals are deflated -- a lot.
don't bother with the readings
easy peasy and interesting   fun   Duneier is great
has a lot of potential but a bit of a let down
if duneier does most lectures!
if you like springsteen's music I would take this
pretty easy course, not a lot of work
take it
take it, take it, take it
why
descrip: New Jersey's Bruce Springsteen and his E-Street Band chronicle life in the U.S. focusing on a range of topics from loneliness, community, and freedom, to teenage pregnancy, street car racing, girl watching, and the plight of veterans. Each Monday lecture will begin with one or more songs in order to focus on what sociology says about the issues they raise. During the Wednesday sessions, guests who have led lives like a character in that week's song will be interviewed in class. In keeping with Springsteen's commitment to local community and to his home state of New Jersey, the class will make a required field trip to Atlantic City.

title: Water: Keystone for Sustainable Development
descrip: See website

title: Being and Doing: Dance for Every Body
reviews: Definitely take this course if you want to learn more about modern art in general. Aynsley has a unique perspective on the area that will help students view concepts through a new lens.
I think playfulness was a really big part of this class, and also openness.

I would recommend this course to every single student at Princeton University. I know I would be skeptical reading this review, but the class encouraged me to do self reflection and explore my relationship with myself, my friendships and art. I learned so much from Aynsley, who is authentic and unique and beautiful and constantly striving to help her students grow and work through themselves. I loved loved loved this class.

Take this class. If this class fits into your schedule, take it, even if your schedule feels full. If this class doesn't fit into your schedule, make room for it for a semester.
If you are interested in a class that teaches you about LIVING then take this!!
It's a must-take whether you are experienced in dance or not.
One of the best courses you can take at Princeton.
TAKE IT!
Take it
Take it if you're interested! You can definitely get a lot out of it if you put in some effort.
Take this class...you won't become a better scholar, you'll become a better human being
descrip: This studio course is open to beginning and advanced dancers. We'll explore dance as a way to deepen both our self-knowledge and engagement with others. We'll delve into dance as meditation, using tools from ecstatic dance, yin yoga, and improvisation to establish a personal practice. We'll examine genre-bending performances occurring outside of theaters and study how dance reflects- and can change -contemporary issues, taking up such topics as power, class and gender. In final creative projects, we'll look at artists/dancers as entrepreneurs in the public sector and as catalysts for change in their own communities.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: Literature and the Arts
reviews: Be prepared for late nights and grueling days trying to keep up with all the reading and study the material to the vast depth that this course requires. However, the lectures are fantastic.
Depends on the year and the professors teaching it. Look at the books and also who is teaching, this course can either be amazing or pretty meh.

Don't drop out after first semester. It's hard, it's so hard, but it's honestly worth it. The professors, the students, the intellectual gain is unbelievable. Stay the course, do as much reading as you can because you lost a lot of motivation, but at the end you won't be sorry.
Finish your reading for the week the weekend before - it's how I was able to complete all of the readings. Always write your papers a week in advance so you will have time to edit.

If you are not a huge fan of philosophy, then this semester of HUM might be more challenging for you compared to the fall semester. Towards the end, a lot of the texts will be referenced/the professors will begin to make more connections to previously read texts, so if you don't keep up with the reading it might be more difficult for you to keep up. However, there are still a lot of interesting texts covered by this course, so don't be afraid to continue the course!

If you took the first semester of HUM, I cannot recommend highly enough that you complete the entire sequence. Distribution and concentration requirements will still be there next year; the opportunity to complete the HUM Sequence with your cohort won't be. If you're concerned about writing sem or having to take 5 classes in the spring, it is doable. There were a number of us who had HUM and writing sem as part of a 5-class spring semester, and while it was an absurd amount of writing, it was manageable and absolutely worthwhile. Advice includes: try to get at least a bit ahead on reading over Intersession and Spring Break, be on top of your game with consistent time management, and utilize the Writing Center and your grader's office hours for the papers.

For someone who hasn't taken HUM 216-217, I still highly recommend taking this course because even just one semester of HUM is an amazing intellectual experience. That said, I recommend that you consider waiting to take HUM 216-217 in the fall so you can take the entire sequence with HUM 218-219 the following spring. There's a real benefit to taking the entire sequence, and it is also totally doable for upperclassmen to take HUM (we had a sophomore in our class who loved it).

If you're looking at this course evaluation, you're either a fall HUM student looking to continue or someone who might join mid-year. In either case, you should sign up for HUM 218-219. It is fantastic with great professors in the spring and great readings. If you did it in the fall, as Professor Feeney has said you need "to complete the telos" and take it in the spring to reach modernity and be fully enlightened.

It may be more difficult to do the second half of the course due to spring semester's faster pace, but it is well worth it. I found that having HUM count as two classes was extremely helpful. It is possible to get the whole experience of the course by focusing on several readings you really enjoy and skimming the rest. While the pace and content is much different from that of HUM 216-217, the course still provides a good overview of how philosophy, literature, and the arts intersect with history. This year was heavy on German philosophy, but Kant is well worth reading--Hegel, Schopenhauer, and Nietzsche are influential but still sophists. A lot of my classmates disliked Descartes, but he is unique as the bridge between ancient and modern; he uses the old dialectical method which I found entertaining.

It's HUM. It's legendary for a reason. I don't how next semester's massive enrollment expansion will affect the quality of the course (I fear it will lose a measure of its camaraderie and close-knit community feel) but I'm sure it will still be more than worthwhile. It's a lot, but it's worth it.
It's a significant time commitment, and a lot of reading, but it's extremely worthwhile and any student interested in the humanities should strongly consider this sequence.

Read on time. It sounds cliche, but this course truly will be as helpful to you as you make it. No one will be checking up on you to make sure you are doing the reading - so be accountable to yourself and maybe even find other friends in the course who you can be accountable to to make sure you are doing the reading.

Second semester HUM was not as good as first semester HUM for me, but that could have been a result of the specific professors teaching the course and the fact that I did less reading. I guess my advice would be if you take second semester, try to stay on top of the readings still, because you will have less motivation, but enjoyment of the class is definitely proportional to the amount you read.
TAKE IT

TAKE IT! I'm going to start with the negatives, but read through this whole evaluation to get my positives at the end. I was disappointed by this semester as compared to first semester. HUM 218-219 was poorly organized in several ways: readings were not listed accurately on the syllabus, and we would only receive exact page selections in scattered emails containing Blackboard announcements; nobody told the students in advance that they needed to distinguish between specific works of certain authors like Montaigne and Leibniz for the final exam; preceptors especially at the beginning of the semester often had students give very general or fluffy comments on the texts, or dominated the conversation by essentially turning precept into lecture; the papers were spaced badly so that originally there was no Dean's Date paper and they all would have been due two weeks apart, crammed into February through April; the person giving the philosophy lectures (Daniel Cloud) was ineffective, etc. In spite of all these concerns, I greatly enjoyed HUM 218-219 for the many excellent lectures, precepts and readings whose high quality carried over from first semester, and I felt that I learned and grew exponentially by not only taking the first semester, but also completing the entire sequence. If you can only take one or the other, fall HUM is much more important and more formative--with more essential texts and, in 2014-2015, better professors and precepts--than spring HUM, and students are also more engaged and on top of their readings in fall HUM. The drop-off in student preparation reduces the quality of discussions in the spring, but this decline is compensated in part by the benefit of better knowing your classmates and therefore being able to anticipate and respond to their comments more. If at all possible, I would recommend taking both fall and spring HUM; the texts you read, the people you befriend and the conversations you have are really a magical experience that you cannot get elsewhere at this University. I also found that I grew greatly as a writer throughout HUM; the papers came much more easily to me after the first or second one of the spring. I feel that I am leaving the HUM Sequence with much better writing skills, improved speaking skills, appreciation for and much greater awareness of the trajectory of Western culture, friends who are like me interested in humanistic inquiry, and a sharper and more insightful mind. Anyone who likes to read and has an interest in the HUM Sequence should sign up: it will change your life, and I am so thankful for this opportunity.
Take it! It's a great experience and will give you so much knowledge.
Take it. You won't regret it. Honestly, the best class you can take freshman/ sophomore year at Princeton.
Take the HUM sequence! The course is fascinating, and the sense of community between the students should not be underestimated either.

Take this class! Do the readings that you find interesting, and don't worry too much about the ones that you don't - although you should probably go to lecture anyway. Go to lunch with your fellow students, and go to office hours with your professors. Show up to precept 5 mins early - sometimes great discussions start then. Make the most of this class - it doesn't last forever, and it's a one-of-a-kind experience!
Take this course for the books. Precepts, lectures, essays, and the exam are not very inspiring.

Take this course if you are willing to make it your absolute primary commitment and if you love reading. The professors are the best around, the syllabus will enrich your soul. But be warned that this course will dominate you, you won't be able to stay on top of it.
Taking it is preferable to not taking it. However, if only one semester of HUM is possible, take the first one.
The only regrets you'll have from HUM is having to spend so much money on the reading list and not being able to finish all of the amazing readings.

You get as much out as you put in. You can choose to do few readings, but you will not learn much. The more reading you do, the more the course is worth it. It's not worth it if you hardly do any reading.
prereqs: Students who wish to enroll but who did not complete HUM 216-217 in fall term 2014 should email Lin DeTitta, ldetitta@princeton.edu..
descrip: This team-taught double credit course examines European texts, works of art and music from the Renaissance to the modern period. Readings, lectures, and discussions are complemented by films, concerts, museum visits and special events. It is the second half of an intensive interdisciplinary introduction to Western culture that includes history, religion, philosophy, literature and the arts. Although most students will have taken 216 - 217, it is possible for freshmen and sophomores to join at this point.

title: The Civilization of the High Middle Ages
reviews: A great course to expand your knowledge of the middle ages and get a glimpse of the variety it contains. The assignments are very manageable and Jordan's lectures are great.

I know everyone says in all-caps "TAKE THIS COURSE," but I am going to tell you: Take this course. It will transform you perspective not only of the Middle Ages (which rule), but also about modern thought in our world today. Best professor and lecturer I have ever met. I would take this course again and again if it were possible. Bottom line: You are missing out if you don't take this gem of a course.
If you're interested in the middle ages, I would strongly recommend this class. The lectures are interesting and the readings are great.
Professor Jordan is very engaging and the time period is worth knowing more about.
Read the textbook weekly.
Read the textbook! It's very helpful for the exams.
Take it and learn from a master.

Take it!! It is a QUALITY choice for fulfilling your HA requirement.  If you are interested in the subject at all, you will love it.  Even if not, Prof. Jordan is hilarious and makes it interesting.  (it is also very little work, except for readings - show up to lecture and attend precept, and you're golden)
Try to get into Professor Jordan's precept if you can!
While there are better medieval classes-professors at Princeton, that  is only because the medieval department is so strong. I would strongly recommend taking this but less than Helmut's class
recommend if interested in Middle Ages/already have a background in European history
stay on top of the readings
descrip: In lectures, to provide my interpretation (and a conspectus of differing interpretations) of the civilization of Western Europe, 11th-14th century; by the readings, to introduce students to the variety of surviving sources; through the paper, to give students a taste of doing medieval history.

title: Religion and Public Life
descrip: Presentation and critical discussion of empirical research in progress by participants. Focuses on the use of social science methods in the study of religion and on applications of recently published work about religion and society. Includes an emphasis on religion and public policy in the U. S. and in comparative perspective.

title: Algebraic Geometry
descrip: Introduction to affine and projective algebraic varieties over fields.

title: Research Seminar in Ancient and Medieval Japanese History
descrip: This course is a research and writing seminar that introduces major historical methods of research in ancient and medieval Japan. In addition to weekly research assignments, students identify a research topic by the third week of the class, and complete a research paper at the end of the semester (entailing 15-20 pages). Instruction focuses on research methods and topics, although some reading of sources also occurs.

title: Quantitative Physiology & Tissue Design
reviews: Amazing course. Take it please please please. Especially if you're interested in both medicine and engineering. This course allows you to see how to apply engineering concepts to modeling and describing the body. Great for someone math-oriented. There's a lot of differential equations, so definitely be sure you have the math background. I can't imagine not knowing diff eq and transport/fluid dynamics while taking this class. If you have taken these classes, it'll be a piece of cake. If you haven't, it'll be a lot harder. But overall the best course I've taken here at Princeton. TAKE IT. YOU HAVE TO. NELSON'S AMAZING.

First of all, it's important that students are aware of the requirements for this class, if the registrar hasn't yet updated them.  Students should have taken MAT 301 and MAE 305 in order to be in this class.  I hadn't fulfilled these requirements and had only taken the equivalent of MAT 103; therefore, I lacked the base needed to understand the math in this class. With that being said, I really enjoyed what I was able to understand and especially enjoyed the hands on experiments and dissections.  I think this was a really great course-- Allison (preceptor) was very willing to help and the material was really enjoyable.  I would definitely recommend it to pre-med engineers.

I would highly recommend this course to students if they have any general interest and an engineering background. The level of math would be difficult (though not insurmountable) if you do not frequently take STEM courses.

It is very quantitative, there is a lot of math. It felt like CBE341: Pipes / Transport on body parts. If that's the kind of thing you're interested in, then take this class. I didn't get much of the "tissue design" aspect of the class.

Professor Nelson is one of my favorite professors at Princeton! She is funny, kind, and very clear in her teaching. This class also made me appreciate how amazing our bodies are! Great field trips and demonstrations and a wonderful course.
Really great class with very interesting material- just be prepared for pretty technical and quantitative problem sets and tests.

TAKE IT!!! This was probably my favorite course at Princeton. It is really interesting and really well-taught. Definitely take it if you are at all interested! Although a really strong math background and probably CBE 341 or some class like that would be really helpful.
Take it if you're interested in studying the body from a quantitative perspective, the problem sets aren't too bad and the material is interesting.
Take this course! It does require some background knowledge in math (i.e., algebra and some differential equations) but nothing too out of the ordinary.
Take this course!! It's very exciting and teaches a lot on how the body is modeled with math.
The problem sets are definitely doable, but I would start fairly early so that you can go to office hours and ask questions.
descrip: A treatment of the quantitative tools to understand the human body. Course reviews cell biology and anatomy, then examines cells, tissues, and organs using principles from engineering kinetics and transport processes. Topics include: cell physiology; organ system physiology (including the cardiovascular, renal, and respiratory systems); and pathophysiology. Clinical treatments for human disease will also be analyzed.

title: Apocalypse Now
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Comparative Transformations in the Near East and Eurasia
descrip: This seminar is comparative study of the political, intellectual, religious, and cultural transformations of the lands of the Near East and Eurasia from the late seventeenth to the early twentieth centuries. The course investigates the common geopolitical, economic, and intellectual challenges that Western Europe posed to the societies of the Near East and Eurasia. It seeks to understand the responses of the latter on their own terms, and to relate them to each other. The course aims to stimulate students to move beyond regional particularities and think outside the models and assumptions provided by European historiography.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: (same as for ISC 233 evaluation)

If you are passionate about science and research, this is the class for you. Do be prepared for a large workload (40  hours per week), but what you get out of the class is tremendous: you learn topics you would never touch on in an intro class (statistical mechanics, quantum) and really learn the fundamental physics behind what make chemistry and biology work. On top of that, you'll form an incredibly tight community with the rest of the ISC students.
Keep up with the work. Don't miss class.
Look at other evaluation.
Problem sets during second semester seemed easier; however, the material is more mathematical.
See ISC 233.
See other.
YAS ISC'S AMAZING DO IT DO IT DO IT.
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: W. Bialek, T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti (CBE); H. Yang (CHM); R. Sedgewick (COS); E. Wieschaus (MOL); C. Broedersz, J. Gadd, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session each week.

title: Friendship
reviews: Great reading list and very engaging set up . Offered a welcome break from the traditional classroom setting / seminar style class
If Princeton decides to bring Professor Love back, take a course with her!
Professor Love is SO COOL and this class was so much fun. The pedagogical experiments keep things interesting and the readings and conversations in class are so engaging
Take it!
Take it! And be ready to read and discuss...otherwise class time won't be interesting.
take it
take this class if you have the chance i highly recommend it!!!!
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the history and philosophy of friendship. We will consider friendship in relation to eros and same-sex desire; as a recurrent trope in literary history; as a mode of political thought; and in relation to questions of representation and truth. We will reflect at length on recent queer rethinkings of friendship as a way of life, and consider the intersection of class, race, and gender in the making of queer communities. In addition, this course will explore the classroom as a space for the rethinking of social relations.

title: Energy Conversion and the Environment: Transportation Applications
reviews: Definitely take it! One of the best MAE classes I've taken. Professor Mueller is wonderful and the class is incredibly interesting. The problem sets don't take an unreasonable amount of time.
If you have any interest in engines or chemistry or energy or cars or planes or science, TAKE THIS COURSE.

If you need an upper level MAE elective, this is it. I didn't really want to take engines or rockets, but this was definitely the right choice! It is so well taught and Prof. Mueller takes incredible care of his students. If you are interested in engines or just want a very well taught course, TAKE IT!
It's a good course, it teaches about engines
My favorite course at Princeton.  Take it.

Take it! Get somebody who's already taken the class to give you Professor Dryer's old notes before the class starts, and then just read them start to finish over a weekend. That will really help orient you to the class and give you a head start when you reach the concepts in lecture. Wish I'd done that over winter break!

This course is not super easy, but well worth taking. It is my favorite MAE course I've taken at this school, largely because Prof. Mueller is such a good lecturer and the topics covered are diverse/interesting.
You'll work hard, but it's worth it.
requires a decent amount of work, but definitely worth it. you learn some really cool practical and theoretical knowledge about engines
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or equivalent, or by permission of instructor..
descrip: Overview of energy utilization in and environmental impacts of propulsion systems for ground and air transportation. Roughly half of the course will be devoted to reciprocating engines for ground transportation, and the other half of the course will be devoted to gas turbine engines for air transportation. The course will focus on device efficiency/performance and emissions with future outlooks for improvements in these areas including alternative fuels and alternative device concepts. Relevant thermodynamics, chemistry, fluid mechanics, and combustion fundamentals will be reviewed or introduced and will permeate the course material.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Development Disasters: Unintended Consequences
descrip: Economic growth and development projects often come with unintended consequences. Large scale infrastructure projects can lead to massive resettlement of local populations, and development projects can result in environmental damage. This course reviews these effects, both socio-political as well as environmental, and identify ways to mitigate or avoid `development disasters'. The `disasters' to be examined include human-made issues as well as tsunamis, earthquakes, flooding, etc. The link between human-made and natural disasters constitute an important dimension of this course.

title: Modern Latin America since 1810
reviews: A lot of work. But Professor Karl will be one of the most engaging and caring professors you will have. Take it, enjoy it, but don't be shocked if it's your heaviest class.

Absolutely take this course. Professor Karl has an equal devotion and passion in the subject of Latin America and the success of his students. One of the best professors at Princeton by far. Incredible person and incredible class.
An entire continent and 200  years of history condensed into one semester.

Definitely take it! You definitely have to do the readings and listen closely in lecture and go to precept to understand what's going on but it's so worth it. If you have any interest in Latin America take it!
Definitely worth taking if you enjoy history courses
Do the readings.
I would highly recommend taking this class. There is a lot of reading (200 per week), but the course is well worth it, to experience Professor Karl if nothing else.
I would recommend this class to anyone with a remote interest in Latin America. Professor Karl is amazing.

If you're willing to work hard, this is a great course. Not really the best to PDF, you won't get much out of it, but if you want to learn more about Modern Latin America from economic, social, and political perspectives, it's a fine course.

It's a lot of material--200 years worth of a whole content means details fly by and you have to keep track of a lot of figures you've never heard of.  Pay attention in lecture or you'll lose sense of where in the trajectory of the Latin American story you are, and the essays and readings will be more difficult.
Keep on top of the readings

One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. There readings are all interesting. The assignments are good as well. Karl is engaging and also really really friendly. Take it even as a non-history/humanities person.
Record the lectures and then go back into them afterwards - it's the only way you'll get all the information you need.

Stay on top of the reading or at least to the point where you understanding what are the major factors and themes that contribute to the guiding questions of the class (he states the three questions in the first lecture). Always remember that he is an email away or a short walk to Dickinson. Don't fear asking the question that is on your mind because 95 percent of the time more that 95 percent of the class is thinking of that question too. Don't you dare miss a single lecture, they are worth gold and more and must not be missed. I admired every moment of this class and it hit a special place in my heart. I was saddened to realize that I know nothing of the history of my Latino heritage. I thank Robert Karl from here on out for helping me learn of who I am and what my people can become. High praise for this class and Karl and I pray that you consider taking his class-it's not to be missed.
TAKE THE CLASS Professor Karl is fantastic and it's a super interesting and important subject

TAKE THIS COURSE! 
It was one of the best choices I've made at Princeton and Professor Karl and his preceptors are the best. You can tell that they all care about all of the students.
Take it if you're interested!
Take it! It's certainly work but very valuable and thought-provoking. Really great class if you have an interest in history and/or Latin America.
Take it! It's well taught and really interesting.

Take it! Seriously!
Take it seriously!
The readings are long, the lectures are dense, and the course is fast, but it's worth it.
Take it. Professor Karl rocks.
Take this course ! It is a must do if you are even mildly interested in Latin America. Professor Karl is an amazing professor and really cares about his students.
Take this course if you are at all interested in Latin America--but be sure to do the readings and go to every single lecture. It's trite, but it's true: you will get out what you put in.
Take this course only if you care very much for Latin America and want to learn more about development. If not, this course will not be interesting to you.

The readings are long but really interesting, especially in the later half of the semester, the professor and preceptors are so engaging, definitely take it and learn a lot. Lectures are overwhelmingly informative, but the preceptor was great about breaking the material down into the big ideas afterwards.
This course is a lot of work and not to be taken lightly, but fascinating and well worth the time and effort if you're ready to commit to it.

This course is really great. It gives you a broad overview of Latin American history since 1810 and provides you a sense of what was happening in many different countries during this time. Professor Karl is a great professor and lecturer. He knows a lot about Latin America, and it is obvious that he cares deeply about his students. I would highly recommend this course to others.

This course is very important to unlearning US-centric misconceptions about Latin America, especially if you're going into politics/WWS. I highly recommend taking HIS 303 with Candiani first to get the colonial basis, but Prof Karl does a good summary of that course and this covers independence up to present day Latin America. There's a lot of national case studies with emphasis on politics, the state, national and global economy, etc. Readings work as a supplement, they're usually engaging but can be pretty lengthy. Professor Karl definitely knows his stuff, especially on his specialty, Colombia, so expect a lot on that. Overall definitely worth taking.

This is a good history course to take, especially if you're interested in Latin America (Bolivar, slavery, Castro, etc.).  Teresa was a good preceptor.  Be prepared for a lot of work and larger readings in the second half of the semester.
This is a great course! Readings are really interesting, lectures are fast-paced but informative and fun, overall a truly interesting and engaging class!
descrip: This course surveys the main themes of Latin American history from independence to the present. The main focus is on the interaction between states and citizens, social relations, and economic development.

title: American Mysticism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Research Methods in Demography
prereqs: POP 501/ECO 571/SOC 531 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Source materials used in the study of population; standard procedures for the measurement of fertility, mortality, natural increase, migration, and nuptiality; and uses of model life tables and stable population analysis and other techniques of estimation when faced with inaccurate or incomplete data are studied.

title: Topics in German Culture and Society - German Speeches (1800-2014)
reviews: Don't be intimidated to speak up. Participation is key to understanding.
Jump at the chance to take a class with Wegmann.  He is charismatic, friendly, and insightful.  You will learn a lot, and enjoy it.
Not a ton of reading or work and an interesting seminar.
Practice your German before taking this and put in the time to really study the material. Wegmann is an awesome guy.
Take a 200-level before taking this course. At the very least, only enroll if you are sincerely confident in your German proficiency. If you aren't, it will make participating in class hard.
Take it if you're interested in German media.
Take it.
very interesting class. take it if you have a fine knowledge of German history, literature and politics, with some political theory background. Take it only after GER0207 or similar classes...
descrip: We will read, hear and/or watch notable speeches of the 19th and 20th century and analyze them from historical, political, rhetorical and media historical perspectives. After formulating their own analysis of a speech, students will discuss its immediate and long term effects. List of speakers: Luther, Goethe, Bismarck, Freud, Hitler, Adenauer, C. Wolf, Brandt, Dutschke, Merkel, etc.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: At times, this course is treated more like a cognitive psychology class than a cognitive neuroscience class, but overall, it provides important neuroscience information for one considering a certificate or concentration in neuroscience.
Go to lecture, understand the experiments and the results, and take the lab section.
I liked the subject matter more than the class itself.

I would advise students to take thorough notes because the exam questions are based primarily on the lectures and you can use your notes on the exams. The book is not very useful unless you are confused about a topic and want to look at it in more detail. Treat the book as more of a reference, so you do not need to read the entire thing.
Interesting course, but completely different from NEU 258.
Interesting, but wouldn't take it if you don't need to.
It is a lot of application-based learning.  It does not require much time outside of the classroom.  Take it if you're interested in neuroscience!

It's not a very well taught class. Make sure you ask questions about all concepts and experiments covered in class that you don't understand, otherwise you'll have a lot of trouble studying. Also take good notes.

Lectures are interesting. If you have a general interest in the material, take the precept. The first 4 or 5 lab sessions are the worst classes I've ever taken in college. The second half of lab is fine, but it doesn't really make up for it.

Not nearly as good as 258. Some interesting material, but you'll have to do the work yourself to understand it. The lectures aren't too detailed which seems strange, but then again neither are the assessments. Strange course, but not exceedingly painful.
Only take if you have taken 258.  Do not expect to be amused by the lectures.  You should really have a love of neuroscience or you will not enjoy this class.
TAKE THIS COURSE it is so great and Yael is great and it is great.
Take if if you have to.
Take it if you have to for the major/certificate, but if you're just interested in neuro, take 258 or some other class.  This was a frustrating, boring experience.
Take it if you want to take higher-level neuroscience classes. It's easier if you take 258 first, but I didn't and was fine. Otherwise, read a book and use your time for something else!
Take it if you're interested in neuroscience! Probably a good STL. My impression is that the lab version is easier than the precept version.
Take really well organized notes
Take this course if you are genuinely interested in neuroscience.
Take this if you're getting a certificate or concentrating in NEU, but for general interest, I still preferred 258 to 259
The course goes into a lot of detail, so if you're not really interested in all the nit and grit... you might get lost sometimes. Otherwise, its a great course.

You have to go into this course with the right attitude. If you decide  to enjoy the course and get the most out of it, you will have a great experience. If you decide to hate it before you've even started, you will probably nitpick and find reasons to dislike it. It's an excellent course, so just make sure you're taking it because you love neuroscience. There are no other reasons to take this course. Not a good choice to fulfill your EC or STL or whatever. Also, don't take the lab if you don't have to.
if you can avoid it, avoid it
if you have to take it, then do, but if you are not planning on pursuing a neuro major or certificate, don't..
only take if you need it. otherwise kind of unnecessary
take advantage of prof niv-- she is a truly caring person and a great mentor!
take it! It's a lot more "theoretical" if you will but extremely fascinating and Professor Niv is great
take it, but make sure you understand the type of material involved. a lot of students come in imagining something different for cog neuro
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention, language, memory, learning and decision making and executive functions of the frontal lobe. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed. Labs will involve hands-on experience with behavioral experiments, fMRI, EEG and computational modeling, including design of the experiment, analysis etc.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Like all other Chinese courses at Princeton, CHI 304 is very busy and requires a lot of time. In the end, it's worth it if you have a genuine passion and interest for learning Chinese.
Put in the work
Review the chapter readings more than once before going to class
Take it!
Yes if you are interested in the certificate program of an intensive course. It is challenging/very time-consuming.
You should take this if you want to learn Chinese
prereqs: CHI 303 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of CHI 303, designed to improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of newspaper essays and commentaries.

title: Ecology and Epidemiology of Parasites and Infectious Diseases
reviews: Alright course, but you don't exactly have a choice if you study abroad.

Definitely, definitely go to Panama. Andy is fantastic at telling stories, so whenever you have the chance, ask him about his life. He is amazing to talk to, and gives incredible lectures. A drawback is that he is incredibly whimsical and changes the schedule a lot, but you can deal with that.
It was not my favorite course of the semester, but it was pretty good. Definitely go to Panama!
It's a good deal: it's in Panama, the lecture material is very interesting, and it is not too much work. Dobson is a solid lecturer and a fascinating guy to talk to.

Stay engaged during lecture, and start thinking about potential projects early during the course. The course is a fabulous opportunity to get to know Professor Dobson, who is full of anecdotes and cool experiences - ask him questions during and after class and make the most of it!
This class was not much work. It was fun, but don't expect Dobson to help you much.

This course opened my eyes to how influential and prevalent parasites are, and it's very interesting to learn about the effects on animal behavior and plant growth. You'll see some really cool parasites in dissection of organisms you wouldn't have even suspected had an infection.  It sounds like the course changes quite a bit every year, but it will probably be a bit disorganized; the instructors are teaching, but they are also on "vacation".
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: An introduction to the biology of viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, worms, arthropods, and parasitic plants. The major emphasis will be on the parasites of animals and plants, with further study of the epidemiology of infectious diseases in human populations. Studies of AIDS, anthrax, and worms, and their role in human history will be complemented by ecological and evolutionary studies of fig wasps, measles, myxomatosis, and communities of parasitic helminths. The course combines lectures with daily field laboratories to explore the dynamics and abundance of parasite in a variety of host species in the Panama Canal zone.

title: Beginning Czech II
prereqs: Prerequisite: CZE 101.
descrip: This course builds on the introductory course CZE101 and is designed to teach the basics of Czech grammar, vocabulary, and communication in a variety of situations. The course focuses on all four language skills: reading, writing, listening comprehension, and speaking. It introduces the rich Central European traditions as they manifest in Czech culture, visual art, film, music and literature.

title: Psychology for Policy Analysis and Implementation
descrip: Course covers basic concepts and experimental findings of psychology that contribute to an understanding of the effects of policy on human behavior and well-being; and psychological factors that affect the formulation, communication, and execution of policy. Topics include a descriptive analysis of boundedly rational judgment and decision making, a consideration of social motives and attitudes, and an introduction to the ways in which agents influence and negotiate with one another, including an examination of the psychological roots of conflict.

title: Structural Design
reviews: Always go to precept.

Hard to see the relevance of some of the issues to what we will engage with as architects (e.g., designing the re-bar in a reinforced concrete beam) so unless interested specifically in structures as an engineer would not recommend
It's structures. You have to take it. Maybe you'll learn some things, maybe not, it depends on if you're awake.
Keep up with homework.
Take the course if you want to know how building works.
Try to get out of it
good course by a great instructor
descrip: Introduction to the design of building structures of steel, timber and reinforced concrete.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II
reviews: Don't get a B-.
If you can get a better TA, go for it
If you come in without a strong math education like I did, this class was very helpful in teaching the topics we would need.
It takes a lot of time if you don't have a lot of math background.

It would be really helpful if you were to read ahead and be prepared to ask questions during class. Although the amount of time that you will need to spend on assignments makes this really hard to do. Read the recommended books, start working on assignments early, and go to office hours.
Study
This course is much better than MAE501. Unlike 501, the workload is significant but not unreasonable and a significant portion of the material covered is useful.
ask Phil questions, take his quarters
the learning curve would be steep if the student has no solid math background. though tough, you will learn A LOT.
descrip: A complementary presentation of theory, analytical methods, and numerical methods. The objective is to impart a set of capabilities commonly used in the research areas represented in the Department and more broadly in engineering and the physical and biological sciences. Analytical methods will be emphasized, but standard computational packages will be made available and some assignments will be designed to use them. Topics will include Complex variables, PDE, Fourier and Laplace Transforms, and a brief introduction to numerical methods for ODE and PDE.

title: Metabolic Engineering
reviews: For a senior spring course, this was more work than I desired. Make sure you're really interested in the subject before taking the class, because the non-seniors in the class will be on top of the readings (you're asked to read a couple papers for each class in the second half of the course) and ready for discussion, and you may just be stressing about thesis. You'll have to spend a good deal of time memorizing lots of metabolic pathways for the midterm, and in prepping for the final proposal assignment. However, the class does provide a great overview of metabolic engineering, and if you're truly interested in the field and willing to put in the time, it will be worthwhile.
Highly recommend it. Weekly work really isn't bad, but beware that the midterm is a challenge, and the final project is worth a lot.
I think this class is great to PDF. Wish I could've.
If you're interested, take it! Taking biochem might be helpful, but its doable if you dont.
Professor Brynildsen is great!
Read literature carefully.

This is a good class for coming up with personal research ideas. 

Second half of the semester is talking about current research, which is cool. First half is background info, which is quite dense at times.

Very cool class that actively engages students in talking with a professor on interesting topics in the field. The midterm and lecture material before then are annoying, but afterwards it becomes very minimal work and you get a lot out of it. Brynildsen cares about a lot about his students, even though he often times does not show it.
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215, or equivalent. Designed for sophomores, juniors, and seniors in engineering, molecular biology, and chemistry..
descrip: Introduction to the engineering of metabolism. The objective of this course is to introduce students to current techniques and challenges within the field of metabolic engineering. Specific topics will range from applications for energy and the environment to human health. The course will also include lectures from industrial speakers, a mock NSF panel review of research proposals, and debates structured as reviewers discussing the appropriateness of manuscripts for publication.

title: Physical Optics
prereqs: PHY 104 or ELE 351..
descrip: This course presents an introduction to wave dynamics and imaging. Topics include geometrical and Fourier optics, diffraction, microscopy, photography and 3D imaging. Applications in computational and biomedical imaging will be stressed.

title: Creative Non-Fiction
reviews: Anyone who has the slightest interest should apply!
CHANGED MY LIFE
Do all the readings. They're worth it.

If you can take this class and have any interest whatsoever in writing (journalism/creative-non-fiction), you must not pass this up. I can almost guarantee that you won't receive the kind of detailed written and oral feedback that McPhee provides. He approaches your work as though he is an editor of The New Yorker reviewing your piece for publication. He wants to retain your voice while eliminating all the ugly excess that often stands in its way. Be sure to listen closely to him.
If you love writing, apply. Exposes you to all kinds of jobs in the creative non-fiction world, especially but not limited to writing
Keep an open mind.
Listen to McPhee-- outline, draft, and rewrite.  It really makes your writing better.

Professor McPhee cares SO much about his students and the course. He puts a ton of effort into making sure his students learn. I highly recommend taking this to anyone who has even the slightest interest in literature, creative nonfiction or journalism. 
McPhee is a patient professor who has great passion for the craft of nonfiction and compassion for his students. Professor McPhee is such a sweet professor who lives up to his legacy of being dedicated, talented, and caring.
Start the pieces early (two weeks in advance); it is difficult and stressful to write well (to write for the purpose of writing) in a condensed amount of time.

Take this course.  Professor McPhee is a Princeton treasure.  Within the class there exists a spirit of collaboration and camaraderie (likely due to the fact that it is only sophomores) that one is often hard-pressed to find at the school. You will become a much stronger writer and probably a happier college student after taking this course

This is far and away the best course at Princeton. If you are interested in writing, apply! Do not pass up this chance to learn from Professor McPhee. There is no professor in Princeton who cares as much about his students and their work.

You have to put in the effort to make the bi-monthly assignments really worth the effort. Put time into thinking about your topic and the presentation of the topic. The course rests on your engagement outside of seminar rather than in it.

You will get exactly as much out of this class as you put into it.
