Put in a lot, because Professor McPhee will read your work very carefully and with the utmost respect, and give you line-by-line feedback, so you really do want to do a good job. Also be prepared to stay engaged for a 3-hour-long seminar which can sometimes be hard on a Monday afternoon, but there is a break in between and you can get coffee from the cafe across the way. Take great notes and ask questions -- you will value these notes throughout your future writing career.
prereqs: Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu/journalism/courses. For the writing sample, submit whatever you consider to be your best work, from any source, written since you came to Princeton, including, if you like, a new piece written for the application..
descrip: This is a course in factual writing and what has become known as literary nonfiction, emphasizing writing assignments and including several reading assignments from the work of John McPhee and others. Enrollment is limited to 16 second-year students, by application only.

title: Electronic Commerce
reviews: Definitely take if you need an additional ORFE departmental, it's one of the easiest.
Great class if you are looking for something very hands-on and if you have an entrepreneurial spirit.
Great guest speakers.

I recommend it, but at the end of the day, your enjoyment of the class will come down to whether or not you can tolerate Kornhauser. If so, it's an easy, fun ORFE class. If not, you'll hate Kornhauser with a burning passion by the end of the professor, but it will still be an easy class.

If you actually want to learn E-Commerce, this is probably not the class for you (check out the EGR classes instead). That being said, if you're taking this, you're probably an ORFE looking for an easy departmental, and this satisfies the bill. There aren't too many assignments, and the assignments themselves are simple coding (html/javascript/php) assignments with most of the code given to you. Guest lecturers are pretty interesting so it's worth it just to attend them and learn from people who've done interesting things in different areas. Not really sure what I've learned about e-commerce, but on the bright side I've heard from a range of interesting speakers.
Just go to all lectures and precepts.

Most people recommend taking a course with Kornhauser at some point. I'd say take it for a departmental to avoid problem sets, proofs, and R, since his courses are the only non-quantitative ORFE courses. You'll have to design websites, but you're given a lot of guidance to do so and Chenyi is super helpful!
Not a crazy amount of work, interesting guest speakers, but not the most organized class. A lot of what you learn is out of date as well

This class is a mixed bag, and honestly, you get from it what you put into it. You can get away with sitting in the back on your computer during lecture doing other work, but if you do that, you miss out on interesting class discussions about e-commerce today or hearing what some alumni guest speakers have to say about the real world (plus you are rude). Try to start your final project early so that you can get a lot of feedback as the semester progresses and so your reading week isn't consumed by this class.
Would definitely take this class.
prereqs: COS 126 or equivalent.
descrip: Electronic commerce, traditionally the buying and selling of goods using electronic technologies, extends to essentially all facets of human interaction when extended to services, particularly information. The course focuses on both the software and the hardware aspects of traditional aspects as well as the broader aspects of the creation, dissemination and human consumption electronic services. Covered will be the physical, financial and social aspects of these technologies

title: Cultures of the Afro-Diaspora
reviews: Cultures of the Afro-Diaspora is an incredible course. I am so sad that Professor Vazquez is no longer teaching at Princeton. However, I took the class with several students doing the LAS certificate and they suggested that similar courses like that do exist in the department, so try to take some if you can!
If you are considering taking this course, make sure you do all the readings. In a seminar class, this is very important.
Like all courses it is important that you do all reading assignments and attend every seminar because the writing assignment use all course material.
Take this course!
descrip: This course analyzes key readings and studies on Afro-diasporic cultures across the Americas in the 20th century. From reggae's unrelenting rhythms to the dances that move carnaval, the New World thrums with activity from populations that have persevered conditions of displacement to create new aesthetic forms. We will investigate expansive notions of blackness that move beyond national paradigms and the productive pressure that performance puts on ontologies of identity such as the Afro-Latino, African American, and West Indian in theory and literature. Artists include Bob Marley, Katherine Dunham, Jorge Ben, and Patato y Totico.

title: Byzantium in the 10th Century: The Age of Reconquest
reviews: Definitely take it if you have a legitimate interest in the near east and late Roman world, or the early middle ages-- it's a lot of reading and you have to really engage with it to get everything out of the class that you can. Very rewarding.
Professor Haldon's class was very straight forward, with informative readings on a variety of topics and lots of opportunities to read aloud particularly interesting topics.

This is a great source if you're committed to attending and staying engaged. The readings take time but are not too arduous, and the weekly (informal) presentations allow each student to explore the topics that most interest them.
prereqs: Any history course on Byzantine or Medieval history..
descrip: This course introduces the social, political, and military history of the 10th-century Byzantine state at the height of its power, and seeks to understand the background to the recovery of Byzantine political strength at that time. These dynamics will be studied in the context of internal social, economic, and administrative developments, as well as in the context of the wider political world. In particular, we will focus on relations with the Abbasid Caliphate and the regional emirates of Syria and Iraq, as well as with the various western powers with which Byzantium had dealings.

title: Taboo and Transgression
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Russian Literature (Half-Term) - The Poetics of Place in Russian Literature
descrip: Using Toporov's conception of the "Petersburg text" as a point of departure, the class moves in various directions, from the city to the countryside, from the center to the periphery, from the Russian to the Soviet empire. For the final paper, students work on a text not on the reading list.

title: Writing and Urban Life
reviews: DEFINITELY take this course.

Have a pretty advanced level of reading Portuguese and know how to read Spanish. Also talk to the professor early, weeks in advance before a project is due because it may be difficult to meet with him as the deadline approaches.

If you're interested in studying Brazilian and Portuguese literature and social/historical contexts surrounding the readings, then you'll like this class. If you don't want to put effort into doing the readings and trying to understand them, then the three hours of class will drag on and you won't enjoy it. The professor is wonderful and has a lot of super-sharp insights that add a lot to the class.
Professor Carvalho is so much fun, and very approachable.
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission.
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar explores different writers' representations of urban experience, and how the evolution of cities has been shaped by writing. Issues to be approached will include the impact of technological developments and urban transformations on literary imaginaries and city life; the interface between literacy, orality and visual cultures; relationships between fiction, poetry, and social history; dichotomies between urban and natural; intersections between modernity, writing, and city planning.

title: Irreversible Processes in Plasmas
reviews: Keep up with the material and you will reap the benefits.
Take this class and you would learn a lot.
descrip: Introduction to theory of fluctuations and transport in plasma. Origins of irreversibility. Random walks, Brownian motion, and diffusion; Langevin and Fokker-Planck theory. Fluctuation-dissipation theorem; test-particle superposition principle. Statistical closure problem. Derivation of kinetic equations from BBGKY hierarchy and Klimontovich formalism; properties of plasma collision operators. Classical transport coefficients in magnetized plasmas; Onsager symmetry. Introduction to plasma turbulence, including quasilinear theory. Applications to current problems in plasma research.

title: Queering Civility: Unruly Performances and Troubled Public Norms
descrip: Calls for civility saturate contemporary public culture. Cultural commentators look to the promise of civility to solve the "problems" and challenges of stabilizing public norms. Civility is invested with the hope of regulating unseemly, offensive and non-normative practices across a variety of contexts. In this course, we will examine civility as an object for which we long and which in its various manifestations can be seen doing the work of stabilizing dominant norms. We will examine case studies in which calls for civility are often complicit with established norms that perpetuate inequalities.

title: The History of American Capitalism
reviews: A great history departmental, will present Levy's provocative model of capitalism as a social system rather than a strictly economic one.  He traces the development of myths and popular opinions on the marketplace and its role in society alongside the actual changes taking place in global capital flows, rising US preeminence, and various moments of crisis.  There are a ton of readings, but they're presented in a Pequod that makes it very easy to skim/not read and still do well.  That said, the readings are their own justification, and wading your way through them will be incredibly rewarding.
Definitely one of the most interesting courses I've taken. It's not easy but it is fun and I enjoyed the readings and discussions.
Do the readings and go to class
Easy interesting course, Levy's very knowledgeable. Good for taking it normally or if you want a really easy pdf.
Every student should take this course, particularly anyone interested in American politics or the future of the American and global economy.

Great history class...lectures are interesting and applicable. Helps if you took AP US Hist. in high school because then you have an even  better understanding of the context of what is learned in class. Get Chris Florio as your preceptor if you can!
I think everyone should take this course to have a basic understanding of major changes over the course of American economic history and Professor Levy is awesome.
I would say to attend as many precepts and lectures as possible and to really follow along with the material; it's a great course.
I would strongly recommend other students to take this course, and to take the readings seriously.

If the nature of the class interests you and you are prepared to go to all the lectures, take this course! Professor Levy is an awesome speaker and the course structure is really interesting. A lot of the primary source readings are really cool, but there is a ton of reading and some of it pretty slow. You can get away with not reading much, but you won't get nearly as much out of it.

If you don't do all the readings and just do most of them, this course will still be great. However, if you challenge yourself to do the reading every week and come to lecture/precept ready to discuss, this course will be twice as memorable and fun.
Interesting class, minimal workload so good for PDF. I really liked this class because it wasn't about memorizing facts, but rather more about analyzing history.
It's definitely worth taking even if its out of general interest.
It's not about 'capitalism' in the way that you think - there's a lot of social / cultural stuff going on.  Anyone interested in American history would like this course
Levy is a great lecturer, and the reading list ensures you will be engaged and fascinated all the way through.

Make sure you read most of each weeks readings and skim the longer ones. The secondaries usually shed light on the concepts of the primaries.They're typically longer so I found it helpful to skim them.
Read the primary sources and try to connect the concepts to important lecture notes. Secondary sources aren't so important.
Start the reading for each week as early as you can because its a pretty heavy amount of it.

TAKE THIS COURSE! I liked this class so much, I very nearly switched to being a history major. The subject matter is extremely extremely interesting. Two pieces of advice. 1) Take very good/detailed notes on a laptop and 2) Look at the reading guides/lecture handouts for ideas and themes when writing the take home exams!

The reading load is significant, and doing the reading is a large portion of the course so maybe reconsider if you don't feel like you could take this class seriously. But really, really, really great course. Tied as my favorite course this semester.
TAKE THIS COURSE, and choose Chris Florio's precept. If you like history, you will gain so many insights into the history of capitalism.
Take it if you want a good, interesting HA.
Take it!
Take it! Take good notes in lecture, because it's the central source of information.

Take it!!! Especially if you're considering majoring in Economics or History (or even if not!). This course was extremely engaging and fascinating to learn about. Professor Levy is a great lecturer and (for a history course) the weekly reading is pretty manageable. Overall, this was one of my favorite classes so far.
Take it.
Take it. Its a great learning experience.
Take it. Professor Levy is brilliant and you learn a ton. And it's easily graded!
Take the class. It's pretty relaxed. Just listen in lecture and it's hard to mess up the exams.
Take the course.

Take this class! I have very, very high standards for what a good class is, and this class definitely exceeded them. Professor Levy is an excellent lecturer, the precepts are very well-run, and the exams are very fair. You will gain a lot from this class, and I highly recommend it.
Take this course if you want to think critically about the world we live in.
Take this course.
Take this course. Be prepared for some reading, but take it.
Take this course. Go to lecture and take copious notes in lecture and precept to make written work and exams easy.
Take this! It's one of my favorite courses at Princeton so far.
The most amazing class. The readings are a lot to get through but you will love the lectures and the perspective you gain.
The only downside is the amount of reading.
This isn't really economic history.
Would strongly reccommend
make time to do the readings so you can really engage during precept and understand more during lecture
nah
take it
prereqs: No prior course work in economics is either required or assumed..
descrip: This course offers a broad overview of American capitalism from colonial times up to the present. It introduces students to the economic transformation of America from a rural colonial outpost of the British Empire to the largest industrially developed economic power in the world. The course will consider the political, social, geographical, legal, moral, environmental, technological, and cultural dimensions of economic life--all together attempting to provide a total picture of the historical characteristics and dynamics of American capitalism.

title: Capitalism, Utopia, and Social Justice
descrip: See website

title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: It's really fun, and if you took 305 then by the time you take 306 you'll be pretty decent at Chinese that you won't have to spend as much time as you did first semester getting in the habit of reading Chinese again (unless you were always in that habit, but I hadn't touched Chinese in like 5 years before I started it at Princeton). Honestly, I don't think it's as hard as people are making it seem. Definitely one of my average workload classes. The teachers are fantastic, but both of them are leaving next year, so I don't know who will be teaching then. However, all the Chinese department's teachers are awesome, and this course really teaches you a lot of useful knowledge about Chinese society, in addition to helping you learn the language. Highly recommended!!
Make sure you are committed and have time and you will have a great time.
Pay attention to the study guides!
Review the lessons before class. Then review the lessons after class too.
Take it with bro teachers
prereqs: CHI 305 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 305, designed to further improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of essays published in contemporary Chinese newspapers and magazines.

title: Advanced Spanish
reviews: Get a different professor.
Good luck..
Gorka is great.
Great class to take! You get to become closer to your classmates through group projects as well!
I consistently made a lot of mistakes, but I also leraned a lot through the way. If you are someone who is pretty nit-picky, if you can relax that, you might learn more.
I would advise students to make sure that they did the readings and understood the grammar aspect of this course in preparation for the exams.

I would recommend this class. I feel that my command of Spanish has noticeably improved, particularly in terms of grammar. It requires a lot of work but also teaches you about interesting aspects of Latin American culture and society.
If you are actually interested in learning about the culture and the application of Spanish, take 108. Otherwise, you might be better off in 107.
If you are coming out of Spanish 105, 108 is a necessary and enjoyable next step.
If you have to complete the language requirement, get Gorka!
If you open yourself up to learning, even if you have to take the class just for a requirement, it will be more fun and interesting.
If you want to get better at spanish, this is a nice way to do that. Grading isn't the easiest though so be prepared.
If you're taking a language course, then Spanish might be an enjoyable option. Be prepared to spend a decent amount of time if you want a good grade.
It is definitely worth the shot! I would take it again.
It is similarly run to Spanish 105.  The grammar and expectations are just higher.   Definitely see some improvements in your Spanish writing and speaking ability.
KEep on top of it
Keep practicing the grammar, even if there aren't any assignments that you have to hand in.
Monserrat is an amazing professor! I loved this class!
Pay attention in class and participate.
Practice speaking outside of class and accept the fact that you will probably get a b
Professor Bores is really good. She's a bit of a tough grader but she's nice and really good at explaining things.
Put in effort with all of the work.
Should be prepared to keep up in every class.
Stay on top of grammar and readings, will make it easier at the end.
Stay organized and you'll enjoy it
Take it if you like Spanish, or need the credit
Take it!
Take this course and take it with Gorka! Your spanish will really improve!
Take this course.  It is mostly interesting and my professor is great!
Take! Very helpful in development of skills such as writing and reading and speaking
Understand that this course will take a large portion of your week simply to complete relatively routine assignments. Other than that, it is taught well and improves your Spanish.
Well you do have to take it, but take Spanish. It's a beautiful language that can make you view the world in a different way.
its a lot of work, and probably not worth it if you only want to improve your speaking/conversational spanish
practice everyday.
take it
prereqs: SPA 105 or satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test..
descrip: SPA 108 aims to develop fluency by broadening vocabulary, and precision by improving grammatical accuracy while providing numerous opportunities to engage in oral and written communication. Through the interpretation and analysis of images, texts, paintings, songs, audiovisuals, and films students will explore the Spanish speaking cultural identity of Mexico City and Los Angeles. SPA 108 familiarizes students with two of the largest Spanish speaking communities in order to highlight the interplay between language and culture, and to raise awareness of how cultures construct meaning.

title: Introduction to Music
reviews: A pretty easy and interesting course if you don't underestimate the exams.
An enjoyable course that isn't a lot of work?? a very good idea to take!

As some with a fair amount of musical training (two instruments for 10  years each), I took this course primarily because I wanted something very easy for senior spring, but I ended up enjoying it a lot more than I expected that I would. It was especially interesting to be exposed to music before Bach and after Stravinsky, since for many musicians that's where "mainstream" repertoire ends.
Attendance is key. Most important is that you stay up to date with listening assignments

Do all of the listenings and readings. You will find a whole lot of music that you will like that you would not have otherwise been exposed to. Also, if you do the readings completely and all the listenings, and take notes as class progresses, and then you just review those notes and such, it doesnt take more than a few hours to prepare for the midterm and final.
Do it, but be aware that 'Music History' is a more accurate moniker.
Do not take this class.
Easy and light LA course to take.
Fun, relatively easy distribution.
Getting behind on listenings can be dangerous... As long as you keep up with the assignments, this course is pretty straightforward.
Go to all of the lectures. You're really missing out if you don't.
Go to lecture, take notes, enjoy.
Good course to PDF, otherwise not very interesting.
Good intro to music history, great as a PDF distribution.
Great class with small time commitment but you learn about a lot of cool music.
Have time set aside for the assignments in the course or the subject matter won't seem tangible.

I highly recommend this course! I have such a greater appreciation of classical music after taking this course. Take it if you're interested at all in music or music history, or if you just want to be exposed to some wonderful music

I took it for an LA with Steichen, and it was a terrible decision. Not an easy LA because he is so boring and it is really hard to pay attention. Could be an interesting course I guess but wait for another prof. nice guy though
I would future students to stay on top of all the side assignments, particularly the Blackboard readings
I would recommend this class as it is interesting and provides a great perspective of music.
I would suggest to go to every lecture, and also to listen to Jim's Spotify playlist throughout the semester.
I would take this class, it's interesting!!
I'd recommend it but do not expect an easy class. You have to definitely put some work in it.
If possible, take another LA.

If you have not taken any music  class before, whether it involves history or theory, then you will have to put in a bit of effort to maintain a good grade. If you earn in it for the grade, then take the course. it is one of the funnest and most enjoyable course I've taken so far.
It is a very interesting course, even if you don't know anything about music, and not too much work. I learned a lot from it and I really enjoyed the class overall.
It is not a bad course to fulfill your LA requirement, but the course can get very boring at times.
It will certainly not be he most difficult class you take at Princeton, but it is still very intriguing and educational.
It's an enjoyable class.
It's really boring and the exams are too difficult.  Not hard at all but exams kind of stressful even if you are PDFing
Keep up with the weekly work.

Listen to the music!!  Don't just try memorizing names and dates and verbal descriptions of works (as my ex did)!!  That will never work, as it did not work for her.  Moreover, listening to this stuff should be fun.
Not the easiest LA. Do not just take this course for the sake of fulfilling the distribution - there are better more interesting courses where you won't have to waste a PDF.
Only take this if you're very interested in the subject.  It is not a fun/easy 5th class, and there are way better PDF classes to take.
PDFable. Also pretty easy to get an A if you have time to do the readings
Take it for an easy A.
Take it if you need a 5th course. You can PDF it but also do well if you just pay attention during lecture
Take it if you're interested in music history and you want to spend maybe a few hours a week working.
Take it!

Take it, especially if you appreciate music. You don't need to be a musician, but it's more interesting and rewarding if you are. It gives a lot of general overview of music history and some interesting music concepts. Pretty low workload, and it's just fun to listen to music in class and think about music in new ways.
Take this course.

Take this course. You will enjoy it. This is an underrated course at Princeton. I have begun to appreciate Western music much more after this class. You will be able to survey and enjoy Vivaldi, Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Wagner without having to worry too much about the exams.
Take this with Steichen - not a crazy amount of work and quite interesting!
This class is a great deal about the history music. Put in the work and you will get a good grade.

This course is definitely less work than other classes, but if you're not that into medieval, classical, and baroque music, then I wouldn't recommend taking this class. We spent a good portion of the course listening to Gregorian chants and trying to differentiate them from one another for the midterm exam. I wasn't too keen about that. I think taking a harder course that you're more interested in would be a better approach if you're an engineering major looking for that fifth class. However, if you do like learning about the history of music and musical elements in a composition, then this course might be for you. It really depends on the person.

This is a relatively easy class to pass if you're doing P/D/F, but you can also get a lot more out of it if you're interested in doing so. The lectures were entertaining and the discussions in precept can be engaging if you come to them prepared.

This is an awesome course for anyone with an interest in music history. The syllabus covers all the most important composers with some of the best works ever composed. The lectures are interesting and it's light in terms of workload. A lot of people make a big deal about memorizing the pieces, but if you keep up with the listening throughout the semester, it is easy to identify what is what. You don't need any background in music to understand or appreciate the material. It's also a nice change of pace to listen to music and watch staged works for weekly assignment. Strongly recommend for a 5th class.
Useful, important stuff to know about Western music. I enjoyed it, though prof. Steichen could be really dry (to be fair, sometimes really funny). Take itttttttt
Wonderful course about the history of music!
definitely take it for the LA, probably not as interesting for music students. it's definitely focused more on history and less on analysis.
okay course.
study for the exams bc they're not easy
prereqs: No previous experience or training in music required..
descrip: Music 103 is an introduction to Western Art Music (works from 1100 to the present). The course defines the basic elements of music - pitch, rhythm, melody, harmony, and form - and the historically significant styles and genres of composition. Emphasis is placed on significant premiere performances, music and politics, and music and the other arts (film, dance, literature).

title: Introduction to Archaeology
reviews: Make sure to be super familiar with the readings going into class.
Take this class if you're interested in archaeology.

This is class that somehow challenges you without being too hard. Some of the problems really make you think but classroom dynamic is very friendly and invites discussion. The material itself is fascinating.

You should take this course even regardless of if you want to be an Art and Archaeology Major. Professor Arrington is an amazing professor--you dont want to miss any of his classes! It is a great way to get an LA if you dont want to do literature and it includes history, art, material culture, anthropology, sociology, and science. Everyone can find at least one thing they truly enjoy about archaeology because it involves work with other disciplines.
take the course even if you have no experience in archaeology. professor arrington is awesome and you'll learn a lot.
descrip: An introduction to the history, methodologies, and theories of archaeology. The seminar discusses topics and problems drawn from a wide range of cultures and periods. Issues include trade and exchange; the origins of agriculture; cognitive archaeology (the study of the mind); biblical archaeology (the use of texts); artifacts in their cultural contexts; and the politics of the past. Emphasis on what constitutes archaeological evidence, and how it may be used. Required for majors concentrating in archaeology; open to all. No prerequisites

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Juniors only (except for sophomores who have completed EGR 251)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Levantine Colloquial Arabic
reviews: Take this class if you really want to hammer in your speaking, it will push you to be much more comfortable speaking! Don't take this class if you are uncomfortable talking in Arabic a lot and making mistakes; if you don't like speaking Arabic and are unwilling to do so you are not only going to hate the class and not progress but you will be doing a disservice to your fellow classmates who want to speak only in Arabic.

The course is an introduction to levantine colloquial, which is a hard subject to teach given the lack of written materials to work with. The primary focus is listening skills, as achieved mainly through watching films and listening to music. There are two required presentations. The workload is light, but interesting.
Watch the films, and make sure you want to take this course. Only for those interested in Colloquial Arabic.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or equivalent..
descrip: An introduction to spoken Levantine dialect. Materials in the course are designed to promote functional usage of the language, stressing the vocabulary and grammar of conversation as used in daily life in the Levant, particularly Palestine, Jordan, Lebanon, and Syria.

title: The Philosophy of Kant - Critique of Pure Reason
descrip: A study of central themes of Kant's Critique of Pure Reason, focusing on the Transcendental Dialectic and Doctrine of Method sections of the work.

title: Beginner's Russian II
reviews: I would strongly recommend the course. Overall it was a very interesting course and the professor made it very entertaining.
If you truly want to learn, choose your TA wisely. Keep up with the homework, because it builds up fast. The poetry and short story readings are a lot of fun!
If you're interested in the language, take it!
It is a difficult course, even though the instructors are great, so go in expecting a difficult workload.
Keep up with it. It doesn't take too much time if you just practice vocab, take time to go over the concepts every day.
Keep up with the work.
Seriously paying attention in class and understanding each concept as you go will save time later on.
Take it. It's interesting but harder than most intro languages.
Take this course if you're in the beginning stages of Russian!
Will teach you Russian, but it's not an amazing class
prereqs: RUS 101 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The objective of RUS 102 is to give a basic knowledge of Russian: basic training in speaking, reading, writing, and comprehending the Russian language in a cultural context.

title: Non-Cognitivism in Ethics
reviews: Kohler won't be back and the course will probably be taught entirely differently with someone else. Super interesting topic, but know what you're getting into - metaethics isn't exactly the sexiest topic
Take if interested in meta-ethics. Prof. Kohler is fantastic.
prereqs: One previouse Philosophy Course.
descrip: Meta-ethical non-cognitivisms is the view that moral judgements do not represent the world as being a certain way, but are non-representational states that play a motivating role in the production of action, comparable to emotions, desires, or intentions. Non-cognitivism is an important view in the landscape of the contemporary meta-ethics. But, it is also one of the most difficult views to fully understand. This course is an intensive introduction to this meta-ethical view and investigates both its benefits and problems in great detail. Readings will be drawn primarily from contemporary sources.

title: Topics in Ethnography (Half-Term) - Oral History and Ethnography
descrip: This seminar seeks to understand how oral history can be used to improve ethnographic work, focusing on problems of representation, methodology, and knowledge production.

title: Architecture of Princeton University
reviews: Definitely take this course, no matter your experience with architecture! It will give you a great appreciation for our beautiful campus and will inspire you to take pleasure in continuing to learn more about the campus each and every day!
Fantastic course to learn more about the history of Princeton and the architecture of Princeton with a Princeton alumnus.
Generally very interesting and relevant for any Princeton student. PDF it.
Give yourself a tour of campus to study for your exams. Yes, you may look silly talking at a building, but what other course can you walk around campus and study for at the same time?
Good class, but a tough grader. Definitely not an easy A
I chose to PDF this class so that I could focus on enjoying the material that was presented, as opposed to stressing over grades and I don't regret that decision.  This was a great class to take!

If you take great notes and do all the readings, you will get a lot out of the course.  Also do not be afraid to discuss any questions or topics of interest with the professor, Dr. Maynard is more than happy to answer them.
It is a wonderful course and you should definitely take it but if you are taking it as a fun course, it might be good to PDF it.
It was a good course! Just long lectures.
Maynard is a great lecturer, but grading is extremely harsh. A worthwhile PDF.
Really cool class to take; however, be warned: Professor Maynard can be a bit 'old school.'
Start your paper early, go to class.
TAKE IT!!! AND TELL ALL YOUR FRiENDS TO TAKE IT TOO!! Seriously one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.

TAKE IT.  Prof. Maynard is an incredible professor, a captivating and humorous lecturer, and the subject matter is so interesting, because it's about PRINCETON, where we experience our college times day in and day out.

TAKE THIS COURSE! Without a doubt one of the best courses I've taken. The material is fascinating and incredibly relevant, as everything is about Princeton. I came in having never taken an architecture or art and archaeology class. It didn't matter. Professor Maynard's enthusiasm and passion for the subject are contagious, and you will find yourself both knowing and wanting to learn more after every class. This course has broadened my perspective in an important way. Give it a try?you will not regret it.
Take it - it's not particularly hard, low time investment, and Professor Maynard's breadth and depth of information are awe-inspiring. The lectures alone are worth signing up.
Take it if you're interested in architecture or just want a nice PDF, especially if you're a senior.

Take the course. Prof. Maynard's excitement for Princeton is contagious. You will learn why so many things are the way they are around campus. You will also be equipped for endless small talk with other Princetonians.

Take this class. Prof. Maynard loves this topic and it really shows. Even if you know nothing about architecture coming in, you won't feel behind. Be on top of the paper. I ended up spending about 6-8 hours in Mudd library, which was cool, but takes some planning. Go on the field trip. And just enjoy learning about the place you're spending your 4 years from a different perspective.

Take this course. Lectures are excellent, Prof. Maynard is incredibly engaging and a great guy, his book got me interested in this campus and was ultimately the reason why I wrote my thesis about Princeton.
This course is an excellent way to study history and architecture through the Princeton lens. I found a deeper appreciation for the Princeton campus after taking this course.
descrip: Listed by Forbes magazine as one of the World's Most Beautiful Campuses, Princeton has long been an architectural paragon, much-admired and copied. Its astonishingly varied buildings can help tell the story of American architectural history from the 1750s on. This course will examine Princeton's fascinating relationship to ever-changing architectural trends in America and Britain. Controversies will be emphasized, from nineteenth-century fights about Gothic Revival to current debates about Neo-modernist designs by world-famous architects. Walking tours and a field trip will enhance your understanding of America's fourth-oldest campus.

title: Topics in Ergodic Theory - Introduction to Ergodic Theory
descrip: This course covers current topics in Ergodic Theory. More specific topic details provided when course is offered.

title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy II
reviews: I would recommend it
descrip: Theoretical and empirical study of the public regulation and deregulation of rate of return, prices, and entry in public utilities and franchise oligopolies. Theory and practice of antitrust policy is examined, including some elements of antitrust law. In addition, regulation of product quality, advertising, and safety is examined. This course draws heavily on material developed in 541.

title: Independent Study I
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Minmin Fan in E-211..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.

title: Living with Animals
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Viscous Flows and Boundary Layers
reviews: Fully expect to spend 20 hours or more on some problem sets. Only take the course if you must, or will utilize viscous flows in your research.

Great course with Professor Howard Stone, really hit home the beauty of fluid mechanics, power of dimensional analysis, and seeing the structure of PDEs in addition to the algebra. The assignments are lengthy though manageable. I took this course without prior coursework in fluid mechanics and did okay, but an undergraduate background in the subject would definitely help.

I would strongly recommend this course to a student that is interested in fluid mechanics. However, I would caution the prospective student that they should have a firm understanding of basic fluid mechanics theory and know how to solve PDEs, both of which I lacked when taking this course.
It's a lot of work, but you will learn a lot.  Make sure you are ready to commit some time.
Look over the course notes before class. Look at the supplementary material.
Please take this course!!!
Take it, but don't take too many other courses with it. I was taking 4 classes in total this semester ( research) and that definitely didn't work out.
The course work is heavy and you will learn a lot if you go through this course.
This course has a significant workload and can be pretty challenging at times, but I learned a lot and it stimulated my curiosity. Howard Stone is an excellent teacher.
scaling, scaling, scaling
descrip: An introduction to the mechanics of viscous flows. The kinematics and dynamics of viscous flows. Exact solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations. Lubrication theory. The behavior of vorticity. The boundary layer approximation. Laminar boundary layers with and without pressure gradients. Introduction to stability. Introduction to turbulence.

title: Cross-Cultural Encounters in the Medieval Mediterranean
reviews: Hand in the response papers on time!
I strongly recommend this course to other students.
Think if you are really interested in medieval history before making a decision.
n/a
descrip: The littoral of the Mediterranean Sea has long been viewed as a major place of contact, conflict and exchange for groups belonging to the three Abrahamic religions: Judaism, Christianity and Islam. This course approaches the encounters of different religions and ethnicities in such a manner as to introduce students not only to the classic historiography on the subject, but also to the main controversies and debates current in scholarship. Our discussions involve forays into the fields of transnational and global history.

title: Global Intellectuals: How Thinkers and their Books Shaped the World
reviews: I would strongly advice students to take it because of the methodological training to approach a work, and because, in my experience, it was a place where I could voice my own opinions without being judged.

Small seminars in the History department are a great learning experience. You'll have the opportunity to interact with a professor and really learn. Work on the readings early and bring some comments ready for the each seminar.
Take it! Wonderful!
Take it, but only if you want to do the work.

Take this course as soon as possible!

Not only are the books highly relevant and interesting, but Professor Adelman keeps each  seminar fresh and interesting--playing devil's advocate and giving voice to the author of the week to further a class discussion.
descrip: How have big books shaped how we think about the world? This course will survey some of the most influential to affect how we think about our planet. Each case study will ask students to consider the biography of the author, their historical context, the book itself, and its effects on the public and policy worlds. Since this is a research seminar, each student will be asked to apply their skills to a case study of their choosing in consultation with me. The final two weeks of the semester will be devoted to shared readings of pre-circulated materials from sources the students have chosen for their case studies.

title: Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
reviews: Enjoy the process and don't stress out about it.

Take it, and don't stress about how well you're doing in it. You may be scared about having your work workshopped, but it isn't really that scary. Try new things, try new authors that you haven't read before, and be open to everyone's feedback, even if you don't end up changing your translation accordingly.
This class was one of the most fun classes I have taken at Princeton. It's very stress free but you still learn a lot.
prereqs: This class is open to any student with fluency in a language in addition to English, by application only. Students apply with either 3-4 pages of original literary translation, or a paragraph explaining their interest in the course. See the Creative Writing Program webpage for application information..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students must be fluent in their chosen language.

title: 19th-Century Poetry
descrip: How did we get from 1821, when poets were the "unacknowledged legislators of the world" (Shelley) to 1939, when Auden wrote "poetry makes nothing happen"? This survey of 19th-century British poetry explores poetry's engagement with political and social movements (from education to empire, sexual politics to steam engines). We will think about how and why poets were deeply invested in national movements at the same time that they were ambivalent about their role in society. We will also consider how the afterlife of 19th-century poetry haunts our conception of literary "modernism."

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Current Issues in Defense Policy
descrip: The US faces a complex security environment defined by novel threats, rising competitors and shrinking budgets. This course uses history and theory to help students wrestle with some of the most pressing debates in contemporary defense policy. Topics include conventional force planning for peer state competitors; unconventional force planning for climate change; nuclear deterrence and the debate over Global Zero; civil-military relations and the military's sexual assault problem; and planning for future war in an era of precision weapons and unmanned equipment.

title: Art and Science of Motorcycle Design
descrip: See website

title: Atmospheric Thermodynamics and Convection
reviews: A course worth taking.
Not a lot of work. Take it if you work on atmospheric sciences.
Take it! Very helpful coverage of the subject matter.
descrip: Thermodynamics of water-air systems. Overview of atmospheric energy sources and sinks. Planetary boundary layers. Closure theories for atmospheric turbulence. Cumulus convection. Interactions between cumulus convection and large-scale atmospheric flows. Cloud-convection-radiation interactions and their role in the climate system.

title: Introduction to Psychology
reviews: ATTEND EVERY SINGLE LECTURE!!! The lectures are very very interesting, and the exams are based entirely on lecture content, so if you consistently go to class (and make sure to get notes from a friend if/when you miss) you will do well. Only read the chapters if you're really interested in a particular topic, because they're really lengthy and more detailed than the exams require.
Attend all of the lectures.
Be prepared to code!
Definitely go to all the lectures. Don't try to do all the readings, but if needed, seek help from your lab instructor or professor well in advance.
Don't procrastinate labs, and go to lectures since they're super interesting. Make sure to ask your preceptor for help on labs if you need it.
Frustrating if you are looking for a stimulating class. Not a great indicator of psych major.  Difficult labs.
G
Get a good lab section, make sure to learn everything in a lot more detail for exams than he covers in lecture. otherwise great course!
Give yourself ample time from the laboratories.
Go to lecture and understand examples given in lecture
Go to office hours.  Your professor is truly one of the greatest on campus.  Ask about research to learn the concepts.
Good option for STL, but be prepared for a lot of work (not too difficult, just a lot)
Have fun!
I am glad I took this course because it showed me what psychology is as a discipline. You don't need to do any of the readings from the book (maybe don't buy it).

I think the course will be enjoyable with any professor, but if Turk-Browne is teaching, TAKE IT. He does not assign that much reading and the labs are all interesting. He is also an absolutely amazing lecturer who makes the class even more interesting. Take it if you want a low-stress STL

I would advise students to go to all of the lectures and take thorough notes because the exams are primarily based on the lectures. You don't really need to read the textbook unless there is a topic you have difficulty understanding. Treat the textbook as more of a reference. Be prepared to have lots of fun in the labs!
I would highly recommend this to any student who has a moderate interest in psychology.
I would recommend having some prior programming knowledge for this course, as it will make labs much easier to follow at times.
If you are interested in psychology this course is a great starting point! Labs are long though, and I definitely wouldn't recommend scheduling yours at night.
If you hate math and science, take this course. Otherwise, if, like me, you just want to learn about the brain, it'll be worth investing in a more challenging, thorough, rigorous curse.
If you like psychology take it. A lot of people liked it. I really didn't care for it at all. Not much work but the exams are kind of tricky, not what you would expect for an intro class.
If you're not a science person, it's probably a good STL to take. Not the best class, but there are interesting things to learn.
If you're planning on being a psych major you need to take it. It's an intro course so don't expect much
Interesting course
It is very interesting with Turk-Browne as the professor.
Labs are kinda boring

Lectures were great but labs were really stressful and time consuming. I would encourage someone interested in Psych to take a different psych course that was more specialized to see if they liked it.
Make sure you maintain a good pace during labs/don't get behind or else it all becomes a lot harder and more complicated
Must take at Princeton, regardless of major!
Pay attention in lecture, it will help you out a lot for the exams.

Pay attention in lectures and take good notes, also try printing out lectures and studying those. Labs are going to be hellish if you don't have a background in statistics so really take the time to do your lab assignments and always ask questions to ensure you do well.

Prof. Turk Browne is a great lecturer and you will learn a lot of really interesting stuff in lecture. Labs aren't a deal breaker - they require a lot of software use which they mainly guide you through but at times they can be kind of hard and I'd suggest starting them early. Overall, would recommend if you need an STL- it's pretty interesting.

Professor Turk-Browne is a really great lecturer and he and lab TAs are very accessible. content is interesting, labs somewhat painful but not too hard. grading is fair. don't have to read the textbook.
Recommend if you want to be a psych major or just interested in learning about the mental processes and behaviors of people.
SUPER interesting material - incredible STL - loved it!
TAKE THIS CLASS  W PROF TURK-BROWNE!!!! Labs aren't hard and shouldn't scare you off!
Take it
Take it for your STL or if you're interested in psych as a major. The R in labs isn't that bad compared to what I heard about last semester and Prof Turke Brown makes the material very interesting!
Take it take it! Its extremely interesting and a relatively easy STL.
Take it with Professor Turk-Browne. He's a great lecturer and if you like the topic, this is a great STL. Labs aren't great but they aren't that hard either, for the most part.
Take it!
Take the class, go to lecture because that's the best part, and take a deep breath and do the labs as quickly as possible without stressing out too much.
Take the class.
Take this course for an introduction to Psychology. Taking it has now made me want to be a Psychology major.
Take this course if you are interested in general psychology. The labs are hard though so be prepared for that.
Taking notes on a laptop would be better than hand notes in this class.

The labs have improved a lot since fall '14, so don't worry about them being impossible. They aren't terribly hard but they are just very tedious and kind of pointless. If you are interested in PSY, take it I guess.
This course is great if you want to know anything about psychology as a field! Very interesting.
This is a pretty solid STL; the lectures are excellent. Just be prepared for the labs to be tedious at times, and don't worry too much about the textbook.
This is a solid intro course. Attending lecture is an absolute must, but Professor Turke-Brown's lectures were always really interesting.
Try to come in with some coding experience, even if it is limited in nature.

Whether for an STL or just for general knowledge, TAKE THIS COURSE! If you get Prof. Turk-Browne as an instructor and Adam for labs, you're in for an informative and fun class that you'll remember for a while.
Worth taking as an STL or otherwise.
go to lecture
good class
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course is a prerequisite for majoring in psychology and can also be used to satisfy the science and technology with laboratory general education requirement.

title: Topics in Tonal Theory - Analysis Workshop
descrip: Analytical exercises, both prepared and at sight, covering a range of tonal instrumental music. The goal is to increase familiarity and facility with mainstream analytical methods.

title: The Roman Republic
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of reading, but also for some excellent lectures!
Budget a lot of time for this course. Don't treat any work as optional.
Chaplin is always a good speaker. The course overall was just ok, but I'm not really into history
Class is okay. I wouldn't take it for an HA just because the lectures are so quick that you end up missing a lot.
Definitely take it.
Definitely take this course.
Definitely take this! Champlin is a fabulous lecturer!
Do the readings and go to lecture. You will not regret it.
Do the readings and pace yourself with them.
Do the readings religiously and keep comprehensive lecture notes.
Go to all the lectures because they're great and will really make things clear.  Start papers early and make sure you don't take the sources at face value.
Go to lecture, read the book ahead of time and be prepared for precept and this course will not be too hard.
Go to lecture. Its the same material you'll get from the book.
Good luck! Be familiar with the background of this time period or keep an extensive timeline including political and military events - it's a LOT of material for 12 weeks for an intro student.

I took this as a PDF due to general interest and managed an A- by the midterm without doing any reading, so it is a good PDF class. However, the weekly quizzes require you to at least know what the topic of discussion is that week and perhaps skim the Internet for some basic details. I also stopped going to lecture after the midterm, as they were rather dry and often confusing.
I would advise students to really pay attention in precept and come prepared. I learned a lot during that time, especially if I had done the readings carefully.
If you are unfamiliar with Roman history, that timeline they suggest is so important.
If you like history and/or Roman history, definitely take it.
Interesting look into Rome - great for history majors - know the overall themes for the exam essays.

It's a great HA choice! Paper-light, lots of little grades as opposed to big ones (there is a midterm and final, but they count for relatively little). Lectures are great, precepts are great, readings are great (and not too heavy), though there are precept quizzes.
It's a really fun course. The readings aren't too bad as long as you keep up with them.
It's a very good class.  Take it if you want to learn more about Roman history, or if you need to get an HA.
Keep up with the readings, even if you have a lot of other work. Budget your time effectively.
Keep up with the readings.
Lectures are fascinating, preceptors are really helpful, and you will love the Romans even more.
Professor Champlin is an excellent lecturer, and the grading isn't too tough. If you're interested in Rome, take it/
TAKE IT.
Take it and enjoy it! Champlin is really good and this is a well organized class.
Take it!

Take it! Especially if you're into history or Rome. You'll learn a lot. Be sure to do the readings though, it'll be hard to follow the discussion in precept if you don't. And you can do really well in the course just by getting the reading done.
Take this course if your a history major or remotely interested in Rome.
The course work is fairly straightforward and it's a great way to learn about Roman history.
Weekly quizzes, do the reading.
Would recommend for those with any kind of interest in Classics or the Roman Republic in general.
relatively easy his course with a great lecturer
take it
descrip: A study of the causes and consequences of one small city-state's rise to world empire, through analysis of primary sources in translation. Emphasis on the development of Roman society, and the growth and demise of republican government.

title: Quantum Optics
reviews: If you are at all interested in quantum optics, or in gaining skills needed for theoretical research or understanding in modern quantum cavity systems, this course is great for you. Even if not, the quality of lectures makes the course worth taking all in its own.
My only advice is to take it and read external materials, such as Haroche's book "Exploring the Quantum", Walls & Millburn book
humor and lot to learn
descrip: Semiclassical field theory of light-matter interactions. Quantum theory of light, vacuum fluctuations and photons. Quantum states and coherence properties of the EM field, photon counting and interferometry. Quantum theory of light-matter interactions, Jaynes-Cummigns (JC) model. Physical realizations of JC model, case study:circuit QED. Quantum theory of damping. Resonance fluorescence. Coupled quantum non-linear systems.

title: The "Eastern Question" and its Legacies
descrip: This course examines the diplomatic, military, and political events, known as the "Eastern Question," that shaped the Middle East between the 1600s and the First World War. It emphasizes the perspectives of the Russian and Ottoman Empires, the linkages between international and domestic issues, and changing ideas about international law. Topics include war, diplomacy, migration, and humanitarian intervention. The course takes a chronological and thematic approach, concluding with a discussion of how these themes affect the history of, and our views of, crises in Ukraine, Syria, and Libya.

title: Advanced Arabic II
prereqs: ARA 301 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Study of Modern Standard Arabic at the advanced level, continued from ARA 301. Attention given to speaking, listening, reading and writing, with special emphasis on grammar and readings in a variety of authentic texts.

title: Policy Research Seminar
reviews: Any student interested in international relations in the Woodrow Wilson School should consider this seminar for their JP. Kotkin is serious about academic rigor, and students should learn a lot from him.
Be prepared for a tough class.
Do the assignments and try to make them fit your JP so you don't feel like you're wasting your time.
Do the readings, they will help you understand how to structure your junior paper and expose you to a variety of interesting concepts.
Don't do quant. It's just a repeat of stats.
Don't obsess too much over the lab material?you won't be using much of it anyway
I mean you have to take it. Not much else to say. Find a topic you don't hate.

It's weird to have to "rate" this course, since it's required for everyone. Professor Cameron was a really nice adviser, and he was super helpful when you went to meet with him. He's not the best teacher, since he doesn't come to class with lesson plans, and he tends to be very unorganized, but I really appreciated learning from him in office hours. Also, I definitely walked away learning a TON about research design. It just wasn't very interesting. With respect to lab, I appreciate that WWS is trying its best to make it better. Improvements still need to be made, but they're working on it, and it wasn't as bad as it was last year.
Prior is a great professor and is one of the leaders in this field, so take this course with him if you get the opportunity.
Prior is great.
Professor Buckinx is a great professor and Dov is really helpful in developing research questions and topics.
Professor Buckinx is a great resource!
SAVE YOURSELVES. TAKE A SEMINAR THAT ALLOWS A QUALITATIVE JUNIOR PAPER.
Take Professor Jacobs' class and meet with her often. She is very helpful.
Take it - it's not like you have a choice though, so pick a topic you're interested in.
Take it!
The methods lab are more helpful if you've consolidated your own dataset early on. DSS is a wonderful resource center.
Well, you have to take it.
You have to

You have to take it, so make sure that you take a PRS with a good professor and an interesting topic- the American Cities Then and Now was amazing and Prof. Isenberg is also amazing. Also, do the qualitative lab unless you're very good with numbers.
necessary evil

quantitative lab is great. stata is annoying at first, but honestly the most useful thing you can have as a skill set. 
pick your section wisely.
you're gonna have to take it anyway so just make sure you have a seminar you like
prereqs: Assignment to these seminars is by a separate application process through the department..
descrip: The junior policy research seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in policy research and writing. Students may choose from a range of topics.

title: Topics in Postcolonial Literature - The African Novel
descrip: This course will study the development of the African novel from Amos Tutuola's 1946 The Palm-Wine Drinkard to two 2006 novels, Tsitsi Dangarembga's The Book of Not and Chimamanda Adichie's Half of a Yellow Sun. We will be asking, however, what the very notion of "development" entails: moving away from literary traditions that are synonymous with colonialism; appropriating and subverting them; or recuperating an African past that Europeans have claimed, since Hegel, doesn't exist? More urgently, we will ask how the idea of "development" in the emergent world has affected the work of cultural production, for better or worse.

title: Composition
descrip: Emphasis will be placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.

title: The New Hollywood
reviews: Do the reading, and then some! Also, consider taking the time to watch some of the 'recommended' films. This is a fascinating era, and you won't be taking advantage of the professors knowledge unless you really dive into it.
Great.

I'd recommend this course.  If you're interested in film analysis and good, contemplative, moody films, you will enjoy this course.  Basically, if you're a big fan of modern, anti-hero, new wave television, this class will explore the films of the late 60s and early 70s when film was pushing those same boundaries.  Sometimes the seminars go on a bit too long and sometimes there can be too much reading in a given week to explore to the fullest, but overall, the quality of the films and the quality of the lectures and papers elevate the course to high levels.
If you are interested in watching a bunch of top-notch films, take this class!
TAKE THIS COURSE. you will love it if your are interested in history and movies. Professor Cramer is also very nice and great to listen to in class.
Take this course! Prof. Cramer is a great teacher and I really liked his seminars. We had interesting discussions and the movies that we watched were very engaging.
Very different kind of material from any other class. If you want to be culturally literate take this.
descrip: This course will examine the so-called "New Hollywood": the films (The Conversation, Badlands, Mean Streets, The Long Goodbye) and filmmakers (Coppola, Malick, Scorsese, Altman) who reinvigorated the Hollywood studio system in the late 1960s, only to be displaced by the blockbuster and "high concept" films that followed. Films of the period will be examined within the context of industrial and cultural history, with special attention paid to the changing dynamics within the American film industry, and to the cultural shifts that these films both responded to and expressed.

title: Size Matters: Crossed-Cultural Perspectives on Scale
descrip: When the Spanish conquered the Inca Empire, they became immersed in a civilization with its own age-old intellectual tradition that they often did not understand. Scale, or relative size, was a relational property that Andean people long employed to convey meaning between objects, individuals, and features of the experienced world. This course will juxtapose the way scale was conceptualized and utilized in the Andes with a variety of readings on scale from European sources-including architecture, cartography, literature, and other realms-to better understand the oceans that separate the cognitive orientations of these equally Old Worlds.

title: Beginner's Italian II
reviews: Do the homework every day. Even though it might not be much, it is really useful in gauging whether you know a certain concept or not. And even if you feel shy, try to talk and answer the teacher in Italian. It will help you improve immensely. To study for the midterm, take your previous quizzes and study your mistakes. If you do not understand something, go immediately to Professor Dossena: She is wonderful and will explain the concepts to you. In fact, try to get Dossena as your professor: She is very nice and an excellent teacher
Do the nightly homework. Do the readings. Look up movie summaries online (not necessary to watch the 2 hour films). Study the night before the quizzes).
Do your daily homework.
Fully engage with professor De Feo
Go for it.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who would like to improve their language skills and get a better feel for the culture.
If you need an easy language class, this is it.

If you study a bit each day, it will really pay off. Don't leave a lot until the end, as language skills develop over time. Also, go to class and participate. Participation is extremely helpful because a lot of speaking time is offered in class.
It's a great class.
It's pretty much exactly what you would expect from an language 102 course: challenging but not overly difficult.
Italian is fun
Love Italian!!! The department is great!
Meet with your professor outside of class if there is something you're not clear on. Remember material from previous sections, it will make your life a whole lot easier for each quiz.
Professoressa Antonucci was very good

Slightly more difficult than ITA 101, but it is once again not curved so it's everyone working together. THE ITALIAN DEPARTMENT IS ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE. 100% the best language department on campus. The professors and classes are engaging, easy, and interesting!
Study outside of class and really try during.
Study together.
Take it
Take it with Dossena, she's a beauty.
Take it!
Take it! So much fun, low stress environment.

Take this course with Dossena if you can. There is always the possibility of switching precepts during the first few weeks. Take advantage of this opportunity and you will not regret it. Dossena is a fair grader and an attentive teacher. She is very interested in making sure that you succeed. If you put in the effort to doing well (making sure to study consistently) you will very muchh enjoy this course.
Take this course, make sure to do all the homework and just have fun with it!
The Italian department is a great way to go for the language requirement, or if you're just interested in the language.
The class is very easy if you actually spend the 30 minutes (or less) per day to study the material and do the homework.
These professors and the entire Italian department are great!
fine course nothing special
take italian!
prereqs: ITA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Further study of Italian grammar and syntax with increased emphasis on vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Skills in speaking and writing (as well as understanding) modern Italian will also be further developed. Some aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.

title: Queer Sexualities: Biopsychosocial and LGBT Perspectives
descrip: Queer Sexualities is an interdisciplinary course, which intertwines the study of human sexuality from scientific and public health perspectives with queer academic writing about sexual orientation and gender. Through the lenses of human sexuality theory, social science and medical perspectives, biological and sexual functioning, and LGBT history and subcultures, this course will explore the many ways in which queer sexualities, identities, and relationships are constructed, expressed, and regulated.

title: Computational Finance in C++
reviews: A very helpful course for those interested in derivatives pricing and creating Excel formulae. I would recommend it especially to those interested in trading and structuring.
Course is interesting, but more focused on mathematical finance than C  .
Great course.
Great lectures and assignments! Take it!
Take this course if you like programming/comp finance and if you want to become a quant.
This is an AMAZING class that you shouldn't miss, especially if Prof. Sotiropoulos is teaching it.
Very good if you want to see what quants actually do
Very useful for those students who want to have an industry-standard (finance) training in C  .
use the Cplusplus website tutorials
prereqs: Basic knowledge of C++ programming and Microsoft Excel usage. Junior & Senior enrollment by Instructor permission only--must contact instructor PRIOR to signing up..
descrip: The intent of this course is to introduce the student to the technical and algorithmic aspects of a wide spectrum of computer applications currently used in the financial industry, and to prepare the student for the development of new applications. The student will be introduced to C++, the weekly homework will involve writing C++ code, and the final project will also involve programming in the same environment.

title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives
reviews: Attend lectures especially in the second half, fight for points with the TA in the first half homeworks
It is a good class for understanding replicating strategies and determinants of derivatives markets fluctuations. Don't take the class if you are interested in option pricing.
It is not a very enlightening course. The first half is classic options theory which we have seen many times before. The second half is interesting but not enough to take the course
This is a great course. Even if you do not know anything, you can learn from the basics of derivatives to the application to the commodity futures only by lectures.
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The course offers an introduction to financial derivatives and the models used to price them. Pricing techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), as well as extensions to accommodate time-varying volatility and more complex contracts. We also devote great attention to discuss the roles played by derivatives in shaping financial markets and the real economy by using commodity markets as a focal point. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and spreadsheet programming.

title: Meanings in the Visual Arts: An Introduction to the History of Art
reviews: A great team-taught survey of Art History. You'll learn things you certainly would not have known elsewhere, taught by foremost experts because the lecture style allows for a different Art faculty member every lecture. Papers are easy but there is a lot of material for midterm and final, so do well to prepare in advance for all the images and their thematic considerations.
Absolutely take it! It was a great introduction to the discipline of art history and to a variety of periods of art and and types of art from around the world.
Go to lecture, go to precept and you will be set. The exams require a bit of memorizing to do well.
Great into course for people who don't know anything about art!
Great survey class!!! Great lectures! Great introduction to art! Just be aware of the having to know every single artwork and every single period by heart at the end of the semester!
I would say that lectures are the most important aspect of the course. It is important that as many as possible are attended.
Readings aren't worth the time, a pretty easy fifth class but definitely can be boring. Go to lectures and precepts, memorize for midterm and final
Study for the exam!!!!! There is no other easy way to do well in this class. Do not be fooled, it is a challenging class.

Take it for a general overview of art. Teaches you how to think about art when viewing it. The lectures are more important than the readings. PDF if you don't want to stress about memorizing about 150 images for the final. Overall, really interesting and you learn a lot.
Take it if you're interested, or you think you might be. I thought this was a very good survey course.

The lectures are super important so take good notes. The professor isn't as important because the guest professors do all of the lectures. If you're really interested in different types of art, this class will definitely help you see them in a different light.

This course is a great overview of art history. I would say just make sure you're going to most of the lectures and doing most of the reading, or else you won't get anything out of it and it will be boring for you. This is a great introduction to the department and a good way to learn some culture.
You should take it.
go to lecture, reading unnecessary
descrip: Introduction to the history of art and discipline of art history. Not a comprehensive survey but a sampling of arts -- painting, sculpture, architecture, photography and prints -- and artistic practices from diverse historical periods, regions, and cultures. The course balances historical development with various ways art historians and other observers interpret art, and with attention to individual works of art. Lectures by various faculty of the Department of Art and Archaeology in their fields of expertise; precepts facilitate direct engagement with works of art in Princeton University Art Museum.

title: Financial History
reviews: Be prepared for the time commitment of the readings. Great course because of the vast amount of material that is covered and the professor who guides you through it.
I would recommend taking this course, but do note that this course is very much a history course, and will require you to do the readings.
I would recommend the course to anyone with an interest in finance or its foundations.
James is a poor lecturer. It's more of a 3 hr listen to his musings than a structured discussion. Readings are good though
Only take if highly interested in subject matter
Take this course if you have any interest in the larger-scale history of economics.
descrip: The course examines the history of financial innovation and its consequences. It examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, and securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader development? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility? How is resulting conflict and instability managed, on both a national and international level?

title: Development and Dissent in India - South Asia
reviews: I would only take this course if you care about issues in rural india very deeply. There aren't many others who are better equipped than P.Sainath. The course doesn't involve a lot of time-crunching work.
just provide your own structure

take this course. professor sainath will inspire you. he's not the usual ivory tower intellectual - his work is in the real world, and that's what you'll learn and write about. 
there are 4 assignments in all, so it's quite writing intensive, but he's always available to discuss ideas and offer (lots of) helpful feedback on drafts. he welcomes a more journalistic style, and for me it was a relief, a pleasure and a learning experience not to have to write thoroughly academic papers. i learnt a new way of writing. 
you also get to learn about his experiences as a journalist in india, which is really cool. i suggest you leave any politically conservatives views at home.
descrip: Introduction to mass human displacement by industrial and other projects and the dilemmas of development that this process entails, including country to city migration, unemployment and land acquisition by the state, as well as citizens' resistance. This seminar will help students develop an understanding of, and the tools to study, write and report on development and dissent in their own societies and globally.

title: Intensive Korean II
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. Credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing two-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: A continuation of Korean 103. This course covers the 2nd Year Korean material focusing on complex grammatical structures, reading, and writing. Journals are kept for writing practice. The students who have successfully completed KOR 103 and KOR 108 will be placed in the 3rd or 4th year Korean if they wish to continue.

title: Automatic Control Systems
reviews: "Feedback for other students" -- no negative feedback, though you'll learn about that in the course.
All the different concepts work together, so it is important to remember the older material as new material is taught.
Along with Prof. Arnold's Materials, this is probably the best MAE class that you are required to take as an MAE undergrad. Lucky you!
Awesome class!
Being familiar with Matlab related computation tools might be good as preparing.
Cool class. A decent mount of work but it is interesting.
Don't fall behind, put a lot of effort into understanding psets
