Go to office hours! They are helpful for the homework
I believe all engineers will love this class!

I really loved it, but if you're looking at this course, doesn't feel like you'll have a choice either way.
GO TO OFFICE HOURS. They are really helpful.
Just stay on top of the material and always go to class.
Leave lots of time for the problem sets, and go to all the lectures.
Lectures are more than worth the time, and don't procrastinate on the problem sets!
Make sure you do the homework well and understand the underlying theory. The questions on the exams will not be just like the homework, but similar.
Rowley is a great professor though the material is difficult so keep up.

TAKE IT.  But maybe not senior spring.  It's a lot of work, but extremely well taught and lots of help is available.  Rowley is super approachable and awesome.  Yibin, Scott, and Anthony are the best TAs you could ask for.
Take it! You're going to have to, and that's okay. Just make sure you take good notes. His notes are good, but they don't cover everything he goes over in lecture.
Take it.
Take the course with Professor Rowley. You probably don't have a choice anyway but I liked it a lot.
Take the course, and enjoy it! Pay attention to the small details, because that is where the difficulty in the subject lies.

This is a great course on controls engineering.  While it is not easy, you will learn a lot about a topic that is applicable to many different fields. Do the homework and be ready for super long exams.
Very very good course. Take it
Work on the homework over the weekend, so you can start off the week going to office hours with substantive questions. It helps much more here than in some other classes.
You gotta love it.
You might need to devote much time to this course since it has a lab part. But you will get many stuff out of this course as well.
You probably have to take it and it can be a decent amount of work, but a very well run course and fairly interesting.
this is definitely one of my favorite courses at princeton. awesome material, fun and stress-free lab, and great lecturer
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop an understanding of feedback principles in the control of dynamic systems, and to gain experience in analyzing and designing control systems in a laboratory setting.

title: The History of Incarceration in the U.S.
reviews: Definitely take this course!  One of the best courses I have taken in my undergraduate career.
Excellent seminar!

Great class in which you will learn a lot about various topics in the history of incarceration in the US. There is a lot of reading, but it is interesting and on the whole manageable. Would definitely recommend.

I highly, highly recommend this course. Prof. Kunzel is an amazing professor. Her kindness and expertise make this a really transformative learning experience. I really liked the format of weekly readings and writing assignments and then a final paper.
Take it, especially if you're interested in policing and modern incarceration.
Take this course!!! Kunzel is wonderful, the readings enjoyable, and the discussions very engaging.
descrip: The prison is a growth industry in the U.S.; it is also a central institution in U.S. political and social life, shaping our experience of race, class, gender, sexuality, citizenship, and political possibility. This course explores the history of incarceration over the course of more than two centuries. It tracks the emergence of the penitentiary in the early national period and investigates mass incarceration of the late 20th century. Topics include the relationship between the penitentiary and slavery; the prisoners' rights movement; Japanese internment; immigration detention; and the privatization and globalization of prisons.

title: Contemporary Spain in Context
reviews: Although the class was a lot of work, it was ultimately worth it and I would strongly recommend it to anyone else.
Be aware that this course will be a lot of work that you can not fake. However, it is worth it, as German is an incredible professor.
Be prepared for a heavy workload, however, the trip to Spain makes it worth it.
Highly recommended. Be prepared to do a lot of work, learn a lot and see your Spanish improve dramatically.

If you are passionate about Spanish and want the opportunity to be stretched past your comfort level academically but with amazing support and guidance at every step, take this class. Although it is a lot of work, it all pays off, and the final investigation paper is truly a work to be proud of.

Pay attention in class, PARTICIPATE, and do a selected amount of the readings well.  You can't do all of the readings, but have something to contribute to class based on the readings you did.  Also, put in a lot of work to anything you submit, since German does not have you submit a lot of written work.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
TAKE THIS CLASS. Best decision I've made so far here. German is one of the most brilliant and compassionate professors I've ever encountered. It's a lot of work, but it is entirely worth it.
Take it. Don't be scared of the work, as I was; you will rise to the occasion. And German will put as much into it as you do.

This class is a heavy load of work, a lot of materials to prepare for each class and a high standard of expectation for your research work. However, all the hard work is definitely worth it! You gain a lot from how hard you are pushed in the class, and gain a critical perspective on topics you may have never learned much about before.
This course is very intense and time-consuming so be prepared.
This course was immensely time-consuming, but more than worth it for a genuinely interested student.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission. Applicants must submit a motivation letter and will be contacted for an interview. Preference given to potential Spanish and Portuguese concentrators.
descrip: This course provides a general introduction to Spanish history and contemporary issues which includes a mandatory field trip to Madrid and Barcelona during the spring semester break. Materials will include literature, art and films. Museums, urban history, Franco's dictatorship, the transition to democracy, the 2008 crisis and new social movements like Occupy will be among the topics addressed.

title: Advanced Sculpture
reviews: Absolutely take sculpture. The method of thinking is applicable to all other classes and your way of life.
Allow yourself the time to really push yourself with each assignment

One of the best courses Princeton offers. Gives you the chance to think and address problems in a much different way than most other classes, and Martha Friedman is one of the best professors at Princeton.
Take this class! Well taught and helps you grow as a person and as an artist. You'll only get out of it whatever you decide to put into it.
Take this if you want to get closer to finding your voice/vision as an artist.
prereqs: VIS 203/204, or VIS 221/222, or VIS 231/232, or VIS 331/332 or instructor's permission..
descrip: In this course, each student will determine a specific theme that they will poke, prod and refine throughout the semester, ultimately completing three fully realized, thematically-linked sculptures and/or installations. While wood, metal and plaster will be readily available, various mixed media and experimental materials and approaches are highly encouraged. Regular individual and group critiques monitor the progress of each project. In addition, the class will collaboratively complete and install and outdoor public sculpture somewhere on campus. Field trips and image driven discussions will be part of the course.

title: Origins and Nature of English Vocabulary
reviews: Good class if your in to that kind of thing. Not very fun for math/science people.
I think it's a fun course to take and would suggest it if you're interested in the subject. You should know what kinds of things you'll be studying and know that you'll enjoy learning about it.

I would advise a student to only take this course if they are very interested in the topic.  Since I was very interested, I thoroughly enjoyed it, but I could imagine some parts of it being dry to a student who was not interested in linguistics or classics.
I would recommend taking this only if you have some knowledge of linguistics already.
Take it only if you're going to stick with the lectures all semester

This course could have been interesting and exciting, but it was very disorganized. I would recommend signing up for the course and attending the first lecture at least to see if the syllabus is any more organized than it was this year (the second half of the semester was very up in the air on the syllabus), because this class definitely has the potential to be a great one.

This is a very interesting course to take if you like linguistics, or English. It won't be fascinating to everyone, but it is still very useful to have a knowledge of where our language comes from, especially for a literature student.
Wait to take this course with a different instructor if you want to actually get anything out of it. If you're looking to take this for a distribution requirement, look elsewhere.
descrip: The origins and nature of English vocabulary, from Proto-Indo-European prehistory to current slang via Beowulf. Emphasis on linguistic tools and methodology. Topics include the Greek and Latin elements of English, the Roman alphabet and spelling, social and regional variation, the matter of "proper" language, and the "National Language" debate.

title: American Politics
reviews: A good foundational class to take it you are interested in American politics!  Professor Frymer is really engaging!
Awesome class! Genuinely really enjoyed it. Not too much work, but really interesting. liked doing the readings and Frymer was great
Definitely take it if you want to know more about American politics.
Do not take this course if you already know something about American politics. There are much more engaging Politics courses at Princeton. Although, it is a very easy PDF.

Do the readings. Get the response papers done early. Make sure your precept isn't near the end of the weekend, or you'll get screwed with nearly impossible turn around times for the response papers. That sucked. Otherwise it was good.

Frymer is a great lecturer, and an even better preceptor. This is a survey course, and not too difficult. You don't really need to do all of the readings; just get the gist of each author's point. Take it even if not a POL major. He relates the stuff to modern day politics and it's just fun to get an overview of American political institutions
Frymer is wonderfully fair.  Take this course
Frymer's smart and charming.
Great course overall! Worth taking in order to become a more informed citizen or simply for general interest!
Great distro requirement. Good professor (Frymer is great), low workload, interesting material. Take it.
Highly recommend
I highly recommend it.

I would recommend taking this course if you're interested in politics and don't have much background in the area. It provides a good overview of the political system and the political culture in American. The grading can be a bit harsh, so if this isn't required, I would recommend taking it PDF.

I've taken 33 courses at Princeton and a few abroad, and this is (by a wide margin) the worst course I've taken (when taught by Prof. Frymer).  I've heard the course is excellent when taught by Prof. McCarty, so if he's teaching it take it, and if not, wait for him to teach it.
If you have an interest in how politics works in America, take this course. Manageable workload, and Frymer is the man.
It gives you a very thorough and engaging overview of american politics and government. Very interesting.
It's a pretty standard lecture class- some good moments, sometimes it can be pretty slow. Your preceptor can make a huge difference.
It's an easy class. You can skate by without necessarily doing the reading.

It's an interesting course, however that it is pretty broad (covers ideas of liberalism/republicanism, constitution, how congress is structured, power dynamics, etc.). I took the course thinking it would be solely about current day politics (ie. Republicans vs. Democrats), but there was really only 1 or 2 weeks on that. Much more of the course is about how the system came to be and what influences it now.
It's mostly common sense, so not really a mind-blowing class.
Maybe don't take it.
N/A
Not the most interesting course in the world, but definitely not the worst either.  Great PDF if you're not Woody Woo.
Not too challenging and overall fairly interesting.
Papers/midterms are graded very harshly. Can be difficult to understand what you're doing wrong.
Pick like 1 or 2 readings to do a week, otherwise it's too much
Preceptor matters, beware. Frymer is a great guy, recommend,

Professor Frymer is a great lecturer, and he made the subject matter interesting. Course readings were very engaging. However, if you are expecting a class that details the nitty gritty of the American government, then you are in for a surprise. It is really a class in which the students engage with the writings of political science scholars, and as a result, the course is more subjective than objective.
Readings
Split the readings with your friends, even for the final you can get by with a summary of most articles.
TAKE IT. And pay attention in precepts because they can make or break your understanding of material.
Take it
Take it but make sure you have a good preceptor!
Take it if it?s a requirement. It?s relatively interesting
Take it if you have to.
Take it with Frymer, try to get Vlad as a preceptor. Do the readings. Easy politics class in my opinion.
Take it! Painless WWS departmental with engaging lectures.
Take it. Do all the readings. They're not that long and quite manageable. Get Vlad as your preceptor and you're set. It's a chill class. You'll enjoy it.
Take it. Something Princeton Graduates should know a lot about

Take this class for any politics requirement or general interest in learning about American politics. There is a good amount of reading but it's manageable and they're all interesting. Overall it's a great class!

Take this class! As a comparative politics student, it had me considering the American politics track for a little bit--that's how good it was. You learn about things that happen in the everyday world of American politics that you may not necessarily have the space to deeply engage with outside of a serious class. And even if you already do, this class provides the theories and context to do so as best as possible. Take it! Paul is awesome and so is this class.
Take this for sure and go to lectures.
This course is really good. I highly recommend it to anyone. It's pretty easy and surprisingly interesting. You learn some pretty interesting concepts in the class.
This is a good course, especially for people who want to get a broad overview of American Politics.
Unless you have to take this specific class, I would urge you to opt for a higher level politics class. Analysis here was not very deep, and grading was harsh.
Very interesting course!
Would totally recommend. I learned a lot about politics. Frymer is an amazing professor. Even better preceptor. Take this class for sure.
You won't learn much if you know just about anything in terms of American Politics, but it's a fun class.
great class, great preceptor and great professor.
n/a
take it. but try to do the big readings
descrip: An introduction to the national institutions and political processes of American government and democratic representation. Topics include the Constitution, the American political tradition, public opinion, interest groups and social movements, political institutions, civil rights, civil liberties, and matters of public policy.

title: Things
reviews: Do take this class, and make sure to complete all the readings to fully engage during class time. Fantastic seminar
If interested in the topic and open to considering the subject matter through alternative methods (experiments, exercises, "thing labs"), then definitely take the course.
If you are looking for a conceptual course wherein you are likely to move your mind as much as your body this is that course.
Professor Burnett is very intellectually engaging - the course comes recommended!
Recommend.
Take it.
This is a great class with very little busy work and lots of opportunities for both creative and analytic thinking
descrip: A review of recent thinking/writing about objects; an effort to experiment with activations of this work. Our course will explore approaches to material culture from the early modern period to the present, with particular attention to new philosophical and anthropological perspectives. Historical questions will be paramount, but aesthetic and epistemological problems will also be engaged. Guided by diverse readings, we will endeavor to heed Wordsworth's bold injunction--to "see into the life of things."

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: History, Philosophy, and Religion
prereqs: See HUM 218.
descrip: In combination with 218, this is the second half of a year-long interdisciplinary sequence exploring Western culture from the 15th to the 20th centuries. Students must register for both HUM 218 and HUM 219, which constitute a double-course. The lecture component for 219 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 218. There are no separate meeting times for 219.

title: Modernism and Modernity - Signal to Noise -Vicissitudes of the Acoustic
descrip: Insisting on the (long-ignored) importance of the acoustic in fields such as film & media studies, architecture, literature, art history, and cultural theory, this seminar will interrogate sound as a testing ground for key socio-political shifts such as globalism, digitization, etc. Exploring the role of sound within histories of (post-)modernity, it will examine technologies of production, transmission and reception; the geo-political roles and uses of sonic materials; the dynamics of social and individual modalities of acoustic experience, and the challenges posed by sound to the theoretical hegemony of certain models of "representation."

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
reviews: AWESOME CLASS. Professor Garlock is a great professor and I loved hearing his lectures and anecdotes. However, it is as demanding as any class at Princeton. Be prepared to put in time for the final project, and take pride in it. It is the best opportunity to prepare for professional civil engineering that Princeton offers. Be intentional about taking this junior year or senior year. You need to have most of the core structural engineering courses complete before taking this class, but it is challenging to take concurrent with thesis.
Be ready to think independently.
I mean, you're not going to take this course unless you're a civil engineering, and in that case it's required.

While a fun course, it can be very challenging, especially in the beginning when you're trying to figure out how to go about starting, and the end (especially if you've had some hiccups along the way). If possible, talk to students who have taken it before and ask for advice. But overall, it was a good learning experience.
prereqs: Students should have taken both CEE 312 and CEE 366, or have permission from the instructor..
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: The Great War in the Middle East
descrip: World War I changed - and ended - the lives of millions. Its impact upon the Middle East is widely acknowledged but not often explored. The war destroyed the old imperial Ottoman order, paving the way to the elimination of the Caliphate and the emergence of nation-states across the Middle East and the Caucasus. It fundamentally altered concepts of identity, patterns of authority, notions of religion, and ethnic and political borders. This seminar examines the Great War in the Middle East from right before WWI through the immediate post-war period. Topics include geopolitics, empire, Pan-Islam, nationalism, ethnic conflict, Zionism, and oil.

title: Introduction to Programming Systems
reviews: Amazing course if you want to pursue a computer science degree. Even if you don't, it's a great course to have if you have a general interest in computer science.
Assignments are interesting and instructive. Lectures are not very interesting and often not correlated to the assignments but they show up on the exams.
Be aware that it is very different from 126/226, but the material is stuff you need to know if you plan to work in the computer science industry.

Be prepared to sink time into the course. The assignments take significantly longer than those in COS226, and the graders are also super anal about comments and whatnot. (I swear, all the points I lost this semester were solely because of style). Otherwise a decent course, taking ELE206/COS306 beforehand really helps a TON though.
Be prepared to spend a loooot of time on the assignments.

Be prepared to work hard and learn an incredible amount. The lectures are really well organized and the precepts are incredibly useful. Would recommend if you have any interest in understanding how computers work
Beware high workload, but is worth. Especially if you want to write large and meaningful programs.
Definitely take it if you're interested in computer science or computer architecture of any form
Definitely worth taking. I've heard Dondero is the best preceptor, but Petras is also very good. The assignments are very time consuming, as is the final project, so take that into account.

Difficult or not, this class is exceptionally well taught and designed. It was a pleasure to learn C and study the computer "under the hood". I think this course is highly useful for anyone interested in computers.

Each assignment takes around 8 hours, but you learn a lot, and you learn a lot of things the hard way. This is one of the most practical, handson courses at Princeton. Not intellectually challenging, but practically challenging. You learn a lot of real-world coding skills.

Everyone who wants to say they know something about computer science should know something about systems. Also great for just learning to be comfortable with low level languages and UNIX. Even though the material can be pretty dry at times for someone who's more interested in theory and/or higher level stuff.
Give yourself sufficient time to start the assignments. Office hours are very helpful.
Go to office hours frequently!
Great course, but long projects
I highly recommend it.
I loved Professor Dondero! He made the course for me and was so patient and helpful for everything. Get him as your preceptor!
I would highly suggest that they be in Prof. Dondero's precept.

I would take this course, but I would take COS 226 first, and I would not take this course if you have 5 courses this semester.  Be prepared to spend about 15 hours a week outside of class for this course.

If you are doing software engineering in the future, this is a good chance before you start coding without knowing what is happening under the hood. And learning an efficient programming language - C - is worth your time.

If you have taken COS 126 and wish to continue exploring computer science in a more "low-level" fashion, this is definitely right up your alley. Even if it doesn't sound particularly interesting, you might be quite surprised: particularly if you're being taught by Professor Dondero. Professor Dondero has this way of teaching the material that makes it not only engaging and interesting, but really quite enjoyable as well. Many of the assignments are also really cool, since they showed how much you learned how to do just in one semester of C programming. So, I would definitely recommend this class, though it's at its best with Dondero.

If you're coming in fresh from 126, expect to work especially hard in the beginning of the course to get used to the new topics and pace. It's very different from 126 because you're programming at a much lower-level, but it's extremely rewarding in its own way. Also (and this really pertains to all assignments), absolutely start the final shell assignment EARLY. It's an extremely time-consuming project but so rewarding in the end when you get it. I'd also say that you should gauge how comfortable you are with programming and know for yourself how long you need for assignments, because everyone works at a different pace for this kind of thing, so do what works for you and not for other people. Also, I highly recommend using the resources like office hours and lab TAs.
If you're considering it for general interest make sure you have long term interest in Cos because otherwise low level language will be useless to you.

Interesting material once you get the chance to delve into it on your own in the assignments. Take with a friend, split the lectures, and sign each other in since those aren't useful (saying this as someone who usually attends 100% of classes regardless)

It is a bit more "dry" than 226 but definitely has interesting components. The assignments aren't that bad besides Shell, which was personally a huge time sink. If you are considering taking it, you probably have to take it anyways. Precepts are essential. Hope that next semester they don't have attendance sheets for lecture...
It is taught very well.
It's amazing if you're at all interested in the subject matter! Take it. Very well-taught and well-organized.
Learn to ask for help and ask what you don't know.  Start early so you have time to ask questions.
Make sure to leave enough time for assignments.
One of the best structured classes you will ever take. Definitely understand more about how computers work at a low level.
Start assignments early!
Start early and you won't struggle as much. Exams can be a struggle if crowded exam schedule.

Take if you want to learn C, else if you're curious about the software side of systems, else if you have to. Else, you have no really good reason to take it. The assignments can be long, and the class can be quite difficult at times. ELE 206 makes a good companion course to this, since they cover opposite sides of the same coin.
Take it if you like Linux/UNIX/C programming language.
Take it if you like coding. Or think there is a small chance you might like coding.
Take it only if you have the time and the interest.
Take it only if you have to for COS
Take it!
Take this course, it is really really awesome. Go to lecture, just know that it will be a little dry sometimes.
Take!
Takes A LOT of time
The assignments take forever but not as bad as everyone makes it out to be. You actually learn how a computer works so its cool

The course teaches a lot of material in a short amount of time. The assignments can be very time consuming and vary a lot (5-20  hours) in how long they take to complete. Plan ahead accordingly, and pay attention in precepts, as they explain there in detail how to do the assignments.
The programming assignments are very time demanding, particularly assignments 4 and 7. That said I think I have learned a lot in this class and anyone doing the certificate should take this class.

The programming assignments may take a lot of time depending on how good you are at debugging things, but overall it's a good class, and you will get a lot out of it if you choose to put in the effort.
This class is very time-consuming mostly because of the programming assignments, but these assignments are well-designed such that you learn the material very well.

This class requires A LOT of time to complete the assignments fully. If you plan to take it make sure you are not taking more than 2 other classes that require this level of engagement.
But it is a great course and you learn a lot of great concepts.
This class will be a lot of work, so just be prepared for that. It would also be helpful to have Winter Break to work on the Shell assignment, because it's a lot of work.
This class will be a much larger time sink than 126 or 226 but it is interesting if you enjoy learning about how things go on behind the scenes in a computer system

This course is challenging. It will take a lot of your time, and you will be frustrated more than once by the assignments. But overall, its worth taking. It gives you a great background in C programming, and you learn a lot about how computers actually work at a lower level.

This course is time consuming.  Fun, but time consuming.  If you are going to take this class, don't take it in the spring, take it with only three other classes (four classes total), and most importantly, this must be the hardest class in your schedule, no exceptions.
Try to get Dondero as your preceptor! If you can't, just go to his office hours. Start the assignments as early as possible because they take longer than you think!

You are going to hear things about how 217 is difficult and how you are going to struggle with certain programming assignments. Ignore all of that. This is one of the best computer science courses I've taken so far. 226 and 217 are both extremely well organized and people seem to like them a lot. I personally enjoyed 217 more. If you have the option, get Dondero as your preceptor, he is amazing.

You can enjoy the course. The preceptors and resources available make it a very accessible course. Make sure the last time you wrote code was at most 3 months before taking it otherwise refresh on the basics. Ain't nobody got time for that in this course.
You should take it, because otherwise 50% of COS classes aren't available for you to take, and COS classes are cool.
You will put a lot of time into this class
yes definitely as most people going in this direction have to anyways
prereqs: COS 126, ISC 231-234, or approval by the COS placement officer..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.

title: Writing The Other
reviews: It is a challenging subject to teach and to learn, and for that reason there are some uncomfortable discussions and writing exercises, which in my opinion is a very good thing. Might push your comfort zone a little bit. The readings in the class are interesting, and probably wouldn't be found in most other cwr classes.
Take it if it's offered again!

Take this - Hanna's an amazing instructor, and the course is mind-blowing (and it also allows you to stitch back your blown mind). Especially if you are interested in representation issues/methodologies in writing, this is a great course.
Writing the other is difficult, but this class brings up a lot of interesting theoretical issues that will make you think differently about your writing.
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level CWR courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Writing about people who do not share our race, culture, gender, or sexual orientation is high-risk, particularly if we write from a place of privilege. Often, the fear of appropriation and stereotyping means that we avoid writing about characters of other backgrounds completely. Instead of excluding writing about or from the perspective of characters of Otherness at all, this course will provide the background and space to think critically and openly about the representations our work creates, even as we attempt to create our own work in this context.

title: Experimental Physics Seminar
reviews: Best course ever. You sit through ~30 minutes of lecture that you don't need to pay attention to. Then you get to just play around with circuits and soldering. Make sure you get Tully and the TAs to help you. The labs aren't that difficult, and you'll finish an hour early on average. There's no other work for the class at all, and it's pdf-only. What more could you want?
Easiest class, take it as a senior!
Take for a relatively easy course senior spring. From experience, only seniors are able to get into the class as the class fills up right at 7:30AM.
Take it if you need an STL. It would help to have some science background, but most don't and get by.
Take it! Don't worry if you don't know the detailed physics--you learn on-the-go for the labs.
Take this class if your aim is to have a truly light semester.
Take this course if you have any interest at all in electronics and hands-on, stress-free work!

The course has no out of class work and is PDF, so if that's what you're looking for, definitely take it. Professor Tully is nice but often fails to adequately explain things so that you can't work through the lab without a lot of help. But Professor Tully will make his rounds and help you with anything you don't get so have no fear.
solid class to take senior year spring
descrip: The seminar introduces students to the basic techniques of electronics and instrumentation used to conduct experiments in the physical sciences. The course begins by teaching a foundation in analog and digital circuits including programmable digital logic devices using an iPad interface for data acquisition. Students develop measurement techniques in a wide range of experimental areas.

title: Fanfiction: Transformative Works from Shakespeare to Sherlock
reviews: Definitely take this course if you're into fandom and fanfiction as a whole. It really provides a fascinating survey of the landscape of fanfiction. Even if you only have a passing interest, I think this course can help you appreciate the workings of fandom much more.
Do it.
Have fun, and find a part of fandom that interests you!
I would tell this student that they will definitely learn about something interesting if they take this class.

If you are interested in fan fiction, go ahead and take the class! Just be aware that it isn't like any other English courses, and it's pretty unstructured and all over the place. If you're not interested in fan fiction, you probably shouldn't take it.

If you like fanfiction a lot, this class will probably be very interesting and easy for you. Doing the readings was the hardest part for me. If you don't already like fanfiction though, I'd think twice before taking this course. It's hard to feel motivated to do the work when the topic is something you lack interest in.
If you like fanfiction, take it. If you dont, its a waste of your time.
It vacillates from being an easy class and a difficult one (the participations are really annoying to do). If you are big on fandom, then take it. If not, consider taking another easier elective.
It's an English class with modern material and perspectives. Not stodgy.
It's silly, no work, but good fun.
Keep up with the readings and write your papers ahead of time.
Not an amazing course.

TAKE THIS CLASS if it's ever offered again if you have any interest in fan activity, fanfiction, transformative works, media production, Sherlock (Holmes), ideals of originality/creativity, and intersectionality/identity in literary works.
Take it if you like fanfiction. I'm not sure if it will be offered again, but try to get Anne for precept. She's problematic, but really gets fanfiction and is smart about it.
Take it if you want a fun LA!

Take this course seriously! It may be about fanfiction but there is a lot going on and you will need to put in work and be organized. I also recommend that you have at least one particular fandom that you are passionate about so that the work in this course will go more smoothly for you, and if you hate Sherlock, definitely don't take this because it is the Professor's fav. (Sherlock is great though! Don't hate it.)
The course will look like fun - and it is - but can be frustrating as well.
The lectures may seem laid back and fun, but you actually have to do some thinking in this class. Go to lecture and take time to do the assignments well.
The material and guests were interesting but if you know a lot about fan fiction already I don't know how much you'll get out of this class.
This class was amazing, whether you're interested in fanfiction or not. Take a class with Professor Jamison the next time she teaches at Princeton.
Took it for friends and to write the assignment, the course material is not so good.
descrip: What makes "fanfiction" different from Shakespeare basing his plays on sources, or House turning a Victorian detective into a doctor in West Windsor? What can amateur, unauthorized stories about other people's characters do for readers and writers that paid, official culture can't or won't? We'll be reading a lot of fanfic and looking at cultural uses of adaptation and appropriation such as TV shows, web series, and avant-garde poetry.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
prereqs: This class is available for 300-level (departmental) credit, by application only, for any student who has previously taken two 200-level workshops in the Creative Writing program. Students must have fluency in a language in addition to English. Applications must include 3-4 pages of either original literary translation or original work from their previous workshops. See Creative Writing website for application information..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students must be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Between Resistance and Collaboration: The Second World War in Europe
reviews: Definitely take this class.

Definitely take this course if you are interested in the period or if you are just looking to fulfill your HA requirement. Also try to get in Professor Gross' precept. He isn't a particularly difficult grader and is extremely knowledgeable about the material (unsurprisingly).
Definitely would recommend to anyone interested in WWIII or European history
Highly highly recommended. Gross is of course a towering figure in World War 2 studies as well as a very approachable professor.

I really enjoyed this class, the readings are extensive, but aren't really necessary to do in full which is nice.  It was a fairly chill class and the workload wasn't too bad when the readings weren't taken too seriously.

This course gives you a lot of information that can be interesting and exciting to put together, but do not expect lecture guides or crystal clear instructions. Professor Gross and Marzenna James are both very kind and intelligent!
You should be interested in the subject, great readings, somewhat boring lectures
take it if you want a fairly easy history course and you like WWII
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators..
descrip: In the broader context of conflict between fascism, communism, and liberal democracy, we shall examine various patterns and methods of occupation, collaboration, and resistance during World War II in Western and Eastern Europe. The Holocaust of European Jewry and the technology of terror will be discussed. We will try to ascertain how elites and different social strata were affected by the impact of war and occupation. Students will be asked to read historical studies as well as personal narratives by eyewitnesses and participants.

title: Introduction to Differential Equations
reviews: I would suggest adhering to the textbook and going to office hours. I would recommend reading before class to know whats going on

If you are in any field that uses serious mathematics, differential equations are an essential tool for solving problems. Take this course if you are interested in a slightly more theoretical treatment, though no proof experience is necessary (most proofs were only a few lines in complexity).
Not a hard class, especially for math majors.
Read the textbook and be willing to find resources on your own.
The difficulty y(t) of this course satisfied the differential equation y' = e^(-y) with initial condition y(0) = 0.
They will have to work hard from the beginning.

This class is meant for people who are interested in a much more theoretical and proof-based dif eq. If you have only taken 201 and 202, I would recommend taking MAE 305 instead. Long problem sets and hard exams. Pusateri is an ok lecturer but not super involved in having you pass. Needs to be more practice problems available for exams.
This course was not particularly engaging to me because there were a lot of different topics that seemed random at times. Grading was a little arbitrary. Definitely a mix of computation and theory.
highly recommend this course
ok
work hard every week, make sure you understand the pset every week
descrip: This course will introduce the basic theory, models and techniques for ordinary and partial differential equations. Emphasis will be placed on the connection with other disciplines of science and engineering. We will try to strike a balance between the theoretical (e.g. existence and uniqueness issues, qualitative properties) and the more practical issues such as analytical and numerical approximations.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
reviews: Go for it !!!
Take the course but push for a more debate-type style during class.
prereqs: FIN 501, FIN 522.
descrip: Course examines the concept of risk and its mitigation, and how the ideas can be applied in the practice of risk management for financial and non-financial companies. The basic toolkit draws on economics, probability theory and statistics, and they are integrated with more advanced concepts drawn from portfolio choice, derivative securities and dynamic hedging. Overall aim of the course is to demonstrate how the main concepts have practical applications.

title: Topics in Low Dimensional Topology - Smooth surfaces in 4-manifolds
descrip: For Spring 2015, we discuss various classical constructions of spheres in the 4-sphere and slice discs in the 4-ball as well as some classical invariants that smoothly distinguish them. We look at a recent construction of slice knots due to Gompf, Scharlemann and Thompson as well as the theory immersions, crossing changes and moves on surfaces based on the work of Hirsch -Smale, Giller and Roseman.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: Attend lectures
Definitely take it. Probably unique among engineering courses for the different arguments about the whole structural art concept.

Definitely take the course if you're at all interested in structures, city environments, or engineering. The course is extremely manageable as long as you go to lectures and do the homework. The exams don't have any surprises. Really interesting and easy.
Definitely take this for a great way to get an LA if you're not into English/writing/etc. Really cool if you're into architecture or structural engineering at all!
Don't let yourself fall behind.
Get started on your term paper early!
I would tell them that this class is not very difficult but still gives you a great understanding of structures. If you are interested in structural art you will love it.
It's fun, learn about bridges. And other stuff. Pay attention to lecture. Do the readings.
Make sure to do the readings.
Really great course. Interesting material and not too much course load.
TAKE IT!
Take it for a fun LA if you like, but it's better if you're interested in structures and finding out about the world around you!
Take it! Absolutely awesome course to learn about bridges/structures!
Take it. A great 5th class. Go to lecture and precept and you shouldn't have anything to worry about.
Take it. Garlock is so passionate and it rubs off on you.
This course was actually really good and kinda fun, it is also very easy and not a lot of work, so its good if you actually just want an easy class that is fairly interesting.
This is a great intro course and the course load is manageable.  Also the lectures and precepts are very interesting.  I think its an engaging course from both a BSE and AB perspective.
This is one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton. I would take this course if you have even a remote interest in bridge design or structural engineering.
This is probably the least art/writing intensive LA you can get away with. As long as you keep up with the readings, or go to lecture, you can succeed with minimal effort.

Would not recommend as an LA in its current form, but the lectures are actually highly informational if you go (if you don't go, you'll get nothing out of this class). Make sure you're committed and interested-- definitely a course to shop
lot of busy work just so you know
take it if you want a relatively straightforward class with clear expectations
take it!
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through critical analysis of major works students are introduced to the methods of evaluating structures as an art form. Students study the works and ideas of individual structural artists through their elementary calculations, their builder's mentality and their aesthetic imagination. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities.

title: Philosophical Analysis Since 1950
prereqs: One other philosophy course or permission of instructor required..
descrip: A study of philosophical analysis in the 2nd half of the 20th century. Topics include the later Wittgenstein, the ordinary language school or philosophy, Quine's naturalism in Semanties, Davidson's views on the truth, and Kripke's reconceptualization of semantic and metaphysical categories.

title: Programming Languages
reviews: Although some of the Coq proofs can be very difficult, this class on a whole is easier than COS 340. Proving stuff in Coq is fun albeit a bit mindless. I relied on mindless guess and check far too often.

Apparently the course is completely different on even/odd years, since Walker and Appel switch off teaching it. I've heard Walker's course is completely different, focusing on pen-and-paper proofs and properties of (largely functional) programming languages, the lambda calculus, etc. rather than on formal theorem proving.
Definitely a must take for COS majors!
Definitely take it. But be ware, it may be more theoretical than you are used to. Certainly nothing beyond 340 though.
Either don't work ahead on the homework or be prepared to be bored in lectures.
Good class. Tedious problem sets.

I strongly recommend this course as it covers many interesting subjects in programming languages. The focus of the course is on proving properties about programming languages and therefore provides a different and interesting view for anyone who has been engaged a lot in programming.
I would recommend other students to take this course.
I would suggest this class for students interested in theorem proving.
If Appel is teaching, take it only if you're very interested in how to prove program correctness. The class is a lot more about theorem proving and logic than it is about programming languages.
Interesting course. Start the homework early.
Lectures can be boring at times. Material is interesting, though probably will not be useful for everyone. Easy theory class, especially after Functional Programming.
PL is a doable theory course, but not particularly enjoyable or organized.
Read/review the Coq files BEFORE going to class so you know what's going on. At the beginning of the course, do the proofs on paper and see how they're translated into Coq.
Start early on the psets.
Take this class over algorithms to satisfy the theory requirement.
The class is ok if you have to take it.

The class with Andrew Appel is a combination of learning about Coq and functional programming first, then learning about programming languages and SAT solvers. After taking this class, you'll be well-equipped to start doing research in formal verification or programming languages.

This class gave a lot of homework. Going to lecture is useful so you can learn Coq techniques from a wizard.

I'm not sure I agree with the decision to use Software Foundations and Coq for learning programming languages. I actually learned things when I did the proofs on paper. On the other hand, formalizing things in Coq was confusing and frustrating. I suggest re-doing the class with the textbook "Types and Programming Languages."
The course is awesome. It is a lot of work, but worth it if you can devote the time.
There's a lot of time-consuming work, but it's really fun and interesting. A great course for the Theory requirement.
This is a very interesting course. It is a bit challenging at first but I think it's a great class (and it hits the theory requirement)

This is a very manageable theory course.  It's not too time-consuming (for a theory course), and I found the material interesting.  Lectures aren't particularly engaging--they mostly just read through the notes that you'll be using for the homework assignments--but you won't be tested on anything that's not in the notes.  The midterm difficulty was reasonable, and there is no final.  I've heard a rumor that the course is entirely different depending on whether Professor Appel or Professor Walker teaches it.  This year was Appel, and the course was machine-assisted theorem proving using the Coq language.

This is more of a course about using Coq (an automated proof assistant) than proving things about programming languages. So much time is spent on Coq that you don't really get an understanding of what's actually going on in the proofs. Many of the problem sets are very painful and a ton of work. That said, it might be a bit easier to get a better grade than in some other theory classes. I think this class is very different when Walker teaches it.

This wasn't the best class I've taken in the department. To a certain extent, the material wasn't for me. However, I can see why other people would find it interesting. If you liked 326, give it a shot.
Work with other people. You can get stuck in proofs a lot of times just by overlooking something and it helps to have people you can check your sanity with.
personally i liked 326 much better
prereqs: Undergraduates: COS326 or permission of instructor. Graduates: none.
descrip: Logic and formal reasoning about software, treating programs and programming languages as mathematical objects about which precise claims can be made. Basic concepts and techniques such as operational semantics and axiomatic semantics for specifying programming languages; structure, definition and properties of type systems; invariants and assertions for specifying programs. Use of automated tools such as interactive proof assistants, model checkers, and/or satisfiability-modulo-theories solvers.

title: Research Seminar in Empirical Investigation
descrip: Preparation of research papers based on field observation, laboratory experiments, survey procedures, and secondary analysis of existing data banks.

title: Theories of Psychotherapy
reviews: Definitely recommend this course.
Don't take if you've already taken one of Comer's classes, because he mostly just replays the same videos (So i've heard). Take to discover if you're interested in being a psychotherapist.
Go to every lecture - you will not regret it, enjoy Professor Comer
Great course.  The group project is a bit tedious, but other than that its genuinely very interesting.
I would only recommend this class if you are very interested in learning bout psychotherapy. Otherwise I would not recommend taking this class.
Take it if you like the idea of clinical, applied psychology.
Take it!
Take this class! The topics are very interesting and the reading workload is fairly nice.
Take this course if you are interested in becoming a psychologist!
Take this course, it is perfect for anyone interested in social relationships and abnormal psychology.
The group project can be overwhelming; try to meet often and split the work evenly.
This class has a lot of overlap with Comer's Controversies in Abnormal Psychology class, so if you took that you may feel bored in this class.
prereqs: PSY 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course will examine the different theories, models, techniques, and settings that comprise the practice of clinical psychology in general, and psychotherapy in particular.

title: The Sentence: Prose Style as Study and Practice
reviews: Definitely take it! It was a pleasure having a course with professor Johnson. Give yourself enough time to actually do the reading and writing assignments properly. Good if you like creative writing.
If you're an aspiring writer, take it.
It's a fun workshop but it's pretty loose. Not that much is demanded so you get out what you put in.
Take this course! If you write anything, and especially have an interest in both creative and analytical/academic work, this is a wonderful class.
This is a great, great class. You will look at the written and spoken word in a whole new light after taking this class. Not to mention it's very well taught. I highly recommend it.
This should be a required course for English concentrators or its equivalent. English majors should have to go beyond just writing seminar during freshman year in terms of a writing focused class.
prereqs: This seminar is designed for students who take a serious interest in their powers of speech and writing..
descrip: The course has two objectives. First, it explores the glories of English prose style by concentrating on its most coherent and powerful structure, the sentence, in all its rich varieties of organization, sonority and rhythm. To accomplish this, we will study masterworks of English style drawn from scripture, essays, novels, poems, plays and speeches. The second objective is to invite students to develop their own writing by imitating these models. We will give equal attention to the analysis of literary texts necessary to be a good reader and to the directed practice necessary to become a good writer.

title: Contemporary Art: 1950 to the Present
reviews: Difficult material to wrap your head around, but the class is engaging yet easy enough to approach this period of art in a meaningful way.

Do the precept readings, and go to lecture, it's a great way to learn about the artistic movements and what fueled them up until our time, and helps one appreciate the movements, and if not appreciate, at least understand.
Don't take it--too broad, too fast, and poorly organized
Don't take with this professor.
Focus on the concepts that interest you most -- there's enough wiggle room in the assignments that you don't have to say everything about everything
Great professor and excellent course for both art history and non-art history majors.
I would advise students to attend all lectures and make sure to do the readings in advance.
If you have any interest in modern art (or phalluses...) take this class.
It is not entirely necessary to do the readings, but if you pay attention in lecture and do the readings for precept I think you will be good to go.
Please take this course. You will enjoy it. Art History is the best. And this is the best Art History course.

Professor Perl definitely loves her material and will try to fit a lot of analysis and artwork into 50 minute lectures. Don't worry about getting everything down; the papers and examinations don't require extremely minute memorization. Know general things about the artwork, movements, and just try to join in with her really genuine enthusiasm for the work. Enjoy the class!

Professor Perl is a new lecturer and her lectures show it--they are very fast and disorganized and throw tons of information at you. Precepts are really well done and the material is interesting. Do the readings--but it's possible to skim if you need to. Papers and exams are graded fairly but there is a lot of work during reading and finals period (but almost none the rest of the time).
Recommend.
TAKE IT
Take it if you are interested in contemporary art. It's not a joke class if you're looking for a gut, but it's really cool!
Take it!  Great introduction to the world of contemporary art.  Lectures are super engaging and the assignments are the right balance of challenging and manageable.

Take it! Do the readings. Show up for the lectures. Don't take it if you're not up for the workload, because if you try to slack off, you'll do poorly and you'll feel like an idiot for having wasted all the knowledge being thrown at you.
Take it! You won't regret it.
Take this course if you're interested in Modern Art because you will learn a ton

Take this course. It's easy to PDF, and if you show up to lecture you will take away a lot from it. Contemporary art--along with a fine knowledge of wines and travel--is essential for any Princeton undergrad seeking to make it as an elite.
good class, would recommend
no not unless they are art history major.
take it
this was my first art course at princeton, and i absolutely loved it.

very interesting content, lectures somewhat chaotic with a ton of information thrown at you but very interesting nonetheless. readings are good and Ashley is best preceptor. professor perl was very knowledgable and really cared about course and students. good art history course to take because highly relevant with social/ political content of recent decades!
descrip: A critical study of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of postwar art--abstract-expressionist, pop, minimalist, conceptual, process and performance, site-specific, etc. Special attention to crucial figures (e.g., Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Robert Smithson) and problems (e.g., "the neo-avant-garde", popular culture, feminist theory, political controversies, "postmodernism").

title: The Russian Short Story
prereqs: SLA 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: All readings are in Russian. This course traces the development of the Russian short story from the 1830's to 1930's. The entire course is conducted in Russian and special emphasis is placed on active use of the language.

title: Functional Analysis
prereqs: MAT 314/320, 332; MAT 317/330 or MAT331/335 helpful but not required; or permission by instructor..
descrip: Basic introductory course to modern methods of analysis. Specific applications of methods to problems in other fields, such as partial differential equations, probability, & number theory are presented. Topics include Lp spaces, tempered distribution, Fourier transform, Riesz interpolation theorem, Hardy-Littlewood maximal function, Calderon-Zygmund theory, oscillatory integrals, almost orthogonality, restriction theorems & applications to dispersive equations, law of large numbers & ergodic theory. Course also discusses applications of Fourier methods to discrete counting problems, using Poisson summation formula.

title: Modern Classical Dynamics
reviews: A very enlightening course. Background in tensor analysis and quantum mechanics is helpful but not required.

I have heard great things about this class in the past, but I did not find it that amazing. Polyakov has many fascinating digressions, but he is a hard to understand lecturer and is quite disorganized in his presentation.

Polyakov is brilliant and teaches a lot of interesting material in this course. Mostly covers mathematical formulation of Hamiltonian mechanics and fluid dynamics. Make sure to slow him down with questions.

Professor Polyakov is one of the best professors I have had at Princeton. Every class seems to have a profound insight about physics. He is not the best lecturer, but pay attention to everything he says. He has off-handedly made comments that answer my long-lingering questions about quantum mechanics, relativity, action-principles, etc.
The material is interesting and the course is relatively relaxed, but the lectures are very difficult to follow.

Unless this course vastly improves, I would not recommend taking it. It's very disorganized, lectures are incomprehensible, the material is disjointed, and despite much effort I feel that I've hardly learned anything.
descrip: Discussion of the most beautiful and important parts of classical dynamics: variational principles, ergodicity and chaos, fluid dynamics of vortices, shock waves and solitons as well as the theories of developed turbulence.

title: Neurogenetics of Behavior
reviews: A really fun class for anyone interested in genetics and neuroscience! Weekly readings are manageable, and required presentations are challenging but worthwhile.

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS COURSE. Very engaging, interesting, and enlightening course that teaches you not only Neurogenetics and the techniques and models available to scientists, but also how to read scientific papers critically and make more sense of them. The professors are very approachable, helpful, and knowledgeable, and not taking this course would be something to regret!!
Definitely take it!
Take it if you're interested in the subject and willing to put in the work to learn it.

This class has helped me develop a greater appreciation for how the advancements in science are through these accumulations of papers, each paper representing at least an entire year of experiments and careful analysis.
prereqs: MOL 214 or 215 and NEU 258 or ISC 235/236 or written permission from the instructor. MOL 342 (Genetics) is recommended.
descrip: How do seemingly simple organisms generate complex behaviors? This course will explore our current understanding of the genetic and neural basis for animal behavior, with an emphasis on cutting-edge research and model systems that are amenable to genetic manipulation. Each week we will discuss a new behavior with a focus on the underlying mechanisms; students will also lead discussions of primary literature. The goal of this course is to provide required background, knowledge, and critical thinking skills to move beyond the published literature to proposing original experiments. This effort will culminate in a final paper from each student.

title: Microeconomic Theory II
reviews: Do all of the problem sets thouroughly.
If you have a little bit idea for the contents of the curriculum, it would help a lot because professors assume (I think) that you know a little.
Studying for exams wont help. Just know how to think really hard!
Sure value
This course was an incentive compatible learning mechanism. We all learned a lot and reached a Pareto optimal Walrasian equilibrium.
You can use your time better than this.
descrip: This course is the second term of a 2 term sequence in Microeconomics.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Information Technology and Public Policy
descrip: Information technology plays an ever-growing role in our lives, our economy, and our government, putting pressure on existing policy arrangements and raising entirely new policy issues. This course examines a range of infotech policy issues, including privacy, intellectual property, free speech, competition, regulation of broadcasting and telecommunications, cross-border and jurisdictional questions, broadband policy, spectrum policy, management of the Internet, computer security, education and workforce development, and research funding.

title: Sensation and Perception
reviews: Awesome class! You get to learn about a ton of illusions and how they work.
Do make the effort to go to the lectures. They are the most interesting part of the course, and the rest is really low-time-commitment and easy to manage, if not a little "fast-food-boring".
Good PDF option.  The material is cool and interesting and it is very manageable with easy exams.
Great course! Should definitely take it if you have any interest in how human senses work.
Great, interesting class to PDF, good class for a neuroscience certificate candidate who does not want an overly biological/computational approach.
I highly recommend this class for anybody interested in psychology/neuroscience. I feel like I learned a lot, and Professor Pillow's lectures help make the material even more interesting.
I really enjoyed this class - the material was interesting and presented in an engaging way. All exams were multiple choice, which might change.
I would recommend this course. It was engaging material and pretty low time commitment. A good 5th course to take.
If you want a manageable workload, yet an incredibly interesting course with an engaging lecturer, take this class!!
If you're interested in the material, it's a really accessible course for any student. The topics are really interesting, but the curve might be harsh.
Its not hard, but because of that can get easy to zone out.
Pillow is a great lecturer.  Exams were all multiple choice and too easy.  Huge amount of overlap with NEU 258 material for students who already took that.
Pillow makes lectures interesting and you learn a lot about perception without much work.
Really awesome class with an interesting professor! Definitely take it. Minimal workload.

Really strong overview of the visual system, but didn't focus much on the other sensory modalities. Probably will make a lot more sense if you've taken some psych or neuro classes before. Precept was pretty boring.
Seems easy, but difficult to do well
Straight forward and easy exams! Professor Pillow is pretty awesome! precepts not the greatest
Take it if you want an easy class, but don't take it if you like learning.
Take it if you're interested in neuroscience
Take it if you're interested in this as a NEU/PSY concentrator. Otherwise, this course still offers a lot of insight about how we perceive the world that could be useful to anyone.
Take it!
Take it! So interesting, not very hard.
Take it! You will learn a lot and it doesn't take too much out of you.
Take it, even if you have no neuroscience background.
Take the course if even mildly interested in the intersection of neuroscience   psychology.
Take this course! Interesting!
Take this course! It is a great way to learn more about the way your own body works in daily life. If you are at all interested in neuroscience, you'll find this material interesting.

The material is very interesting, as are the lectures, and the workload is light. The exams are doable even without studying. You don't have to prepare much for precepts either if you don't want to, although it makes things pretty boring. If you want an easy class/to get superficial exposure to fun material, go for it; if you're looking to be truly stimulated, look elsewhere.
This course is interesting and easy. Not much work -- one presentation and some multiple choice exams.
This is a very easy, low stress course. Take it if you need a neuro class.
Very interesting and great course, definitely take!
Very interesting with minimal work required. Exams based on lectures with a few precept questions.
Would not recommend
easy AND interesting. definitely take it!
really interesting, but repetitive with NEU258- everything was covered then...
take it! loved it!
descrip: This course will provide an introduction to the scientific study of sensation and perception, the biological and psychological processes by which we perceive and interpret the world around us. We will undertake a detailed study of the major senses (vision, audition, touch, smell, taste), using insights from a variety of disciplines (philosophy, physics, computer science, neuroscience, psychology) to examine how these senses work and why. We will begin with physical bases for perceptual information (e.g., light, sound waves) and proceed to an investigation of the structures, circuits, and mechanisms by which the brain forms sensory percepts.

title: The Making of Modern France: French Literature, Culture, and Society from 1789 to the Present
reviews: Don't do all the readings because you will discuss very few of them in class.
Great class for bridging between 207 and 300-level French classes! Professor Wampole is the best, so any class with her will likely be a hit.
It is a great course to improve you knowledge about and consideration of modern French/European history, and to really apply French language skills in a sophisticated, practical context.
TAKE THIS CLASS PLEASE IF YOU ARE A FRENCH SPEAKER AND WANT TO LEARN ABOUT FRENCH CULTURE WITH A COOL HIP TEACHER AND YOU ARE WWS TAKE THIS CLASS.  IF YOU WANT TO FOCUS ON GRAMMAR ONLY TAKE 208.
Take it but know it's a lot of work
Take this class. You won't be disappointed.
prereqs: Prerequisites: 107, 108, or equivalent. 207 recommended as a co-requisite..
descrip: This course examines the major historical and cultural developments that have shaped France since the Revolution. By studying a series of classic texts, important films, paintings, and essays, we will undertake an interdisciplinary tour through two centuries of French cultural history, addressing issues such as nationhood, colonialism, democracy, and consumer society. The focus will be on the relations between artistic renovation, social change, and historical events.

title: Problems in Greek Literature - Ancient Prose Fiction
descrip: A survey of Greek prose fiction with the aim of exploring the structures, techniques, themes, influences, and preoccupations of the ancient novel/romance in its cultural and historical contexts. Attention to theories of the genre and its development in the expanded borders of the Greek world from the Hellenistic period to late antiquity. We will focus primarily on Chariton, Achilles Tatius, Longus, and Heliodorus, with attention, if interest warrants it to the Roman examples of Petronius and Apuleius. Appropriate secondary readings, including Bakhtin, Foucault, Goldhill, Konstan, Whitmarsh, Morales, Morgan.

title: Cultures of Punishment
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Life in a Nuclear-Armed World
descrip: See website

title: Computational Neuroscience and Computing Networks
descrip: Introduction to a mathematical description of how networks of neurons can represent information and compute with it. Course will survey computational modeling and data analysis methods for neuroscience. Topics will include representation of visual information, spatial navigation, short-term memory, and decision-making. Two 90 minute lectures, one laboratory. Lectures in common with NEU 437. Graduate students will carry out and write up an in-depth semester-long project.

title: The Media in America - What to Read and Believe in the Digital Age
reviews: Absolutely worth taking. You'll learn more about the media, get up to date on current events, meet incredible speakers (we couldn't even count how many Pullitzers they had combined), go on awesome field trips, improve your writing through feedback, and pursue a research topic that interests you. It's as work intensive as you make it. Highly recommend.

Definitely take it. Professor Stephens is great and clearly enjoys teaching the class which makes it that much more enjoyable to take it. Amazing guest speakers who are extremely prominent in journalism and very cool field trips as well as just cool seminars week to week. Easily my favorite class thus far at Princeton.

Definitely take this course. Professor Stephens is one of the best professors you will have at Princeton and this course focuses on pressing issues facing the news industry today. Plus, we had the opportunity to meet really incredible, famous journalists and take field trips to the Daily Show and the New York Times. Overall learned a lot about how to be a journalist as well. Definitely recommend.
If this course is still The Media in America: What to Read and Believe in the Digital Age with Prof. Stephens, TAKE IT.  This class was probably one of my favorite classes at Princeton.

Please, if you're taking this course, do a lot of work on your final project throughout the course. I wish I were prouder of my final project, and I want anyone who takes this course to be able to be proud as well.
Take this class. Professor Stephens was great and you will learn a lot. Not overwhelming at all.
Take this course if you have any interest in journalism, or even if you don't! It was fantastic.
Take this course! Professor Stephens is an awesome professor. The speakers and field trips in this class are unmatched.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu/journalism/courses.
descrip: This seminar will explore the challenges and opportunities that today's rapidly evolving media landscape presents to freedom of the press, and to the democracy that the media serve. Discussion will focus on where news comes from and how citizens can best assess the credibility of individual news reports. Students will evaluate how successful traditional mass-media outlets and emerging digital media have been at accomplishing the lofty goals embodied in the First Amendment. They will craft strategies for determining their own personal media diet and work to develop new models for serious, sustainable news ventures.

title: Biophysical Chemistry II
prereqs: Some background in chemistry and familiarity with basic biochemical terms is assumed, but there are no specific prerequisites..
descrip: Broad introduction to major contemporary techniques used to study structures, functions, and interactions of biological macromolecules, including quantitative theory of molecular interactions. Aims to convey to students with diverse backgrounds and interests the utility of various experimental methods for solving molecular problems. Emphasis is on applications, practical aspects, and experimental design, and on strengths and limitations of individual methods and complementarities among them.

title: Intimate Geographies: Space and Place in Modern Hebrew and Arabic Literature
descrip: What are the meanings of space and place for people in a region where geography is overwhelmingly politicized? This course will explore the fictional and autobiographical poetics of social space as expressed in literature and film from Israel and the Arab world. Although these works focus on dramas of love and loss, friendship and the family, we will also see how political conditions influence personal and collective experiences of space. Along the way, we will gain additional insights from theoreticians who have explored the meanings of space as a place, as a condition, and as a practice. All readings are in English translation.

title: Art for Everyone
reviews: A great PDF course. However, I do wish we had been able to work in more art mediums that weren't just computer or technology-based.
A very entertaining course taught by one of the best instructors in the department! One of the easier courses at Princeton, but you will still learn many useful skills!
Absolutely take it. It may not be a ton of work, but it's definitely not a joke class. The material is really cool and interesting and a great digression from engineering
Definitely take it. It is a p/d/f only course, which takes off the pressure a little bit if you're not the most acute in art. It's very interesting and you get hands-on experience.
Take it!! Fia's awesome, and you'll do well if you do the work and readings.
Take this course! Fia is great and the class isn't demanding at all. You'll do some pretty unique projects but it's a very easy and fun course.
not a lot of work, stretches your creativity - get prepared to get weird
prereqs: Restriction: This course is not open to students who took VIS 472, Special Topics in Visual Arts - Art for Everyone.
descrip: This studio class will address the increasing social pressure on art to become more widely distributed, immediately accessible, and democratically produced. For the past fifty years, expanding definitions of what art might be fueled by a greater emphasis on active audience participation have encouraged an atmosphere in which anyone can claim to be an artist. Through studio work in a wide range of graphic and digital media, supported by readings and discussions, this class will take a hands-on approach to the question of whether art by everyone for everyone constitutes a dreamed-of utopia, a universal banality, or a cultural nightmare.

title: Topics in Number Theory - Algebraic Number Theory
prereqs: Prerequisites: MAT 214 and 345 or equivalent..
descrip: Course on algebraic number theory. Topics covered include number fields and their integer rings, class groups, zeta and L-functions.

title: What is Vernacular Filmmaking?
reviews: Definitely take it.  It gave me a new perspective on film and allowed me to appreciate it more as an art-form.
Definitely take it. Very interesting if you like movies. You will be introduced to some great films. Professor Kiss is awesome.
I would recommend this course to students who have not taken a film course before, or who are interested in European films specifically.
Take it to get pushed into a new way of seeing a medium you're already familiar with.
Take it, and watch all the films.
descrip: We will study films that address global audiences while rooted in particular, local,vernacular sources of artistic creation. In order to understand this aesthetic phenomenon of World Cinema, we will examine theories of World Literature. Especially, we will focus on Auerbach's famous book, Mimesis and his work on the formation of vernacular audiences.

title: Gender and Sexuality in American Politics and Policy
descrip: This course examines the ways in which gender and sexuality shape and are shaped by U.S. politics and public policy, emphasizing intersections with other categories, identities, and forms of marginalization including race, ethnicity, class, ideology, and partisan identification. We examine the history, approaches, and controversies in research about gender and sexuality in U.S. politics from a range of theoretical and methodological approaches. We also explore feminist, queer, and intersectional theories and methodologies, related work from other disciplines, and research that does not fit neatly into traditional disciplinary categories.

title: From the Earth to the Moon
descrip: See website

title: Reasoning about Computation
reviews: Are you good at self-teaching ?
Attend lectures and read (lots of good/useful information can be fund in the reading that might not have been discussed in class). The course is difficult.
Budget your time wisely. The material's actually pretty interesting as long as you don't hate yourself doing it.
Challenging material if you aren't familiar with rigorous mathematics, but definitely worthwhile. You'll be surprised with how much material you've learned by the course's end
Clear up your semester and make the rest of it easy if you have to do this class.
Do not take this course unless you absolutely must.

Don't take this class unless you have to. I'm a Engineering COS major who cruised through 126,217,226 with ease. I am not a potential math major. This class was super hard, and a massive time sink (problem sets every week, yay). Please, for your sanity, take it in a 4-class semester.
