Life is hard and you are going to get wrecked (unless you were nationally ranked in the AMC/AIME and loved the problems). Just accept your terrible fate. Also, I didn't join a group, which meant midterms and the final (when you *have* to work alone) were less bad, but also meant I was alone on that struggle every week, which sucked.
Don't take this. I'm sorry if you have to.
Don't take unless you have to (COS majors), poorly taught and mostly not very interesting. Except to spend 10  hours on every problem set, most likely a lot more, and probably still not do very well.
Don't this class unless you need to. It actually would be interesting though to pdf if you wanted to learn because the material is interesting.
Don't.
Extremely high work load. Take at your own risk.
Find a good group of students to work with. Always ask questions/check proofs if given the chance.

Find a group. Shiva is a good professor. He really cares about us. We were all doing so badly that he created Thursday Struggle Sessions where he helped the strugglers. He also made it so we could drop 6 problems and 1 on each exam. Hollerrrrr. Be prepared for high averages and evil math lovers. <3
I don't recommend taking it with Shiva

I think it's important for every computer science major to take COS 340. Topics like graph theory, NP-completeness, computability, and probability form the basis of theoretical computer science. To gain an appreciation for the achievements in research up to this point, it's necessary to take a course like this one, and 340 is all that we have for an introductory level. Having said that, it was hands down the most difficult class I've ever taken. I had never done a proof before (unless you count the two-column proofs from high school geometry) and the topics were all completely new. The course progressed at a rapid pace and there was almost no sense of building on past material. I never felt prepared for the problem sets, which often fell into the category of "you see the trick or you don't". The problem sets took me around 25 hours per week. Our year, it felt like the course staff was against us, publishing unfavorable curves and always looking for mistakes in our proofs rather than trying to give us points for what we did correctly. It seemed like the instructors were out of touch with how difficult the course was for someone who had never done a proof before. It's almost impossible to fulfill the theory requirement without this course, so there's really nothing else to say. I would give advice on how to prepare, but I don't have an answer for that. If you've taken upper level math at Princeton, I guess this course could be easy for you, as indicated by some of the comments I heard throughout the semester. Otherwise, anticipate that this will be your semester's most difficult class and leave enough time for it.
If you don't have to, avoid this class.

If you take it if you have to, you'll hate it.
If you take it because you're interested/experienced, I hate you.

If you're COS, you don't really have a choice. The course is very intellectually stimulating and it's a good way to learn how to write proofs. At the same time, assignments can be quite time consuming.
If you're a COS major then you have to take this "core elective"

If you're a COS major, this class is basically required, and I'm truly sorry for that. Every semester, something like 20-30% of the students drop because the assignments are really difficult and graded harshly.

It is not really a cos class, it is a math class. Take it if you are interested in approaching cos from a proof-based point of view, of if you are interested in increasing your "culture" in discrete math/connections between math and cos.
It's highly recommended for COS majors and you should probably take it; it's important and valuable to know this material.
It's really hard, Shiva made it harder this year. But preceptors and Shiva are very open to helping - take advantage of that!

Make sure you attend office hours (not the lecturer's), because the TA's will often give away hints to solving the problems, which will make your life much easier. Also, beware of the curve, as many people drop early on and the curve becomes really tough as towards the end of semester, the median is 100% on almost every homework problem and even most exam problems.
Not terribly valuable. Takes a lot of time.
Only take this course if you have to. If Shiva is teaching, wait for another semester.

Read the problems early each week because you never know when an idea will hit you! Carry around the p-set everywhere so you can check the problem wording or jot down ideas when something inevitable strikes you! And don't be afraid to ask for help, go to office hours, etc. You won't be able to solve these problems without understanding the concepts and example problems thoroughly. But they are very doable with some critical thinking, a good work group, and some time if you do.
Take a math course before this like 214 or 215.
Take it if you enjoy theory and/or are a COS major.

Take it with Braverman. Taking it with Kintali was a pretty rough experience, but he's not going to be teaching it anymore. Also, office hours are super helpful, and if Ted is still here, definitely go to his. Latexing takes a very long time, so beware of starting the pset late, finishing it, and not having time to latex. Happened to me once. The course overall is really interesting, and I really enjoyed the problems, but they do take a LOT of time. Literally the most time intensive course I've ever taken.

Take it! If at all possible, take it the same semester as a group of close friends as you do all work in this class in groups of threes. There is a definite difficulty curve, I hardcore struggled until a switch flipped in me after the first midterm. Go to Office Hours (they sometimes give answers! And always give spot-on help), especillay just to ask about concepts. This class covers a wide variety of material and it will all come up on the time-limited mideterms and final, so keep up. Also, READ THE BOOK. The MIT coursenotes are hilarious and perfect and will make you fall even more in love with COS 340. As you may be guessing from these reivews, this class has quite a bit of Stockholm Syndrome going on...
Take this class, but be prepared to put in a lot of time.

This class is a huge, huge time commitment. Be prepared for tears and stress. Take it with friends. And if you don't, you will make friends. This class brings people together. Start early, go to office hours, read the notes. It's a lot, but the material is super interesting. You will survive.
This course is definitely a time-suck. Make sure you have a good group beforehand, and ideally have at least one person take a course in number theory.

This course relies heavily on proofs, but does not teach you how to do a proof. Ideally take a math class involving proofs before hand because the math department will teach you how to do a proof. (Or if you're not a COS major, just take a math class instead of this class)
Tough course but definitely take it for a theory requirement

Unless you have extensive experience with the mathematics and proof-writing in this course, it will consume a huge amount of time. This is not to say that it is impossible to do well and learn the material rapidly, but be prepared to work harder than you have for any previous course just to pass.

Very time consuming, but I definitely greatly improved my mathematical ability. Get a strong group to work on problems together. No idea how hard Tarjan's version will be, but the class was hard when Kintali taught it.
Work. Work. Work. Work.

You have to take this course in order to fulfil you theory requirement. It is a terrible course, worse than undergoing surgery without anesthetic. Go to lecture, try and piece together the material, and get the Math Olympiad students taking the class to teach you the things they learned in middle school that the lecturer can't figure out how to teach you at Princeton.
You'll be fine if you have proof-based math experience. Otherwise, get ready to work hard.

You'll only take this course if you have to, so just try to get through it. There's no point to this recommendation, because nobody takes this for fun (unless you're a math major, congrats on your future A).
You'll probably have to take it for the theory requirement, but if you don't, run far far away from this class (unless you're a math genius).
you have to take it. shiva is leaving so you should be fine.
prereqs: COS 126 and 226 (or sufficient mathematical background), and MAT 175, 202, 204. COS 226 can be taken along with COS 340 in the same term. Please contact the professor directly with any questions you may have..
descrip: An introduction to mathematical topics relevant to computer science. Combinatorics and probability will be covered in the context of computer science applications. The course will present a computer science approach to thinking and modeling through topics such as dealing with uncertainty in data and handling large data sets. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts such as NP-completeness and cryptography that arise from the world view of efficient computation.

title: Women, Gender and Islam
reviews: Be prepared to do a large amount of work and come prepared to be engaged with all the lectures.
Develop a thick skin.
If Professor Guessous teaches this class again, I would so recommend taking it with her. Challenging but very rewarding. Regardless, very much enjoyed course content.

If you are interested in the topic you should take the class,  but beware if Prof.  Nadia is teaching the course.  Her attitude and rude comments were enough for me to want to drop the course.  I have never had a proffesdor as rude as she has been. Never getting grades in the course also just adds to the stress of it all.
Take only if you are very interested in Anthropological studies. Prof is a little scary and favors those who see things like she does.
Terrible. Prof Guessous was condescending and unhelpful. Unclear assignments. No feedback. Worst office hours ever. Topic was interesting but I was so disappointed.
descrip: This seminar introduces students to the varieties of ways in which Muslim women of different generations, social classes, educational background, political orientation and regions inhabit and embody their Muslim identities. Our focus will be on Muslim women in the modern Middle East. Readings are drawn from the fields of history, religious studies, and anthropology. Readings also include novels and memoirs in translation. Films are an integral part of the course.

title: Modern Jewish History: 1750-Present
reviews: As a non-History major, I found the course very accessible. Professor Dweck also does an excellent job in engaging the class.

Best class I've taken at Princeton. Prof. Dweck is so dynamic and brilliant (and he knows it, but that's another story) and the subject matter is actually really fascinating. The readings are good, the papers are reasonable (and graded leniently) and those lectures are just so phenomenal. 80 minutes flew by, every time.
Come to class prepared to talk.
Definitely take this class!
Do the readings :)
Do the readings so that you can participate in discussions! They are necessary to complete in order to keep up with the material!
I highly recommend this course. Dweck is very engaging and cares about his students. The readings are actually interesting and the writing assignments are creative.
I you are interested in Jewish history take this course.
If you're generally interested at all, it's a great HA with a phenomenal professor.
Professor Dweck is an amazing teacher and you will learn so much through this course. Definitely worth it.
Take it!  Professor Dweck is a great lecturer and overall a great person.  The subject is fascinating as well.
Take the course! Great introduction to modern jewish history. But make sure you do all of the readings carefully.
This is a great course - Prof. Dweck is a very engaging lecturer, and cares about his students and is a reasonable grader.

This is a must-take class. Professor Dweck is an incredible professor, and you will not be disappointed by the lectures or readings. I cannot overemphasize how incredible Professor Dweck is. Modern Jewish History might not sound relevant or interesting to people who are not Jewish, but the course covers a lot of European history as it traces the Jewish population from the 1400s onwards. As a result, I learned a lot more about European history than I anticipated going into the class.
Though the reading assignments may seem a bit long or dense, this is a great class! Professor Dweck's knowledge, enthusiasm, and humor make the class thoroughly enjoyable.
Try to do the readings. It will make the lectures more interesting if you are prepared.
descrip: This course surveys the breadth of Jewish experience from the era of the Enlightenment to the contemporary period. Tracing the development of Jewish cultures and communities in Europe, the Middle East, and the United States against the background of general history, the lectures focus on themes such as the transformation of Jewish identity, the creation of modern Jewish politics, the impact of anti-semitism, and the founding of the State of Israel.

title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition
reviews: Be prepared to work hard!
Be very open minded
Good intro to MUS theory...Tymoczko isn't the most inspiring person/professor but he presents the material in a more vivid way than other theorists here.

Great course, highly recommended for those with at least a decent musical background and interest in music whatsoever. This class changed the way I listen to and think about music. Try to get into Dmitri's precept if you want to maximize your learning experience, though he can be tougher than the other preceptors.
I rarely give such high ratings during course evaluations, but this course with Prof. Tymoczko deserves it
If play an instrument, I highly recommend taking it. It's a time commitment, but it's 100% worth it.
If you already took 105, take this because it is much more interesting and somewhat easier too.
If you need it for the certificate program then you have to take it, but also take it if you're interested in the technicalities of music theory and if you like composition (lots of composing)

If you're reading this deciding whether to take 105 in the fall for 2015, do it! Dmitri IS teaching 105-106 next year (but maybe for the last time), so do it then because his lectures are great and I've heard the class is duller without him. If you're reading this while taking 105 in fall 2015, take 106 right after if you think you ever will, since it builds on 105. 105 was more fundamentals, 106 is more fun music and composition (you can finally start to break some rules!). If you didn't like composing for piano though, there's a lot more of that here. Know that Dmitri's precept is great for learning, but graded more harshly for sure.
It is fast paced. You will learn more than you ever thought possible.

It's worth taking, but don't take it if you think you can just be writing anything you want. It's a lot of forced composition, and it's in styles I assume don't really inspire real art from most of you.
Keep up with the material, and practice! It's important to familiarize yourself with the course material, as there is a lot to learn and memorize.
Listen to a lot of music. Start the homework early. Don't be afraid to email him, but also be very clear and respectful in the emails.
ONLY take this is you are considering being a music major or obtaining a certificate!!!! Otherwise, it is so much time.
Only continue from 105 if you're serious about studying music.

Particularly if you took MUS 105, this course is exceptionally good. The material that is covered is, in my opinion, far more interesting than the material covered in 105. Overall, this course was a blast (though it is difficult).
READ THE HANDOUTS! PRACTICE!

Start the assignments early and don't overcomplicate what you are asked to do. (For example, compositions are graded based on whether you included the necessary elements; don't burden yourself by trying to make some crazy clever piece). STUDY THE HANDOUTS!!! Dmitri's handouts are insanely clear and informative.  This is where much of the exam material will be drawn from.
Start your psets the day they are posted.

Take full advantage of your preceptors, and take the time to ask them about their work and studies.  Do ear training exercises on Teoria even when they are not assigned.  If you can, take the course and simultaneously participate in one of Princeton's many performing groups, because it definitely supplements your training in theory to be applying the principles in a separate performance venue.
Take it!
Take it.
Take this course with Dmitri while you still can!!

Take this course!  It will help you understand many types of music better.  There is a much greater breadth of material covered in 106 as opposed to 105.  106 is better than 105, so don't be discouraged from taking 106 because of any difficulties with 105.
The class takes up a lot of time, only take it if you are serious about music and willing to put in the work.
practice!
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of the instructor. This course is a prerequisite for all upper-level theory work, and should be taken by any freshman considering majoring in music, entering the Certificate Program, or taking upper-level music courses..
descrip: A continuation of MUS 105, with an emphasis on the harmonic and formal principles of Western classical music. We will focus on modulation, chromatic harmony, and form, continuing to study and compose music in classical and other styles.

title: Infection: Biology, Burden, Policy
reviews: Definitely take it! Make sure you participate. Don't be afraid to ask questions.
Great course, light workload, just be weary that participation is a big chunk, and is a little difficult to get.

Great course. Great professors, readings, and assignments. Not a lot of effort required but you learn a lot and enjoy the course. These professors are incredibly gifted and fun; it was great to have a chance to get to know them.
Great course. Not too much work, and you learn a lot from the presentations. Great professors who really know a lot about the topic.
Interesting course but 30  size makes participation difficult.
Not the best course to take if you're interested in learning about both science and policy.
One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. A must take for mol majors.
Regardless of your academic background, this course is very relevant and great to take. A biology background isn't necessary if this is something you are truly interested in.
Strong scientific background is necessary for policy students.
Strongly recommended - regardless of your major.
TAKE THIS COURSE!

TAKE THIS. Professors Mahmoud and Shenk are fantastic, and you'll learn a lot, while having very interesting class discussions. You must take a course with Professor Mahmoud and Shenk before graduating!
Take it.

Take this class. Take this class. Take this class. One of the best classes I've ever taken at Princeton. This is an example of one of the classes that you come to Princeton for. Makes all the MOL/pre-med prerequisites you took worth it.
This course was good in that I learned more about infectious diseases, but a little disappointing because I did not learn as much about health policy.
This is a good course - it is similar to GHP 400, but there are fewer guest lectures and less discussion (basically more like a traditional lecture course). I really liked the oral presentation part.
Worth taking for the professors, but expect to hear a lot you've heard before if you're GHP or MOL.

You may find it less engaging at points if you're a MOL major or WWS student, but there is a lot of useful material that is still familiar to your discipline and the class is highly interactive and useful.
prereqs: MOL101, MOL 214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will examine fundamental determinants of human microbe interaction at the biological and ecological levels. The focus will be on major global infectious diseases, their burden of illness and policy challenges for adequate prevention and control. Each infectious agent will be discussed in terms of its biology, mechanisms of pathogenesis, and epidemiology, as well as strategies for its control. Specific emphasis will be placed on the public health aspects of each disease.

title: Scripture and Tradition among Early Rabbis and Christians
prereqs: The course does not have a language requirement, but graduate students able to do so are encouraged to prepare primary sources in the original Hebrew and Greek..
descrip: Scholars commonly define rabbinic Judaism by recourse both to the notion of "Oral Law," a received tradition, and to scriptural interpretation - midrash. The first part of the course examines these two authority paradigms, calling into question the entrenched scholarly assumption that they are complementary. Textually, our focus is the tannaitic legal commentaries ascribed to the schools of Rabbi Ishmael and Rabbi Akiva. The second part of the course examines the role of received tradition in early Christian circles, with special attention paid to the Apostolic Father Papias.

title: Civitas Foundation Finance Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Nonlinear System Theory
prereqs: Prerequisite: ELE521/MAE547 or MAE434.
descrip: This course covers topics in nonlinear dynamical systems including phase plane analysis, Lyapunov stability, input-output stability, passivity, averaging and singular perturbations for time-scale separation.

title: Educational Psychology
reviews: Do the readings and engage in class! You get what you put in.
Have fun

I would recommend those taking the course to keep up with the readings and papers as they come along (as the deadlines in the class may be bypassed and all the work turned in on Dean's date). Otherwise, if you are interested in the subject, the class and Prof. Glat give a good introduction to Educational Psychology.
It's required for TPP, so you probably don't have a choice. Just know that Prof. Glat is a terrible instructor and the content overlaps significantly with TPP 301.

Keep up on the weekly reaction papers and try to schedule the observations during the semester! There is a lot of extra work in this class that you do not want to leave to the last minute, since the final paper also requires substantial research and time!
Take if and only if you care about teaching.
Take it if you have any interest in education
Take it! Education  Psychology   Glat=WIN!
This is a great class, I highly recommend it.
You will be busy, especially if taken concurrently with TPP 301.  With classroom observations and write-ups, time management is essential, especially as the end of the course nears.
prereqs: This course is required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Priority is given to Juniors and Seniors in TPP. Other Juniors and Seniors may enroll only with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.

title: The Great Russian Novel and Beyond: Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, and Others
reviews: A very good course for people interested (especially if it is not the main interest) in literature.

A wonderful class - great texts, nice precepts that are usually with the professor herself who is very nice and funny, only thing that could get better was the actual stimulating-ness of the lectures (could use more visuals etc instead of just talking)
Anyone with the chance to take this course should- Professor Chances is both brilliant and incredibly kind, the class is genuinely interesting, and the readings are otherworldly.

Chances is amazing, great lecturer, will teach you everything about these authors and the period. It is a TREMENDOUS amount of work. Says around 150 pages a week when it is actually usually 400, and the midterm questions were fiendishly difficult
Definitely take this class - it is wonderful!
Don't do all the reading if you can't manage, you'll be fine if you attend lecture and pay attention in precept
Great class, but if only if you can feasibly complete the readings, as they are heavy
Highly recommended if you like Russian literature and don't mind keeping up with the readings.
I highly recommend this course if you are interested in Russian literature, history, or literature in general. It is also a good general LA.
I would encourage them to keep up with the readings from day one. It is essential that you finish all the readings if you wish to get the most out of the course.
If you have the time in your semester to dedicate (to do the reading), I would definitely recommend this course.
Interesting class, awesome material, a little disorganized but still would take it again!
It's a fair amount of reading but it covers some really major Russian works of literature. There is also good diversity in the works assigned, so you get to cover a lot of different authors.
Russian literature is really interesting and meaningful, and Professor Chances really brings it alive. Definitely recommend.
TAKE IT.
Take it and it gives you a great background on some of the best pieces of russian literature,
Take it if you're remotely interested in Russian literature!

Take it! If you're interested in Russian Lit, or think you might be, or want to explore some of the greatest writers about the human condition (and this should be everyone) this course is a good fit. Professor Chances presents the material comphrensivoely and cogently, and is an eminently erudite, skillful, and kind professor.
Take this course if you like to read and you want to read Russian books! Very simple.
The readings are amazing, and Professor Chances is a passionate lecturer and a friendly preceptor. Overall a great class!

This class is great for giving an overview of some of the greatest works of Russian literature.  Be prepared to do a lot of reading, but the reading is fun to do if you enjoy Russian literature.  Overall the class is very enjoyable.
Try to stay on top of the readings.
prereqs: Curiosity. Knowledge of Russian not required. Open to first-year students as well as to sophomores, juniors, and seniors in any department..
descrip: An examination of significant trends in Russian literature from the 2nd half of the 19th century to the Russian Revolution and a bit beyond. The course focuses on many masterpieces of 19th & 20th-century Russian literature. The works (mostly novels) are considered from a stylistic point of view and in the context of Russian historical and cultural developments. The course also focuses on questions of values and on the eternal "big questions" of life that are raised in the literature. Authors read include Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bely, Nabokov, and Kharms.

title: Elementary Turkish II
reviews: N/A. If you're considering TUR 102, you've probably already taken 101 and don't have much choice. That said, it's a great course as Professor Hatemi is a superb professor.
prereqs: TUR 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Familiarity with all grammatical aspects of Modern Turkish. Reading text of moderate difficulty; developing communicative skills: ability to comprehend and engage in daily discourse; ability to write short compositions.

title: Cognitive Psychology
reviews: A great class to take to fulfill the RIS certificate requirement.
Be sure that you like the idea of a more technical psychology. This is not social--in fact, it's meant for robotics certificates. I didn't know that going in, so be careful!
DO NOT TAKE.
Go to lecture.
I don't know what labs will be like for this class in the future, so I can't really say.
I hear they are changing the course, so I don't think this is relevant anymore if they add a lab to this.
I know that this course is changing considerably (labs? How are they going to squeeze labs into this course?), so I'm not sure whether to recommend it or not.

I would recommend taking the class, especially if Dr. Taylor is teaching it.  Although the textbook is listed as required reading, it's not actually useful and in some cases got me in trouble; go with his lecture slides instead.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in the subject matter. It is probably not a course you want to take for a distribution requirement or without previous knowledge of the material.
If you want a really interesting class that is almost no work if you PDF, this is for you. Jordan is a great lecturer and the small amount of reading you have to do is interesting.
If you're interested in robotics or applied neuroscience, this is a good course. If the layout stays the same (weekly journal readings and a quiz), it is a VERY manageable class and worth it.
It isn't too hard to do reasonably well and the topic is reasonably interesting, especially if you like cognitive psychology.
It was a fun class to take with a group of friends.
Its really easy to PDF.
Loved the class. Professor Taylor rocks and Matt is a great preceptor.  No complaints.
Make sure to go to the lectures. They're interesting and go by quickly. That should be more than enough to learn all the material.
Study lecture slides and attend all lectures.
Study specific facts and experiments
Take good notes in lecture, as the Powerpoints are hard to follow if you don't have explanations for the slides.
Take it if you have any interest in the material. Prof. Taylor's lectures are great, precepts are straight to the point and helpful, and exams are completely reasonable.

Take it if you're interesting in cognitive psych. It's not always the most new/interesting material, but there are some cool parts. It's not a tremendous amount of work, either, though sometimes the precept papers are a bit hard to get through. It's a fun class!
Take it with Sam!!
Take it!
Take it! It is so fun and you will learn so much!
Take the course and go to lecture.
Take this over PSY 208 (for non-psych majors)!!! Its the same material but it is much easier to understand and much more engaging.
Taylor's a great prof. take it

This is a good class to satisfy a distribution requirement. It is a broad survey of several topics in cognitive psychology. Professor Taylor is great, demos during lectures are really interesting. I would definitely recommend.
Try to find another class to fulfill the EC.  It's probably better to find a subject you genuinely are interested in, though Prof Taylor does do a good job of making the material interesting.
Very interesting class and not difficult. I loved this class, take it.

Very nice fifth course. Solid overview of the field of cognitive psychology that helps you better understand what's going on in your brain. Interesting lectures and generally relevant readings. Expect 1-3 hours of work per week.
take this class!
descrip: The course will survey the major themes and experimental findings of Cognitive Psychology. We will address the question of how scientists probe the nature and underlying structure of human thought. Topics covered include attention, perception, imagery, memory, language, thinking, decision making, and cognitive neuroscience.

title: Women and Gender in Early Modern England
descrip: In this seminar we will explore women's lives in early modern England, ideas about gender and sex, and the interactions of people and ideas. While we will cover exceptional women (queens, witches, writers), we will focus on the ordinary women who made up the majority of the population. Readings will be drawn largely from primary texts, including letters, memoirs, testimony, ballads, ephemera, and advice books. By exploring how legal and religious institutions shaped women's lives, we will gain insight into major issues (family, law, poverty, consumption, crime, the social order, etc.) in early modern English society as a whole.

title: Advanced Topics in Modern Architecture - History and Theory of Architecture and Climate
reviews: Careful with who's instructing the course when you signed up.
descrip: Architects have long been concerned with the relationship of a building to its climate. Focused on the decade immediately following World War II, before mechanical HVAC systems were affordable or widespread, this seminar explores the archive of methodological experiments and technological devices that were intended to refine the climatic performance of a building. Many of these explorations took place at Princeton, in architecture and elsewhere. We also explore the conceptual frameworks that allow us to consider these architectural experiments in light of the historiographic and epistemological challenges posed by climate change.

title: Biology of African Animals and Ecosystems
reviews: Be prepared to write alot of papers
Definitely do the readings before the trip if you can.
prereqs: EEB 211 and EEB 321. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: Students will be immersed in an intensive field experience in Kenya gaining sophisticated training in fieldwork and biological research on African animals and ecosystems. In addition to this training, participants will observe and study organisms ranging from acacia ants to giraffes, go-away-birds to zebras. The course is designed to give students a broad, hands-on understanding of ecology, evolution, and conservation. Lectures include core topics in ecology and evolution. Students will gain experience with experimental design, data collection, and analysis. Limited to students in the Tropical Biology and Sustainability Program in Kenya.

title: Public Finance
reviews: Don't take unless you love economics regarding taxes. Surprisingly difficult.

Excellent course if Rosen is teaching.  Mostly just rehashing intermediate Micro theories in public finance contexts, with more discussion of actual policy later in the semester.  I could see how the material could get a bit dry, but Rosen's experience and insights from his time government allow him to describe how these policies actually play out in the real world and the issues he encountered with them.
Go to every lecture as they are very important for the exams.

Great course! Rosen is a phenomenal teacher. If you aren't at all interested in tax policy the second half might be dull for you, but he admits that right up front. If you are interested in all that stuff, it's one of the best classes out there! Also it's both interesting and not too much work, which is the ideal situation.
Harvey Rosen is very engaging and if you want to learn about a somewhat dry but practical subject, take this course.

I don't know why, but I think I'm in the minority... I didn't like this class at all. Maybe I just don't mesh well with Rosen's teaching style. Anyway, not that much work, but exams were hard since I mostly had to learn the material on my own..
I would definitely recommend taking this course.
If you haven't had a course with Professor Rosen, I'd strongly recommend taking this class.
Really good class. No work from week to week and if you just go to lecture and pay attention (which is easy to do with Rosen) then you'll be able to do well.
Rosen is a very good lecturer
Rosen is great. Take it for his insights and his experience with actual public policy
Take it! Rosen is great--make sure you go to all the lectures.

The class is very good, although personally I didn't find the subject matter very interesting. I would take this class if you are somewhat interested in public finance; if you aren't, or are foreign, you learn a good amount about the United States government, tax code, etc. Helpful stuff.
The information is useful, and Professor Rosen makes taxes as interesting as they can be. Stay on top of the material as the semester progresses. It will make studying for the final a lot easier.
Would strongly recommend. Rosen is a great professor. If you're interested in the tax system at all, this is the class to take.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 or WWS 300..
descrip: This course is about the microeconomic functions of government -- the way in which government expenditure and tax policies affect resource allocation and the distribution of income.

title: Illusions, Delusions, and Neuroscience
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Information Signals
reviews: Be direct and ask more questions on Piazza. Go to Cuff's office hours. Focus on the homework. Do not take if you're not ELE.
Be prepared for the material not to click for a while
Definitely spend the time to go to Professor Cuff's office hours. He does such a great job  disseminating information in smaller settings.
Definitely take it!
Don't be afraid to view each lecture video more than once - it is not a waste of time in the long run!

Don't take it as a freshman unless you are a math whiz and like signals and want to be an ELE major.  It's probably better as a sophomore after you've taken some other ELE courses.  Also, it's really math-focused which can be painful at times.  Know your Matlab too for labs!

If you are ELE, you'll need to take it. There is not much you need to prepare, and multivariable/linear algebra are not really even prerequisites. However, you will need a sharp mind with the concepts behind calculus and infinite sums to be able to do well in the course, and this only comes with experience, so it may be good to be at least up to diff. eq. in math before you give this class a go.

If you are not ELE, then you should only take it if you are interested in applied mathematics, or if its somehow relevant to your major. Its content primarily consists of how to use different integral transforms, (Fourier, Laplace, Z-trans), with some content involving encrypting and compressing data, as well as some control theory with linear time-invariant systems.

If you're not an ELE major, think carefully before taking this class. I think it's an amazing introduction to Fourier, signals, and systems, and you learn a lot. But the first week is deceptively simple (complex numbers) and then just jumps into Fourier series. It didn't really come together until week 4 for me, but once it did it was amazing. Make sure to rewatch lecture videos (at 2x speed) if you feel like lecture is too confusing. Also do not fall behind on the content. If you miss a class, and you will, watch the videos to make it up right away. It's very manageable unless you let the missed lectures build up and then have to cram like 6 for a pset. Overall, would recommend but you need to come in ready to put in a lot of effort. Luckily lectures cover most the needed material (no textbook reading needed).

If you're taking this course because you want to learn about signal processing, be aware that the course is mostly math, and probably isn't going to be as fun as you were expecting. The material however is undeniably useful.
Just learn it all by yourself.

Labs are poorly organized, class is good. Content is scattered all over the place, but you definitely learn interesting things, and Cuff is a very understandable lecturer and all around smart and nice guy.
Lots of math. Only take if you like math or have to take it.

Not a very good course if you want to 
"try something new".
Only take if you're ELE
Only take it if it is a requirement. More technical than anyone outside of EE would like.
Only take it if you have to or if you want to break the curve as a math major
Probably only take it if you need to for a requirement. While you can learn quite a bit, expect to do a lot of self study.

Prof. Cuff is not the best lecturer, but the material is actually super cool if you are into those kinds of things. But Prof. Cuffs recorded versions of the class lectures are easier to follow since the math goes much faster in class. Take it if you want to understand systems, little bit of control and fourier series/ transforms.

Read the textbook along with going to lecture if having problems. Make sure to understand things as you move forward because the class builds. Do practice problems from the book. Do a lot of them. And don't just do them before the midterm, do them before each problem set. Find a problem that is similar and do if it you have trouble on the problem site. This is a hard class that you should only take if you have to, or unless you like/are really good at math.
Take this class, and go to lecture.
Take this only if you have to.

This course is really interesting and the material is widely applicable. However, it is hard. Professor Cuff is actually a really engaging and caring professor but unfortunately that doesn't come across as much when he is lecturing. However, I think he is continuously improving. Labs were really cool and not too difficult and you could go to the lab whenever you wanted. Problem sets took time and sometimes had a lot of computations and proofs. There are no practice exams! The midterm Exam really caught me off guard because it's all about seeing the tricks and not actually calculating the Fourier Series. However, once I  saw that I prepared for the final properly. I saw shortcuts in his lecture examples and studied the homework problems carefully. If you are engaged and diligent you can learn a lot but it is not easy and could be improved.
While the course itself is not bad, I couldn't imagine someone taking it that was not required to take it.
Work in groups on assignments and compile your own practice problems for exam preparation.
prereqs: The prerequisite for this course is knowledge of elementary calculus..
descrip: Signals that carry information play a central role in technology and engineering---ranging from sound and images to MRI, communication, radar, and robotic control. This course teaches mathematical tools to analyze, manipulate, dissect, and preserve information signals. For example, many continuous signals can be perfectly represented through sampling (Nyquist theorem), which leads to digital signals. A major focus of the course is the Fourier transform. We also study linear time-invariant systems, modulation, quantization, and stability (Laplace transform and z-transform). Lab design projects in Matlab include a "Shazam" music ID system.

title: Intermediate Korean II
reviews: Definitely recommend if you're looking for a language course! Contrary to other language course where textbooks are poorly written or teachers are not engaged, Korean is easy to learn and teachers and classmates are extremely kind that this may be the only class you won't skip!
Definitely take the course if you're interested in Korean! Not a huge time commitment and the professor is wonderful. A great 5th course!
Fun and easy class!
Korean may be a difficult language to learn, but taking it is definitely worth it!
Take it!
Take the course! The professor is awesome and makes learning the language super fun!
Take this course and don't skip class.
prereqs: KOR 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 105. Continued development of four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) in Korean. Complex grammatical structures and irregularities will be taught while the basics are reviewed. Idiomatic expressions will be introduced; journals will be kept for writing practice.

title: Extramural Research Project
descrip: Research project designed in conjunction with the student's advisor and an industrial, NGO, or government sponsor that will provide practical experience relevant to the student's research area. A final paper is required.

title: Intermediate Syriac
descrip: Study of selected passages from various genres of Syriac literature. Knowledge of Syriac is required.

title: Topics in Science, Technology and Environmental Policy - Global Environmental Governance
descrip: Examines intl law & governance in the context of environmental problems. Considers the need for regulation under conditions of scientific uncertainty in issues such as climate change, fisheries management, whaling management, biodiversity conservation, and ozone depletion. Explores the efficacy of diverse regulatory approaches, mechanisms for scientific advice to policymakers & participation by business firms and NGOs. Considers intersections between environmental regulation (both domestic and international) with trade, investment, & multilateral development and aid programs.

title: Ancient Greek: An Intensive Introduction
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to Ancient Greek. It covers in one semester material usually done in the two-semester introductory sequence (CLG 101/102). Students who complete this course can take CLG105 in the Fall and CLG108 in the Spring. This course aims at providing a reading knowledge of Classical Greek, quickly. Students are expected to be motivated and will have to set aside sufficient time for daily assignments.

title: Seminar in Observational Astrophysics - Seminar in Observational Astrophysics
reviews: Definitely start early on your presentations and meet with the course coordinator(s) to get feedback after your talk.
Don't wait too long to start working on your talk, and know the material well enough to ask pertinent questions.
Good course to practice giving talks!
Good way to improve your academic talk skills.
Have fun and be curious.
I would strongly recommend this course for astro majors.
Plan ahead and practice.
The seminar this term is quite useful, prepared us of knowledge regarding the future mission LSST. I also learned about background of multiple fields.
descrip: Students prepare and deliver presentations on selected topics in observational astronomy, and discuss each other's work.

title: Lighting Design
reviews: If you are even remotely in theater (acting, directing, design), you MUST take this course. Jane Cox is an incredibly brilliant designer, and you will learn a ton about making theater from every perspective. Jane is one of the kindest and most supportive people I know, and she is very invested in helping her students succeed. Highly HIGHLY recommended!
If you have an interest in lighting design, definitely take this class. Professor Cox is incredibly talented and is also very personable. I would highly recommend taking it!
It's a long 4 hour seminar but you'll get to pick up practical skills; not only of lighting but of theater, an eye for design, and working with classmates! A  Class :)

Jane Cox is AMAZING. You will learn so much about theater and how to think and talk about it and how to collaborate with others in addition to how to turn on the lights. A perfect combination of technical and theoretical! One of the BEST classes I have taken at Princeton.
Take this class if you like doing theater!
Take this class! Jane is truly phenomenal. She is an incredibly wonderful professor and mentor. You will learn so much about theater with her!!
descrip: An introduction to the art and craft of lighting design for the stage and an exploration of light as a medium for expression. Students will develop an ability to observe lighting in the world and on the stage; to learn to make lighting choices based on text, space, research, and their own responses; to practice being creative, responsive and communicative under pressure and in company; to prepare well to create under pressure using the designer's visual toolbox; and to play well with others-working creatively and communicating with directors, writers, performers, fellow designers, the crew and others.

title: Human Evolution
reviews: Attend lecture!

Definitely always go to class and make the best effort that you can to be attentive (it's hard because he closes all of the window shades).  There's not a huge push/necessity to do the readings, but skim over them to see which ones interest you and read those so that you can comment on them in exams.

Go to lecture and you'll have an enjoyable and manageable semester.  Things could totally change with a new professor, however.
Also, great way to get an EC and super easy PDF.
Go to lecture. Don't worry about the readings.
Go to office hours. Alan is very good at helping you formulate ideas for essay topics.
Not a great course, but not terrible either. Not much work.
Pretty easy course. Not at all heavy on the workload (especially if you are not taking the EEB lab component).
TAKE IT! It's not extremely had but it is SUPER engaging and will make you wonder about the material instead of just scrambling to learn it.
TAKE THIS CLASS. One of hte most enjoyable lectures I have ever had.
Take it! Professor Mann is one of the best professor's I've had here and do the fossil project at the end (just a short paper due on Dean's Date). It was probably my favorite part of the course.
Take this course, it's wonderful.  It's a good in-between the sciences and the humanities and is a great introduction to some of the thinking that takes place in anthropology.
You are signing up for a 200 level anthro course and not a 300 level EEB course. If you've taken EEB 309 (evolution) already, you'll find a lot of this information to be redundant.
prereqs: Students who wish to receive EEB credit for the course Human Evolution should enroll in this course, ANT 206B/ EEB 306. All other students should enroll in ANT 206A, including EEB (or MOL) majors who do NOT need to receive EEB credit for taking this course (and would not complete the fossil lab project). Please consult your adviser in EEB (or MOL) if you are unsure whether you need EEB credit..
descrip: An investigation of the evidence and background of human evolution. Emphasis will be placed on the examination of the fossil and other evidence for human evolution and its functional and behavioral implications. (See below to determine whether this course or ANT 206A is more appropriate for your interests and needs.)

title: Black & White Photography
reviews: Glad I took black and white over digital. Entirely changed the way I look at photography. If you really want to improve your photography skills, even as a digital photography, black and white analog is an important step.
Great introduction to black and white photography.
Take it! Kathryn is an amazing professor. You learn so much and can see your improvement.
Take it! Photography is rad, and so is Katherine.
Take it! The photo skills learned in this class will last for life.
Take this course if you have the time, it will take up a lot of your time, but it is worth it.
descrip: An Introduction to the processes of analog photography through a series of problems directed toward the handling of film-based cameras, light-sensitive paper, darkroom chemistry, and printing. Weekly laboratory sessions will explore the critical issues of working with black and white imagery today, supported by slide lectures, readings, and discussions of photography as a documentary tool, a political device, an art form. Class critiques of student work are augmented by feedback from guest photographers.

title: Water Quality Modeling and Analysis
reviews: It is very useful for those who want to get some basic knowledge in the field of water quality and modeling.
Take it! Great course on water quality modeling.
The biggest part of the workload for this course is the class project.
descrip: The course explores construction and solution of water-quality models for transport and transformation of pollutants in surface runoff, streams, lakes, estuaries, and groundwaters; and the basic principles of water quality modeling. It reviews existing models and the utility and appropriateness of various modeling techniques for analysis and prediction.

title: Fakes, Frauds, and Charlatans
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Construction and Interpretation
reviews: Depends on your interests
I found the course and instructor to be both interesting and engaging. I would very much encourage enrollment in this seminar.
I think my favorite parts of the course were when Guy walked us through actual construction or building documents - was really great to see how he read them.
It's great!
Speak up!

This is a great option for a building tech class. The class format is a laid-back student-led discussion. You will learn a lot about a handful of structurally interesting buildings from the 20th century.
descrip: This seminar will examine the relation of construction, structure and building services to the production of meaning through a series of case studies of buildings and bridges and as well as general surveys of the work of specific engineers and architects.

title: Rocket and Air-Breathing Propulsion Technology
reviews: Chose rockets instead of engines because I heard problem sets and exams are super easy despite the huge tons of materials to memorize. I spent literally only 1-2 hours on problem set each week. But if you're really passionate about propulsion, go for engines instead because the professor is much more engaging and interesting!
Great course. Sometimes Professor Ju can be a little hard to understand, but it's more than worth it for the subject material and his enthusiasm for the course.

If you are interested in learning about the material, then it is absolutely interesting and worth taking. If you have no definite interest in the subject, then it's probably worth taking a different class for the requirement.
Not a difficult course and covers some very interesting material. It's not an exciting course but a good choice if you're interested in propulsion.
Take it if you're interested in the details of how rockets work or if you're looking for an MAE elective with, finally, a reasonable workload.
Take it!
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222.
descrip: The study of principles, flight envelopes, and engine designs of rocket and ram/scramjet propulsion systems. Topics include jet propulsion theory, space mission maneuver, combustion control, and system components of chemical and non-chemical rockets (nuclear and electrical propulsion), gas turbine, ramjet, and scramjet engines. Characteristics, optimal flight envelopes, and technical challenges of combined propulsion systems will be analyzed.

title: Topics in Critical Theory - Comparative Literature Writing and Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: The Writing and Dissertation Colloquium is a biweekly forum for graduate students in Comparative Literature to share works in progress with other graduate students. The seminar welcomes drafts of your prospectus, article, dissertation chapter, conference paper, exam statement and grant or fellowship proposal. Work is pre-circulated. The 90 minute sessions, done in conjunction with a rotating COM faculty member, are designed to offer written and oral feedback.

title: East Central Europe in the 20th Century: History, Politics and Culture
descrip: In this course we will examine history, politics, and culture of East Central Europe after World War I. We will study a variety of institutions and cultural trends using narrative history, as well as literary essays and political manifestos.

title: Sex on the Brain
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Race, Drugs, and Drug Policy in America
reviews: A good amount of work, so make sure you are willing to put the time in.
A lot of work for this course

A lottttt of readings, but the lectures were really interesting. Don't have to do all the readings, but go to lecture. Professor Wailoo is really enthusiastic about the subject and makes for worthwhile lectures if you care about any part of race, drugs, or drug policy.
Be prepared for the amount of reading.

Beware that lectures nearly always run over, and that you are expected to submit a written response after each lecture.  Start writing before the lecture ends so that you can get out on time.  You should also quickly look over (at least) the readings for each week.  Not only will you be a better contributor in precept, but you will also have a much easier time figuring out your topics and accompanying sources for your papers because you will have a richer understanding of the history of race, drugs, and drug policy.
Definitely take it.  It's really interesting, and Prof. Wailoo is a great lecturer
Do as much of the readings as you can and make sure you go two times a week to see one of the better lecturers on campus.
Do the readings. Attend lectures. This is also a great course for pre-meds interested in learning about the history of iatrogenic drug abuse.
Don't take if you're a history major, a seminar on this would be much better.
Final was a bit tough for me (I dont write quickly), but interesting material. I would say take it, especially if you're just trying to PDF
Great course, make sure to keep up with readings and talk to teachers about any questions.

I would recommend they take it, but warn them about the problems I had with the quantity of reading and advise them to plan to concentrate their attention on the assigned primary sources. Recommend, leaning strongly.
It's a great class.  But make sure you give yourself enough time to write the second paper - it sneaks up on you.
Keep up with the readings.
Only take this if you're prepared to stay engaged and work hard

Pay attention in lecture.organize the course early so you can follow the logic of the course Well. Do the readings and try your best to contribute well to precept. don't be afraid just ask a question. Just make sure you have learned something when you come out of precept
Professor Wailoo is a great lecturer, and the material is really interesting, but be prepared for massive amounts of reading.
Read all of the readings and let yourself enjoy learning the material.
Superb lectures - definitely take if WWS or HIS or just generally interested in the history of medicine and drug policy
Take it

Take it! And get Dov as a preceptor if you can.  He's awesome. Professor Wailoo's an engaging lecturer and this course is meticulously organized and designed. The subject matter is very interesting and varied, and Professor Wailoo actually spends a lot of time talking about the late 19th and early 20th century- it's definitely not just a late 20th century class. Lots of reading, all of it interesting.
Take it, but find a reading group and don't try to take notes by hand. Also don't schedule a class for right afterward that you can't show up a few minutes late for

Take this course no matter what you have decided to concentrate in. Understanding the complexities of public policy and coming to the conclusion that the status quo is not without causation is an important part of historical analysis.
Take this course with Dov as your preceptor!
Take this course with Dov, be prepared to write two long papers.

Take this course. It's a good one to PDF if you're generally interested in the topic but don't have the time to put in extra effort. The final exam is primarily based on the lectures rather than the readings, so you can get by without doing the majority of them.
The class is not easy, but very interesting and rewarding
The course is really interesting if you are invested and do the readings/go to lectures.

The worst lecture slides of all time, no organization, painful to review. The order of information was very unclear, not chronological, not by drug, by what?? some complex logic left unexplained..? Went over class time every single time, so annoying and kind of unimaginable that he couldn't figure that out?
There is a lot of reading, but the class is interesting in manageable, so I recommend it.
This class has a lot of reading and a lot of information.

This class was awful which was surprising because I took it for the rave reviews other students had given it.  The lectures were way too broad and unfocused, you could literally make a course out of just one lecture.  It is way too survey and tackles way too many drugs through way too many time periods through the perspective of way too many disciplines to really teach you anything substantive.  I would tell other students not to take this class, especially not for a grade.  PDF maybe, but there is so much reading that its not even enjoyable.  My precept was also 90% PDFing seniors so every class was pretty much one long awkward silence.  Definitely not a class you should take for fun or for a grade.  SKIP!

This course is definitely some work. 2 papers, including a 12-17 page one, as well as a 3 hour final exam. There is A LOT of reading so definitely be aware of that. The lectures go extremely fast which can be quite stressful. However, you do learn a lot.
This is a course that requires a lot of work but is fascinating.
Took it as a pdf and loved it!!
Try to keep up in lecture
You will be expected to turn in a writing assignment at the end of every lecture, so make sure to factor that into your schedule.

a LOT of reading. only take it if you have a reading group. otherwise its a very interesting course! papers can be a bit challenging and final exam covers a lot of material but super engaging and relevant.
great course- one of the best i've taken at Princeton
descrip: From "Chinese opium" to Oxycontin, and from cocaine and "crack" to BiDil, drug controversies reflect enduring debates about the role of medicine, the law, the policing of ethnic identity, and racial difference. This course explores the history of controversial substances (prescription medicines, over-the-counter products, black market substances, psychoactive drugs), and how, from cigarettes to alcohol and opium, they become vehicles for heated debates over immigration, identity, cultural and biological difference, criminal character, the line between legality and illegality, and the boundaries of the normal and the pathological.

title: Genome Integrity and Human Disease
reviews: Take it!  Carefully chosen readings, fantastic subject matter, and engaging & enjoyable discussions.  Professor Zakian really cares about her students.

Take it! The small size of the class was great and Professor Zakian is just so intelligent and wonderful! However, I wouldn't recommend if you do not have a strong background in molecular biology. You might have extreme difficulty understanding the readings.
Take it--it's one of my favorite courses at Princeton!  Definitely challenging and be ready to put in the work, but you'll become a better scientist and thinker with a new appreciation for the field.
Take your time reading the papers, especially if it is your first experience with primary literature.
The class is very time consuming but otherwise absolutely outstanding. Do not be afraid of the work, you get used to it and it is so worth it.

This is my favorite MOL course so far. The small size gives you all the best things about seminar classes without the inevitable slog in the last hour of the 3-hour format. Also, Prof. Zakian is both incredibly knowledgeable and a great people-person.
You'll do well as long as you read the papers for each class and come prepared to have a discussion about them.
descrip: This is a seminar style course dealing with the basic science that led to the molecular understanding of human diseases associated with defects in genome maintenance, such as aging and cancer. Each class focuses on a single paper from the primary literature. Class participation and short weekly papers are key aspects of the course. The first two-thirds of each class is a group discussion of the assigned paper. The last third is a lecture-type introduction to the material for the next class. Topics include telomeres, trinucleotide repeats, fragile sites, transcriptional sources of genome instability, and massive genome rearrangements.

title: Seminar in American Art - Terrains of Knowledge
descrip: The history of landscape is a history of space as well as a history of translation of space into image, entity, or idea. "Terrains of Knowledge" examines this history in terms of the concept of "terrain," both as a physical place or space and as a domain of knowledge. Making an image of the land--be it a map, scientific illustration, painting, or earthwork--has always been a matter of communicating and producing knowledge. This seminar will consider a range of visualized terrains in the American context in terms of the terrains of knowing reflected, fostered, or dismantled in the act of picturing.

title: The Body in Space: Art, Architecture, and Performance
reviews: Do the reading, talk more in class.
Do your readings, you will get much more out of it.
Have an interest in the arts and space.
Keep note of the images as they are not posted to the internet after lecture.
Precepts aren't lectures?participate..
Recommend.
This is a great class. Especially if you want to learn how to construct an argument from close readings of texts and images, Spyros's lectures provide a good model.
i highly recommend taking the class and try to be involved with the class as much as possible.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites but classes in the 200 or 300 level in either architectural theory or art history would be useful..
descrip: An interdisciplinary investigation of the status of the human body in the modern reinvention of space within the overlapping frames of art, architecture, and the performing arts, from the fin-de-siecle to the present. Works by artists, architects, theater designers, and film makers who address the human figure in space will be supplemented by readings on architectural theory, intellectual and cultural history, psychoanalysis, anthropology, and aesthetics. Course will address issues of bodily empathy, the relation between bodily perception and space, as well as the animation and mechanization of bodies and things inside modern enclosures.

title: Ethics and Public Health
reviews: I'm not sure if how this course will run with another instructor, but the material is very interesting and thought-provoking. Make sure to participate even if you are not fully comfortable with the ideas expressed in the readings.
If you're interested in the subject, take it.

Prof. Schwartz is leaving Princeton, so the class might be very different in the future. Overall, this was a good, interesting, and easy course. The workload was light, and you could definitely do well with skimming the readings. Assignments were short and open-ended, and classes were usually pretty good but sometimes dry. Take it if you're interested!
Professor Schwartz is so excited and very passionate about the subject and it helps to keep the class moving. Too bad you all won't be able to take it with him, but would totally recommend it.

This class is great. Very manageable reading and work load. The material is very interesting and relevant and Professor Schwartz is amazing. This course was structured very well and was very approachable for someone with no ethics background. Strongly recommend.

This is a great class that opens up your eyes to new topics and issues in the world of public health. Not challenging at all and not necessary to do all the readings. Seminars can be long and boring/dry at times. This class will really force you to think about your opinion in terms of how involved the government should be in people's personal lives. Take if interested in the intersection of government and health.

This was one of the best courses I've taken here. I'd recommend to anyone in the GHP program, anyone interested in domestic health issues, and anyone who wants to take an EM that is directly applied to topics everyone will face at some point.
Would highly recommend! One of my favorite classes at Princeton, and great even for students (like myself prior to taking this class) who know very little about public health.
you can read one reading from every "section"
descrip: This course will examine issues at the intersection of ethics, policy, and public health, paying particular attention to the centuries-long tension between individual rights and the common good. Ethical arguments are increasingly visible in public health activities in the United States and worldwide, demonstrating the continued relevance of long-standing debates over the proper role of government in promoting the health of individuals and communities. The course will explore ethical, historical, and policy aspects of public health activities, and it will consider the relationship between public health ethics and bioethics.

title: Contemporary Theories of Gender and Sexuality
reviews: If you are interested in feminism, I would definitely give this a try. The Second Sex is so important and it is so satisfying to dive through it cover to cover. And don't be intimidated--Gayle is a great, friendly, incisive guide to the material.
Take if you have had a little exposure to theory / philosophy.
Take this course. You will be moved both by Beauvoir and by Gayle's passion for teaching her.

The Second Sex is an amazing read and even after studying it over the course of a semester, I still feel as if there is so much more to gain from a second, third, or fourth read. Would so recommend this class!
very engaging course
prereqs: GSS 201 or equivalent..
descrip: We will take as our primary text the new translation of Simone deBeauvoir's landmark volume The Second Sex, one of the most significant origin points of current understandings of gender. In our sustained consideration of The Second Sex, we will explore Beauvoir's ideas about the influence of sex and gender on childhood, the family, sexuality, relationships, aging, work, the social order, and the philosophical imaginary. We will also consider contemporary fiction and film alongside that text, taking Beauvoir as our tour guide as we encounter and interpret contemporary representations of gender.

title: Job, Suffering and Modernity
descrip: See website

title: Photo, Urbanism and Civic Change between 1960-1980
reviews: Don't take this class - it doesn't give you a good window into urban studies and the final project is a headache.
I don't think it's possible for this course to be taught again because of it's unique format. So you missed out!
I would not recommend taking this class. Although the subject matter is interesting, the layout of the class and the assignments were not ideal.
I would probably not recommend this class to anyone in the future because although the instructors had a good idea, it was not executed well.
Interesting readings and materials, but could use better class structure and more teaching during classes.
No, unless it is heavily improved.
Take part in discussion and it will go well.
The course material is so interesting, but the class discussion leader format just did not work out.
The topics can be a little bit scattered and communication with the professors is difficult, but the material is really interesting.
Very discussion based, not a lot of variety.
Wouldn't recommend taking a course with Aaron, but Kate was pretty good. Just make sure you write exactly what they want because if they disagree with you, you'll get a bad grade.
descrip: In conjunction with the concurrent exhibition The City Lost and Found, this course focuses on an extraordinary period of visual responses to the changing fabric of America's three largest cities: New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles. We explore their seismic transformations, from political protests to urban renewal projects. Students assess original artworks, films, texts, photographs, and a variety of print media (all on view in the Princeton University Art Museum) and analyze readings from disciplines as diverse as cultural geography, urban planning, urban theory, and art history.

title: Economics of Health and Health Care
reviews: A very interesting application of economics to a specific field.
Consider taking it with Professor Rees. You'll learn alot but not alot of work.

I chose to take this class because I thought it was going to be the one Reinhardt teaches. Reinhardt opted not to teach this semester, so a visiting professor named Daniel Rees taught instead. Professor Rees was one of the best lecturers I've had at Princeton. He was funny, engaging, and made you want to learn. I learned a whole lot about analyzing data and running regressions. Much of what we learned is very applicable to real life, and the math behind it was broken down very well by David Zhang and Professor Rees. Take this course, spend about a week on the research paper, and study regressions in depth for the midterm and final.

I would expect that another student taking this course would have a very different experience than the one I had, as Professor Rees is visiting this semester and is not the usual instructor for the course.
Interesting and easy class

TAKE THIS COURSE if offered again with Prof. Rees. Extremely informative. Not too much work per week. Very interesting material, and helped me understand how economic papers are conducted and interpreted by the field.

This is not a course about health care! It is a very interesting class of the econometrics of risky behavior, but do not take this course if you think it will teach you about health care. It is a great class however!
great course
you'll love it, no matter your experience with econ, healthcare, statistical analysis. you'll learn a lot no matter what, too
prereqs: ECO 202 or equivalent..
descrip: Smoking, binge drinking, unprotected sex, substance use, poor dietary habits and physical inactivity are responsible for hundreds of thousands of preventable deaths and impose billions of dollars in medical care costs each year in the United States. This course teaches an economic approach to analyzing the various polices that affect these risky health behaviors. The extensive economic literature on the causes and consequences of risky health behaviors will be studied. Students will use the statistical software package STATA and individual-level data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) to conduct original research.

title: Sisters' Voices: African Women Writers
reviews: I would advise students to take this course but they have to be willing to do a good amount of reading.
It's a great course to get a knowledge of African literature. The workload isn't bad and you can choose when you want to do the essays. I'd say take it
Read the books, participate in class, use her office hours.
Take it!
Take the course. It is fun.

This is a great course if you need an LA. Workload is manageable, and you can schedule papers for when you have a quieter week in the semester. The level of thought, while somewhat disappointing, is not terribly challenging.
great reading
descrip: In this class, we study the richness and diversity of poetry, novels, and memoirs written by African women. The course expands students' understanding of the long history of women's writing across Africa and a range of languages. It focuses on their achievements while foregrounding questions of aesthetics and style. As an antidote to misconceptions of African women as silent, students analyze African women's self-representations and how they theorize social relations within and across ethnic groups, generations, classes, and genders. The course increase students' ability to think, speak, and write critically about gender.

title: Advanced Political Institutions
descrip: Designed to expose students to substantive and methodological controversies that are currently engaging scholars of political institutions. Integrates theoretical and quantitative skills by focusing on the processes of extracting hypotheses from formal models, stating hypotheses in a manner conducive to tests, collecting data, conducting tests, and making inferences. Assumes prior completion of POL 542.

title: Contemporary Technique and Choreography
reviews: Dance classes are always great. Super chill.

Give your all in studio and do not fall behind in your work for choreography. Make it a point to find your classmates outside of class if need be. Be as well prepared as possible for all showings, especially the final one.
Schedule for Friday mornings was a little difficult, but otherwise it's such a rewarding, fun, and fulfilling class!

This class is great if you want a good dance course. I was worried about being under-qualified for the course but the instructors Nicole and Rebecca do a very good job of catering to all levels of dance ability while they teach.
be prepared to work on pieces a lot outside of class.
prereqs: DAN 219, equivalent previous training, or instructor's permission. Interview information: there is no application for this course. In order to assure correct placement, interested students should contact Professor Tina Fehlandt (Fehlandt@) by email to schedule an interview during the time period of November 10th through 21st, 2014..
descrip: Incorporating aspects of jazz, modern and ballet, this contemporary dance class focuses on strengthening fundamental alignment and coordination. Technique class will start with exercises designed to organize the body and prepare for more technical movement. Class will build in physical intensity culminating in phrase work that is vigorous and challenging. In choreography, students will develop their understanding of the ways in which structural elements and movement vocabularies contribute to a dance's impact and content.

title: Great Moments in Computing
reviews: A great survey of computing history from a very technological perspective. Some of the papers are really tough to read, but classes really help at understanding them and are super interesting
Awesome course, gives you a great knowledge of the full spectrum of CS fields.

Don't be discouraged from talking if you're an undergrad, even though you're sitting at a table with grad students who are literally writing their dissertations on these topics. Just ask a question, point something out, engage.
I would suggest taking the class without any reservations.
I wouldn't take this course again if the class size remains 20-30 people large. It's too big to have good discussions.

If you are interested in reading landmark papers in COS, you should take this course. Even if you have no future academic plans, I would still recommend the course, because you learn various things a long the road.
It's a course on the coolest things to happen in CS. If you love CS, you'll enjoy the class. Martonosi does a great job with keeping discussions engaging and interesting.

Quite a bit of content, but you only go as deep as you want to -- you can spend a lot of time and energy on each paper, or you can pick and choose which ones you want to really get a deep understanding of.
