But that's really what a course like this should be about, and you really ought to be self-motivated enough to do the readings deeply.
Start the final project early.
Take it. It's a consistent and fair amount of work, and the papers are generally interesting, or at least very worth reading.
Take this if you want a review of how computer science has evolved from the great papers of the last century. In other words, take this class.
This course gets an A .  I had to specially apply to the register to give it that grade, but it was worth it.
prereqs: COS 217 and 226 or equivalent. Undergrads: Juniors and seniors only.
descrip: Course covers pivotal developments in computing, including hardware, software, and theory. Material will be covered by reading seminal papers, patents, and descriptions of highly-influential architectures. Course emphasizes a deep understanding of the discoveries and inventions that brought computer systems to where they are today, and class is discussion-oriented. Final project or paper required. Graduate students and advanced undergraduates from ELE, COS, and related fields welcome.

title: Quantitative Physiology
descrip: A treatment of the quantitative tools to understand the human body. Course reviews cell biology and anatomy, then examines cells, tissues, and organs using principles from engineering kinetics and transport processes. Topics include: cell physiology; organ system physiology (including the cardiovascular, renal, and respiratory systems); pathophysiology. Clinical treatments for human disease will also be analyzed.

title: Race, Labor, and the Long Civil Rights Movement
descrip: This course explores the relationships between race and labor in the long civil rights era. Its purpose is to examine the interplay of racial and class formation, and the intersections between antiracist and labor movements through an interdisciplinary framework. The assigned texts analyze how racial differences among workers have been both produced and contested. They introduce theories and methods to analyze civil rights struggles as labor struggles, emphasizing the role of culture in movements for racial and economic justice. Along with our key texts we will also screen films and listen to musical recordings and oral testimonies.

title: Understanding Tonality
reviews: It's a great class and I would advise technical music people to go out of their way to take it.  I would warn students without strong analysis backgrounds that it will be hard to keep up.
Take it if you know your stuff. This class is hard.
Take it if you like theory or are a serious composer.

This class is very difficult in terms of music theory, and you should be wary of taking it if you feel shaky about your theory skills. However, if you want to be challenged and are interested in analyzing music, there's no better class!
take matters into your own hands and grapple with the music to find deep and meaningful answers to theoretical questions
prereqs: Music 206 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: In this course we will try to understand the complex phenomenon of "tonality." We will theorize about harmony, voice leading, scales and study works by Schubert, Chopin, Wagner, Debussy, Ravel, Stravinsky, Reich and contemporary jazz.

title: Biotechnology
reviews: Definitely take this class! It is very rewarding intellectually!!
Great course for someone with a solid background in molecular and cell biology who wants to see how basic science is used to develop clinical treatments.
It's a great course and you will learn a lot about new biological methods.
Take it if you want. you aren't missing a ton :|
Take it! Very interesting.
There are readings for each class and participation is valued. Discussed topics are interesting most of the time, and the workload is pretty manageable (three assignments and one final paper).
This is less difficult than some MOL classes I've taken, but still be prepared with the readings and pay attention in lecture.
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345, or permission of the Instructor.
descrip: This course will consider the principles, development, outcomes and future directions of therapeutic applications of biotechnology, with particular emphasis on the interplay between basic research and clinical experience. Topics to be discussed include production of hormones and other therapeutic proteins, gene therapy, oncolytic viruses, and stem cells. Reading will be from the primary literature.

title: Introduction to Media Theory
reviews: AMAZING. LIFECHANGING

Absolutely take this course if you have ever considered it. You will learn SO much about writing and reading and media studies, and your mind will be regularly blown in class by all the fascinating lectures.
Be willing to do independent work. He will not hold your hand.

Take it!  Levin is one of the best professors at Princeton.  This course will make you question everything, from language, to writing, to the way we perceive the world.  Understanding, or at least trying to understand to ways in which the technologies we invent shape us in new ways is essential to living in a technological world, and getting to learn from a professor as good as Levin makes this daunting process considerably more enjoyable than it would be otherwise.
The class is interesting and Prof. Levin is very engaging. Just be aware that there is a fair amount of quite theoretical reading.
Tom Levin is a one of a kind professor. Take advantage! This class will change how you think about the world

You definitely should take this class, especially if you're thinking about media, art, technology, etc. Take it! Talk to Professor Levin, he's so knowledgeable in so many areas it's crazy how he fits it all in his head
descrip: Through careful readings of a wide range of media theoretical texts from the late 19th to early 21st century, this seminar will trace the development of critical reflection on technologies and media ranging from the printing press to photography, from gramophones to radio technologies, from pre-cinematic optical devices to film and television, and from telephony and typewriters to cyberspace. Topics include the relationship between representation and technology, the historicity of perception, the interplay of aesthetics, technology and politics, and the transformation of notions of imagination, literacy, communication, reality and truth.

title: Mind Games
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Painting
reviews: Go in with an open mind ready to be free in your painting! She really welcomes a range of styles, but will want you to be loosened up and enjoying what you are doing.

Go in with an open mind!
Don't be afraid to try both oil and acrylic paint!
Be experimental! Don't paint on a canvas!
If you're looking to work on your painting, this is the class to take.
Love Pam!! This class is very heavy on independent work- you won't be hand held, but in the best way
Take it!
This class helped me develop a style, and every moment was challenging and enjoyable
Wonderful class; Pam can't be beat. Keep an open mind, Pam will help you get there
prereqs: VIS 203/204 or VIS 309.
descrip: Painting has always entailed artists establishing a particular link between thinking, seeing and making. This course explores a variety of possible "equations" by which a painting gets made. Students will experiment with different media and approaches: direct observation, ways to use photography, digital images and post-digital imagery. Translation and transformation will be emphasized. Experimentation will provoke students to work in new and unpredictable ways, as well as enable them to discover and develop their own artistic preoccupations. Slide lectures, critiques, and weekly assignments with readings are integrated into studio practice.

title: Themes in Islamic Law and Jurisprudence
descrip: Selected topics in Islamic law and jurisprudence. The topics vary from year to year, but the course normally includes reading of fatwas and selected Islamic legal texts in Arabic.

title: Readings in Modern Japanese II
descrip: One or two short novels will be used to read for critical thinking. Reading is under focus but speaking, listening and writing (including translation) are intensively practiced. This course is designed to help students develop critical thinking through reading and discussing Japanese novels.

title: Seminar on Student Learning and Methods for Teaching
reviews: I recommend this course if you are seriously considering becoming a teacher.
If you wanna teach, take it! If not, it's a lot of out-of-class observation for a "just because" class.
While most of the students in this class are going into teaching, I highly recommend it for anyone interested in working in or around education issues!
Yes --- if you have any interest in teaching please consider! Even if you are not doing Teacher Prep.
only if you're in TPP.
prereqs: The course is required for students in the Program in Teacher Preparation and is open to non-program students provided space is available. Interested non-program students should contact the Teacher Preparation Office for permission to take the course..
descrip: A study of essential methods of learning and teaching, including learner characteristics and needs, organization and structure of educational institutions, development of curriculum and instructional goals, preparation of evaluation and assessment, and design of subject/level specific methodologies and classroom management techniques. Required course work includes 18 hours of site-based field experience and evening laboratory sessions.

title: Multivariable Calculus
reviews: A lot of material, fast-paced, made for engineers.
Come to every class, do every problem set, and do a little bit of math everyday - either studying or working practice problems - instead of cramming before the 2 quizzes and 2 exams.
Do ALL the practice quizzes and tests. You'll need it.

Do not take this class unless you have to or unless you care about math and have a lot of time to dedicate to doing tons of practice exams before tests.  In my opinion this class was not worth the mental strain.  I took MAT 201 as a premed when I could've taken 175 and regretted it - if you're taking this class to "challenge yourself," don't do it... It's hard but in my opinion not terribly rewarding.
Don't focus too much on the theory, which will make sense in the context of practice problems (in my experience).
Don't take it unless it's a distributional requirement.
Don't take the class unless you have to.
Don't take this course unless you have to. If you do, shop around and make sure you get a good instructor!
Don't worry about your grade, it probably won't be what you want. Instead focus on how cool the math is!!

Even if you aren't an engineer or STEM student, this is a class worth taking if you want a little more math knowledge. It doesn't demand a ton of your time. If you just work through a couple old quizzes, midterms, and finals before each one you'll do fine.

Find a textbook that you can read and understand. Go to office hours as often as possible if you have questions and review the material you have learned over the week as you do problem sets. The class can teach you a lot, but as it is taught now that will mean you have a lot of work to do on your part.
For a required course this was much better than expected. Make sure you get a good preceptor as the textbook is not very good.
Get help if you need it.
Go to class and stay engaged!
Go to class! If you're into math, this is a really interesting course.
Go to lecture and do problems sets and you will be fine.
Great if you like math and are good at it. Otherwise, too complicated to keep up.
Hard class, study for the final.
I don't know. Learn to work freaking hard.
I like the overall concepts of the course but make sure you have a good prof!
I suppose that the quality of the course will depend on the professor, but multivariable calculus is useful and interesting. Take it!
I would recommend to other students that they stay on top of all of the topics and don't let anything slide by just because you don't think its worth it to fully understand it.

If you don't need to take this class, I wouldn't necessarily recommend it (I took it as a prerequisite for Econ departmentals). The exams are really difficult, and the material was tough for me to understand fully. It was definitely a lot of negative reinforcement for me in the beginning, but if you can put in the time it's worth it!
If you're into engineering or the sciences, this is a must-have math toolbox.

If you're taking this course, it's probably because you have to. If you want to learn multi for your own sake you should probably take 203. I wish 203 had been offered during the spring semester. You don't really need to go to class if you understand the material sufficiently from the textbook. Just don't be that asshole who hands in the homework on Monday and immediately leaves.
If, like me, you had very little math background going into the course I encourage you to find an instructor you understand well.
Interesting material and not as bad as everyone says, but it's still math at Princeton.
It's a good into to multivariable calc! Make sure to study hard, though.
It's a necessary course.

It's a standard Princeton math class. Which means fast pace, and hard exams. To do well, you should first make sure you know how to use the basic concepts and types of problems, using the textbook or something to help. The exams inevitably involve a lot of improvising anyway, so doing practice exams might give you a foothold.
It's better not to go to lecture and actually read the textbook instead (unless they change it where they make attendance mandatory).  Whatever is in the classes is also in the textbook.

It's definitely a challenging course. Study early and often and do not fall behind the course. Also try and stay awake in class, but if you realize that you will be falling asleep everyday in class, you are better off not going and using that time to self study.
Just attend precept and do the homework and you'll pass.
Just be aware that the homework problems are way easier than exam problems.
Just do enough practice exams/quizzes and you will do well. Don't try to only memorize a couple of equations.
Keep up with concepts throughout the semester. GO TO CLASS.
Make sure to supplement class lectures to outside sources, such as youtube. It can be very helpful to see concepts from a different angle, and can especially good on the confusing sections.
Multivariable Calculus is very interesting and you should try it.

Only take it if you have to. It's not all that hard, but I don't really feel like I learned much of anything. You also have to teach yourself most of it, and the exams are way harder than the problem sets. Do lots of practice exams.
Only take it if you need to satisfy a departmental
Only take this if you have to.

Please keep up. On a weekly basis, be sure that you know how you are faring. I didn't take enough advantage of office hours and I would recommend that you do.

For midterms and exams, do as many of the old versions that you can. Beyond grasping the concepts which are not too difficult, your performance on exams depends heavily on your degree of practice.
Read the book and go to McGraw study halls for homework help.  Office hours are inefficient because you have to listen to other people's questions.
Read the book, do the assignments
Read the text at some point, it really helps. Also do most of the hw if you can
Read the textbook!
Read the textbook.
Shop around for a solid professor. Life will be easier if you actually learn things in lecture.
Sit in on a few different classes and go to a class where the teacher teaches clearly.
Start doing practice problems (from Blackboard) as early as possible, in addition to past quizzes and tests. Go to office hours.
Start psets early so you can go to office hours.
Stay on top of all the material and take advantage of the available practice exams
Stay on top of p-sets and GO TO OFFICE HOURS!
Stay on top of the material.
Stay on top of the problem sets.
Study until it hurts for the quizzes and exams.

Supplement lectures with Adrian Banner's videos on YouTube, I found they really helped structure the course and understand/connect the concepts. Don't let yourself get bogged down in the theory--it's very complicated, but if you aim to understand the intuition and the big concepts and relationships, it becomes marginally less hard.
Take it if you have to for B.S.E., econ, etc. There's not much of a need to otherwise.
Take it if you have to for your major etc
Take it if you need multivariable.
Take it is you are really interested in calc or you have to
Take it only if you have to.
Take it slow, but make sure to know the concepts. Don't rush too much otherwise you'll get lost trying to remember everything learned from the past.
Take it!
Take it, but have thick skin since the test averages are low.
Take it.
Take it. It's not as bad as everyone says.  Just make sure you do your p-sets with effort.
Take it...only if you have to.
Take only if you have to. Other than that, you should probably find another course.
The exams are much harder than the psets. Make sure you understand the concepts deeply and can do computation like its second  nature.

The material in the course is interesting, however the concepts were not, at least in my opinion, explained very well in class. The assignments tested knowledge of equations and formulas rather than the concepts, which is not good, since the exams are very concept heavy. But, if you go to office hours and ask questions, you should be fine.

This challenging course will teach you very much. You will not only learn multivariate calculus, but also how to apply the material in ways you didn't know you could, to new and very interesting problems. If you give it your best, you will come out having a learned a lot!
Try not to just study the day before exams and quizzes.
Try to enroll in Dan's precept, and if you can't then consider showing up to it anyway (like many did)
Try to get Dan as your teacher he is extremely helpful and clearly explains all the concepts.
Use supplementary resources and go to office hours.
Watch Adrian Banner videos on YouTube, he explains things really well
okay but I suggest doing 203 if you took multi before in high school and want to do something more challenging. however, this course should be appropriate if you haven't took multi before.
study hard, its a hard class
prereqs: MAT 104 or equivalent..
descrip: Vectors in the plane and in space, vector functions and motion, surfaces, coordinate systems, functions of two or three variables and their derivatives, maxima and minima and applications, double and triple integrals, vector fields and Stokes's theorem.

title: Provincializing European History in Spanish America (16th century)
prereqs: Advanced knowledge (written, read, and spoken) of Spanish is required..
descrip: How did 16th century history, a provincial set of knowledge elaborated in Medieval Europe and Northern Italy, became a discipline able to interpret Indian pasts and societies once applied and adapted to the New World? This course explores the new forms of history writing which appeared in the New World during the 16th century. Special attention is given to Indian and Mestizo figures who conceived and wrote histories while creating the political and religious conditions for a new society (early colonial society). Both 16th century European historicism and native reactions to be analyzed and discussed. Course is taught in Spanish.

title: Sociological Studies of Inequality(Half -Term)
descrip: This segment of the JDP seminar covers theory and research on social stratification, the major subfield in sociology that focuses on inequality. Course begins by reviewing major theories, constructs, measures, and empirical work on inequality. Weeks two through six focus on institutions that are expected to produce (and reproduce) inequalities, including families, neighborhoods, schools, labor markets, and penal policy.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Psychology and Inequality
descrip: Two major areas of psychology contribute to the study of social policy and inequality.The first is social psychology, which focuses on inter-group relations, interpersonal perception, stereotyping, racism, aggression, justice and fairness. The second domain involves the fields of social-cognition, judgment and decision making, areas of research that study human information processing in a way that is not about individual differences, and often not social.

title: Advanced Social Statistics
descrip: Thorough examination of the linear regression model with a focus on both the theory underlying the model and the application of regression using contemporary software. Topics include 1) probability theory underlying statistical modeling and hypothesis testing in general, 2) assumptions underlying the linear model, 3) estimation of the model via least squares and maximum likelihood, 4) diagnosing violations of assumptions, assessing the consequences of violations, and remedying them, and 5) extending the model and estimation methods to other data settings.

title: Microeconomic Analysis of Government Activity
prereqs: Prerequisite: WWS 511c (OR an A-/A in WWS 511b)..
descrip: This course focuses on the role of the government in the economy and aims to provide an understanding of the reasons for government intervention in the economy, analyzing the benefits and costs of possible government policies, and the response of economic agents to the government's actions. The course covers education, labor, and tax policy, social insurance programs, public goods, environmental protection, and the interaction between different levels of government.

title: Why Global Warming is Controversial
descrip: See website

title: Interdisciplinary Research - Anthropology of Ethics
descrip: This seminar concerns the ethics of knowledge production. As a grounding, we scrutinize politically-charged ethics talk and practice in US anthropology. The potential of an anthropology of ethics (that is, of treating "ethics" as an ethnographic object) is developed through comparisons between ethics talk and practice in anthropology, sociology, psychology, and history, all of whose ethical controversies do boundary work (constitute disciplinary knowledges and communities as moral orders) and are implicated in extra-academic public discourses of various kinds. Participants are also welcome to develop that potential in other ways.

title: Personal Identity
reviews: Good upper level philosophy course. Glad I took it as a senior and not a freshman/sophomore
Only take if you are really interested in this sort of philosophy.  And if you are, then it will be really good.

PHI 311 is probably the best philosophy course offered at Princeton.  The material is quite complex - if you are looking for an easy EC, this is not for you - but very rewarding.  You will view your life differently having taken the course.

Solid course for PHI majors. Johnston can be pretty unclear in lectures, but will always clarify if asked. Readings aren't so necessary and essays just require summarizing material covered in lecture. Don't take as a first philosophy class

TAKE IT. The subject content is fascinating, and it exposes you to many interesting philosophical problems that have bearing on morality and how we live our lives. I would recommend the course to anyone, whether you are majoring in philosophy or just have a general interest in the subject matter.
Take it. Professor Johnston is a genius, and you will learn to think about deep, important questions in interesting, unexpected ways.
descrip: This course will focus on the conditions for personal identity over time, with implications for the beginning and end of life. We will investigate what it is rational to care about in caring about survival or continued existence, and whether our account of what it is rational to care about should change if we discover either that (1) there is no human soul or (2) no self or subject behind our various conscious acts.

title: Decoding Dress
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Elementary Japanese II
reviews: Be really sure you want to take this, its a lot of work and pretty difficult.
Definitely take if you have any interest in Japanese. The teachers are fantastic and the course is well structured.
Definitely take it if interested in learning JPN
Definitely take it if you have an interest in Japanese. The teachers are all amazing - as instructors, but also as people. It is slightly harder than 101, but definitely worthy it!

If you have any interest in Japanese this class will more than satisfy it. Alternatively, if you don't know what language to take, this class makes a highly complex language incredibly accessible with all of the help offered. Cannot recommend it enough.

If you took 101, nothing about 102 should surprise you other than the fact that you do have to do more work. If you find that you were or are struggling, visit the senseis often and frequently. They are very active in helping you figure out ways to learn and get better.
Practice practice practice Review kanji everyday and go to office hours and language tables. Speaking practice is crucial!
Professors are amazing. Workload is substantial, but if done in advance, it is not that bad. Textbook is also great.
Recommended if there's interest in Japanese. A very good course.
Take it. Definitely take it.

Take this course if you are interested in japanese or in learning another language--you will learn a lot and be challenged. Make sure, however, that you are willing to engage yourself with the class and language, or it will be hard to achieve the grade you want,
Take this course! Best course I've taken so far.

This course is wonderfully taught. The senseis really care about their students, and want to see you do well. The course is relatively fast-paced but comfortable, so before you know it you'll find that you can hold a conversation in Japanese! I recommend this course very strongly to anybody interested in the Japanese language!

Understand that learning a language is very demanding and requires that you do something everyday to master it. Make sure you have an outside of class application for the language - ie if you really like anime  that's significant in aiding your learning.
Yes.  Do it. You'll love it.
take it!
prereqs: JPN 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of JPN 101, which emphasizes the basic four skills to achieve survival proficiency level.

title: Chinese Politics
reviews: Best class I've taken at Princeton by far. If you are even vaguely interested in Chinese politics, this class is a must.

Definitely consider taking the course if you're interested at all in understanding China's rise in the past few decades. It can be quite eye-opening to learn how the politics/government of another successful country can be so vastly different from our own in some ways.
Great course. Take it. You'll love it and you'll learn a lot. Do all the readings (they're not that long), and you're good. The professor is amazing and the preceptor was great.
If you're not interested in China, you should be, and you should take this course.
Lots of reading but very interesting and learn a lot

Please take this course. I really like the course and the professor is super nice and smart and he's very open to mentor students which is amazing!!! I wish I had taken this course when I was a freshman/sophomore:(

Prof. Truex's course is honestly one of the best class I have taken at Princeton if not the absolute best. Prof. Truex is class of 2007 and the fact that he has gone through the Princeton experience and tries to make the course cater to students comes through repeatedly. The readings are manageable but you still feel come out feeling that you know substantially more about China and its political system. Get into his precept if possible. It's truly an incredible class.
Recommend if you are interested in China
Strongly Recommend
Take it!

Take this course! Not much work, professor and preceptors are chill and friendly... but you learn so, so much. Even if you know nothing about China,  you won?t be overwhelmed. Even if you know a lot, you?ll learn something new.

Take this course! Truex is an incredibly engaging guy and a clear and concise lecturer. Moreover, as a recent Princeton grad himself ('07), he was very aware of our overall courseload and assigned really do-able amounts of reading. I loved this class and highly recommend everyone who is slightly interested in the topic to take it.
Take this if you're even remotely interested in China. Prof Truex is a champ, and the class is fascinating.
prereqs: All students interested in China are welcome. No previous knowledge of China/Chinese is required..
descrip: This course provides an overview of China's political system. We will begin with a brief historical overview of China's political development from 1949 to the present. The remainder of the course will examine the key challenges facing the current generation of CCP leadership, focusing on prospects for democratization and political reform. Among other topics, we will examine: factionalism and political purges; corruption; avenues for political participation; village elections; public opinion; protest movements and dissidents; co-optation of the business class; and media and internet control.

title: Social Networks
reviews: Absolutely one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton - they really craft the class with care to immerse you in the subject matter in a way that builds a knowledge step by step, Prof Salganik is a big big name in his field and yet really cares about you understanding and enjoying the class, and the homework and tests will be fun and fair
Absolutely take it if you are at all interested about what a social network really is, or how Facebook can be more than just a procrastination website.
Always make sure to ask question in precept, especially if you don't understand something in the reading or in the lecture material.

Amazing class. You shouldn't pass up the opportunity to take it. The homework and the tests are manageable, and it all feels RELEVANT, which doesn't always happen in classes. Prof. Salganik and the preceptors are great, so youthful and relatable. One of my favorite classes I've taken in my 3 years at Princeton.
Definitely take this course! It's extremely interesting, fun, and will change the way you look at your social world - online and off.

Definitely take this course! The material covered is very interesting and is always related back to your everyday life. Social networks affect us so much, so definitely learn about them to get a better understanding of how you can use them in your life.
Definitely take. Challenging but rewarding. I learned a lot. The hard stuff at the beginning becomes intuitive by the second half of the semester.
Definitely would recommend!

Do all the readings, you will be lost if you do not.
Spend less time on the problem sets and really study for exams.
Do the readings and go to lecture!
Do the readings in time for the midterm and final. You can be getting 100s on the problem sets and still be really behind in knowledge / studying for the exam.
Go to class and don't fall behind on the readings

Great class really enjoyed it! Average and totally reasonable workload. Professor really cares about what he's doing. Well-organized and well-taught. Definitely recommend to all majors (though easiest for math/science people).
Great! Genuinely interesting material and taught by instructors who care about the course.

I strongly recommend taking Social Networks. It is a valuable course with real-world applications. The subject matter is presented so that it is accessible to students from all disciplines. It also provides a solid foundation for study in a variety of topics (i.e. counter-terrorism, epidemiology, marketing) and will change the way you see the world.

I would (and have!) strongly recommended this course to anyone. While we have problem sets every week, don't let those two words scare you off. As long as you keep up with the readings and the homework, you will do well.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student.  I would advise a student considering this course to definitely take it, and to engage thoroughly with the material in order to get the most out of the course.
I would recommend taking this course if sociology is of interest to you. I thought the course was VERY organized and enjoyable
I would take this course if you are interested in the subject
I wouldn't take this course unless needed for a departmental
If it sounds interesting to you, take it!
Interesting class. You read a lot of papers and conduct surveys for psets.
It is a LOT of work for a 200-level course, and the exams are very difficult to study for. Be cautious and get very good at multiple choice, or you won't do well on the exams.
Keep up with readings because they'll catch up to you.
Really interesting material. No curve so don't make silly mistakes on exams. Lectures really interesting but precepts weren't very helpful as we just went over the problem sets.
Stay on top of the readings
TAKE THIS CLASS- it is awesome and not that hard.
Take it while you can. Try and get Andrew as your preceptor.
Take it!
Take it! Interesting material and fairly low workload.
Take it! It is by far one of my favorite classes I have taken and very interesting.
Take it!! It will change the way you think about your own social network and the networks that exist throughout the world.
Take this course! Extremely interesting, very intuitive and you will learn a lot. Salganik is exemplary, as is this course.
Take this course. It's not too hard and it's interesting.

The professor is an expert in the area, and he provides not only excellent lectures, but also thought-provoking readings from the forefront of scientific thought in the area. The workload is average to slightly below average, but the ideas that you learn about are intriguing and will probably change how you see the world.
Very easy class and genuinely interesting at times.
You should only take this course if you are genuinely interested in the material because it is a lot more work than it seems--there is a lot of busy work.
You'll learn about a lot of interesting, relevant information. It's a fun class, but be prepared to memorize facts and studies for tests
recommended especially if you are interested in sociology or computer science
take it! very interesting
descrip: This course provides students an introduction to the study of social networks. We will focus on understanding the causes and consequences of patterns of social relationships.

title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
reviews: Don't write off the course as easy. Their are nuances and intricacies that you must understand.
Go to lectures (though you really don't have to) because Sundar is a good lecturer and it'll keep you up to date instead of playing weekly catch up with problem sets.
Go to office hours for problem sets and get help with MATLAB if you are unfamiliar with it. This might be the last year taught by Prof. Sundaresan so the course might be taught differently next year
Good CBE departmental, average amount of work.
It is a lot easier than transport.
It was an alright class. Sundar was really interesting. Slightly less painful than transport but also means that the curve is worse.
It's a pretty good class.
Its a required class so just study hard and do your best!
Make sure to read the material well, prepare well for exams. Good luck!
My favorite departmental so far! Work hard and you'll be rewarded.
Probably the best course in CBE
Really read the book. It is very helpful (unlike the thermo, sep, and transfer books). Sorry it was professor sundar's last time. He was a great teacher
Take it because you have to.
Take this course if you are interested in chemical reactor design. It is well taught. Get help if anything doesn't make sense.
The material in the course ties together everything you've learned, and does so in an interesting and engaging manner. I highly recommend it.
This is a required course but is fun as long as you stay up to date with the material.  Prof. Sundaresan knows a lot about everything engineering.
This is one of the best CBE departmentals you will take. It helps to balance the horrificness that is core lab.
You have to take it but this is probably the best course in the department if not tied with Thermodynamics! You'll love it!
know MATLAB
prereqs: CBE 341.
descrip: Introduction to chemical reaction engineering and reactor design in chemical and biological processes. Concepts of chemical kinetics for both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions. Coupled transport and chemical/biological rate processes.

title: Reading Literature: Theory
reviews: Don't be afraid to participate!
If you have the chance to take this course, don't let it pass you by. Or, be on the look out for anything taught by Professor Chaudhary or Professory Salamon - I certainly will be.
It is a great course. Professor Salamon and Professor Chaudhary teach so well together--It's really wonderful.

My first piece of advice would just be to take it. I both learned a lot and was very interested all semester. One warning I have is that some of the readings can take a very long time, and especially in such a small class where discussion is very student-driven, not doing the readings will be a huge disadvantage. Also, you have to be pretty self-motivated because you could theoretically probably get away without doing all the readings but the course would be nowhere as good if you did.
Take it if you are willing to devote the time necessary if not then don't. Seniors don't take.
Take this class
prereqs: First-year students are welcome. ENG 209 is a prerequisite for the concentration in English, but is open to all..
descrip: How does one interpret texts, including fiction, film, and the online world? This course will introduce students to the basics of critical theory and different methodologies of interpretation. No prior background in literature or theory is required.

title: Monotheism and Society from Constantine to Harun al-Rashid
reviews: Definitely take it. You'll take away so many great skills from the course and get to participate in lively discussion every week without fail.
Jack is amazing, take a course with him, but only take this course if you like primary sources and are OK with lots of great questions, but not many answers.
descrip: The goal of this seminar will be to introduce students to some of the most important ideas and debates surrounding the two major religious revolutions of Late Antiquity: the triumph of Christianity and the subsequent emergence and world conquests of Islam. The course will focus on extensive reading in both primary and secondary literature and students will be introduced to and trained in using major instrumenta studiorum for this period; texts may also be read in Greek, Syriac, and Arabic. No prior knowledge of Late Antiquity, Christianity, or Islam will be assumed.

title: Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - Symmetry, Diffraction and the Structures of Non-molecular Solids
reviews: Cava is the man. Definitely take this class if he offers it. There are no other crystallography classes at the university, and Cava is a very smart person.
Course is excellent but can be boring if you really have no interest in crystallography.
If you are interested in crystallography and inorganic chemistry, this is a great choice. Prof. Cava is an excellent lecturer.
yes
descrip: Topics vary year to year; subject matter is selected from among the following related to the inorganic chemistry of solids: point group and space group symmetry, crystallography, methods in X-ray, neutron and electron diffraction science, the structures of solids, the electronic structure of non-molecular solids, the optical, electronic and magnetic properties of non-molecular solids and their relation to crystal structure, structure-property relations. In 2014-2015: minimal diffraction and crystallography, maximal solid state chemistry, structures, and properties of solids.

title: Topics in Poetry - Contemporary Poetry
reviews: Absolutely take this!
Start the poetry books early, don?t read the entire thing the night before class begins.
TAKE IT
Take it if you enjoy poetry or are afraid of it but want to learn how to appreciate it better
Take it. I promise you will learn tons and will absolutely think of it as your favorite class (and this is coming from an engineering major)

Take it. I was a non-humanities person who took this course on a whim, and it was one of my favorites at Princeton. You'll learn a lot about poetry. Writing reviews is hard, but they force you to engage with texts in ways papers don't. You'll learn how to approach poetry from many ways, and better yet, you'll learn how to put your thoughts about poems into words. I knew very little about poetry going into this course, and now reading poetry excites me. Kotin is very nice and great a facilitating discussion. It is also cool to meet a lot of the poets whose work you are reading through guest seminars.
This is without a doubt the best course I've taken at Princeton.

Yes, absolutely. Professor Kotin in twelve weeks has changed the way that I read poetry. I now am eager to embrace the bewilderment attendant to each interaction with a new poet/poem/book of poems. Poetry by its nature always at first destabilizes and befuddles its readers, and this class has made me marvel at the fact that we can be confused by language so constantly and utterly.
descrip: This seminar focuses exclusively on books of poetry published in 2014 and 2015. We will read work by established and emerging poets, and attend poetry readings in Princeton (and possibly New York and Philadelphia). Poets will also visit the class to discuss their work and/or the work of writers they admire. Students will write reviews, rather than essays, and, in the process, learn about (and contribute to) the institutions that support and promote contemporary writing.

title: Topics in Spanish Civilization of the Golden Age - Disidentes Y Marginados Del Siglo De Oro
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission..
descrip: A reading of texts selected from the works of Spain's social and religious minorities. The authors of such works are either non-conformists who adopt a critical view of Golden Age Spain or members of minority groups (New Christians, Moriscos, women). The texts will be read against the background of the social and religious history of the period.
